superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter X c
The thirteenth letter of the alphabet: called XiynN. It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice]; and of the letters termed XajoriyRap, (TA,) from AlXRajoru, which means “ the place of the opening of the mouth. ” (TA on the letter j. See also XiyonN in art. Xyn.) It is sometimes substituted for the affixed pronoun of the second pers. fem., ki; as in raOayotuXi for raOayotuki, and as in the following verse,
faEayonaAXi EayonaAhaA wajiyduXi jiyduhaA
walekinRa AlsRaAqi minoXi raqiyqu
[And thy two eyes are her two eyes, and thy neck is her neck; but the bone of thy shank is slender]; i. e. EayonaAka and jiyoduki and minoki: this substitution for the affixed pronoun of the second pers. fem. is of dial. of Benoo-'Amr and Temeem; and is not restricted to cases of pausation, as is shown by the verse above cited, though some assert it to be so: it is also substituted for the k of diyk, when with kesr, so that they said diyXK: also for jK, as in mudamRaXN[or mudomaXN], for mudamRajN [or mudomajN]: and for s, as in jaEoXuwXN, for jaEosuwsN. (MF. [See also De Sacy's Chrest, Arabe, sec. ed., iii. 530-31.]) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Three hundred.]

XuWobuwbN c
XuWobuwbN A shower, or fall, or what pours forth at once or without intermission, of rain (S, A, O, K) &c.: (S, O:) or of rain with hail; for otherwise this term is not applied to rain: (ISd, TA:) pl. XaMbiybu: (S, A, O, K: *) this is the pl. of XuWobuwbN (K, TA) in all its senses: (TA:) or rain that falls upon one place and misses another; like najowN and najaMCN. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- [A thin, not wide, cloud, of which the rain falls with vehemence. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)] ― -b3- A heat, or an unintermitted act, of running. (TA.) ― -b4- Sharpness, vehemence, force, or strength, of anything: (K:) violence, or vehemence, of impetus or pushing or driving, (S, A, O, K,) of rain, (A,) or of anything. (K.) Kaab Ibn-Zuheyr says, speaking of a he-ass and she-asses,
UicaA maA QnotaHaAhunRa XuWobuwbuhu
raOayota lijaAEiratayohi guDuwnaA
i. e. When he runs vehemently [towards them, or rather when his vehemence of running is directed towards them], thou seest a wrinkling [or wrinkles] in his jaAEirataAni [dual of jaAEirapN, q. v.]. (S, O.) ― -b5- The first appearance [or bloom] of beauty. (K.) One says of a girl, or young woman, UinRahaA laHasanahu XaMbiybi Alwajohi Verily she is goodly in respect of the first appearances [or bloomings] of beauty of countenance in the eye of the beholder. (O.) ― -b6- The vehemence of the heat of the sun. (K.) ― -b7- And The Tariyqap of the sun: (K:) XaMbiybu AlXRamosi signifies the lines, or streaks, (TaraAYiq,) of the sun when it rises. (O.) ― -b8- XaMbiybu AlSRamogi What flows, of the [manna, or gum, called] migofar [q. v.], and remains like strings, or threads, between the trees and the ground. (T, L.) [See also maEaAbiybu.]

XaYiytN c
XaYiytN A horse that has a habit of stumbling; or that stumbles often: (S, K:) it has no corresponding verb: and accord. to As, it signifies (S) a horse whose hind hoofs fall short of reaching [the spots that have been trodden by] his fore hoofs: (S, K:) [but see XabuwbN:] pl. XuWuwtN. (TA.) [See also OaHaqRu.]

1 XaYifato rijoluhu c
1. XaYifato rijoluhu, (S, O, K,) aor.
XaAa^a
, (K,) inf. n. XaOafN; (S, O;) and XuYifato rjlh; (O, K;) His foot became affected with an ulcer, or imposthume, such as is termed XaOofapN, breaking out in it. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, (O,) XaOfu AljuroHi (O, K, [in my MS. copy of the K XaOofu, and so accord. to the TK, and in the CK without C, but I think that the right reading is XaOafu, and that its verb is XaYifa, or it may be XaOofu, and inf. n. of XuYifa,]) signifies The wound's becoming in a corrupt state, so that it will hardly, or not at all, be cured. (O, K.) ― -b3- XaYifa Sadoruhu EalaIRa His bosom bore concealed enmity and violent hatred, or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against me. (TA.) ― -b4- XaYifato OaSaAbiEuhu, (Az, O, K,) or yaduhu, (M, TA,) His fingers, or his hand, became cracked, or disintegrated, in the parts around the nails; (Az, M, O, K;) as also saYifato, (O, TA,) and saEifato: so say AZ and IAar, and in like manner says Th. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XaYifotuhu, (S, O, K,) and XaYifotu lahu, (AZ, O, K,) aor.
XaAa^a
, (K,) inf. n. XaOofN, (S, O, K,) in the Bári' XaOafN, with fet-h to the C, (TA,) and XaMfapN; (O, K;) and XaYifotu minohu, inf. n. XaOofN, omitted in the K [and S, and O], but correct, as Sgh has indicated in the Tekmileh; (TA;) I hated him; (S, O, K;) like Xanifotu lahu; (S and O in art. Xnf;) namely, a man: (S, O:) or the first and second signify, (K,) or the first also signifies accord. to IAar, (O,) I feared, when I saw him, namely, a man, that I should smite him with an evil eye, or should guide against him one whom he disliked, or hated; (O;) or I feared that he would smite me with an evil eye, or I guided against him one whom he disliked, or hated. (K.) ― -b2- And XuYifa He (a man, A'Obeyd, O) was frightened, or afraid. (A'Obeyd, O, K.)

10 AisotaXoOafato c
10. AisotaXoOafato, said of a quroSap, [so in the TA, an evident mistranscription, app. for qaroHap, and so in the next paragraph, i. e. an ulcer, or imposthume,] means SaAra lahaA OaSolN [It had, or acquired, root, or rootedness, or permanence; as though it became a XaOofap]. (TA.)

XaYifN c
XaYifN [part. n. of XaYifa, and properly meaning Having an ulcer, or imposthume, such as is termed XaOofap,] is applied as an epithet to a heart, in the following verse, cited by IKtt,
yaA OayRuhaA AljaAhilu OalRaA tanoSarifo
walamo tudaAwi quroSapa Alqalobi AlXRaYifo
[in which quroSapa is doubtless a mistranscription (like that in the next preceding paragraph) for qaroHapa; the obvious meaning of the verse being, (assumed tropical:) O thou ignorant one, wherefore wilt not thou revert, when thou hast not cured the sore of an ulcerated heart?]. (TA.)

XoCANfp c
XoCANfp Original text has hamza and sukun above sheen.
An ulcer, or imposthume, (qaroHapN,) that breaks out in the bottom of the foot, and is cauterized, (S, IAth, O, K,) or is cut, (Yaakoob, IAth, O,) and goes away; (Yaakoob, S, IAth, O, K;) and the word is also pronounced without C [i. e. XaAfapN]: (IAth, TA:) or an ulcer, or imposthume, in the foot of a person, who dies if it is cut: (O, K:) and it is also said to be a tumour in the hand, and foot, from the entering of a piece of wood, or stick, into the flesh of the foot, or the palm of the hand, and its remaining therein, so
that the place swells, and becomes large. (TA.) AisotaOoSala QllRehu XaOofatahu (S, O, K) is a prov. (S, O) meaning (assumed tropical:) May God cause him to go away like as the XOfp above mentioned goes away: (S, O, K:) or this means may God extirpate him: for ― -b2- XaOofapN is also syn. with OaSolN [i. e. Root, &c.]: (O, K:) so says Sh. (O.) [See also 10 in art. ASl: and see what here follows.] ― -b3- It is also said to signify The family and household of a man: and hence the form of imprecation, AisotaOoSala QllRehu XaOofatahumo [May God extirpate their family and household]. (TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) Enmity. (TA.)

XaOafapN c
XaOafapN, thus with fet-h to the C, is an epithet applied to a man, meaning Mighty, potent, powerful, or strong; inaccessible, or difficult of access. (TA.)

rijolN maXoWuwfapN c
rijolN maXoWuwfapN A foot affected with an ulcer, or imposthume, such as is termed saOofapN, breaking out in it: (O, K:) from XuYifato rijoluhu. (O, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- And maXoWuwfN, from XuYifa, Frightened, or afraid; (A'Obeyd, O, K;) applied to a man. (A'Obeyd, O.)

1 XuYima Ealayohimo c
1. XuYima Ealayohimo (S; MA, K,) inf. n. XuWomN, (MA,) He (a man, S) was, or became, unlucky, or inauspicious, (SaAra XuWomFA, S, K, in the MA Xwm Xd,) to them: (S, MA, K;) as also XaOamahumo, and XaOama Elyhm, and XaWuma Elyhm: (K:) or XaOamahumo, (AZ, Ham p. 224,) or XaOama Ealayohimo, (S,) or both of these, (TA,) aor.
XaAa^a
, (S, TA,) inf. n. XaOomN, (TA,) he drew upon them ill luck, or evil fortune; (S, TA;) or caused ill luck, or evil fortune, to befall them from him: (AZ, Ham ubi suprà, TA:) or XuWumN as an inf. n. signifies the being unlucky: and the rendering unlucky: and so XuwmN [as it is commonly pronounced: see XuWumN below]. (KL.) ＝ -A2- And XaOamahumo, inf. n. XaOomN, so in the L; in the K, XaORamahumo↓, inf. n. taXoYiymN; but the former is the right; (TA;) He made them to go, or journey, to AlXRaOom [i. e. Syria]. (K, TA.)

2 XaARa^a
2: see what next precedes.

3 XaAYimo biOaSoHaAbika c
3. XaAYimo biOaSoHaAbika Take thou the direction of the left hand with thy companions: (S, K, TA:) yaAmino signifies “ take thou the direction of the right hand. ” (TA.) ― -b2- And XaMma He (a man) came to AlXRaOom [i. e. Syria]: like yaAmana signifying “ he came to El-Yemen. ” (TA. [See also 4.])

4 AXOm c
4. AXOm He desired the left: like as Oayomana signifies “ he desired the right. ” (TA in art. ymn.) ― -b2- And He (a man, S) came to AlXRaOom [i. e. Syria]: (S, K, TA: [see also 3:]) or he went thither: and Oayomana signifies “ he came to El-Yemen. ” (TA.) ＝ -A2- maA OaXoOamahu (S, K, TA) How unlucky, or inauspicious, is he! (TA:) the vulgar say, maA OayoXamahu. (S, TA.)

5 tXORm bihi c
5. tXORm bihi, (MA, TA,) from AlXRuWomu, (TA,) He found him, or it, unlucky, or inauspicious: and he became unlucky by means of him, or it: (MA:) or tXORm signifies he had ill luck, or evil fortune. (KL.) See also 6. ― -b2- And tXORm He took the direction of his left hand: (K, TA:) and in like manner tayaAmana, [whence it seems that tXORm in the sense expl. above may be a mistake for tXMCm↓,] “ he took the direction of his right hand. ” (TA.) ― -b3- And He asserted his relationship to [the people of] AlXRaOom [i. e. Syria]: (S, K:) a verb similar to tkwRf and tqyRS. (S.)

6 tXMCmwA bihi c
6. tXMCmwA bihi, (S, Msb, K, TA, &c.,) in some of the copies of the K tXORmwA↓, (TA,) [and in like manner tXORm bihi, which is often opposed to tayamRana bihi, (see an instance in Bd xvii. 14,) is used in the K in art. ETs, and tXORm minohu in the TA in the same art. as on the authority of IKh, whence it seems that both these verbs are correct in the sense here following, though the former is probably preferable, and bihi AstXOm↓ is used in the same manner in “ Les Oiseaux et les Fleurs, ” p. 83, as mentioned by Freytag, so that tXORm bh and AstXOm are the contr. of tymRn bh and Astymn,] They augured evil from him, or it; regarded him, or it, as an evil omen; (Msb, KL; *) like taTayRaruwA bihi: (Msb:) deemed him, or it, unlucky, or inauspicious. (KL.) ― -b2- tXMCm, thus, with medd, also signifies He took the direction of AlXRaOom[i. e. Syria]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 5.

10 UisotaXoAa^a
10: see the next preceding paragraph.

AlXRaOomu c
AlXRaOomu, the name of a certain country [i. e. Syria], is masc. and fem.; (S;) sometimes masc.: (K:) and may also be pronounced AlXRaAmu [as it commonly is in the present day]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And as this country lies on the north of Arabia, AlXRaOomu also signifies The northern region; opposed to Alyamanu.]

XuWomN c
XuWomN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) thus, with C, but always pronounced XuwmN, without C, (TA,) is an inf. n.: (MA, KL: [see 1, first sentence, in two places:]) and signifies [as a simple subst.] Unluckiness, inauspiciousness, unfortunateness, unprosperousness, evil fortune, or ill luck; contr. of yumonN; (S, K;) [i. e.] i. q. aHosN: (Har p. 158:) evil [of any kind]; syn. XarRN: (Msb:) [and particularly] an evil omen: (PS:) and maXoOamapN↓ signifies the same as XuWomN: (TA:) [or, like manoHasapN, a cause of unluckiness, &c.:] maXaAYimu is a pl. of XuWomN, [or of maXoOamapN↓: if of the former,] irreg., like as its syn. manaAHisu is [said to be] of naHosN. (TA in art. nHs.) It is said in a trad., Uino kaAna AlXRuwomu fafiI valaAv K AlmaroOapi waAldRaAri waAlfarasi, meaning If there be that whereof the consequence is disliked, or hated, and feared, [or if there be unluckiness,] it is in three things, the wife, and the house, and the horse: i. e., if any of you have a wife whose companionship he dislikes, or a house in which he dislikes dwelling, or a horse that he dislikes taking for the purpose of keeping post on the enemies' frontier, let him separate himself therefrom, by divorcing the wife, and removing from the house, and selling the horse: or, as some say, the XWm of the wife is her not producing children; and that of the house, its straitness, and the badness of its neighbour; and that of the horse, one's not going to war upon it. (JM.) ― -b2- See also maXoWuwmN. ＝ -A2- Also Black camels: and HiDaArN signifies “ white ” camels, (K, TA,) and is also written and pronounced HaDaArN: (TA:) neither of these has a sing.: (K:) both occur in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb: but accord. to one reading thereof it is Xiym; pl. of OaXoyamu: so says AA: and IJ says that XuwmN, [without C,] being originally XuyomN, of the measure fuEolN, may also be pl. of OaXoyamu. (TA.)

XaOomapN c
XaOomapN and maXoOamapN↓ The left, meaning the left side or direction or relative location or place; (S, K;) i. q. [yasorapN and] mayosarapN; (S;) contr. of yamonapN and mayomanapN. (K.) One says of a man, qaEada XOomapN [He sat on the left]. (S.) And one says, xuco bihimo XaOomapF i. e. [Take thou with them] the direction of the left hand. (S.) And naZarotu yamonapF waXaOomapF [I looked in a right direction and in a left direction]. (TA.) And hence OaSoHaAbu AlmaXoOamapi↓, in the Kur [lvi. 9 and xc. 19], (TA,) meaning [The occupants of the left: or] those who shall have their records given to them in their left hands: or the occupants of the low, or ignoble, place, or station: or the havers of unfortunateness (AlXRuWom): and OaSoHaAbu Almayomanapi is expl. as having the contr. senses. (Ksh and Bd in lvi. 9.) ＝ -A2- Also, the former, A mole (xaAlN) upon the person: thus, with C, as mentioned by IAth: also mentioned without C in art. Xym. (TA.) ― -b2- See also XaAmapN as meaning “ a black she-camel, ” in art. Xym.

XiYomapN c
XiYomapN Nature; natural, native, or innate, disposition, temper, or other quality or property: (K, TA:) mentioned thus, as with C, by AZ and Lh, and said by IJ to be sometimes thus pronounced; but the pronunciation thereof with C is held by ISd to be extraordinary. (TA.) [See art. Xym.]

XaAmiIRN c
XaAmiIRN, (S, Msb, K, TA,) without C, (TA,) and XaMmK↓, (S, Msb, K,) of the measure faEaAlK, (S,) an allowable form, without I, (Msb,) like tahaAmK and yamaAnK, (TA,) and XaMmiIRN↓, (Sb, S, K,) [Syrian;] of, or relating to, AlXRaOom: (S, Msb, K:) one should not say XaOomK; any instance [of this] occurring by poetic license being accounted for as a case of the use of the name of the country for the rel. n.: (S:) the fem., applied to a woman, is XaAmiyRapN and XaMmiyapN↓, the latter without teshdeed: (S, TA;) the pl. of XaAmiIRN is XuwaAmN, like guraAbN [in measure]. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, Northern.]

XaMmK c
XaMmK, and XaMmiyapN the fem. of the former; and

XaMmiIRN c
XaMmiIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XaAYimN c
XaAYimN: see maXoWuwmN.

OaXoOamu c
OaXoOamu [More, and most, unlucky, inauspicious, unfortunate, or unprosperous]. The Arabs say,
OaXoOamu kulRi QmoriY K bayona laHoyayohi, (Meyd, TA,) as some relate it, or, as others relate it, fakRayohi, which means the same, (Meyd,) [app. meaning accord. to the TA, The most unlucky thing of every man is between his two jaws, or the two lateral portions of his lower jaw; but it is said that] OaXoOamu is here used in the sense of XuWomN [i. e. the unluckiness, &c.]; and in a similar manner [the contr.] Oayomanu is used [in the sense of yumon]: so says AHeyth: (Meyd:) the prov. meaning the tongue. (AHeyth, TA.) The fem. is XuWomaI. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) Alyadu AlXRuWomaI The left hand or arm; contr. of AlyumonaI; (K, TA;) i. q. AlXRimaAlu. (TA.) It is said in a trad., respecting camels, laA yaOotiI xayoruhaA UilRaA mino jaAnibihaA AlOaXoOami [Their goodness comes not save from their left side]: i. e. they are milked and mounted only from the left side. (TA.) ― -b3- See also maXoWuwmN, in three places. ― -b4- Zuheyr, in the following saying,
fatunotajo lakumo gilomaAna OaXoOama kulRuhumo
kaOaHomari EaAd K vumRa turoDiEo fatafoTimo
uses it in the sense of the inf. n. XuWom; (S;) meaning gilomaAna XuWomK: (S, and EM p. 124:) he says, And it, i. e. war, will bring forth for you boys of ill luck, or evil omen; all of them like Ahmar of' Ád: then it will suckle these boys, and wean them: by Ahmar of ' Ád, he means Ahmar of Thamood, for Ahmar was the surname of him who hamstrung the she-camel of Sálih, and his name was Kudár: he says thus for the sake of the measure: or, as some say, Thamood were called 'Ád-el-Ákhireh. (EM.)

maXoOamapN c
maXoOamapN: see XuWomN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also XaOomapN, likewise in two places.

maXoWuwmN c
maXoWuwmN, (S, MA, K, KL,) and maXuwmN, (S, K,) the latter like maquwlN, (TA,) [a contraction of the former,] Unlucky, or inauspicious, (S, MA, K, KL,) EaI qawomihi [to his people, or party], (S, MA, K,) and EalaI nafosihi [to himself]: (Ksh and Bd in lvi. 9:) [and so XuWomN↓; (as in an ex. in the first sentence of this art.;) this being an epithet as well as a subst., like its syn. naHosN; syn. with maXoWuwmN, like as naHosN is syn. with manoHuwsN; and app., like naHosN, used alike as sing. and pl., for it seems to be originally an inf. n.:] and so XaAYimN↓; (K;) or this signifies drawing ill luck, or evil fortune, upon his people [and upon himself]: (S, TA:) and OaXaAYimu, a pl., likewise signifies unlucky, or inauspicious; (KL;) contr. of OayaAminu; (S, K, TA;) these being pls. of OaXoOamu↓ and Oayomanu: (TA:) the pl. of maXoWuwmN is maXaAYiymu, (S, KL, TA,) which is extr., for by rule it should be maXoWuwmuwna. (TA.) One says also TaAYirN OaXoOamu↓ meaning [An omen] happening, or occurring, (jaArK,) with unluckiness, or inauspiciousness; [i. e. an unlucky, or inauspicious, omen;] (K, TA;) and [in like manner] TayorN OaXoOamu↓: and the pl. is OaXaAYimu [as above]. (TA.)

1 XaOanotu XaOonahu c
1. XaOanotu XaOonahu i. q. qaSadotu qaSodahu [meaning I pursued his (another's) way, or course, doing as he did]; (S, L, K: * in the K, XaOana XaOonahu and qaSada qaSodahu;) and in like manner one says, XaOonahu AXtOn↓. (K.) ― -b2- And AiXoOano XaOonaka Do thou what thou dost well. (S, L, K. *) And Keep thou to thy affair. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- And maA XaOana XaOonahu He did not know, or had not knowledge of, him, or his affair or case or state: (Lh, IAar, L, K:) [from a passage in the L, imperfectly written, it seems, accord. to Lh, to be said of one who does what another likes or dislikes, app. without regard to his liking it or disliking it, agreeably with what here follows:] or (K) this means, (S, K,) or means also, (L,) he did not care for, mind, heed, or regard, him. (S, L, K. [In the S and L, the verb in the sense thus expl. is in the first pers.: and in one place in the L it is expl. by OaraAda, which often has this meaning.]) One says also, laOaXoOannRa XaOonahumo, meaning I will assuredly know, or try, prove, or test, (laOaxoburanRa,) their affair or case or state: (L:) or this means I will assuredly corrupt, or pervert, or mar, their affair or case or state: (S, L, K: *) and laOaXoOananRa xabarahu, (L,) or xabarahumo, (K,) means I will assuredly know, or try, prove, or test, [his, or their, state, or] him, or them. (L, K. [In the CK and in my MS. copy of the K, laAuxobiranRahumo, is erroneously put for laOaxoburanRahumo.]) ＝ -A2- XaOana baEodaka means SaAra lahu XaOonN [i. e., app., He became a person to whom importance attached (accord. to the general meaning of lahu XaOonN) after thou knewest, or sawest, or mettest, him; baEodaka being for baEoda Eahodika bihi, agreeably with common usage]. (K.)

4 AXOn XaOonahumo c
4. AXOn XaOonahumo is mentioned by Golius as meaning “ Corrupit ac pervertit rem eorum, ” as on the authority of the S, (the right reading in which has been given above,) and on that of the KL, in my copy of which I find nothing of the sort.]

8 UiXotaAa^a
8: see 1, first sentence.

XaOonN c
XaOonN A thing, an affair, or a business; syn. OamorN; (S, L, K;) and xaTobN [in the same sense, or in that next following]: (L, K:) a great thing or affair: (Har p. 274:) state, condition, case, quality, or manner of being; syn. HaAlN: (S, L:) [also property, or nature: and importance attaching to a person or thing:] pl. XuWuwnN and XiYaAnN, (L, K,) the latter mentioned by IJ on the authority of AAF, and XuwnN occurs in poetry for the former of these, or as another pl. originally XuWonN, of the measure fuEolN. (L.) It is said in the Kur [lv. 29], kulRa yam K huwa fiI XaOonK [Every day He is employing Himself in an affair of some kind]: expl. as meaning that, of his business (mino XaOonihi [which may also be rendered “ of his property ”]) it is to render mighty one who is brought low, and to bring low one who is mighty, and to enrich one who is poor, and to impoverish one who is rich; and no affair occupies him so as to divert him from an affair (laA yaXoEaluhu XaOonN Eano XaOonK). (L.) [And one says, maA XaOonuka What is thy affair? or what is thy case? And XaOonaka, for AiXoOano XaOonaka i. e. Pursue thy way or course, or thy affair; or do what thou dost well; or keep to thy affair: or the like: and to this is often added, wamaA turiydu i. e. and what thou wilt, or wishest, or desirest. And mino XaOonihi Oano yafoEala kacaA It is of his business, or of his property, or nature, to do, or that he should do, such a thing. And rajulN saholu AlXRaOoni (a phrase occurring in the S and K in art. hX) A man of easy nature. And lahu XaOonN, sometimes meaning There is for him, or he has, a great thing or affair to perform or transact: but more commonly, great importance attaches to him, or to it: see 1, last sentence. And a grandee, or a prince, is said to be EaZiymu AlXRaOoni i. e. Of great importance or rank or dignity.] ＝ -A2- Also [A suture of the skull; i. e.] the place of junction of the qabaAYil [or principal bones, namely, the frontal, occipital, and two parietal, bones,] of the head: (K:) sing. of XuWuwnN, (Mgh,) which signifies the places of junction, (As, S, Mgh, L,) and of meeting, (S, L,) of the qabaAYil (As, S, Mgh, L) of the head; (S, L;) between every two of which qbAYl is a XaOon: (As, L:) [it is fancifully said that] from them come the tears: (As, S, L:) the pl. is also expl. as meaning the salaAsil [i. e. sutures as being likened to the slAsl (or lines) of writing] that unite the qbAYl: by Lth, as the namaAnim [likewise meaning sutures resembling lines of writing] of the skull; between the qbAYl: by AHát, as the XuEab [meaning serrated edges] that unite the qbAYl of the head. (L.) ― -b2- And The channel by which the tears flow, or run, to the eye: pl. [of pauc.] OaXoWunN and [of mult.] XuWuwnN: (L, K:) [perhaps thus called because supposed to come from the sutures of the skull: but they may have been supposed to come thence because tears are called maMCu AlXRuWuwni (as in a verse cited voce rasama); for this phrase may have been misunderstood as signifying “ the water of the sutures of the skull, ” whereas it seems to be properly rendered “ the water of the channels of the tears: ”] it is said that the XuWuwn connect the qbAYl of the head [expl. above] to the eye: Lth says that they are the ducts (Euruwq) of the tears from [the interior of] the head to the eye: and Th, that they are certain ducts (Erwq) above the qbAYl, which become strong by degrees as the man advances in age: (L: [but it seems that Th has confounded explanations of XWwn in two different senses:]) accord. to ISk, (S,) or AA and others, (L,) the XaOonaAni are two ducts (EiroqaAni) descending from [the upper part of] the head to the eyebrows and then to the eyes. (S, L.) ― -b3- [The pl. XuWuwnN is also expl. as though meaning Tears themselves, in a phrase mentioned voce caYirN (q. v.), on the authority of the K.] ― -b4- And XuWuwnN Alxamori means (assumed tropical:) The effluvia of wine that creep (maA dabRa mina Alxamori) in the veins of the body. (L.) ― -b5- XaOonN also signifies A vein of earth in a mountain, (L, K,) i. e. a cleft therein, (L,) in which palm-trees are
planted; (L, K;) or in which trees of the kind called naboE grow; or that produces plants, or herbage: (L:) pl. XuWuwnN: (L, K:) which is said by ISd to mean lines, or streaks, in a mountain: or, as some say, cracks, or clefts: and to these cracks, or clefts, the poet Keys Ibn-Kuráa likens [imaginary] clefts in the liver, occasioned by love. (L.)

UinRahu lamiXoOanu XaOon K Oano nufosidaka c
UinRahu lamiXoOanu XaOon K Oano nufosidaka is a saying mentioned by Lh, expl. [only] by the words AI An nEml fI fsAdk [i. e. Oano naEomala fiI fasaAdika, app. meaning Verily he is busying himself in the doing of a thing in order that we may labour in causing thee to be in a bad, or corrupt, state]. (L.)

XaAhobalRuwT c
XaAhobalRuwT [a Pers. word, and also used by the Arabs in the present day, applied to The chestnut]: also written XaAho balRuwT. (TA voce balRuwTN and voce jamalN.)

XaAhiynN c
XaAhiynN A certain well-known bird, (K, TA,) of those that prey; (Msb, * TA;) it is of the birds called Suquwr [pl. of SaqorN], as are also the baAXaq and the baAziI and the zurRaq and the yuWoyuW; (AHát in “ the Book of Birds, ” TA in art. bXq;) [said by Golius, on the authority of Dmr, to be the white falcon; and to this bird it is perhaps applied by some of the Arabs; but some of them, I believe most of them, and I believe also that they do so most properly, apply this appellation in the present day to the gerfalcon, which is not wholly white; and some, to the falcon gentle:] the word is [of Pers. origin,] not genuine Arabio; (TA;) it is an arabicized word: the pl. is XawaAhiynu, and sometimes XayaAhiynu is used in its stead, formed by substituion [of I for w] for facilitating the pronunciation. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The Eamuwd [meaning beam] of the balance. (K.) ― -b3- And i. q. SanojapN [which signifies A balance, and a steelyard, and a weight of a balance]: so in the Expos. of the “ Muwatta. ” (MF, TA.)

1 XaOawotu Alqawoma c
1. XaOawotu Alqawoma, (AZ, S,) aor.
XaAu^a
, (JM, PS,) or
XaAa^a
, (Ham p. 786,) inf. n. XaOowN, (AZ, S, K,) I preceded, or outwent, the people, or party. (AZ, S, K. *) Accord. to [several of] the copies of the K, XaMCahu i. e. like XaAEahu in measure, which is incorrect, [in other copies XaMCaAhu↓, agreeably with what is said in the S,] signifies He strove, or contended, with him to precede him, or outgo him: or he preceded him, or outwent him: but in the S it is said, XaMCaAhu, of the measure faAEalahu, signifies he strove, or contended, with him to precede him, or outgo him: and XaMCahu like XaOaAhu, [the former belonging to art. XwO and] formed by transposition, signifies he preceded him, or outwent him; and both of these are used by the poet (El-Hárith Ibn-Khálid El-Makhzoomee, TA) in his saying,
marRa AlHuduwju wamaA XaOawonaka naqorapF
walaqado OaraAka tuXaMCu biAlOaZoEaAni
this [passage in the S], however, is taken from what is said by A'Obeyd, in [his work] “ ElGhareeb el-Musannaf, ” which is as follows: XaMCaniI AlOamoru, like XaAEaniI [in measure], and XaMniI, like XaEaAniI, mean the affair, or event, grieved me; and thus in the verse of El-Hárith Ibn-Khálid, which he cites; and the same is said in the T on the authority of IAar, who says that the poet has used two dial. vars.: [accordingly the verse may be rendered, The camels with their saddles upon them passed along and they grieved thee not at all; but I see thee that thou art grieved by the women borne in the camel-vehicles:] it is said in the M, XaMCaniI AlXRaIoCu means the thing preceded me, or outwent me: and also the thing grieved me: formed by transposition from XaMniI, as is proved by its having no inf. n.: IAar says that they are two dial. vars. because of his not being a grammarian. (TA.) [See also 8.] ＝ -A2- And XaOawotu AlbiYora, (Lh, TA,) or XOwt mina AlbiYori, (S,) inf. n. XaOowN, (K, TA,) I drew forth the earth from the well: (S, K: *) or I drew forth a basketful of earth (XaOowFA) or two basketfuls of earth (XaOowayoni) from the well. (Lh, TA.)

3 XaMCaAhu c
3. XaMCaAhu: see 1. yuXaAwiI occurs in a verse of Milhah El-Jarmee, meaning yusaAbiqu, from XaOowN meaning TalaqN: one says XaOaAhu, aor. yaXoOaAhu, meaning sabaqahu: but the verb of the measure regularly formed from AlXRaOowu is XaMCI; so that yXAwI is formed by transposition and by the change of the C into I. (Ham p. 786.)

6 taXaMCaI maA bayonahumaA c
6. taXaMCaI maA bayonahumaA, (S, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, taXAwaI,]) like taXaAEaI [in measure], (S,) The space between them two became farextending. (S, K.) ― -b2- And tXMCI Alqawomu The people, or party, became scattered, or dispersed. (S, K.)

8 AiXotaOaI c
8. AiXotaOaI He preceded, or outwent: (S, K:) so says El-Mufaddal. (S.) ― -b2- And He gave ear, hearkened, or listened. (S, K.)

XaOowN c
XaOowN The utmost extent, term, limit, point, reach, or goal. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And A heat, or single run to a goal or limit: so in the saying, EadaA XaOowFA (S) or jaraI XaOowFA (Msb) [He (a horse, TA) ran a heat]. ― -b3- And i. q. himRapN: thus in the saying, UinRahu labaEiydu AlXRaOowi (assumed tropical:) [Verily he is far-aiming, or far-aspiring, in purpose, desire, or ambition]: (Lh, TA:) and saOowN is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A [basket such as is termed] zabiyl; and so miXoMpN↓: (K:) or zabiyl↓ in which the earth of a well is taken forth; of the measure of miXoEaApN; and the pl. is maXaMCK: (S:) and XaOowN signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (K,) the earth that is taken forth from a well (S, K) with the like of the miXoMp, (as in a copy of the S,) or such as fills the mXoMp: (so in another copy of the S [agreeably with what next follows]:) a zabiyl of the earth of a well. (As, T, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, i. e. as being likened to a zbyl of the earth of a well, (assumed tropical:) The dung that the he-ass and the she-ass casts forth: (As, T, TA:) or the dung of the she-camel; (M, K;) but the more approved word is [saOowN,] with s. (M, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also The nose-rein (zimaAm) of a she-camel. (Lth, K.)

miXoMpN c
miXoMpN; see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

muXotaOK c
muXotaOK [part. n. of 8, q. v.: ― -b2- and] i. q. muxotalifN [app. as meaning Disagreeing, differing, or discordant]. (TA.)

1 XabRa c
1. XabRa, aor.
Xabiba
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. XabaAbN (S, Mgh, Msb, K *) and XabiybapN (S, Msb, K *) and XubuwbN and XabiybN, (TA,) He became a youth, or young man; i. e. he attained to the state termed XabaAbN meaning as expl. below; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) said of a boy. (S, Msb.) [And in like manner XabRato is said of a girl, i. e. She became a young woman.] ― -b2- XubRa used as a noun: see below. ― -b3- [Perhaps as an inf. n. of which the verb is XabRa, (as Freytag has assumed,) but more probably of XubRa, which will be found mentioned in this paragraph, for I do not find the former verb in the requisite sense,] XabRN signifies Anything's being, or becoming, raised, or elevated. (K.) ― -b4- XabRa said of a horse, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Xabiba
, and
Xabuba
, (S, K,) inf. n. XibaAbN and XabiybN (S, Msb, K) and XubuwbN, (K,) He was brisk, lively, or sprightly, (S, Msb, K, *) and raised his fore legs (S, Msb, K) together, (S, Msb,) as though in leaping, (TA,) and played. (S. [See also XabRat in art. Xbw, said of a mare.]) And likewise He was or became, restive, or refractory: one says, briYotu Uilayoka mino XibaAbihi and Xabiybihi and EiDaADihi and EaDiyDihi [I am irresponsible to thee for his being restive, or refractory, and for his biting]. (S.) ― -b5- XabRati AlnRaAru, [aor., accord. to rule,
Xabiba
,] (Msb, K,) and XubRat [pass. of the trans. verb XabRa, q. v. infrà], inf. n. XubuwbN (which is of the intrans., TA) and XabRN (which is of the trans. verb, TA), The fire burned, burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed. (Msb, K. [See also 5.]) [And hence,] XabRati AlHarobu bayonahumo (tropical:) [War, or the war, burned, or burned fiercely, between them]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- XubRa It was raised, or elevated. (O, TA.) ― -b2- XabRa AlnRaAru, aor.
Xabuba
, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. XabRN (S, O, K) and XubuwbN, (S, K,) or the latter is the inf. n. of the intrans. verb mentioned above, (TA,) He kindled the fire; or made it to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; (S, O, Msb, K; *) as also XbRbhA↓, inf. n. taXobiybN; (L;) and AXbRhA↓: (A and TA in art. HX:) and so XabaAhaA. (TA in art. Xbw.) And in like manner, XabRa AlHaroba (assumed tropical:) He kindled war, or the war; or made it to burn, or burn fiercely. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence,] XabRa, aor.
Xabuba
, said of the blackness of a garment, (Sh, A, TA,) (tropical:) It heightened and increased, (A,) or made to appear bright and beautiful, and [as it were] burning, or glowing, (Sh, TA,) the whiteness of the wearer. (Sh, A, TA.) And XabRa lawonahaA (aor. as above, S) (assumed tropical:) It
(a woman's hair) showed, [or set off,] and rendered beautiful, her colour, or complexion: (S:) it (a woman's head-covering, and her hair,) increased, and showed, [or heightened, and set off,] her beauty: (K:) it (a woman's black headcovering) increased her fairness, and rendered her beautiful. (TA.) And yaXubRu Alwajoha, said of patience, (assumed tropical:) It gives beauty and colour to the countenance. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- See also 4, in two places.

2 XbRb AlnRaAra c
2. XbRb AlnRaAra, inf. n. taXobiybN: see the preceding paragraph. ― -b2- Hence, taXobiybu AlXRiEori (tropical:) The making the commencement of poetry elegant, or ornate, by the mention of women: (L, TA:) or the primary meaning of AltRaXobiybu is the mention of the days of youth and of play or sport, and amatory language; and it is in the commencing of odes; and the commencement thereof is so called, absolutely, though there be not in it any mention of youth: (TA:) it means AlnRasiybu, (S, O,) or AlnRasiybu biAlnRisaMCi, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AltRaXabRubu bAlnisACi,]) i. e. bicikorihinRa: (TA:) one says, yuXabRibu biqulaAnapa, (S, O,) and bihaA ytXbRb↓ [if this be not a mistranscription for yuXabRibu], (TA,) meaning yanosibu bihaA: (S, O, TA:) [see this fully expl. in art. nsb: i. e.] XbRb bifulaAnapa, inf. n. taXobiybN, means, (tropical:) He spoke of such a female in amatory language [in the commencement of his ode], (Msb, TA,) and alluded to the love of her: (Msb:) and XbRb qaSiydatahu (assumed tropical:) He embellished [the commencement of] his ode by the mention of women: (Mgh, Msb:) and XbRb qaSiydatahu bifulaAnapa (tropical:) [He embellished the commencement of his ode by mentioning, in amatory language, such a female]: (A, TA:) and XabaAbN↓ is used in the sense of taXobiybN; thus a qaSiydap is said to be HasanapN AlXRabaAbi (tropical:) [Beautiful in the mention of women &c.]; and Jereer is said to have been OaraqRu AlnRaAsi XabaAbFA (tropical:) [The most elegant of men in the mention of women &c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Hence, i. e. from taXobiybN AlqaSiydapi, may be derived AltRaXobiybu as a conventional term in the science of the division of inheritances; meaning (assumed tropical:) The mention of daughters according to the different degrees [of descent]: (Mgh:) it is as when one says, “ he died, and left three daughters of a son, subordinate one to another, and three daughters of a son's son, in like manner, and three daughters of a son's son's son, in like manner, and the sons died and the daughters remained. ” (O.) ― -b4- taXobiybu Alkutubi signifies (assumed tropical:) The commencing of books, or writings: and hence XabRaba yujaAwibuhu, occurring in a trad., meaning (assumed tropical:) He commenced answering him: not from the taXobiyb of women in poetry. (TA.)

4 AXbRhu QllRehu c
4. AXbRhu QllRehu God made him, or may God make him, to become a youth, or young man; i. e., to attain to the state termed XabaAbN meaning as expl. below: and AXbR QllRehu qaronahu means the same: (S, A, TA:) the latter [lit. means God made, or may God make, his equal in age to become a youth, &c., (see Har p. 572,) and therefore] is tropical. (A, TA.) ― -b2- OaXobayotu Alfarasa I excited the horse to be brisk, lively, or sprightly, and to raise his fore legs together, as though in leaping, and to play. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b3- AXbR AlnRaAra: see 1. ― -b4- OuXibRa liIa AlrRajulu, inf. n. UiXobaAbN; as also XubRa↓; (tropical:) The man appeared before my upraised eyes when not hoped for. (AZ, TA.) ― -b5- And OuXibRa liI kacaA, and XubRa↓, (tropical:) Such a thing was prepared, or appointed, or ordained, for me. (S, K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- OaXabRu (tropical:) He became one whose child, or children, had attained to the state of XabaAb [i. e. youth, or young manhood, &c.]: (K:) [or] OaXabRa AlrRajulu baniyna (tropical:) the man became one whose children had attained to that state: (S, TA:) and in like manner, OaXabRato OawolaAdFA is said of a woman. (TA.) ― -b2- And OaXabRa said of [the species of bovine antelope called] the wild bull, (S, K,) He became such as is termed XababN [q. v.], i. e., (S,) he became advanced in age, or full-grown; (musinR, S, K;) one whose state termed UisonaAn [q. v.] had ended. (S.)

5 taXabRaRa
5: [taXabRati AlnRaAru The fire became kindled; or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame: see also 1.] One says on the occasion of kindling fire,
taXabRabiI taXabRuba AlnRamiymaho
jaMCato bihaA tamorN UilaI tamiymaho
[Be thou kindled like the state of kindling of the calumny that Temr brought to Temeemeh: but to what this alludes I know not]: it is like the saying, Oawoqada biAlnRamiymapi naArFA [He kindled a fire with calumny]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also 2.

10 UisotaXobaba
10: It is said in a trad., yajuwzu XahaAdapu AlSRiboyaAni EalaI AlkibaAri yusotavabRuwna [The boy's giving testimony against those that are full grown is allowable, when they (the former) are deemed to have attained to the state of youths, or young men]: it is as though it were said that if they take upon themselves the bearing witness in boyhood, and give their testimony when full grown, it is allowable: (TA:) or yusotaXabRuwna means they shall be sought youths, such as have attained to puberty, or maturity, in the case of giving testimony: or they shall be waited for, in the case of giving testimony, until the period of becoming youths, or young men. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And it is said in another trad., AisotaXibRuwA EalaI Oasowuqikumo fiI Albawoli, i. e. Sit upon your shanks as one does when preparing to rise, not stooping with the whole body near to the ground; [having your feet only upon the ground; in the voiding of urine:] from XabRa Alfarasu meaning “ the horse raised his fore-legs together from the ground. ” (TA.)

R. Q. 1 XaboXaba c
R. Q. 1. XaboXaba He completed [a thing]; (AA, O, K;) said of a man. (AA, TA.)

XabRN c
XabRN, and its fem. XabRapN: see XaAbRN. ＝ -A2- Also The stones of zaAj [or vitriol]: (K:) or the stones from which zAj and the like thereof are obtained; the best whereof is that which is brought from El-Yemen, which is white XbR, and is very glistening: (TA:) [but XabRN yamaAniIRN, as also XabRN alone, is a name now commonly given to alum:] or it is a certain thing resembling zAj: (S, Msb:) or a species thereof: accord. to El-Fárábee, the stones from which come zAj and the like: Az says, it is one of the minerals produced by God in the earth, with which one tans, and resembling zAj, and the name [correctly] heard is thus, with b, but is by some mistranscribed with the three-dotted v, [i. e. XavRN,] which is a kind of tree of bitter taste, and I know not whether one tans with it or not: accord. to Mtr, in the saying that one tans with XbR, this word is a mistranscription; for XbR is a dye, and one does not tan with a dye; it is mistranscribed for XavR, which is a kind of tree like the dwarf apple-tree, whereof the leaves are like those of the xilaAf [q. v.], and with them one tans: El-Fárábee also says, in the section of v, that the XavR is a species of mountain-tree, with which one tans: from all which it appears that one tans with both of them; for an affirmation is to be preferred to a negation: (Msb:) and it is a well-known medicine; (K, TA;) as some say: so accord. to the correct copies of the K, in some of which, daMCN is put for dawaMCN. (TA.)

XubR c
XubR and dubR, though originally verbs, are used as nouns, by the introduction of mino before them: one says, OaEoyayotaniI mino XubRa UilaI dubRa and mino XubRK UilaI dubRK [expl. in art. dba]: (S:) and in like manner they are used in another saying expl. in art. db [q. v.]: (S in that art.:) or, without tenween, they may be regarded as verbs used in the way of HikaAyap [or imitation]. (MF.)

XabRapN c
XabRapN The burning, burning up, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming, of fire. (TA.)

XababN c
XababN and XabuwbN↓, applied to a [bovine antelope of the species called the] wild bull, (As, S, K,) and to a sheep or goat, (K,) and muXibRN↓, applied to the former, and miXabRN↓, (As, S, K,) sometimes, applied to the former, (As, S,) or to both, (K,) Advanced in age, or full-grown, (musinRN, S, K,) whose state termed UisonaAn [q. v.] has ended; (As, S;) and muXibRapN↓ is in like manner applied to a she-camel as meaning musinRapN: (TA:) or XbuwbN↓, (AA, K,) applied to both, (K,) as also muXibRN↓, (TA,) or to a bull, (AA,) is syn. with XAbRN↓ [meaning youthful, or in the prime of life]: (AA, K, TA:) and accord. to AO, XababN, applied to a bull, means that has attained to the end of XabaAb [i. e. youthfulness, or the prime of life]: (S, TA:) or, as some say, that has attained to the end of his full growth and strength; as also XabuwbN↓, which is likewise applied to the female; or, accord. to AHát and ISh, when he is a year old, and weaned, he is called dababN; and then, XababN [meaning more than a year old]; and the female, XababpN. (TA.)

XabaAbN c
XabaAbN and XabiybapN↓ [both mentioned above as inf. ns.] (S, Msb, K) [and XabaAbiyRapN↓ which is a simple subst.] Youth, youthfulness, the prime of man-
hood, or young manhood; syn. fataMCN; (K;) or HadaAvapN; contr. of XayobN: (S:) or the state from puberty to the completion of thirty years; or from sixteen years to thirty-two; after which a man is called kaholN; (TA;) the age before Alkuhuwlap: (Msb:) or the state between thirty and forty: (Mgh:) or, accord. to Mohammad Ibn-Habeeb, the state from the seventeenth year to the completion of fifty-one years is termed XabaAbiyRapN↓; the period before, from birth, being termed guluwmiyRapN; and in the period after, a man being called XayoxN, until he dies. (TA.) One says, saqaI QllRehu EaSora AlXabiybapi↓ [May God freshen as with rain the times, or mornings, or afternoons, of youth, &c.], and EuSuwra AlXRabaAYibi [the times, &c., of the states of youth, &c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [XabaAbN often signifies (assumed tropical:) The sap, or vigour, of youth or young manhood.] One says, AisotaHaAra XabaAbuhaA, as in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, (assumed tropical:) The sap [or vigour] of youth (maMCN AlXRabaAbi) flowed in her. (IB, TA in art. Hyr.) And AimotalaOa XabaAbFA (assumed tropical:) [He became full of the sap, or vigour, of youth or young manhood]. (The lexicons, &c., passim.) [But] maMCN AlXRabaAbi signifies [also] (tropical:) The freshness, or brightness, and beauty, of youth. (Har p. 340.) [And XabiybapN↓ app. signifies also (assumed tropical:) Youthful folly, or the like; (see an ex. voce gamorapN;) and so, probably, does XabaAbN.] ― -b3- [Hence,] XabaAbN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The first, or beginning, or the new, or recent, state, of a thing; (K, TA;) and so XabiybapN↓. (TA.) One says, qadima fiI XabaAbi AlXRahori (A, TA) (tropical:) He came, or arrived, in the beginning of the month. (TA.) And laqiytuhu fiI XabaAbi AlnRahaAri (A, TA) (tropical:) I met him in the beginning of the day: (TA:) and jiYotuka fiI XabaAbi AlnRahaAri and biXabaAbi AlnRahaAri (assumed tropical:) I came to thee in the beginning of the day: (Lh, TA:) or XabaAbu AlnRahaAri means the period when the sun has risen high, when one fifth of the day has passed. (A in art. rOd.) And one says also faEala celika fiI Xabiybatihi↓ He did that at the commencement thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also XaAbRN ＝ -A3- And see 2.

XibaAbN c
XibaAbN an inf. n. of XabRa said of a horse. (S, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

XibaAbN c
XibaAbN: see XabRa, in three places. ― -b2- Also A horse whose hind feet pass beyond his fore feet; (K;) which is a fault: accord. to Th, such is termed XabiybN↓: IM says that the correct word is XaYiytN: [but] see this in its proper place. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A thing with which a fire is kindled, or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; (S, K;) and so XibaAbN↓. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence, as also XibaAbN↓,] (tropical:) A thing that serves [as a foil] for beautifying, or setting off, (K,) [or making to appear bright and beautiful,] or for increasing, or enhancing, and strengthening, [or heightening, in beauty,] (S, TA,) to another thing. (S, K, TA.) So in the saying, hecaA XabuwbN likacaA (tropical:) This is a thing that serves for increasing, or enhancing, [or heightening, in beauty,] to such a thing. (S, TA.) One says of a woman's headcovering, huwa XabuwbN liwajohihaA (tropical:) [It is a thing that serves for giving an appearance of additional brightness and beauty to her face]. (A.)

XabiybN c
XabiybN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XabiybapN c
XabiybapN: see XabaAbN, in five places.

EasalN XabaAbiIRN c
EasalN XabaAbiIRN Honey of Shebábeh (XabaAbap); (A, TA;) or, of Benoo-Shebábeh, (Mgh,) a people of Et-Táïf, (A, Mgh, TA,) of [the tribe of] Khath'am, who possessed bees, and hence it was thus called. (Mgh.)

XabaAbiyRapN c
XabaAbiyRapN: see XabaAbN, in two places.

XabRacaA zayodN c
XabRacaA zayodN i. q. HabRacaA [q. v. in art. Hb]. (Th, TA.)

XaAbRN c
XaAbRN part. n. of XabRa said of a boy; (Msb;) [Youthful, or in the prime of manhood; a youth, or a young man;] in the state from puberty to the completion of thirty years; or from sixteen years to thirty-two; after which a man is called kaholN; (TA;) in the age before Alkuhuwlap: (Msb:) or in the state between thirty and forty: (Mgh:) [or in the state from the seventeenth year to the completion of fifty-one years: (see XabaAbN:)] and IAar mentions XabRN↓ as an epithet applied to a man [in the same sense as XaAbRN]: (TA:) a female is termed XaAbRapN (S, Msb, K) and XabRapN↓; both signifying the same: (S, K:) the pl. of XaAbRN is XubRaAnN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and XababapN (S, A, K) and XabaAbN↓, (S, A, * K,) or the last is an inf. n. used as an epithet applied to a pl. number, (Mgh, and Ham p. 50,) or it is a quasi-pl. n.: (TA:) females, (Msb,) or women, (K,) are termed XawaAbRN (Msb, K) and XabaAYibu, (K,) the latter said by AZ to be allowable in the sense of the former, (TA,) which is pl. of XaAbRapN, (Msb,) XabaAYibu, accord. to Az, being pl. (not of XaAbRapN but) of XabRapN, like as DaraAYiru is of DarRapN: (TA:) the dim. of XaAbRapN is XuwayobRapN↓, and some of the Arabs say XuwaAbRapN↓, changing the I into A before a double letter [as in duwaAbRapN for duwayobRapN]. (ISd, L in art. hd.) One says, mararotu birijaAl K XababapK meaning XubRaAnK [i. e. I passed by men that were youths, or persons in the prime of manhood]. (S.) ― -b2- See also XababN.

XuwaAbRapN c
XuwaAbRapN: dims. of XaAbRapN fem. of XaAbRN, q. v.

XuwayobRapN c
XuwayobRapN: dims. of XaAbRapN fem. of XaAbRN, q. v.

XawoXabN c
XawoXabN The scorpion. (IAar, K.) ― -b2- And The louse; syn. qamolN: (K in this art.:) or the ant; syn. namolN: (K in art. XXb:) fem. [or perhaps n. un.] with p. (TA.)

muXibRN c
muXibRN, and its fem., with p: see XababN, in three places. ― -b2- Also the former, A lion: (K:) or a full-grown lion: syn. OasadN kabiyrN. (TA.)

miXabRN c
miXabRN: see XababN.

muXabRabN AlOaZaAfiri c
muXabRabN AlOaZaAfiri [or rather AlOaZaAfiyri, pl. of the pl. OaZofaArN or of OuZofuwrN,] (tropical:) Having sharp-pointed nails or talons or claws; as though they flamed, by reason of their sharpness. (A, TA.)

maXobuwbN c
maXobuwbN [pass. part. n. of 1]. You say naArN maXobuwbapN A fire kindled, or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame: XaAbRapN in this sense is not allowable. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] applied to a man, (A, TA,) (tropical:) Comely, (S, TA,) of goodly countenance; (A, TA;) as though lighted up: bright, or fair, in complexion, and of goodly countenance; as though his countenance were lighted up with fire: pl. maXaAbiybu. (TA.) And (tropical:) A man of acute mind. (TA.) And TalaEati AlmaXobuwbataAni AlzRuharataAni [or AlzRahoraAwaAni?] (tropical:) Venus and Jupiter, so called on account of their beauty and splendour, rose. (A, TA.)

XibitRN c
XibitRN [Anethum graveolens, or dill, of the common garden-species;] a certain herb, or leguminous plant, well known: (K:) it is said that sibitRN is an arabicized word from XibitRN; but it has been stated before [in art. sbt, q. v.,] that both these are arabicized words from Xiwico [or Xiwido]; and that sbT [i. e. siTRN] is a dial. var. (TA.) [See also XibivRN.]

1 XabVva
1: see the next paragraph, in two places.

5 tXRbv bihi c
5. tXRbv bihi He, or it, clung, caught, clave, or adhered, to it, (S, A, L, Msb, K, * TA,) namely, a thing; (S, L, TA;) as also Xabiva bihi↓, aor.
Xabava
, inf. n. XabavN: (L, TA:) or, accord. to Esh-Shiháb, in the Expos. of the Shifè, to a thing in which was weakness: or, accord. to the 'Ináyeh, he, or it, clung, &c., to it with weakness; and therefore mutaXabRivN↓ is used as an epithet applied to a spider; and tamasRuka signifies a stronger action; and tXbRv bh is also expl. as meaning he, or it, took fast, or firm, hold upon it: (L, TA:) and he stuck, or fixed, or struck, the claw, or talons, or nails, into it: (MA, PS:) and AlXRaIoCa Xabiva↓ he laid hold upon the thing, and took it: IAar was asked respecting some verses, and he said, maA OadoriI mino Oayona XabivotuhaA I know not whence I laid hold upon them [and took them]. (L, TA.)

Q. Q. 1
Q. Q. 1: accord. to the S and L, Xanobava: see art. Xnbv.

XabavN c
XabavN The spider: (K:) or a large spider, with many legs. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (K) A certain small creeping thing, (S, A, Msb, K,) having many legs, (S, A, K,) of the OaHonaAX [or creeping things &c.] of the earth: (S, Msb:) it should not be called XibovN: (S:) or a certain small creeping thing, having six long legs, yellow in the back, and in the outer sides of the legs, black in the head, and blue in the eye: or a certain small creeping thing, having many legs, large in the head, of the AHnAX of the earth: or a certain small creeping thing, wide in the mouth, high in the hinder part, that perforates the ground, is found where there is moisture, and eats scorpions; and it is what is called XaHomapu AlOaroDi: (TA:) pl. XibovaAnN. (S, A, Msb, K.) The [marks termed] Oavor of the blade of a sword are likened by
a poet, (S, TA,) namely, Sá'ideh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh, (TA,) to the tracks of XibovaAn. (S, TA.)

rajulN XabivN c
rajulN XabivN A man whose nature it is to cling, catch, cleave, or adhere, to a thing. (S, K.) And DirosN DabivN XabivN [A tooth, or molar tooth,] that catches, or fastens, to a thing. (TA.)

XubavapN c
XubavapN, (K,) or XubavapN DubavapN, (TA,) A man (TA) who cleaves to his qiron [i. e. opponent, or adversary], not quitting him. (K, TA.)

XibivRN c
XibivRN [erroneously written in some copies of the K XibovN, and in the L XibivN,] A certain wellknown plant; (AHn, L, Msb;) a certain herb, or leguminous plant; (K;) [i. q. XibitRN and sibitRN, q. v.; i. e. anethum graveolens, or dill, of the common garden-species:] Sgh says that Xbv is a foreign word of which sibitRN is an arabicized form; and it is made of the measure fiEilRN because this measure has many examples; whereas the measure fiEilRN, of which UibilN is an instance, is extraordinary. (Msb.)

XabRaAvN c
XabRaAvN: see what next follows.

XabRuwvN c
XabRuwvN and XabRaAvN↓ [so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K, but the latter is strangely said in the TA to be with kesr,] sings. of XabaAbiyvu, which signifies The flesh-hooks (kalaAliyb) of the fire. (K.)

AlXRanobavu c
AlXRanobavu: see art. Xnbv.

AlXRunaAbivu c
AlXRunaAbivu: see art. Xnbv.

mitaXabRivN c
mitaXabRivN an epithet applied to a spider: see 5.

1 XabuHa c
1. XabuHa, (S, K,) inf. n. XabaAHapN, (TK,) said of a man, (S,) He was, or became, broad in the fore arms: (S, K, TA:) or long therein. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XabaHahu, (A, O, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) aor.
XabaHa
, (K,) inf. n. XaboHN, (TK,) He extended, stretched, or stretched out, it, or him; (A, O, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) namely, a thing; (IF, L, Msb;) a hide, or skin, (A, L, K,) or some other thing, (L,) between pegs, or stakes; (K;) and a man, (Mgh, L, Msb,) between two things, to be flogged, (L,) [i. e.,] between two stakes inserted and fixed in the ground, (Mgh, Msb,) which are called EuqaAbaAni, (Mgh,) when he was beaten, or crucified, (Mgh, Msb,) or like him who is crucified; and XbRHhu↓ is used, accord. to some, in the same manner. (L.) And XabaHa yadayohi He extended, or stretched forth, his arms, or hands: (L:) or XabaHa [alone] he extended his arm, or hand, to offer a prayer, or supplication; (K;) or he extended and raised his arms, or hands, in his prayer, or supplication. (A.) And AlHirobaMCu yaXobaHu EalaI AlEuwdi (tropical:) The chameleon extends (S, A, O) itself (S, O) or its fore legs (A) upon the branch. (S, A, O.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, He cut, hewed, or pared, it, namely, a stick, or piece of wood, so as to make it wide. (O, L. [See also 2.]) ― -b3- And He clave it, or split it, (K, * TA,) namely, another's head, or anything whatever. (TA.) ― -b4- XabaHa lanaA He (a man, K) stood erect [as though drawing himself up] to us. (O, K.) ― -b5- And XabaHa laka It (a thing) appeared, or became apparent, to thee. (L.) ＝ -A3- XubiHa biOamorK He was, or became, attached, or addicted, to an affair; or fond of it. (O.)

2 XbRHhu c
2. XbRHhu: see 1. ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. taXobiyHN, (S,) He made it (a thing) wide. (S, K.) ― -b3- And taXobiyHN signifies also The act of paring, or peeling, or the like. (O. [See also 1.]) ― -b4- And The act of pulling, or plucking, out, or up. (O.) ＝ -A2- And XbRH, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He (a man, TA) became aged, and saw a [thing such as is termed] XabaH appearing as though it were two. (O, K.)

XaboHN c
XaboHN: see XabaHN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also maXobuwHN.

XabaHN c
XabaHN (S, A, O, Msb, K) and XaboHN↓ (S, O, K) i. q. XaxoSN [i. e. The body, or bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance, of a man or some other thing or object, which one sees from a distance]: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) a man, or some other creature, of which the XaxoS [or body, &c.,] appears to one: (L:) and a thing that is perceived by sense (A, O, L) and by sight: (O, L:) pl. OaXobaAHN, (A, O, Msb, K,) which is of the former, (A, Msb,) and [of the latter] XubuwHN. (K.) One says, laAHa liI XabaHN, meaning XaxoSN [i. e. A body, or bodily form, appeared, loomed, or gleamed, to me]. (A.) And humo OaXobaAHN bilaA OarowaAHK [They are bodies without souls]. (A.) And OacaqRu mino XabaHK baATilK, (A, O,) and mino xayoTi baATilK, a prov., (O,) meaning [More minute, or inconsiderable, than] the atoms that are seen in the rays of the sun entering from a mural aperture in a chamber: (A, * O:) or, as some say, than the thread that comes forth from the mouth of the spider; [meaning gossamer;] called by the children muxaATN AlXRayoTaAni. (O.) And AlOasomaMCu DarobaAni OasomaMCu OaXobaAHK waOasomaMCu OaEomaAlK, meaning [Nouns are of two sorts,] the names of things perceived by sense, and the names [of actions, or rather of accidents or attributes, i. e.] of other things; like as they say OasomaMCu AlOaEoyaAni and OasomaMCu AlmaEaAniI. (A.) And halaka OaXobaAHu maAlihi The known ones of his camels, and sheep or goats, and other cattle, perished. (O, K. *) ＝ -A2- XabaHN also signifies A door or gate, of high structure; (O, K;) and so XaboHN↓: (K:) [but the latter may have originated from a mistranscription; for Sgh says,] and so XabajN. (O.) ＝ -A3- See also XabaHapN.

XaboHapN c
XaboHapN A rafter, or timber, (Euwd,) of the ceiling, or roof, of a house: so in a trad. where it is said, fanazaEa saqofa baytiI XaboHapF XaboHapF [And he pulled off the roof of my house, rafter by rafter, or timber by timber]. (JM, * TA.)

XiboHapN c
XiboHapN of horses: what is thus called is well known [as being A rope which is extended from a horse's fore leg to his hind leg: so in the present day]. (TA.)

XabaHapN c
XabaHapN a word occurring in the K and TA voce muXoTN and in the TA voce miHarRN &c. [app. as meaning A broad piece of wood]. ― -b2- AlXRabaHataAni signifies The two pieces of wood of the minoqalap, (O, K,) which is the thing upon which bricks are carried from place to place: the pl. is AlXRabaHaAtu and [the coll. gen. n., of which XabaHapN is the n. un., is] AlXRabaHu↓. (O.)

XaboHaAn c
XaboHaAn [whether with or without tenween is not apparent, as the fem. is not mentioned,] Tall; (AA, S, O, K;) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)

XabiyHapN c
XabiyHapN sing. of XabaAYiHu, (O,) which signifies Pieces of wood, (O, K,) broad, (O,) placed transversly, (O, K,) contrariwise, or on contrary sides, (O,) in the [camel's saddle called] qatab (O, K) that is of wood: so expl. by Shujáa. (O.)

muXRabaHN c
muXRabaHN, applied to a [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, Strong, or stout: (O, K: *) or, as some say, wide. (O.) ― -b2- And [applied to a stick, or piece of wood,] Pared, (K, TA,) and cut, or hewed [app. so as to be made wide: see 1]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And A species of fish.. (TA.)

maXobuwHN c
maXobuwHN Wide between the shoulders. (L.) ― -b2- maXobuwHu AlcRiraAEayoni and AlcRiraAEayoni XaboHu↓ A man broad in the fore arms: (S, K:) or long therein: but AAF and Ibn-El-Jowzee prefer the former explanation. (TA.) ＝ -A2- maXobuwHN biOamorK Attached, or addicted, to an affair; or fond of it. (O.)

1 Xabara c
1. Xabara, aor.
Xabura
(S, A, Msb) and
Xabira
, (S,) inf. n. XaborN; (IAar, S, Msb, K;) and XbRr↓, inf. n. taXobiyrN; (IAar, K;) He measured by the Xibor [or span] (IAar, S, A, Msb, K) a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, K,) or a thing: (A, Msb:) from AlXRiboru; like as one says buEotuhu from AlbaAEu. (S.) mano laka Oano taXobura AlbasiyTapa (tropical:) [Who will be guarantee for thee that thou wilt measure the earth with thy span?] is a prov. applied to him who imposes upon himself that which he is unable to accomplish. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Xabara AlmaroOapa, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He compressed the woman. (TA.) ― -b3- Xabarahu, (ISk, S, A,) aor.
Xabura
and
Xabira
, (TA,) inf. n. as above; (S, K;) and AXbrhu↓, (S, A,) inf. n. UiXobaArN; (K;) and XbRrhu↓, inf. n. taXobiyrN; (TS, TA;) He gave him (ISk, S, A, TS, K *) wealth, or property, (ISk, S, A,) or a sword, (ISk, S,) or a coat of mail. (S, IB.) ＝ -A2- Xabira, aor.
Xabara
, He exulted; or exulted greatly, or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (TS, K, TA.)

2 XabRara
2: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also XbRrhu, (AHeyth, K,) inf. n. taXobiyrN, (AHeyth, TA,) He magnified him, or honoured him; namely, a man: (AHeyth, K, TA:) and made him a near companion, a familiar, or a favourite. (AHeyth, TA.)

4 AXbr c
4. AXbr He (a man) begat children tall in the OaXobaAr, i. e. statures: and he begat children short therein. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- AXbrhu: see 1.

5 tXbRr c
5. tXbRr He was, or became, magnified, or honoured: and made a near companion, a familiar, or a favourite. (AHeyth, TA.)

6 tXAbrA c
6. tXAbrA They (two bodies of men, S) drew near, each to the other: (S, K:) as though they became a span (Xibor) distant, one from the other; or as though each extended the span to the other. (S.)

XaborN c
XaborN The measure [of the width (see ciraAEN)], by the span, of a garment, or piece of cloth: so in the saying, kamo Xaboru vawobika [How much is the measure of the width, by the span, of thy garment, or piece of cloth?]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Stature; (Fr, K;) and so XiborapN↓; whether short or tall: (TA:) pl. [app. of the latter] OaXobaArN. (IAar, TA.) You say, maA OaTowala Xaborahu How tall is his stature! (TA.) ― -b3- Life, or age; as also XiborN↓. (TS, K.) Thus in the saying, qaSRara QllRehu Xaborahu and Xiborahu↓ [May God shorten, or God shortened, his life]. (TS, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The act of giving: (A, IAth:) like as baAEN and yadN are said for “generosity.” (A.) ― -b5- See also XabarN, in two places. ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) The due for marriage, and for concubitus; (Sh, S, * K; *) such as what are termed mahorN and EuqorN. (Sh, TA.) You say, OaEoTayotu AlaroOapa XaborahaA I gave the woman her due for marriage, or for concubitus. (S.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) The hire that is given for the stallion-camel's covering of the female. (IAar, T, S, Msb, K. *) The taking of this is forbidden. (T, S, Msb.) ― -b8- (tropical:) Marriage: (IAth, K:) because it is accompanied by a gift. (IAth, TA.) baAraka QllRehu fiI XaborikumaA May God bless your marriage is a saying mentioned in a trad. (IAth, TA.)

XiborN c
XiborN A span; the space between the extremity of the thumb and that of the little finger (Msb, K) when extended apart in the usual manner: (Msb:) of the masc. gender: (K:) pl. OaXobaArN, (S, Msb, K,) the only pl. form. (Sb.) [See also buSomN, and ciraAEN.] [Hence,] qaSiyru AlXRibori (applied to a man, S) (tropical:) Contracted, or short, in make: (S, A, K:) or, accord. to some of the lexicons, in step. (TA.) ― -b2- [As a measure in astronomy, it is said in several of the law-books to be The twelfth part of the rumoH; and therefore twentytwo minutes and a half, accord. to modern usage: but there is reason to believe that ancient usage differed from the modern with respect to both of these measures, and was not precise nor uniform. See rumoHN.] ― -b3- qibaAlu AlXRibori (assumed tropical:) The serpent: (IAar, K:) and so qibaAlu AlXRisoEi. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- See also XaborN, in two places.

XabarN c
XabarN (tropical:) A gift; (S Mgh, K, TA;) as also XaborN↓ (Mgh, TA) and XiborapN↓: (IAar, TA:) and wealth, or the like; syn. xayorN: (K:) the first is a word similar to xabaTN and nafaDN; and he who says that it is used by poetic license for XaborN [as it is said to be in the S] is in error: XaborN↓ and XabarN are said to be two dial. vars., like qadorN and qadarN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A certain thing which the Christians give, one to another, (yataEaATaAhu AlnRaSaAraI, K, TA, abEoDuhumo libaEoDK, TA,) like the qurobaAn [or Eucharist], (K, TA,) seeking to ingratiate themselves thereby: (TA:) or the Eucharist (qurobaAn) itself: (K:) or a thing which the Christians give (tuEoTiyhi), one to another, as though seeking to ingratiate themselves thereby: (Kh, Sgh, TA:) or (TA, in the K “and”) bodies: and powers, or faculties: (K, TA:) or (TA, in the K “and”) the Gospel. (K, TA.)

XiborapN c
XiborapN: see XaborN: ― -b2- and see also XabarN.

XabRuwrN c
XabRuwrN A trumpet; syn. buwqN; (S, K;) a certain thing in which one blows: (Mgh:) said to be an arabicized word; (S;) not genuine Arabic: (Mgh, TA:) accord. to IAth, it is Hebrew: (TA:) [app. from the Hebr. שׁוֹפָּר, as observed by Golius.] ― -b2- See also OuXobuwrN.

rajulN XaAbiru AlmiyzaAni c
rajulN XaAbiru AlmiyzaAni (assumed tropical:) A man that is a thief. (Sgh, K.)

OaXobaru c
OaXobaru Wider in span; syn. OawosaEu XiborFA. (A, TA.) So in the saying, huwa OaXobaru mino SaAHibihi [He is wider in span than his companion]. (A.)

OuXobuwrN c
OuXobuwrN A certain fish; (K;) called by the vulgar XabRuwr↓. (TA.)

maXobarN c
maXobarN sing. of maXaAbiru, (TA,) which signifies Certain notches (HuzuwzN [pl. of HazRN, in the CK erroneously written xuwuwozN,]) in the cubit, by means of which buying and selling are transacted: (K, TA:) of them is the notch (HazR) of the span, and the notch of the half of the span, and of the quarter thereof: every notch of these, small or great, is termed maXobarN: mentioned by Sgh, from Aboo-Sa'eed. (TA.) ＝ -A2- maXaAbiru also signifies Rivers, or rivulets, (OanohaAr,) that are depressed, so that the water comes to them from several places, (K, TA,) of such as overflows from the lands: (TA:) pl. of maXobarN and maXobarapN↓. (K, TA.)

maXobarapN c
maXobarapN: see what next precedes.

maXobuwrapN c
maXobuwrapN A liberal, bountiful, or generous, woman. (IAar, K.)

XubaATN c
XubaATN (AA, K) and XubaATu, being perfectly and imperfectly decl., (AA, TA,) The name of a month in Greek; (AA, K;) i. q. subaAT, q. v. (AA, TA.)

XabRuwTN c
XabRuwTN (S, K) and XubRuwTN, (K,) the latter mentioned in the O on the authority of Lth, but in the L on the authority of Lh, and said by him to be a Greek word, (TA,) [a coll. gen. n.,] n. un. with p, and sometimes that with fet-h is without teshdeed, (K,) i. e. XabuwTapN, mentioned by ISd, but with the expression of a doubt as to its correctness, (TA,) [now applied to A species of cyprinus, or carp: or, accord. to Golius, a fish resembling the alosa, or shad, but three times larger; wont to be brought from the Euphrates to Aleppo:] a species of fish, (Lth, S, K,) slender in the tail, wide in the middle part, soft to the feel, small in the head, resembling a barobaT [or Persian lute]: (Lth, K:) the brbT when long, not broad, is likened to this fish; and this fish, to the brbT: the pl. is XabaAbiyTu. (TA.) [See subRuwHN.]

1 XabiEa c
1. XabiEa, [aor.
XabaEa
,] inf. n. XibaEN (IDrd, S, Msb, K) and XiboEN, (IDrd, Msb, TA,) which is a contraction of the former, or accord. to some it is a subst., having the signification assigned to it below, (Msb,) or it is both, (TA,) and XaboEN, (Ibn- 'Abbád, K,) He was, or became, satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach; XibaEN being the contr. of juwEN, (S, K,) and one of those inf. ns. [which are of a measure often] denoting natural affections or qualities [such as riwFI and simanN &c.]. (S.) You say baladN qado XabiEato ganamuhu A country of which the sheep, or goats, have become completely satiated, or satisfied, by abundance of herbage. (TA.) And XabiEotu xubozFA, and laHomFA, (S, Msb, K,) and mino xubozK, and mn laHomK, (S, K,) I was, or became, satiated, sated, or satisfied, with bread, and with flesh-meat. (S, K.) ― -b2- Hence, metaphorically, XabiEotu mino hecaA AlOamoi warawiytu (tropical:) I have become, or I became, disgusted [or satiated to loathing] with this thing, or affair. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- [See also another metaphorical usage of this verb voce HuzaAnapN.] ＝ -A2- XabuEa Eaqoluhu (assumed tropical:) His intellect was, or became, full, perfect, (K,) strong, or solid. (TA.)

2 XabRaEato ganamuhu c
2. XabRaEato ganamuhu, (S, K, [in some copies of the former, erroneously, XabiEato,]) inf. n. taXobiyEN; (K;) and XubRiEato; (as in one place in the TA;) (tropical:) His sheep, or goats, were, or became, nearly, but not quite, satiated, or satisfied. (S, K, TA.)

4 AXbEhu c
4. AXbEhu [signifying It satiated him, sated him, or satisfied his stomach,] is said of food and of abundance of drink. (TA.) ― -b2- OaXobaEotuhu [I satiated him, sated him, or satisfied his stomach; or] I fed him so that he became satiated, sated, or satisfied. (Msb.) And OaXobaEotuhu mina AljuwEi [I fed him so as fully to relieve him from hunger]. (S, K.) [Hence,] OaXobaEotu AlvRawoba (S, TA) mina AlSRibogi (S) (tropical:) I saturated the garment, or piece of cloth, with the dye. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AXbEhu (tropical:) He made it (namely anything, TA) full, without lack or defect, or abundant, or copious. (K, * TA.) It is said of other things beside substances; as, for instance, of blowing, and of reading or reciting, and of any expression. (TA.) You say also, saAqa fiI hecaA AlmaEonaI faSolFA muXobaEFA [He carried on, respecting this idea, a full section]. (TA.) [And AXbE HarakapF He rendered a vowel full in sound, by inserting after it its analogous letter of prolongation. And such a letter of prolongation is said to be inserted, or added, liloUiXobaAEi to render the sound full; as in nukaAtN for nukatN, and OanoZuwru for OanoZuru, and maraADiyEu for maraADiEu. And UiXobaAEFA is also used as signifying For the sake of, or by way of, pleonasm, or giving fulness of expression.] ＝ -A2- AXbE AlrRajulu The man's beasts were, or became, completely satiated, or satisfied, by abundance of herbage. (TA.)

5 tXbRE c
5. tXbRE He ate immediately after eating. (K.) ― -b2- He feigned himself satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach, not being so. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence,] (tropical:) He made a boast of abundance or riches, (Msb, K, * TA,) or of more than he possessed; and invested himself with that which did not belong to him. (TA.) [See mutaXabRiEN.]

XiboEN c
XiboEN a subst., signifying A thing that satiates one, sates one, or satisfies one's stomach; (S, Msb, K;) consisting of bread, and of flesh-meat, &c.; (Msb;) as also XibaEN↓: (K:) accord. to some, the former is an inf. n.: (Msb:) or it is an inf. n. and also a subst. signifying as above. (TA.) You say, AlrRagiyfu XiboEiI The cake of bread [is that which] satiates me, &c. (Msb.)

XibaEN c
XibaEN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Thickness in the shanks. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also XiboEN. You say, OaroDN caAtu XibaEK A land having abundance of herbage, and plenty. (Mgh.)

XuboEapN mino TaEaAmK c
XuboEapN mino TaEaAmK The quantity with which one is satiated, sated, or satisfied, once, of food. (S, K.)

OaroDN XabiEapN c
OaroDN XabiEapN i. q. caAtu XibaEK [q. v.]. (Mgh.)

XaboEaAnu c
XaboEaAnu Satiated, sated, or satisfied in stomach; (S, Msb, * K;) as also XaAbiEN↓, but this is allowable only in poetry: (K:) fem. of the former XaboEaI, (S, Msb, K,) and XaboEaAnapN (Sgh, K) is sometimes used: (Sgh:) the pl. of XbEAn and of XbEI is XibaAEN and XabaAEaI. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] qawomN UicaA jaAEuwA kaAEuwA wataraAhumo sibaAEFA UicaA kaAnuwA XibaAEFA [A people who, when they are hungry, are fearful and cowardly, and thou seest them to be beasts of prey when they are satiated]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] XaboEaI AlxaloxaAli (tropical:) A woman who fills up the anklet by reason of her fatness. (S, K, TA.) And XaboEaI AlsRiwaAri (tropical:) Who fills up the bracelet by reason of fatness. (K, TA.) And XaboEaI AlwiXaAHi (tropical:) A woman large in the belly. (TA.) And XaboEaI AldRiroEi (tropical:) A woman bulky in make: (A, O, L, TA:) in the K erroneously written XaboEaI AlcRiraAEi, and expl. as meaning bulky in the forearm. (TA.)

XabiyEN c
XabiyEN Food that satiates, sates, or satisfies the stomach. (Fr.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) An arrow that kills much or many or often. (Ibn-'Abbád.) ― -b3- vawobN XabiyEu Algazoli (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, [of full texture, or] of many threads: (S, K, TA:) pl. viyaAbN XuboEN. (TA.) And HabolN XabiyEN, (K,) or XabiyEu AlvRalRapi, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A rope abundant, (K, TA,) and firm, or strong, in the wool, (TA,) or in the hair, or fur, [of which it is composed:] (K, TA:) pl. XuboEN. (TA.) ― -b4- rajulN XabiyEu AlEaqoli (assumed tropical:) A man full, or perfect, (K, TA,) and strong, or solid, (TA,) in intellect; (K, TA;) from IAar; (TA;) as also muXobaEuhu↓. (K.) And Alqalobi rajulN muXabRaEN↓ [or perhaps Alqalobi muXobaEu↓] (assumed tropical:) A man strong, or firm, in heart. (TA.)

XubaAEapN c
XubaAEapN A portion of food that remains, or is redundant, after one is satiated, or satisfied. (Ibn-Abbád, K. *)

XaAbiEN c
XaAbiEN: see XuboEaAnN. ― -b2- bahiymapN XaAbiEN A beast that has attained to eating; an epithet applied to such a beast until it is nearly weaned. (TA.)

fulaAnN fiI riIRi wamaXobaEK c
fulaAnN fiI riIRi wamaXobaEK [Such a one is in a state in which he is satiated, or satisfied, with drink and food]. (T, A, TA, in art. nZr.) [See manoZarN.]

muXobaEN c
muXobaEN pass. part. n. of 4 [q. v.]. See also XabiyEN, in two places.

muXabRaEN c
muXabRaEN: see XabiyEN. ― -b2- AlbaMCu AlmuXabRaEu [or AlmuXabRaEapu] The letter P. (TA in art. bls.)

mutaXabRiEN c
mutaXabRiEN (tropical:) One who invests himself with, and makes a boast of, more than he possesses; who invests himself with that which he does not possess; (S, TA;) who affects goodly qualities more than he possesses; like him who feigns himself satiated, or satisfied in stomach, not being so: (TA:) or he who feigns himself satiated, or satisfied in stomach, not being so: and hence, (assumed tropical:) a lying person, who affects to be commended or praised for, or boasts of, or glories in, that which he does not possess. (Mgh.) Thus in a trad., (S, Mgh,) in which it is said, AlmutaXabRiEu bimaA laA yamoliku kalaA bisi vawobaIo zuwrK, (S, TA,) or bimaA layosa Einodahu, (Mgh,) (tropical:) [He who invests himself with, and makes a boast of, more than he possesses, &c., is like the wearer of two garments of falsity: or] accord. to A'Obeyd, it means [that such is like] the hypocrite who wears the garments of the devotees in order that he may be thought to be a devotee, not being so: or, as some say, the person who wears a shirt to the sleeves of which he attaches two other sleeves in order to make it appear that he is wearing two shirts: or [the wearer of the garments of the false witness; for] it is said that there used to be in the tribe the man of goodly exterior, and when false witness was needed, he bore [such] witness, and was not rejected, because of the goodliness of his apparel. (Mgh.) [See also art. zwr, in which this trad, is cited with a small variation.]

1 Xabiqa c
1. Xabiqa, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Xabaqa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XabaqN, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb,) He was, or became, affected with vehement lust, or carnal desire: (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) said of a man; (M, Msb;) and in like manner one says of a woman; and also, sometimes, of other than human beings. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And Xabiqa mina AllRaHomi He suffered indigestion, or turned away with disgust, from flesh-meat. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

XabiqN c
XabiqN Affected with vehement lust or carnal desire; (Msb, TA;) applied to a man; and sometimes to other than man: (Msb:) fem. with p. (Msb, TA.)

XuwbaqN c
XuwbaqN A certain wooden implement of the baker, or maker of bread; (K;) a baker's rolling-pin; (MA;) [thus called, and also Xuwbak, in the present day;] an arabicized word, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) from [the Pers.] juwbah [or Juwbaho, or from the Pers. Xuwbajo]. (TA.) [See also kariybo.]

1 Xabakahu c
1. Xabakahu, aor.
Xabika
, (K, TA,) inf. n. XabokN; (TA;) and XbRkhu↓, inf. n. taXobiykN; He infixed, (K, TA,) and inserted, (TA,) one part thereof into another, or parts thereof into others: (K, TA:) so in the M: (TA:) [but the latter more usually signifies he infixed, and inserted, many parts thereof into others: (see 8, first sentence, respecting its quasipass.:) and hence, he made it reticulated, retiform, like a net; and like a lattice, or trellis, or grating, or cage: and both signify also he made it commingled in its several parts, intricate, complicated, perplexed, or confused; either properly, as when the object is a fabric, or anything made by art, or created; or tropically, as when the object is ideal:] primarily, (TA,) AlXRaboku signifies AlxaloTu [i. e. the mixing together a thing or things]; and [implies] AltRadaAxulu [i. e. the entering of one part of a thing into another part, or of parts of a thing or things into other parts; or the being intermixed, or intermingled]. (S, TA.) Hence, AlOaSaAbiEi taXobiyku↓, (S, TA,) meaning The inserting of some of the fingers [i. e. those of one hand] amid the other fingers; (Msb, TA;) which it is forbidden to do in prayer: (TA:) one says, [XbRk OaSaAbiEahu, or] XbRk bayona OaSaAbiEihi, He inserted, or interserted, his fingers together [so as to conjoin his two hands]: (MA:) or, as some interpret it, taXobiyku AlOaSaAbiEi which is forbidden in prayer is (assumed tropical:) the mixing, and entering, into contentions, or altercations. (TA.) [Hence also,] kaAnati AlrRiyHu XabRakatohumo↓, a saying of Mohammad Ibn-Zekereeyà, meaning (assumed tropical:) The wind had made them like the Xabakap [or net], in the interkniting and contraction of the limbs. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Xabakahu Eanohu, inf. n. as above, means (assumed tropical:) He, or it, diverted him, or occupied him so as to divert him, from him, or it. (TA.)

2 XabRaka
2: see above, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see also 8, in two places.

3 XAbk bayonahumaA c
3. XAbk bayonahumaA, inf. n. muXaAbakapN, [app. (assumed tropical:) He caused an embroilment between them two,] occurring in a tradition, (TA.)

4 AXbkwA c
4. AXbkwA They dug wells (O, K) such as are called XibaAkN (O) or such as are called XabakapN. (K.) ― -b2- And OaXobaka It (a place) had [such] wells dug in it by many persons. (TA.)

5 taXabRaka
5: see 8, in four places.

6 taXaAobaka
6: see 8, in three places, ― -b2- tXAbkt AlsRibaAEu The beasts of prey leaped [the females]; syn. nazato: (K:) or desired to do so (OaraAdati AlnRizaMCi). (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- taXaAbakaA [app. (assumed tropical:) They became embroiled, each with the other;] quasi-pass. of XaAbaka bayonahumaA. (TA.)

8 AXtbk c
8. AXtbk, quasi-pass. of Xabakahu, It had one part thereof infixed, (K, TA,) and inserted, (TA,) into another, or parts thereof into others; as also tXbRk↓, quasi-pass. of XbRkhu: (K, TA:) so in the M: but ↓the latter imports muchness, or multiplicity: (TA:) [i. e. it signifies it had many parts thereof infixed, and inserted, into others: and hence, it was reticulated, retiform,
like a net; and like a lattice, or trellis, or grating, or cage: and both signify also it was, or became, commingled in its several parts, intricate, complicated, perplexed, or confused; either properly, as when said of a fabric, or anything made by art, or created; or tropically, as when said of what is ideal.] One says, AXtbkt AlnRujuwmu, and tXAbkt↓, and XabRakat↓, [or the last may be a mistranscription for tXbRkt↓,] The stars were intermixed among themselves, and confused: (TA:) [or were clustered together:] or AiXotibaAku AlnRujuwmi signifies the stars' being numerous, and being intermixed among themselves; from Xabakapu AlSRaAYidi [“the net of the fisherman” or “sportsman”]: (Mgh:) or their being numerous, and [as though] gathered [or clustered] together: (Msb:) or, as some say, the appearing of all the stars [which causes them to appear confused]. (TA.) And AXtbkt AlEuruwqu The veins were knit together, commingled, or intricately intermixed or intermingled; syn. AiXotajarat. (O, TA.) And AXtbk AlsRaraAbu The mirage became intermixed, or confused. (TA.) And AXtbk AlZRalaAmu (tropical:) The darkness became confused. (S, O, TA.) And AXtkbt AlOumuwru, and tXAbkt↓, and XbRkt↓, (K, TA,) and tXbRkt↓, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The affairs became intricate, complicated, perplexed, or confused. (K, TA.) And AXtkbt AlHarobu bayonahumo (assumed tropical:) The war, or fight, became intricate, and entangled between them; syn. naXibat. (TA in art. nXb.) And AXtbkt OanoyaAbuhu waQxotalafato [His canine teeth locked together, and were dissimilar]; referring to a lion. (O. [See also XaAbikN.]) AiXotibaAku AlrRaHimi means (tropical:) The close [or intimate] connexion of relationship by birth: (TA:) [and in like manner, AlOaroHaAmi taXaAbuku↓ such connexion of relationships by birth: see an ex. of its part. n., voce muXotabikN.]

XabakN c
XabakN: see XabakapN. ― -b2- Also The teeth of a comb; (O, K;) because of their nearness together. (TA.)

bayonahumaA XubokapN c
