[or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of XajarapN; a pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] of which there are few other instances; qaSobaMCu of qaSabapN, and TarofaMCu of TarafapN, and HalofaMCu of HalafapN; or, accord. to As, the sing. [or n. un.] of HlfMCu is HalifapN: and accord. to Sb, XajoraMCu is sing. and pl., and so are qaSobaMCu and TarofaMCu and HalofaMCu: (S:) or XajoraMCu signifies tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, Xajar: (A:) or a collection of Xajar. (TA.) ― -b2- Xajarapu AlbaqRi &c.: see in arts. bq &c. ― -b3- In the saying in a trad., that the Xajarap and the Saxorap are of, or from, Paradise, by the former is said to be meant The grape-vine: or the tree beneath which allegiance was sworn to the Prophet; and which, it is said, was a Xamurap [or gum-acacia-tree]: (TA:) and by the latter, the Sxrp [or rock] of Jerusalem. (TA in art. Sxr, q. v.) ― -b4- By AlXRajarapu AlTRayRibapu, mentioned in the Kur in xiv. 29, is said to be meant The palm-tree: or a certain tree in Paradise: and by AlXRajarapu Alxabiyvapu, in the next verse but one, the colocynth, and the kaXuwv: [see art. xbv:] or each may have a more general application. (Bd in xiv. 31.) And AlXRajarapu AlmaloEuwnapu, mentioned in the Kur xvii. 62, means The tree called AlzRaqRuwm: and some explain it as meaning the Devil: and Aboo-Jahl: and El-Hakam Ibn-Abi-l-'As. (Bd.) ― -b5- XajarapN also signifies (tropical:) The stock, or origin, of a man: (O, TA:) [hence,] one says, huwa mino XajarapK TayRibapK (tropical:) [He is of a good stock or origin]; and mino Xajarapi AlnRubuwRapi (tropical:) [of the prophetic stock, meaning of the stock of the Prophet]. (A.) [And (assumed tropical:) A genealogical tree; a pedigree.] ― -b6- Also, (CK,) or XajorapN↓, (O, and K accord. to the TA, [but probably thus in the TA only because found to be so in the O,]) (assumed tropical:) A small speck, or speckle, on the chin of a boy: (O, K:) on the authority of IAar. (TA.) ― -b7- And one says, maA OaHosana Xajarapa DaroEihaA, (so in my copy of the A, and accord. to the CK,) or DrEhA Xajorapa↓, (O, and so accord. to the text of the K as given in the TA, [but Z has, in the A, distinguished the phrase as tropical, and hence it seems that he held the former reading to be the right,]) (tropical:) How goodly are the shape, (A,) or the size, (O, K,) and the appearance, of her udder! (A, O, K:) or the veins and skin and flesh thereof! referring to a she-camel. (O, K.)

XajirN c
XajirN: see 1, last sentence: ＝ -A2- and its fem., with p, see voce XajiyrN.

XijarN c
XijarN; and its n. un., with p: see XajarN.

XajorapN c
XajorapN: see XajarN, last two sentences.

XajoraMCu c
XajoraMCu, as a quasi-pl. n.: see XajarN. ＝ -A2- Also fem. of OaXojaru as syn. with XajiyrN.

AlHuruwfu AlXRajoriyRapu c
AlHuruwfu AlXRajoriyRapu [The letters of which the Xajor is the place of utterance; (in the CK, AlXRajariyRapu;)] the letters j and X and D. (K.)

XajaArN c
XajaArN: see miXojarN, in two places.

XijaArN c
XijaArN: see miXojarN, in four places. ― -b2- Also The wood of a well, (S, K, KL,) by means of which the bucket is drawn out therefrom: (KL:) pl. XujurN: (S:) this pl. occurs in a verse, accord. to J; but the right reading in that instance is sujul, as is shown by the rhyme of the poem. (Sgh, TA.) ― -b3- Also [A wooden bar of a door;] a piece of wood which is put behind a door; called in Pers. mataros, (S, K, TA,) written by Az matRaros. (TA.) ― -b4- And A piece of wood with which a couch-frame (sariyr) is repaired, by its being affixed as a DabRap [q. v.], (S, K,) beneath it. (S.) ― -b5- And A piece of wood which is put in the mouth of a kid, to prevent its sucking. (TS, K.) ― -b6- And A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon camels. (S, K.)

waAdK XajiyrN c
waAdK XajiyrN, and OaXojaru↓, (K,) or the former, (S, A,) but not the latter, (S,) and muXojirN↓; (K;) and OaroDN XajiyrapN, (S, TA,) and XajirapN↓, (A, K,) and XajoraMCu↓, (S, Msb, K,) and maXojarapN↓; (AHn, S, * K;) A valley, and a land, abounding with Xajar or OaXojaAr [i. e. trees, or shrubs]. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- XajiyrN also signifies Strange, or a stranger; applied to a man, (S, A, K,) and to a camel. (S, K.) ― -b3- And An arrow that is used in the game called Almayosir, thrown among arrows not from its kind of tree: (S, K:) or one that is borrowed, and from the winning of which [on former occasions] one augurs good. (TA.) ― -b4- Also Bad, corrupt, or disapproved. (Kr, K.) ― -b5- And A companion: (M, K:) or a friend: (A:) pl. XujaraMCu. (M, TA.) ― -b6- And A sword. (K.)

XajaArapN c
XajaArapN: see miXojarN.

XawaAjiru c
XawaAjiru [pl. of XaAjirapN fem. of XaAjirN]: see muXotajirN. ― -b2- Also Withholding, or debarring, and diverting, things. (TA.) You say, XajaratoniI Eanohu XawaAjiru [Withholding, or debarring, or diverting, things withheld, or debarred, or diverted, me from it]. (S.)

OaXojaru c
OaXojaru; and its fem., XajoraMCu: see XajiyrN. ― -b2- Also (K) Containing more Xajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]: (S, K:) so in the saying, hecihi AlOaroDu OaXojaru mino hecihi [This land is one containing more trees than this]. (S, K. *) It has no known verb. (TA.)

maXojarN c
maXojarN (S, K, TA) [and] maXojarapN↓ (Mgh, Msb) A place (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of growth (Mgh, K) of Xajar or OaXojaAr [i. e. trees, or shrubs]: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or, as some say, the former signifies many Xajar. (TA.) ― -b2- The former also signifies A place of muXaAjarap [i. e. contending, disputing, or litigating]: pl. maXaAjiru: and, some say, it is an inf. n. (Har p. 473.) ― -b3- See also miXojarN, in two places.

muXojirN c
muXojirN: see XajiyrN. ― -b2- You say also OaroDN muXojirapN meaning A land giving growth to Xajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]. (TA. [See also maXojarN.])

miXojarN c
miXojarN i. q. miXojabN [i. e. A thing composed of pieces of wood, or sticks, the heads of which are bound together, and the feet parted asunder, upon which clothes &c. are put]: (S:) or pieces of wood, or sticks, tied together, like the miXojab, upon which articles of furniture, or utensils, are put: (M, Msb:) pl. maXaAjiru. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (M,) The wood, (K,) or pieces of wood, (M,) of the [kind of camel-vehicle for women called] hawodaj; (M, K;) as also maXojarN↓ and XijaArN↓ and XajaArN↓: (L, K:) n. un. maXojarapN and XajaArapN↓: (TA:) or a vehicle used by women, smaller than the hawodaj, having the head uncovered; (AA, K, * TA;) as also maXojarN↓ and XijaArN↓ and XajaArN↓: (K:) accord. to Lth, XijaArN↓ signifies the wood [or frame-work] of the hwdj, which when covered becomes a hwdj: (TA:) As
says that maXaAjiru signifies the pieces of wood of a hwdj: AA, that it signifies vehicles smaller than hawaAdij, having the heads uncovered; also called sujurN, of which the sing. is XijaArN↓. (S.)

maXojarapN c
maXojarapN: see XajiyrN: ― -b2- and see also maXojarN.

muXajRarN c
muXajRarN Figured work (TA) having the form of Xajar [i. e. trees, or shrubs]: (K, * TA:) and silk brocade (diybaAj) figured with the forms of Xajar. (S, K.)

muXotajaru AlrRimaAHi c
muXotajaru AlrRimaAHi [The place of the commingling of spears; or of the thrusting, or piercing, therewith]. (Ham p. 161.)

muXotajirN c
muXotajirN and mutaXaAjirN↓ Commingled [and confused]: you say rimaAHN muXotajierapN and mutaXaAjirapN↓ and XawaAjiru↓ Spears commingled and confused. (TA.)

mutaXaAjirN c
mutaXaAjirN: see what next precedes, in two places.

1 XajuEa c
1. XajuEa, aor.
XajuEa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. XajaAEapN, (S, Msb,) He (a man, S) was, or became, courageous, brave, valiant, bold, daring, or stronghearted (S, Msb, K) on the occasion of war, or fight, (S, K,) making light of wars, by reason of his boldness. (Msb.) AZ says that sajaAEapN sometimes denotes a comparative quality in relation to him who is weaker than the person to whom it is ascribed. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- XajaEahu, aor.
XajaEa
, [which in this case is contr. to the general rule, notwithstanding the guttural letter, for by rule it should be
XajuEa
,] He overcame him, or surpassed him, in XajaAEap [or courage, &c.]. (K.) [See 3.] ＝ -A3- XajiEa, aor.
XajaEa
, (Msb,) inf. n. XajaEN, (IDrd, Msb, K,) He was, or became, tall. (IDrd, Msb, K.)

2 XjREhu c
2. XjREhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taXojiyEN, (K,) He encouraged him; or strengthened his heart; (S, K;) and emboldened him: (K:) or he said to him, Thou art XujaAE [or courageous, &c.]. (Sb, S, K.)

3 XaAjaEotuhu faXajaEotuhu c
3. XaAjaEotuhu faXajaEotuhu [I strove to overcome or surpass him, or contended with him for superiority, in XajaAEap (or courage, &c.), and] I overcame him, or surpassed him, therein. (TA.)

4 maA OaXojaEahu c
4. maA OaXojaEahu [How courageous, brave, valiant, bold, daring, or strong-hearted, is he, on the occasion of war, or fight!]. (TA in art bsl.)

5 tXjRE c
5. tXjRE He affected (takalRafa) courage, bravery, valour, boldness, daringness, or strength of heart on the occasion of war, or fight; (S, K;) [he encouraged himself; made himself, or constrained himself to be, courageous:] and he feigned, or pretended to have, courage, &c., on the occasion of war, or fight, not having it in him. (TA.)

XajaEN c
XajaEN Penetrating energy; boldness. (As.) ― -b2- Quickness of the shifting of the legs, in camels, (S, K,) or, accord. to IB, in horses. (TA.)

XajiEN c
XajiEN; fem. with p: see XujaAEN, in three places. ― -b2- XajiEu AlqawaAYimi Quick in the shifting of the legs, applied to a he-camel; and so XajiEapN and XajoEaMCu↓, applied to a she-camel. (S, K.) And qawaAYimu XajiEaAtN Quick, and light, active, or nimble, legs. (TA.) ― -b3- Mad, applied to a camel. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

XijaEN c
XijaEN: see XujaAEN.

XajoEapN c
XajoEapN: see XujaAEN: ＝ -A2- see also XujoEapN: ― -b2- also Tall, and uncompact in frame: ― -b3- and crippled by disease; or having a protracted disease: [whence] it is said in a prov., OaEomaI yaquwdu XajoEapF [A blind man leading one crippled by disease, or having a protracted disease: but in Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 119, the last word is written XajaEap, and said to be pl. of XaAjiEN↓, and to signify, app., suffering paralysis]. (TA.)

XujoEapN c
XujoEapN: see XujaAEN. ＝ -A2- Also Cowardly, weak, (Ibn-'Abbád,) lacking strength or power or ability, lean, or emaciated, and small in body, having no heart; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) as also XajoEapN↓: (Lh, K:) the former seems to have the meaning of a pass. part. n., [i. e. of maXojuwEN, q. v.,] like suxorapN and other words. (Ibn-'Abbád.)

XijaEapN c
XijaEapN: see XujaAEN.

XajaEaMCu c
XajaEaMCu [or XijaEaMCu or XajoEaMCu]: see XujaAEN.

XajoEamN c
XajoEamN A bulky serpent: or a malignant and audacious serpent: regarded by Sb as a quadriliteral-radical word. (TA.) [See also XujaAEN.]

XajaAEN c
XajaAEN: see what next follows.

XujaAEN c
XujaAEN and XijaAEN↓ (Lh, ISk, S, Msb, K) and XajaAEN↓, (Msb, K,) which is of the dial, of Benoo- 'Okeyl, being made by them to accord with its contr., which is jabaAnN, (Msb,) and XajiyEN↓ (Lh, S, Msb, K) and OaXojaEu↓ (S, K) and XajiEN↓ (K) and XijaEN↓, (as in some copies of the K,) or XijaEapN↓, (as in other copies of the K and in the TA,) [of all which forms the first is the most common,] Courageous, brave, valiant, bold, daring, or strong-hearted (S, Msb, K) on the occasion of war, or fight, (S, K,) making light of wars, by reason of boldness: (Msb:) fem. [of the 1st and 2nd and 3rd respectively] XujaAEapN and XijaAEapN (S, * Msb, * K) and XajaAEapN (Msb, * K) and XjAE also [without p] (Msb) and [of the 4th] XajiyEapN↓ (Msb, K) and [of the 5th] XajoEaMCu↓ and [of the 6th] XajiEapN↓: (K:) pl. masc. (of the 1st, S, Msb) XijoEapN [a pl. of pauc.] (AO, S, Msb, K) and [of the first three, and perhaps of the 4th also,] XajaEapN (S, K) and (of the 1st, S) XijoEaAnN (Lh, S, K) and (of the 4th, S) XujoEaAnN (Lh, ISk, S, K) [or, accord. to IDrd, XjEAn is a mistake, as is said in the TA, but the word is there written without any syll. signs,] and (of the 4th, S, Msb) XujaEaMCu↓ (S, Msb, K) and [of the 4th, and perhaps of others also,] XijaAEN, (K,) and also, (but these are quasi-pl. ns., TA,) XajoEapN↓ (AO, S, K) and XujoEapN↓ (K) and XajaEaMCu↓ [app. a mistake for XijaEaMCu or XajoEaMCu]: (TA:) pl. fem. [all of XajiyEapN, or the last of XajoEaMCu or of XajiEapN,] XajaAYiEu and XijaAEN and XujuEN: (Lh, K:) or XujaAEN is [an epithet] peculiar to men: (K, * TA:) AZ says, “ I have heard the Kilábees say, rajulN XujaAEN, but they do not apply this epithet to a woman: ” (S:) XajiEapN↓ and XajiyEapN↓, however, are applied to a woman, and signify bold, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) longtongued, and vehemently clamorous, towards men; (Ibn-'Abbád, TA;) audacious in her speech, (Ibn- 'Abbád, K, [but these two epithets as applied to a woman and signifying “ bold ” &c. are omitted in the CK,]) and in her length of tongue, and vehement clamorousness. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b2- XujaAEN (S, Msb, K) and XijaAEN↓ (K) also signify (assumed tropical:) The serpent; (K;) and so does OaXojaEu↓: (TA:) or (tropical:) the male serpent: (Mgh, K:) or a certain species of serpent, (Sh, S, Msb, K,) as also OaXojaEu↓, (S,) small, (K,) or slender, and asserted to be the boldest of the serpent-kind: (Sh:) pl. XijoEaAnN (Lh, IDrd, K) and XujoEaAnN, (IDrd, K,) the former of which is the more common: (IDrd:) the pl. of OaXojaEu is OaXaAjiEu; or, as some say, this is pl. of OaXojiEapN, which is pl. [of pauc.] of XjAE, signifying the serpent. (TA.) [See also XajoEamN, above.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) The serpent called SafarN, that presents itself in the belly (S, K, * TA) of a man, as the Arabs assert, when he has been long hungry: (S, TA:) but As says that XujaAEu AlbaToni signifies (assumed tropical:) vehemence of hunger. (Az, TA.)

XijaAEN c
XijaAEN: see XujaAEN, in two places.

XajiyEN c
XajiyEN; fem. with p: see XujaAEN, in three places.

XaAjiEN c
XaAjiEN: see XajoEapN.

OaXojaEu c
OaXojaEu; fem. XajoEaMCu: see XujaAEN, in four places. You say also, labuWapN XajoEaMCu A bold lioness. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, accord. to some, it signifies, (S,) or it signifies also, (K,) In whom is lightness, or unsteadiness, like what is termed hawajN, (S, K,) by reason of his strength. (S.) See also XajiEN. ― -b3- Mad; or possessed by a devil: (TA:) Lth says that, applied to a man, it signifies one who is as though there were in him madness, or diabolical possession; but Az says that this is a mistake; for, were this its meaning, the poets would not have used it in praise. (TA, in another part of the art.) ― -b4- Tall: (IDrd, Msb, K:) and so the fem. applied to a woman. (IDrd, Msb.) ― -b5- Bulky; big-bodied; or stout: or, as some say, youthful; or in a state of youthful vigour. (TA.) ― -b6- The lion. (Lth, S, K.) ― -b7- It is said in the K that AlOaXojaEu also signifies AldRahoru [i. e. Time; or fortune; &c.]; and J says that this is what the poet means by the expression, OaXojaEu OaxRaAcN: but this cannot be the correct meaning, for the poet, namely El-Aashà, says,
biOaXojaEa OaxRaAcK EalaI AldRahori Hukomuhu
by AlAXjE meaning himself, or some other thing. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) and UiXojaEN, (K,) or the latter accord. to some, but this was not known to Abu-l-Ghowth, (S,) sing. of OaXaAjiEu, [in some copies of the S written OaXaAjiyEu, but the former, which, as is mentioned in the TA, is found in the
handwriting of J, is that which is commonly known,] which signifies [The knuckles nearest to the wrist; this being what is meant by] the bases (OuSuwl) of the fingers, which are connected with the tendons of the outer side of the hand: (S, K:) in the T, we find the heads (ruWuws) of the fingers, instead of ASwl: (TA:) or AXjE in the hand and foot [but see what follows] signifies the tendons extended above the sulaAmaI [here meaning the metacarpal and metatarsal bones] from the wrist to the bases (OuSuwl) of the fingers or toes, which are called OaTonaAbu AlOaSaAbiEi, above the outer side of the hand: or the bone which connects the finger with the wrist; [i. e. the metacarpal bone;] every finger having to it a bone thus called: he who says that the OaXaAjiE [so here instead of AXjE as above] are the tendons calls those bones the OusonaAE. (TA.) Aboo-Bekr is described as EaAriI AlOaXaAjiEi Eano mafaASili AlOaSaAbiEi, meaning Having little flesh upon what are thus termed: or having their tendons apparent. (TA.) [See also raAjibapN and burojumapN.] ＝ -A3- OaXojaEu mino diykK [More courageous than a cock] is one of the proverbs of the Arabs. (Mgh.)

muXojaEN c
muXojaEN, like mujomalN, (K, TA,) i. e. having the form of a pass. part. n., (TA,) [in the CK maXojaE, like maHomal,] In the utmost state of madness, or diabolical possession: (K:) so says Ibn-Abbád; and hence, accord. to him, XujaAEN [but in what sense he does not say]. (TA.)

maXojuwEN c
maXojuwEN Overcome, or surpassed, in XajaAEap [or courage, &c.]. (K, TA.)

1 Xajina c
1. Xajina, (S, L, K,) aor.
Xajana
; (K;) and Xajuna, aor.
Xajuna
; inf. n. [of the former] XajanN [in some copies of the K XajonN] and [of the latter, or of both,] XajuwnN; (L, K;) He grieved, mourned, or lamented; or was sorrowful, sad, or unhappy; (S, L, K;) and was anxious: and tXjRn↓ signifies the same: (L:) or this last signifies, (K,) or, as Lth says, it seems to signify, (L,) he remembered; syn. tacakRara. (L, K.) And Xjnt AlHamaAmapu, [app. both Xajinat and Xajunat,] inf. n. XujuwnN, The pigeon cooed in a wailing and plaintive manner. (L.) [See also XajanN below.] ＝ -A2- Xajanahu, (S, L, K,) [aor.
Xajuna
, accord. to the usual rule of the K,] inf. n. XajonN and XujuwnN, (L, K,) signifies the same as AXjnhu↓, (S, L, K,) i. e. He, (another person, S,) or it, (an affair, or an event, or a case, L, K,) caused him to grieve or mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy. (S, L, K.) ＝ -A3- XajanatoniI AlHaAjapu, (S, L,) and Xajanatohu, (L, K,) aor.
Xajuna
, inf. n. XajonN, (S, L,) Want, or the want, detained, or withheld, (S, L, K,) me, (S, L,) or him. (L, K.) And maA Xajanaka EanRaA What detained, or withheld, thee from us? (L.)

4 AXjnhu c
4. AXjnhu: see the preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- AXjn Alkaromu The grape-vine had a branchlet of a bunch of which all the grapes came to maturity. (L, K. [See XijonapN.])

5 taXajRana
5: see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- tXjRn AlXRajaru The trees were, or became, tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense. (L, K.)

XajonN c
XajonN (S, L, K [in the CK XajanN, but expressly said in the S to be biAltRasokiyni]) A road of a valley; (S, L;) or a road in a valley: or in the upper, or uppermost, part thereof: as also XaAjinapN↓: (K:) pl. of the former XujuwnN: (S, L, K:) and of XawaAjinu↓: (K:) or XaAjinapN↓ signifies a valley in which are many trees; (S, L;) or a place in which are Xujuwn, which means tangled trees; (Ham pp. 761-2;) and XawaAjinu is its pl.: (S, L, and Ham p. 762:) or XaAjinapN↓ signifies a sort of valley producing good herbage: or, as some say, XawaAjinu signifies the upper, or uppermost, parts of a valley; and its sing. is XajanN↓ [thus written in the L in this instance], as ISd mentions on the authority of A'Obeyd, but adding that, as such, it is irregular, and that it is more properly to be regarded as pl. of XaAjinapN↓. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, AlHadiyvu cuw XujuwnK, (S, Meyd, L, K,) Xujuwn being pl. of XajonN, with the j quiescent; (Meyd;) a prov., (Meyd, L,) meaning (assumed tropical:) The story is involved, or intricate; (S, Meyd, L;) or has several ways [in which it may be understood]; (Meyd;) or has several modes, or manners; and objects of aim: (L, K:) applied to a story by which one calls to mind another: (A'Obeyd, Meyd, L:) the first who said it was Dabbeh Ibn-Udd Ibn-Tábikhah: he had two sons, named Saad and So'eyd: and some camels belonging to him ran away by night, so he sent his two sons to seek them; and they separated; and Saad found them and restored them; but So'eyd went on seeking them; and El-Hárith Ibn-Kaab met him; and there were upon the young man two [garments such as are called] burds (burodaAni), which El-Hárith asked him to give to him, but he refused to comply with his desire; whereupon he slew him, and took his two burds: and Dabbeh, when he saw a dark object in the night, used to say, OasaEodN Oamo suEayodN [“ Is it Saad or So'eyd? ” (see saEodN)]; and this saying of his became current as a prov.: some time after this, having gone on pilgrimage, he met El- Hárith Ibn-Kaab at 'Okádh, and saw upon him the two burds of his son So'eyd, and asked him respecting them; and he answered that he had met a young man wearing them, and slain him, and taken them: Dabbeh said, “ With this thy sword? ” and he answered, “ Yes: ” and he said, “ Give it me that I may look at it, for I think it to be sharp: ” and El-Hárith gave it him: and he took it, and shook it, and said, UinRa AlHadiyva cuw XujuwnK; and slew him with it: whereupon it was said to him, “ O Dabbeh, in the sacred month? ” and he said, sabaqa AlsRayofu AlEacola [“ The sword preceded the censure ”): these three provs. he originated. (Meyd.)

XujonN c
XujonN and XijonN: see the next paragraph.

XajanN c
XajanN Grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness; (S, L, K;) and anxiety: (L, K:) pl. OaXojaAnN (S, L, K) and XujuwnN; (L, K; [in the latter of which these pls. are mentioned after all the explanations of the sing.;]) the former a pl. of pauc., and the latter of mult. (Ham p. 404.) [See a verse cited voce EaraDN, in which it means A cause of anxiety.] ― -b2- And The soul's love, or its inclination, or its blamable inclination: (L:) [or] love that is followed by anxiety and grief. (Kull p. 165.) ― -b3- And A want, (S, L, Msb, K,) as also XajiynN↓, (L,) wherever it be: (S, L, K:) pl. XujuwnN (S, L, Msb, K) and OaXojaAnN; (L, Msb, K;) the latter being pl. of XajiynN also. (L.) A rájiz says,
liI XajanaAni XajanN binajodi
waXajanN liI bibilaAdi AlsRinodi
[I have two wants; a want in Nejd, and I have a want in the country of Es-Sind]. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also An intricately-intermingling branch of a tree; (L, K;) and a XuEobap [i. e. branch, or branchlet, or the like,] of anything; (K;) like XijonapN↓ and XujonapN↓ and XajonapN↓ (L, K) in the former sense: (L: [accord. to the K, app., in the latter sense:]) or, accord. to IAar, one says XujonapN↓ and XujonN↓ meaning a branch of a tree, [or the latter app. means branches, for it seems to be a coll. gen. n.,] and XijonapN↓ and XijonN↓, and [the pl. of XujonapN↓ is] XujonaAtN and XujunaAtN: (L:) or, accord. to J, (L,) XijonapN↓ and XujonapN↓ signify roots of trees intricately intermingling: (S, L:) [but] the primary signification of XijonapN↓ and XujonapN↓ is a branchlet (a XuEobap of a guSon) of a tree: (L:) or XijonapN↓ signifies tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also XijonapN. ― -b3- And see XajonN. ― -b4- Also, (K,) or Xjnp, (L, [thus written without any syll. signs, perhaps fem. of XajanN, i. e. XajanapN, but it seems to be indicated by the context in the L that it is XujonapN↓,]) A she-camel compact in make, of which the several parts are interknit, one with another, (L, K, *) like the parts of a tree. (L.)

XajonapN c
XajonapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XujonapN c
XujonapN: see XajanN, in six places: and XijonapN. ＝ -A2- Also, as some say, Leanness; or slenderness, and leanness; or leanness, and lankness in the belly. (L.)

XijonapN c
XijonapN: see XajanN, in five places. ― -b2- Also, i. e. with kesr, (K,) or XajanN↓ and XajanapN↓, (L,) A branchlet of a bunch of a grape-vine of which all the grapes come to maturity. (L, K.) ― -b3- XijonapN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Relationship closely, or intimately, connected. (L.) One says, bayoniI wabayonahu Xijonapu raHimK, and raHimK Xujonapu↓, (assumed tropical:) Between me and him is a relationship closely, or intimately, connected. (S.) And it is said in a trad., AlrRaHimu XijonapN mina QllRehi i. e. (tropical:) AlrRaHimu is derived from AlrRaHomen: (S, L: [see raHimN:]) or, accord. to AO, (L,) the meaning is, [AlrRaHim is] relationship, from God, closely, or intimately, connected, like the roots of trees. (S, L.) ― -b4- Also A crack, or cleft, in a mountain. (Lh, L, K.)

XajanapN c
XajanapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

Xajuwnu c
Xajuwnu XaAjinatiI↓ is a saying of the Arabs like their saying EaAbilatiI Eabuwlu [i. e., app., My withholder is death, or shall be death alone; for Xajanatohu Xajuwnu may be rendered Death withheld him, like as Eabalatohu Eabuwlu is rendered “ death separated him ”]. (L.)

XajiynN c
XajiynN: see XajanN.

XaAjinN c
XaAjinN Grieving, mourning, or lamenting; or sorrowful, sad, or unhappy; (S, L;) and anxious. (L.) ＝ -A2- See also an ex. of its fem., with p, voce Xajuwnu.

XaAjinapN c
XaAjinapN [as a subst.]; pl. XawaAjinu: see XajonN, in five places.

1 XajiIa c
1. XajiIa, aor.
Xajawa
, inf. n. XajFA, He was choked; or his throat, or fauces, became obstructed; (S, K;) bihi by it; i. e. a bone or the like. (K.) One says, Ealayoka biAlkaZomi walawo Xajiyta biAlEaZomi [Keep thou to self-restraint though thou be choked by the bone]. (TA.) ― -b2- And, [hence, by a metaphor, (see Har p. 33,)] aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He grieved, mourned, or lamented; or was sorrowful, sad, or unhappy: (S, Msb:) and he was, or became, anxious, or disquieted in mind. (S.) ― -b3- Also, aor. and inf. n. as above, said of a creditor (gariym), He went away, Eanohu [from him]. (K. [See 4.]) ＝ -A2- XajaA bayonahumo It was, or became, an occasion of contention, or dispute, or of disagreement, or difference, between them. (K.) ＝ -A3- XajaAhu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Xajuwa
, inf. n. XajowN, (S, Msb,) [app. originally syn. with OaXojaAhu in the first of the senses assigned to the latter in the next paragraph: ― -b2- and hence,] (assumed tropical:) It (anxiety, Msb) grieved him; or caused him to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy; (S, Msb, K;) as also AXjAhu↓. (K.) And, said of wealth (AlginaI), inf. n. XajowN, It excited his griefs, mournings, &c., and his desire. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, and AXjAhu↓, (assumed tropical:) It caused him to be mirthful, (Ks, K, TA,) and excited him. (Ks, TA.) Thus each of these verbs has two contr. significations. (K.) But MF observes that TarRabahu, the explanation here given in the K, is said by the author of the K [in art. Trb] to denote a lightness arising from joy or grief. (TA.) [Generally, however, it means as rendered above.]

4 AXjAhu c
4. AXjAhu, inf. n. UiXojaMCN, It choked him; or caused his throat, or fauces, to be obstructed; syn. OagaSRahu; (S, TA;) said of a bone lying across in the throat, or fauces. (TA.) [This is clearly shown to be the meaning in the S, as well as in the TA, intended by OagaSRahu; with which it is also syn. in another sense; for] ― -b2- It signifies [also] (assumed tropical:) It, or he, caused him to fall into grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness. (K.) See also 1, in two places. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) He subdued, overpowered, or overcame, him, (K, TA,) so that he grieved, or was sorrowful. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) He angered him. (Ks, TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) He made him to go away. (Az, TA.) And OaXojayotuhu EanRiI (assumed tropical:) I gave him (i. e. a creditor or petitioner) what contented him, so that he went away. (TA.)

6 taXaAjato Ealayohi c
6. taXaAjato Ealayohi, (As, T, K, * TA,) said of a woman of the desert with reference to a young man who had been dallying, and holding amorous converse, with her, (As, T, TA,) (assumed tropical:) She resisted him, and expressed grief, or unhappiness, to him, or on account of him, [i. e. on account of his advances,] saying, Alas, my grief, or my unhappiness! (As, T, K, * TA.) And said of a woman with reference to her husband, meaning (assumed tropical:) She expressed grief, &c., as above. (A, TA.)

XajFA c
XajFA A bone, or some other thing (S, K) of the like sort, (K,) sticking fast, (S,) or lying across, or forming an obstruction, (K,) in the throat, or fauces, (S, K,) of a human being, and of a beast; (TA;) a thing in the throat, or fauces, that [chokes one, or] prevents from swallowing: (Har p. 69:) an inf. n. used as a subst. [properly thus termed]. (Har p. 33.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

XajowN c
XajowN (assumed tropical:) Anxiety, or disquietude of mind; and grief, mourning, lamentation, sorrow, sadness, or unhappiness; (S;) [and] so XajFA↓: thus termed because a man is choked thereby. (Har p. 33.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A want; an object of want. (Az, K, TA.) One says, bakaI fulaAnN Xajowahu [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one wept for his object of want]: and daEati AlHamaAmapu XajowahaA [app. (assumed tropical:) The pigeon called for its object of want]. (TA.)

XajK c
XajK (assumed tropical:) Grieving, mourning, or lamenting; or sorrowing, sad, or unhappy; applied to a man; (S, Msb;) and XajiyapN, of the measure faEilapN, applied to a woman: one says, wayolN lilXRajiI mina AlxaliIRi [mentioned and expl. voce xaAlK, in art. xlw, where each of these epithets is written with teshdeed to the I; and likewise in another saying there mentioned]: (S:) or, in this saying, (TA,) it signifies occupied [by anxiety or grief]; (K, TA; [in the CK, AlXRajA is erroneously put for AlXRajiI;]) and xaliIR means “ free [therefrom]: ” so says AZ: and in this instance AlXRajiI may mean occupied by a bone choking, or obstructing, his throat, or fauces, or by anxiety, and not having found a way of escape therefrom; or by his opponent, or adversary, whom he has been unable to withstand: (TA:) and sometimes one says XajiIRN↓, like as one says HazinN and HaziynN; though this is rare; (Msb;) it is mentioned in the 'Eyn; but XajK is more known; and is said by Az to be the chaste form: (TA:) Mbr says, the I of AlxlI is with teshdeed, and the I of AlXRajiI is without teshdeed, (S,) and sometimes this I is with teshdeed in poetry; (S, K;) but if you make it to be from XajaAhu, it is XajiIRN↓ only, syn. with maXojuwRN. [i. e. grieved, &c.]; (S;) and so it is said to be by Az and Z: and Az adds, the second way of accounting for it is, that they often lengthen faEilN with a I, saying, fulaAnN qaminN likacaA and qamiynN, and samijN and samiyjN, and karK and kariIRN: and the third way is, that they assimilated one word in measure to another, as in AlgadaAyaA waAlEaXaAyaA, the [proper] pl. of gadaApN being only gadawaAtN. (TA.)

XajiIRN c
XajiIRN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

mafaAzapN XajowaMCu c
mafaAzapN XajowaMCu [A desert, or waterless desert,] difficult to travel. (S, K. *)

XajawiIRN c
XajawiIRN, with fet-h to the j; rel. n. of XajK. (S.)

XajawojFI c
XajawojFI, (S, K,) of the measure faEawoEalN [and therefore with tenween], (Mz 40th nwE, and MF and TA,) like xajawojFI &c., (S, * and Mz ibid.,) and XajawojaMCN↓, (K,) applied to a man, (S,) Long in the legs: (S, K:) or very tall: or very tall, with bigness (Dixam, in the CK Daxom,) of the bones: or long in the back, short in the leg; (K;) thus in the M; but Az says the reverse, i. e. long in the legs, short in the back. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or the former, (TA,) A bulky horse. (K.) ― -b3- And The EaqoEaq [or magpie]; (K;) [and] so XajajaI; (K and TA in art. Xj;) fem. with p [i. e. XajawojaApN]. (K.) ― -b4- And A wind continually blowing; as also XajawojaApN. (K.) All this is in the M. (TA.)

XajawojaMCN c
XajawojaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph.

OamorN XaAjK c
OamorN XaAjK An affair, or event, grieving; or causing to mourn or lament, or to be sorrowful or sad or unhappy. (TA.)

1 XaHRa c
1. XaHRa, (Msb,) sec. pers. XaHaHota, aor. yaXuHRu and yaXiHRu, (S, O, Msb, K,) the latter of these aors. agreeable with analogy as the verb is intrans., and the former deviating therefrom; (MF;) and sec. pers. XaHiHota, aor. yaXaHRu; (S, O, Msb, K;) [the first of which, having for its aor. yaXuHRu, is the most common;] inf. n. XuHRN (S, A, O, Msb, K) and XiHRN and XaHRN, (ISk, O, K,) of which three inf. ns. the first is the most approved; (TA;) He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious; syn. yaxila: (Msb:) or bxl relates to single things, or particulars; and XHR, to things in general: or bxl relates to wealth, or property; and XHR, to wealth, or property, and to kindness, or beneficence: or XHR, signifies he was, or became, niggardly, &c., as above, in the utmost degree: (TA:) or he was, or became, niggardly, &c., as above, (S, A, O, K,) and covetous, or vehemently or greedily or excessively or culpably desirous, (K,) or with covetousness, or vehement or greedy or excessive or culpable desire. (S, A, O.) You say, XaHRa bihi and XaHRa Ealayohi; (T, M, K;) by the former meaning He was, or became, niggardly, &c., of it, i. e., of his property, or the like; and by the latter, he was, or became, niggardly, &c., to him, i. e., to an asker, or a beggar, or a seeker, or the like: (MF:) or [in some cases, as will be seen from phrases mentioned below, (see XaHiyHN,)] meaning by the latter the same as by the former. (L.) [Thus] one says, huwa yaXuHRu bimaAlihi [He is niggardly, &c., of his property; and sometimes, in the same sense, yaXuHRu EalaI maAlihi]. (A.) And XaHRa baEoDuhumo
EalaI baEoDK [Some of them were niggardly, &c., to some; meaning they were niggardly, &c., one to another]. (Msb, K.)

3 huwa yuXaAHRuniI bikacaA c
3. huwa yuXaAHRuniI bikacaA [He is niggardly, tenacious, &c., as above, with me, of such a thing]. (A.) [The inf. n.] muXaAHRapN [in the CK erroneously written maXAHRap] is syn. with DinRapN: (K, TA:) hence the saying, laA muXaAHRapa fiI AlAiSoTilaAHi [There shall be no acting in a niggardly manner, of one with another, in the making of peace, one with another]. (TA.) And one says, fulaAnN yuXaAHRu EalaI fulaAnK Such a one is tenacious of such a one; syn. yaDanRu bihi. (S, L.)

6 tXAHR Alqawomu c
6. tXAHR Alqawomu The people, or party, were niggardly, tenacious, &c., as above, [see 1,] one to another, (Msb, K, TA,) fiI AlOamori [in the affair], (K, TA,) and Ealayohi [for it], (TA,) and vied in hastening to it, (TA,) fearing lest it should become unattainable. (K, TA.) And taXaAHRaA EalaI AlOamori laA yuriydaAni Oano yafuwtahumaA (S, O, K, TA) They two (i. e. two men, S, O) contended together for the thing, or affair, each of them being unwilling that it should become beyond his reach, or attainment. (TA.) And taXaAHaHaA AlmaMCa [or taXaAHRaAhu] i. q. tajaAXaEaAhu [i. e. They straitened each other in pressing to the water, and vied, each with the other, in endeavouring to satisfy their thirst]. (TA in art. jXE.)

R. Q. 1
R. Q. 1: XaHoXaHapN [inf. n. of XaHoXaHa] The being cautious, wary, or vigilant; or fearing. (O, K.) ― -b2- The crying of the [bird called] Surad. (K.) You say, XaHoXaHa AlSRuradu The Srd uttered its cry. (O, TA.) ― -b3- The camel's reiterating of his voice, [or his being not clear, or his being sparing,] in his braying. (K.) You say of the camel, XaHoXaHa fiI hadiyrihi [He reiterated his voice, or] he was not clear, (S,) or he was sparing, (L,) in his braying. (S, L.) ― -b4- And The flying swiftly. (S, K.)

nafosN XaHRapN c
nafosN XaHRapN: see XaHiyHN.

OawoSaI fiI SiHRatihi waXiHRatihi c
OawoSaI fiI SiHRatihi waXiHRatihi means [He made his will during his state of soundness, or health, and] in his state of which he is tenacious [or the state which he is reluctant to quit] (fiI HaAlihi AlRatiI yaXuHRu EalayohaA). (O, K.)

XaHaAHN c
XaHaAHN: see the next paragraph in four places.

XaHiyHN c
XaHiyHN (S, A, Msb, K) and XaHaAHN↓ (S, A, K) and XaHoXaHN↓ and XaHoXaAHN↓ and XaHoXaHaAnN↓, (K,) applied to a man, Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious: (Msb:) or niggardly, &c., as above, in the utmost degree: (TA:) or niggardly, &c., as above, (S, A, K,) and covetous, or vehemently or greedily or excessively or culpably desirous, (K,) or with covetousness, or vehement or greedy or excessive or culpable desire: (S, A:) and nafosN XaHRapN↓ signifies the same as XaHiyHapN [a soul that is niggardly, &c.]: (IAar, TA:) the pl. (of XaHiyHN, S, Msb) is OaXiHRapN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, A, Msb, K) and XiHaAHN (S, A, K) and OaXiHRaMCu. (Msb, K.) You say, [huwa XaHiyHN biXaIoCK and] XaHiyHN EalaI XaIoCK He is niggardly, &c., of a thing. (L in art. Xd.) OaXiHRapF EalaI Alxayori, in the Kur [xxxiii. 19], means [They being niggardly, or vehemently desirous, of the good things, i. e.] of the wealth and spoils: (TA:) and OaXiHRapN Ealayokumo, in the same verse, means [They being niggardly] of aid [to you]. (Jel.) ― -b2- [Hence,] UibilN XaHaAYiHu, [in which the latter word is pl. of XaHiyHapN,] (O, K,) or XiHaAHN, (A,) (tropical:) Camels that yield little milk. (A, O, K, TA.) And zanodN XaHaAHN↓ (tropical:) A piece of stick, or wood, for producing fire, that does not yield fire. (S, A, K.) And maMCN XaHaAHN↓ (assumed tropical:) Water little in quantity; not copious. (K.) And OaroDN XaHaAHN↓ (assumed tropical:) Land that will not flow with water unless in consequence of much rain; (S, O, K;) as also XaHoXaHN↓: (O, K:) and also, (ISk, L, TA,) or ↓the latter word, (so accord. to the K,) (assumed tropical:) Land that flows in consequence of the least rain; (ISk, K, TA;) as though it were niggardly of itself to the water: (TA;) like HaXaAdN [in this, or in the former, sense]: (ISk, L:) thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) And accord. to AHn, XiHaAHN signifies (assumed tropical:) [Small water-courses such as are termed] XiEaAb any one of which is made to flow if a skinful of water is poured into it. (TA.)

XaHoXaHN c
XaHoXaHN: see XaHiyHN, in three places. ― -b2- Also Evil in disposition; (O, K;) and so XaHoXaAHN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- Very jealous; (Fr, S, O, K;) as also XaHoXaAHN↓ and XaHoXaHaAnN↓. (Fr, O, K.) ― -b4- Courageous; (S, K;) and so XaHoXaAHN↓. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, (S, O, K, TA,) applied alike to a male and to a female, (TA,) and XaHoXaAHN↓, (K, TA,) or XaHoXaHaAnN↓, (S, * O,) One who keeps, attends, or applies himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to a thing: (S, O, K, TA:) who strives, labours, or exerts himself, therein: (TA:) or, as some say, (S, O,) penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, therein: (S, O, TA:) the first, (S, O, K, TA,) and ↓second, (TA,) applied to an orator, or a preacher, (S, O, K, TA,) in this last sense, (S, O, TA,) or as meaning eloquent (K, TA) and powerful: (TA:) and both, as epithets of general application, penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, in speech, or in going or journeying: the first is also applied to an orator, or a preacher, as meaning skilful: (TA:) and ↓the last of these three epithets is applied by Dhu-r-Rummeh to a driver of camels, who urges them by singing to them. (S, O, TA.) ― -b6- Also the first, applied to a raven, or crow, (guraAb,) That croaks much. (O, K.) ― -b7- And Light, or agile; applied to an ass; as also XuHoXuHN↓, (O, K,) as some say. (O.) ― -b8- And Swift in flight; applied to a qaTaAp. (S, O, K.) ― -b9- Also, and XaHoXaHaAnN↓, Tall, or long, (Fr, O, K, TA,) and strong. (TA.) ― -b10- And the former, applied to a [desert such as is termed] falaAp, Wide; (O, K, TA;) in which the places of alighting are far apart, and in which is no herbage. (TA.)

XuHoXuHN c
XuHoXuHN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XaHoXaAHN c
XaHoXaAHN: see XaHiyHN: ― -b2- and see also XaHoXaHN, in five places. ― -b3- Also, applied to a woman, Resembling a man in her strength, (O, K,) and her exertion, or energy. (O.)

XaHoXaHaAnN c
XaHoXaHaAnN: see XaHiyHN: ― -b2- and see also XaHoXaHN, in four places.

muXaHoXaHN c
muXaHoXaHN Niggardly, tenacious, stingy, penurious, or avaricious; [like XaHiyHN;] (TA;) possessing little, or no, good. (O, K, TA.)

1 XaHaba c
1. XaHaba, aor.
XaHuba
(S, A, O, K, &c.) and
XaHaba
, (A, O, K, &c.,) but the former more commonly obtains, (TA,) inf. n. XuHuwbN; (S, O, K;) and XaHuba, (Fr, S, A, O, K, &c.,) inf. n. XuHuwbapN, (Fr, S, O, K,) but this form of the verb is disapproved by AZ and 'Iyád; (TA; [in which, however, nine authorities for it are mentioned;]) said of one's body; (Fr, S, O;) or of one's colour, or complexion, (A, K,) and so XuHiba, (A, O, K,) inf. n. XuHuwbN; (A;) [It was, or became, altered [for the worse, wan, or haggard], (Fr, S, A, O, K, &c.,) in consequence of emaciation, (K,) or hunger, (A, K,) or sleeplessness, and the like, (A,) or travel, (K,) or work, or disease, or impatience, or distress or fatigue: or, accord. to the author of the “ Wá'ee, ” XuHuwbN signifies emaciation itself: (TA:) in this sense, it is of the dial. of Benoo-Kiláb. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- XaHaba AlOaroDa, (IDrd, O, K,) aor.
XaHaba
, inf. n. XaHobN, (IDrd, O,) He pared the ground, or scraped off its superficial part, with a shovel, (IDrd, O, K,) or some other thing: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd, O.)

XaHibN c
XaHibN: see what follows.

XaAHibN c
XaAHibN A man having his colour, or complexion, altered [for the worse, wan, or haggard], (TA,) or so XaAHibu AllRawoni, (A,) in consequence of disease, or travel, or the like: (TA: [see 1:]) and emaciated, or lean; (TA, KL;) as also XaHibN↓. (KL.) It is said in a trad., laA taloqaI AlmuWomina UilRaA XaAHibFA [Thou wilt not find the believer otherwise than wan, or haggard; or emaciated, or lean]; because XuHuwb is one of the effects of fear, and of paucity of food, and of little enjoying of plentifulness and pleasantness or easiness, and softness or delicacy, of life. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also applied as an epithet to a sword, meaning Altered in its colour by blood that has dried upon it: used in this sense by the poet Taäbbata-sharrà. (TA.)

1 XaHaja c
1. XaHaja, aor.
XaHaja
and
XaHija
, inf. n. XaHiyjN (S, O, K) and XuHaAjN (As, S, O, K) and XaHajaAnN (O, K) and taXoHaAjN; (O, L;) and tXHRj↓; and AstXHj↓; (L, TA;) He uttered his voice or cry; [brayed;
croaked;] said of a mule, (S, O, K, &c.,) and of an ass, (ISd, O,) and of a raven, or crow; (S, O, K, &c.;) and sometimes, (tropical:) of a man: (L:) or XaHiyjN is used in relation to a mule; and XaHajaAnN, in relation to a raven, or crow: (T, TA:) or the former of these two signifies the reiterating of the voice or cry of the raven, or crow; and when it stretches forth its head [and croaks], you say naEaba: and accord. to the L, the first and second inf. ns., used in relation to an ass, signify the uttering certain of his voices or cries: Th is thought by ISd to have mentioned also XaHija; but the latter doubts its correctness: and XuHaAjN is also expl. as signifying the raising of the voice; but as used more especially in relation to the mule and the ass. (TA.) XaHaja is also said of a raven, or crow, meaning He, being advanced in age, had a rough, or harsh, voice or cry: (O, K:) [he croaked roughly, or harshly, by reason of age:] it is said in the M that XaHiyjN and XuHaAjN signify the crying of a raven, or crow, when advanced in age. (TA.)

5 taXaHRaja
5: see the preceding paragraph.

10 AstXHj c
10. AstXHj [He desired a raven, or crow, to croak]. One says of ravens, or crows, AusotuXoHijona faXaHajona [They were desired to croak, and they croaked]. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also 1.

XaHRaAjN c
XaHRaAjN, applied to a mule, an ass, and a raven or crow, that brays, or croaks, or raises its voice, much: and by Er-Rá'ee it is applied to (tropical:) a muWacRin. (TA.) ― -b2- banaAtu XaHRaAjK, (S, A, O, K,) and XaAHijK↓, (L,) Mules: (S, A, O, K:) and asses. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And XaHRaAjN and miXoHajN↓ The wild ass: (S, O, K:) in the L said to be the wild pigeon: [but HmAm is evidently there a mistranscription for HimaAr:] each an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.)

banaAtu XaAHijK c
banaAtu XaAHijK: see XaHRaAjN. ― -b2- XawaAHiju [pl. of XaAHijapN] Ravens, or crows: which are also called musotaXoHajaAtN↓ and musotaXoHijaAtN↓, meaning desired to croak and croaking. (O, K.) Dhu-r-Rummeh uses the phrase biAlfiraAqi musotaXoHijaAtN↓ [Ravens croaking by reason of separation]. (O, TA.)

miXoHajN c
miXoHajN: see XaHRaAjN.

musotaXoHajaAtN c
musotaXoHajaAtN: see the next but one of the preceding paragraphs, in three places.

1 XaHaca c
1. XaHaca, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
XaHaca
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. XaHocN, (S,) He sharpened (S, A, Msb, K) a knife, (S, A, L, K,) and a sword, and the like, (L,) or an iron implement, (Msb), with a whetstone or other similar thing; (TA;) as also AXHc↓; (K;) and XHRc↓, inf. n. taXoHiycN. (KL.) ― -b2- [Hence,] XaHacota EalayonaA lisaAnaka (tropical:) [Thou hast sharpened against us thy tongue]. (A and TA in art. rhf.) And AiXoHaco lahu garoba cihonika (tropical:) [Sharpen thou for it the edge of thine intellect]. (A.) And XaHacahu biEayonihi, (K,) or bibaSarihi, (A,) (tropical:) He looked sharply at him. (K, * TA.) And XaHaca AljuwEu maEidatahu (assumed tropical:) Hunger made his stomach keen, and strengthened it, (L,) and inflamed it. (L, K.) ― -b3- Hence also, i. e. from XaHaca in the sense first expl. above, (Har p. 377,) fulaAnN yaXoHacu AlnRaAsa, (inf. n. XaHocN, K,) (tropical:) Such a one begs importunately of men: (A, K, * and Har ubi suprà:) and XaHacotuhu I begged importunately of him. (Msb.) ― -b4- And XaHacahu (assumed tropical:) He drove him away; namely, a man; (K;) as also tXHRchu↓, (CK, and so accord. to the O,) or XHRchu↓, (K accord. to the TA,) inf. n. taXoHiycN. (TA.) [See also 5 below.] And XaHacotuhu, (O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (assumed tropical:) I drove him vehemently. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b5- XaHocN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The being angry. (K.) You say, XaHaca Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He was angry with him. (TK.) ― -b6- And i. q. qaXorN [The act of paring, or peeling, &c.]. (O, K.) You say, XaHacahu, i. e. qaXarahu [He pared it, peeled it, &c.]. (TK.)

2 XaHRaca
2: see above, in two places.

3 XaAHacaniI c
3. XaAHacaniI, inf. n. XiHaAcN, He assisted me, by alternating with me, (raAsalaniI,) and did like as I did, in sharpening a sword and the like. (Ham p. 533.) ＝ -A2- XAHct AlnRaAqapu The she-camel raised her tail, and then twisted it vehemently, when in labour, being near to bringing forth. (O, K.)

4 OaXoHaca
4: see 1, first sentence.

5 raOayotuhu yataXaHRacu c
5. raOayotuhu yataXaHRacu (tropical:) [I saw him applying himself to importunate begging]. (A, TA. [In both this meaning is indicated by the context.]) ＝ -A2- taXaHRacaniI fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) Such a one drove me away, and subjected me to trouble, or difficulty. (TA.) See also 1.

XaHacaAnN c
XaHacaAnN (assumed tropical:) [Having a keen appetite;] hungry. (S, M, L, K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A vehement driver. (K TA. [See also miXoHacN.]) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Light, or active, in his work (fiI saEoyihi). (O, K.)

XuHocuwcN c
XuHocuwcN, applied to a man, i. q. naziqN (assumed tropical:) [Light, and unsteady, or lightwitted; &c.]. (TA.)

XaHiycN c
XaHiycN, applied to a knife [&c.], Sharpened; (Lth, A, TA;) as also maXoHuwcN↓. (Lth, TA.)

XaHRaAcN c
XaHRaAcN (tropical:) An importunate beggar: (A, K: *) one should not say XaHRaAvN: (K:) the latter is said by IB to be a vulgar corruption; but several authors assert it to be correct, because c is changed into v without any error in speech, as is asserted by El-Khafájee and others; and accord. to the A, both these words signify as above: (TA in art. XHv, and partly repeated in the present art.:) [it is said, however, that] XaHRaAcN meaning a beggar does not occur in the language of the Arabs. (Har p. 377.)

miXoHacN c
miXoHacN A whetstone; or thing with which, or upon which, one sharpens. (S, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] A rough, severe, or violent, driver: (O, K: [see also XaHacaAnN:] and applied also as an epithet to a driving. (O.)

maXoHacapN c
maXoHacapN [A cause, or means, of sharpening: a word of the class of majobanapN &c.]. One says, hecaA kalaAmN maXoHacapN lilofahomi (tropical:) [This is discourse that is a cause, or means, of sharpening of the understanding]. (A.)

miXoHaAcN c
miXoHaAcN An [elevation such as is termed] Oakamap, wide within, (O, K, TA,) not rough in the stones [thereof], but extending long upon the earth, not having in it trees nor soft ground: (O, TA:) or, accord. to ISh, (O, TA,) level ground, (O, K, TA,) in which are pebbles like those [that are strewn in the court] of the mosque, and in which is no mountain: but he says that ADk disapproves the word: (O, TA:) accord. to Fr, (O,) the head of a mountain, (O, K, TA,) when sharp, or pointed: pl. maXaAHicu. (O.)

maXoHuwcN c
maXoHuwcN: see XaHiycN. ― -b2- fulaAnN maXoHuwcN Ealayohi (tropical:) Such a one is an object of anger. (O, TA.)

1 XaHaTa c
1. XaHaTa, aor.
XaHaTa
, inf. n. XaHoTN (S, K) and XaHaTN (K) and XuHuwTN (S, K) and maXoHaTN; (K;) and XaHiTa, aor.
XaHaTa
, (K,) inf. n. XaHaTN; (TA;) It was, or became, distant, or remote: (S, K:) or XaHoTN and XaHaTN signify the being distant, or remote, in all states or circumstances. (TA.) You say, XaHaTa AlmazaAru The place of visiting was, or became, distant, or remote. (S.) And laA OanosaAka EalaI XaHoTi AldRaAri I will not forget thee notwithstanding the distance of the dwelling. (TA.) And El-'Ajjáj says,
waAlXRaHoTu qaTRaAEu rajaMCi mano rajaA
[And distance is the severer of the hope of him who hopeth]. (TA.) ― -b2- XaHaTa fiI AlsRawomi He went far, or far from what was right, and exceeded the due limit, in the demanding of a price. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (TA,) XaHaTa AlbaEiyra fiI AlsRawomi, (K, TA, [in the CK, and in a MS. copy of the K, AlbREiyru,]) aor.
XaHaTa
, inf. n. XaHoTN, (TA,) He went to the utmost of the value of the camel in the demanding of a price: (K, TA:) or he went far from what was right, and exceeded the due limit: (K:) and XaHiTa signifies the same; (K;) or is thought to do so by ISd. (TA.) Hence, also, what is said in a trad., by Rabee'ah, respecting a man emancipating a portion of a slave: yakuwnu EalaI AlmuEotiqi qiymapu OanoSibaMCi XurakaMYihi yuXoHaTu AlvRamanu vumRa yuEotiqu kulRahu [The value of the portions of his copartners shall be imposed upon the emancipater;] the price of the slave shall be carried to the utmost; [then he shall emancipate the whole of him:] or the meaning is, the price of the slave shall be collected; from XaHaTa AlUinaMCa, which see below. (TA.) ― -b4- XaHaTa fulaAnFA He preceded, outwent, got before, or passed beyond, such a one, and became far from him: (K, TA:) and in like manner, Alxayola [the horses, or horsemen]. (T, TA.) One says also, XaHaTato banuw haAXimK AlEaraba The sons of Háshim surpassed, and outstripped, the Arabs [in general] in excellence. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XaHaTa AlUinaMCa He filled the vessel. (Fr, K.) ＝ -A3- See also 5.

2 XHRThu c
2. XHRThu, inf. n. taXoHiyTN, (S, K,) He made him (a slain man) to struggle, or flounder, bidamihi
in his blood: (S:) or he besmeared, bedawbed, befouled, or defiled, him, biAldRami with blood. (K.)

4 AXHThu c
4. AXHThu He made him, or caused him, to be, or become, distant, or remote; he put him, sent him, or removed him, far away. (S, K.)

5 tXHRT c
5. tXHRT He (a slain man) struggled, or floundered, bidamihi in his blood: (S:) and XaHoTN↓ [inf. n. of XaHaTa] also signifies the struggling, or floundering, in blood: (Lth, ISd, K:) or the former signifies he struggled, or floundered, and rolled, or wallowed, fiI damihi in his blood: (TA:) or became besmeared, bedawbed, befouled, or defiled, (Mgh, K,) and he rolled, or wallowed, (Mgh,) or struggled, or floundered, (K,) fiI damihi in his blood. (Mgh, K. *) And It (the fœtus) struggled, or floundered, fiI AlsRalaI in the membrane enclosing it. (K.)

XaHRaATN c
XaHRaATN: see what next follows.

manozilN XaAHiTN c
manozilN XaAHiTN A distant, or remote, place of abode; as also XaHRaATN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- XawaAHiTu AlOawodiyapi, [the former word being pl. of XaAHiTapN,] The distant, or remote, parts of the valleys. (TA.)

XawoHaTN c
XawoHaTN Certain trees, (K,) a species of the trees of the mountains, (S,) meaning of the mountains of the saraAp, [the mountain-range extending from near 'Arafát to Nejrán in El-Yemen,] for there they grow, (TA,) of which bows are made: (S, K:) AHn says, One acquainted with [the kind of trees called] the XwHT has informed me that it grows in the manner of the Oaroz [or pine-tree], many rods growing from one stem; its leaves are thin and long, and it has a fruit like the long grape, [the word here rendered “ grape ” is Enbp, but it has been altered in the MS., and may therefore be incorrect,] except that its extremity is more slender, and it is soft, and is eaten: (TA:) or i. q. naboEN: (IB:) or a species of the naboE, (K,) of which bows are made: (TA:) or the XwHT and nbE and XiroyaAn are one; the name varying according to the excellence of their places of growth; what is upon the summit of the mountain being called nbE; what is upon its base, or foot, or lowest or lower part, XryAn; and what is in the depressed tract by its base, XwHT: (Mbr, Az, K:) IB says the same with respect to the nbE, but that the XwHT is that which is upon the lowest part of the mountain; and this is confirmed by what is said by AZ and others: El-Ghanawee El-Aarábee says, the nbE and XwHT and saraMC are one: as to the XryAn, no one holds it to be of the nbE except Mbr: Aboo-Ziyád says that bows are made of the XryAn, and they are good, but of a black colour tinged with redness: and AHn says in one place, that the nbE and XwHT are yellow in the wood, heavy in the hand; and when they become old, they become red: (TA:) the n. un. is with p. (K.)

1 XaHuma c
1. XaHuma, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
XaHuma
, (K,) inf. n. XaHaAmapN, (MA, Msb,) He (a man, S, K) was, or became, fat; (S, MA, K;) as also XaHima, aor.
XaHama
: (TA:) or he was, or became, abundant in the fat of his person. (Msb.) And XaHumato Uibiluhu (K) His camels were, or became, fat. (TA.) And XuHimati AlnRaAqapu; and XaHamat, aor.
XaHuma
; of the classes of EuniIa and naSara; inf. n. XaHomN and XuHuwmN; The she-camel became fat after leanness. (TA.) ― -b2- XaHima, (S, K,) aor.
XaHama
, (K,) inf. n. XaHamN, (TA,) He was, or became, eagerly desirous of fat. (S, K, TA.) And He ate much fat. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XaHamahu, (K,) or XaHama OaSoHaAbahu, (S,) aor.
XaHama
, (K,) inf. n. XaHomN, (TA,) He fed him, or his companions, with fat; or gave him, or them, fat to eat. (S, K.)

4 AXHm c
4. AXHm He had much fat in his possession: like as AlHm signifies “ he had much flesh in his possession. ” (TA.)

XaHomN c
XaHomN, (S, Msb, K,) of an animal, (Msb,) a word of well known meaning, (S, Msb, K,) Fat; (MA, KL;) the substance of fatness: (ISd, TA:) XaHomapN is a more special term, (S, Msb,) [i. e. a n. un.,] signifying a piece thereof: (K:) the pl. of the former is XuHuwmN. (Msb, TA.) It is said of the Jews, in a trad., Harumato Ealayohimu AlXRuHuwmu fabaAEuwhaA waOakaluwA OavomaAnahaA [Fats have been forbidden to them; but they have sold them, and have devoured the prices thereof: see Lev. vii. 23]: the fat that is forbidden to them is that of the kidneys and of the stomach and of the intestines into which the food passes from the stomach; but not that of the Oalayop [meaning the “ rump, ” and also the “ tail of a sheep, ”] nor of the back. (TA.) One says, laqiytuhu biXaHomi kulaAhu [lit. I met him, or found him, with the fat of his kidneys,] meaning, (tropical:) in his state of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (K, TA.) And of him who is deemed weak, one says, fulaAnN XaHomN lilomubotaliEi (tropical:) [lit. Such a one is fat for the swallower]. (Ham p. 771.) ― -b2- Also The hump of the camel: (TA:) heard by Az from the Arabs in this sense. (TA in art. Hm.) ― -b3- And The whiteness [app. meaning the white part] of the belly. (TA.) ― -b4- XaHomapu AlOucuni [The lobe, or lobule, of the ear;] the part, of the ear, to which the quroT [i. e. ear-ring or ear-drop] is suspended; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. the soft portion of the lower part of the ear: or the place of the perforation for the quroT. (TA.) ― -b5- XaHomapu AlEayoni The muqolap of the eye; (TA;) i. e., what comprises the white and the black of the eye: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán; ” and S and Msb and K voce muqolapN:) [this is what is generally meant by it; i. e. the globe of the eye:] in the T it is said to be the Hadaqap [i. e. black, or what is in the middle of the white,] of the eye: and some say that it is the XaHomap [app. meaning the whole substance] that is beneath [or behind] the Hadaqap. (TA.) ― -b6- XaHomapu AlHanoZali [and XaHomuhu, as in the K in art. HnZl,] The inner part [i. e. the pulp] of the colocynth, exclusive of its seeds. (K.) ― -b7- XaHomapu AlrRumRaAni The thin yellow [pulp] that is amid the seeds of the pomegranate; (K;) or, as in the M, the substance that separates the seeds of the pomegranate. (TA.) ― -b8- XaHomu AlnRaxoli The heart pith, or cerebrum, (jumRaAr,) of palm-trees: (S in art. jcb:) and XaHomapu AlnRaxolapi the heart (jumRaArap) of the palm-tree. (M, TA.) ― -b9- XaHomapu Almaroji The xiTomiIR [or marsh-mallow]. (K.) ― -b10- XaHomu AlOaroDi The truffle; as a gen. n.; syn. AlkamoCu: (TA in art. kmO:) and XaHomapu AlOaroDi the truffle; as a n. un.; syn. AlkamoOapu: (K:) or the white truffle; syn. AlkamoOapu AlbayoDaMCu. (S.) [It should be observed that AlkamoCu is generally held to be a n. un.; and AlkamoOapu, to be a coll. gen. n.; contr. to analogy: but they are here evidently used in the reverse manner.] ― -b11- XaHomapu AlOaroDi also signifies A certain white worm: or is of (min [which is omitted in some of the copies of the K]) the [long worms, found in moist earth, and in the mud of rivers, called] xaraATiyn: (K, TA:) or a white EaZaMCap [n. un. of EaZaMCN, q. v.], not big: or, as some say, it is not of the [species called] EaZaMC; it is more pleasant [to the taste], and better: and [because it dwells in the sand-hills,] they say [i. e. call it] also XaHomapu AlnRaqaA, like as they say banaAtu AlnRaqaA: (TA:) it is the [reptile called] Hulakap, which dives into the sand, and to which the fingers (banaAn) of virgins are likened. (TA in art. ArD. [See HulakapN: and see also XabavN.]) ― -b12- Oabuw XaHomK is an appellation of The small species of what is called HimaAru qabRaAna. (TA in art. qb, q. v.) ― -b13- [See also XaHomapN below.]

XuHomN c
XuHomN, with damm, [as though pl. of OaXoHamu, which I do not find mentioned,] White; applied to men. (IAar, TA.)

XaHimN c
XaHimN Eagerly desirous of fat. (S, K.) One says, rajulN XaHimN laHimN A man eagerly desirous of fat and of flesh. (TA.) ― -b2- EinabN XaHimN Grapes having little juice (K, TA) and thick skin. (TA.) ― -b3- And rumRaAnapN XaHimapN A pomegranate having thick XaHomap [or pulp amid the seeds]. (TA.)

XaHomapN c
XaHomapN [n. un. of XaHomN, which see throughout. ＝ -A2- Also] A certain bird. (K. [For TaAYirN, which I regard as the right reading, in the CK, I find in other copies of the K AlTRaAYiru as an explanation of AlXRaHomapu.]) ＝ -A3- And A certain game of the children of the Arabs of the desert. (K, * TA.)

XaHiymN c
XaHiymN Fat, as an epithet applied to a man: (ISk, S, K:) or abundant in the fat of his person. (Msb.)

XaHRaAmN c
XaHRaAmN A seller of fat; (S, K;) as also XaAHimN↓. (K.) ― -b2- And One who feeds men much with fat. (TA.)

XaAHimN c
XaAHimN One who feeds men with fat. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A man having, or possessing, fat; like laAHimN signifying “ having, or possessing, flesh: ” possessive epithets like laAbinN and taAmirN. (TA.) ― -b3- See also XaHRaAmN.

muXoHimN c
muXoHimN, (S, [so in my copies, see 4, of which it is the part. n.,]) or muXaHRimN↓, like muHadRivN [in measure], (K,) [both perhaps correct,] A man having much fat in his house or tent. (S, K.) ― -b2- And the former, A man whose camels are fat. (K.)

muXaHRamN c
muXaHRamN: see maXoHuwmN.

muXaHRimN c
muXaHRimN: see muXoHimN.

maXoHuwmN c
maXoHuwmN Food, and bread, into which fat has been put; (TA;) [and so muXaHRamN↓, for] one says xubozapN muXaHRamapN [a cake of bread, &c., into which fat has been put]. (K in art. rbq.)

1 XaHana c
1. XaHana, (S, L, Msb, K,) aor.
XaHana
, inf. n. XaHonN, (L, Msb,) He filled (S, L, Msb, K) a ship, (S, L, K,) or a house, or chamber, &c.: (Msb:) he filled, [or laded,] and completely equipped or furnished, a ship. (L.) And in like manner, It (i. e. what was in it) filled a ship. (L.) And, (S, L, K,) as also AXHn↓, (K,) He filled a town or city (S, L, K) biAlxayoli [with horsemen or the horsemen]. (S, L.) ＝ -A2- Also, (L, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (L,) and so the inf. n., (L, Msb,) He drove away (L, Msb, K) a people, or party, (L,) or him. (Msb.) And (L) one says, marRa yaXoHanuhumo, (S, L,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He passed along driving them away, and pursuing them. (S, L.) AZ heard an Arab of the desert say, AiXoHano Eanoka fulaAnFA, meaning Remove thou, and put far away, from thee such a one. (L.) And one says of a thing that is intensely acid, UinRahu yaXoHanu AlcRubaAba i. e. Verily it drives away the flies. (TA.) ＝ -A3- XaHonN also signifies The running vehemently. (L.) And XaHana, He went far, or far away. (K.) And one says, XaHanati AlkilaAbu, (L,) [and XaHinat, as appears from what follows,] aor. taXoHanu and taXoHunu, (L, K,) like tamonaEu and taEolamu and tanoSuru, (K,) inf. n. XuHuwnN, (L,) The dogs went far in pursuit without catching any prey, or game. (L, K.) ＝ -A4- XaHina Ealayohi, aor.
XaHana
, (L, Msb, K,) inf. n. XaHanN; (L, Msb;) and XaHana, aor.
XaHana
, inf. n. XaHonN; (Msb;) He bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him; (Msb, K;) and (Msb) bore, (L,) or showed, (Msb,) enmity towards him. (L, Msb.)

2 XHRnhu c
2. XHRnhu He made him, or appointed him to the office of, a XiHonap, q. v.; occurring in postclassical works.]

3 XAHnhu c
3. XAHnhu, (L, Msb, K,) inf. n. muXaAHanapN, (L, Msb, KL,) He regarded him, or treated him, with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; (Msb;) or with enmity; being so regarded, or treated, by him: (L, Msb, K, KL:) or, as some say, muXaAHanapN is such reviling, and blaming, upbraiding, or reproaching, reciprocally, as does not amount to fighting one another; from XaHonaMCu meaning “ enmity. ” (L.)

4 AXHn c
4. AXHn: see 1. ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. UiXoHaAnN, (L,) He sheathed the sword: (L, * K:) and he drew the sword: thus having two contr. significations. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, L, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, L,) He (a boy, or child, S, L, and, as some say, a man, L) was ready, or about, to weep: (S, L, K:) or his eyes watered at the approach of weeping (L.) ― -b2- And AXHn lahu bisahomK He prepared himself to shoot him, or to shoot at him, with an arrow. (K.)

6 taXaAHunN c
6. taXaAHunN The regarding, or treating, one another [with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; (see 1, last sentence; and 3;) or] with enmity. (L.)

XaHonapN c
XaHonapN [thus written, with fet-h to the X, but I incline to think that it is correctly XiHonapN↓,] The contents of a ship, that fill it. (L.)

XiHonapN c
XiHonapN: see what next precedes. ― -b2- [Also] A body of men sufficing for the guarding, controlling, or firm holding, of a province, or city, on the part of the Sultán. (Az, L, K. *) And (K) A troop of horsemen keeping post (S, L, K) in a country or town. (S, L.) IB says that the vulgar usage of this word as syn. with OamiyrN [i. e. A commander or commandant, &c., being used app. only in post-classical times, from the Pers. XaHonaho, meaning in Pers., and hence in Arabic also, a viceroy, prefect, chief of the police, or the like,] is a mistake. (L.) ― -b3- And The quantity of fodder appointed to beasts as sufficing them for a day and a night. (Az, L, K.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

XaHonaMCu c
XaHonaMCu Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (L:) or vehement hatred: (Msb:) and enmity; (S, L, Msb, K;) as also XiHonapN↓. (S, L, K.) Hence the saying, kaAna bayonahu wabayona Oaxiyhi XaHonaMCu i. e. [There was between him and his brother] enmity. (L.)

XuHuwn c
XuHuwn in the following verse, cited by ISd,
taOaTRarona fiI AlmiynaMCi vumRa tarakonahu
waqado lajRa mino OaHomaAlihinRa XuHuwnu
may be, accord. to him, an inf. n. of XaHana, or an extr. pl. of XiHonapN: (L:) [but I rather think that it is a pl. of XaAHinN↓, like as XuhuwdN is of XaAhidN; and accordingly I would render the verse (which evidently relates to ships) thus: They kept close in the port, then they left it, and laders had persisted in contention by reason of their burdens, i. e. the burdens of the ships, because of the labour that they occasioned.]

XaAHinN c
XaAHinN [act. part. n. of XaHana]: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- See also maXoHuwnN. ＝ -A2- Also A dog going far in pursuit without catching any prey, or game: pl. XawaAHinu. (L.) ＝ -A3- And Bearing enmity [or rancour &c. (see 1, last sentence,)] towards another: one says, huwa XaAHinN laka [He is bearing enmity &c. towards thee]. (L.)

maXoHuwnN c
maXoHuwnN A ship (fulokN, so in the Kur [xxvi. 119 &c.], S, L, or marokabN, K [in the L, erroneously, rakabN],) Filled [or laded, and completely equipped or furnished: see 1, first sentence]; (S, L, K;) as also XaAHinN↓, like kaAtimN in the sense of mukotuwmN, (L, K,) mentioned by Kr. (L.)

muXoHaYinRN c
muXoHaYinRN Becoming angered; or made angry. (K.)

EaduwRN muXaAHinN c
EaduwRN muXaAHinN [An enemy who regards, or treats, another with rancour, &c., being so regarded, or treated by him: see 3]. (S, L.) AlmuXaAHinu as used in a trad. means The schismatic innovator in religion: (L, K:) so says El-Owzá'ee: or the transgressor: (L:) or it means he who has in his heart rancour &c. (XaHonaMC) towards the Companions of the Apostle of God: or he who forsakes the institutes, or rule and usage, of his prophet; who speaks against his people; who sheds their blood. (TA.)

1 XaHaA c
1. XaHaA, (K,) or XaHaA faAhu, (Ks, S,) aor.
XaHawa
, (Ks, TA,) or
XaHuwa
, (S,) inf. n. XaHowN, (Ks, S, TA,) said of a man, (TA,) He opened his mouth; (S, K, TA;) as also AXHI↓ [or app., AXHI faAhu], (K,) and faAhu XHRI↓, inf. n. taXoHiyapN. (TA.) XaHaA faAhu [meaning as above] is also said of the ass when about to bray. (TA.) And one says of the bit, XaHaA fama AldRaAbRapi [It opened the mouth of the beast]. (TA.) [See also art. XHI.] ＝ -A2- And XaHaA fuwhu, (S, K, *) aor.
XaHuwa
, (S,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) His mouth opened; (S, K;) as also fwh XHRI↓; (TA;) but one should not say AXHI fwh. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- And XaHaA, inf. n. as above, He stepped, paced, or walked. (TA.) Hence it is related in a trad. of 'Alee, that, having mentioned sedition, or conflict and faction, or the like, he said to 'Ammár, lataXoHuwanRa fiyhaA XaHowFA laA yudorikuka AlrRajulu AlsRariyEu, meaning Thou shalt assuredly go [or step or pace] quickly, and advance, therein [so that the swift man shall not overtake thee]. (TA.) And it is said that XaHaA fiyhi signifies He went far; and took a wide, or an ample, range; in it. (TA. [See also 5.])

2 XaHRawa
2: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

4 OaXoHawa
4: see 1, first sentence.

5 tXHRI c
5. tXHRI, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, primarily signifies He took a wide, or an ample, range in anything. (TA. [See also 1, last explanation.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] tXHRI Ealayhi He spread out, or stretched out, his tongue, [or he gave wide range to his tongue,] respecting him [or against him]. (K.)

XaHFA c
XaHFA, (K,) thus with the short A, (TA,) Wide; applied to anything: and XaHowaMCu↓, applied to a well, signifies the same: (K:) or the latter, thus applied, wide in the head [or upper part]. (TA.)

XaHowapN c
XaHowapN A step, pace, or single act of stepping or pacing. (S, K.) One says, farasN baEiydu AlXRaHowapi A horse having a far extent of step: (S, TA:) and ragiybu AlXRaHowapi (S in art. rgb) a horse wide of step; that takes a large space of ground with his legs. (TA: but there, AlXRaHowi [which is the inf. n.].) ― -b2- [Hence,] rajulN baEiydu AlXRaHowapi fiI maqaASidihi (tropical:) [A man who strides along in his pursuits]. (TA.) ― -b3- And UinaMCN waAsiEu AlXRaHowapi i. e. (tropical:) [A vessel wide] in the interior. (TA.)

XHMC c
XHMC: see the next paragraph.

XaHowaMCu c
XaHowaMCu: see XaHFA. ― -b2- Also A she-camel wide of step: and it is said in a trad. that the Prophet had a horse named AlXHMC↓, thus related, with medd, [app. AlXRaHaMCu, like AlwasaAEu,] expl. as meaning the wide of step: so says IAth. (TA.)

XaAHK c
XaAHK [act. part. n. of 1: fem. XaAHiyapN; pl. of the latter XawaAHK and XaAHiyaAtN]. One says, jaMCati Alxayolu
XawaAHiIa The horses came opening their mouths: (S, A, K, * TA:) and so Oaqobalati Alxayolu XaAHiyaAtK. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And jaMCanaA XaAHiyFA He came to us stepping along. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) He came to us without any want. (TA.) ― -b4- AlXRawaAHiI is applied by the vulgar to The large pieces of wood resembling columns: but [SM says,] I have not seen any mention thereof in the [classical] language. (TA.)

1 XaHiIa c
1. XaHiIa, like raDiIa, inf. n. XaHoIN, is said by ISd and in the K to be a dial. var. of XaHaA, inf. n. XaHowN, i. e., as ISd says, meaning He opened his mouth; but the latter, he says, is the better known: this, however, requires consideration: for it is said in the Tekmileh that XaHaI fulaAnN, aor. yaXoHaI, inf. n. XaHoIN, is a dial. var. of [XaHaA, aor.] yaXoHuw, inf. n. XaHowN, on the authority of Lth. (TA.)

1 Xaxaba c
1. Xaxaba, (Mgh, TA,) aor.
Xaxuba
[and
Xaxaba
], inf. n. XaxobN, said of milk, (Mgh,) and of anything, It flowed. (Mgh, TA.) And Xaxabotuhu I made it to flow. (Mgh.) You say, Xaxaba AllRabanu, aor.
Xaxuba
and
Xaxaba
, (S, O, CK,) inf. n. XaxobN, (S, O,) The milk flowed in an extended stream from the udder when milked; (S, O, CK;) and (assumed tropical:) in like manner one says of blood: (O:) or Xaxaba AllRabana, aor.
Xaxuba
and
Xaxaba
, he made the milk to flow in a continuous stream from the udder (K accord. to the TA [and accord. to the context in the K, in which it is immediately added faQnoXaxaba, showing that AnXxb↓ has the former of these two significations as quasi-pass. of Xaxaba, and the like is said in the A,]) between the vessel and the teat. (TA.) Hence, i. e. from Xaxaba AllRabanu, the saying of ElKumeyt,
wawaHowaHa fiI HiDoni AlfataApi DajiyEuhaA
walamo yaku fiI AlnRukodi AlmaqaAliyti maXoxabu
[And he who lay upon his side with her, or her bedfellow, breathed audibly, by reason of the cold, in the bosom of the young woman, and there was not, among the she-camels that had no young ones living, and that should therefore abound with milk, because not suckling, any flowing of milk in a continuous, or an extended, stream, or any time, or place, thereof, for maXoxabN may be, agreeably with a general rule, an inf. n. or a n. of time or of place]. (S.) And some expl. XaxobN as signifying The sounding, or sound, of milk when it is being drawn from the udder. (TA.) One says also, Xaxabato OawodaAju Alqatiyli damFA i. e. (tropical:) [The external jugular veins of the slain person] streamed, or flowed with blood: (Msb, TA: * [and the like is said in the Mgh:]) and Xaxabotuhu OanaA (assumed tropical:) [I made it to stream, or flow]: the verb being intrans. and trans. (Msb.) And huwa yaXoxubu damFA (assumed tropical:) He, or it, flows [or streams] with blood; the last word being in the accus. case as a specificative: and be, or it, pours forth, or makes to flow [or stream], blood; the last word, when this is the meaning, being in the accus. case as an objective complement: but the former is that which is commonly known. (Mgh.) And Xaxabato yadaAhu HatRaI maAta (assumed tropical:) [His hands flowed, or streamed, with blood, until he died: or poured forth blood, &c.]: said, in a trad., of one whose knuckles, or finger-joints, were cut. (TA.) AnXxb↓, also, is said of blood [as meaning (assumed tropical:) It flowed, or streamed]. (TA.) And damFA AnXxb↓, said of a vein, means (assumed tropical:) It flowed, or streamed, with blood. (S, K, TA.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the HawoD [or pool (of the Apostle)], yaXoxuabu fiyhi miyzaAbaAni mina AljanRapi (assumed tropical:) [Two spouts will pour forth into it from Paradise]. (TA.) And one says, Xaxabotu AllRiqaAHa I milked the milch camels. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And marRa yaXoxabu fiI AlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) He went, or passed by, (O,) or ran, (El-Fáïk, TA,) swiftly [in the land, or upon the ground]. (El-Fáïk, O, TA.)

7 UinoXaxaba
7: see the preceding paragraph, in three places.

XaxobN c
XaxobN: see the next paragraph. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Blood. (K.)

XuxobN c
XuxobN Milk coming forth, (A,) or milk that has come forth, (K,) from the udder, (A, K,) when drawn therefrom; (TA;) and so XaxobN↓; (A, K;) which is also an inf. n.; (TA;) or this latter is an inf. n., (S, O,) and the former [is a subst. properly so called, and] signifies an extended stream of milk, (S, A, O,) like a thread, or string, (A,) when it is drawn from the udder; (S, A, O;) of the measure fuEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (A:) or the milk that comes forth from beneath the hand of the milker at each squeeze of the udder of the ewe or she-goat. (TA.) It is said in a prov., XuxobN fiI AlUinaMCi waXuxobN fiI AlOaroDi, (S, Meyd, A, O,) i. e. One extended stream of milk from the udder into the vessel, and one &c. upon the ground: (Meyd:) applied to him who hits the mark one time and misses another time (S, Meyd, A, O) in what he says; or says right one time and wrong another time. (Meyd.) And in another prov., XuxobN TamaHa An extended stream of milk from the udder that has fallen upon the ground so as to be unprofitable; for such is the meaning of TamaHa in this case: applied to a man who has made a slip, or mistake: or it means a good hap that has escaped one's opportunity to avail himself of it. (Meyd.) See also the next paragraph.

XuxobapN c
XuxobapN A single stream of milk from the udder; (A, K;) pl. XixaAbN [q. v.]: (K;) or it signifies, (K,) or so XuxobN↓, (TA,) an extended stream of milk (K, TA) when it is drawn (TA) from the udder, streaming continuously (K, TA) between the vessel and the teat. (TA.)

XixaAbN c
XixaAbN Milk when it is drawn from the udder: (A, K: [in which latter it is also said to be pl. of XuxobapN:]) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

wadajN XaxiybN c
wadajN XaxiybN (assumed tropical:) [An external jugular vein] cut so that its blood has flowed, or streamed, forth. (TA.)

OuXoxuwbN c
OuXoxuwbN The sound of the streaming of milk. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- [And it seems to be used as an epithet; for it is added that] one says, UinRahaA laOuXoxuwbu AlOaHaAliyli [app. meaning Verily she is one whereof the orifices of the teats produce a sound by the streaming of the milk]. (S, O.)

maXoxabN c
maXoxabN: see the verse in the first paragraph.

1 Xaxuta c
1. Xaxuta, (S, K,) aor.
Xaxuta
, inf. n. XuxuwtapN, (K,) said of a man, (S,) [and app., in like manner, of anything,] He [or it] was, or became, thin, or slender, (S, L, K,) lean, and lank in the belly, not in consequence of emaciation. (L, K.)

2 taXoxiytN c
2. taXoxiytN The bringing, conveying, or causing to come; syn. UibolaAgN. (K.) One says, XxRthu Uilayohi He brought it, &c., to him. (TK.)

XaxotN c
XaxotN and XaxiytN↓, (S, A, K,) the former also pronounced XaxatN↓, (K, TA,) by some, (TA,) applied to a man, (S,) Thin, or slender, (S, A, L, K,) lean, and lank in the belly, not in consequence of emaciation: (A, L, K:) slender in the body: fem. of the first with p: (TA:) pl. XixaAtN: (S, A, K:) or XaxotN signifies thin, or slender, as applied to anything: thus it is applied to him who is thin, or slender, in the neck, and in the legs: one says, [of a beast,] UinRah laXaxotu AljuzaArapi Verily he is thin, or slender, in the legs: (TA:) and qawaAYimuhu XixaAtN His legs are thin, or slender: (A:) and HaTabN XaxotN Slender firewood. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] UinRahu laXaxotu AlEaTaMCi (assumed tropical:) Verily he is one who gives little. (TA.) And zayodN Xaxotu Alxuluqi (tropical:) Zeyd is low, ignoble, or mean, in natural disposition. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Some say that it is arabicized, from the Pers. saxot. (TA.)

XaxatN c
XaxatN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XaxiytN c
XaxiytN: see XaxotN: ― -b2- and also what here follows.

XixRiytN c
XixRiytN and XaxytN↓ and XixotiytN Dust (gubaArN) rising, or spreading, or diffusing itself. (K.)

XixotiytN c
XixotiytN: see what next precedes.

1 Xaxara c
1. Xaxara, aor.
Xaxira
, inf. n. XaxiyrN (S, K) and XaxorN, (K,) He raised his voice, with snorting; said of an ass: (S:) he uttered a sound from the fauces: or from the nose: (K:) or from the mouth, without the nose: (TA:) he (a horse) neighed: (K:) or uttered a sound after neighing: (TA:) or uttered a sound from his mouth, (K, TA,) without the nose: (TA:) As says that among the sounds made by horses are those termed XaxiyrN and naxiyrN and kariyrN; the first of which is from the mouth; the second, from the nostrils; and the third, from the chest: some say that Xaxara is like naxara [he snorted]. (TA.)

XaxorN c
XaxorN The first period or stage of youth; (K, TA;) and the sharpness thereof; like XaroxN. (TA.)
― -b2- The part, of a raHol [or camel's saddle], that is between the qaAdimap and the Mxirap, (O, K, TA,) which are the karRaAni: (TA:) [said to be] also called the Xarox, [which is an evident mistake, perhaps originating from its having been said that XaxorN and XaroxN are syn., meaning in another sense, mentioned above,] (O, TA,) and the Xajor [q. v.]: (TA:) or the space between the upper part of the two extremities [at the fore part and hind part] of the [saddle called] qatab. (JK.) ― -b3- And The chink of the buttocks. (JK, O. [In the K, for waXaxoru AlAisoti XaqRuhaA, the reading in the JK and O, is put waXaxara AlAisota XaqRahaA.])

XixRiyrN c
XixRiyrN That utters much, or often, the sound termed naxiyr: (K:) or, as in some copies of the K [and in the O], Xaxiyr: (TA:) [see naxara and Xaxara:] applied to an ass in this sense, (O,) or as signifying vociferous. (TA.)

1 Xaxasa c
1. Xaxasa, aor.
Xaxasa
, (K,) inf. n. XaxosN, (S, A, O, K,) It was, or became, conflicting, incongruous, or dissimilar, in its several parts; XaxosN being syn. with AiDoTiraAbN and AixotilaAfN [here used in the same, or nearly the same, sense]. (S, A, O, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. as above; (Lth, O, K;) or XAxs↓; (so says Lth, TA; and so in a copy of the A;) and tXAxs↓; (O, K;) said of an ass, (Lth, A, O, K,) He opened his mouth on the occasion of gaping (Lth, O, K) and smelling the urine of a she-ass: (Lth, O:) or he opened his mouth, raising his head, after smelling the dung. (A.) It is said that the primary signification of AlXRaxosu is The opening of the mouth to gape. (Ham p. 196.)

3 XAxs faAhu c
3. XAxs faAhu, said of time, It caused his teeth to become incongruous; (ISk, A, O;) some of them being long and some of them being broken: (ISk, O:) this is the case in extreme old age: (A, TA:) XixaAsN and muXaAxasapN, [as inf. ns. of the pass. verb,] in relation to the teeth, signify their being in such a condition that some of them incline and some of them have fallen out: (JK, TA: *) one says, [Xuwxisa faAhu, or Xuwxisato OasonaAnuhu, and] fuwhu tXAxs↓, (A,) or tXAxst OasonaAnuhu, (S, O, K,) His teeth became incongruous, (S, A, O, K,) and some of them inclined and some of them fell out, (S, O, K,) by reason of extreme old age. (S, A, * O, K.) ― -b2- XAxs AlSRadoEa, said of the repairer of a wooden bowl, He made the crack of the bowl to incline, so that it remained not closed up. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

4 AXxs c
4. AXxs (assumed tropical:) He showed a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, face, (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, K,) lahu to him, (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA,) fiI AlmanoTiqi in speech; as also AXxS. (Aboo-Sa'eed, O, TA.) ― -b2- And AXxshu, (O, K,) and AXxs bihi, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He spoke evil of him behind his back, or in his absence, or otherwise, with truth, or though it might be with truth; syn. AigotaAbahu; (O, K, TA;) as also AXxS bh. (TA.)

6 tXAxs c
6. tXAxs: see 1: and 3. ― -b2- It (a crack in a wooden bowl) was made by the repairer to incline, so that it remained not closed up.
