(TA.) ― -b3- It, said of the upper part of a man's skull, (i. e. said of his qiHof, IDrd, O,) or said of his head, (K,) became severed in twain, in consequence of a blow: (IDrd, O, K:) or said of the two [lateral] bones of his head (qiHofaA raOosihi), meaning tdAnyA wAxtlfA; [but the former of these two verbs is app. a mistranscription for tabaAyanaA; and the meaning, they became separated, each from the other, and not fitting together:] and it is sometimes said of the thumb; and of a vessel. (TA.) ― -b4- tXAxs Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people, or party, became distant, or remote, one from another. (JK.) ― -b5- tXAxs Oamoru Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) The state of affairs of the people, or party, became divided, (O, K, * TA, *) and conflicting, or inconsistent. (TA.) And tXAxs maA bayona Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) The state between the people, or party, became bad, or corrupt. (ISk, S, O, K. *)

XaxiysN c
XaxiysN (assumed tropical:) An affair, or a state of affairs, (OamorN,) disorganized, disordered, or unsettled; syn. mutafarRiqN. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Speech in which is a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, look: (JK: [like XaxiySN:]) or (tropical:) incongruous, or discordant, speech; (O, K, TA;) as also mutaXaAxisN↓, (A 'Obeyd, TA, in art. XxS,) and mutaXaAxiSN. (K ibid.) ― -b3- [A man] adverse to that which he is commanded to do. (TA.)

mutaXaAxisN c
mutaXaAxisN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 XaxaSa c
1. XaxaSa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
XaxaSa
, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. XuxuwSN, (S, Msb, K,) He, or it, rose; or became raised, or elevated. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] It (a star) rose. (K.) And XaxaSa lahu XaxoSN [A figure seen from a distance rose to his view]. (TA in art. zwl.) ― -b3- XaxaSa baSaruhu (S, Mgh, Msb, K, [in some copies of the K, baSarahu, but this occurs afterwards in that work,]) is said when a man opens his eyes and then does not move his eyelids; [and signifies (tropical:) His eyes, or lit., his eye, became fixedly open:] (S, K: *) or it signifies his eye became raised: (Msb:) or his sight became stretched and raised. (Mgh.) [See the Kur xiv. 43, and xxi. 97.] You say, XaxaSa Uilayoka baSariI (tropical:) [My eye, or eyes, became fixedly open, or raised, or my sight became stretched and raised, towards thee]. (A.) And XaxaSa baSaru AlmayRiti, (A,) inf. n. as above, (IAth,) (tropical:) [The eye, or eyes, of the dying man became fixedly open: or] the eyelids of the dying man became raised upwards, and he looked intently, and became disquieted, or disturbed. (IAth.) ― -b4- saxaSati Alkalimapu mina Alfami (assumed tropical:) The word, or sentence, rose [from the mouth] towards the palate: this is sometimes natural: i. e., one's raising his voice, and not being able to lower it. (K.) ― -b5- XaxaSa AlsRahomu (inf. n. as above, Msb,) (tropical:) The arrow rose [so as to deviate] from the butt, or object of aim: (K:) or the arrow passed beyond the butt, or object of aim, going above it: (A, Msb:) or rose in the sky. (ISh.) ― -b6- XaxaSa (aor. as above, Msb, and so the inf. n., S, Msb,) also signifies He went, or went away, from one town or country to another: (S, A, K:) or he went forth from one place to another, (Msb,) or from his place of alighting or abiding: (TA:) or [so accord. to the TA, but in the K “ and ”] he journeyed upwards. (K, TA.) You say also, XaxaSa mino qawomihi He went forth from his people: and XaxaSa Uilayohimo he returned to them. (TA.) ― -b7- Also, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) It (a thing) rose; or swelled; or became swollen: (M:) it (a wound) rose, and became swollen: (M, K:) [it was, or became, protuberant, or prominent.] ＝ -A2- XaxaSa baSarahu, (Msb, K, TA,) or XaxaSa bibaSarihi, (Mgh,) or both, (TA, [in which it is said to be tropical,]) and XaxaSa bibaSarihi UilaI AlsRamaMCi, (Msb,) or XaxaSa [alone], (so in a copy of the A, [in which it is mentioned among proper expressions,]) (assumed tropical:) He raised his eye, or sight, (K, TA,) towards the sky, and did not move his eyelids; said of a dying man: (TA:) or he stretched and raised his sight: (Mgh:) or he opened his eyes, (A, Msb,) and did not move his eyelids, (A,) or [looking fixedly,] not moving his eyelids. (Msb.) ― -b2- yaXoxaSu biSawotihi falaA yaqodiru EalaI xafoDihi (assumed tropical:) [He raises his voice, and is not able to lower it]. (K.) ― -b3- XuxiSa bihi, (S, K,) coordinate to EuniIa, (K,) or XuxiSa [alone], (so in a copy of the A,) or XaxiSa bihi OamorN, coordinate to taEiba, inf. n. XaxaSN, (Msb,) (tropical:) [He was disquieted by a thing that happened to him: or] a thing that disquieted him happened to him: (S, A, K:) or a thing happened to him and disquieted him: (Msb:) as though he were raised from the ground by reason of his disquietude. (TA.) [See also 4.] ＝ -A3- XaxuSa, aor.
XaxuSa
, (S, K,) inf. n. XaxaASapN, or this is a simple subst., [for] ISd says, I have not heard a verb of which it may be the inf. n., (TA,) [if used, signifying] He (a man, S) was, or became, big, bulky, or corpulent. (S, K.)

2 XxRS AlXRaIoCa c
2. XxRS AlXRaIoCa, (A,) inf. n. taXoxiySN. (TA,) (tropical:) He individuated the thing; syn. EayRanahu. (A, TA.) [From XaxoSN, q. v.]

4 AXxShu c
4. AXxShu [He made him, or it, to rise, or become raised or elevated]. You say, AXxS nafosahu [He raised himself; or drew, or stretched, himself up]. (S and K in art. Elb.) ― -b2- AXxS bisahomihi (tropical:) He made his arrow to pass beyond the butt, or object of aim, going above it. (A.) ― -b3- And AXxShu He made him to go, or go away, from one town or country to another: (S:) or to go forth from one place to another: (A, * Msb:) or to go, or journey: (A in art. syr:) or to journey upwards. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) He disquieted him, (K, TA,) so that he went away from a place. (TA.) [See also 1.] ＝ -A2- AXxS (tropical:) His (an archer's) arrow passed beyond the butt, or object of aim, (S, A, Msb, K,) going above it. (S, A, Msb.) ＝ -A3- The time of his journeying, going away, or departing, came, or arrived. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A4- AXxS Uilayohi (tropical:) He showed him a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, face, or countenance; looked at him in a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, manner; (A, TA;) or so AXxS lahu, (TA in art. Xxs,) fiI AlmanoTiqi in speech; as also AXxs. (Aboo
Sa'eed, O and TA in art. Xxs.) ― -b2- AXxS bifulaAnK (tropical:) He spoke evil of such a one behind his back, or in his absence, or otherwise, with truth, or though it might be with truth; syn. AigotaAbahu; (Yaakoob on the authority of AO, S, A, K;) as also AXxs. (AO, Yaakoob, S.)

5 tXxRS c
5. tXxRS [quasi-pass. of 2; (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, individuated; it, or he, had, or assumed, the quality of individuality or personality; syn. taEayRana].

XaxoSN c
XaxoSN The body, or bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance, (sawaAd,) of a man, (S, A, Msb, K,) or some other object or thing, (S, A, K,) which one sees from a distance: (S, A, Msb, K:) applying in common to what is termed juvRapN and what is termed TalalN, in relation to a man; i. e., in relation to a man sitting or sleeping [or lying down], and in relation to a man standing erect: (Msb, voce juvRapN:) or it is applied only to a body, or material substance, composed, [not simple,] and having height: (El-Khattábee, Msb, TA:) or any body, or material thing or substance, [that is somewhat high, and conspicuous, or] having height and appearance: (IAth, TA:) pl. (of pauc., S) OaXoxuSN (S, K) and (of mult., S) OaXoxaASN [which is properly another pl. of pauc.] and XuxuwSN (S, A, K) and XixaASN. (TA.) ― -b2- Then used as signifying (assumed tropical:) A man himself; a man's self, or person; his caAt; (Msb;) [i. e.,] a person; a being; an individual; syn. nafosN [also syn. with caAtN]; (L, TA;) as in the following verse of 'Amr Ibn-Rabee'ah, cited by Sb:
fakaAna mijanRiI duwna mano kunotu OatRaqiI
valaAvu XuxuwSK kaAEibaAni wamuEoSiru
(assumed tropical:) [And three persons, namely, two girls whose breasts were beginning to swell and one who had attained the age of puberty, were my shield against such as I was fearing]: meaning valaAvapu OanofusK: (L:) [the poet making the word in question fem. because it relates here to females: but] Rubeh is related to have said valaAvapu OaXoxuSK, meaning, of women. (M, voce nafosN.) A XaxoS [meaning a person] ceases to be a XxS by its being divided; whereas, when a jisom is divided, no part of it ceases to be a jsm. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. jsm.) It is said in a trad., laA XaxoSa Oagoyaru mina QllRehi (tropical:) [There is not any being more jealous than God]; XxS being here metaphorically used for caAt: or the meaning is, a person (XxS) should not be more jealous than God: but accord. to one relation, the words are laA XaIoCa Oagoyaru mina QllRehi [which has the first of the two meanings mentioned above]. (IAth, TA.) [It is also used in a pl. sense: see a verse of Ziyád el-Aajam in art. AlI.]

XaxiySN c
XaxiySN Big, bulky, or corpulent: (S, K, TA:) or great in XaxoS [or person] and make: (TA:) applied to a man: (S:) fem. with p; (S, A, K;) applied to a woman. (S, A.) ― -b2- A lord, master, chief, man of rank or quality, or a personage. (AZ, K.) ― -b3- manoTiqN XaxiySN (tropical:) Sour, crabbed, or austere, speech. (Ibn-'Abbád, A, K. [See also XaxiysN.])

XaxaASapN c
XaxaASapN Bigness, bulkiness, or corpulence: or greatness of XaxoS [or person] and make. (TA.) [Said to be a subst.: but see XaxuSa.]

XaAxiSN c
XaAxiSN [part. n. of the intrans. verb XaxaSa]. [Hence,] baSarN XaAxiSN (tropical:) [An eye fixedly open: or raised: or sight stretched and raised: see 1]: you say, samiEotu biquduwmika faqalobiI bayona janaAHaIRa raAqiSN wabaSariI taHota HijaAjiI XaAxiSN (tropical:) [I have heard of thy coming, and my heart is throbbing between my two sides, and my eye beneath my bone of the eyebrow fixedly open, &c.]. (A, TA.) With the pl., OaboSaArN, you say XaAxiSapN, (A, Msb, TA,) and XawaAxiSu, (A, TA,) or XuxuwSN [like XuhuwdN as pl. of XaAhidN; if not an inf. n., as which it may be applied, in the place of an epithet, to a pl. subst.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- sahomN XaAxiSN (tropical:) An arrow passing beyond the butt, or object of aim, going above it. (S, A.) You say, rumiIa biAlXRaAxiSaAti (tropical:) [He was shot at with arrows which passed beyond him, going above him: perhaps doubly tropical, meaning he was assailed with invectives which did not harm him]. (A.) ― -b3- XaAxiSN also signifies A man prosecuting war [during three or more days together,] not on alternate days: and of such it is said in a trad., that he may shorten prayer. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XaAxiSN as the act. part. n. of the trans. verb, [for XaAxiSN baSarahu,] (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) [A man raising his eye, or sight, and looking fixedly; as does a dying man: or stretching and raising his sight: (see 1:) or] a man opening his eyes and not moving his eyelids. (S, * Msb.)

maXoxaSN c
[maXoxaSN, as though signifying The place of a XaxoS used in the sense of Suwrapi: accord. to modern usage sing. of] maXaAxiSu deenárs [or pieces of gold] figured [or stamped with effigies]. (TA.)

muXaxRaSN c
muXaxRaSN (tropical:) A thing individuated. (A, TA.)

mutaXaAxiSN c
mutaXaAxiSN Discordant; (A'Obeyd, K;) applied to language, or speech; (A'Obeyd, TA;) and to a thing, or an affair; (TA;) and mutaXaAxisN signifies the same. (A'Obeyd, TA.)

1 XadRa c
1. XadRa, as an intrans. verb, aor.
Xadida
, inf. n. XidRapN: see 8; and see also XidRapN. ― -b2- [Hence,] laXadRa maA is an expression used in the same sense as laEazRa maA (A and K in art. Ez) and laHaqRa maA: (A and TA in that art.:) [and in like manner without the l: thus] one says, XadRa maA OanRaka caAhibN, meaning HaqRa OanRaka caAhibN [i. e. It is distressing, or it distresses me, that thou art going away]: and if you please, you may consider XadRa as similar to niEoma; as when you say, niEoma AlEamalu OanRaka taquwlu AlHaqRa [Excellent, or most excellent, is the deed, thy saying the truth]. (Sb, TA.) [And it is also used to render intensive a verb following it; as in the saying, laXadRa maA OabogaDaniI Much indeed, or greatly indeed, did he hate me.] ― -b3- XadRa Ealayohi, aor.
Xadada
(S, L) and
Xadida
, (L,) inf. n. XadRN (S, L) and XuduwdN, (L,) He charged, or made an assault or attack, upon him, in war, or battle. (S, L.) You say, XadRa EalaI AlEaduwRi XadRapF waAHidapF, and XadRaAtK kaviyrapF, He made one charge, or assault, or attack, upon the enemy, and many charges, &c. (L.) And XadRa EalaI qironihi bisikRiynK, or biEaSFA, He made an assault, or attack, upon his adversary, with a knife, or with a staff; as also Ealayohi AXtdR↓. (Mgh.) And XadRa AlcRiYobu EalaI Alganami The wolf asaulted, or attacked, the sheep or goats. (L.) In the phrase, XadRuwA AlUigaArapa, the meaning is XadRuwA liloUigaArapi [They made a charge for the purpose of a sudden attack upon an enemy, or a predatory incursion]; and therefore AlAgArp is put in the accus. case, not as an objective complement. (Ham p. 8.) ― -b4- XadRa, (S,) aor.
Xaduda
and
Xadida
, (TK,) inf. n. XadRN, (S, L, K,) also signifies He ran; (S, L, * K; *) and so AXtdR↓. (S, L, K.) rubRa XadRK fiI Alkurozi [Many a run is in the sack] is a prov., originating from the fact that a man riding a pregnant mare was pursued by an enemy, and she cast her foal, which ran with its mother, whereupon the horseman alighted, and carried it off in a sack; and the enemy overtook him, and said to him, “Throw to me the foal;” and he replied in these words, meaning that the foal was of generous race: it is applied to him whose internal, or intrinsic, qualities are commended. (Meyd.) And one says, XadRa fiI AlEadowi, (A, Mgh, L,) inf. n. XadRN; (L;) and AXtdR↓; (A, Mgh, L;) He hastened, or was quick, in running: (Mgh, L:) and XadRa AlUiHoDaAra [meaning the same]. (S in art. Afr.) ― -b5- XadRa AlnRahaAru, (S, L,) and AlDRuHaI, (L,) inf. n. XadRN; (L, K; but in the latter, AlnRaAr is erroneously put for AlnRahaAr; TA;) and AXtdR↓; (L;) The day, and the morning, became advanced, the sun being high. (S, * L, K. *) [See also XadRN below.] ＝ -A2- XadRahu, aor.
Xaduda
(S, A, L, Msb) and
Xadida
, the latter anomalous, for the aor. of a trans. verb of this class, of the measure faEala, should be
Xaduda
only, and that of an intrans. verb of the same class and measure should be
Xadida
, and this is the only instance, or almost the only one, of its kind, with both of these forms of aor., except EalRa [and batRa] and namRa AlHadiyva, but there is one trans. verb of the same class having the latter form of aor. only, namely, HabRa, (Fr, S, L,) inf. n. XadRN, (L, Msb, K,) He made it, or rendered it, hard; used in relation to substances and attributes: (L:) he made, or rendered, it, or him, firm, compact, or sound; and strong, powerful, or forcible; vigorous, robust, or sturdy; syn. OaHokamahu, (L,) and qawRaAhu; (S, A, L, K; *) as also XdRdhu↓, [inf. n. taXodiydN,] i. e. as syn. with AHkmhu (L) and qwRAhu: (S, A, L:) he bound, or tied, him, or it, firmly, fast, or strongly; syn. Oawovaqahu: [which may also be meant to convey the signification immediately preceding this last:] (S, L, Msb, K:) and [simply] he tied, bound, or made fast, him, or it; syn. rabaTahu. (S and Msb and K &c. in art. rbT.) One says, XadRa EaDudahu i. e. He
strengthened [his fore arm, or perhaps his upper arm, but the former is app. here meant]. (S, L.) And XadRa EalaI yadihi He strengthened him, [lit. his arm, or hand,] and aided him. (L.) And XadRa QllRehu mulokahu, and XadRadahu↓, God strengthened, or may God strengthen, his dominion. (S, L. [See also a similar ex. voce OazorN.]) And XadRa AlEuqodapa [He tied firmly or fast or strongly, or he pulled tight, or tightened, the knot], (A, Mgh, Msb,) and AlwavaAqa [the bond]. (Kur xlvii. 4.) [And XadRa AldRaAbRapa He bound the saddle on the beast: see an ex. voce daliylN.] XadRu AlrRiHaAli [lit. The binding of the camels' saddles upon their backs] is a metonymical phrase for (tropical:) the going a journey. (Mgh, Msb.) And XadRu AlmiYozari, occurring in a trad., [lit. The binding of the waist-wrapper upon the waist] is a metonymical phrase for (tropical:) the avoiding of women: or the exerting oneself, or employing oneself vigorously or laboriously, in work: or for both of these together. (L.) maA Oamoliku XadRFA walaA UiroxaMCF [lit. I possess not power to tighten nor to slacken] means I am not able to do anything. (TA.) [And XadRahu also signifies He pressed, compressed, or squeezed, it: and he pulled, or strained, it.] waQXodudo EalaI quluwbihimo, in the Kur [x. 88], means And put Thou a seal upon their hearts, so that they may not heed admonition, nor be disposed, or directed, to that which is good. (L.) ＝ -A3- OaXadRu laqado kaAna kacaA, as also OaXadu without teshdeed, means OaXohadu [q. v.]: (K:) a strange saying. (TA.)

2 XadRaRa
2: see the preceding paragraph, latter half, in two places. ― -b2- XdRdhu, inf. n. taXodiydN, also signifies He made it, or rendered it, namely, a beating, and anything, hard to be borne, heavy, vehement, violent, intense, severe, strict, rigorous, or excessive; he intensified it, or aggravated it: (L:) taXodiydN is the contr. of taxofiyfN [in this sense and in other senses here following]. (S.) [Hence, the objective complement being understood,] one says, XdRd Ealayohi, (A, Msb,) which is the contr. of xafRafa [i. e. of xafRafa Eanohu; thus meaning He rendered his burden, suffering, distress, uneasiness, or the like, hard to be borne, heavy, vehement, violent, intense, severe, strict, rigorous, or excessive; intensified it, or aggravated it; or he pressed hard upon him; treated him with hardness, strictness, severity, or rigour]: (Msb:) and mano XadRada XadRada QllRehu Ealayohi [Whoso treateth others hardly, God will treat him hardly]. (A. [See also 8.]) ― -b3- [taXodiydN, as opposed to taxofiyfN, also signifies The characterizing of a letter by a lengthened pronunciation equivalent in grammatical analysis and in prosody to doubling, denoted in writing by the sign called XadRap↓, i. e. by the sign R over that letter; as also tavoqiylN.] ― -b4- See also sadRadahu.

3 XAdRhu c
3. XAdRhu, (A, L,) inf. n. muXaAdRapN and XidaAdN, (L,) He vied with him, contended with him for superiority, or strove to surpass him, in strength, power, or force. (A, L.) [Hence,] mano yuXaAdidi AldRiyna yagolibohu, (A,) or mano yuXaAdRa hecaA AldRiyna bigolibohu, i. e. Whoso contendeth for superiority in strength with this religion, and withstandeth it, or opposeth it, and tasketh himself with religious service beyond his power, it (the religion) will overcome him: a trad. (L.) And lano yuXaAdRa AldRiyna OaHadN UilRaA guliba No one shall contend for superiority in strength with religion, &c. but he will be overcome by the religion. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- See also 5.

4 AXdR c
4. AXdR, (S, A, L, K,) inf. n. UiXodaAdN, (K,) He, (a man, S, L, K, *) or they, (a company of men, A, L,) had, (A, L,) or had with him, (S, L, K,) [or had with them,] a strong beast, (S, L, K,) or strong beasts. (A, L.) ＝ -A2- [maA OaXadRa kacaA How hard, hard to be borne, vehement, violent, intense, or the like, or how great, is such a thing!]

5 tXdRd c
5. tXdRd He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, firmness, strength, vigour, hardiness, courage, vehemence, severity, strictness, or rigour; he exerted his strength, force, or energy; strained, or strained himself, or tasked himself severely; syn. taSalRaba; (A and TA in art. Slb;) and jahada nafosahu; (L;) [fiI AlXRaIoCi in the thing; as also fiyhi XaAdRa↓; for] AlmuXaAdRapu fiI AlXRaIoCi and AltRaXadRudu fiyhi signify the same: (S, L, K: * [see an ex. of tXdRd in the first paragraph of art. jld:]) [and] both of these phrases signify the showing hardness, &c., in the thing. (PS.) You say also tXdRd liloOamori He applied himself with hardness, firmness, vigour, hardiness, severity, or rigour, to the affair. (MA.) And taXadRadati Alqayonapu The slavesongstress strained herself, or tasked herself severely, in raising her voice in singing. (L.) ― -b2- Also He (a man) was, or became, hard, or difficult: you say, saOalonaA fulaAnFA HaAjapF fataXadRada EalayonaA [We asked of such a one a thing wanted, and he was hard, or difficult, to us]. (TA in art. wEr.) ― -b3- And He was, or became, niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious. (MA, KL.)

6 tXAdRwA c
6. tXAdRwA [They vied, contended for superiority, or strove to surpass one another, in strength, power, or force: see 3]. (TA in art. Hms: there coupled with AiqotataluwA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

8 AXtdR c
8. AXtdR; (S, A, L, Msb;) and XadRa↓, aor
Xadida
, (L, Msb,) the only form of its aor., (L,) inf. n. XidRapN, (S, Msb,) whence the former verb; (S;) and tXAdR↓; (L;) It was, or became, hard, (L, and MA and KL and PS in explanation of the first,) said of a substance and of an attribute: (L:) it, or he, was, or became, firm, compact, or sound; (L &c. as above;) strong, powerful, or forcible; vigorous, robust, or sturdy; (L, and A and MA and KL in explanation of the first, and Msb in explanation of the second:) [also it was, or became, bound, or tied, firmly, fast, or strongly:] and the first of these verbs, [and the second also,] it was, or became, hard to be borne, heavy, vehement, violent, intense, pressing, severe, strict, rigorous, tight, strait or difficult, distressing or distressful, afflictive, calamitous, or adverse. (MA, L, KL.) It is said in a trad., laA tabiyEuwA AlHabRa HatRaI yaXotadRa i. e. [Ye shall not sell grain] until it becomes hard, or firm, or strong. (L.) And you say, AXtdRt AlEuqodapu [The knot became tied firmly, fast, or strongly; or became tight]. (A, Mgh, Msb.) And AXtdR AlzRamanu Ealayohimo The time, or fortune, became hard upon them; or severe, rigorous, distressful, afflictive, calamitous, or adverse, to them. (L. [See also 2.]) And AXtdR bihi AlOamoru [The affair, or event, distressed, or afflicted, him; like AXtdR Ealayohi]. (L in art. jd, &c.) ― -b2- See also 1, former half, in four places.

XadRN c
XadRN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, L, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] XadRu AlnRahaAri, and XadRu AlDRuHaI, The time when the day, and the morning, is advanced, the sun being high. (L.) One says, jiYotuka XadRa AlnRahaAri, and XadRa AlDRuHaI, (L, and the like is said in the A,) and fiI XadRi AlnRahaAri, and fiI XadRi AlDRuHaI, (L,) I came to thee in the time when the day, and the morning, was advanced, the sun being high. (A, * L.)

XadRapN c
XadRapN [inf. n. of un. of XadRahu: as such signifying] A single act [of making, or rendering, hard, firm, compact, or sound; strong, powerful, or forcible: and] of binding, or tying, firmly, fast, or strongly. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 2, last sentence but one. ＝ -A2- Also [inf. n. of un. of the intrans. verb XadRa: as such signifying] A single charge or assault or attack in war or battle. (S, A, * Mgh, L, K. *)

XidRapN c
XidRapN inf. n. of XadRa↓ (L, Msb) as syn. with AiXotadRa: (L:) [and] a subst. from [i. e. syn. with] AiXotidaAdN: (K:) The attribute denoted by the epithet XadiydN: (S:) hardness, (A, MA, L,) in substances and in attributes; (L;) firmness, compactness, or soundness; strength, power, or force; vigour, robustness, sturdiness, or hardiness; (MA, L; see OaXudRN, which, accord. to some, is a pl. of XidRapN;) courage, bravery, firmness of heart: (L:) niggardliness, tenaciousness, or avarice: (A: [see also 5, last sentence:]) vehemence, violence, intenseness, stress, pressure, severity, strictness, rigour, tightness, straitness or difficulty: (MA:) hardship, rigour of fortune: (MA, L:) famine, dearth, want of victuals; hardness, straitness, or difficulty, of subsistence [&c.]: (L:) trouble, distress, affliction, calamity, or adversity; (MA, L;) as also [XudRaI↓, in these as well as in some of the preceding senses, and] XadiydapN↓, [rather meaning a hard, or distressing, event, an affliction, or a calamity, and rarely used,] of which, (L,) or of XidRapN, (MA, L,) the pl. is XadaAYidu, (MA, L,) agreeably with analogy if of XadiydapN, but extr. if of XidRapN: and this pl. also signifies seditions, discords, or dissensions, whereby men are put into a state of commotion: (L:) and the rigours, or pangs, (gamaraAt,) of death: (S and Msb in art. gmr:) accord. to Sb, the pl of XidRapN is XidadN, which, he says, preserves its original form [without idghám] because it does not resemble a verb. (L.) One says, qaAsayotu minohu XidRapF [I endured, from him, hardness, &c.; or from it, hardship, &c.]. (A.) And fulaAnK xfotu XudRaI↓ meaning XidRatahu
[i. e. I feared the hardness, &c., of such a one]: so says AZ: and he cites this verse:
faUinRiI laA Oaliynu liqawoli XudRaI↓
mina AlHadiydi walawo kaAnato OaXadRa↓
[And, or for, I will not become gentle for a hard saying, (lit. a saying of hardness,) though it should be harder than iron]. (L.) And OaSaAbatoniI XudRaI↓ meaning XidRapN [i. e. Hardship, &c., befell me]. (AZ, S.) [And XidRapN also signifies A strong, an intense, or a great, degree of any quality &c.]

XudRaI c
XudRaI: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

XadiydN c
XadiydN Possessing the quality of XidRap: (S, L:) i. e. hard; applied to a substance and to an attribute: firm, compact, or sound: (L:) strong, powerful, forceful; vigorous, robust, sturdy, or hardy; (A, Mgh, L, Msb;) applied to a thing, (Msb,) and to a man; (A, Mgh, L;) as also Xadiydu AlquwaI: (Mgh:) pl., applied to men, OaXidRaMCu and [applied to things and men] XidaAdN (A, L) and XududN, (Sb, L,) which last preserves its original form [without idghám] because not resembling a verb: (L:) also courageous, brave, firm of heart: (L, K: *) and niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious; (A, L, Msb, K;) as also mutaXadRidN↓: (S, A, L, K:) and [as is implied by the first explanation above, and shown by frequent usage,] vehement, violent, intense, pressing, severe, strict, rigorous, tight, strait or difficult, hard as meaning hard to be borne, troublesome, distressing or distressful, afflictive, calamitous, or adverse. (L, KL, PS, &c.) You say, huwa XadiydN EalaI qawomihi [He is hard, or severe, or rigorous, to his people]. (A.) [And XadiydN EalaI kacaA Niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious, of such a thing.] Aboo-Dhu-eyb says, using Xadiyd in the sense of XaHiyH,
HadaronaAhu biAlOavowaAbi fiI qaEori huwRapK
XadiydK EalaI maA DumRa fiI AllRaHodi juwluhaA
[We lowered him, with the grave-clothes, into the bottom of a cavity in the ground, the sides whereof were tenacious of what was comprised in the lateral hollow which was the place of the corpse]. (L.) And the words of the Kur [c. 8], waUinRahu liHubRi Alxayori laXadiydN, accord. to Zj, mean And verily, on account of the love of wealth, he is niggardly, or tenacious, or avaricious. (L.) Xadiydu AlEayoni applied to a man, and Xadiyodapu jafoni AlEayoni metaphorically applied by a poet to a she-camel, mean Whom sleep does not overcome. (L.) And AlXRadiydu means The lion; (K;) because of his strength and hardiness. (TA.) [Xadiyd with a subst. or an inf. n. following it in the gen. case, the latter having the article Al prefixed to it, or being prefixed to another noun in the gen. case, supplies the place of an intensive epithet; as in Xadiydu AlsRawaAdi Intensely, or very, black; and Xadiydu AlgaDabi Vehemently, or exceedingly, or very, angry; and] misokN Xadiydu AlrRaAYiHapi Strong-smelling musk; (L;) [and rajulN Xadiydu bayaADi AlEayoni A man intensely white in the eye.] ― -b2- AlHuruwfu AlXRadiydapu [The strong letters] are those letters which, in a state of quiescence, prevent the current of the voice in their utterance; namely O, b, t, j, d, T, q, and k; (TA;) the letters comprised in the words Oajadota Tabaqaka. (K.)

XadiydapN c
XadiydapN [as a subst. from XadiydN, rendered such by the affix p]: see XidRapN.

OaXadRu c
OaXadRu [Possessing the quality of XidRap, in a greater, and in the greatest, degree; i. e. more, and most, hard, &c.]. See an ex. in a verse cited voce XidRapN. Halabota biAlsRaAEidi AlOaXadRi, or HalabotuhaA Alx, is a prov., expl. in art. Hlb. And baqiIa OaXadRuhu. [The hardest part of it has remained] is another prov., applied to him who attains a part of that which he wants, and is unable to attain the completion thereof. (TA. [See also Freytag's “ Arab. Prov., ” i. 169.]) [With an indeterminate subst. or inf. n. following it in the accus. case, it supplies the place of a simple epithet denoting the comparative and superlative degrees; as in OaXadRu sawaAdFA More, and most, black; and OaXadRu gaDabFA More, and most, angry.] ― -b2- OaXadRu AlnRahaAri The time when the day is most advanced, the sun being at the highest. (L. [See XadRu AlnRahaAri.])

OaXudRN c
OaXudRN, (S, A, Mgh, L, K, &c.,) also pronounced OuXudRN, (Seer, K,) but the latter form is rare, (TA,) is both masc. and fem., (Zj, TA,) and as used in the Kur it has somewhat different meanings: (Az, TA:) in the phrase HatRaI yaboluga OaXudRahu, (S, K,) and other phrases in the Kur, (TA,) OaXudR is expl. as meaning The state of strength; (S, Mgh, L, K;) which is from eighteen to thirty years: (S, L, K:) or from about seventeen to forty: (Zj:) or from thirty to forty: (Zj in another place:) or puberty: (Az, Mgh, L:) or firmness, or soundness, of judgment, produced by experience: (L:) or puberty together with such maturity as gives evidence of rectitude of conduct or course of life; (Zj, Az, Mgh, L;) which may be at, or before, the age of eighteen years; accord. to most of the men of science, and among them Esh-Sháfi'ee; (Zj, Az, L;) and the extreme term of which is three and thirty years: (Mgh:) or the age of forty years; as in the Kur xlvi. 14: (L:) OaXudRN [originally OaXodudN] is a sing. having a pl. form, like MnukN; and these two words are [said to be] the only instances of the kind: (S, K: [but see MnukN:]) or a pl. having no proper sing., (S, Mgh, K,) like MsaAlN and OabaAbiylu and EabaAdiydu and macaAkiyru: (S:) or its sing. is XidRapN↓, (AHeyth, S, Mgh, K,) accord. to Sb; and this is good with respect to the meaning, because one says, balaga AlgulaAmu XidRatahu; (S;) but fiEolapN does not form a pl. of the measure OafoEulN; (S, K;) for as to OanoEumN, (S,) which is said by AHeyth to be pl. of niEomapN, (TA,) [and respecting which Mtr says that] OaXudRN is said to be pl. of XidRapN like as OanoEumN is of niEomapN, formed by regarding the p as elided, (Mgh, [and AHeyth says the like,]) it is only pl. of nuEomN in the phrase yawomu nuEomK: (S:) or its sing. is XadRN, like as kalobN is of OakolubN; or XidRN, like as ciYobN is of OacoWubN; (S, K;) accord. to some; (S;) but neither XadRN nor XidRN has been heard from the Arabs [as sing. of OaXudRN]; and they are only deduced from analogy: (S, K:) or it is pl. of OaXadRu; and the O is not regarded in the formation of this pl. (IJ, from A 'Obeyd.)

maXadRu AlEiSaAbapi c
maXadRu AlEiSaAbapi [The place, or part, where the fillet, or the like, is bound, or tied]. (A.)

muXidRN c
muXidRN A man having, (A, Mgh, L,) or having with him, (L,) a strong beast, (A, Mgh, L,) or strong beasts; (L;) contr. of muDoEifN. (Mgh, L.) It is said in a trad., yarudRu muXidRuhumo EalaI muDoEifihimo [He among them who has a strong beast, or strong beasts, shall give back a portion of the spoil to him of them who has a weak beast, or weak beasts]; meaning that the strong warrior and plunderer shall share with (yusaAhimu) the weak in the plunder that he gains. (L.)

mutaXadRidN c
mutaXadRidN: see XadiydN.

1 Xadaxa c
1. Xadaxa, (S, A, Msb, &c.,) aor.
Xadaxa
, (Msb, K, *) inf. n. XadoxN, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) He broke, or crushed, syn. kasara, (S, A, Msb, K,) and faDaxa, (TA, and Ham p. 363,) or haXRama, (TA,) a hollow thing, (S, A, L, TA,) or a soft, or tender, or an easily-broken, thing, (A,) or a moist thing, (K,) or a moist and soft thing, such as the Earofaj and the like, (L, TA,) a person's head, (S, A, L, Msb, TA,) and a colocynth, and an unripe date, (A,) and any hollow bone, and a rod, (Msb,) or, as some say, a dry thing, (K,) with the hand, or with a stone &c.: (Ham ubi suprà:) or he pressed, or squeezed, syn. gamaza, [app. so as to crush,] a hollow thing, or a soft, or tender, or an easilybroken, thing, as a head, and a colocynth, and an unripe date. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Xadaxa dimaMCahumo taHota qadamihi (tropical:) He made their blood (lit. bloods) to go for nothing, or to be of no account. (A, K. *) And [simply] Xadaxa AldRimaMCa (assumed tropical:) He made the blood [of men] (lit. bloods) to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by mulcts; or to be of no account. (Ham p. 91.) And Xadaxotu AldRiyaAta taHota qadamaIRa (assumed tropical:) I made the bloodwits to be of no account [so that they should not be exacted]. (Ham ibid.) ― -b3- And Xadaxahu He hit, or hurt, his muXadRax, i. e. the part of the neck so called. (K.) ＝ -A2- And Xadaxa aor.
Xadaxa
, (TA,) inf. n. XadoxN (K, TA) and XuduwxN, (TA,) He, (a man, TK,) or it, (a thing, or an affair, TA,) deviated, or declined, (K, TA,) from the right course, aim, or scope, (TA,) or from the [proper] way. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- Xadaxati AlgurRapu, (S, TA,) aor.
Xadaxa
, (TA,) inf. n. XadoxN (K, TA) and XuduwxN, (TA,) The blaze on the horse's forehead spread widely upon the face (S) [from the forelock to the nose, without reaching to the eyes: see XaAdixapN]: or spread, and extended downwards, (K, TA,) filling the forehead, without reaching
to the eyes: or covered the face from the root of the forelock to the nose. (TA.)

2 XadRaxotu AlrRuWuwsa c
2. XadRaxotu AlrRuWuwsa I broke, or crushed, the heads; or did so much: the verb is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or application to many objects. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [And XdRx Albusora He pressed, or squeezed, the unripe dates, so as to crush them: see muXadRaxN.]

5 taXadRaxa
5: see what next follows.

7 AnXdx c
7. AnXdx It was, or became, broken, or crushed; (S, A, Msb, K, TA;) said of a hollow thing, (S, A, TA,) or a soft, or tender, or an easily-broken thing, (A,) or a moist thing, (K,) or a moist and soft thing, (TA,) a person's head, (S, A, Msb, TA,) a colocynth, and an unripe date, (A,) and any hollow bone, and a rod, (Msb,) or, as some say, a dry thing; (K;) and so tXdRx↓ [but app. implying muchness, or frequency, or relation to many things, as quasi-pass. of 2, q. v., whereas the former verb is quasi-pass. of 1]: (K:) or it was, or became, pressed or squeezed [app. so as to be crushed; or it was, or became, crushed by being pressed or squeezed: see muXadRaxN]. (A.)

XadaxN c
XadaxN An abortive fœtus, (L, K, TA,) in a soft, or tender, state, before it has become firm. (L, TA.) ― -b2- See also XaAdixN, in two places.

XadoxapN c
XadoxapN A soft, or tender, or succulent, plant: (K:) applied in the M as an epithet to the species of plant called Eijolap. (TA.)

XaAdixN c
XaAdixN A child that is soft, or tender; (K;) as also XadaxN↓: (IAar, L:) or gulaAmN XaAdixN signifies a youth: (A:) accord. to IAar, a boy is called jaforN; then, yaAfiEN; then, XadaxN↓; then, muTabRixN; and then, kawokabN. (TA. [See also muTabRixN.]) ＝ -A2- Also A thing, or an affair, deviating from the right course, aim, or scope, (K, TA,) or from its [proper] way. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

XaAdixapN c
XaAdixapN, [as a subst.,] (S, L, K, TA,) or gurRapN XaAdixapN↓, (A,) A blaze on a horse's forehead spreading [widely (see 1)] upon the face, (S,) or covering the face, (A,) from the forelock to the nose, (S, A,) without reaching to the eyes: (S:) or spreading, and extending downwards, (K, TA,) filling the forehead, without reaching to the eyes: or covering the face from the root of the forelock to the nose: (TA:) or such as is long; such as is round being called watiyrapN. (AO, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A notorious, and a bad, or an evil, an abominable, or a foul, deed. (S, TA.) A rájiz says,
laA humRa UinRa AlHaAriva bona jabalaho
zanRaI EalaI Oabiyhi vumRa qatalaho
warakiba AlXRaAdixapa AlmuHajRalaho
i. e. [O God, (laAhumRa being for AallRehumRa,) verily El- Hárith Ibn-Jebeleh straitened, or oppressed, his father, (zanRaI being for zanRaOa,) then slew him,] and committed a bad and notorious deed in slaying him. (S.)

OaXodaxu c
OaXodaxu A horse having a blaze such as is termed XaAdixapN: fem. XadoxaMCu. (K, L, TA.) ― -b2- AlOaXodaxu The lion. (K.)

muXadRaxN c
muXadRaxN Unripe dates pressed, or squeezed, (yugomazu, in some copies of the S and K and in the L and TA yugomaru, [but the former I think to be evidently the right reading,]) until they become broken or crushed (yanoXadixu), (S, A, * L, K,) and dried for the winter, (A,) or then dried in the winter. (L.) ＝ -A2- AlmuXadRaxu i. q. muqaTRaEu AlEunuqi [app. meaning The part of the neck where it is cut up by the butcher]. (K.)

miXodaAxN c
miXodaAxN [A post-classical term] A surgical instrument with which the head of the fœtus is crushed [in the womb]. (Albucasis de Chirurgia, p. 342.)

1 Xadiqa c
1. Xadiqa, inf. n. XadaqN, said of a man, He was wide in the Xidoq [q. v.]. (M, TA. *) ― -b2- And He was eloquent. (TA.)

5 tXdRq c
5. tXdRq He twisted his XidoqaAni, [i. e. the two sides of his mouth, or the quivering flesh of his mouth, inside his cheeks,] in order to affect clearness, or distinctness, of speech, or to be more clear, or distinct, in speech. (K.) And tXdRq fiI kalaAmihi He opened his mouth and was diffuse in his speech. (M, TA.)

XadoqN c
XadoqN: see what next follows.

XidoqN c
XidoqN (Lth, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and XadoqN↓ (Lth, M, O, Msb, K) The quivering flesh (TafoTafap) of the mouth, inside the two cheeks; (Lth, O, K;) or so the dual of each: (M:) or the side of the mouth; (S, Mgh, Msb;) so says Az: (Msb:) pl. (of the former, S, Msb) OaXodaAqN (Lth, S, M, O, Msb, K) and (of the latter, Msb, TA) XuduwqN. (M, Msb, TA.) One says, nafaxa fiI Xidoqayohi [He blew in the sides of his mouth so as to distend them]. (S.) And UinRahu lawaAsiEu AlOaXodaAqi, meaning [Verily he is wide] in the Xidoq; using the pl. as a sing.; a phrase mentioned by Lh. (M, TA.) XidoqaA Alfarasi means The chink of the mouth of the horse, to the extremity thereof at [the place of] the bit [on each side]. (M.) tarokabu XidoqahaA mina AlnRaXaATi [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) She goes at random, (like tarokabu raOosahaA,) by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness,] is said of a woman and of a she-camel and of a mare. (K voce miDoraArN.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) The two sides of a valley; as also XadiyqN↓: (K:) or the duals, XidoqaAni and XadoqaAni, have this signification; the sings. signify the side of a valley; (O;) or so XidoqN, with kesr; (Msb;) and so XadiyqN↓. (O.)

XadaqN c
XadaqN [mentioned above as inf. n. of 1] Wideness of the Xidoq: (S, K:) or, as in the T, wideness of the XidoqaAni. (TA.) ― -b2- And Eloquence. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- and (assumed tropical:) A bending, or winding, in a valley. (TA.)

XidaAqN c
XidaAqN A certain brand with which a camel is marked upon the Xidoq. (M, TA.)

XadiyqN c
XadiyqN: see XidoqN, in two places.

XadoqamN c
XadoqamN and XadoqamiIRN: see the next paragraph; the former in three places: and see also art. Xdqm.

OaXodaqu c
OaXodaqu A man wide in the Xidoq: (M:) or a man wide in the XidoqaAni: (Mgh, Msb:) or wide in the Xidoq, and inclining therein in any manner: (TA:) fem. XadoqaMCu: (M, K:) and pl. XudoqN: (K:) and XadoqamN↓ and XadoqamiIRN↓ signify the same as OaXodaqu; the m being augmentative, as in fusoHumN and sutohumN; or, accord. to IJ, it is radical: (M, TA:) whence, i. e. from XadoqamN in the sense expl. above, (I 'Ab, TA,) one says also XidoqN XadoqamN↓, meaning a wide Xdq: (I 'Ab, M, TA:) and XafapN XadoqaMCu means a lip wide in the part where each Xidoq is cleft [by the extremity of the mouth]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- It is also applied as an epithet to an orator, (S, M, K, TA,) meaning Eloquent; (M, K, TA;) good and eloquent in speech; (M, * TA;) and so XadoqamN↓. (TA.)

mutaXadRiqN c
mutaXadRiqN One who twists his XidoqaAni in order to affect clearness, or distinctness, of speech, or to be more clear, or distinct, in speech. (S. [See 5.]) ― -b2- Diffuse in speech, without preparation, or caution, or precaution: or one who ridicules men, twisting his XidoqaAni with them and against them. (TA.) And mutaXadRiqN fiI manoTiqihi Diffuse in his speech. (TA.)

XadoqamN c
XadoqamN Wide in the Xidoq [or side of the mouth]; (S, K;) applied to a man; as also XadoqamiIRN↓; (TA;) and XudaAqimN↓: (K, TA:) [mentioned under this head in the S and K, but] the m is augmentative. (Az, S.) It has been erroneously said that it is with the pointed c. (MF.) ― -b2- See also OaXodaqu. ― -b3- Also The lion; (K;) and so XudaAqimN↓. (IB, TA.) ― -b4- And A certain stallion-camel belonging to En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir: whence XadoqimiyRaAtN↓ Certain camels, so called in relation to that stallion. (S, K.)

XadoqamiIRN c
XadoqamiIRN: and XadoqamiyRaAtN: see the preceding paragraph.

XudaAqimN c
XudaAqimN: see the first paragraph, in two places.

1 Xadana c
1. Xadana, (S, K,) aor.
Xaduna
, (S,) inf. n. XuduwnN, (S, K,) said of a gazelle, and of the young of any cloven-hoofed animal, and camel, and solid-hoofed animal, He became strong, and in no need of his mother: (K:) or he became strong, and in a good state of body, and active and grown up, and vied with his mother in his faculties [so I render
maAlaka OumRahu of which I do not find any explanation] so that he went along with her; and [in this sense] it is said of a colt also: (TA:) or, said of a young gazelle, he became strong, and his horns came forth, and he became in no need of his mother: and sometimes it is said of a colt [in a similar sense]. (S.) Hence, it is said of a boy, meaning He became strong, and active and grown up. (Har p. 536.)

4 AXdnt c
4. AXdnt She (a gazelle) had a young one that had become such as is termed XaAdin. (S, K.)

XadonN c
XadonN A kind of tree, (K, TA,) having weak, or soft, and thick stems, (TA,) the flower of which is like the jasmine (K, TA) in form, but tinged with redness, and more pleasant [in odour] than the jasmine; said by IB to be of pleasant odour. (TA.)

XadaniyRaAtN c
XadaniyRaAtN Certain she-camels, so called in relation to a place in El-Yemen, (S, K, and EM p. 229,) named Xadan: (TA, EM:) or in relation to a certain stallion. (IAar, K, TA. [In the CK, faHolN is erroneously put for faHolK.])

XaAdinN c
XaAdinN A young gazelle that has become strong, and whose horns have come forth, and that has become in no need of his mother: (A 'Obeyd, TA: [see XaSarN:]) when used alone, [not as an epithet, in which quality it seems to be applied also to the young of any cloven-hoofed animal, and camel, and solid-hoofed animal, (see 1,)] it means [simply] a young gazelle. (S, TA.)

muXodinN c
muXodinN [without p] A doe-gazelle whose young one has become such as is termed XaAdin: (S, K, TA:) or who has a XaAdin following her: and in like manner applied to other animals of the clovenhoofed kind, and of the solid-hoofed, and to a camel: (TA:) pl. maXaAdinu and maXaAdiynu, (S, K,) like maTaAfilu and maTaAfiylu, (S,) [pls. of muTofilN,] the latter pl. anomalous. (TA.)

maXoduwnapN c
maXoduwnapN, applied to a girl, i. q. EaAtiqN [i. e. That has newly attained to puberty, and has not been married; or that is between the periods of puberty and middle age; &c.]. (IAar, K.)

1 Xudiha c
1. Xudiha, (JK, S, K,) inf. n. XadohN, (S,) He (a man, JK, S) became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or became bereft of his reason or intellect; i. q. duhiXa: (JK, S, K:) and also, (K,) or, accord. to AZ, only, (S,) he was, or became, busied, occupied, or employed; or busied, &c., so as to be diverted from something; or diverted from a thing by being busied; syn. Xugila: (S, K:) and he was caused to become confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; (K;) as also AnXdh↓, or AXtdh↓, (K, accord. to different copies: the former accord. to the TA.) Accord. to Az, XadohN is not from AldRahaXu, as it is thought to be by some [and as is implied by what here follows]. (TA.) ― -b2- Xadahahu He confounded, or perplexed, him, so that he was unable to see his right course; or bereft him of his reason or intellect; syn. OadohaXahu; (K;) as also AXdhhu↓: (A 'Obeyd, K:) or the former verb, in the act. form, has not been heard: (Har p. 64:) and [it is asserted that] one does not say AXdhhu↓. (JK.) ＝ -A2- Xadaha raOosahu i. q. Xadaxahu [i. e. He broke his head]. (K.)

maXaAdihu c
maXaAdihu [a pl. of which the sing. is app. maXodahapN] Things that cause one to be busied, occupied, or employed; or busied, &c., so as to be diverted from something; or diverted from a thing by being busied; syn. maXaAgilu [pl. of maXogalapN]. (Z, K.)

1 XadaA c
1. XadaA, (Msb, K,) first pers. Xadawotu, (S,) aor.
Xaduwa
, (Msb,) inf. n. XadowN, (S, Msb,) He drove camels: (S, K:) or he collected and drove a detached number of a herd of camels. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) XadaA, (Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He acquired somewhat of polite literature, (S, Msb, K, TA,) or of science, and guided himself thereby to the knowledge of somewhat more, (Msb,) and likewise of song; (TA;) as though he drove it and collected it: (S, TA:) or XadaA mina AlEilomi, and mina AlginaMCi, (MA, TA,) XayoYFA, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (MA, TA,) he acquired somewhat of science, and of song: (MA:) or he knew well some sort of science, and of song; and so of other things. (TA.) XadowN signifies (assumed tropical:) A man's doing well, or knowing well, somewhat of a thing or an affair. (TA.) And Xadawotu minohu baEoDa AlmaEorifapi means I knew [somewhat of] him, or it, [but] not well. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) He recited a verse, or two verses, (S, K,) singing, (K,) or prolonging, or straining, his voice, as in singing [and as is commonly done in the driving of camels; whence, app., this meaning of the verb]. (S.) And XadaA XiEorFA, (S, K,) or ginaMCF, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He sang poetry, (S, K,) or a song: (S:) or he recited it with a trilling, or quavering, or prolonging and modulating of the voice. (S.) ― -b4- And XadaA Xadowahu i. q. naHaA naHowahu (assumed tropical:) [He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed his course, towards him, or it; agreeably with the explanation in the TK: or he purposed his (another's) purpose]. (K.) ― -b5- And XadaA fulaAnFA fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) He assimilated such a one to such a one; or he likened such a one to such a one; syn. XabRahahu UiyRaAhu. (ISd, K, TA. [In the CK, fulaAnFA is not repeated.])

4 AXdI c
4. AXdI (assumed tropical:) He became a good, or an excellent, modulator of his voice, or maker of melody. (K.)

XadFA c
XadFA A remnant of strength; and a portion, or somewhat, thereof: (K:) a dial. var. of XacFA. (TA. [See XacaApN, in art. Xcw.]) A remnant, or remainder, of anything. (TA.) A small quantity or number: (TA:) and so XadowN↓, (M, K,) whatever it be, (M, TA,) of much or many, (M, K,) whatever the latter be. (K.) And The extremity of anything: (K:) a dial. var. of XacFA. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Heat. (K.) ＝ -A3- And Mange, or scab: (K: [in the CK, AlHarobu is put for Aljarabu:]) a dial. var. of XacFA. (TA.)

XadowN c
XadowN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XaAdK c
XaAdK act. part. n. of 1; signifying Driving, or a driver of, camels: &c.: (K, * TA:) pl. XudaApN. (TA.) ― -b2- [And particularly] (assumed tropical:) One who acquires somewhat of polite literature, (S, Msb,) and of science, and guides himself thereby to the knowledge of somewhat more. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A reciter of verses, who sings in reciting, or prolongs, or strains, his voice, as in singing: a singer of poetry: (TA:) [and simply] a singer. (S.)

1 XacRa c
1. XacRa, (S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
Xacica
and
Xacuca
, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) the former agreeable with analogy, and that which is mentioned by the leading writers on inflection, and the latter anomalous, (TA,) and Esh-Shiháb mentions
Xacaca
, but this is not known, and there is no reason for it unless faEila be established as a form of the pret., and this has not been mentioned, (MF,) inf. n. XucuwcN (S, M, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and XacRN, (M, L, K,) It (a thing, M, L) was, or became, apart, (S, A, L, Msb,) and it fell, or went, or came, out, or forth, (S, M, L, K,) from the generality of things, or the general assemblage, main body, bulk, or common mass, (S, M, A, L, K,) to which it pertained, (M, L,) or from other things: (Msb:) it (anything) was, or became, apart, or alone: and he (a man) was, or became, apart from his companions, or alone: (Lth, L:) and (assumed tropical:) he [app. a beast] took fright, and ran away. (Msb.) You say, XacRa Eanohu It was, or became, apart, &c., from it. (S, L.) And XacRa Eani AljamaAEapi He was, or became, apart from the collective body [or generality] of people. (Mgh.) And maA yaXicRu Ealayohi XaIoCK (assumed tropical:) [Nothing is out of his way, or sphere, or compass]. (S and K in art. Hwc.) And XacRa AlHaSaI The pebbles became scat-
tered, or dispersed. (L.) ― -b2- XacRa, aor.
Xacica
and
Xacuca
, inf. n. XucuwcN and XacRN, also signifies (tropical:) It (a word, form or measure, construction, or government,) deviated from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of analogy, or rule; deviated from common, or constant, analogy, or rule; was extraordinary, or exceptional, as to rule; or was anomalous, abnormal, or irregular: and it (the same) deviated from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of usage; deviated from common, or constant, usage; was extraordinary, or exceptional, as to usage; or was unusual: [the verb is used absolutely to express each of these meanings; the context in general showing clearly which meaning is intended: the former is that which is most frequently intended: and] the former meaning is also expressed by the phrase XacRa fiI AlqiyaAsi or Eani AlqiyaAsi: and the latter, by the phrase XacRa fiI AlAisotiEomaAli. (Mz, 12th nwE.) [See also the contr. AiTRarada: and see XaAcRN, below.] ＝ -A2- See also 4.

4. AXcRhu; (S, M, K;) and XcRchu↓; (K;) and XacRahu↓, aor.
Xacuca
, only; (M, K;) but As disallows this last form of the verb; (IJ, L;) He, or it, caused it to be, or to become, apart, (S, L,) to fall, or go, or come, out, or forth, from the generality of things, or the general assemblage, main body, bulk, or common mass, (S, M, L, K,) to which it pertained: (M, L:) and the first signifies he removed it, and put it far away; namely, a thing: (K:) and he set him, or exposed him, apart from his companions, or alone: (IJ, L:) and he scattered, or dispersed, it. (IKtt.) A poet says,
faOaXacRaniI limuruwrihimo fakaOanRaniI
guSonN liOawRali EaADidK Oawo EaASifi
[And he, or it, (perhaps meaning fortune,) exposed me apart from my companions, to their passing by, or by reason of their passing away, so that I was as though I were a branch that should become a prey for the first lopper or stormy wind]. (IJ, L.) And one says of a she-camel, AXcRt AlHaSaI She scattered, or dispersed, the pebbles [with her feet]. (TA.) ― -b2- AXcR also signifies naAdRK jaMCa biqawolK XaAcRK↓ (assumed tropical:) [He said what deviated from the common course of speech]. (K, TA.)

XacRaAn c
XacRaAn: see XaAcRN, in four places.

XicRaAnN c
XicRaAnN The [species of lote-tree called] sidor. (K.)

XaAcRN c
XaAcRN A thing that is, or becomes, apart, (S, L, Msb,) and that falls, or goes, or comes, out, or forth, from the generality of things, general assemblage, main body, bulk, or common mass, (S, L,) to which it pertains: (L:) anything apart, or alone: and a man apart from his companions, or alone: (Lth, L:) and [app. a beast] taking fright, and running away: (Msb:) XucRaAnN is a pl. thereof, like as XubRaAnN is of XaAbRN; [and so is XucRaAcN, agreeably with analogy;] and XacRaAn↓ is used in a similar sense, but is an epithet of the measure fiEolaAn, not a pl. of XaAcRN. (L.) maA yadaEu fulaAnN XaAcRFA walaA naAdRFA UilRaA qatalahu [Such a one does not leave any one apart from his companions, nor any one taking fright and running away, but he slays him,] is said of a courageous man whom no one encounters without his slaying him. (IAar, L.) And one says XucRaAnu qawomK Those, of a people, who have become apart, or separate, from their companions. (L, from a trad.) And XucRaAcu AlnRaAsi Those who are among a people but do not belong to their tribes (S, L) nor to their places of abode: (L:) and those who are scattered, or dispersed, of people; (A, L;) as also AlnRaAsi XacRaAnu↓, (S, L,) and XucRaAnuhumo. (L.) And qawomN XucRaAcN A people not among their own tribe nor in their own places of abode: (L, K: *) or a people among another people, not among their own tribes nor in their own places of abode. (M, TA.) And XucRaAcu AlMfaAqi The strangers. (Har p. 352.) And jaAWuwA XucRaAcFA They came few in number. (L, K. *) And AlUibili XacRaAnu↓ and XucRaAnuhaA Those that are scattered, or dispersed, of the camels. (L.) And XucRaAnu AlHaSaI (M, L) and AlHaSaI XacRaAnu↓ (S, IJ, M, L, K) What are scatterred, or dispersed, of pebbles; (S, L, K;) what have flown about, and become scattered or dispersed, thereof: (M, L:) and in like manner one says of other things, (L, K,) or of similar things. (M, L.) ― -b2- Applied to a word, form or measure, construction, or government, it signifies (tropical:) Deviating from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of analogy, or rule; deviating from common, or constant, analogy or rule; extraordinary, or exceptional, as to rule; or anomalous, abnormal, or irregular: such a word, &c., though itself admitted if agreeable with common usage, is not taken as an example to be imitated: also, applied to the same, deviating from the common, or constant, course of speech in respect of usage; deviating from common, or constant, usage; extraordinary, or exceptional, as to usage; unusual: [used absolutely to express each of these significations; the context in general showing clearly which signification is meant: the former is that which is most frequently intended:] a word, &c., may be XAcR in respect of usage but agreeable with common analogy or rule; as the pret. of yacaru and yadaEu; and the regular phrase makaAnN muboqilN, the epithet more commonly heard being baAqilN: and XAcR in respect of analogy, or rule, but agreeable with common usage; as OaxowaSa AlrRimovu, and AisotaSowabotu AlOamora: and XAcR in respect of analogy, or rule, and of usage, together; as vawobN maSowuwnN, and misokN madowuwfN: (Mz, 12th nwE: [and the like is said, but less fully, in the Msb:]) the pl. masc. is XucRaAcN; and pl. fem. XawaAcRu. (Mz, ib.) See 4, last sentence. [See also the contr. muTRaridN: and see XacRa, latter part.] ― -b3- Applied to a tradition, (assumed tropical:) Having a single ascription, attested by a [single] sheykh, whether he be trustworthy or not: in the latter case, not accepted: in the former case, one hesitates respecting it, and does not adduce it as an argument, or evidence. (KT.)

and

, (K,) inf. n. XacobN, (TA,) He stripped off, or removed, the bark of a tree; as also XcRb↓, inf. n. taXociybN: (K:) he cut off portions of a tree, or the bark thereof. (TA.) He cut, or cut off, a thing; (O, K;) aor.

, inf. n. XacobN. (O.) He cut, or lopped, a tree: or he divested it of its bark. (A.) He pruned, or pared, a tree by cutting off its Xacab, i. e. its straggling branches, or its thorns, or its bark; aor.

, inf. n. XacobN; and XcRb↓ has the like meaning, but importing muchness, or relation to many objects: and Xacaba also signifies he trimmed, or cleared, anything by removing another thing from it: (Msb:) or he pruned a tree by lopping off its branches so that it became apparent: (K, TA:) and he pruned a palm-tree by cutting off from it its Xacab, meaning its branches: (TA:) and [in like manner] XcRb↓, (S, TA,) inf. n. taXociybN, (S, K, TA,) he pruned a tree by cutting off its Xacab, meaning its straggling branches not in the choice, or best, part thereof: (S:) or he trimmed a palm-trunk (K, TA) by lopping off the stumps of the branches: (TA:) AlrRayaAHiyni taXociybu↓ [likewise] signifies the pruning, or cutting off, the superfluous portions of the straggling extremities of the sprigs of sweet-smelling plants: (Mgh:) and Xuciba Eanohu, said of anything, signifies it was removed from it, namely, another thing. 2. XcRb, inf. n. taXociybu: see above, in four places. ― -b2- [Hence,] taXociybN signifies also The shaping an arrow by the first operation: (AHn, K:) the second operation is termed tahociybN. , inf. n. XacobN: (Sh, TA:) and Eanohu Xacaba↓ he repelled from him, or defended him. 5. tXcRbwA (tropical:) They became dispersed, or scattered. (A, K.)

XacabN Pieces, or cuttings, of trees; (As, A 'Obeyd, K;) n. un. with p: (As, A 'Obeyd:) or bark of trees: (K:) pieces of bark, and pieces of wood, or sticks, or twigs or branches, in a dispersed, or scattered, state; (O, K;) pl. choice, or best, part thereof: (S, O:) also the superfluous portions of the straggling extremities of the sprigs of sweet-smelling plants, which are pruned, or cut off. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Anything in a scattered, or dispersed, state. (Kt, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Somewhat remaining of herbage [&c.]: (S, A, O, K: [in the first and third of which is added wahuwa AlmaOokuwlu, app. referring to the herbage of which the remainder is thus called, meaning, “ it being what has been eaten: ”]) pl. as above, i. e. OaXocaAbN. (S, O, K. *) One says, fiI AlOaroDi XacabN mino kalaO (tropical:) In the land is somewhat remaining of herbage. (A, TA.) And maA baqiIa lahu UilRaA XacabN mina AlEasokari (tropical:) [There remained not to him save a relic of the army]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) Household goods, or furniture and utensils, consisting of what are termed qumaAX [q. v., perhaps here meaning the meaner sorts thereof,] &c.: (A 'Obeyd, O, K:) pl. as above. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- And A dam; or thing constructed, or raised, to keep back the water of a torrent. (S, O, K.)

rajulN Xacibu AlEuruwqi (assumed tropical:) A man whose veins are apparent. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- And Xcb [app. XacibN] is syn. with EaZibN, meaning A man alighting, or abiding, in places of dried-up herbage, and in a waterless desert. (TA in art. EZb.)

XaAcibN c
XaAcibN (tropical:) Going, or being, away from his home, or place of settled abode. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Solitary, or alone, and whose prosperity is despaired of; (K, TA;) as though stripped of good. (TA.)

XawocabN: see muXacRabN, in three places.

miXocabN A pruning-hook. (O, * K, * TA.)

muXacRabN A palm-trunk pared (S, O, TA) of its prickles (TA) [or of the stumps of its branches or of its lower branches: see the verb of which it is the pass. part. n.]. ― -b2- (tropical:) Tall; (S, A;) as also XawocabN↓; (S;) the former as an epithet applied to a horse, (S, A,) from the same epithet as applied to a palm-trunk: (A:) and (assumed tropical:) tall, and goodly in make; (A, K;) and so XawocabN↓; (Mgh, K;) as though pruned: (Mgh:) and ↓the latter, applied to anything [meaning any animal], (assumed tropical:) tall, and excellent or of high breed or strong and light and swift: A 'Obeyd says that the former signifies (assumed tropical:) excessively tall, and is applied in this sense to anything [i. e. a man and any animal]: Kt says, after explaining XacRabotu AlmaAla as it has been expl. above, that he who is excessively tall is as though his frame were disconnected, and not compact; and therefore he is thus termed: but IAmb says that Kt has made a mistake in asserting that this epithet signifies (assumed tropical:) tall, conspicuous for tallness, and that it is from the palm-tree from which the branches have been lopped off, (in consequence of which, as is said in the Fáïk, it becomes taller, MF, TA,) and that he who is (assumed tropical:) conspicuous for tallness is not thus called unless somewhat deficient in flesh: it is applied to a horse as meaning (tropical:) tall, and not very fleshy. (So in some copies of the K.) ― -b8- tXcRrwA fiI AlHarobi i. q. taTaAwaluwA [app. as meaning They behaved overbearingly in war]: (S, K:) or taXacRurN signifies the protracting of war. (KL.) ― -b9- tXcRrt AlnRaAqapu The she-camel pastured upon herbage (K, TA) that rejoiced her, (TA,) and she shook her head by reason of joy thereat. (K, TA.) And The she-camel drew together her two sides, and raised her tail. (TA.) ― -b10- And tXcRr AlsRawoTu The whip inclined, and became in motion. (K.)

XacorN c
XacorN Pieces of gold that are picked up from the mine (S, A, K) without the melting, or smelting, (S, K,) of the ore: (S:) n. un. with p: (S, K:) and pl. XucuwrN. (A.) And Beads made of gold to form divisions between pearls and jewels: (TA:) or beads by means of which other beads of a string are divided: (K:) or small pearls: (S, K:) or small things of gold, like the heads of ants, which are affixed to a [ring of the kind called] xawoq: (Sh:) or, as some say, green beads: (Har p. 600:) n. un. with p. (K.) ＝ -A2- Xcr [app. XacorN] signifies [also, like taXacRurN,] Briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: and quickness in an affair. (Ham. p. 54.)

tafarRaquwA Xacara macara c
tafarRaquwA Xacara macara, and Xicara micara, They [dispersed, or became dispersed, or] went, or went away, in every direction: (S, L, K:) it is not said of a people coming: (L:) the m in mcr is sometimes changed into b; or, accord. to some, bcr is the original, being from AltRabociyru; but MF thinks that mcr is the original, as it is only an imitative sequent, in which no regard is had to the meaning of “ dispersion. ” (TA.)

XawocarN c
XawocarN A [garment of the kind called] miloHafap: an arabicized word; (S, K;) from the Pers. jaAdaro [or JaAdaro or JaAdiro]. (S.) And i. q. UitobN; (A, K, TA;) i. e. A [garment of the kind called] burod, which is slit [in the middle], and worn by a woman, who throws it upon her neck, [putting her head through the slit;] having neither sleeves nor an opening at the bosom: (TA:) or [a garment] like the SidaAr, [which is said by some to be the same as the Uitob,] worn by a young woman: (Har p. 55:) a garment which a woman wears beneath her vawob: (Fr:) a certain garment which a woman and a girl wear, extending to the extremity of the upper half of the arm. (Lth.) [The modern JAdr of Persia and El-'Irák seems to be generally what is commonly called in Egypt a “ miláyeh, ” correctly “ muláäh ” (mulaMCap), figured and described in my work on the Modern Egyptians: or, in some instances, a similar covering of plain white, or dark blue, cotton; the former of which is now called in Egypt an “ izár. ” (See Dozy's “ Dict. des Noms des Vêtements chez les Arabes, ” pp. 216-219.)]

XiycaArapN c
XiycaArapN A very jealous man; (K;) as also XinocaArapN and XibocaArapN. (TA.)

AlmutaXacRiru c
AlmutaXacRiru The lion: (K:) because of his briskness, or quickness to act, or readiness to leap. (TA.)

XacaA c
XacaA, aor.
Xacuwa
: see 4. ＝ -A2- Also He perfumed himself (taTayRaba) with musk, (K, TA,) which is termed XacowN, or, as in copies of the M, XicowN. (TA.) ― -b2- And XacaA biAlxabari, (K, TA,) inf. n. XacowN; or, accord. to the Tekmileh, bAlxbr XcRI↓, there written with teshdeed; (TA;) (tropical:) He knew the information, or story, and made it known, or understood. (K, TA.)

2 XacRawa
2: see the preceding paragraph.

4 AXcI c
4. AXcI He annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt: or he did what annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt: syn. McI: (S, Msb, TA:) and (TA) so XacaA↓, (K,) aor.
Xacuwa
, inf. n. XacFA, (TA,) or XacowN. (TK [accord. to which the latter verb is trans.].) ― -b2- And AXcAhu Eanohu, (K,) inf. n. UiXocaMCN, (TA,) He put aside, or away, and removed far off, him, or it, from him, or it. (K, TA.)

XacFA c
XacFA Annoyance, molestation, harm, or hurt; or a thing that annoys, molests, &c.: (S, Msb, K:) and evil, or mischief; (S, Msb;) as also XacaApN↓; as in the saying UinRiI laOaxoXaI XacaApa fulaAnK i. e. [Verily I fear, or dread,] the evil, or mischief, of such a one. (TA.) ― -b2- Dog-flies; (S, K;) which also sometimes light upon the camel: (S:) or flies in general: (K:) or large blue flies that light upon beasts, and annoy, or molest, or hurt, them: (TA:) n. un. XacaApN↓. (S. [It is said in the Msb that XacFA, of which the n. un. is XacaApN, is also with kesr (i. e. XicFA↓); but in what sense is not specified.]) One says of him who is vehemently hungry, Darima XacaAhu [lit. His flies have become vehemently hungry, or burning with hunger]. (S.) ― -b3- And [app. because of the annoyance that it occasions,] Mange, or scab: (ISd, K:) and so XadFA. (K in art. Xdw.) ― -b4- And [app.
because of its pungency,] Salt: (S, K:) said in the M to be pl. [but properly coll. gen. n.] of XacaApN↓, which signifies a piece of salt. (TA.) ― -b5- See also XacowN. ― -b6- Also Fragments of aloes-wood (S, * K, * TA) with which one perfumes himself. (TA. [The same is also indicated in the S.]) ― -b7- And Sharpness, (S,) or strength, (Fr, T, K,) of pungency of odour; (Fr, T, S, K;) accord. to the M, of sweet odour. (TA.) ― -b8- See also XacaApN. ― -b9- Also The extremity of anything: (TA:) and so XadFA. (K and TA in art. Xdw.) ＝ -A2- And A sort of trees, (S, K,) used for masaAwiyk [i. e. sticks with which the teeth are cleansed], (K,) growing in the Saráh (AlsRaraAp) and having gum. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And A sort of ships or boats: (Lth, S, K:) n. un. XacaApN↓: (Lth, S:) [or] XacaAwapN↓ signifies one of a sort of small ships, or boats, like those called zabaAzibu [pl. of zabozabN]: and its pl. is XacaAwaAtN. (Msb.)

XicFA c
XicFA: see the next preceding paragraph.

XacowN c
XacowN, so accord. to the K, but written in copies of the M with kesr [i. e. XicowN↓], (TA,) Musk; (IAar, K, TA;) as also XacFA↓: (IJ, TA:) or the odour thereof: (As, T, Sgh, K:) or the colour thereof. (K.)

XicowN c
XicowN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XacaApN c
XacaApN: see XacFA, in three places. ― -b2- Also Sharpness. (TA.) ― -b3- And Strength, and boldness, of a man. (Lth, TA.) ― -b4- [Or] A remnant of strength: (S, K:) pl. XacawaAtN (TA) and [coll. gen. n.] XacFA↓. (S, * TA. [See also XadFA, in art. Xdw.]) ＝ -A2- As an epithet applied to a man, (TA,) Evil in disposition, (K, TA,) sharp in temperament, that annoys, or molests, or hurts, by his evil, or mischief: in some of the copies of the K, AlXRaIoCu Alxalaqu is erroneously put for AlsRaIRiCu Alxuluqi. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See again XacFA, last sentence.

XacaAwapN c
XacaAwapN: see XacFA, last sentence.

1 XarRa c
1. XarRa, (L, K,) sec. pers. Xarirota, (S, Msb, K, MF,) aor. yaXarRu; (L, Msb, MF;) and sec. pers. Xarurota, (S accord. to some copies, L, Msb, K, MF,) aor. yaXurRu; (L, Msb, K, * MF;) and sec. pers. Xararota, (S accord. to some copies, M, K, MF,) aor. yaXirRu; (M, K, MF;) of which three vars. the first is the best known; and the last is strange, and disallowed by most authorities; (MF;) inf. n. [of the first or third] XarRN (S, K) and [of the first] XararN (S) and [of the second or third] XaraArapN, (S, K,) and XirRapN also is an inf. n. [syn. with XarRN]; (S;) He (a man) was, or became, evil, a wrongdoer, unjust, bad, corrupt, wicked, mischievous, vitious, or depraved. (S, * L, Msb, K, * &c.) The manner in which the K mentions XarRa with the two aors. yaXurRu and yaXirRu [only, omitting the most common aor., i. e. yaXarRu,] obviously demands consideration. (MF.) One says, Xarirota yaA rajulu [Thou hast been evil, or a wrongdoer, &c., O man], (S, K,) and so Xarurota and Xararota. (S accord. to different copies, and K.) ― -b2- XarRa, aor. yaXarRu, also signifies He increased in evil, wrongdoing, &c. (L.) It is said in a prov., kulRamaA takobaru taXarRu [In proportion as thou growest old, thou increasest in evil, &c.]. (AZ, L.) ― -b3- maA XarRahu: see 4, last sentence. ＝ -A2- XarRahu, (O, K,) aor. yaXurRu, (O, TA,) inf. n. XurRN, (O, K,) with damm, (K, [which is said in the TA to indicate that the aor., not the inf. n., is with damm, but this is inconsistent with the common practice of the author of the K, and is evidently wrong,]) He blamed him; found fault with him; attributed or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, fault, defect, blemish, or something amiss. (O, K, * TA. [See also 4.]) One says, maA qulotu caAka liXurRika waUinRamaA qulotupu ligayori XurRika I said not that to find fault with thee, but I only said it for a different purpose than that of finding fault with thee: (S, TA:) or this has a different meaning, which see below, voce XurRN. (TA.) One says also, qado qabilotu EaTiyRataka vumRa radadotuhaA Ealayoka mino gayori XurRika walaA DurRika, meaning [I have accepted thy gift; then I have given it back to thee] without rejecting it to thee or blaming thee [and without injuring thee]. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also XarRahu, (S,) or XarRahu fiI AlXRamosi, (A,) [aor. and inf. n. as in the next sentence;] and XrRrhu↓, (A,) inf. n. taXoriyrN; (S;) and AXrRhu↓; and XaroXarahu↓; (A;) He spread it (i. e. a garment, or piece of cloth, S, or some other thing, TA) in the sun: (S, A, TA:) this is the primary signification. (TA.) And [hence,] XarRahu, (S, K,) aor. yaXurRu. (S,) inf. n. XarRN; (S, K;) and AXrRhu↓, (K,) inf. n. UiXoraArN; (TA;) and XrRrhu↓, (K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and XarRaAhu [or XaraAhu without tesh-deed?]; (K;) He put it (i. e. [the preparation of curd called] OaqoT, and flesh-meat, S, K, and the like, and salt, S, and a garment, or piece of cloth, and the like, K) upon a xaSafap, (S, K,) i. e. a mat, (TA,) or some other thing, (K,) to dry. (S, K.) And XrRhu He sprinkled it; namely, salt. (R, MF.)

2 XrRrhu c
2. XrRrhu inf. n. taXoriyrN, He rendered him notorious, or infamous, among men. (Yz, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, latter part, in two places.

3 XArRhu c
3. XArRhu, (K,) inf. n. muXaArRapN, (S,) He acted with him in an evil manner; (K;) he treated him with enmity, or hostility: (L, TA:) he contended, or disputed, with him: (S, L, TA:) he did evil to him, obliging him to do the like in return. (L, TA.) [See also 3 in art. XrI: and see an ex. voce jaArRa.]

4 AXrRhu c
4. AXrRhu He attributed, or imputed, to him evil, wrongdoing, injustice, or the like: (S, K:) but some disallow this. (S. [See also 1.]) ― -b2- OaXarRuwhu They banished him, or drove him away, and caused him to be alone. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, latter part, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] AXrRhu signifies also (tropical:) He manifested it, revealed it, published it, or made it known. (S, A, K.) Thus in a verse of Imra-el-Keys, where he says, lawo yuXirRuwna maqotaliI (assumed tropical:) [that they might publish, or make known, my slaughter]; as related by As; but it is better with s. (S.) ＝ -A3- maA OaXarRahu, and maA XarRahu↓, [the latter of which is extr. with respect to form, but more commonly used than the former, meaning How evil, wrongdoing, unjust, bad, corrupt, wicked, mischievous, vitious, or depraved, is he!] phrases similar to maA Oaxoyarahu and maA xayorahu [which have the contr. meaning]. (TA in art. xyr.)

8 AXtrR c
8. AXtrR, said of a camel, [and of any clovenhoofed animal,] i. q. AjtrR, i. e. He ruminated, or chewed the cud: j and X being from one place of utterance. (IAth, TA.)

10 AstXrR c
10. AstXrR He became possessor of a great herd, such as is termed UiXoraArap, of camels. (K.)

R. Q. 1 XaroXarahu c
R. Q. 1. XaroXarahu, (A 'Obeyd, K,) inf. n. XaroXarapN, (S,) He split it, or clave it: (A 'Obeyd, S:) and cut it much, or in many pieces. (A 'Obeyd, S, K.) ― -b2- He bit it, and then shook it; namely, a thing. (O, K, TA. [In the CK, naqaDahu is erroneously put for nafaDahu.]) ― -b3- XaroXaratohu AlHayRapu The serpent bit him. (L, K. *) ― -b4- XrXrt AlmaAXiyapu AlnRabaAta The cattle ate the herbage. (K.) ― -b5- XrXr AlsRikRiyna He sharpened, (K,) or rubbed, (O,) the knife upon a stone, (O, K, TA,) so that its edge became rough. (O, TA.) ― -b6- See also 1, latter part. ＝ -A2- XaroXara, inf. n. as above, It (a bird) expanded and flapped its wings, without alighting; like raforafa. (TA in art. frX.)

R. Q. 2 taXaroXara c
R. Q. 2. taXaroXara It became separated, or scattered. (A.)

XarRN c
XarRN (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and XurRN↓, (Kr, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (TA,) and XirRapN↓ (Ham p. 629) Evil, [moral and physical;] (L, Msb;) wrongdoing, injustice, badness, corruptness, wickedness, mischievousness, vitiousness, or depravity: (Msb:) [and evil fortune, misfortune, woe, or unhappiness:] contr. of xayorN: (S, A, K:) pl. XuruwrN. (Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., in a form of prayer, (TA,) used by the Prophet, (Msb,) waAlxayoru kulRuhu biyadayoka waAlXRarRu layosa Uilayoka, (Msb, * TA,) meaning [And all good is in thy hands, and evil i. e.] wrongdoing, or injustice, or corruptness, is not imputable to Thee: (Msb, TA:) or evil is not a means of advancement in thy favour, or of obtaining thine approval: or evil speech does not ascend to Thee. (Nh, L.) ― -b2- XarRN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Poverty. (K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Fever. (K.) ― -b4- It is also an epithet, applied to a man, (Yoo, S,) and so is XariyrN↓, (Akh, S, A, Msb, K,) meaning Evil, wrongdoing, unjust, bad, corrupt, wicked, mischievous, vitious, or depraved: (Yoo, * Akh, * S, * A, * Msb, K: *) [fem. of the former XarRapN, like as xayorapN is fem. of its contr. xayorN; and XurRaI, fem. of OaXarRu, is used in the same sense, as will be shown in what follows:] the pl. of XarRN, (Yoo, S,) or of XariyrN↓, (Akh, S, Msb, K,) is OaXoraArN, (Yoo, Akh, S, Msb, K,) and of the former XiraArN; (Ham p. 514;) and you say qawomN OaXirRaMCu [pl. of XarRN or of XariyrN↓]. (S.) A woman of the Arabs, (S, L,) who, accord. to some, was of the Benoo-'Ámir, (L,) is related to have said, OuEiycuki biQllRehi mino nafosK HarRaI waEayonK XurRaI↓, meaning [I charm thee by invoking God, against
a thirsty soul, and] an evil, or a malignant, eye: (S, L:) or an eye that looks at one with vehement hatred. (TA.) And AlXRarRu [The evil one] is an appellation of Iblees. (K.) ― -b5- [It is also used to denote the comparative and superlative degrees; like the contr. xayorN.] You say, huwa XarRN minoka [He is worse, or more evil or wrongdoing &c., than thou]. (K.) And hecaA XarRN mino caAka [This is worse, &c., than that]. (Msb.) And fulaAnN XarRu AlnRaAsi [Such a one is the worst, &c., of mankind]; (S;) and OaXarRu↓; (S, Msb, K;) this latter being the original, (Mgh, Msb,) but rare, (K,) or bad, (S, K,) peculiar to the dial. of the Benoo-'Ámir, (Msb,) or unused. (Mgh.) The fem. [of XarRN] is XarRapN, [like as the fem. of its contr., xayorN, is xayorapN,] (K,) and (of OaXarRu, S, * or of XarRN, which is used for OaXarRu, Kr) XurRaI↓. (S, Kr, K.) And [using the dim. form of XarRN,] you say, minoka huwa XurayorN↓ [He is a little worse, &c., than thou]. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. xyr. [See xayorN.]) ＝ -A2- maA XarRa for maA OaXarRa: see 4.

XurRN c
XurRN A vice, fault, defect, blemish, or something amiss: (TA:) a thing disapproved, disliked, or hated. (K, TA.) You say, maA radadotu hecaA Ealayoka mino XurRK bihi I did not give this back to thee on account of any fault &c., in it, but I preferred to give it to thee. (TA.) And maA qulotu caAka liXurRika I said not that on account of a thing that thou disapprovest, &c.: (K, TA:) or this has a different meaning, expl. above in the first paragraph. (TA.) ― -b2- See also XarRN, first sentence.

XirRapN c
XirRapN: see XarRN, first sentence. ― -b2- Also The inordinate desire, or eagerness, (S,) and sprightliness, of youth: (S, K:) and in an absolute sense, inordinate desire, or eagerness; and [simply] desire; and sprightliness: (TA:) [and] sharpness, and angriness. (Har p. 35.) It is said in a trad., UinRa lihecaA AlquroMni XirRapF vumRa UinRa lilnRaAsi Eanohu fatorapF [Verily there is an eagerness for this Kur-án: then men have a weariness of it]. (L.)

XararN c
XararN; n. un. with p: see what next follows.

XaraArN c
XaraArN, (S, A, O, Msb, TA,) accord. to the K XiraArN, but this is a mistake, (MF,) and XararN↓, (S, A, O, Msb, K,) which is a contraction of XaraArN, (Msb,) Sparks of fire: (S, O, Msb, K:) n. un. of each with p. (S, A, O, Msb, * K.) See an ex. voce XarRaArN.

XariyrN c
XariyrN: see XarRN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also The side of the sea, or of a great river; (AHn, K;) the shore thereof: (Kr, TA:) or the part that is near to a sea or great river: pl. OaXirRapN: (AA, TA:) which signifies also seas or great rivers [themselves]. (TA.) ― -b2- And (as some say, TA) A kind of tree that grows in the sea, or in a great river. (K, TA.)

XurayorN c
XurayorN dim. of XarRN: see the latter, last sentence but one.

XariyrapN c
XariyrapN A [large needle such as is termed] misalRap (K, TA) of iron. (TA.)

XirRaArN c
XirRaArN [Emitting many sparks]. One says, Oabuwka naArN XarRaArapN waOatota minohaA XaraArapN↓ [Thy father is a fire that emits many sparks, and thou art a spark from it]. (A.)

XarRaAnN c
XarRaAnN Certain insects (K) resembling baEuwD [or gnats], (S, K,) which cover the face of a man, but do not bite; sometimes called AlOacaI: (S:) of the dial. of the people of Es-Sawád: (T, TA:) [it is with tenween; for] the n. un. is with p. (K.)

XirRiyrN c
XirRiyrN (S, A, K) Abounding in XarR [or evil or wrongdoing &c.; very evil &c.]; applied to a man: (S, A:) pl. XirRiyruwna (K) and OaXoraArN, which latter is anomalous. (Ham. p. 699.)

XaroXarN c
XaroXarN, (IAar, S, K,) or (so in the S, but in the K “ and ”) XiroXirN↓, (Ibn-Ziyád, S, K,) A certain plant, (S, K,) which extends along the ground like ropes, (Ibn-Ziyád, AHn, K,) in the same manner as the quTob, but having no thorns that hurt any one: (Ibn-Ziyád, AHn:) Az says that it is a well-known plant, seen by him in the desert; that it fattens the camels, and makes their milk plentiful; and that it is mentioned by IAar and others among the plants of the desert: XiroXirapN↓ is expl. in the K as though it were the name of another plant; but it is not so; for XiroXirN is the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] thereof: it is a herb smaller than the Earofaj, having a yellow flower, and twigs, or shoots, and large dust-coloured leaves: it grows in plain, or soft, ground; and spreads wide, as though it were ropes, by reason of length, of the measure of a man in a standing posture; and has berries (HabR), like those of the haraAs. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XiwaMCN XaroXarN Roasted flesh-meat, of which the grease, or gravy, drips; (S, K;) like XaloXalN and raXoraAXN. (TA.)

XiroXirN c
XiroXirN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XaroXarapN c
XaroXarapN, ('Ináyeh, and so in some copies of the K,) or XuroXurapN↓, (so in other copies of the K, accord. to the TA,) sing. of XaraAXiru, (K,) which signifies The fringe-like extremities of a tail; (S, * K, * A, TA;) and of wings. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, metaphorically, [or synecdochically,] the pl. is used as signifying (tropical:) The whole: and hence the saying, OaloqaI Ealayohi XaraAXirahu (tropical:) He betook himself altogether to it; as though, says As, by reason of his eagerness, he threw himself altogether upon it: accord. to EshShiháb, it means he betook himself [to it], openly or secretly: or XaraAXiru signifies (assumed tropical:) the whole body; (K;) and AlqI Elyh XrAXrh and OajoraAnahu and OajoraAmahu, provs. mentioned by Meyd, all signify the same [app. (assumed tropical:) he threw upon it the weight of his body: see Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 409 and 410: and see art. jrm]: or the first of these means (assumed tropical:) he loved it so that he courted death, or destruction, (Aisotaholaka,) in his love of it: (TA:) or he loved it with a love that he would not give up, because of his necessity: (Lth, TA:) or (tropical:) he desired it inordinately, or eagerly, and loved it. (A.) [See also OaloqaI Ealayohi OarowaAqahu, voce rawoqN. Accord. to different authorities,] XaraAXiru also signifies (assumed tropical:) Burdens, or weights; (S, K;) sing.
