(IAar, Mgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- XaraEa AlmaAla, aor. as above, [inf. n., app., XaroEN,] He brought the cattle to the watering-place; a also AXrEhu↓: (Msb:) and the former is trans. in this sense by means of bi: (Har p. 21:) or XaraEa (TA) and XrRE↓, inf. n. of the latter taXoriyEN, (S, TA,) he made the beasts, (S,) or his camels, (TA,) to enter into the water [to drink]: (S, TA: *) and naAqatahu AXrE↓ he made his she-camel to enter into the watering-place: (TA:) or taXoriyEN↓ signifies the bringing camels to the wateringplace to drink without requiring in doing so to draw with the pulley and its appertenances nor to give them to drink in a watering-trough or tank. (O, K.) It is said in a prov, (S,) Oahowanu AlsRaqoIi AltRaXoriyEu↓ (S, K) The easiest mode of watering is the making of the camels to enter into the water: applied to him who takes an easy way of performing an affair, and does not exert himself therein. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 889.]) ― -b2- XaraEa AlbaAba UilaI AlTRariyqi He made the door, or entrance, to communicate with the road: (Msb:) and AlI AlTryq AXrEhu↓ (S, Msb, K, TA) signifies the same; (Msb, TA;) or he opened it (i. e. the door, or entrance,) to the road. (S, Msb, K, TA.) And AljanaAHa UilaI AlTRariyqi AXrE↓ He put the jnAH [meaning projecting roof] towards the road. (Msb.) ― -b3- And XaraEa (K) and AXrE↓ (S, K, TA) and XrRE↓ (TA) He directed (S, K, TA) a spear, (S, TA,) or spears, (K,) and a sword, (TA,) qibalaha (S) or naHowahu (TA) [i. e. towards him]: or AXrE↓ signifies he inclined a spear. (Msb.) ― -b4- And XaraEa, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (Msb,) inf. n. XaroEN, (TA,) He made apparent, manifest, or plain, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) a road; (Mgh, TA;) as also AXrE↓; and XrRE↓, inf. n. taXoriyEN: (K, TA:) and in like manner, an affair, or a case; and religion. (TA.) Accord. to Az, this meaning of XaraEa is from XaraEa AlUihaAba [which see in what follows]. (TA.) One says, XaraEa QllRehu lanaA kacaA God made apparent, manifest, or plain, to us, such a thing. (Msb.) And XaraEa fulaAnN Such a one made apparent, manifest, or plain, the truth, or right. (TA.) ― -b5- And XaraEa lahumo i. q. sanRa [i. e. He instituted, established, or prescribed, for them, or to them, a religious ordinance, a law, &c.]: (S, K) whence [accord. to some,] XariyEapN and XiroEapN. (TA.) ― -b6- XaraEa AlUihaAba, (S, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. XaroEN, (S,) He stripped off the hide: (S, K:) or, accord. to Yaakoob, as heard by him from Umm-El-Homáris El-Bekreeyeh, he slit the hide in the part between the two hind legs, (S, TA,) and then stripped it off: or he slit the hide, [and then stripped it off,] not making of it a ziqR [q. v.], nor stripping it off [entire] by commencing from one hind leg. (TA.) ― -b7- XaraEa AlHabola He loosed, or undid, the rope, or cord, or the slip-knot thereof, (OanoXaTahu,) [then, app., doubled it in the middle, to put that part round something to be carried,] and inserted its two halves (quTorayohi) into the loop. (O, K.) ― -b8- And XaraEa AlXRaIoCa He raised, or elevated, the thing much; (K;) as also AXrEhu↓. (TA.)

2 XarRaEa
2: see 1, in six places. ＝ -A2- XrRE AlsRafiynapa, inf. n. taXoriyEN, He made, or put, a sail (XiraAE) to the ship, or boat. (TA.)

4 OaXoraEa
4: see 1, former half, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, AXrE yadahu UilaI AlmiToharapi (assumed tropical:) He put his hand [to and] into the mThrp [or vessel for purification]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. (respecting the [ablution termed] wuDuwoC), HatRaI OaXoraEa fiI AlEaDudi meaning Until, or so that, he made the upper half of the arm to reach to (lit. to enter) the water. (TA. [This ex. is elliptical
and inverted; for HtRI AXrE AlEaDoda fiI AlmaMCi.]) ― -b3- And OaXoraEaniI AlrRajulu (assumed tropical:) The man sufficed me; or gave me what sufficed me: and AXrEnI AlXRaIoCu (assumed tropical:) The thing sufficed me. (TA.) ― -b4- And OaXoraEa said of a plant, or of herbage, [app. for OaXoraEa AlUibila,] (assumed tropical:) It became full-grown, and satiated the camels. (TA.) ― -b5- See, again, 1, latter half, in six places.

8 fulaAnN yaXotariEu XiroEatahu c
8. fulaAnN yaXotariEu XiroEatahu [meaning Such a one originates, or embraces, or follows, his way of religion] is similar to the phrases yafotaTiru fiToratahu and yamotalRu milRatahu; from XiroEapu AldRiyni and fiToratuhu and milRatuhu. (TA.)

XaroEN c
XaroEN, originally an inf. n.: ― -b2- then applied as a name for A manifest, a plain, or an open, track, or road, or way: ― -b3- and then, metaphorically, to The divine way of religion; so says Er-Rághib; (TA;) syn. with XariyEapN, q. v. (Msb.) ― -b4- In the saying mararotu birajulK XaroEika, (so in the K,) or mrrt birajulK XaroEuka mino rajulK, (so in the S and O, [for huwa XaroEuka,]) with kesr and with damm to the E [of XrEk], (TA,) i. e. [I passed by a man] sufficing thee [as a man], (S, O, K,) the meaning is, of the sort to which thou directest thyself and which thou seekest (fiyhi wataTolubuhu taXoraEu↓): (S, O:) and the word in this sense is used alike as sing. and pl. (S, O, K) and dual, because it is [originally] an inf. n. (S, O.) You say, XaroEuka hecaA [and hecaAni and heWulaMCi] i. e. Sufficient for thee [is this and are these two and are these]. (S: and the like is said in the Mgh.) And it is said in a prov.,
XaroEuka maA balRagaka AlmaHalRaA
thus correctly, for it is a hemistich; not AlmaHalRa, as in the S and K; (TA;) i. e. Sufficient travel-ling-provision for thee is that which will cause thee to reach the place [of alighting] to which thou repairest: (K, TA:) applied to the case of being content with little. (S, K.) ― -b5- See also XaraEN, in two places. ― -b6- And see XiroEapN.

XiroEN c
XiroEN [in the CK, erroneously, XaroE,] The like of a thing; as also XiroEapN↓: (K, TA:) [but the former is masc. and ↓the latter is fem.; for] one says, hecaA XiroEu hecaA This is the like of this; and so hecihi hecihi XiroEapu↓: and hecaAni XiroEaAni these two are likes. (S, O, TA.) [The pls., or rather coll. gen. ns. and pls., following this meaning in the K belong to XiroEapN and XaroEapN in another sense; as is shown by exs. in the O and TA.] ＝ -A2- Also The chords of the barobaT, (O, K, TA,) which is the [Persian] Euwd [or lute]. (TA.) [In this sense, a coll. gen. n.:] see its n. un. XiroEapN. ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) (tropical:) The [thong called] XiraAk of a sandal. (O, K, TA.) It is related in a trad. that a man said, UinRiI OuHibRu AljamaAla HatRaI fiI XiroEi naEoliI (O, TA) i. e. (tropical:) [Verily I love elegance, even] in the XrAk of my sandal. (TA.)

XaraEN c
XaraEN: see XariyEapN. ＝ -A2- One says, AlnRaAsu fiI hecaA AlOamori XaraEN and XaroEN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Msb,) allowed by Kr and Kz, but disallowed by Yaakoob, (IDrst, TA,) The people are in this affair equals: (S, Msb, K:) in this sense, used alike as sing. and pl. and fem. (S, TA) and masc.: (TA:) [of XaraEN] Az says that it seems to be pl. [or quasi-pl. n.] of XaAriEN↓, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN; i. e., [the phrase means] the people enter into this affair (yaXoraEuwna fiyhi) together. (TA.) One says also, AlnRaAsu XaraEN waAHidN and wAHd XaroEN↓, meaning The people are one sort. (K.)

XaroEapN c
XaroEapN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

XiroEapN c
XiroEapN: see XariyEapN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A custom. (TA.) ― -b3- See also XiroEN, first sentence, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also A snare for the birds called qaTFA, (Lth, O, K, TA,) with which to capture them, (O, TA,) made of sinews: (Lth, O, TA:) pl. XiraEN. (O.) ― -b2- Also, (S, O, K,) and XaroEapN↓, (K,) A string, or chord: (S, O, K, TA:) or such as is slender: or while continuing stretched upon the bow; (TA;) and so XiraAEN↓; (Lth, O, K;) or upon the lute; and so XiraAEN↓: (TA:) the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] (of XiroEapN↓, S, O, [i. e. of this n. un. meaning the “ chord of a lute, ” as is shown by exs. in the O and TA,]) is XiroEN↓ (S, O, K) and (that of XaroEapN↓, TA) XaroEN↓, (O, K, TA,) like as tamorN is of tamorapN, (O, TA,) and [the pl. properly so termed] (of XiroEapN, S, O) XiraEN, and pl. pl. XiraAEN: (S, O, K:) and the pl. of XiraAEN↓ as a sing. syn. with XiroEapN is XuruEN. (TA.)

XaraEapN c
XaraEapN i. q. saqiyfapN [i. e. A roof, or covering, such as projects over the door of a house &c.; or a place roofed over]: pl. OaXoraAEN. (O, K.)

XaroEiIRN c
[XaroEiIRN Of, or relating to, the religion or law. ― -b2- And Accordant to the religion or law; legal, or legitimate.]

XuraAEN c
XuraAEN A plant, or herbage, full-grown, (O, K, TA,) that satiates the camels. (TA.)

XiraAEN c
XiraAEN: see XariyEapN. ＝ -A2- The XiraAEN of a ship or boat (S, Mgh, O, Msb) is called in Pers. baAdobaAn [i. e. A sail]; (MA, Mgh, KL;) i. q. qiloEN; (MA, TA;) a thing like a wide mulaMCap [q. v.], (O, K, TA,) of cloth or of matting, (TA,) [raised, or attached,] upon a piece of wood [i. e. a mast or a yard]; which is beaten upon by the wind (tuSafRiquhu AlrRiyHu,) and causes the ship, or boat, to go along: (O, K, TA:) so called because it is raised (yuXoraEu i. e. yurofaEu) above the ship, or boat: (TA:) pl. OaXoriEapN and XuruEN; (O, K;) the former a pl. of pauc. (O.) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA, [and the same is implied in the S and O,]) (tropical:) The neck of a camel. (S, O, K, TA.) Sometimes they said of a camel, rafaEa XiraAEahu, meaning (tropical:) He raised his neck: (S, O, TA.) ― -b3- One says also rajulN XiraAEu AlOanofi, meaning (assumed tropical:) A man having the nose extended, and long. (TA. [See OaXoraEu.]) ― -b4- See also XiroEapN, in three places.

XariyEN c
XariyEN Courageous; (O, K, TA;) applied to a man. (O, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Good, or excellent, flax. (K.) ― -b2- And The lyf [or fibres that grow at the base of the branches of the palm-tree] of which the prickles (Xawok) are strong, and such as, by reason of their thickness, are fit for the sewing of leather therewith. (TA.)

XaraAEapN c
XaraAEapN Courage; (O, K;) as an attribute of a man. (O.)

XariyEapN c
XariyEapN and maXoraEapN↓ (S, O, Msb, K) and maXoruEapN↓ (Msb, K) and maXoraEN↓ (TA) and XaraEN↓ (O, TA *) and maMCK XiraAEu↓ (TA) A watering-place; a resort of drinkers [both men and beasts]; (S, O, K, TA;) a place to which men come to drink therefrom and to draw water, (Msb, * TA,) and into which they sometimes make their beasts to enter, to drink: (TA:) but the term mXrEp↓, (Az, Msb,) or XryEp, (TA,) is not applied by the Arabs to any but [a watering-place] such as is permanent, and apparent to the eye, (Az, Msb, TA,) like the water of rivers, (Msb,) not water from which one draws with the well-rope: (Az, Msb, TA:) the pl. of XariyEapN is XaraAYiEu; and that of maXoraEapN↓ or maXoraEN↓ [or of both] is maXaAriEu; which is also expl. as meaning gaps, or breaches, in the banks of rivers or the like by which men or beasts come to water: (TA:) and [in like manner it is said that] XariyEapN signifies a place of descent to water: (Lth, TA:) or a way to water. (Bd in v. 52.) ― -b2- And hence, (Lth, Kr, Msb, TA, and Bd ubi suprà,) AlXRariyEapu, (Lth, Kr, S, Msb, K, &c.,) as also AlXRiroEapu↓, (Msb, K, &c.,) and AlXRaroEu↓, (Msb,) signifies likewise AldRiynu; (Msb, and Bd ubi suprà;) because it is a way to the means of eternal life; (Bd ibid.;) or because of its manifestness; (Msb;) [i. e.] The religious law of God; (Lth, Kr, S, O, K, * TA;) consisting of such ordinances as those of fasting and prayer and pilgrimage (Lth, Kr, TA) and the giving of the poorrate (Kr, TA) and marriage, (Lth, TA,) and other acts (Lth, Kr, TA) of piety, or of obedience to God, or of duty to Him and to men: (Kr, TA:) pl. as above. (Msb.) XariyEapN signifies also [A law, an ordinance, or a statute: and] a religion, or way of belief and practice in respect of religion: (Fr, TA:) and a way of belief or conduct that is manifest (Ibn-'Arafeh, Mgh, K) and right (Ibn-'Arafeh, K) in religion; (Mgh;) and so XiroEapN↓. (K.)

XuraAEiIRN c
XuraAEiIRN, as an epithet applied to A spear-head and a spear, of Shuráa, (TA,) which was the name of a certain man who made spear-heads and spears, (K, TA,) as they assert: but IAar says that it may be a reg. rel. n. from XuraAEN, or an irreg. rel. n. from some other name of which the radical latters are XrE: and [SM says also that,] applied to a spear, it signifies long: (TA:) or XiraAEiIRN↓, thus applied, has this meaning, a rel. n. [from XiraAEN]. (S, O.) XuraAEiyRapN and XiraAEiyRapN↓ [in the
CK without teshdeed], applied to a she-camel, signify (tropical:) Long-necked; (O, K, TA:) thus expl. by ISh: but Az thinks the latter to be the more probably correct; the neck being likened to the XiraAE of the ship or boat, because of the height thereof. (O.)

XiraAEiIRN c
XiraAEiIRN; and its fem., with p: see the next preceding paragraph.

XarRaAEN c
XarRaAEN A seller of the flax called XariyE. (IAar, K.)

XaAriEN c
XaAriEN Entering into water [to drink]: pl. XurRaEN and XuruwEN: (KL:) these pls. are applied in this sense to camels. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Entering into an affair (fiI OamorK). (Az, TA.) See XaraEN. ― -b3- And sing. of XurRaEN in the phrase HiytaAnN XurRaEN, (TA,) which means Fishes lowering their heads to drink: (Aboo-Leylà, TA:) or raising their heads: (K, TA:) or directing themselves, or repairing, (XaAriEaAtN,) from the deep water to the bank, or side: (S, TA:) and HytAn XuruwEN signifies the same: (TA:) or XurRaEFA in the Kur vii. 163, referring to fish, means appearing upon the surface of the water. (Bd, Jel. *) ― -b4- Also, applied to a place of alighting, or an abode, (manozilN,) Situate upon a road that is a thoroughfare: and XaAriEapN applied to a house (daArN) signifies the same; (K;) or having its door [opening] upon such a road; (TA;) or near to the road and to the people [or passengers]: (Mgh, * TA:) and duwrN XaAriEapN houses having their doors opening into the streets: or duwrN XawaAriEu, as expl. by IDrd, houses upon one open road. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kaAnati AlOabowaAbu XaAriEapF UilaI Almasojidi The doors were opening towards the mosque. (TA.) ― -b5- And Anything near (K, TA) to a thing, or overlooking it: whence XaAriEapN applied to a house (daArN) near to the road and to the people, as expl. above. (TA.) [Hence,] nujuwmN XawaAriEu Stars near to setting. (K.) ― -b6- [Also Pointing directly towards a person; applied to a spear.] One says rimaAHN XaAriEapN and XawaAriEu (K, TA) and XurRaEN as in some of the copies of the S (TA) Spears pointing directly: and rimaAHN maXoruwEapN↓ and muXoraEapN↓ spears directed. (K, TA.) ― -b7- Also [used as a subst.] A main road: (S, O:) or it signifies, (Mgh, TA,) or so TariyqN XaAriEN, (Msb,) (tropical:) a road, or way, into which people enter (yasolukuhu AlnRaAsu, Msb, or yaXoraEu fiyhi AlnRaAsu, Mgh, TA) in common, or in general; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) by a tropical attribution; (Mgh;) [i. e.] XaAriEN in this case has the meaning of maXoruwEN [or maXoruwEN fiyhi]; (Msb;) or as meaning cuw XaroEK mina Alxaloqi [having an entering of people]: (TA:) or it signifies a manifest, plain, or conspicuous, road or way: (Mgh, TA:) [in the present day, XaAriEN commonly signifies any great street that is a thoroughfare:] the pl. is XawAriEu. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- AlXRaAriEu also means The learned man who practises what he knows and instructs others: (K, TA:) or so AlXRaAriEu AlrRabRaAniIRu. (O.) And hence it is applied to designate the Prophet: [or as meaning The legislator: or the announcer of the law:] or because he made manifest and plain the religion, or religious law of God. (TA.)

OaXoraEu c
OaXoraEu A nose of which the end is extended (K, TA) and elevated, and long. (TA.)

maXoraEN c
maXoraEN: see XariyEapN, in two places.

muXoraEN c
muXoraEN: see its fem., with p, voce XaAriEN.

maXoraEapN c
maXoraEapN and maXoruEapN: see XariyEapN, in four places.

bayotN muXarRaEN c
bayotN muXarRaEN A high, or lofty, house or tent. (TA.)

maXoruwEN c
maXoruwEN: see its fem., with p, voce XaAriEN: ＝ -A2- see also 1, first sentence.

1 Xarufa c
1. Xarufa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Xarufa
, (K,) inf. n. XarafN (S, * O, * Msb, * K, TA) and XaraAfapN, (TA,) said of a man, (S, O, TA,) He was, or became, high, elevated, exalted, or eminent, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) [in rank, condition, or estimation,] in respect of religion or of worldly things: (K, TA:) [generally meaning he was high-born, or noble:] part. n. XariyfN [q. v.]. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) [See also XarafN, below.] ― -b2- [Hence one says,] Xarufato nafosuhu Eani AlXRaIoCi His soul was above the thing; disdained, or scorned, it. (L in art. Anf.) ― -b3- Xarafati AlnRaAqapu, and Xarufat, (O, K,) aor. of each
Xarufa
, inf. n. XuruwfN, (K,) reg. as of the former verb, and irreg. as of the latter, (TA,) The she-camel was, or became, such as is termed XaArifN [q. v.]. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- Xarafahu, aor.
Xarufa
, (IJ, S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. XarofN, (TA,) He overcame him, or surpassed him, in Xaraf [i. e. highness, elevation, or eminence, of rank, condition, or estimation; or nobility]; (IJ, S, O, K, TA;) and so Xarufa Ealayohi: (Z, TA:) or he excelled him (TaAlahu, K, TA, in the CK [erroneously] TAwalahu,) in the grounds of pretension to respect or honour (fiI AlHasabi). (K, TA.) See 3. ― -b2- Xarafa AlHaAYiTa, (K, TA,) aor.
Xarufa
, inf. n. XarofN, (TA,) He put to the wall a Xurofap [q. v.]. (K, TA.) [See also 2.] ＝ -A3- Xarifati AlOucunu, and Xarifa Almanokibu, aor.
Xarafa
, (K, TA,) inf. n. XarafN, (TA,) The ear, and in like manner the shoulder, was, or became, high, (K, TA,) and prominent: or, as some say, stood up. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And Xarifa, [from XarafN signifying the “ hump ” of a camel,] (O, K,) said of a man, (O,) He kept constantly, or continually, to the eating of the [camel's] hump. (O, K.)

2 XrRfhu c
2. XrRfhu, inf. n. taXoriyfN, He (God) rendered him high, elevated, exalted, or eminent, [in rank, condition, or estimation; or ennobled him:] (S, KL, * PS: *) and he held him, or esteemed him, to be so. (MA, PS.) ISd thinks that the verb may also mean He regarded with more, or exceeding, honour. (TA.) [And Golius explains it as meaning He decked with a royal garment; on the authority of the KL; in my copy of which I find no other meaning assigned to it than the first mentioned above.] One says, XarRafa QllRehu AlkaEobapa, (O, K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) [God rendered, or may God render, the Kaabeh an object of honour, or glorious,] from AlXRarafu, (O, K, TA,) i. e. Almajodu. (TA.) [taXoriyfN is also used as a subst. properly so called; and as such is expl. by itself in this art.] ― -b2- Also He put to it Xuraf [pl. of XurofapN, q. v.]; (O, K;) namely, his house, (K,) or a [palace, or pavilion, or other building such as is called] qaSor, &c.; inf. n. as above. (O.) [See also Xarafa AlHaAYiTa.] ― -b3- XrRf AlmarobaOa, expl. in the K as syn. with AXrfhu and XArfhu, is a mistake for tXrRfhu [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b4- XrRf AlnRaAqapa, inf. n. as above, means He almost severed the teats of the she-camel by binding them [tightly] with the SiraAr [q. v.]: (IAar, O, TA:) this being done for the preservation of her [stoutness of] body, and her fatness, so that burdens may be put upon her in the coming year. (TA.) ― -b5- [XrRf, app. for XrRf AlEunuqa, is also said by Reiske, as mentioned by Freytag in his Lexicon, to signify He (a camel going along) raised the neck: but his authority for this is not stated.]

3 XArfhu c
3. XArfhu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. muXaArafapN, (TA,) He vied with him, or contended with him for superiority, in Xaraf [i. e. highness, elevation, or eminence, of rank, condition, or estimation; or nobility]; (S, O, K, TA;) faXarafahu↓ and he overcame, or surpassed, him therein. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 5. ― -b3- Also He was, or became, near to it; he drew near to it, or approached it; namely, a thing: and he was, or became, near to attaining it, [and in like manner XArf Ealayohi, as used in the S and K in the beginning of art. blg, he was, or became, at the point of reaching it, or attaining it, namely, a place,] or of obtaining it, or getting possession of it: [and he was, or became, at the point of experiencing it, (See Bd in lxxviii. 14,) and doing it; followed by Oano and an aor.:] and, as some say, he looked for it, or expected it; his mind told him of it; he looked for its coming to pass. (TA.) See also 4, in two places.

4 AXrf c
4. AXrf It rose; or it was, or became, high or elevated; [so as to overtop, or overlook, what was around it or adjacent to it: overtopped, surmounted, overpeered, overlooked, overhung; was, or became, protuberant, prominent, or projecting: and rose into view, came within sight or view, or became within a commanding, or near, view:] said of a place [&c.]. (Msb.) One says of a piece of ground, OaXorafa EalaI maA Hawolahu [It rose above, or overtopped, what was around it]. (Sh, TA.) And OaXorafa liI XarafN famaA zilotu OarokuDu HatRaI Ealawotuhu [An eminence rose into view to me, and I ceased not to urge on my beast until I ascended, or mounted, upon it]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] OaXorafotu Ealayohi I looked upon it, or viewed it, (S, O, Msb, K, *) from above; (S, O, K;) [I overlooked it, or looked down upon it: and I came in sight of it: got a view of it: and got knowledge of it; became acquainted with it; or knew it: all of which meanings may be intended to be conveyed by the explanation in the Msb, which is AiTRalaEotu Ealayohi:]
and AlXRaIoCa XaArafotu↓ signifies the same as OaXorafotu Ealayohi [app. in the first of the senses expl. in this sentence, as well as in another sense expl. in what follows]: (S, O:) and XaArafuwhumo↓ signifies the same as OaXorafuwA Ealayohimo. (TA.) ― -b3- And AXrf EalaI Almawoti He (a sick man) was, or became, on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of death. (O, K.) And AXrf bihi EalaI Almawoti [He made him to be on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of death]. (T and K in art. crf.) ― -b4- And OaXorafato nafosuhu EalaI XaIoCK His soul was vehemently eager for a thing. (Mgh. [See also 10.]) UiXoraAfN signifies The being eager, and the being vehemently eager: and hence the saying, in a trad., mano Oaxaca AldRunoyaA biUiXoraAfi nafosK lamo yubaArako lahu fiyhaA [Whoso takes the enjoyments of the present world with eagerness, or vehement eagerness, of soul, he will not be blessed therein]. (TA.) ― -b5- And AXrf Ealayohi He regarded him with solicitous affection or pity or compassion. (O, * K.) ― -b6- [And AXrf liI He, or it, came within sight, or view, to me; or came within a commanding, or near, view of me: see an ex. voce Oajohada; and another voce rabaOa.] ― -b7- And [hence,] AXrf laka AlXRaIoCu The thing became, or has become, within thy power or reach; or possible, practicable, or easy, to thee. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 5, in two places.

5 tXrRf c
5. tXrRf, said of a man, is from AlXRarafu, (O,) and signifies SaAra muXarRafFA [He became elevated, or exalted, in rank, condition, or estimation; or ennobled]. (K.) ― -b2- tXrRf bihi He became elevated, or exalted, in rank, condition, or estimation; or ennobled; by, or by means of, him, or it: (MA:) [or he gloried, or prided himself, by reason of it, or in it; i. e.] he reckoned it, (S,) or regarded it, (O,) as a glory or an honour [to himself], (S, O,) and a favour. (O.) ＝ -A2- tXrRf AlmarobaOa, (S, O, TA,) in the K, erroneously, XarRafahu; (TA;) and AXrfhu↓; (S, O, K;) and XArfhu↓, (K,) inf. n. muXaArafapN; (TA;) He (a man, S, O) ascended, or mounted, upon the elevated place of observation. (S, O, K.) And AlXRaIoCa AXrf↓ and EalaI AlXRaIoCi signify the same as [tXrRfhu and] tXrRf Ealayohi, i. e. He ascended, or mounted, upon the thing. (TA.) ― -b2- It is said in a trad., with reference to certain future trials, or conflicts and factions, (fitan,) mano taXarRafa lahaA tasotaXorifohu↓ i. e. Whoso finds a place of refuge [for escaping, or avoiding them, let them invite him, or cause him, to seek, or take, refuge, virtually meaning] let him seek, or take, refuge therein. (O, TA. *) ＝ -A3- tuXurRifa Alqawomu The people, or party, had their OaXoraAf [or eminent, or noble, men, pl. of Xariyf,] slain. (O, K.)

8 AXtrf c
8. AXtrf He, or it, stood up, or upright, or erect; (S, O, TA;) and (TA) so AstXrf↓ [if this be not a mistranscription, which I incline to think it may be as the former verb (of which see the part. n. below) is not mentioned in the K]. (K, TA.)

10 AstXrf AlXRaIoCa c
10. AstXrf AlXRaIoCa, (S, O, Msb, K,) and lilXRaIoCi, (Msb in art. TmH,) He raised his eyes (S, O, Msb, K) towards the thing, (O, K,) or to look at the thing, (Msb,) or looking at the thing, (S,) and expanded his hand over his eyebrow like as does he who shades [his eyes] from the sun. (S, O, K.) A poet says,
taTaAlalotu waQsotaXorafotuhu faraOayotuhu
faqulotu lahu MOanota zayodu AlOaraAmili
[I stretched up myself, and raised my eyes towards him, expanding my hand over my eyebrow like him who is shading his eyes from the sun; and I said to him, Art thou Zeyd-el-Arámil?]. (O.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) OumironaA Oano nasotaXorifa AlEayona waAlOucuna, (Mgh, * O, K, TA,) in a trad. (O, TA) relating to the sheep or goat to be slaughtered as a victim on the day of sacrifice, (TA,) means We have been commanded to pay much attention to the eye and the ear, and to examine them carefully, in order that there may not be any such defect as blindness of one eye or mutilation (Mgh, * O, K, TA) of an ear: (TA:) or, (Mgh, O,) as some say, (O,) [in the K “ that is, ”] to seek that they be of high estimation, by being perfect (Mgh, * O, K) and sound: (Mgh, O:) or, accord. to some, it is from AlXRurofapu signifying “ the choice ones, ” or “ best, ” of cattle; and the meaning is, we have been commanded to select them. (TA.) ― -b3- And yasotaXorifu maEaAliIa AlOumuwri (tropical:) He desires, or seeks, [or raises his eye to,] the means of attaining eminence. (Msb in art. Xwf.) ― -b4- AstXrf Uibilahumo means He (a man) smote their camels with the [evil] eye; syn. taEayRanahaA: (S, TA:) or he looked at them (tEyRnhA) to smite them with the [evil] eye. (TA.) ― -b5- AstXrfhu HaqRahu He defrauded him of his right, or due. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 5: ＝ -A3- and 8.

Q. Q. 1 Xaroyafotu AlzRaroEa c
Q. Q. 1. Xaroyafotu AlzRaroEa I cut off the XiroyaAf [q. v.] of the seed-produce; (S, O;) and so Xaronafotuhu: (O and K * in art. Xrnf:) of the dial. of El-Yemen: but Az doubts whether the word be with n; and the I and n are both held by him to be augmentative. (O.)

XarofN c
XarofN: see the next paragraph, near the end.

XarafN c
XarafN Highness, elevation, exaltation, or eminence, [in rank, condition, or estimation, in respect of religion or of worldly things: (see the first sentence of this art.:)] (S, O, Msb, K:) [generally meaning high birth:] glory, honour, dignity, or nobility; syn. majodN: or not unless [transmitted] by ancestors: (K:) [for] accord. to ISk, XarafN and majodN may not be unless [transmitted] by ancestors; but HasabN and karamN may be in a man though he have not ancestors [endowed therewith]: (O:) or, (K,) accord. to IDrd, (O,) it signifies highness of Hasab [which means grounds of pretension to respect or honour, consisting in any qualities (either of oneself or of one's ancestors) which are enumerated, or recounted, as causes of glorying]: (O, K:) and XurofapN↓ signifies the same as XarafN; (TA;) or the same as faDolN and XarafN [meaning a favour and a glory or an honour]; as in the saying, OaEudRu UitoyaAnakumN XurofapF [I reckon your coming a favour, and a glory or an honour]; (O, K;) and OaraI celika XurofapF [I regard that as a favour, and a glory or an honour]: (O:) the pl. of XarafN is OaXoraAfN, like as that of sababN is OasobaAbN. (TA.) nuhobapN caAtu XarafK means Spoil, or booty, of high value, at which men raise their eyes, and look, or which they smite with the [evil] eye: [see AisotaXorafa Uibilahumo:] but the phrase is also related with s. (TA. See sarafN.) ― -b2- See also XariyfN, with which, or with the pls. of which, it is said to be syn. ― -b3- Also An elevated place; an eminence: (S, Mgh, O, K:) accord. to Sh, any piece of ground that overtops what is around it, whether extended or not, only about ten cubits, or five, in length, of little or much breadth in its upper surface: (TA:) pl. OaXoraAfN: (TA voce waToCN:) and maXaArifu AlOaroDi signifies the high, or elevated, places, or parts, of the earth or ground: (S, Msb, K:) sing. maXorafN↓, with fet-h to the m and r. (Msb. [See also muXorafN.]) A poet says,
MtiI AlnRadiIRa falaA yuqarRabu majolisiI
waOaquwdu lilXRarafi AlrRafiyEi HimaAriI
[I come to the assembly, and my sitting-place is not made near to the chief person or persons, and I lead to the high elevated place my ass]: he means, I have become unsound in my intellect in consequence of old age, so that no profit is gotten from my opinion, and I am not able to mount my ass from the ground, unless from a high place. (S.) ― -b4- [Hence, (tropical:) The brink, verge, or point, of some event of great magnitude, or of any importance: not well expl. as meaning] the being on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of some event of great importance, good or evil: (O, K:) one says in the case of good, huwa EalaI XarafK mino qaDaMCi HaAjatihi (tropical:) [He is at the point of accomplishing the object of his want]: and in the case of evil, huwa EalaI XarafK mina AlhalaAki (tropical:) [He is on the brink, &c., of destruction]. (O, TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) The hump of a camel. (O, K, TA.) ― -b6- And app. sing. of OaXoraAfN in a sense expl. below: see the latter word. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And A heat; a single run, or a run at once, to a goal, or limit: (O, K:) or, (K,) accord. to Fr, about a mile: (O, K:) or about two miles. (TA as from the K and on the authority of Fr.) One says, EadaA XarafFA Oawo Xarafayoni [He ran a heat, or two heats]: (O:) and [in like manner,] AisotanRatN XarafFA Oawo Xarafayoni, (O, K,) occurring in a trad., said of a mare, or of horses. (O.) ＝ -A3- Also, (O, TA,) accord. to IAar, (O,) A red clay or earth: and i. q. magorapN [i. e. red ochre]; as also XarofN↓: accord. to Lth, a kind of trees, having a red dye: and said to be the same as [the Pers.] dAr PrnyAn [i. e. daAro ParoniyaAn, meaning Brazil-wood, which is commonly called in Arabic baqRam]. (O, TA: * in the former of which, the Pers. word here mentioned is written without the points to the P; and in the latter, AldAbrnyAn.)

XurofapN c
XurofapN: see the next preceding paragraph, first quarter. ― -b2- Also The choice ones, or best, of maAl [meaning cattle]. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- The Xurofap of a [palace, or pavilion, or other building such as is called] qaSor (S, O, Msb, K) [and of a mosque] is
well-known; (K;) [An acroterial ornament, forming a single member of a cresting of a wall or of the crown of a cornice, generally of a fanciful form, and pointed, or small, at the top:] pl. XurafN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA,) a pl. of mult., and XurufaAtN and XurafaAtN and XurofaAtN, which are pls. of pauc., or, as some say, XrfAt [i. e. XurufaAtN] is pl. of XurufapN↓, with two dammehs: EshShiháb says that XurofaAt is expl. as meaning the highest portions of a qaSor; but what are thus termed are only what are built on the top of a wall, distinct from one another, [side by side, like merlons of a parapet,] according to a well-known form: (TA:) the Xurofap is what is called by the [common] people XurRaAfap↓: (Ham p. 824:) the XurRaAfap of a mosque is a word used by the lawyers, and is one of their mistakes, as IB has notified: so says MF: its pl. is XaraAriyfu. (TA.) ― -b4- The XurufaAt (thus with two dammehs, K) of a horse are The neck and qaTaAp [i. e. croup, or rump, or part between the hips or haunches,] thereof. (O, K.)

XurufapN c
XurufapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XariyfN c
XariyfN High, elevated, exalted, or eminent, (S, O, * Msb, K, TA,) [in rank, condition, or estimation,] in respect of religion or of worldly things: (TA:) [generally meaning high-born, or noble:] possessing glory, honour, dignity, or nobility: or such, and having also [such] ancestry: (TA:) [using it as not implying highness, or nobility, of ancestry,] you say, huwa XariyfN Alyawoma [He is high, or noble, to-day], and Eano qaliylK XaArifN↓ as meaning one who will be Xariyf [after a little while]: (Fr, S, K:) the pl. [of pauc.] is OaXoraAfN and [of mult.] XurafaMCu (S, O, Msb, K) and XarafN↓, so in the K, app. denoting that this last is one of the pls. of Xryf, and it is said in the O that XarafN is syn. with XurafaMCu; but in the L it is said that it is syn. with XariyfN; and hence the saying huwa Xarafu qawomihi meaning He is the Xariyf of his people, and karamuhumo meaning the kariym of them; and thus it has been expl. as used in a trad.: (TA:) [but both these assertions are probably correct; for it seems to be, agreeably with analogy, an inf. n. used as an epithet, and therefore applicable to a single person and to a pl. number, and also to two persons, and likewise to a female as well as to a male.] ― -b2- [By the modern Arabs, and the Turks and Persians, it is also applied, as a title of honour, to Any descendant of the Prophet; like sayRid. And, with the article Al, particularly to the descendant of the Prophet who is The governor of Mekkeh; now always a vassal of the Turkish Sultán.]

XuraAfiIRN c
XuraAfiIRN, applied to a [lizard of the kind called] DabR, and to a jerboa, Large in the ears, and in the body: (TA:) and so XuraAfiyRapN applied to a she-camel; (O, K, TA;) as also XarofaMCu↓. (TA.) And OucunN XuraAfiyRapN i. q. XufaAriyRapN [q. v.], (K, TA,) or An ear that is high, long, and having hair upon it. (IDrd, O, TA.) See also OucunN XarofaMCu, voce OaXorafu. ― -b2- Also A kind of white garments or cloths: (O, K: *) or a garment, or piece of cloth, that is purchased from a country of the foreigners adjacent to the land of the Arabs. (As, O, K. *)

XurRaAfapN c
XurRaAfapN; pl. XaraAriyfu: see XurofapN.

XiroyaAfN c
XiroyaAfN (S, O, K) and XironaAfN (O and K in art. Xrnf) [but see Q. Q. 1] The leaves of seedproduce that have become so long and abundant that one fears its becoming marred; wherefore they are cut off. (S, O, K.)

XaArifN c
XaArifN: see XariyfN. ― -b2- Applied to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) High [app. meaning much advanced] in age: (A, TA:) or advanced in age; (S, O, K;) decrepit; (IAar, K;) as also XaArifapN: (K:) [see daluwqN, in three places:] pl. XurofN, like buzolN and EuwcN pls. of baAzilN and EaAYicN, (S, O,) or XurufN, like kutubN, (K,) or the latter is allowable in poetry, (O,) or the former is a contraction of the latter, (IAth, TA,) and XawaArifu [also pl. of XaArifapN] (O, K) and XurRafN and XuruwfN: (K:) it is said that XaArifN is not applied to the he-camel; but it is so applied, as well as to the she-camel, accord. to the Towsheeh of El-Jelál. (TA.) Hence, as being likened to black decrepit she-camels, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) AlXRurufu Aljuwnu, with two dammehs, [which I think a mistake, unless it mean with a dammeh to each word,] (K,) or AlXRarofu Aljuwnu, (O, IAth, TA,) occurring in a trad., meaning (assumed tropical:) [Trials, or conflicts and factions,] like portions of the dark night: (O, * K, * TA:) thus expl. by the Prophet: (O, TA:) but some relate it otherwise, with q, (K,) saying AlXRuroqu Aljwn, pl. of XaAriqN, (O, * TA,) meaning “ [trials, &c.,] rising (O, K, TA) from the direction of the east. ” (O, TA.) ― -b3- Also applied to an arrow, as meaning Old: (S, O, K:) and applied to a garment or a piece of cloth [app. in the same sense]: (A and TA voce TariydN:) or an arrow long since laid by [expl. by baEiydu AlEahodi biAlSRiyaAbapi; but I think that the right reading is bEyd AlEhd liAlSRiyaAnapi, and have assumed this to be the case in my rendering]: or of which the feathers and the sinews [wherewith they are bound] have become uncompact: or slender and long. (TA.) ― -b4- danRN XaArifN [A wine-jar] of which the wine is old. (TA.) ― -b5- And XaArifN [alone] A receptacle for wine, such as a xaAbiyap and the like thereof. (O, K.)

AlXRaAruwfu c
AlXRaAruwfu A kind of cord or rope; syn. HabolN: [so in the O, and in one of my copies of the S: in my other copy of the S, and in the K, jabalN, i. e. the name of a certain mountain:] a postclassical word. (S, O.) ― -b2- And XaAruwfN also signifies A broom: (S, O, K:) a Pers. word, (S,) arabicized, from jaAruwbN, (O, K,) originally jaAIo ruwbo, which means “ a place-sweeper. ” (O.)

OaXorafu c
OaXorafu [More, and most, high, elevated, exalted, or eminent, in rank, condition, or estimation; &c.; generally meaning more, and most, high-born or noble; (see XariyfN;)] surpassing in Xaraf. (S, O.) ― -b2- manokibN OaXorafu A high shoulder; (S, O, K;) such as has a goodly rising; which implies what is termed UihodaMC [inf. n. of OahodaOahu, and here app. meaning the “ being curved in the back ”]. (TA.) And OucunN XarofaMCu A long ear; (S, O, K;) standing up; rising above what is next to it: and so Acn XuraAfiyRapN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- See also XuraAfiIRN [OaXorafu also signifies Having a prominent, or an apparent, ear: opposed to OasakRu, q. v. ― -b4- Hence,] AlOaXorafu is an appellation of The bat; (O, K, TA;) because its ears are prominent and apparent: it is bare of downy and other feathers, and is viviparous, not oviparous: so in the saying of Bishr Ibn-ElMoatemir,
waTaAYirN layosa lahu wakoru
waTaAYirN OaXorafu cuw jurodapK
[And a flying thing that has prominent and apparent ears and a denuded body, and a flying thing that has no nest]: (O, TA:) in the K is added, and another bird, that has no nest, &c.: but this is taken from an explanation of the latter hemistich of the verse cited above; which explanation is as follows: (TA:) the bird that has no nest is one of which the Bahránees [so in the TA, but accord. to the O “ the sailors, ”] tell that it does not alight save while it makes, of the dust, or earth, a place in which it lays its eggs, and which it covers over; then it flies into the air, and its eggs break open of themselves at the expiration of the term thereof; and when its young ones are able to fly, they do after the habit of their parents. (O, L, TA: and the same is said, less fully, in the K.) ― -b5- madiynapN XarofaMCu A city having Xuraf, (Mgh, O, K, *) pl. of XurofapN [q. v.]: (O:) the pl. of OaXorafu and of XarofaMCu, accord. to rule, is XurofN. (Mgh. [In the copies of the K, AlXRurufu is erroneously said to be pl. of AlXRarofaMCu.]) It is said in a trad. of Ibn- ' Abbás, OumironaA Oano naboniIa AlmadaAYina XurofFA waAlmasaAjida jumRFA i. e. We have been commanded to build cities with Xuraf and mosques without Xuraf. (Mgh, O. *)

OaXoraAfN c
OaXoraAfN The ears and nose of a man: (O, K, TA:) its sing. in this sense is not mentioned: it is app. XarafN↓; like sababN, sing. of OasobaAbN. (TA.)

taXoriyfN c
taXoriyfN inf. n. of 2 [q. v.]. (S &c.) ― -b2- [And also a post-classical term applied to An honorary present, such as a garment &c.: and a letter, i. e. an epistle, considered as conferring honour: pl. taXoriyfaAtN.]

maXorafN c
maXorafN: see XarafN, in the middle of the paragraph: and see also what here next follows.

muXorafN c
muXorafN, (O, K,) like mukoramN, (K,) or maXorafN↓ [q. v. voce XarafN], (so in my two copies of the S,) A place from which one overlooks, i. e. looks upon, or views, [a thing] from above. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Hence the saying in a trad., maA jaMCaka mino hecaA AlmaAli waOanota gayoru muXorafK walaA saAYilK faxocohu (O, TA) i. e. [What comes to thee of this property] thou not coveting nor looking for it [nor asking it, take it]. (O.)

muXorifN c
muXorifN [part. n. of 4;] High; (S, Mgh, Msb;)
[or overtopping; &c.;] applied to a mountain, (S,) or a place. (Mgh, Msb.)

suyuwfN maXorafiyRapN c
suyuwfN maXorafiyRapN Certain swords, (S, O, K,) so called in relation to maXaArifu, (S,) or in relation to maXaArifu AlXRaAmi, (O, Msb, K,) i. e. certain towns, or villages, of the land of the Arabs, near to the riyf [q. v.]: (S, O, Msb, K:) so says AO: (S, O:) or, as some say, this is a mistake, and they are so called in relation to a place of El-Yemen: (Msb:) [or, accord. to some, in relation to AlmaXaArifu, certain towns, or villages, near Howrán: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., iii. 53:)] and it is said that maXoraf was the name of a blacksmith who made swords: (TA:) one says sayofN maXorafiIRN, (S, O, Msb,) not maXaArifiIRN, because a rel. n. is not formed from a pl. of the measure of maXaArifu. (S, O.)

muXarRafN c
muXarRafN [Elevated, or exalted, in rank, condition, or estimation; or ennobled]; (K, TA;) an epithet applied to a man; from AlXRarafu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with the red clay or earth [&c.] called Xaraf. (IAar, TA.)

maXoruwfN c
maXoruwfN (S, TA) and maXoruwfN Ealayohi (Z, TA) Overcome, or surpassed, in Xaraf [i. e. highness, elevation, or eminence, of rank, condition, or estimation; or nobility]. (S, Z, TA.)

muXotarifN c
muXotarifN A horse high in make. (S, O, K.)

1 Xaraqati AlXRamosu c
1. Xaraqati AlXRamosu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
Xaruqa
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. XuruwqN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and XaroqN, (S, Msb,) The sun rose; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also OaXoraqat↓: (K:) the sun rose from the east; and in like manner one says of the moon, and of the stars: (M:) or the sun rose so that its light began to fall upon the earth and trees: (T and TA in art. cr:) and AXrqt↓ signifies, as distinguished from Xaraqat, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) or signifies also, (K, TA,) for both verbs are correctly expl. in the K as above, (TA,) it shone, or gave its light, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) and spread (M, TA) upon the earth, or ground: (TA:) or, as some say, Xaraqat, and AXrqt↓ are syn., (M, Msb,) as meaning it (the sun) shone: (M:) and XaroqN [as inf. n. of the former verb] signifies the shining of the sun. (K.) ― -b2- And Xaraqa AlnRaxolu, and AXrq↓, The palm-trees showed redness in their fruit: (M, K: *) or showed the colours of their dates. (AHn, M.) [See also Xariqa in what follows.] ＝ -A2- Xaraqa AlXRaApa, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Xaruqa
, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. XaroqN, He slit the ear of the sheep, or goat, (S, O, Msb, K,) in the manner expl. voce XaroqaMCu. (Msb.) ― -b2- And Xaraqa AlvRamarapa, (Az, K,) inf. n. XaroqN, (IAmb, Az, TA,) He plucked the fruit: (Az, K, TA:) or cut it. (IAmb, Az, TA.) One says in crying baAqilRaMC [or beans], Xaroqu AlgadaApi TariIRN The cutting of the morning, fresh! meaning what has been cut, and picked, in the morning. (IAmb, Az, TA.) ＝ -A3- Xariqa, [aor.
Xaraqa
,] inf. n. XaraqN, It (a place) was, or became, bright by reason of the sun's shining upon it; as also AXrq↓; (M, TA;) [whence,] QloOaroDu binuwri rabRihaA waOaXoraqati↓ occurs in the Kur [xxxix. 69 as meaning And the earth shall shine with the light of its Lord]: (M:) [in other instances,] OaXoraqati AlOaroDu means The earth was, or became, bright with the sunshine. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps, or, though not immediately, from what here next follows, some other applications of this verb, to denote redness.] ― -b3- Xariqa biriyqihi, (S, M, Msb, K,) and biAlmaMCi, and the like, (M,) aor.
Xaraqa
, (Msb,) inf. n. XaraqN, (M, Msb,) He (a man, M, Msb) was, or became, choked with his spittle, (S, M, Msb, K,) and with water, &c. (M.) [And jariDa and gaSRa and XajiIa are sometimes used in the same sense in relation to spittle &c.] ― -b4- [Hence,] Xariqa AljuroHu biAldRami (assumed tropical:) The wound became [choked or] filled with blood. (Msb.) ― -b5- And Xariqa AlmawoDiEu biOaholihi (tropical:) The place became [choked or] filled and straitened by its occupants. (TA.) ― -b6- And Xariqa Aljasadu biAlTRiybi (tropical:) [The body became choked in its pores with perfume]. (TA.) ― -b7- [And Xariqa AlvRawobu biAljaAdiIRi (assumed tropical:) The garment, or piece of cloth, became glutted, or saturated, with the dye of saffron: see the part. n. XariqN.] ― -b8- And Xariqato Eayonuhu (tropical:) His eye became red [being surcharged with blood]; as also AiXoraworaqatN↓: (M, TA:) and so Xariqa AldRamu fiI Eayonihi: (K, TA:) or this last signifies the blood appeared in his eye: (M:) and Xariqato biAldRami it (the eye) had the blood apparent in it, [as though it were choked therewith,] without its running from it. (TA.) ― -b9- And Xariqa lawonuhu, inf. n. XaraqN, (assumed tropical:) His colour, or complexion, became red, by reason of shame, or shame and confusion. (TA.) ― -b10- And [hence, app.,] Xariqa AlXRaIoCu, inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) The thing became intensely red, with blood, or with a beautiful red colour. (M, TA.) ― -b11- And also (assumed tropical:) The thing became mixed, commingled, or blended. (M, TA.) ― -b12- Xariqati AlXRamosu, inf. n. as above, means (tropical:) The sun had a duskiness blended with it, and it [app. the duskiness] then became little: (TA:) or it was near to setting: (M, K:) or became feeble in its light; (O, K;) app. from XariqN applied to flesh-meat as meaning “ red, having no grease, or gravy, ” and applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, as meaning “ red, that has become glutted, or saturated, (Xariqa,) with dye; ” because its colour, in the last part of the day, when it is setting, becomes red. (O.) ― -b13- The phrase yuWaxRiruwna AlSRalaApa UilaI Xaraqi AlmawotaI, (S, M, O, K, [in the CK, erroneously, Xaroqi,]) occurring in a trad., (S, M, O,) in a saying of the Prophet, (O, K,) is expl. as meaning Who postpone, or defer, the prayer until there remains not, (S, M, O, K,) of the sun, (S,) or of the day, (M, O, K,) save as much as remains (S, M, O, K) of the life, (S,) or of the breath, (M, O, K, [but in the CK, nafosi is put in the place of nafasi,]) of the dying who is choked with his spittle: (S, M, O, K:) or the meaning is, until the sun is [but just] above the walls, and [diffusing its feeble light] among the graves (M, O, K *) as though it were a great expanse of water. (M, O.) AZ says, yukorahu AlSRalaApu biXaraqi AlmawotaI means Prayer is disapproved when the sun becomes yellow: and faEalotu celika biXaraqi AlmawotaI I did that when the sun was becoming yellow. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Xariqati AlXRaApu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Xaraqa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XaraqN, (S, Msb,) The sheep, or goat, had its ear slit (S, Msb, K) in the manner expl. voce XaroqaMCu. (Msb, K.)

2 XrRq c
2. XrRq, (TA,) inf. n. taXoriyqN, (S, O, K,) He took to the direction of the east, or place of sunrise: (S, O, K, TA:) he went to the east: he came to the east: (M, TA:) and he directed himself to the east. (TA.) ― -b2- And He prayed at sunrise: and hence, app., He performed the prayer of the festival of the sacrifice: (TA:) or this meaning is from Xaraqati AlXRamosu. (Mgh: it is also mentioned in the M.) ― -b3- XrRqt AlOaroDu, inf. n. as above, The land became affected with drought, and dryness of the earth, being [parched by the sun and] not reached by water: whence the term XaraAqiIR↓ [q. v.] in the dial. of Egypt. (TA.) ― -b4- taXoriyqN also signifies The being beautiful, and [sunny or] shining in face. (Sh, O, K.) ＝ -A2- XrRq AllRaHoma, (M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) He cut the flesh-meat into strips, and dried it in the sun, or spread it in the sun to dry: (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) or [simply] he cut it into pieces, and into strips. (Msb.) [In like manner also] taXoriyqu AlXRaEiyri signifies The throwing barley in a sunny place in order that it may dry. (Mgh.) And one says of the [wild] bull, yuXarRiqu matonahu, meaning He exposes his back to the sun in order that what is upon it of the dew of night may dry: in this sense the phrase is used by Aboo-Dhu-eyb. (M.) ― -b2- OayRaAmu AltRaXoriyqi is an appellation of The three days next after the day of sacrifice: (S, M, O, Msb:) [i. e. the eleventh and twelfth and thirteenth days of Dhu-l-Hijjeh:] these days were so called because the flesh of the victims was therein cut into strips, and dried in the sun, or spread in the sun to dry: (S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K: *) or because the victims were not sacrificed until the sun rose: (IAar, S, O, K:) or from the prayer of the day of sacrifice, which they follow: (Mgh:) or because they used to say, [on that day,] (S, M, O,) in the Time of Ignorance, (M,) vabiyro kayomaA nugiyro OaXoriqo↓, (S, M, O,) which means Enter thou upon the time of sunrise, Thebeer, (addressing one of the mountains of Mekkeh, M, * Mgh,) that we may push, or press, on, or forward, (M, Mgh, Msb,) to return from Minè: (M: [see also 4 in art. gwr:]) Aboo- Haneefeh used to hold that AltRaXoriyq means AltRakobiyr [i. e. the saying AallRehu Oakobaro]; but none beside him has held this opinion. (TA.) It is said in a trad. that the days thus called are days of eating and drinking, and of celebrating the praises of God. (O.) ― -b3- XrRq AlvRawoba (assumed tropical:) He made [or dyed] the garment, or piece of cloth, yellow: (Ibn-'Abbád, O:) [or he dyed it red: (see the pass. part. n., below:)] or taXoriyqN signifies the dyeing with saffron, (M, L,) so that the thing dyed is saturated, (L,) or not so that the thing is saturated: (so in a copy of the M:) it is not with safflower. (M, L.
[See also 4, last signification.]) ＝ -A3- XrRq AlaHowaD is sometimes said for SarRajahu, meaning He plastered the watering-trough, or tank, with XaAruwq [q. v.], or SaAruwj. (M in art. Srj.)

4 AXrq c
4. AXrq: see 1, in six places. One says also, AXrq wajohuhu, (S,) and lawonuhu, (M,) His face, (S,) and his colour, or complexion, (M,) shone, (S, M,) and was bright, with beauty. (S.) ― -b2- Some allow its being made trans.; [meaning It caused, or made, to shine;] as in the saying,
valaAvapN tuXoraqu AldRunoyaA bibahojatihaA
Xamosu AlDRuHaI waOabuw UisoHaAqa wAlqamaru
[There are three things, with the beauty of which the world is made to shine; the sun of the bright early morning, and Aboo-Is-hák, and the moon]: but there is no proof in this, because [the right reading may be tuXoriqu, and so] AldnyA may be an agent; therefore the making the verb trans. [in this sense] is said to be post-classical, though it is mentioned by the author of the Ksh. (MF, TA.) ― -b3- It signifies also He entered upon the time of sunrise: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) similarly to Oafojara, and OaSobaHa, and OaZohara. (TA.) See 2. ＝ -A2- AXrq EaduwRahu He caused his enemy to become choked [with his spittle, or with water, or the like: see 1]. (O, K.) And OaXoraqotu fulaAnFA biriyqihi (tropical:) [I choked the utterance, or impeded the action, of such a one;] I did not allow such a one to say, or to do, a thing. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- AXrq AlvRawoba biAlSRibogi, (Moheet, A, O,) or fiI AlSRibogi, (K,) (tropical:) He exceeded the usual degree in dyeing the garment, or piece of cloth; [saturated it with dye;] or dyed it thoroughly. (K, TA. [See also 2, last signification but one.])

5 tXrRq c
5. tXrRq He sat in a sunny place (S, O, K) [at any season, (see maXoruqapN,) or particularly] in winter. (O, K.) ― -b2- And tXrRqwA They looked through the miXoriyq of the door, i. e. the chink thereof into which the light of the rising sun falls. (O.)

7 AnXrqt Alqawosu c
7. AnXrqt Alqawosu The bow split. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

12 AiXoraworaqato Eayonuhu c
12. AiXoraworaqato Eayonuhu: see 1, latter half. ― -b2- AiXoraworaqa biAldRamoEi (tropical:) He became drowned in tears. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA.)

XaroqN c
XaroqN [an inf. n.: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also] The sun; (S, O, K;) and so XaraqN↓: (K, and thus in one of my copies of the S in the place of the former:) [or] XaroqapN↓ has this signification: (M, Msb:) and XaroqN signifies the rising sun; (M, TA;) as some say; (M;) thus accord. to AA and IAar; (TA;) and so XaraqN↓, (M, Msb,) and XaroqapN↓, and XariqapN↓, (M, K,) and XaraqapN↓, (TA,) and XaAriqN↓, (S, * M, K,) and XariyqN↓: (M, K:) one says, TalaEati AlXRaroqu The sun rose; (S, M, O; in one of my copies of the S AlXRaraqu↓;) but not garabati AlXRaroqu: (M:) and Mtiyka kulRa XaAriqK↓ I will come to thee every day that the sun rises: or, as some say, XaAriqN signifies the upper limb (qaron) of the sun: (M:) and one says, laA Mtiyka maA carRa XaAriqN [I will not come to thee as long as a sun, or the upper limb of a sun, rises, or begins to rise]. (S, M.) ― -b3- See also maXoriqN, in three places. ― -b4- Also A place where the sun shines (Hayovu tuXoriqu AlXRamosu). (K.) See maXoruqapN. ― -b5- The warmth of the sun. (TA.) ― -b6- The light that enters from the chink of a door; (IAar, Th, K;) as also XiroqN↓. (K.) In a trad. of I'Ab, (TA,) it is said of a gate in Heaven, called AlmiXoriyqu↓ [q. v.], qado rudRa HatRaI maA baqiIa UilRaA Xaroquhu (O, K, TA) i. e. It had been closed so that there remained not save its light entering from the chink thereof: so says I'Ab. (O, TA.) ― -b7- And A chink, or fissure. (K, TA.) One says, maA daxala Xaroqa famiI XaIoCN Nothing entered the chink of my mouth. (Z, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain bird, (Sh, M, K,) one of the birds of prey, (M,) between the kite and the hawk, or falcon, (Sh, K,) or between the kite and the [species of falcon called] XaAhiyn [q. v.]: (O:) pl. XuruwqN. (M.)

XiroqN c
XiroqN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XaraqN c
XaraqN [inf. n. of Xariqa, q. v. ― -b2- And also a subst.]: see XaroqN, in three places. ― -b3- Also A thing [such as spittle and the like (see Xariqa)] obstructing, or choking, the throat, or fauces. (S, and Har p. 477.)

XariqN c
XariqN A place bright by reason of the sun's shining upon it; as also muXoriqN↓. (M, TA.) ― -b2- A man choked with his spittle, or with water, or the like. (M, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A plant, or herbage, having plentiful irrigation; or flourishing and fresh, or juicy, by reason of plentiful irrigation; syn. rayRaAnu. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, red; that is glutted, or saturated, [so I render AalRaciI Xariqa,] with dye: (O:) and XariqN biAljaAdiIRi applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, [app. signifies (assumed tropical:) glutted, or saturated, with the dye of saffron: see also muXarRaqN, and see 4.] (TA.) One says also SariyEN XariqN bidamihi (assumed tropical:) [Prostrated,] dyed with his blood. (M, TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) Flesh-meat (S, M, O, TA) that is red, (M, O, TA,) having no grease, or gravy. (S, M, O, TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A thing intensely red, with blood, or with a beautiful red colour. (M.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) A thing mixed, commingled, or blended. (M.)

XaroqapN c
XaroqapN: see XaroqN, in two places: ― -b2- and see maXoruqapN, in two places.

XuroqapN c
XuroqapN (assumed tropical:) Anxiety, grief, or anguish; syn. in Pers. Oanoduwho. (KL.)

XaraqapN c
XaraqapN: see XaroqN: ― -b2- and see maXoruqapN. ＝ -A2- Also A brand with which a sheep, or goat, such as is termed XaroqaMC, is marked. (O, K.)

XariqapN c
XariqapN: see XaroqN.

XaApN XaroqaMCu c
XaApN XaroqaMCu A sheep, or goat, having its ear slit (S, Mgh, O, K) lengthwise, (K,) without its being separated: (TA:) or having the ear slit in two, (As, Msb, TA,) as though it were a zanamap [q. v.]: (As, TA:) or XaroqaMCu applied to an ear signifies cut at its extremities, without having anything thereof separated: and applied to a she-goat (maEozap), having its ear slit lengthwise, without its being separated: and, as some say, applied to a XAp, having the inner part of its ear slit on one side with a separating slitting, the middle of its ear being left sound: or, accord. to Aboo-'Alee in the “ Tedhkireh, ” XaroqaMCu signifies having its ears slit with two slits passing through, so as to become three distinct pieces. (M.)

XaroqiIRN c
XaroqiIRN [Of, or relating to, the east, or place of sunrise; eastern, or oriental]. ― -b2- laA XaroqiyRapi walaA garobiyRapK, (K, TA,) in the Kur [xxiv. 35], (TA,) means Not such that the sun shines upon it at its rising only (Fr, K, TA) nor at its setting only, (Fr, TA,) but such that the sun lights upon it morning and evening: (Fr, K, TA:) or, accord. to El- Hasan, it means not of the trees of the people of the present world, but of the trees of the people of Paradise: Az, however, says that the former explanation is more fit and more commonly receive. (TA.) And makaAnN XaroqiIRN signifies A place, of the earth, or ground, in, or upon, which the sun rises, or shines. (TA.) See also XaAriqN [and XariqN and maXoruqapN]. ＝ -A2- Also A certain red dye. (TA.)

XariyqN c
XariyqN: see XaroqN. ― -b2- Also A boy, or young man, goodly, or beautiful, (K, TA,) in face: (TA:) pl. XuruqN, (K, TA, [in the CK XaroqN, but correctly]) with two dammehs. (TA.) ― -b3- And A woman small in the vulva: (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K:) or having her vagina and rectum united by the rending of the separation between them; syn. mufoDaApN. (M, K.) ― -b4- And AlXRariyqu is the name of A certain idol. (M, TA.)

Xurayoqap c
[Xurayoqap The first part of the rising sun. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.) See also XaAriqN, voce XaroqN.]

XaraAqiIRu c
XaraAqiIRu [The lands that are not reached by the water, or inundation, and that are consequently parched by the sun]: a word of the dial. of Egypt. (TA.) See 2.

XaAriqN c
XaAriqN: see XaroqN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The side that is next the east; (O;) the eastern side; (K;) of a hill, and of a mountain: you say, hecaA XaAriqu Aljabali and XaroqiyRuhu↓ [This is the eastern side of the mountain], and hcA gaAribu Aljabali and garobiyRuhu [in the opposite sense]: (TA:) pl. XuroqN. (O, K.) Hence, in a trad., as some relate it, AlXRuroqu Aljuwnu [meaning (assumed tropical:) Trials, or conflicts and factions, like portions of the dark night, rising from the direction of the east]: but it is otherwise related, with f [in the place of the q: see XaArifN]. (TA.) ― -b3- And AlXRaAriqu is the name of A certain idol, of the Time of Ignorance; (IDrd, M, K;) whence Eabodu AlXRaAriqi, a proper name [of a man]. (IDrd, M.) ＝ -A2- Also [if not a mistranscription for XaAruwqN, q. v., app. Clay, or some other
substance or mixture, with which a place is plastered,] maA yuTayRanu bihi makaAnN. (Ibn-' Abbád, O.)

XaAruwqN c
XaAruwqN signifies [The kind of plaster called] kilosN, [q. v.,] (Kr, M,) i. q. SaAruwjN. (K. [See this last word: and see also the last sentence of the next preceding paragraph above.])

maXoraqN c
maXoraqN: see what next follows.

maXoriqN c
maXoriqN (S, M, O, Msb, K,) which by rule should be maXoraqN↓, (M, Msb,) but this latter is rarely used, (Msb,) The place, (M,) or quarter, or direction, (Msb,) of sunrise; (M, Msb;) [the east, or orient;] and XaroqN↓ signifies the same; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also miXoriyqN↓: (Seer, M:) the pl. of the first is maXaAriqu; and the pl. of XaroqN↓ is OaXoraAqN. (M.) The dual, AlmaXoriqaAni, means The place of sunrise of summer and that of winter [E. 26 degrees N. and E. 26 degrees S. in Central Arabia]. (S, O, TA.) And also The place of sunrise and the place of sunset; [or the east and the west;] (M, O;) the former being thus made predominant because it denotes existence, whereas the latter denotes non-existence: (M:) thus in the saying, (M, O,) in the Kur [xliii. 37], (O,) yaA layota bayoniI wabayonaka buEoda QlomaXoriqayoni [O, would that between me and thee were the distance of the east and the west]. (M, O.) And [in like manner] one says maA bayona AlXRaroqayoni↓, meaning What is between the place of sunrise and the place of sunset. (M.) ― -b2- See also maXoruqapN. ― -b3- The saying, cited by IAar,
qulotu lisaEodK wahowa biAlOazoAriqi
Ealayoka biAlmaHoDi wabiAlmaXaAriqi
he explains as meaning [I said to Saad, he being at El-Azárik (a certain water in the baAdiyap, TA in art. zrq)], Keep thou [to pure milk, and] to the sun [or the places of sunshine] in winter: but [ISd says,] in my opinion, AlmaXaAriq is here pl. of muXarRaqN↓ applied to flesh-meat that is “ [cut into strips and] spread in the sun [to dry]; ” and this is confirmed by his saying bAlmHD, each of them being food. (M.)

muXoriqN c
muXoriqN: see XariqN. ― -b2- Also Entering upon the time of sunrise: the pl. occurs in this sense in the Kur xv. 73 and xxvi. 60. (TA.)

maXoruqapN c
maXoruqapN and maXoraqapN (S, M, O, K) and maXoriqapN, (M, O, K,) the last mentioned by Ks, (O,) A place of sitting in the sun; (S, O, K;) accord. to some, peculiarly, (TA,) in the winter; (O, K, TA;) and XaroqapN↓ and miXoraAqN↓ (S, O, K) and miXoriyqN↓ (O, K) signify the same: (S, O, K:) or a place upon which the sun shines; accord. to some, peculiarly, in the winter, (M,) as also XaroqapN↓ and XaraqapN↓ (M, TA) and XaroqN↓ (M) and mXrq [app. maXoriqN↓, of the pl. of which, or of one of the first three words in this paragraph, see an ex. in a verse cited voce maXoriqN if the explanation of that verse by IAar be correct]. (TA.)

maXoriqiIRN c
maXoriqiIRN (Msb, TA) and maXoraqiIRN both [applied to a man] signify Of the east; or eastern: (Msb:) pl. maXaAriqapN. (TA.)

muXarRaqN c
muXarRaqN A place of prayer; syn. muSalRFI; (As, S, M, Mgh, K;) i. e., in an absolute sense: (TA:) or the place of prayer of the festival (AlEiyd): (TA:) or the place of prayer of the two festivals: and AlmuXarRaqu is said to mean the place of prayer of the festival at Mekkeh: (M, TA:) and the mosque of El-Kheyf. (S, K.) ― -b2- And The festival (AlEiyd) [itself]: because the prayer thereon is after the Xaroqap, i. e. the [rising] sun. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also Flesh-meat [cut into strips and] spread in the sun [to dry: see its verb, 2]. (M.) See also maXoriqN, last sentence. ― -b2- And A garment, or piece of cloth, [dyed yellow: or with saffron: see, again, its verb: or] dyed with a red colour. (O, K.) ＝ -A3- And a fortress [or a watering-trough or tank (see 2, last sentence,)] plastered with XaAruwq. (O, K.)

muXarRiqN c
muXarRiqN Taking to the direction of the east, or place of sunrise: one says, XatRaAna bayona muXarRiqK wamugarRibK [Different, or widely different, are one going towards the east and one going towards the west]. (S.)

miXoraAqN c
miXoraAqN: see maXoruqapN. ＝ -A2- Also A man accustomed to make his enemy to be choked with his spittle. (Z, TA.)

miXoriyqN c
miXoriyqN: see maXoriqN: ― -b2- and maXoruqapN. ― -b3- Also, (M, O, K,) of a door, (M, K,) A chink into which the light of the rising sun falls. (M, * O, K. *) ― -b4- And AlmiXoriyqu is the name of A gate for repentance, in Heaven. (I'Ab, O, K.) See XaroqN.

XiriqoraAqN c
XiriqoraAqN and its vars.: see art. Xqrq.

1 Xarikahu fiyhi c
1. Xarikahu fiyhi, aor.
Xaraka
, inf. n. XirokapN (S, Mgh, * Msb, K) and XarikapN, the former a contraction of the latter, but the more usual, (Msb,) and XirokN (Mgh, Msb) and XarikN, the former of these two a contraction of the latter, but the more usual, (Msb,) or XirokN [q. v. infrà] is a simple subst., (S, K,) [He shared, participated, or partook, with him in it;] he was, or became, a Xariyk [or copartner &c.] to him in it; (Msb;) namely, a sale or purchase, and an inheritance, (S, K,) or an affair; (Msb;) and fyh XArkhu↓ [signifies the same]. (Mgh, Msb, * K. * [It is said in the TA, after the mention of Xarikahu with its inf. n. XirokapN, that it is more chaste than AXrkhu↓; by which it is implied that this latter is sometimes used as syn. with the former; for which I do not find any express authority.] And He entered with him into it; [or engaged with him in it;] namely, an affair. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Xarikati AlnRaEolu, aor.
Xaraka
, The sandal had its XiraAk broken; (Ibn-Buzurj, K;) inf. n. XarakN. (TK.)

2 XarRaka
2: see 4. ― -b2- [The inf. n.] taXoriykN also signifies The selling a part [or share] of what one has purchased for that for which it was purchased. (Mgh, K.) ＝ -A2- XrRk AlnRaEola, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taXoriykN, (S, K,) He put a XiraAk to the sandal; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also OaXorakahaA↓, (S, TA,) inf. n. UiXoraAkN. (TA.)

3 XaArakotu fulaAnFA c
3. XaArakotu fulaAnFA, (S, TA,) inf. n. muXaArakapN, (TK,) [I shared, participated, or partook, with such a one;] I was, or became, the Xariyk [or copartner &c.] of such a one. (S, TA.) El-Jaadee says,
waXaArakonaA qurayoXFA fiI tuqaAhaA
AlEinaAni wafiI OaHosaAbihaA Xiroka↓
[And we shared with Kureysh in their piety and in their several grounds of pretension to respect, with a sharing exclusive of other properties]. (S.) See also 1. [And see 8.]

4 OaXorakotuhu fiI AlOamori c
4. OaXorakotuhu fiI AlOamori I made him a Xariyk [or copartner &c.] to me in the affair: and XarRakotu↓ bayonahumo fiI AlmaAli [I made them copartners in the property; and XarRakahumo, occurring in this art. in the TA, on the authority of Esh-Sháfi'ee, means, in like manner, he made them copartners; and OaXoraka bayonahumo is used in this sense in the present art. in the K]. (Msb.) waOaXorikohu fiI OamoriI, in the Kur [xx. 33], means And make Thou him my Xariyk [or copartner, or associate, or colleague,] in my affair. (S.) And one says also, AXrkhu maEahu fiI AlOamori He made him to enter [or engage] with him in the affair: and AXrk fulaAnFA fiI AlbayoEi He made such a one to enter [or share] with him in the sale or purchase. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AXrk biQllRehi He attributed to God a Xariyk [or copartner &c.] (Mgh, TA) in his dominion: (TA:) [or he attributed to God XurakaMC i. e. copartners &c., such as the angels and the devils: (see Kur vi. 100, &c., and any of the expositions thereof:) i. e. he believed in a duality, or a plurality, of gods:] and [in a wider sense,] he disbelieved [or misbelieved] in God: syn. kafara: (S, * Msb, K, TA:) used in this latter sense because Alkuforu is not free from some kind of Xirok. (Kull p. 49.) ＝ -A2- See also 1: ＝ -A3- and 2.

6 taXaAoraka
6: see the next paragraph, in three places.

8 AXtrkwA c
8. AXtrkwA and tXArkwA↓, (Mgh, Msb,) and AXtrkA and tXArkA↓, (K,) and AXtrknA and tXArknA↓, (S,) [They, and they two, and we, shared, participated, or partook, one with another, and each with the other; or were, or became, copartners, &c.;] fiI kacaA [in such a thing]. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlAiXotiraAku in lexicology signifies The being homonymous; lit. the being shared, or participated, in by several meanings: [used as a subst., homonymy:] (Mz, 25th nwE; and Intr. to the TA:) one says of a noun [or word] that is termed muXotarakN [q. v.], taXotariku fiyhi maEaAnK kaviyrapN [Many meanings share, or participate, in it]. (TA.) ― -b3- And AXtrk AlOamoru (assumed tropical:) The affair, or case, was, or became, confused, and dubious. (TA.)

XarokN c
XarokN: see what next follows.

XirokN c
XirokN is an inf. n. of Xarikahu, as mentioned in the
first sentence of this art.: (Mgh, Msb:) or a subst. therefrom: (S:) and is syn. with XirokapN↓, [signifying A sharing, participating or participation, partaking, or copartnership, and mentioned before as an inf. n.,] (K,) as also are XarikN↓ and XarikapN↓, [likewise mentioned before as inf. ns.,] and XarokN↓ and XarokapN↓, (MF, TA,) and so is XurokapN↓, with damm, (K,) this last said by MF to be unknown, but it is common in Syria, almost to the exclusion of the other dial. vars. mentioned above. (TA.) An ex. of the first occurs in a trad, of Mo'ádh, OajaAza bayona Oaholi Alyamani AlXRiroka, meaning [He allowed, among the people of El-Yemen,] the sharing, one with another, (AlAiXotiraAk,) in land [and app. its produce], by its owner giving it to another for the half [app. of its produce], or the third, or the like thereof: and a similar ex. of the same word occurs in another trad. (TA.) See also an ex. in a verse cited above, conj. 3. And one says, ragibonaA fiI Xirokikumo, meaning We are desirous of sharing with you in affinity, or relationship by marriage. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And A share: (Mgh, O, Msb, TA:) as in the saying, biyEa XirokN mino daArihi [A share of his house was sold]: (Mgh:) and as in the saying, OaEotaqa XirokFA lahu fiI EabodK [He emancipated a share belonging to him in a slave]: (Msb:) pl. OaXoraAkN. (O, Msb, TA.) [See a verse of Lebeed cited voce zaEaAmapN.] ― -b3- It is also a subst. from OaXoraka biQllRehi; (Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) thus in the Kur xxxi. 12; (Mgh, TA;) meaning The attribution of a Xariyk [or copartner &c., or of XurakaMC i. e. copartners &c., (see 4,)] to God: (Mgh:) [so that it may be rendered belief in a plurality of gods:] and [in a wider sense,] unbelief [or misbelief]; syn. kuforN. (S, Msb, K, TA.) And it is also expl. as meaning Hypocrisy: (Mgh, TA:) so in the saying of the Prophet, UinRa Oaxowafa maA OaxaAfu EalaI OumRatiI AlXRiroku [Verily the most fearful of what I fear for my people is hypocrisy]: (Mgh:) and so in the trad., AlXRiroku OaxofaI fiI OumRatiI mino dabiybi AlnRamoli [Hypocrisy is more latent in my people than the creeping of ants]. (IAth, TA.) ― -b4- See also XariykN, in two places.

XarakN c
XarakN The HibaAlap [properly a sing., meaning snare, but here app. used as a gen. n., meaning snares, as will be seen from what follows,] of the SaAYid [i. e. sportsman, or catcher of game, or wild animals, or birds]; one of which is called XarakapN↓: (S, O:) the meaning of the Xarak of the SaAYid is well known; and the pl. is OaXoraAkN; like sababN and OasobaAbN: or, as some say, XarakN is the pl. of XarakapN↓, [or rather is a coll. gen. n. of which XarakapN↓ is the n. un.,] like qaSabN and qaSabapN: (Msb:) [i. e.,] XarakN signifies the HabaAYil [or snares, or by this may perhaps be meant the cords composing a snare, for HabaAYilu is an anomalous pl. of HabolN,] for catching wild animals or the like; and what is, or are, set up for [catching] birds: (K, TA:) one whereof is said to be called XarakapN↓ [a term used in the K, in art. Xbk, as the explanation of XabakapN, which means a net]: (TA:) and the pl. of XarakN is XurukN, with two dammehs, which is extr. [with respect to analogy, like fulukN pl. of falakN]. (K.) Hence the trad., OaEuwcu bika mino XarRi AlXRayoTaAni waXarakihi, meaning HabaAYilihi wamaSaAyidihi [i. e. I seek protection by Thee from the mischief of the Devil, and his snares]. (TA.) ― -b2- Xaraku AlTRariyqi means The main and middle parts of the road; (S, K;) syn. jawaAdRuhu: or the tracks that are [conspicuous and distinct,] not obscure to one nor blended together: (K:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of XarakapN↓: (S:) or the OanosaAE of the road; (As, TA;) i. e. the furrows of the road, made by the beasts with their legs [or feet] in its surface, a Xarakap↓ here and another by the side of it: (TA:) or OaXoraAkN [is its pl., and] signifies the small tracks that branch off from the main road and then stop, or terminate. (Sh, TA.) [See OusRN.]

XarikN c
XarikN: see XirokN, first sentence.

XarokapN c
XarokapN: see XirokN, first sentence.

XurokapN c
XurokapN: see XirokN, first sentence.

XirokapN c
XirokapN: see XirokN, first sentence. ― -b2- Also A piece of flesh-meat; of the dial. of El-Yemen; originally, of a slaughtered camel, in which people share, one with another. (TA.)

XarakapN c
XarakapN: see XarakN, in six places.

XarikapN c
XarikapN: see XirokN, first sentence.

XurakiIRN c
XurakiIRN and XurRakiIRN A quick, or swift, pace: (K:) so says ISd. (TA.) And laTomN XurakiIRN A quick and consecutive slapping, (S, O, K,) like the camel's slapping when a thorn has entered his foot and he beats the ground with it with a consecutive beating. (S, * O.) Ows Ibn-Hajar says,
wamaA Oana UilRaA musotaEidRN kamaA taraI
Oaxuw XurakiIRi Alwirodi gayoru muEatRimi
[And I am none other than one who is ready, as thou seest; one in the habit of quick and consecutive coming to water; not one who is dilatory]: i. e., one coming to water time after time, consecutively: he means, I will do to thee what thou dislikest, not delaying to do that. (S.)

XiraAkN c
XiraAkN The thong, or strap, of the sandal, (Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) that is on the face thereof, (TA,) upon the back [meaning upper side] of the foot, (Mgh, Msb,) [extending from the thong, or strap, that passes between two of the toes, towards the ankle, and having two arms (its EaDudaAni), which are attached to the OucunaAni (q. v.), or pass through these and unite behind the foot: see also xizaAmapN, and faraSahu, whence it appears to mean also each arm, and the two arms, of the XiraAk properly so called: and see sayorN, where it appears to be used as meaning a thong or strap, absolutely:] the XiraAk of the sandal is well known: (O:) pl. XurukN, (O, K, TA,) and accord. to the K OaXorukN also, but this is a mistake. (TA.) To this is likened, in a trad., the shadow at the base of a wall, on the eastern side thereof, when very small [or narrow], showing that the sun has begun to decline from the meridian. (Mgh, Msb,) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A streak of herbage: (S, O, K:) pl. XurukN, (S, O, TA,) expl. by AHn as meaning herbage in streaks; not continuous. (TA.) One says, AlkalaOu fiI baniI fulaAnK XurukN (assumed tropical:) The herbage among the sons of such a one is composed of streaks. (Aboo-Nasr, S, O.) ― -b3- [In the K voce banaqa it is used as meaning (assumed tropical:) A row of shoots, or offsets, cut from palm-trees and planted, such as are termed, when planted, mubanRaqN and munabRaqN.] ― -b4- [Hence,] one says, maDawoA EalaI XiraAkK waAHidK (tropical:) [They went away in one uniform line or manner]. (TA.) And AijoEali AlOamora XiraAkFA waAHidFA (assumed tropical:) Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr, TA in art. bOj.)

XariykN c
XariykN act. part. n. of XarikapN; (Mgh;) i. q. muXaArikN↓ [A sharer, participator, partaker, or partner, with another; a copartner, an associate, or a colleague, of another]; (K;) and XirokN↓ signifies the same: (Az, K, TA:) a sharer in what is not divided: (K and TK in art. xlT:) or a sharer in the rights of a thing that is sold: (Mgh in that art.:) pl. XurakaMCu and OaXoraAkN, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) like XurafaMCu and OaXoraAfN pls. of XariyfN; (S, O, TA;) or the latter is pl. of XirokN↓: (Az, TA:) a woman is termed XariykapN; (S, O, K;) which is applied to a man's jaArap [i. e. wife, or object of love]; (TA;) and the pl. of this is XaraAYiku. (S, O, K.) Az mentions his having heard one of the Arabs say, fulaAnN Xariyku fulaAnK meaning Such a one is married to the daughter, or to the sister, of such a one; what people call the xatan [of such a one]. (TA.)

muXorikN c
muXorikN and muXorikiIRN↓, (S, O, K,) like as one says dawRN and dawRiIRN, and qaEosarN and qaEosariIRN, (S, O,) One who attributes to God a Xariyk [or copartner &c., or XurakaMC i. e. copartners &c. (see 4)]: (O:) [i. e. a believer in a duality, or a plurality, of gods:] and [in a wider sense,] a disbeliever [or misbeliever] in God. (S, O, K.) Abu-l-'Abbás explains [the pl.] muXorikuwna in the Kur xvi. 102 as meaning Those who are mXrkwn by their obeying the Devil; by their worshipping God and worshipping with Him the Devil. (TA.) ― -b2- [In one place, in the CK, the former word is erroneously put for muXotarakN, q. v., last sentence.]

muXorikiIRN c
muXorikiIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

AlmuXarRikapu c
AlmuXarRikapu: see the next preceding paragraph.

muXaArikN c
muXaArikN: see XariykN. ― -b2- riyHN muXaArikN means A wind to which the nakobaMC [q. v.] is nearer than the two winds between which this blows. (K.)

muXotarakN c
muXotarakN, applied to a road (Tariyq, Mgh, Msb, TA), is for muXotarakN fiyhi, (Msb,) meaning [Shared in: or] in which the people are equal [sharers]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, AlOajiyru AlmuXotaraku [in my copy of the Mgh, erroneously, AlmuXotariku,] The hired man [that is shared in; i. e.,] whose work no one has for himself exclusively of others, but who works for every one who repairs to him for work, like the tailor in the sitting-places of the markets; (Msb;) or who works for whom he pleases: as to Oajiyru AlmuXotaraki, it is not right, unless the word thus governed in the gen. case be expl. as an inf. n. (Mgh.) ― -b3- See also AlfariyDapu AlmuXarRakapu, above. ― -b4- AisomN muXotarakN [in like manner for muXotarakN fiyhi A noun shared in by several meanings; i. e. a homonym;] a noun shared in by many meanings, such as EayonN and the like: (Mz, 25th nwE; and TA in the present art. and in the Intr.:) or muXotarakN signifies a word having two, or more, meanings; and is applied to a noun, and to the pret. of a verb as denoting predication and prayer, and to the aor. as denoting the present and the future, and to a particle: (Mz ubi suprà:) [muXotarakN used as a subst., meaning a homonym, has for its pl. muXotarakaAtN.] ― -b5- [AlHisRu AlmuXotaraku, for AlmuXotaraku fiyhi, signifies, in the conventional language of the philosophers, The faculty of fancy; so called because “ participated in ” by the five senses: but it is vulgarly used as meaning common sense.] ― -b6- muXotarakN applied to a man, [for muXotarakN fiyhi,] means (assumed tropical:) Talking to himself, like him who is affected with anxiety; (As, S, K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, muXorikN;]) his judgment being shared in; not one. (TA.)

1 Xaramahu c
1. Xaramahu, (S, K,) aor.
Xarima
, (K,) inf. n. XaromN, i. q. XaqRahu [meaning He slit it; or rent it; and perhaps also he clave it, split it, &c.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- It is also said in the K that AlXRaromu signifies qaToEu maA bayona AlOaronabapi: but mA byn should be struck out: and the passage, moreover, is defective: it should be, as in the M, AlXRaromu and AltRaXoriymu↓ signify The cutting (qaToE [or rather XaqR i. e. slitting or rending]) of the end, or tip, of the nose, and of the vafor [here meaning the vulva, or the orifice of the vagina,] of a she-camel: specially said of these two things. (TA. [See also 2; and see XariymN.]) ― -b3- Xarama AlvRariydapa, aor. and inf. n. as above, and the latter, by poetic license, XaramN, He ate of the sides, or of the edge, of the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth]. (TA.) ― -b4- Xarama lahu mino maAlihi, (S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He gave him little of his mAl (i. e. property, or cattle]. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Xarima, aor.
Xarama
, is quasi-pass. of Xaramahu; [i. e. it signifies It was, or became, slit, or rent;] (TA;) as also AnXrm↓. (S, TA. [In the former it is implied that the meaning of the latter verb is AinoXaqRa.]) ― -b2- Also, aor. as above, (Msb,) inf. n. XaramN, (S, * Msb, K, *) He (a man) had his nose slit: (Msb:) or he had the end, or tip, of his nose cut. (S, * Msb, K. *)

2 taXoriymN c
2. taXoriymN i. q. taXoqiyqN [meaning The slitting, or rending, and perhaps also cleaving, splitting, &c., much, or in several places]: (S, K, TA: [see 2 in art. xrm:]) one says, XrRmhu [he slit it &c.], in relation to the ear &c.: (TA:) [it is used in relation to the end, or tip, of the nose; and to the orifice of the vagina of a she-camel; as shown above:] see 1, second sentence. taXoriymu AlZRiYaAri is [The scarifying of the vulva, or of the orifice of the vagina, for the purpose of] the making a she-camel to affect and suckle a young one not her own [by causing her to imagine, from the pain thus occasioned, that she has recently brought forth that young one]; (TA;) tXrym in this phrase signifying taXoqiyq. (T in art. ZOr.) It is said in a trad. of Ibn-'Omar, that he purchased a she-camel, and, seeing in her what is thus termed, returned her: (S:) in this instance, tXrym AlZYAr means The laceration of the two edges of the vulva on the occasion of ZYAr. (T and TA in art. ZOr: see 1 in that art.) ― -b2- taXoriymu AlSRayodi is The wounding of the skin of the animal of the chase without piercing into the belly, or inside, (L in art. Hq, [see 8 in that art.,]) so that the animal escapes wounded. (S, K. *)

5 tXrRm c
5. tXrRm, (S, K,) said of the skin, (TA,) or of a thing, (S,) It was, or became, rent, or slit, in several places; (S, K, TA;) quasi-pass. of XarRamahu. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Kaab, OataI Eumara bikitaAbK qado taXarRamato nawaAHiyhi i. e. taXaqRaqato [meaning He brought to 'Omar a book of which the sides were slit, or rent, in several places]. (TA.)

7 UinoXarama
7: see 1, near the end.

XaromN c
