XaromN A canal, or cut, (xaliyj,) from a baHor [i. e. sea, or large river]: (S, K:) [now applied to a creek of a sea:] or the lujRap [i. e. main body, or fathomless deep,] of the baHor [or sea]: (K:) or the deepest part thereof: (TA:) or a gamorap [or submerging deep] thereof: pl. XuruwmN. (IB, TA.) ― -b2- And Any fissure in a mountain or rock, not passing through. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain kind of tree. (K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or EuXobN XaromN, (S, [in one of my copies of the S XarimN,]) Abundant herbs or herbage, of which the upper parts are eaten, the middle parts not being required, (S, K,) nor the lower parts. (S.)

XaruwmN c
XaruwmN: see what next follows.

XariymN c
XariymN A woman having her vagina and rectum united by the rending of the separation between them; syn. mufoDaApN; (S, Mgh, K;) as also XaruwmN↓, (S, K,) and XaromaMCu↓; (K;) or the last of these in this sense has not been heard, though mentioned in the sense here following. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also A she-camel having her vafor [here meaning the vulva, or the orifice of the vagina,] cut [or rather slit or rent]; and so XaromaMCu↓, and maXoruwmapN↓: (M, TA:) or XaromaMCu↓ applied to a she-camel and to a she-ass, accord. to the Tekmileh, means having the vulva slit, or rent: therefore the first-mentioned meaning of this epithet, applied to a woman, if correct, may be tropical. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also The faroj [or vulva]; (K;) because of its being cleft. (TA.)

XaArimN c
XaArimN An arrow that slits, or rends, (yaXorimu,) the side of the target. (S, K, TA.)

OaXoramu c
OaXoramu, applied to a man, (IAar, S, Msb, K,) i. q. AlOanofi maXoruwmu↓; (S, K,) [i. e.] Having the nose slit; (IAar, Msb, TA;) like Oaxoramu: (IAar, TA:) or having the end, or tip, of the nose cut: (Msb:) and having the lower lip slit; like OafolaHu: and having the upper lip slit; like OaEolamu: and having the ear slit; like Oaxorabu: and having the eyelid slit; like OaXotaru: it has all these meanings: (IAar, TA:) fem. XaromaMCu, applied to a woman. (Msb.) ― -b2- For the fem., see also XariymN, in three places. ― -b3- The fem. is also applied to an ear (OucunN), meaning Having a small portion cut from the upper part; and so muXarRamapN↓. (TA.)

muXarRamN c
muXarRamN Slit, or rent, in several places: so in a trad., where it is said, fajaMCahu bimuSoHafK muXarRami AlOaToraAfi [And he brought him a copy of the Kur-án having the extremities slit, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also OaXoramu, last sentence.

maXoruwmN c
maXoruwmN: see OaXoramu: ― -b2- and see also XariymN.

Xaronafotu AlzRaroEa c
Xaronafotu AlzRaroEa, mentioned under this head in the O and K: see Q. Q. 4 in art. Xrf. The n is held by Az to be augmentative, if not a mistake for I. (O.)

XironaAfN c
XironaAfN: see XiroyaAfN, art. in Xrf.

Xariha c
Xariha (S, MA, Mgh, Msb, K) EalaI AlTRaEaAmi (MA, Mgh, Msb) wagayorihi, (Msb,) or UilaI AlTRaEaAmi, (TA, [perhaps a mistranscription,]) aor.
Xaraha
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XarahN, (S, MA, Mgh, Msb,) said of a man, (S,) He was vehemently desirous, or greedy; (MA;) or very vehemently desirous, or very greedy; (Mgh, Msb;) or overcome by vehement desire, or greediness; (S, K;) of the food (MA, Mgh, Msb) &c.: (Msb:) or, as some say, he was affected with the worst of vehement desire, or of greediness. (TA.)

XarihN c
XarihN (S, Msb, K) and XarohaAnu↓ (Lth, K) [Vehemently desirous, or greedy; (see 1;) or] very vehemently desirous, or very greedy; (Msb;) or overcome by vehement desire, or greediness: (K:) or, accord. to some, affected with the worst of vehement desire, or of greediness. (TA.)

XarohaAnu c
XarohaAnu: see the next preceding paragraph.

UihoyaA OaXaro UihoyaA c
UihoyaA OaXaro UihoyaA, with kesr to the C in AhyA, and with fet-h to the C in AXr, and to the X, (K, TA,) and with the r quiescent, (TA,) [mentioned in this art. in consequence of the supposing AXr with AhyA after it to compose one word,] but this is not its proper place; (K, TA;) so says Sgh; (TA;) an ancient Greek expression, (K, TA,) or Syriac, or, more correctly, Hebrew; (TA;) [the truth is that it is a mode of writing the Hebrew words אני אהיה שאני “ I shall be that I am, ” in Exod. iii. 14, rendered in our Authorized Version “ I am that I am; ”] said in prayer; (TA;) [virtually] meaning The existing from eternity, that will not cease to be: (K:) Sgh says, thus one of the learned men of the Jews pronounced it to me in 'Adan Abyan: and some say hyA XrAhyA, as though abridging it, meaning yaA HaIRu yaA qayRuwmu [which may be rendered O Ever-living, O Selfsubsisting by Whom all things subsist; but the latter epithet is variously explained]; so says Lth: (TA:) the people now say OahoyaA XaraAhiyaA, (so in some copies of the K,) with fet-h to the C in AhyA, and dropping the C in what follows this word, [which, however, probably means that they say OahoyaA Xaro OahoyaA,] or, as in the handwriting of Sgh, with medd to the C in the former; (TA;) [in my MS. copy of the K MhiyaA XarAhyA; in the CK, MhiyRFA XarAhiyRFA;] which is said in the K to be a mistake accord. to the assertion of the learned men of the Jews: but this, which is said to be a mistake, is what commonly obtains in the books of the people, [i. e. of the Jews,] and they seldom, or never, pronounce it otherwise than thus: As says that the vulgar say yaA hiyaA, which is post-classical; correctly yaA hayaAha [or yaA hayaA], with fet-h to the C: AHát says, I think it to be originally yaA hayaA XrAhyA [which is inconsistent with the Hebrew]: and Ibn-Buzurj says, they said yaA hiyaA and yaA hayaA in speaking to one from a near place. (TA.)

XarowN c
XarowN Honey: (K:) or white honey: mentioned by Sgh: formed by transposition from XaworN: (TA:) and also written XirowN↓. (K.)

XirowN c
XirowN: see what precedes.

XarowaI c
XarowaI, originally XaroyaA: see art. XrI.

XirawiIRN c
XirawiIRN, originally XirayiIRN: see art. XrI.

XirowaAlN c
XirowaAlN is [said to be] a dial. var. of sirowaAlN: (K:) IAmb says that Es-Sijistánee mentions his having heard some of the Arabs of the desert say XirowaAl for sirowaAl; but that it seems he heard them use the Pers. word, [which, it appears, is XarowaAl as well as XalowaAr,] and knew it not: (O, TA: *) XrwAl is a vulgar word, [now commonly pronounced XarowaAl,] and some of the vulgar say XalowaAr, with fet-h to the X. (TA.)

1 XaraAhu c
1. XaraAhu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
XariIa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. XirFI (S, Mgh, Msb, TA) and XiraMCN, (S, * Mgh, Msb, * TA,) the former inf. n. the more in repute, (Msb, TA,) and this is of the dial. of Nejd, the latter being of the dial. of El-Hijáz, or the latter may be said to be with medd for the purpose of assimilating it to a preceding word, accord. to El-Munádee, or it may be regarded as an inf. n. of XaAraAhu, (TA,) i. q. baAEahu [in the sense in which this is generally used, i. e. He sold it]; (S, Mgh, K;) he gave it for a price: (Msb:) and i. q. AiXotaraAhu↓ [in the sense in which this is generally used, i. e. he bought it]; (S, Mgh;) i. e. XaraAhu signifies also he took it, or acquired it, for a price: (Msb:) or this and AXtrAh↓ both signify baAEahu [as meaning he sold it]; (T, * K, TA;) but the former is more used than the latter in this sense: (T, TA:) and both signify also [he bought it; i. e.] he possessed it by sale; (K;) which is the more usual meaning of the latter: (T, TA:) thus the former has two contr. meanings, (S, Msb, K,) and the latter also: (K:) for the two persons selling and buying sell and buy the price and the thing upon which the price is put; so that each of the things given in exchange is sold in one point of view and bought in another. (Msb, TA.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 203], wamina QlnRaAsi mano yaXoriI nafosahu QbotigaMCa maroDaApi QllRehi i. e. [And of men is he] who sells [himself in the endeavour to obtain the approval of God]. (S, * TA.) And in the same, [xii. 20], waXarawohu bivamanK baxosK i. e. And they sold him [for a deficient, or an insufficient, price]. (S, TA.) And in the same [ii. 15], OuwlaAYika QlRaciyna QlDRalaAlapa biQlohudaI QXotarawuA↓, originally QXotarayuwA, (S,) [lit. Those are they who have purchased error with right direction,] meaning, (tropical:) who have taken AlDlAlp in exchange for AlhdI: (Ksh, Bd, Jel:) or (tropical:) who have preferred AlDlAlp to AlhdI: (Ksh, Bd:) [for] of any one who relinquishes a thing and lays hold upon another thing, one says AXtrAh; (K, TA;) which is thus tropically used [as meaning (tropical:) he took it in exchange bigayorihi by giving up another thing]; (TA;) and hence this saying in the Kur-án. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] XaraI binafosihi Eani Alqawomi (tropical:) He advanced before the people, or party, (K, TA,) to their enemy, (TA,) and fought in defence of them: or (tropical:) he advanced to the Sultán, and spoke for the people: (K, TA:) [as though he sold himself for them; the b in bnfsh being app. redundant:] or, as in the Tekmileh, XaraI binafosihi UilaI Alqawomi (tropical:) he advanced to the people, or party, and fought them. (TA.) ― -b3- And XaraI fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. XirFI, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He mocked at, scoffed at, laughed at, derided, or ridiculed, such a one: (K:) [and] so XarRaAhu↓. (TA voce jadRaEahu [q. v.: thus there written, perhaps for the purpose of assimilating it to jadRaEahu].) ― -b4- And i. q. Oarogamahu (assumed tropical:) [He angered such a one; or did evil to him, and angered him]: (Lh, K, TA:) and so Oaworamahu, and gaTaAhu [or perhaps EaZaAhu, for both are expl. alike]: all said of God. (Lh, TA.) And faEala bihi maA XaraAhu (assumed tropical:) He did to him that which occasioned evil to him; or that which displeased, grieved, or vexed, him; syn. saMCahu. (TA.) And laHaAhu QllRehu waXaraAhu (assumed tropical:) [May God remove him far from good or prosperity, or curse him, and do evil to him, or displease or grieve or vex him]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XaraI QllRehu fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. XirFI, (TA,) also signifies God smote him, or may God smite him, with the eruption termed XarFI [q. v.]. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- And XaraAhu, (K,) aor.
XariIa
, inf. n. XirFI, (TA,) i. q. XarRarahu, (K, TA,) i. e. He spread it [to dry]; (TA;) [in copies of the K, in art. Xr, written, in this sense, XarRaAhu↓;] namely, flesh-meat, and a garment, or piece of cloth, and [the preparation of curd called] OaqiT. (K.) ＝ -A4- XariIa, aor.
XaraIa
, inf. n. XarFI, (S, K,) said of lightning, (S, K, &c.,) It shone, or gleamed, much: (S:) or it shone, or gleamed, (K, TA,) and spread in the face of the clouds, or, as in the T, became dispersed in the face of the clouds: (TA:) and AXrI↓ signifies the same; (K;) or it shone, or gleamed, consecutively: the latter verb mentioned by Sgh. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (S,) said of the nose-rein of a camel, (S, TA,) It was, or became, in a state of commotion, (TA,) or, of much commotion. (S, TA.) [See also 12.]) ― -b3- Also, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a man) was, or became, angry: (K, TA:) or he was, or became, flurried by reason of anger. (S, TA.) ― -b4- And, said of evil, or mischief, It spread, bayonahumo among them: (K, TA:) or became great, or formidable; and in like manner said of an affair, or event. (Nh, TA. [See also 10.]) ― -b5- Also, and AstXrI↓, He (a man, S) persisted, or persevered, (S, K,) in an affair, (S,) or in his error, and his corrupt conduct: and the former, said of a man, is like gariIa in measure and meaning [i. e. he persisted, or persevered, in his anger]. (TA.) One says of a horse, XariIa fiI sayorihi, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He per-
sisted, or persevered, in his pace, or going; as also AstXrI↓: (S:) or he exceeded the usual bounds therein, (K, TA,) and went on without languor: (TA:) and fiI Eadowihi AstXrI↓ he (i. e. a horse) persisted, or persevered, in his running: (Mgh:) and XariIa fiI lijaAmihi he (a horse) strained his bridle. (A, TA.) And Xariyato Eayonuhu biAldRamoEi His eye persisted, or persevered, in the shedding of tears, the tears pouring forth consecutively. (TA.) ＝ -A5- And XariIa, (S, K, TA,) aor.
XaraIa
, inf. n. XarFI, (K, * TA,) He, (TA,) or his skin, broke out with the eruption termed XarFI [q. v.]. (S, K, TA.)

2 XarRaIa
2: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

3 XaAraAhu c
3. XaAraAhu, inf. n. muXaAraApN and XiraMCN, i. q. baAyaEahu [as signifying He sold and bought with him: and he bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him: that XArAh has both of these meanings (like bAyEh) is shown by the fact that muXaAraApN is also expl. in the TA, on the authority of Er-Rághib, as signifying the same as qibaADN]. (K.) ― -b2- Also, (Mgh,) inf. n. muXaAraApN, (TA,) He persisted in contention, litigation, or wrangling: (Mgh:) one says, huwa yuXaAriyhi (T, M, K) He persists in contention, litigation, or wrangling, with him: (M, TA:) or he contends in altercation, disputes, or litigates, with him; or does so vehemently, or obstinately; syn. yujaAdiluhu: (K, TA:) and it is said of the Prophet, in a trad., kaAna laA yuXaAriI walaA yumaAriI [He used not to persist in contention, &c.]: (Mgh, TA:) meaning accord. to Th, biAlXRarRi kaAna laA yasotaXoriI↓ [he used not to persist, or persevere, with evil conduct]: (TA:) from AisotaXoraI fiI Eadowihi [expl. above (see 1 near the end)] as said of a horse: (Mgh:) or, accord. to Az, (TA,) originally yuXaAriru; one of the rs being changed into I. (K, * TA. [See 3 in art. Xr: and see also 3 in art. jrI.])

4 AXrI c
4. AXrI, said of lightning: see 1, latter half. ― -b2- Said of a camel, He sped, or went quickly. (IKtt, TA.) ― -b3- AXrI bayonahumo He excited discord, strife, or animosity, between them, or among them. (Az, K.) ― -b4- AXrI AlHamalu (K accord. to the CK, [which, I think, evidently gives the right reading,] in the TA and in my MS. copy of the K Aljml,) i. q. tafalRaqato Eaqiyqatuhu [i. e. The lamb had its wool cleaving open, or becoming cleft]: (K: [Freytag, following the TK, and reading AlHimolu, explains the verb as said of fruit, and meaning “ diffissos habuit nucleos; ” but I cannot find any authority for the signification that he thus assigns to Eaqyqp:]) mentioned by Sgh. (TA.) ― -b5- AXrt AlXRajarapu The plant [crept upon the ground, or] was like the cucumber and the melon; as also AstXrt↓. (TA.) ― -b6- See also 5. ＝ -A2- AXrAhu He filled it; (S, K;) namely, a watering-trough: and in like manner AXrI jafonapF he filled a bowl, (S,) or jifaAnahu his bowls for the guests. (TA.) ― -b2- And He made it to incline, (K, TA,) fiI naAHiyapi kacaA [in the direction of such a thing]. (TA.) Hence the saying of a poet,
waOanRaniI HayovumaA yuXoriI AlhawaI baSariI
mino HawovamaA salakuwA Oadonuw faOanoZuwru
[And that I, wherever love makes my eye, or eyes, to incline, wherever they travel, approach and look: fAnZwr being for faOanoZuru]: or, as some relate it, OavoniI faOanoZuwru [i. e. turn myself, or my eyes, and look]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also He put it in motion; namely, a bridle. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

5 tXrRI c
5. tXrRI It became scattered, or dispersed: (K:) accord. to the M, said in this sense of a company of men. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, said of a man, (S,) or of a party, or company of men, (TA,) He, or they, became like the XuraAp [pl. of XaArK q. v.] in his, or their, actions; (S, * TA;) and so AXrI↓. (IAth, TA.)

6 taXaArayaA c
6. taXaArayaA They sued each other; or cited each other before a judge; syn. taqaADayaA. (A, TA.)

8 UiXotaraIa
8: see the first paragraph, in three places.

10 AstXrI c
10. AstXrI: see 1, latter part, in three places: and see 3. ― -b2- Also He persisted, or persevered, in consideration, or examination. (TA.) ― -b3- And AstXrI fiI diynihi He strove, or exerted himself, or was diligent, or studious, and was careful, or mindful, or regardful, in his religion. (TA.) ― -b4- And AstXrt AlOumuwru bayonahumo The affairs, or events, were, or became, great, or formidable, between them, or among them. (K, * TA. [See also XariIa.]) ― -b5- And see 4.

12 AiXoraworaI c
12. AiXoraworaI It was, or became, in a state of commotion. (K. [See also XariIa.])

XaroIN c
XaroIN The colocynth: (S, K:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (S,) the plant thereof: (S, K:) n. un. with p: (S:) and XaroyaAnN↓ also signifies the colocynth; as a dial. var. of XaroIN: or the leaves thereof. (TA.) One says, huwa OaHolaI mina AlOaroIi waOamarRu mina AlXRaroIi [He, or it, is sweeter than honey and more bitter than colocynth]. (TA.) And fulaAnN lahu TaEomaAni OaroIN waXaroIN [Such a one has two flavours, that of honey and that of colocynth]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And Any kind of plant that spreads upon the ground, running [or creeping] and extending; such as the melon and the cucumber. (AHn, O voce suTRaAHN, q. v., and TA * in the present art.) ― -b3- And Palm-trees that grow from the datestones: (K:) and with p [as the n. un.] one of such palm-trees. (S.) ― -b4- And, accord. to IJ, A kind of tree of which bows are made. (L voce HatRN, q. v. [See also XiroyaAnN.]) ＝ -A2- See also XarFI. ＝ -A3- And see XarowaI.

XarFI c
XarFI A road, (K, TA,) in a general sense. (TA.) And, (K,) with the article Al, [particularly] A road of Selmà, (S, K, TA,) the mountain so called, (TA,) abounding with lions: (S, K, TA:) whence they say of courageous men, maA humo UilRaA Ousuwdu AlXRaraI [They are no other than the lions of Esh-Sharà]. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. naAHiyapN [as meaning An adjacent tract or region]; (S, K;) as also XaraMCN↓: (K:) accord. to some, of the right hand: (TA:) pl. OaXoraMCN. (S, K.) Hence, XaraI AlfuraAti The adjacent tract (naAHiyap) of the Euphrates: (TA:) and OaXoraMCu AlHarami the adjacent tracts of the Sacred Territory; syn. nawaAHiyhi. (S.) ― -b3- And A mountain. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also The bad, or worse, or worst, of cattle: accord. to J, [in the S,] XaroIN↓, [said in the S to be like XawaI AlmaAli,] which is [said to be] a mistake: (K:) but ElBedr El-Karáfee questions it being so: (TA:) and the good, or better, or best, thereof; as also XaraApN↓: thus having two contr. significations: (K:) and so says ISk: but ISd says that UibilN XaraApN↓, like saraApN, means choice camels. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And A certain eruption upon the body, resembling dirhems: (TA:) or small pimples or purulent pustules, having a burning property: (S:) or small pimples or purulent pustules, red, itching, and distressing, generally originating at once, (K, TA,) but sometimes gradually, (TA,) and becoming [more] severe by night in consequence of a hot vapour breaking forth at once upon the body: (K, TA:) thus in the “ Kánoon ” of Ibn-Seenà [or Avicenna]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- cuw AlXRaraI A certain idol of [the tribe of] Dows (dawos), (K, TA,) in the Saráh (AlsRaraAp): so says Nasr. (TA.)

XarK c
XarK Having the eruption termed XarFI, described in the next preceding paragraph. (S, K.)

XirFI c
XirFI, (S, TA,) an inf. n. of XaraI, aor. yaXoriI, (TA,) [when used as a simple subst., signifying A sale and also a purchase,] has OaXoriyapN for its pl., which, as pl. of a sing. of the measure fiEalN, is anomalous. (S, TA.)

XaraApN c
XaraApN: see XarFI, in two places.

XaraMCN c
XaraMCN: see XarFI.

XariIRN c
XariIRN Sold: and also bought: applied in this sense to a male slave; and XariyRapN to a female slave. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A horse that persists, or perseveres, in his pace, or going: (S:) or that exceeds the usual bounds therein, (K, TA,) and goes on without languor: (TA:) or a choice horse: (A, TA:) or an excellent, choice horse. (TA.)

XariyRapN c
XariyRapN A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like: and a nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, of women, Such as bring forth females. (K.) One says, tazawRaja fiI XariyRapi nisaMCK He married among women such as bring forth females. (TA.)

XarowaI c
XarowaI, in which the w is a substitute for I, as it is in taqowaI and the like, (TA,) The like (S, K) of a thing: (S:) because a thing is sometimes bought with the like thereof: (TA:) [used alike as sing. and pl.: and, accord. to the TA, it seems that XaroIN↓ signifies the same.] It is said of Shureyh, kaAna yuDamRinu AlqaSRaAra XarowaI AlvRawobi AlRaciI Oaholakahu [He used to make the washer responsible for the like of the garment, or piece of cloth, that he destroyed]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Omar, relating to the [collecting of the] poorrate, falaA yaOoxucu UilRaA tiloka AlsRinRa mino XarowaI Uibilihi [i. e. And he shall not take any save of that age, of the likes of his camels]. (TA.)

XirawiIRN c
XirawiIRN, in which the w is a substitute for I, and XiraAYiIRN↓, [both signifying Of, or relating to, selling, and also of, or relating to, buying,] are rel. ns.; the former, of the inf. n. XirFI; and the latter, of the inf. n. XiraMCN. (Msb, TA.)

XaroyaAnN c
XaroyaAnN see XaroIN: ― -b2- and see what next follows.

XiroyaAnN c
XiroyaAnN and XaroyaAnN↓, (S, K,) the former of which is the more in repute, (TA,) the former said to be quasi-quadriliteral, like jiroyaAlN, [and therefore mentioned also in the TA in art. Xrn,] but held by IB to be of the measure fiEolaAnN, (TA in art. Xrn,) A kind of tree, (S, K, TA,) of the EiDaAh [q. v.] of the mountains, (TA,) of which bows are made: (S, K, TA:) n. un. with p: the tree thus called grows in the manner, and of the height and width, of the [species of lote-tree called] sidor, and has a yellow, sweet nabiqap [or drupe]: so says AHn: and he adds, Aboo-Ziyád says, bows are made of the XryAn, and the bow made thereof is good, but black tinged with redness; its wood being of those woods of which good bows are [commonly] made; and they assert that it seldom, or never, becomes crooked: Mbr says that the naboE and XawoHaT [q. v.] and XryAn are one kind of tree, but differing in name and estimation according to the places of growth; such thereof as is upon the summit of the mountain being the nbE; and such as is at the base, or foot, or lowest or lower part, thereof, the XryAn. (TA. [But see XawoHaTN.]) ― -b2- Also sing. of XaraAyiynu signifying The arteries; i. e. the pulsing veins; (S, K;) which spring from the heart: (S:) but the anatomists assert that they spring from the liver, and pass by the heart. (TA.) ― -b3- XiroyaAnN, with kesr, signifies also A crack, or fissure, [in a rock,] such as is termed vatRN. (Az, TA.)

XiraAYiIRN c
XiraAYiIRN: see XirawiIRN.

XaArK c
XaArK Selling, or a seller: (Mgh, TA:) and buying, or a buyer: as also muXotarK↓ [in both senses, but generally in the latter sense; whereas XaArK is generally used in the former sense]: (TA:) pl. of the former XuraApN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, (S, TA,) and XaAriIRN↓, in which latter the I is not the I of a rel. n. but is an affix corroborative of the epithet, as in the cases of OaHowaru and OaHowariIRN [or OaHomaru and OaHomariIRN] and SulRabN and SulRabiIRN, (TA,) One of the people to whom is applied the appellation AlXRuraApu, (S, TA,) which means the [heretics, or schismatics, commonly known by the name of] xawaArij [pl. of xaArijiIRN, q. v.]: (S, M, Mgh, K, &c.:) so called because they said, We have sold ourselves in obedience to God, i. e., for Paradise, when we separated ourselves from the erring Imáms: (S:) or because they sold themselves for the sake of what they believed: or because they said, Verily God has purchased us and our possessions: (Mgh:) but ISk says, because of their vehement hatred of the Muslims: and the author of the K says that it is from XariIa signifying “ he was angry, ” and “ he persisted, or persevered; ” and he charges J with error in his explaining it as above, from their saying “ we have sold ourselves ” &c.; but this charge is senseless, for J has followed herein more than one of the leading authorities: the author of the K has followed ISd, who, however, adds, as to themselves, they say “ We are the XuraAp ” because of the saying in the Kur ii. 203 [cited in the first paragraph of this art.], and the saying [in ix. 112] “ Verily God hath purchased, of the believers, themselves ” [&c.]; and the like is said in the Nh, with this addition, that XuraApN is the pl. of XaArK; i. e., it is from XaraI, aor. yaXoriI; or it may be from AlmuXaAraApu meaning AlmulaAjRapu: moreover, the part. n. of XariIa is XarK; and this has not XuraApN for its pl. (TA.)

XaAriIRN c
XaAriIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muXotarK c
muXotarK: see XaArK. ＝ -A2- AlmuXotariI A certain star, (S, K,) well-known; (K;) [Jupiter;] one of the Seven Stars. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And A certain bird. (K.)

1 Xazaba c
1. Xazaba, (S, A, O, K,) and Xazuba, (O, K,) aor. of each
Xazuba
, (K,) inf. n. XuzuwbN (S, A, O, K) and XazobN, (K,) He was, or became, such as is termed XaAzibN meaning as expl. below: (S, A, O, K:) [mostly] said of a horse. (S, A, O, TA.)

2 XzRbhu c
2. XzRbhu, (O, K,) inf. n. taXoziybN, (K,) He, or it, caused it (a rod, O) to wither: (O, K, TA:) and he, or it, made him to become lean, or light of flesh; slender, and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly. (TA.)

XazobapN c
XazobapN: see what follows.

XaAzibN c
XaAzibN Lean, or light of flesh; slender, and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly; applied to a horse: (S, O:) [or] XazobapN↓ signifies thus, applied to a she-ass, (K, TA,) and a she-camel: (so accord. to the CK:) and XaAzibN, lean, &c., as above; and tough; (A, K;) applied to a horse, (A, TA,) and to a man, &c.: (TA:) or lean, or light of flesh, though not emaciated: (As, TA:) and, applied to a man, very slender or slim or spare: (A:) pl. XuzRabN, (S, A, O, K,) applied to horses, (S, A, O,) and [as also of XaAzibapN] XawaAzibu. (K.) And XaAzibapN A she-gazelle lean, or light of flesh; or slender, and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly; in consequence of her having come from after: pl. XawaAzibu. (TA.) ― -b2- And Rough; (S, K, TA;) applied to a place. (S, TA.)

1 Xazarahu c
1. Xazarahu, and Xazara Uilayohi, aor.
Xazira
, (K,) inf. n. XazorN, (TA,) He looked askew, or sideways, at him, (IAmb, K,) not turning his face towards him, (TA,) [or with a slight turning of the face, (see laHaZahu,)] by reason of hatred or of awe: (IAmb:) or he looked at him with a look of aversion: or he looked at him from the right and left: (K:) or from the outer angle of the eye: generally, in anger: or with hatred and anger: (TA:) or, (K,) as also naZara Uilayohi XazorFA, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) he looked at him from the outer angle of the eye, (S, A, Msb, K,) with anger, (S, K,) or with aversion, like as one looks who hates another, (A, Mgh,) or like one who is averse and angry: (Msb:) or Xazarahu signifies he looked at him with the look of an enemy. (TA.) The saying of 'Alee, AiloHaZuwA AlXRazora waQToEunuwA Alyasora, is expl. as signifying Look ye from the right and left [and thrust ye straight forward]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Xazarahu, (Fr, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Fr,) He smote him with the [evil] eye. (Fr, K.) ― -b3- Also Xazarahu He thrust him, or pierced him, (K,) with a spear-head. (TA.) And TaEanahu XazorFA He thrust him, or pierced him, sideways. (A.) ― -b4- Xazara Aljabola, aor.
Xazira
and
Xazura
, (K,) inf. n. XazorN, (TA,) He twisted the rope, or cord, from the left [by rolling it against his body from left to right]: (ISd, K:) or he twisted it upwards [by rolling it upwards against his thigh or body]: (As, AM:) or he twisted it from without [by rolling it against his thigh], and turned it towards his belly [contrarily to the usual manner, which is termed yasorN, and which is the twisting downwards, by rolling the rope or cord downwards either against the body or against the thigh]; (ISd, K;) as also AstXzrhu↓. (K.) [See also XazorN, below.]

3 XAzrhu c
3. XAzrhu, inf. n. muXaAzarapN, He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility: whence [the manner of looking termed] AlXRazoru. (AA.)

4 AXzrhu QllRehu c
4. AXzrhu QllRehu God cast him into an evil case from which he could not extricate himself. (TA.)

5 tXzRr c
5. tXzRr He was angry. (K.) [See also tXcRr.] ― -b2- He prepared himself, liloqitaAli for fight, (K,) and lilsRujuwdi [for prostration in prayer]. (Mgh.)

6 tXAzrwA c
6. tXAzrwA They looked, one at another, in the manner termed XazorN, (S, K,) from the outer angle of the eye. (TA.) [See 1.]

10 AstXzr c
10. AstXzr: see 1, last sentence but one. ＝ -A2- Also It (a rope or cord) was twisted in the manner described above, in the explanation of Xazara AlHabola. (K.)

TaEonN XazorN c
TaEonN XazorN A thrusting, or piercing, from the right and from the left: (S, M, TA:) or with the right hand and the left. (TA.) ― -b2- fatolN XazorN A twisting upwards, contrarily to the manner in which the spindle [usually] turns. (S.) [See 1.] ― -b3- gazolN XazorN Spun thread [app. twisted in a manner the reverse of that which is usual: (see 1; and see also radonN:) or] that is uneven. (K.) ― -b4- TaHana biAlrRaHaI XazorFA, [in which XazorFA appears to be an inf. n., though its verb is not mentioned,] He ground with the hand-mill turning it from his right: [i. e., making it to revolve in the same course as do the hands of a watch:] (S, A, K: *) the contrary [which is the common way] is termed batRFA (A, TA.) ― -b5- And maA zaAla XazorFA He ceased not to be taking the wrong way. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- XazorN also signifies Difficulty (K) in an affair. (TA.)

fiI laHoZihi XazarN c
fiI laHoZihi XazarN [In his glance is a sidelong and
angry look, from the outer angle of the eye: see 1]. (S, K. *) ― -b2- XazarN signifies [also] Disquietude. (Mgh.)

entry.key: OataAhu AldRahoru biXazorapK laA yanoHalRu minohaA

superEntry.entry:
OataAhu AldRahoru biXazorapK laA yanoHalRu minohaA c
OataAhu AldRahoru biXazorapK laA yanoHalRu minohaA [Time, or fortune, brought him a calamity from which he was not to be extricated;] meaning, destroyed him. (TA.)

XuzorapN c
XuzorapN (tropical:) Redness in the eye, and, or with, (so in the K accord. to the TA, but in the CK “ or, ”) what is termed XazarN in the glance thereof. (K.)

labanN OaXozaru c
labanN OaXozaru (tropical:) Red milk. (TS, K.) ― -b2- EayonN XazoraMCu (tropical:) An eye that is red, and (so in the K accord. to the TA, but in the CK “ or, ”) with what is termed XazarN in the glance thereof. (K.)

HabolN maXozuwrN c
HabolN maXozuwrN A rope, or cord, twisted from the left; (Lth, A, Msb, TA;) which is the stronger way: (Lth, A:) or upwards: (As, T, S:) [see 1:] and gadaAYiru musotaXoziraAtN↓, (S, TA,) and musotaXozaraAtN↓, (TA,) [Pendent locks of hair] so twisted. (S, TA.)

musotaXozarN c
musotaXozarN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 XasaEa AlnRaEola c
1. XasaEa AlnRaEola, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
XasaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XasoEN, (O, K,) He put a XisoE [q. v.] to the sandal; (S, * Msb, * K;) as also XasRaEahaA↓, and OaXosaEahaA↓. (S, O, K.) ＝ -A2- XasiEati AlnRaEolu, aor.
XasaEa
, The sandal had its XisoE broken. (Ibn-Buzurj, O, K.) ― -b2- XasiEa Alfarasu, aor. as above, inf. n. XasaEN, The horse had a gap, or space, between his central incisor and the tooth next to it. (Aboo-Málik, IDrd, O, K. *) ＝ -A3- XasaEa, aor. as above, inf. n. XasoEN and XusuwEN, It was, or became, distant, or remote; said of a place of alighting, or abode. (K.) And, said of anything, i. q. tanaMCaI [It was or became, far from another thing]: and XaxaSa [it rose, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- XasaEa He put, or sent, or removed, him, or it, away, or far away; as also AXsEhu↓. (TA.)

2 XasRaEa
2: see the preceding paragraph.

4 OaXosaEa
4: see 1, first and last sentences.

XisoEN c
XisoEN (S, O, Msb, K, &c.) and XisiEN (K) and XisoEanRN↓, so in some of the copies of the K, (TA,) [thus in my MS. copy of the K, and also in the O,] with an augmentative n, (O, TA,) The qibaAl of the sandal; (K;) [i. e.] the appertenance of the sandal that is attacked, or tied, to its zimaAm; (S;) [meaning] one of the thongs, or straps, or strips of leather, of the sandal, being that which passes between two toes, of which the [lower] end enters the hole, or perforation, that is in the fore part of the sandal, and which is attacked [at its upper end] to the zimaAm [or, as it is also called, the XiraAk, a thong, or strap, or strip of leather, extending towards the ankle, and having two arms, (its EaDudaAni,) which are attacked to the OucunaAni (q. v.), or pass through these and unite behind the foot]: (IAth, TA:) a poet says, referring to camels,
OaHoduw bihaA munoqaTiEFA XisoEanRiI↓
[I urge them on by singing to them, with the interdigital thong of my sandal broken]: (Lth, O, TA:) the pl. of XisoEN is XusuwEN (S, O, Msb, K, TA) and OaXosaAEN: (O, K, TA:) ISd and Z affirm that it has only the former pl.; but AHei contradicts this: (TA:) the latter pl. [a pl. of pauc.] occurs in the saying of 'Obeyd Ibn-Eiyoob El- 'Amberee,
yudiyru naEolayohi liYalRaA tuEorafaA
yajoEalu OaXosaAEahumaA naHowa AlqafaA
[He turns round his sandals, in order that they may not be known by their prints upon the ground; putting the interdigital thongs thereof in the direction of the back of the neck]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qibaAlu AlXRisoEi signifies (assumed tropical:) The serpent; mentioned by IAar with qibaAlu AlXRibori. (TA.) ― -b3- And XisoEN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The extremity of a place. (O, K.) One says, HalalonaA XisoEa AldRahonaMCi (assumed tropical:) [We alighted in the extremity of the sandy desert, or of the desert called Ed-Dahnà]. (O.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A narrow tract of land. (O, K.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Somewhat remaining of property or cattle. (IAar, O, K, TA.) And (K) (tropical:) A small quantity or number of property or cattle. (Mohárib, O, K, TA.) One says, lahu XisoEu maAlK (tropical:) He has a small quantity of property, or a small number of cattle; (Mohárib, O, K, TA;) or a small collection of camels and of sheep or goats: (K, TA:) and Fr adds maAlK XasiyEu↓ [app. in the same sense: but see another explanation of XisoEu maAlK in what follows]. (O.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) The greater portion or number of property or cattle. (El-Mufaddal, O, K, TA.) Thus it has two contr. [?] significations. (K.) One says, cahaba XisoEu maAlihi (tropical:) The greater portion of his property, or the greater number of his cattle, went, or passed, away. (El-Mufaddal, O, TA.) ― -b7- And fulaAnN XisoEu maAlK (tropical:) Such a one is a good manager of cattle or camels &c.; (S, O, K, TA;) one who keeps assiduously to the tending, or pasturing, thereof: (A, TA:) and Fr says, huwa maAlK XasiyEu↓, as syn. with XisoEu maAlK. (TA: [but see above.])

XisoEanRN c
XisoEanRN: see XisoEN, in two places.

XasuwEN c
XasuwEN: see XaAsiEN.

XasiyEu maAlK c
XasiyEu maAlK: see XisoEN, in two places.

XaAsiEN c
XaAsiEN A man having his XisoE broken. (O, K.) ― -b2- Also Distant, or remote; and so XasuwEN↓: (S, O, K:) both applied to a place of alighting, or abode: (O, K:) pl. [of either, irreg.,] XusoEN. (K.) One says bilaAdN XaAsiEapN [Distant countries or towns]. (Msb.) And rajulN XaAsiEu AldRaAri A man whose house, or abode, or country, is distant. (TA.) And XafarN XaAsiEN A far journey. (TA.)

XawoXabN c
XawoXabN, mentioned in the K under this head and in art. Xb: see the latter art.

1 XaSara c
1. XaSara, (A 'Obeyd, O,) aor.
XaSura
, (O,) inf. n. XaSorN, (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K,) He sewed (a garment, or piece of cloth, A 'Obeyd) with wide stitches, or with stitches far apart, (S, O, K,) as in the manner termed baXokN. (A 'Obeyd.) ― -b2- XaSara Eayona AlbaAziI, (S, O,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) He sewed up the eye of the hawk. (S, O.) ― -b3- XaSara AlnRaAqapa, (M, O, K,) aor.
XaSura
and
XaSira
, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, M, O, K,) He transfixed the sides of the she-camel's vulva with small sharp-pointed pieces of wood, or prickles, (M, O, * K, *) and twisted round behind them sinews, (M,) or a string made of hairs from her tail, (M, O, * K, *) on account of the protruding of her womb on the occasion of her bringing forth; (M, O, K;) syn. of the inf. n. tazoniydN. (S.) See also XiSaArN, below. ― -b4- And XaSara AlnRaAqapa, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) signifies also He inserted the piece of wood called XiSaAr between the nostrils of the she-camel; and so XSRrhA↓, (K,) inf. n. taXoSiyrN. (TA.) ― -b5- XaSaratohu XawokapN, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) A thorn pricked, or pierced, him. (O, K.) ― -b6- XaSarahu biAlrRumoHi, (O,) inf. n. as above, He pierced him (O, K *) with the spear. (O.) ― -b7- XaSorN also signifies A bull's, (O, K,) and a gazelle's, (TA,) smiting (O, K, TA) a man (O, TA) with his horn. XuTobapN (S, K) and XiTobapN↓ (K) and XaTobapN↓ (TA) and XuTabapN↓, (K,) which last is said by some to be a n. un. of XuTabN [mentioned in what follows as a pl.], (MF,) A [raised] line (Tariyqap, S, O, or Tariyq, K, [meaning a ridge, and sometimes also a depressed line, as shown voce muXaTRabN, i. e. a channel,]) in the maton [i. e. broad side, or middle of the broad side, of the blade] (S, O) of a sword: (S, O, K:) pl. XuTabN and XuTubN, (S, O,) or XuTuwbN and XuTabN and XuTubN: (K: [in which it is said that the pl. is XuTuwbN and XuTabN like gurafN and kutubN: but I think that XuTuwbN is a mistranscription, and that the right reading is XuTabN and XuTubN like gurafN and kutubN:]) hence it would seem that XuTabN and XuTubN are pls. of one sing.; but Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee expressly states that the former is pl. of XuTobapN; and the latter, of XaTiybapN↓; (MF;) of which XaTaAYibu also is a pl.; (L in art. Emd;) and which signifies [the same as XuTobapN, i. e.] the rising Eamuwd [i. e. the ridge] in the maton of a sword. (ISh, TA.) [See also muXaTRabN: and see EamuwdN and mayonN.]

XaTobapN c
XaTobapN: see XaTobN (near the end) in two places: ― -b2- and see also XuTabapN: ― -b3- and XaTiybapN, in three places.

XuTabapN c
XuTabapN: see XuTobapN.

XiTaAbN c
XiTaAbN The instrument with which a barocaEap [or cloth put beneath a camel's saddle] is quilted. (K.)

XaTiybapN c
XaTiybapN A slice, or strip, of flesh-meat: (TA:) or a piece cut lengthwise of a camel's hump; (S, O, K, TA;) as also XiTobapN↓: (O, K:) or a piece cut in the form of a strip, but not separated, of a camel's hump; and so ↓the latter word: pl. of the former XaTaAYibu. (AZ, TA.) ― -b2- And A piece cut lengthwise of a hide or of leather; (S, O;) as also XiTobapN↓. (O.) ― -b3- And A piece of [the tree called] naboE of which a bow is made. (S, O.) ― -b4- See also XaTobN. ― -b5- And see XuTobapN. ― -b6- Also, applied to a she-camel, Tough; syn. yaAbisapN. (K.) ― -b7- And [the pl.] XaTaAYibu Different, or various, parties, sects, or classes, (K, TA,) and sorts, of men &c. (TA.) ― -b8- And Difficulties, or distresses; (Abu-l-Faraj, O, K;) as also XaSaAYibu. (Abu-l-Faraj, O, TA.)

XaTiybiyRapN c
XaTiybiyRapN, (as in the TA,) or muXaTRabapN↓, (as implied in the K,) A quilted barocaEap [or cloth that is put beneath a camel's saddle]. (K, TA.)

XaTRaAbN c
XaTRaAbN A butcher. (Fr, TA in art. sTr.)

XaATibN c
XaATibN [act. part. n. of the trans. verb XaTaba]. ― -b2- [Hence,] XawaATibu [the pl. of XaATibapN] signifies Women who cut skin, or leather, into strips, after having shaven it or measured it: so accord. to different copies of the K; i. e. baEoda maA yaHoliqonahu or yaxoluqonahu. (TA.) ― -b3- And Women who split palmleaves, and peel the [palm-branches stripped of their leaves, or the portions thereof termed] Easiyb, to make of them mats, and then throw them to the munaqRiyaAt: (TA:) or the sing., XaATibapN, signifies a woman who peels the Easiyb, (As, TA,) or who splits the palm-sticks, to make of them mats, (S,) and then throws them to the munaqRiyap, (As, S, TA,) who removes all that is upon them with her knife until she has made them slender, when she throws them back to the XaATbp: (As, TA:) or a woman who makes mats of XaTob, i. e. [green, fresh] palm-branches [stripped of their leaves]: (ISk, TA:) the pl. occurs in a verse cited voce tacarRaEa. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, [from the intrans. verb XaTaba,] TariyqN XaATibN A road inclining, declining, or turning aside or away. (S, K.) ― -b2- And ramoyapN XaATibapN A shot, or throw, that deflects, or deviates, from a vital part; as also XaATifapN. (TA.) ― -b3- And rajulN XaATibu AlmaHalRi i. q. XaATinN [i. e. A man remote, or distant, in respect of the place of alighting or abode]. (TA.)

muXaTRabN c
muXaTRabN A sword (S, A, K) having XuTab [pl. of XuTobapN], (A, K,) i. e. (A, TA) having TaraAYiq [here meaning ridges, as expl. above, voce XuTobapN], (S, A, TA,) in its maton; [or ridges and channels,] these being in some cases elevated and depressed [lines]; (TA;) as also maXoTuwbN↓: (K, TA:) said by some, [but not so accord. to the A,] to be tropical, as being likened to pieces of a camel's hump cut in strips. (TA.) And in like manner, A garment, or piece of cloth, having TaraAYiq [as meaning lines, or streaks, or stripes]. (S, TA.) And OaroDN muXaTRabapN (tropical:) Land that is furrowed (A, Msb, K) a little, (K,) not much, (Msb,) by a torrent. (A, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Flowing [water &c.; because of the streaks, or lines, with which its surface is diversified]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also XaTiybiyRapN. ― -b4- And see XaTobN, last sentence.

maXoTuwbN c
maXoTuwbN: see the next preceding paragraph. ― -b2- farasN maXoTuwbu Almatoni waAlkafali means A horse swollen with fat in the two portions of flesh and sinew next the back bone, on each side, [and in the rump,] (O, K,) and whose creases of the skin are far apart. (O.) ― -b3- See also XaTobN, last sentence.

1. XaTarahu, (A, MA, O, TA,) [aor.
XaTura
,] inf. n. XaTorN; (MA;) and XTRrhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taXoTiyrN; (TA;) He halved it; divided it into halves. (A, MA, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- XaTarahaA, aor.
XaTura
, (S,) inf. n. XaTorN, (S, K,) He milked one XaTor of her, (namely, a camel, or a ewe or goat, S, [i. e., in the former case one pair of teats, and in the latter case one teat,]) and left the other XaTor. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- XaTarato and XaTurato, aor.
XaTura
, (K,) inf. n. XiTaArN, (TA,) She (a ewe or goat) had one of her teats dried up: or had one teat longer than the other. (K.) XaTura
, (S,) inf. n. XuTuwrN (S, K) and XaTorN, (TA,) He was as though he were looking at thee and at another: (S, A, K:) on the authority of Fr. (TA.) ― -b3- XaTara XaTorahu He repaired, or betook himself, in the direction of him, or it: or AlXRaToru in the sense of Aljihapu and AlnRaAHiyapu has no verb belonging to it. (K.) ― -b4- XaTarati AldRaAru The house, or abode, was distant, or remote. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b5- XaTara, (S, K,) aor.
XaTura
; (K;) and XaTura, aor.
XaTura
; inf. n. XaTaArapN, of both verbs, (S, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and XuTuwrN; (L;) [and tXATr↓; (A in art. Ecr;)] He was, or became, or acted, like a XaATir [q. v.]. (S, K.) And XaTara EalaI Oaholihi, (A, Msb,) or XaTara Eanohumo, (S, * K,) aor.
XaTura
, (Msb,) inf. n. XuTuwrN and XuTuwrapN and XaTaArapN, (K,) or this last is a simple subst., (Msb,) He withdrew far away (S, * A, K *) from his family; or broke off from them, or quitted them, in anger: (A, K:) or he disagreed with his family, and wearied them by his wickedness (Msb, TA) and baseness. (Msb.)

2 XaTRara
2: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- XTRr naAqatahu, (S,) or binaAqatihi, (K,) inf. n. taXoTiyrN, (S, K,) He bound two of the teats of his she-camel with the SiraAr [q. v.], (S, K,) leaving (the other) two (unbound). (K.)

3 XaATarotuhu maAliI c
3. XaATarotuhu maAliI I halved with him my property; (S, K;) I retained half of my property and gave him the other half. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And XaATarotu
TaliyRiI I left for my lamb, or kid, one teat [of the mother], having milked the other teat and bound it with the SiraAr [q. v.]. (S.)

6 taXaAoTara
6: see 1, last sentence but one.

XaTorN c
XaTorN The half of a thing; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also XaTiyrN↓: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXoTurN (S, K) and [of mult.] XuTuwrN. (K.) It is said in a prov., AuHolubo HalabFA laka XaToruhu [Milk thou a milking of which half shall be for thee]. (S.) And one says XaEarN XaToraAni Hair [half] black and [half] white. (A.) Accord. to Ibráheem El-Harbee, (O,) the saying of the Prophet, mano manaEa SadaqapF faUinRaA MxicuwhaA waXaTora maAlihi [Whoso refuses to render a poor-rate, verily we take it from him, and half of his property], thus related by Bahz, is a mistake, and the right wording is, waXuTira maAluhu, meaning and his property shall be divided into two halves, and the collector of the poor-rate shall have the option given him and shall take that rate from out of the better of the two halves, as a punishment for the man's refusal of the rate; (O, K;) but it is said that this law was afterwards abrogated: (O:) Esh-Sháfi'ee, however, says that, in the old time, when one refused the poor-rate of his property, it was taken from him, and half of his property was taken as a punishment for his refusal; and he adduces this trad. as evidence thereof; but says that in recent times, only the poor-rate was taken from him, and this trad. was asserted to be abrogated. (TA. [More is there said on this subject, but I omit it as unprofitable.]) ― -b2- It occurs in two trads. as meaning Half a makRuwk [q. v.], or half a wasoq [q. v.], of barley. (TA.) ― -b3- [In prosody, Half a verse.] ― -b4- Also (tropical:) A part, or portion, or somewhat, of a thing; (Mgh, K;) and so XaTiyrN↓. (TA.) In the trad. of the night-journey, fawaDaEa XaTorahaA means (assumed tropical:) [And He remitted] part, or somewhat, thereof; (K;) i. e., of the prayer. (TA.) And similar is the saying in another trad., AlTRahuwru XaToru AlUiymaAni (assumed tropical:) [Purification is part of faith]. (TA.) ― -b5- Either the fore pair or the hind pair of the teats of a she-camel: she has two pairs of teats, a fore pair and a hind pair, and each pair is thus called: (S, K:) and either of the two teats of a ewe or she-goat: (IAar, TA:) pl. OaXoTurN. (S, TA.) Hence the saying, (S,) fulaAnN Halaba AldRahora OaXoTurahu (tropical:) Such a one has known, or tried, varieties of fortune: (S, * TA:) has experienced the good and evil of fortune; (S, K, TA;) its straitness and its ampleness: being likened to one who has milked all the teats of a camel, that which yields plenty of milk and that which does not; the fore pair being the good; and the hind pair, the evil: or, as some say, OaXoTur means streams, or flows, of milk: and [in like manner] one says, Halaba AldRahora XaTorayohi. (TA.) And, as is said in the “ Kámil ” of Mbr, one says of a man experienced in affairs, fulaAnN qado Halaba OaXoTurahu (tropical:) Such a one has endured the difficulties and [enjoyed] the ampleness of fortune, and managed his affairs in poverty and in wealth: lit., has milked his pairs of teats, one pair after another. (TA.) ― -b6- Also A direction in which one looks or goes or the like. (S, A, Msb, K.) One says, qaSada XaTorahu He went in his, or its, direction; towards him, or it. (S, A.) And it is said in the Kur [ii. 139 and 144 and 145], fawalRi wajohaka XaTora Qlomasojidi QloHaraAmi Then turn thou thy face in the direction of the Sacred Mosque. (Fr, S.) The noun in this sense has no verb belonging to it: or one says, XaTara XaTorahu [expl. above: see 1]. (K.) ― -b7- Also Distance, or remoteness. (TA.)

XuTurN c
XuTurN: see XaTiyrN [of which it is both a syn. and a pl.].

waladu fulaAnK XiTorapN c
waladu fulaAnK XiTorapN The offspring of such a one are half males and half females. (S, A, K. [In the Ham p. 478, it is written XaTorp.])

XaToraAnu c
XaToraAnu, (S, A, K,) fem. XaToraI, (K,) A bowl, (S, K,) or vessel, (A, K,) half full. (S, A, K.)

XaTuwrN c
XaTuwrN A ewe, or she-goat, having one teat longer than the other; (S, O, K;) like HaDuwnN in this sense [and perhaps in others also, agreeably with what is said of XiTaArN in the first paragraph of this art.]: (S in art. HaDn:) and (so in the S and O, but in the K “ or ”) one having one of her teats dried up: (S, O, K:) and a she-camel having two of her teats dried up; for she has four teats. (S, O.) And A garment, or piece of cloth, having one of the two extremities of its breadth longer than the other. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

XaTiyrN c
XaTiyrN: see XaTorN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Distant, or remote; (As, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) applied to a town, or country, (As, S,) an abode, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and a tribe. (A.) And so XuTurN↓ in the phrase nawFI XuTurN [A distant tract, or region, towards which one journeys]: (S, K:) so too XaTuwrN↓ in the phrase niyRapN XaTuwrN [which may mean as above, (like niyRapN XaTuwnN,) or a remote, or farreaching, intention, or aim, or purpose]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A stranger; (S, O, Msb, K;) because of his remoteness from his people; (TA;) as in a verse cited voce UicFA: (S, O:) or one who is alone, or solitary: (A:) pl. XuTurN. (TA.)

XaATirN c
XaATirN [One who withdraws far away from his family; or breaks off from them, or quits them, in anger: (see 1, last sentence:) or] one who disagrees with his family, (Msb,) and who wearies them by his wickedness (S, Msb, K) and baseness (Msb) and guile: (TA:) i. q. xaliyEN [meaning as above, and having other similar meanings; generally vitious, or immoral; bad, evil, wicked, or mischievous]: (A:) accord. to some, it is post-classical: Aboo-Is-hák says that it signifies one who takes a wrong course: it is also expl. as signifying one who outstrips; like the [messenger called] bariyd, who takes a long journey in a short space of time: and hence, [as a conventional term of the mystics,] it is applied to one who outstrips, and is quick, in attaining nearness to God: or as meaning one who has wearied his family, and withdrawn far from them [n spirit], though with them [bodily], because of their inviting him to carnal lusts, and accustomed ways [of the world]: (TA:) [in the present day, it is applied to a sharper, or clever thief: and to any clever, or cunning, person:] pl. XuTRaArN. (TA.)

maXoTuwrN c
maXoTuwrN [Halved. ― -b2- And hence,] A verse of the metre termed AlrRajaz, (O, K,) and of that termed AlsRariyE, (TA,) having three of its six feet wanting; (O, K;) properly, having half thereof taken away. (O.) ＝ -A2- Also Bread done over with [the seasoning, or condiment, called] kaAmax. (O, K.)

humo muXaATiruwnaA c
humo muXaATiruwnaA They are persons whose houses adjoin ours. (O, K.).

XiToranojN c
XiToranojN (O, L, Msb, K) and XaToranojN; (L, Msb;) some say the former; and some, the latter; (Msb;) the latter said to be of established authority, as a dial. var., though disallowed in the K [and in the O]; but the former is the more approved on account of its being conformable with Arabic words, (Msb, TA,) such as jirodaHolN, (TA,) which the latter is not; (Msb, TA;) and sometimes it is pronounced with the unpointed s, (O,) this being a dial. var.; (K;) A wellknown game; [namely, chess:] (O, L, K:) a Pers. word, (TA,) arabicized; (Msb, K, TA;) [said to be] from Sado ranoG “ a hundred stratagems; ” or from Xudo ranoj “ trouble departed, ” meaning that trouble departs from him who plays at it; (TA;) [or from XaAho ranoj “ the royal care or sorrow; ” or from XaXo ranoG “ six species or ranks, ” because the pieces are of so many species: (Richardson's Pers. Arab. and Engl. Dict., Johnson's ed.:)] or [accord. to some] it is from AlXRaTaArapu, (O, K,) or AlmuXaATarapu, referring to the word XTrnj; (TA;) or from AltRasoTiyru, (O, K,) referring to the word sTrnj; so says Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee: but, as IB and others have said, these derivations are only partial, making the n and the j to be augmentative letters, and are manifestly incorrect. (MF, TA.)

1 XaTana c
1. XaTana, (S, TA,) [aor.
XaTuna
,] inf. n. XuTuwnN, (PS,) He was, or became, distant, or remote, (S, TA,) Eanohu [from him, or it]. (S.) And XaTanati AldRaAru, (Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., The abode, or dwelling, was distant, or remote. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, remote, or far, from the truth, and from the mercy of God. (Msb.) ― -b3- And XaTana fiI AlOaroDi, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) It entered into the earth, either raAsixFA [app. as meaning becoming firmly fixed therein], or waAgilFA [app. as meaning penetrating, and becoming concealed]. (K.) ＝ -A2- XaTanahu, (S, K,) aor.
XaTuna
, inf. n. XaTonN, (S,) He turned away in opposition to him (namely, his companion, K) from his design, or aim, or his direction that he was pursuing, and his way, or
course; expl. by the words xaAlafahu Eano niyRatihi wawajohihi. (ISk, S, K.) ＝ -A3- And XaTanahu, (S, K,) aor.
XaTuna
, (S,) inf. n. XaTonN, (TA,) He bound him with the XaTan [or rope, or long rope, &c.]. (S, K.)

4 AXTnhu c
4. AXTnhu He made him, or caused him, to be, or become, distant, or remote. (S, K.)

Q. Q. 1 XayoTana c
Q. Q. 1. XayoTana He acted as a XayoTaAn [i. e., as implied in the context, a devil; or one excessively, or inordinately, proud or corrupt or unbelieving or rebellious, or one insolent and audacious in pride and in acts of rebellion]; (K;) and taXayoTana↓; (S, K;) both signify the same; (K, TA;) he became, and acted, like the XayoTaAn. (TA.)

Q. Q. 2 taXayoTana c
Q. Q. 2. taXayoTana: see what next precedes.

XaTanN c
XaTanN A rope, (S, Msb, K,) in a general sense: (K:) or a long rope: (Kh, S, K:) or a long and strongly-twisted rope by means of which one draws water: (TA:) pl. OaXoTaAnN. (S, Msb, K.) Mention is made, in a trad., of a horse as being marobuwTN biXaTanayoni [i. e. Tied with two ropes, or long ropes, &c.,] because of his strength. (TA.) And one says of a strong-spirited horse, UinRahu layanozuw bayona XaTanayoni [Verily he leaps between two ropes, or long ropes, &c.]: a saying applied as a prov. to him who exults, or exults greatly, or excessively, and behaves insolently and ungratefully, and is strong. (TA.) An Arab of the desert described a horse (S, Msb) that did not become abraded in the sole of his hoof (so in a copy of the S) by saying, kaOanRahu XayoTaAnN fiI OaXoTaAnK [As though he were a devil in ropes, or long ropes, &c.]. (S, Msb.)

nawFI XaTuwnN c
nawFI XaTuwnN (S) or niyRapN XaTuwnN (K) [A place to which one purposes journeying] that is distant, or remote. (S, K.) And gazowapN XaTuwnN [A warring and plundering expedition] that is distant. (K.) And HarobN XaTuwnN [Distant war: or] (assumed tropical:) war that is difficult [because distant]. (TA. See an ex. in a verse cited voce jubRapN.) [See also XaTiynN, and XaATinN.] ― -b2- biYorN XaTuwnN (tropical:) A deep well, (S, K, TA,) curving in its interior: (TA:) or a well from which the bucket is drawn out by means of two ropes, from its two sides, wide in the upper part and narrow in the lower part; (K, TA;) so that if one draws out the bucket from it by means of one rope, one draws it against the casing, and it becomes rent. (TA.) And rumoHN XaTuwnN (assumed tropical:) A long and crooked spear. (TA.)

XaTiynN c
XaTiynN Distant, or remote. (TA. [See also XaTuwnN, and XaATinN.])

XaATinN c
XaATinN [Distant, or remote, in respect of the place of alighting or abode]; i. q. XaATibN [q. v.]. (TA in art. XTb. [See also XaTuwnN, and XaTiynN.]) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Far from the truth [and from the mercy of God: see 1]. (TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. xabiyvN (assumed tropical:) [Bad, corrupt, &c.; like saATinN]. (K.) Umeiyeh (S, TA) Ibn-Abi-s-Salt, referring to Solomon, (TA,) says,
OayRumaA XaATinK EaSaAhu EakaAhu
vumRa yuloqaI fiI AlsRijoni waAlOagolaAli
[Whatever bad one disobeyed him, he bound him in irons; then he was cast into the prison and the shackles for the neck and hands]. (S, TA.)

XayoTaAnN c
XayoTaAnN a word of well-known meaning [i. e. A devil; and with the article Al, the devil, Satan]: (S, K:) any that is excessively, or inordinately, proud or corrupt or unbelieving or rebellious, or that is insolent and audacious in pride and in acts of rebellion, of mankind, and of the jinn, or genii, and of beasts; (A'Obeyd, S, Msb, K;) as is shown in relation to the first and second of these by what is said in the Kur vi. 112, and ii. 13 and 96: (TA:) the n is radical, (S, Msb, TA,) the word being of the measure fayoEaAlN, from XaTana, (Msb, TA,) signifying “ he was, or became, distant, or remote, ” (TA,) or signifying “ he was, or became, remote, or far, from the truth, and from the mercy of God; ” (Msb;) as is indicated by the pl. XayaATiynu; [for] the reading of El-Hasan in the Kur xxvi. 210, AlXRayaATuwna, is anomalous, [like basaAtuwna for basaAtiynu,] and is said by Th to be a mistake: (TA:) or, as some say, the n is augmentative, (S, Msb, TA, *) and the I is radical, so that the word is of the measure faEolaAn, (Msb,) from XaATa, aor. yaXiyTu, (Msb, TA,) signifying “ it was, or became, null, void, of no account, ” and the like, and “ it burned, ” or “ became burnt, ” (Msb,) or signifying “ he burned with anger: ” but the former opinion is the more common: (TA:) [in the Kur, the word is always perfectly decl.; and so it is said to be by SM, in art. XyT of the TA; unless used as a proper name: but J says,] if you make it to be of the measure fayoEaAl from taXayoTana said of a man, [or rather because they say of a man tXyTn,] you make it perfectly decl.; but if you make it to be from XayRaTa [“ he burned ” a thing], you make it imperfectly decl., because it is of the measure faEolaAn. (S.) ― -b2- Also The serpent: (S, K:) or a certain species of serpents; (Fr, S, TA;) having a mane, of foul aspect: or, as some say, a slender, light, or active, serpent. (TA.) ― -b3- Respecting the saying in the Kur [xxxvii. 63], TaloEuhaA kaOanRahu ruWuwsu AlXRayaATiyni [Its fruit is as though it were the heads of the XyATyn], Fr says that there are three ways in which it may be explained: one is, that the TlE is likened to the heads of the XyATyn [meaning devils] in respect of foulness, or ugliness, because these are described as foul, or ugly: (S:) or it is likened to the evil in disposition of the jinn, because these are imagined as foul, or ugly: Zj says, in explaining it, that one says of a thing deemed foul, or ugly, kaOanRahu wajohu XayoTaAnK [as though it were the face of a devil], and kaOanRahu raOosu XayoTaAnK [as though it were the head of a devil]; for though the XyTAn is not seen, he is conceived in the mind as the foulest, or ugliest, of things: (TA:) the second is, that [the meaning is foul, or ugly, serpents; for] the Arabs apply the name XyTAn to a sort of serpents, having a mane, foul, or ugly, in the head and face: (S, TA: *) the third is, that a certain foul, or ugly, plat is named ruWuwsu AlXRayaATiyni; (S, TA;) which is expl. in the K only as meaning a certain plant. (TA.) ― -b4- XayoTaAnu AlfalaA [lit. The devil of the waterless deserts] means (assumed tropical:) thirst. (K.) ― -b5- XayoTaAnN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Any blamable faculty, or power, [or propensity,] of a man. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says, rakibahu XayoTaAnuhu i. e. (assumed tropical:) [His anger got the ascendency over him; or] he was, or became, angry. (TA.) And nazaEa XayoTaAnahu (assumed tropical:) He plucked out his pride. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, [probably as being likened to a serpent,] (assumed tropical:) A mark made with a hot iron in the upper part of the haunch of a camel, perpendicularly, upon the thigh, extending to the hock; (K, TA;) from the “ Tedhkireh ” of Aboo-'Alee; (TA;) likewise called muXayoTanapN↓. (AZ, K, TA.)

AlXRayoTaAniyRapu c
AlXRayoTaAniyRapu A certain sect of the extravagant zealots of [the schismatics called] the XiyEap; so named from [their founder] XayoTaAnu AlTRaAqi, (TA,) an appellation of Mohammad Ibn-En-Noaman. (K and TA in art. Twq.)

muXaATinN c
muXaATinN One who draws out the bucket from the well biXaTanayoni, (K, TA,) i. e. with two ropes. (TA.)

muXayoTanapN c
muXayoTanapN: see XayoTaAnN, last sentence.

, inf. n. XaZRN, (TA,) He fastened its XiZaAZ [q. v.] upon the sack: (S:) or he put the XiZaAZ into the bag; [meaning into its loop, or handle;] as also AXZRhu↓: (K:) or the latter signifies he put to it, or made for it, (namely the sack,) a XiZaAZ. (S.)

4 OaXoZaZa
4: see the preceding paragraph.

XiZaAZN The stick, or piece of wood, which is inserted into the loop, or handle, of a sack; (S;) a curved piece of wood, (K, TA,) with a pointed extremity, (TA,) which is put into the two loops, or handles, of a pair of sacks, (K, TA,) when they are bound upon the camel: (TA:) there are two such pieces of wood: (S, * TA:) pl. OaXiZRapN. (K.) And A piece of wood, or peg, with which they make fast the rope of a burden. (Ibn-Maaroof, as cited by Golius.)

XaZiyZN c
XaZiyZN A sack made fast, or bound. (Fr. K.) ＝ -A2- A stick, or piece of wood, split in several places. (Fr, K.)

1. XaZufa AlXRajaru, (S, O, K,) aor.

; (K;) and XaZifa, (O, K,) aor.
XaZafa
; (K;) inf. n. XaZaAfapN, (O, K,) of the former verb; (O;) The trees, not being sufficiently watered, became hard, without losing their moisture. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And XaZifato yaduhu His hand became rough, or coarse. (Har p. 70.) ― -b3- And XaZifa AlEayoXu The means of subsistence became dry and hard. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- XaZifN AlsRahomu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
XaZafa
, (K,) The arrow entered between the skin and the flesh. (S, Msb, K, Omitted in the TA.) ＝ -A3- XaZafotuhu Eani AlXRaIoCu,
(O, TA,) inf. n. XaZofN, (O, K,) I withheld, restrained, or debarred, him from the thing. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b2- And XaZofN signifies also The drawing forth the testicles of a ram: (O, K:) or the compressing them between two pieces of wood, or stick, and binding them with sinew (biEaqabK, in the CK [erroneously] bEaqibK,) so that they wither. (K.)

5 tXZRf c
5. tXZRf He subjected himself to a hard, or difficult, life. (L in art. mEd.)

XaZofN c
XaZofN A splinter, or piece split off, of a staff, or stick. (IAar, O, K.)

XiZofN c
XiZofN Dry bread. (O, K.) ― -b2- And A small piece of wood, or stick, like a peg: pl. XiZafapN. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

XaZafN c
XaZafN and XaZaAfN↓ Straitness; and hardness, or difficulty, or distress; (AZ, S, O, K;) like DafafN: (AZ, S, O:) ISd thinks that the second is a dial. var. of the first; and IB mentions that, in a verse of El-Kumeyt, as related by some, it is with kesr, i.e. XiZaAf [which see in what here follows]: (TA:) and (K) as some say, (TA,) dryness, and hardness, of the means of subsistence: (K:) or XaZafN signifies hardness, and straitness, of the means of subsistence: (Msb:) or hardness, and coarseness, or roughness, thereof; from XaZifato yaduhu [expl. above]: (Har p. 70:) pl. XiZaAfN. (K.) ― -b2- Also A disintegration of the flesh, separating it from the border around the nail. (TA.)

XaZifN c
XaZifN Dry and hard means of subsistence. (K, * TA. [See 1.]) ― -b2- Evil in disposition. (O, K.) ― -b3- Vehement in fight. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b4- A man alighting, or taking up an abode, in places where the herbage is dried up, and in a desert where is no water (falaAp). (TA in art. EZb.) ― -b5- baEiyrN XaZifu AlxilaATi [A stallion-camel] vehement in leaping, or compressing, the she-camels. (S, O, K.) ― -b6- OaroDN XaZifapN Rough, or rugged, land or ground. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

XiZofapN c
XiZofapN Bread that has become burned. (IAar, O.)

XZaAfN c
XZaAfN: see XaZafN.

XZaAfN c
XZaAfN Distance, or remoteness. (O, K.)

XajarN XaZiyfN c
XajarN XaZiyfN Trees that, not being sufficiently watered, have become hard, without losing their moisture. (S, O, K.)

miXoZafN c
miXoZafN One who utters oblique, indirect, or ambiguous, speech or language, deviating from the right way or course. (O, K. Omitted in the TA.)

1 XaZiIa c
1. XaZiIa, [aor. and inf. n. as in the next sentence,] said of a stick, or branch, or piece of wood, [&c.,] It was, or became, split. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- Said of a horse, (As, S, Mgh, K,) aor.
XaZaIa
, inf. n. XaZFI, (K,) His XZI, (As, S, Mgh, K,) i. e. the small bone called AlXRaZaI, (As, S, Mgh, *) moved from its place, (As, S, Mgh,) or became displaced, syn. zuwiIa, (A, TA,) or became unsteady, or wabbling: (K:) and so tXZRI↓, (K, TA,) this latter on the authority of ISd: (TA:) or [the inf. n.] XaZFI, accord. to some, signifies the sinews' becoming split, or slit: (As, S, Mgh:) or XaZFI has this meaning also; (K;) and so taXaZR↓. (ISd, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to the K, XaZiIa, said of a corpse, is syn. with XaSiIa: but correctly, the former verb is XaZaI, aor.
XaZiIa
, inf. n. XuZiIRN, and the latter verb is XaSaA [q. v.], as they are said to be by Az: and in like manner, XaZiI, aor.
XaZiIa
, is said of a siqaMC [or skin for water or milk], meaning It being filled, its legs became raised, or raised high. (TA.)

2 XZRI c
2. XZRI, (TA,) inf. n. taXoZiyapN, (K, TA,) He separated into several, or many, portions or divisions; or dispersed, or scattered; (K, * TA;) [a thing; or] (tropical:) a company of men. (TA.) ― -b2- And He made [a horse] to be such that his XZI (XaZaAhu) became unsteady, or wabbling. (TA.)

4 AXZAhu c
4. AXZAhu He, or it, hit, or hurt, his XZI (XaZaAhu): (K:) Sgh says, by rule it should be XaZaAhu [i. e. the verb should be thus, being derived from AlXRaZaI, like qafaAhu from AlqafaA]. (TA.)

5 tXZRI c
5. tXZRI, said of a stick, or branch, or piece of wood, (A, Msb, K, TA,) or of a thing, (S, TA,) It split, or became split, in pieces, or in several or many places: (A, Msb, TA:) or it became scattered, or dispersed, in splinters, or pieces split off: (S, K:) and it [i. e. anything, nothing in particular being specified,] became separated into several, or many, portions or divisions; or dispersed, or scattered. (TA.) One says also, tXZRI AllRuWoluWu Eani AlSRadafi (tropical:) [The pearls became separated, or scattered, from the oyster-shells]. (A, TA.) See also 1, in two places.

7 AnXZI c
7. AnXZI It broke, or became broken. (TA.) One says, AnXZt AlrRabaAEiyapu The [tooth called the] rbAEyp broke, or became broken. (TA.)

XaZFI c
XaZFI, of a staff, or stick, The like of a liyTap [i. e. a piece, or sharp piece, of the exterior portion], that enters into the hand, and wounds it. (Ham p. 474. [But XaZiyRapN is more commonly used in this and similar senses.]) ― -b2- A small bone, (EuZayomN, K, TA, [in the CK EaZomN, i. e. a bone, and so in my copy of the Mgh,]) or a slender small bone, (As, S,) adhering to the ciraAE [here app. meaning the arm-bone of a horse], (As, S, K,) or to the bone of the ciraAE, (Mgh,) which sometimes moves from its place; (As, S, Mgh; [see XaZiyRapN;]) or to the knee; (K;) thus in the M; (TA;) or to the waZiyf [app. here meaning the fore shank of a horse]; (K;) thus in the A: (TA:) or certain small sinews (EaSab) therein; (K;) i. e. in the wZyf; thus in the T. (TA.) AO says that taHarRuku AlXRaZaI [i. e. The motion of the XZI from its place (see 1)] is like what is termed AinotiXaAru AlEaSabi, except that the horse has more power of endurance of the latter than of the former. (T, TA.) ― -b3- And Portions of a thing that are separated, or dispersed, or scattered. (Har p. 160.) It is said by ISd to be a pl. [or rather it is a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is XaZaApN. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A portion of fur upon the mark left by a gall, or sore, on the back [of a camel], such as reaches the utmost extent thereof: (K, accord. to the TA: [AlXRaZaI being there expl. by the words Alwbrp ElI Avr Aldbrp HtI tblg AqSAhA: in the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K, AldRabarapu ElI Oavari AldRabarapi fI AlmazoraEapi HatRaI taboluga OaqoSaAhaA; which Freytag renders “ sulcus ad latus alterius in arvo ductus, ut ejus extremum attingeret; ” but which, I think, evidently presents a mistranscription and an interpolation:]) the pl. is OaXoZiyapN: and sometimes there are ten [?] portions of fur [of this description, app. meaning, upon one camel: the word that I here render “ ten ” is more like EXh than EXr; but the final letter, as is often the case in the MS. of the TA, is written in a form differing little from a common form of r]: mentioned by ISh, from Et-Táïfee; as is said in the T. (TA.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) The followers, and incorporated confederates, of a people, or party; (S, K;) contr. of the Samiym thereof: (S:) or the freedmen and followers. (M, TA.)

XaZiIRN c
XaZiIRN and XiZiIRN: see the next paragraph.

XiZiyRapN c
XiZiyRapN A splinter, or piece split off, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) of a staff, or stick, and the like, (S,) or of wood, (T, Mgh, Msb,) and the like, (Msb,) or of a reed, or cane, (T, Mgh,) or of silver, (T, TA,) or of bone, (T, Mgh,) or of anything: (M, K:) pl. XaZaAyaA (S, Msb, K, &c.) and XaZiIRN↓, (K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] like as rakiIRN is of rakiyRapN, (TA,) or a quasi-pl. n., like EabiydN, improperly said by IAar to be pl. of XaZFI, (ISd, TA,) and XiZiIRN↓, (K, TA, [in the latter as omitted in the K, with kesr to the X on account of the same vowel-sound following,]) mentioned by Sgh, from Ks. (TA.) AO terms the Uiborap [q. v.] at the head of the elbow [of the horse] a XaZiyRap adhering to the ciraAE, but not [forming a portion] of it. (TA. [See XaZFI.]) ― -b2- Also A bow: (K:) because its wood is split: on the authority of AHn. (TA.) ― -b3- And The shankbone. (K.) ― -b4- And A great mass of rock wrenched from the side of a mountain; (K, TA;) as though it were a piece split off, broken [off] but not parted so as to form an interstice, or a gap: and also a piece cut from a mountain, like a house or a tent: and it is said in the copies of the K that XiZoyapN, with kesr, signifies the same; but the word is correctly XinoZiyapN↓, with an augmentative n as in the T, and mentioned also by Hr in the “ Ghareebeyn: ” pl. of the former XaZaAyaA. (TA.) ― -b5- See also XanoZaApN.

XaAZK c
XaAZK part. n. of XaZiIa [q. v.] said of a horse. (TA.)

XanoZaApN c
XanoZaApN The head, or top, of a mountain, (K, TA,) [and so XaZiyRapN↓, (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees,)] resembling the Xurofap [q. v.]
of a mosque: pl. XanaAZK: and AljibaAli XawaAZiI↓ [likewise] signifies the heads, or tops, of the mountains. (TA.)

XinoZiyapN c
XinoZiyapN: see XaZiyRapN, near the end.

XawaAZiI AljibaAli c
XawaAZiI AljibaAli: see XanoZaApN.

maXoZFI c
[maXoZFI, pl. maXaAZiI, A fragment of wood: (Freytag, from the Deewán of Jereer:) but the pl., when indeterminate, is correctly maXaAZK.]

1 XaERa c
1. XaERa, (O, K, TA,) aor.
XaEiEa
, (O, TA,) inf. n. XaEaAEN (S, * O, * K, * TA) and XaERN, (TA,) It became scattered, or dispersed; (S, O, K, TA;) said of a thing; like XaAEa, aor. yaXiyEu; (TA;) of the urine of a camel; (O, K;) and of a people, or party; (IAar, O, K;) [like XagRa;] and [in like manner] XaEaAEN is used in relation to blood, &c., as meaning the being scattered. (S, O, K, TA. [See also XaEaAEN, below; and XuEaAEN.]) ＝ -A2- XaERa bawolahu, (S, O, K,) aor.
XaEuEa
, (S, O,) inf. n. XaERN (O, TA) and XaEaAEN, (K, * TA,) He (a camel) scattered his urine; as also AXERhu↓: (S, O, K:) or both signify he scattered his urine, and stopped it. (TA.) ― -b2- And XaERa AlgaArapa, (K, TA,) inf. n. XaERN; and XaEoXaEahaA↓; (TA;) He poured upon them the horsemen making a sudden attack and engaging in conflict, or urging on their horses; (K, TA;) and in like manner, Alxayola. (TA.)

4 OaXoEaEa
4: see 1. ― -b2- AXERt AlXRamosu The sun spread, or diffused, its XuEaAE [or beams], (S, K,) or its light. (TA.) ― -b3- AXER AlzRaroEu The corn put forth its XaEaAE, (S, K, TA,) i. e., its awn. (TA.) ― -b4- And AXER AlsRunobulu The ears of corn became compact in their grain, (K, TA,) and dry therein. (TA.)

7 AnXER AlcRiYobu fiI Alganami c
7. AnXER AlcRiYobu fiI Alganami The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats. (O, K, TA.)

R. Q. 1 XaEoXaEahu c
R. Q. 1. XaEoXaEahu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. XaEoXaEapN, (TA,) He mixed it, namely, wine, (S, O, K,) with water. (O.) And He mixed one part of it, namely, a thing, with another part, (O, * K,) like as one mixes wine with water. (O.) And XaEoXaEa AlvRariydapa He mixed the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread] with olive-oil: (O:) or he put much clarified butter to it, (ISh, O, K,) and much grease, or gravy: (K:) or he raised its head; (O, K;) as some say: (Sh, O:) or he made its head high; (O, K;) as some say; from XaEoXaAEN as an epithet applied to a man, meaning “ tall. ” (O.) But the verb is used more in relation to wine than to vryd. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

R. Q. 2 taXaEoXaEa c
R. Q. 2. taXaEoXaEa, said of a man, is from XaEoXaAEN↓ applied to a man as meaning HulowN xafiyfN [i. e. “ such as is excited to briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, and esteemed pleasing in the eye, and is light, or active; ” so that the verb may be rendered He was, or became, such as is excited to briskness, &c.: or he was, or became, such as is termed XaEoXaAEN, q. v.]. (Ham, p. 246.) ― -b2- Said of the month It nearly came to an end; little remained of it: (K, TA:) occurring in a trad.: but accord. to one relation thereof, it is taXaEosaEa; from AlXRusuwEu “ the being distant, or remote: ” and accord. to another, taXaEosaEa, with two ss. (TA.)

XaERN c
XaERN: see XaEaAEN, first and last sentences. ＝ -A2- Also Haste: (IAar, K, TA:) and so XaEiyEN accord. to the K; but this is wrong; the meaning of the latter word being only that given below, voce XaEaAEN. (TA.)

XuERN c
XuERN A spider's web. (AA, K.) ― -b2- See also XuEaAEN.

XaEaAEN c
XaEaAEN [an inf. n. (see 1) used as an epithet, and therefore as masc. and fem. and sing. and pl.;] Scattered, or dispersed; and disordered, or unsettled; syn. mutafarRiqN; (S, K;) as also XaERN↓, [likewise an inf. n. used as an epithet,] applied [like the former] to anything, (K, TA,) such as blood, and an opinion, and a purpose, or an intention; (TA;) and XaEiyEN↓, which is wrongly expl. in the K as syn. with XaERN in another sense, as stated above; (TA;) and XaEoXaAEN↓. (S, K.) One says, cahaba damuhu XaEaAEFA His blood went scattered, or dispersed: (TA:) or XaEaAEN applied to blood signifies spirtling from a wound made with a spear or the like; as in a verse cited voce nafacN. (Az, TA. [See also XuEaAEN.]) And cahabuwA XaEaAEFA They went away scattered, or dispersed. (K.) And OumRapN XaEaAEN A nation, or people, scattered, or dispersed. (TA, from a trad.) And taTaAyarati AlEaSaA XaEaAEFA The staff, or stick, broke into scattered pieces; as when one has broken it by striking with it upon a wall: and in like manner, AlqaSabapu the reed, or cane. (TA.) And raOoIN XaEaAEN A disordered, or an unsettled, opinion. (S, K.) And nafosN XaEaAEN A mind of which the purposes, or intentions, (himamuhaA, as in the S [and O], for which, in the K, humuwmuhaA is erroneously substituted, TA,) and the opinions, (Z, TA,) are disordered, or unsettled, (S, K, TA,) so that it is not directed to a decided affair. (Z, TA.) And TaAra fuWaAduhu XaEaAEFA [His mind fled in a disordered, or an unsettled, state, as though dissipated; expl. as] meaning tafarRaqato humuwmuhu [a mistranscription, as before: correctly tfrRqt himamuhu i. e. his purposes, or intentions, became disordered, or unsettled: see also Ham p. 44, and Har p. 366]. (K.) And a rájiz says,
Algadaro Sadoqu AllRiqaMCi gayoru XaEoXaAEi↓
meaning [Firm, or steady, in encounter, or conflict,] not disordered, or unsettled, in respect of purpose, or intention. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, app., (TA,) Milk mixed with much water; (ISh, O;) syn. DayaAHN. (ISh, O, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also [as a subst.] The awn, or beard, of the ears of corn; (S, O, K;) and so XuEaAEN↓ and XiEaAEN↓ (K) and XaERN↓: (TA:) or the awn, or beard, when it has become dry, as long as it remains on the ears; as also XuEaAEN↓. (Lth, O.)

XaEaAEN c
XaEaAEN (S, O, K) and XuERN↓ (AA, K) [The rays, or beams, of the sun; or] what one sees, (S, O, K,) of the light, like rods, (S,) or extending like spears, (O, K,) at the rising, or the beginning of the rising, (S,) or a little after the rising, (O, K,) of the sun; (S, O, K;) or what one sees, like cords coming towards him, when looking at the sun; or the dispersing light of the sun: (K:) n. un. with p: (S, O, K) [and Freytag states that XiEoXiEapN↓ is said by Jac. Schultens to signify rays: but this I do not find in any lexicon:] the pl. (of XuEaAEN, O) is OaXiERapN, (O, K,) accord. to analogy, (O,) [a pl. of pauc.,] and XuEuEN (O, K) and XiEaAEN↓; (K;) the last anomalous. (TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting [the night called] layolapu Alqadori, it is said, UinRa AlXRamosa taToluEu mino gadi yawomihaA laA XuEaAEa lahaA [Verily the sun will rise on its morrow having no rays]. (S: in the O, mino gadihaA.) ― -b2- In the verse cited voce nafacN, As is related to have read AlXRuEaAEu instead of AlXRaEaAEu, as meaning The light, [or brightness] and redness, and scattered state, of the blood: ISd says, I know not whether he said it meaning by original application or by way of comparison. (TA.) ― -b3- See also XaEaAEN, last sentence, in two places.

XiEaAEN c
XiEaAEN: see XaEaAEN, last sentence: ― -b2- and see also XuEaAEN.

XaEiyEN c
XaEiyEN: see XaEaAEN, first sentence.

XaEoXaEN c
XaEoXaEN, (S, O,) or XaEoXaAEN↓, (K,) or both, (TA,) and muXaEoXaEN↓, (S, TA,) Shade that is not thick, or dense; (S, O, K, TA;) or which has not wholly shaded one, having in it interspaces. (TA.) ― -b2- See also XaEoXaAEN, in two places.

XuEoXuEN c
XuEoXuEN: see the next paragraph but one, in two places: and see XuloXulN.

XiEoXiEapN c
XiEoXiEapN: see XuEaAEN.

XaEoXaAEN c
XaEoXaAEN: see XaEaAEN, in two places: and XaEoXaEN. ― -b2- Also, (S, O, S,) and XaEoXaEN↓ (O, K) and XaEoXaEaAnN↓ (IDrd, S, O, K) and XaEoXaEaAniIRN↓, (O, K,) in which last the relative I is without cause, as in OaHomariIRN and dawRaAriIRN, (TA,) applied to a man, (S,) Tall: (O, K:) or tall and goodly (S, TA) and light of flesh; applied to a man as being likened to the thin [or much diluted] wine termed muXaEoXaEap: or the first signifies long-necked; and so ↓the third, and ↓the fourth; applied to anything, or the last, accord. to the R, applied to a man only: and the first, long applied to a neck: (TA:) and light, or active: (O, K:) or so in journeying; as also XuEoXuEN↓ like hudohudN, applied to a man, or, accord. to Th, to a boy, or young man: or light in spirit: (TA:) see also R. Q. 2: and (K) as some say, (O,) the first signifies goodly, or beautiful, (O, K, TA,) in face: (TA:) and XaEoXaEN↓, (so in the O,) or XuEoXuEN↓, with damm to the X, (TA,) a boy, or young man,
goodly, or beautiful, in face, light in spirit; (O, TA;) on the authority of AA. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Certain trees; or a kind of tree. (TA.)

XaEoXaEaAnN c
XaEoXaEaAnN: see XaEoXaAEN, in two places. With p, applied to a she-camel, meaning Tall: (S, * O:) or large in body: (TA:) pl. XaEoXaEaAnaAtN. (S, O. [In the TA, XaEoXaEaAnaAtN is said to be mistranscribed in the S XaEoXaEaAnaAn: but it is not so in either of my copies.])

XaEoXaEaAniIRN c
XaEoXaEaAniIRN: see XaEoXaAEN, in two places. Also Long and thin; applied to a camel's lip. (TA.)

muXaEoXaEN c
muXaEoXaEN: see XaEoXaEN. ― -b2- With p, applied to wine (xamorN), Mixed with water: (O, * EM p. 183:) accord. to some, [much diluted; i. e.] mixed so as to be thin. (TA.)

1 XaEaba c
1. XaEaba, (S, Msb,) aor.
XaEaba
, (Msb,) inf. n. XaEobN, (A, Msb, K,) He collected; brought, gathered, or drew, together; or united; (S, A, Msb, K;) a thing, (S,) any thing or things, and a people or party: (Msb:) and he separated; put apart, or asunder; divided; disunited; or dispersed or scattered; (S, A, Msb, K;) a thing, (S,) any thing or things, and a people or party: (Msb:) thus having two contr. significations: (S:) so expressly state A'Obeyd and Aboo-Ziyád: (TA:) but accord. to IDrd, it has not two contr. significations [in one and the same dial.]: he says that the two meanings are peculiar to the dials. of two peoples, (Msb, TA, *) each meaning belonging to the dial. of one people exclusively. (TA.)
