; (Msb;) and [in an intensive sense] tXERlt↓; (K, TA;) The fire became kindled; or it burned up, burned brightly or fiercely, blazed, or flamed; syn. taOajRajat, (Lh, TA,) or AiDoTaramat, (S, O, TA,) or tawaqRadat, (Msb,) and Ailotahabat; (K, * TA;) fiI AlHaTabi [in the firewood]. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, AiXotaEala gaDabFA (tropical:) He became excited, or inflamed, with anger: (TA:) or he became filled with wrath. (Msb.) ― -b3- Hence also, AXtEl AlXRayobu fiI AlrRaOosi (tropical:) Whiteness of the hair became glistening in the head; including the hair of the beard. (TA.) And AXtEl AlrRaOosa XayobFA [in the Kur xix. 3, expl. in art. Xyb]. (S, Msb.)

9 UiXoEalRa
9: see 1.

11 UiXoEaAolRa
11: see 1. ― -b2- AXEAlR raOosuhu, (O, K,) inf. n. AiXoEiylaAlN, (TA,) His hair became separated, or loosened, and ruffled, or bristling up. (O, K.)

Q. Q. 4 AiXoEaOalRa c
Q. Q. 4. AiXoEaOalRa: see 1.

XaEolN c
XaEolN (assumed tropical:) A man light, agile, or active, and clever, ingenious, acute, or sharp: (O, K:) and so maEolN. (O, TA.)

XaEalN c
XaEalN [inf. n. of XaEila (q. v.)] and XuEolapN↓ [properly a subst. as distinguished from an inf. n.] (assumed tropical:) A whiteness in the tail of a horse, and the forelock, and the qacaAl [or place where the EicaAr, i. e. each of the two cheek-straps of the headstall, is tied, behind the forelock]: (K:) or in some part of the forelock; or, as some say, in a side thereof: and
sometimes in the qcAl: but mostly in the tail: (TA:) or the former signifies a whiteness in the extremity of the tail of a horse: or, accord. to Lth, a whiteness in the forelock and the tail: or, as some say, in the head and the forelock: [or the quality of having such whiteness: for it is added that] the subst. [app. signifying such whiteness itself] is XuEolapN↓: (Mgh:) or the former, a whiteness in the side of the tail: [or,] accord. to As, XuEolapN↓ is a term applied to a whiteness of the tail when it intermixes with any other colour; and the horse is said to be bayRinu AlXRaEali [i. e. one that exhibits the quality of having such whiteness]. (S.)

XuEolapN c
XuEolapN A firebrand; a piece of wood in which fire is kindled; (Az, K, * TA;) like jicowapN and qayasN and XihaAbN: (Az, TA:) [this is what is meant by its being said that] what is termed XuEolapN mino naArK [the only indication of the meaning in the S and O] is well known: (Msb:) pl. XuEalN; (S, O, TA;) erroneously said in the K to be like kutubN. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN XuEolapu naArK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is a firebrand]. (Er-Rághib, TA voce cakaMCN, q. v.) ― -b2- And [A lighted wick: so in the present day: (see also XaEiylapN:) or] the burnt [or lighted] extremity of a wick. (S voce qiraATN. [And the same meaning is intended there in the K; and also in the TA voce jicowapN.]) ― -b3- And The flame of fire; as also XuEoluwlN↓. (K, * TA. [In the CK XuEuwl; as though it were a second pl. of XuEolapN.]) ― -b4- And XuEolapu, (O, K, TA,) without Al, (K, TA,) is the name of A mare of Keys Ibn-Sebáa; (O, K, TA;) likened to the kindling of fire, because of her swiftness. (TA.) ― -b5- See also XaEalN, in three places.

XuEoluwlN c
XuEoluwlN: see the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also A party, division, sect, or distinct body or class, of men &c. (TA.) [See XaEaAliylu, below.]

XaEiylN c
XaEiylN The like of stars, at the bottom of a cooking-pot; and in tinder, or burnt rag into which fire has fallen. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.) ― -b2- See the next paragraph. ― -b3- And see also OaXoEalu.

XaEiylapN c
XaEiylapN [A lighted wick; i. e.] a wick in which is fire; (S, O, K;) a wick soaked with oil or grease, in which is fire, used for giving light, and not thus called unless kindled with fire: (TA: [see also XuEolapN:]) or the fire that is kindled in a wick: (K:) pl. XuEulN, like as SuHufN is pl. of SaHiyfapN; (T, S, O, TA;) in the K erroneously said to be XaEiylN↓ [which, however, may be correct as a coll. gen. n.]. (TA.)

XaEaAliylu c
XaEaAliylu [a pl., of which the sing. is app. XuEoluwlN, q. v.; Things, and persons, scattered, or dispersed]. Aboo-Wejzeh says,
HatRaI UicaA maA danato minohu sawaAbiquhaA
walilRugaAmi biEiTofayohi XaEaAliylu
[Until, or until when, those of them that outstripped approached him, and there were scattered portions of foam upon his two sides]. (TA.) And one says, cahabuwA XaEaAliyla, (S, O, K,) like XaEaAriyra, i. e., (S, O,) [They went away] in a state of dispersion; (K;) [or] they dispersed themselves, or became dispersed. (S, O.)

XaAEilN c
XaAEilN as used in a verse cited above (see 4) [may be the part. n. of the intrans. verb in the phrase XaEalati AlnRaAru, and thus] may mean [Burning &c.; or] slightly burning: (Ham p. 715:) [or] it signifies cuw UiXoEaAlK [having the quality of kindling, &c.; being said to be a possessive epithet], (S, O, K,) like taAmirN and laAbinN, having no verb: (S, O: [but see 4, first sentence:]) or it may be for cuw XaEolK, meaning muXoEilN. (Ham ubi suprà. [See, again, 4.]) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

OaXoEalu c
OaXoEalu A horse having the whiteness termed XuEolapN (As, S, Mgh, O, K) or XaEalN [q. v.]; (Mgh, K;) as also XaEiylN↓ and XaAEilN↓: (O, K:) fem. of the first XaEolaMCu. (S, K.) ― -b2- And gurRapN XaEolaMCu [A blaze on a horse's forehead or face] taking in, i. e. including, one of the eyes. (Mgh, TA.)

maXoEalN c
maXoEalN A [lamp of the kind called] qinodiyli [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b2- See also maXoEalapN.

muXoEalN c
muXoEalN [pass. part. n. of 4, q. v.]. One says naArN muXoEalapN [A fire kindled, &c.; or] burning up, burning brightly or fiercely, blazing, or flaming. (Lh, TA.) And jaMCa fulAanN kaAlHariyqi AlmuXoEali i. e. [Such a one came like the fire that is] kindled, &c. (S, O.) See also the next paragraph.

jaraAdN muXEilN c
jaraAdN muXEilN (tropical:) Locusts that are numerous, (K, TA,) spreading, (S, O,) in a state of dispersion, (K,) running in every direction. (S, O.) One says, (S, O, TA,) of an army, (TA,) jaAWuwA kaAljaraAdi AlmuXoEili (S, O, TA) (tropical:) They came [like locusts numerous and spreading, &c.,] coming forth from every direction: thus the last word is written accord. to Az [and J] and Sgh; and thus, and also AlmuXoEali↓, accord. to Z. (TA.) And katiybapN muXoEilapN (assumed tropical:) [A military force] spreading, or in a state of dispersion. (S, O.)

miXoEalN c
miXoEalN A certain thing, (S, O, K,) used by the Arabs of the desert, (S, O,) made of skins (S, O, K) sewed together, like the niTaE [q. v.], (S, O,) having four legs (S, O, K) of wood, to which it is bound, so that it becomes like the wateringtrough; (S, O;) [the beverage called] nabiyc is prepared in it, (S, O, K,) because [generally] they have not jars: (S, O:) also called miXoEaAlN↓: (O, K:) pl. maXaAEilu. (S, O.) Xariba miXoEalFA occurs in a trad. [as meaning He drank the quantity that filled a miXoEal of nabiyc]. (O.) ― -b2- Also i. q. miSofaApN [A clarifier, or strainer, for wine &c.]: (O, K:) pl. as above. (TA.)

maXEalapN c
maXEalapN A particular sort of large support for a light: (KL:) [i. e. a sort of cresset, consisting of a staff with a cylindrical frame of iron at the top which is filled with flaming pine-wood or the like or tarred rags, or, as is sometimes the case, having two, three, four, or five, of these receptacles for fire: it is borne before travellers and others at night; and is thus called in the present day, and also, more commonly, maXoEal↓: (two cressets of the sort thus called are figured in my “ Modern Egyptians, ” ch. vi.: see also maXaAEiliIRN, below:)] the place in which fire is kindled: (TA: [a loose explanation, meaning a cresset:]) what is thus called is the thing of which the pl. is maXaAEilu: (S, O:) [accord. to El-Wáhidee, it is miXoEalapN↓; for he says that] AlmXElp with kesr to the m means the instrument in which fire is carried: and maXoElp [thus, with a fet-hah over the nAr,] means fire kindled; or made to burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame; syn. mwqdp mwqdp. (W p. 51.)

miXoEalapN c
miXoEalapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

miXoEaAlN c
miXoEaAlN: see miXoEalN.

maXaAEiliIRN c
[maXaAEiliIRN, a rel. n. formed from maXaAEilu pl. of maXoEalapN, is a n. un. of which the coll. gen. n. is maXaAEiliyRapN, and signifies A bearer of the cresset called maXoEalap: hence applied also to a nightman: and hence, to a cleanser of wells: a scavenger; or remover of offal and the like: and to an executioner. (See De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 201 — 203; and Quatremère's “ Hist. des Sultans Mamlouks, ” sec. part, 4 and 5.)]

4 AXEI Alqawomu AlgaArapa c
4. AXEI Alqawomu AlgaArapa, (S, K,) inf. n. UiXoEaMCN, (S,) The people, or party, spread, or dispersed, themselves, or their horsemen, in the hostile, or predatory, incursion; syn. OaXoEaluwhaA. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- And AXEI bihi, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He was, or became, grieved, or disquieted, by it; syn. AihotamRa. (Ibn-Habeeb, Sgh, K.)

gaArapN XaEowaMCu c
gaArapN XaEowaMCu A raid, or hostile or predatory incursion, spreading widely and dispersedly. (S, K. *) [See an ex. in the last of the verses cited voce rubRa.] ― -b2- And XajarapN XaEowaMCu A tree having spreading branches. (ISd, K.)

jaMCati Alxayolu XawaAEiIa c
jaMCati Alxayolu XawaAEiIa, (S, K,) and XawaAYiEa, from which XwAEI is [said to be] formed by transposition, (S,) The horsemen came scattered, or dispersed, or in a state of dispersion. (S, K.)

1 Xagaba Ealayohimo c
1. Xagaba Ealayohimo, (S, A, Msb, K,) and bihimo, (S, Msb, K,) and fiyhimo, (TA,) and Xagabahumo, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Xagaba
, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. XagobN, (S, * A, * K, * TA,) with which XagabN is syn., (A, K,) a syn. sometimes used, (A,) or this latter is not allowable, (S, K,) as some say, (K,) and is ascribed by IAth to the vulgar, and said by El-Hareeree in the “ Durrat el-Ghowwás ” to be a mistake, but IB says in the commentaries on the “ Durrah ” that it is correct, mentioned by IDrd, and MF says that it is mentioned by IJ, as well as by Z in the A; (TA;) and one says also Xagiba Elyhm, [and it seems to be implied that one says likewise Xagiba
bhm, and Xagibahumo,] aor. as above, (S, K,) inf. n. XagabN; (S, TA;) but this latter form of the verb, with kesr, is of weak authority; (S, * TA;) [whence it seems that XagabN is correct as inf. n. of Xagiba, but disallowed by some who knew not this form of the verb;] He excited, or stirred up, (S, A, Msb, K, TA,) [against them, or] among them, (Msb,) evil, or mischief, (S, A, Msb, K, TA,) and conflict, faction, sedition, or discord, and contention, or altercation, and opposition: (TA:) and [it is said that] taXogiybN is like XagobN signifying the exciting, or stirring up, evil, &c.; (K, TA;) [but] XgRb↓, inf. n. taXogiybN, signifies he excited, or stirred up, evil, &c., much, or often. (O.) A trad. mentioned in [the first paragraph of] art. XEb is quoted by IAth thus: maA hecihi AlfotoyaA AlRatiI Xagabato fiI AlnRaAsi [What is this judicial decision which has excited evil, &c., among the people?]. (TA.) ― -b2- [See also XagobN below.] ― -b3- The saying of 'Amr Ibn-Kameeäh,
faUino taXogibiI faAlXRagobu minRiI sajiyRapN
means (tropical:) And if thou oppose, or contravene, me, and do that which is not agreeable to me, [know that opposition, &c., is a natural disposition of mine; EalaIRa being understood after tXgbI, as appears from what here follows.] (TA. [See also 3, and 6.]) Accord. to El-Báhilee, caAtu XagobK [applied to a she-ass] means (tropical:) Having the quality of opposing or contravening [the male]: so in the saying of El-'Ajjáj,
kaOanRa taHotiI caAta XagobK samoHajaA
qawodaMCa laA taHomilu UilRaA muxodajaA
(tropical:) [As though beneath me were a she-ass] such as opposes or contravenes [the male], long-bodied, long-necked, [that would not bear in her womb aught save a fœtus imperfectly formed;] meaning, laA tuWaAtibhi wataXogabu Ealayohi [i. e. that she (the beast that he was riding) would not comply with his desire, and was contravening him]. (TA.) [Accord. to J,] caAtu XagobK waDigonK, [in the TA wSgb, and so in a copy of the A, an evident mistranscription,] applied to a she-ass that has not conceived during a year or two years or some years, means (tropical:) Refractory, or incompliant, to the strong, or bulky, male. (S: there expl. by the words UicaA waHimato waQsotaSoEabato EalaI AljaOobi [which have been misunderstood by Golius, and rendered by him, and by Freytag after him, as applied to a woman, and meaning respuens maris congressum, aut picâ laborans].) ― -b4- And Xagaba signifies also (assumed tropical:) He declined, or deviated, from the right way or course: (Sh, TA:) or Xagaba Eani AlTRariyqi, aor.
Xagaba
, (K,) inf. n. XagbN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He declined, or deviated, from the road or way. (K.)

2 XagRaba
2: see 1, end of the first sentence.

3 XAgbhu c
3. XAgbhu, (S, A, K, TA,) inf. n. muXaAgabapN and XigaAbN, (TA,) He acted with him in an evil manner; treated him with enmity, or hostility; contended in altercation with him; or did evil to him, obliging him to do the like in return: (A, K, TA:) he opposed, or contravened, him. (TA.)

6 Talabotu minohu kacaA fataXaAgaba waQmotanaEa c
6. Talabotu minohu kacaA fataXaAgaba waQmotanaEa (tropical:) I sought, or demanded, of him such a thing, and he manifested incompliance (taEaASaI), and refused. (A, TA.)

XagobN c
XagobN inf. n. of Xagaba [q. v. passim]. (S, * A, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also Clamour, or a confusion of cries or shouts or noises: (Ham p. 505:) or much clamour and confused or indistinct speech, leading, or conducing, to evil, or mischief. (Har p. 311.) One says Xagobu Aljunodi [The clamour, &c., of the army]. (S, and Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b3- [Hence, app., this word, or the next, is used by some postclassical writers as signifying The plaintive cry of the bulobul. (See De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., iii. 500 — 502.)]

XagabN c
XagabN inf. n. of Xagiba [q. v.]. (S, TA.)

XagibN c
XagibN, (S, O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, XigobN,]) like katifN, (O,) and XagRaAbN↓, (S, O, K,) the latter in an intensive sense, (TA,) and XigabRN↓, (O, K,) [also in an intensive sense,] and miXogabN↓, (S, O, K,) [likewise] in an intensive sense, (O,) and muXagRibN↓, [also in an intensive sense accord. to the explanation of its verb in the O,] (S,) and muXaAgibN↓, and cuwmaXaAgiba↓, (K,) One who excites, or stirs up, evil, or mischief, (S, * K, TA,) and conflict, faction, sedition, or discord, and contention, or altercation, and opposition. (TA.)

XigabRN c
XigabRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XagRaAbN c
XagRaAbN: see XagibN. ― -b2- naAqapN XagRaAbapN (tropical:) A she-camel that does not pursue a direct course, but deviates [therefrom]. (A, TA.)

miXogabN c
miXogabN: see XagibN. ― -b2- fulaAnN miXogabN (assumed tropical:) Such a one is a person who deviates from what is right, or from the truth. (O, TA.)

muXagRibN c
muXagRibN: see XagibN.

cuw maXaAgiba c
cuw maXaAgiba: see XagibN.

muXaAgibN c
muXaAgibN: see XagibN.

1 XagVra
1: The inf. n. XagorN, accord. to Ibn-Nubáteh, primarily signifies The raising the leg or hind leg, without restriction; and then by a metaphorical usage, the doing so for the purpose of copulation, and for making water: but the explanations of J [and of Z in the A] and of Fei and of F are at variance with his assertion. (MF.) [Accord. to these authorities,] Xagara, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
Xagara
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) signifies He (a dog) raised one of his hind legs (S, A, Msb, K) to make water, (S, Msb,) or and made water, or whether he made water or did not: (A, K:) and Xagara birijolihi he (a dog) raised his hind leg, and made water. (TA.) And Xagarato She (a camel) raised her hind leg, and struck [with it, or kicked,] the young one. (A.) And, said of a woman, (Msb, K,) She raised her leg, (Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) or her legs, (so in other copies of the K,) for the purpose of copulation. (Msb, K.) And the verb is also trans.: you say, Xagara AlmaroOapa, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XuguwrN, (K, [but this is a strange form in the case of a trans. verb,]) He raised the woman's leg, (Msb, and so in some copies of the K) or legs, (IDrd, O, and so in some copies of the K,) for the purpose of copulation; and so AXgrhA↓. (IDrd, O, Msb, K.) And XagorN as the act of a stallion [camel] signifies His striking with his head beneath the she-camel, at the part next the udder, and so raising her, and throwing her down [app. for the purpose of copulation]. (K.) ― -b2- Xagarotu birijoliI fiI Algariybi means (assumed tropical:) I overcame the people in guarding, or protecting, the stranger. (AA, O, K.) ― -b3- And XagorN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The being distant, or remote. (Fr, K.) One says, Xagara Albaladu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Xagura
, inf. n. XuguwrN, (Msb, [accord. to the K, app., XagorN,]) (assumed tropical:) The country, or town, was, or became, remote from him who should aid it against the enemy, and him who should exercise sovereign sway, (K, TA,) and from him who should manage its affairs with prudence, precaution, or sound judgment: (TA:) or destitute of a guardian, or protector, to defend it: (Msb:) or destitute of people: [and so, app., Xagara Albaladu birijolihi; for it is immediately added,] one says balodapN XaAgirapN birijolihaA meaning as expl. below: (S:) and Xagarati AlOaroDu the land had not remaining in it any one to defend it, and to manage its affairs with prudence, precaution, or sound judgment. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, i. e. XagorN, The making [another, or others,] to go forth [from a place]. (K.) One says, Xagarotuhu Eani AlOaroDi I made him to go forth from the land: (AA, TA:) and Xagarotu baniI fulaAnK mino mawoDiEi kacaA I made the sons of such a one to go forth from such a place: (S:) or XagaruwA fulaAnFA Eano baladihi They drove away, expelled, or banished. such a one from his country, or town; and the inf. n. is XagorN and XigaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. taforiqapN [The act of scattering, or dispersing]. (K.)

3 XAgrhu c
3. XAgrhu, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. XigaArN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) He gave him in marriage a woman on the condition of his giving him in marriage another, without dowry [from either]; concubitus with each of the said women being [in lieu of] the dowry for the other: or it applies peculiarly to female relations [of the men so contracting]; (K;) so that the meaning is only he gave him in marriage his female relation on the condition of his doing the like to him: (TA:) or he gave him in marriage a female under his guardianship, the other man doing to him the like, on the condition that concubitus with each one of the said females should be [in lieu of] the dowry for the other: (Mgh, * Msb:) or he gave him in marriage his sister on the condition of receiving in marriage the other's sister, without any dowry beside this: (A:) or he said to him, Give me in marriage thy daughter, or thy sister, on the condition of my giving thee in marriage my daughter, or my sister, concubitus with each one of the said females being [in lieu of] the dowry of the other. (S.) The practice of XigaAr was common in the Time of Ignorance, (Msb,) but is
forbidden to the Muslims. (S, A.) ― -b2- XigaArN also signifies Two men's going forth into the field from two armies, and, when one of them has almost overcome his fellow, two men's coming to aid one of them, whereupon the other cries out, laA XigaAra laA XigaAra: (TA:) or two men's acting wrongfully, or injuriously, towards another man: (K, TA:) thus expl. by ISd. (TA.) And The acting with enmity, or hostility. (TA.)

4 AXgr AlmaroOapa c
4. AXgr AlmaroOapa: see 1. ＝ -A2- AXgrt AlrRufoqapu [and app. AXtgrt↓ also (see the last sentence of this art.)] (assumed tropical:) The party journeying together withdrew by themselves from the beaten road. (K, TA.) ― -b2- See also 8, first sentence. ― -b3- AXgrt said of a she-camel, She went with wide steps, and quickly. (TA.) ― -b4- See, again, 8.

5 tXgRr c
5. tXgRr He (a camel) exerted his utmost power, (K,) or spared no exertion, (A'Obeyd, S,) in his pace: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) or ran vehemently: (K:) or went a pace above that termed AllRabaTapu. (TA.) ― -b2- tXgRr fiI OamorK qabiyHK He (a man, O) persevered in an evil, or a foul, affair, and went deep into it. (O, K. *)

8 AXtgr c
8. AXtgr, (JK, T,) or AXgr↓, (S, K,) It (a watering-place) was on one side of the beaten track: (JK, T, S, K:) [both verbs may be correct: that the former is so appears from the fact that] a poet, cited in the T, [describing a water-ing-place,] uses the phrase baEiydu AluXotagari↓ [app. meaning far off on one side of the road]. (TA.) See also 4. ― -b2- AXtgr AlEadadu The number was, or became, large. (S, K.) ― -b3- AXtgr AlUibilu The camels were, or became, many and various. (K.) ― -b4- AXtgrt Ealayohi DayoEatuhu i. q. faXato, (A,) i. e. His affairs became disordered so that he knew not with which of them to begin. (TA in art. fXw.) ― -b5- AXtgr AlOamoru The affair became confused: (K:) or became large, or wide, and great, bifulaAni [with such a one]. (AZ, TA.) ― -b6- AXtgrt AlHarobu The war, or battle, became wide and great. (TA.) ― -b7- AXtgr Ealayohi HisaAbuhu, (T, S, A,) in the K OaXogara↓, but the former is the right, (TA,) (tropical:) What he had to reckon was, or became, too diffuse and numerous to him; (T, K;) such that he could not find the way to sum it up. (S, A.) ― -b8- cahaba fulaAnN yaEudRu baniI fulaAnK faQXotagaruwA Ealayohi Such a one went to number the sons of such a one, and they were too numerous for him. (TA.) ― -b9- AXtgr fiI AlfalaApi He went far into the desert. (S, K.) ― -b10- AXtgr EalayonaA He exalted himself above us, and boasted against us. (K.)

tafarRaquwA Xagara bagara c
tafarRaquwA Xagara bagara and Xigara bigara They dispersed themselves, or became dispersed, in every direction: (S, K:) and in like manner one says of sheep or goats, biagara tafarRaqati Alganamu Xagara: (TA:) Xgr bgr is a compound of two nouns made into one, and indecl., with fet-h for the termination. (S.) The like is not said in the case of [persons &c.] coming, or advancing. (TA.)

XagoraI c
XagoraI A stone at which dogs raise the kind leg and make water, or to make water: (K:) so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)

XagaArN c
XagaArN Empty. (Sgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also, used as sing. and pl., A well, and wells, having much water: (K:) or, as is said in the Nawádir, thus used, having much water; wide, or spacious, in the adjacent part where the camels lie down. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, accord. to the K, Two veins, or ducts, (EiroqaAni,) in the side of the camel: but correctly, as in the Tekmileh, the XagaAraAni are the HaAlibaAni, i. e. two veins or ducts, (EiroqaAn,) in the two sides of the camel. (TA.)

XaguwrN c
XaguwrN A tall she-camel, that raises her legs (taXogaru biqawaAYimihaA) when she is taken to be ridden (K, TA) or to be milked. (TA.)

XagRaArapN c
XagRaArapN A she-camel that raises her legs to strike [with them, or kick]. (TA.)

XaAgirN c
XaAgirN A dog raising one of his kind legs, and making water, or whether making water or not. (A.) ― -b2- balodapN XaAgirapN birijolihaA (tropical:) A country, or town, that does not defend itself from a hostile attack (S, A, K) made by any one, (S, K,) by reason of its being destitute (K, TA) of any to protect it. (TA.) And OaroDN XaAgirapN (assumed tropical:) A land having no one remaining in it, to defend it, and to manage its affairs with prudence, precaution, or sound judgment. (K.) One says also, AlOaroDu lakumo XaAgirapN, meaning (assumed tropical:) The land, or the earth, is wide, or ample, for you. (TA.)

muXotagarN c
muXotagarN: see 8 [of which it is app. an inf. n.].

rufoqapN muXotagirapN c
rufoqapN muXotagirapN, A party journeying together far from the beaten road. (TA.)

Q. 1 Xagorabahu c
Q. 1. Xagorabahu i. q. Xagozabahu, q. v. (AZ, TA.)

XagorabaI c
XagorabaI (TA) and XagorabiyRapN (K) i. q. XagozabaI and XagozabiyRapN. (K, TA.)

Q. 1 Xagozabahu c
Q. 1. Xagozabahu, inf. n. XagozabapN, He threw him down by the trick called XagozabiyRap, expl. below; (S, K;) and Xagorabahu signifies the same. (AZ, TA.) Accord. to IAth, the primary meaning of XagozabapN is A twisting, in a neuter sense; and artifice. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He took him, or seized him, violently. (K.)

Q. 2 taXagozabati AlrRiyHu c
Q. 2. taXagozabati AlrRiyHu The wind whirled (Ailotawat) in its blowing. (K.)

XagozabaI c
XagozabaI: see XagozabiyRapN.

XagozabiIRN c
XagozabiIRN Difficult; (K;) anything deemed difficult. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- A [watering-place such as is termed] manohal lying out of the way. (K, TA.) ― -b3- AlXRagozabiIRu The jackal; syn. Aibonu MwaI. (IAth, TA.)

XagozabiyRapN c
XagozabiyRapN (S, K) and XagozabaI↓, as also XagorabiyRapN (K) and XagorabaI, but more chastely with z, (TA,) A sort of trick in throwing down [or wrestling]; (S, TA;) the twisting of one's leg with the leg of another, (S, K, TA,) and throwing him down (K, TA) in the manner termed XazorFA [or sideways]: (TA:) and one says also, Oaxacahu biAlXRagozabiyRapi, (S, TA, [in one of my copies of the S biAlXRagozabapi,]) meaning the same: (TA:) and SaraEahu SaroEapF XagozabiyRapF: (AZ, TA:) [the pl. is XagaAzibu:] Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
walabRasa bayona OaqowaAmK fakulRN
OaEadRa lahu AlXRagaAziba waAlmiHaAla
[And he involved affairs in confusion between parties, so all prepared for him tricks by which to overthrow him, and artifice] (S, TA.)

HatRaI yakuwna XugozubRFA c
HatRaI yakuwna XugozubRFA occurs in the “ Sunan ” of Aboo-Dáwood, in the chapter on the Eaqiyqap and Eatiyrap; but it is thought by El-Harbee that the last word is for zuxozubRFA, meaning Firm in flesh, and thick, big, or bulky. (L, TA.)

1 Xagafahu c
1. Xagafahu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Xagafa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XagofN, (Msb,) He, or it, struck, or smote, his XagaAf; (O, K;) like kabadahu meaning “ he, or it, struck, or smote, his kabid ” [or “ liver ”]; (O, TA;) so says Yoo: (TA:) or it (i. e. love) rent the XagaAf of his heart: (Fr, TA:) or it (love) reached his XagaAf: (ISk, S, TA:) or Xagafa qalobahu it (love) reached the XagaAf of his heart, i. e. his pericardium. (Msb.) I'Ab read, [in the Kur xii. 30,] qado XagafahaA HubRFA, and expl. the meaning to be [He has affected her so that] the love of him has entered beneath the XagaAf: (S, TA:) or the meaning is, the love of him has struck, or smitten, her XagaAf: (Lth, O, TA:) or he has rent the XagaAf of her heart, i. e. its HijaAb, [app. meaning her midriff,] so as to reach her heart, with love: (Bd:) Abu-l-Ash-hab read qado XagifahaA HubRFA, with kesr to the g, [meaning he has became attached to her, or has loved her,] like the reading of Thábit El-Bunyánee, XaEifahaA, with kesr to the unpointed C: (O, TA:) [for] Xagifahu, aor.
Xagafa
, [inf. n. app. XagafN,] signifies he became attached to him, or loved him. (K, TA.) One says also, Xagafahu AlmaAlu, meaning The property became embellished to him, [or pleasing to him,] so that he loved it. (Msb.) And Xugifa biAlXRaIoCi, like EuniIa, He was, or became, vehemently desirous of the thing; or fond of it. (TA.) And Xagifa biAlXRaIoCi, like fariHa, He became disquieted, or disturbed, by the thing. (TA.)

entry.key: maA hecihi AlfutoyaA AlRatiI taXagRafati AlnRaAsa

superEntry.entry:
5 maA hecihi AlfutoyaA AlRatiI taXagRafati AlnRaAsa c
5. maA hecihi AlfutoyaA AlRatiI taXagRafati AlnRaAsa, a saying of I'Ab, means [What is this judicial sentence] that has put vain suggestions into the minds of the people, and separated them? as though it entered the XagaAf of their hearts. (TA.) [See also 1 in arts. XEb and Xgb.]

XagofN c
XagofN: see XagaAfN in two places.

XagafN c
XagafN [app. inf. n. of Xagifa: and accord. to Fei, app., Love reaching to the pericardium; or heartfelt love; see an ex. in a verse cited voce balo; and see also HubRN, and XaEafN;] a subst. from Xagafa qalobahu, said of love. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also XagaAfN, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also The bark (najab, AHn, O, or qiXor, K) of the kind of tree called gAf. (AHn, O, K. *)

XagaAfN c
XagaAfN The pericardium; i. e. the gilaAf, (S, O, K,) or giXaMC, (Msb,) of the heart: (S, O, Msb, K:) or [app. a mistake for “ and, ” as will be shown by what follows,] its HijaAb [generally meaning the midriff], (K,) [here said to be,] accord. to AHeyth, a certain fat that clothes the heart: (TA:) [J seems to confound the gilaAf of the heart with its HijaAb; for after “ the galAf of the heart, ” he adds, “ and it is a skin beneath it (duwnahu), like the HijaAb: ”] or the HabRap (K) or the suwayodaMC [both generally meaning the core] thereof: (O, K:) or the place of entrance (mawolj) of the phlegm: (Lth, O, K:) and XagofN↓ and XagafN↓ signify the same in the two senses, (K,) or in the first and second senses: (TA:) or Alqalob Xagofu↓ and Xagafuhu↓ signify the same as XagaAfuhu, accord. to AHeyth: (O:) the pl. of the XagaAf of the heart is XugufN; which is metaphorically applied in a saying of 'Alee to the place of the fœtus [in the belly]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (A'Obeyd, S, O, K,) and XugaAfN↓, (K,) the latter agreeable with analogy as the name of a disease, (TA,) A certain disease that attacks one, beneath the XaraAsiyf [pl. of XurosuwfN, q. v.], in the right side: (A'Obeyd, S, O, K:) and (some say, TA) a pain of the belly: (K, TA: [in the CK, AlbaZor is erroneously put for AlbaTon:]) and (some say, TA) a pain of the XagaAf of the heart: (K, TA:) accord. to As, XagaAfN signifies a certain disease in the heart, which, if it reaches to the spleen, kills the patient. (TA.)

XugaAfN c
XugaAfN: see the next preceding paragraph.

maXoguwfN c
maXoguwfN Insane, or mad; (O, K;) like maXoEuwfN. (O.) And maXoguwfN bimaAlK One to whom property is embellished [or rendered pleasing,] so that he loves it. (Msb.)

1 Xagalahu c
1. Xagalahu, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor.
Xagala
, (O, K, MS,) inf. n. XagolN (Msb, K) and XugolN, (K,) the latter on the authority of Sb, (TA,) He, or it, (a man, S, or an affair, Msb,) busied him, occupied him, or employed him; (K;) i. q. OalohaAhu [signifying as above; and particularly he, or it, busied him, &c., so as to divert him from (Eano) something; or diverted him from a thing by busying him, &c.]: (S and Msb and K in art. lhw, and Bd and Jel in xv. 3, &c.:) [XgRlhu↓ signifies he, or it, busied him, &c., much; i. e.] with teshdeed it denotes muchness: (Bd in xlviii. 11:) AXglhu↓ is a good dial. var. of Xagalahu; or is rare; or bad: (K:) accord. to IDrd [and J], (O,) one should not say OaXogalotuhu; (S, O;) for it is bad: (S:) accord. to IF, they scarcely ever say OaXogalotu, [thus in the O, but in the Msb AiXotagala↓,] but it is allowable: (O:) none of the leading lexicologists is known to have pronounced it good. (TA.) [Hence the saying, Xagalato saEaAtiI jadowaAIa (see art. sEw and sEI), or, as some relate it, Xglt XiEaAbiI jdwAI (see art. XEb).] See another ex. voce XaAgilN. One says also Xugila bihi, (Msb, K,) meaning talahRaI [i. e. He was, or became, busied, &c., by it], (Msb,) and bh AXtgl↓ [meaning the same]; (Az, Msb, K;) and Xugilotu Eanoka bikacaA [I was, or became, busied, &c., so as to be diverted from thee, by such a thing], (S, O,) and AiXotagalotu↓ [in the same sense]: (S:) and Eanohu tXAgl↓, (TA,) which likewise signifies talahRaI [meaning as expl. above, or he busied himself, &c., so as to divert himself from him, or it]: (TA in art. lhw, and Bd and Jel in lxxx. 10:) some disallow AiXotagala↓, in the form of an active verb, but say AuXotugila, in the form of a pass. verb; but it is originally quasi-pass of OaXogalotuhu, like as are AiHotaraqa and Aikotahala of OaHoraqotuhu and Oakohalotuhu; [though why of OaXogalotuhu rather than of Xagalotuhu, I do not see:] Az mentions the usage of its act. and pass. part. ns.: (Msb:) accord. to AHát and IDrd, one should not say AiXotagala↓; but IF mentions, as transmitted from the Arabs, AuXotugila fulaAnN biAlXRaIoCi, and the pass. part. n. (O.) ― -b2- One says also, naHonu naXogalu Eanoka AlmarotaEa (assumed tropical:) [We occupy the place of pasturage so as to keep it from thee], and AlmaMCa [the water]; meaning, it is sufficient for us without being more than sufficient. (S in art. Xfh.) And Xugila Eanoka maA EinodanaA (assumed tropical:) [What we had was employed so as to be kept from thee]. (JK in that art.)

2 XagRala
2: see the preceding paragraph.

4 AXglhu c
4. AXglhu: see 1. ― -b2- maA OaXogalahu [meaning How much is he busied! &c.], (Th, S, K,) denoting wonder, (Th, TA,) is anomalous, because one does not [regularly] form a verb of wonder from one in the form of a pass. verb. (Th, S, K.)

6 tXAgl Eanohu c
6. tXAgl Eanohu: see 1. [Accord. to Golius, tXAglwA signifies They occupied one another, on the authority of the KL; in which, however, I find only taXaAgulN expl. as meaning xwdrA bJyzI mXgwl krdn i. e. To make oneself busied, &c., with a thing.]

8 UiXotagala
8: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- One says also, AiXotagala fiyhi AlsRamRu The poison crept into him, or pervaded him; syn. saraI: and AXtgl fiyhi AldRawaMCu The medicine entered into him, and produced an effect upon him, or showed its effect upon him; syn. najaEa. (TA.)

XagolN c
XagolN an inf. n. of 1. (K, Msb.) See the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- And see also XagolapN.

XugolN c
XugolN and XagolN↓ and XugulN↓ (S, O, Msb, K) and XagalN↓ (S, O, K;) Business, occupation, or employment; (PS;) contr. of faraAgN: (K:) [and particularly business, &c., that diverts one from a thing:] or an occurrence that causes a man to forget, or neglect, or be unmindful: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXogaAlN (S, O, K) and [of mult.] XuguwlN: (K:) XugolN is mentioned by Sb as an instance of an inf. n. having a pl., namely, OaXogaAlN; like EaqolN and maraDN. (TA in art. mrD.) [See also OuXoguwlapN.]

XagalN c
XagalN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XagilN c
XagilN Busy, or busied, occupied, or employed: (K:) [and particularly busy, &c., so as to be diverted from a thing:] thought by ISd to be a possessive epithet [meaning cuw XugolK], because it has no verb to which it is conformable: (TA:) it is an epithet applied to a man, from AlXRagolu [or AlXRugolu]: (IAar, in O:) and maXoguwlN↓ signifies the same; (Msb, TA;) and muXotagilN↓ (Az, Msb, K) and muXotagalN↓, (Az, IF, O, Msb, K,) the latter [said to be] extr. [meaning anomalous, for AuXotugila is not mentioned by F]. (K.)

XugulN c
XugulN: see XugolN.

XagolapN c
XagolapN Reaped grain or wheat, collected together, in the place where it is trodden out; syn. bayodarN and kudosN (IAar, O, K) and EaramapN; (IAar, O;) as also XagalapN↓: (IAth, TA:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of the former XagolN↓, (O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, XugalN,]) like as tamorN is of tamorapN. (O, TA.)

XagalapN c
XagalapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XagRaAlN c
XagRaAlN signifies kaviyru AlXRugoli [i. e. Having much business or occupation or employment; or who busies or occupies or employs himself much]. (TA.)

XaAgilN c
XaAgilN act. part. n. of Xagalahu; [Busying, occupying, or employing; &c.;] (S, Msb;) applied to a man, (S,) or to an affair. (Msb.) [Hence,] one says, Eanoka AlXRawaAgilu XagalatoniI↓ [Busying affairs busied me, or have busied me, so as to divert me from thee]: the last word being pl. of XaAgilN. (TA.) XugolN XaAgilN [lit. Busying business, or the like,] has an intensive meaning: (K:) the latter word in this case is a corroborative, as in layolN laAYilN. (S.)

OaXogalu c
OaXogalu [More, and most, busy &c.]. OaXogalu mino caAti AlnRiHoyayoni [More busy than she who was the owner of the two skins of butter] is a prov. [mentioned in the TA]: she was a woman of [the tribe of] Teym-Allah: she used to sell clarified butter, in the Time of Ignorance; and Khowwát Ibn-Jubeyr El-Ansáree came to her, demanding to buy clarified butter of her, and saw no one with her, and he bargained with her: so she untied a skin, and he looked at it: then he said to her, “ Hold thou it until I look at another: ” and she said, “ Untie thou another skin: ” and he did so, and looked at it, and said, “ I desire other than this; therefore hold thou it: ” and she did so: and when her hands were [thus] occupied, he assaulted her, and she was unable to repel the him. (Meyd.)

OuXoguwlapN c
OuXoguwlapN an instance of the measure OufoEuwlapN from AlXRugolu [similar to OulohuwRapN and OulohiyRapN, and to OuloEuwbapN, &c.; app. meaning A thing with which one is busied, &c.: and also syn. with XugolN]. (O, K.)

maXogalapN c
maXogalapN A thing that causes one to be busied, &c.: (K, * TA:) pl. maXaAgilu. (TA.)

maXoguwlN c
maXoguwlN: see XagilN. ― -b2- [Hence,] fulaAnN faArigN maXoguwlN Such a one is devoted to that which is unprofitable. (TA.) ― -b3- And jaAriyapN maXoguwlapN A young woman having a husband. (TA.) ― -b4- And maAlN maXoguwlN Property devoted to commerce. (TA.) ― -b5- And daArN maXoguwlapN A house in which are inhabitants. (TA.)

muXotagilN c
muXotagilN and muXotagalN: see XagilN.

1 XagiIa c
1. XagiIa, aor.
1a2a2a
, inf. n. XagFA, [signifies accord. to some] He (a man) had a tooth, or teeth, exceeding the other teeth: and [accord. to others, agreeably with what is said to be the right meaning of XaAgiyap below,] he had a tooth, or teeth, differing in the manner of growth from the other teeth. (S.) [And] Xagiyati AlsRinRu, aor.
1a2a2a
; (Msb, K;) and Xagat, aor.
1a2u2a
; (K;) inf. n. (of the former, Msb, TA) XagFA (Msb, K, TA) and [of the latter] XuguwRN, (K, TA, [in the CK Xagow, but]) like EuluwRN; (TA;) [accord. to some] The tooth exceeded the other teeth: (Msb:) and [accord. to others] (Msb) the tooth differed from the other teeth (Msb, K, TA) in an absolute sense, (TA,) or in respect of its place of growth, (Msb,) or in its manner of growth, in length, and shortness, and receding, and projecting: (K, TA:) or, accord. to the A, XagFA signifies the differing in respect of the manner of growth and of collocation: or the upper teeth's not falling upon the lower: (TA:) or, as IF says, the advancing of the upper teeth beyond the lower. (Msb.) The epithet applied to a man is OaXogaI↓; and to a woman, XagowaMCu; and the pl. is XugowN: (S, Msb:) [and] the epithet applied to a tooth is XagowaMCu and XagiyaMCu; (K;) or XaAgiyapN↓; (S, Msb;) which last is said by Az to have two meanings; one whereof is exceeding [the other teeth]; and the other, being longer and larger, and differing in respect of the place [or more probably the manner] of its growth from those next to it: (Msb:) or, accord. to a marginal note in the S, in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà, this signifies differing in the manner of its growth from the manner of growth of the others, whether exceeding or not exceeding: or, accord. to a marginal note in the copy of Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee, crooked; not exceeding. (TA.)

2 taXogiyapN c
2. taXogiyapN signifies The dribbling of the urine, (Lth, K, TA,) little by little. (Lth, TA.) One says of a man, XagRaI, (TK,) and bibawolihi AXgI↓, (IAth, TA,) He dribbled his urine, (IAth, TA, TK,) little by little. (IAth, TA.)

4 OaXogawoA bihi c
4. OaXogawoA bihi (assumed tropical:) They disagreed with, differed from, or opposed, the people, in respect of his affair, or case: (K:) as though taken from XagaA AlOasonaAni. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2.

XagFA c
XagFA inf. n. of XagiIa said of a man, (S,) or of Xagiyat said of a tooth. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also a subst. signifying A dribbling of the urine; and so XagoyapN↓. (K.)

OumRu Xagowap c
OumRu Xagowap: see XagowaMCu, voce OaXogaI.

XagoyapN c
XagoyapN: see XagFA.

XaAgiyap c
XaAgiyap: see 1, last sentence.

OaXogaI c
OaXogaI; fem. XagowaMCu and XagoyaMCu; and pl. XugowN: see 1, last sentence. ― -b2- XagowaMCu also signifies An eagle; (S, Msb, K;) because its upper mandible exceeds the lower: (S, Msb:) and so OumRu Xagowap↓. (T in art. Am.)

muXotagK c
muXotagK One who separates himself from every yoke-fellow, or familiar: ― -b2- and one whose age (sinRuhu) is deficient: ― -b3- in both of these senses expl. as an epithet applied by Ru-beh to a rubaAEiIR [or boy four spans in height]. (TA.)

1 XafRa c
1. XafRa, aor.
Xafifa
, inf. n. XufuwfN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and XafiyfN (S, O, K) and XafafN, (CK, [but not in my MS. copy of the K nor in the TA,]) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was thin, fine, or delicate, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) so that what was behind it was visible, (S, * IB, Mgh, [for xalaqahu in some copies of the S, and xalofahu in others, I read maA xalofahu, which is the right reading accord. to IB and the TA, agreeably with the reading in the Mgh, which is maA waraMCahu,]) or so as to tell what was beneath it: (O, K:) [and it, (a gem, or the like,) was translucent: or was transparent. (See XafRaAfN.)] One says, XafRa Ealayohi vawobuhu His garment was thin, &c., upon him. (S.) ― -b2- ― -b3- And XafRa jisomuhu, aor.
Xafifa
, inf. n. XufuwfN, His body became lean, or emaciated. (S, O, K.) ＝ -A2- XafRa, aor.
Xafifa
, inf. n. XifRN, It (a thing, O, Msb) exceeded; or was, or became, redundant. (S, O, Msb, K.) Hence, in a trad., XafRa naHowFA mino daAniqK It exceeded by about a dAnq. (Sh, O.) And one says, XafRa Ealayoh, aor. yaXufRu, [so in the L and TA, contr. to rule, probably a mistranscription for yaXifRu,] inf. n. XufuwfN; and XfRf↓, and AstXfR↓; [app. meaning, as seems to be indicated by the context, It exceeded it:] and Xafifotu fiI AlsRiloEapi [app. a mistranscription for Xafafotu] I gained in, or upon, the the article of merchandise: (TA: [and so, app., XafRafotu↓: see XafRaI:]) and fI tijaAratihi AstXfR↓ [He obtained what is termed XifRN in his traffic; i. e.] he made gain, or profit, in his traffic; syn. rabiHa. (S and K in art. rbH.) ― -b2- And sometimes (Msb) it signifies also the contr.; i. e. It fell short; or was, or became, deficient. (Msb, K.) One says, (O, Msb,) of a dirhem, (O,) hecaA yaXifRu qaliylFA This falls short, or is deficient, a little. (O, Msb.) And XafRa Eanohu AlvRawobu, aor.
Xafifa
, The garment was too short for him. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also XafRa, (O, K,) aor.
Xafifa
, (O,) It (a thing, O) was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, or agitation. (O, K.) ＝ -A4- And XafRa laka AlXRaIoCu i. q. daAma and vabata [app. meaning The thing belonged, or pertained, to thee permanently, or constantly; or may the thing belong, &c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A5- XafRahu, (S, M, O, K,) aor.
Xafufa
, inf. n. XafRN (S, M, TA) and XufuwfN, (M, TA,) It (anxiety) rendered him lean, or emaciated; (S, O, K;) as also XafoXafahu↓; (S;) both are also expl. as meaning it rendered him lean, or lank in the belly, so that he became slender: (TA:) or, accord. to the M, it (grief, and love,) pained his heart: or rendered him lean, or emaciated: or deprived him of his reason: and it is said of grief as meaning it manifested what he felt of impatience. (TA.) And XafRa AlnRufuwsa, as used in a verse of Towbeh Ibn-El- Homeiyir, It hurt and melted the souls. (Ham p. 594.) ＝ -A6- See also 8, in two places.

2 XafRaRa
2: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

4 OaXofafotuhumo c
4. OaXofafotuhumo I preferred them, or judged them to excel. (K.) You say, OaXofafotu baEoDa waladiI EalaI baEoDK I preferred some of my children above some. (S. [And the like is said in the Mgh.]) And OaXofafotu hecaA EalaI hecaA I preferred this above this. (Msb.) ― -b2- And AXfR fulaAnN AldRirohama Such a one made the dirhem to exceed: or, made it to fall short. (TA.) ＝ -A2- OaXafRa Ealayohi [if not a mistranscription for OuXifRa, which I rather think it to be,] He excelled him, or surpassed him. (TA.) ＝ -A3- OaXafRa Alfamu The mouth had in it a fetid odour. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)

6 taXaAfafotuhu c
6. taXaAfafotuhu I took away his or its, XifR, i. e. excess, or redundance. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in three places.

8 AXtfR maA fiI AlUinaMCi c
8. AXtfR maA fiI AlUinaMCi (S, O, K) kulRahu (K) He drank what was in the vessel, all of it, (S, O, K,) even the XufaAfap [or last drop or remains], (O,) not leaving any of it remaining; (S;) [and so AijotafRa;] as also tXAfR↓: (S, O, K:) and AstXfR↓ AlmaMCa He drank the water to the uttermost, not leaving any of it remaining; as also XafRahu↓, aor.
Xafufa
, inf. n. XafRN: and AlmaMCa Xafafotu↓ I drank much of the water without having my thirst satisfied. (TA.) [Hence,] in the trad. of Umm-Zara, waUino Xariba QXotafRa [And if he drank, he drank up all that was in the vessel]. (S, O.) And it is said in a prov., layosa AlrRiIRu Eani AltRaXaAfRi↓ (S, O, TA) i. e. The satisfying of thirst is not from the drinking up all that is in the vessel; for it is sometimes effected by less than this: (O, TA:) it is applied in forbidding one's going to the utmost in an affair, and persevering therein. (S, * O, TA.) Accord. to IAar, one says also taXaAfayotu AlmaMCa I exhausted the water; which, ISd says, is originally taXaAfaftu↓. (TA.) ― -b2- 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Sebreh El-Harashee uses the first of these verbs metaphorically in relation to death; saying,
saAqayotuhu Almawota HatRaI QXotafRa Mxirahu
meaning (tropical:) [I vied with him in giving the draught of death] until he drank the last of it, i. e., the last of death. (TA.) ― -b3- And AXtfR AlbaEiyru AlHizaAma kulRahu means The camel filled, and took up wholly, the girth, (O, K, TA,) so that nothing remained of it redundant, by reason of the largeness of the middle of his body. (TA.)

10 AstXfRhu c
10. AstXfRhu, (O, K,) or AstXfR maA waraMCahu, (S, Msb,) He saw what was behind it. (O, Msb, K.) [Thus the former signifies He saw through it: and it is used in this sense both properly and tropically.] ― -b2- Hence the saying to the seller of cloths, AisotaXifRa hecaA AlvRawoba, [which may be rendered Look thou through this garment, or piece of cloth; but is expl. as] meaning make thou this garment, or piece of cloth, single, [by unfolding it,] and raise it, or hold it up, in shade, in order that I may see whether it be close in texture or flimsy. (TA.) ― -b3- AstXfR also signifies [agreeably with the explanation of AstXfR maA waraMCahu mentioned above] (assumed tropical:) He distinguished a thing plainly, like as one distinguishes plainly a thing behind glass. (Har p. 244.) ― -b4- And one says, katabotu kitaAbFA faQsotaXafRahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) [I wrote a letter, or writing, &c., and] he examined attentively what was in it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 8. ＝ -A3- And see 1, in two places. ＝ -A4- [Freytag mentions as a signification of AstXfR “ Desiderio alicujus rei implevit; ” with AlI before the object: but he names no authority for this; and I doubt its correctness.]

R. Q. 1 XafoXafahu c
R. Q. 1. XafoXafahu: see 1, latter part. ― -b2- Also, accord. to IAar, (O, TA,) inf. n. XafoXafapN, (K, TA,) It (heat, and cold,) dried it up; namely, a thing, (O, K, TA,) such as herbage, (O, TA,) &c. (TA.) And accord. to AA, AlXRafoXafapu signifies The hoar-frost's burning [meaning blasting] the herbage of the earth: or the burning of a medicament that is sprinkled upon a wound: (O:) or it has the former of these two meanings, and signifies also the sprinkling of a medicament upon a wound. (K. [But I think that, for wacarRu AldRawaMCi in the K, we should read wacarRi AldRawaMCi, and thus reconcile the K in this case with the O: see, however, what next follows; which may be regarded either as confirming the reading in the K, or as having misled its author, in this instance.]) ＝ -A2- AlXRafoXafapu signifies also The sprinkling of urine and the like. (K.) You say, XafoXafa bibawolihi He sprinkled his urine. (O.) ＝ -A3- Also The trembling, and the being confused (AlAixotilaATu), (O, K, TA,) resulting from intense jealousy. (TA. [See muXafoXafN.]) ― -b2- And XafoXafa Ealayohi He was solicitously affectionate, or pitiful or compassionate, towards him, (TA.) [See, again, muXafoXafN.])

R. Q. 2 taXafoXafa c
R. Q. 2. taXafoXafa, said of herbage, It began to dry up. (TA.)

XafRN c
XafRN A thin, fine, or delicate, garment or piece of cloth; (AZ, S, Mgh, O, * Msb, K; *) as also XifRN↓ (AZ, S, O, Msb, K) and XafiyfN↓: (Msb:) you say vawobN XafRN (S, Mgh, Msb) and XifRN↓ (S, Msb) and XafiyfN↓. (Msb:) [see also XafRaAfN:] and the garment, or piece of cloth, itself, is termed XafRN and XifRN↓: (Har p. 70:) [i. e. each of these words is also used as a subst.; and this is perhaps meant in the O and K: or] XafRN signifies also a certain thin, fine, or delicate, veil or covering: or, accord. to Aboo-Nasr, a certain thin, fine, or delicate, veil or covering, of wool, through which one sees what is behind it: (S:) pl. XufuwfN. (O, Msb, K.) Among the verses of “ the Book ” [of Sb, cited as exs. therein], is the following:
lalobosu EabaMCapK wataqarRu EayoniI
OaHabRu UilaIRa mino lubosi AlXRufuwfi
[Verily the wearing of a woollen cloak, my eye being therewithal unheated by tears, is more pleasing to me than the wearing of thin, fine, or delicate, garments]. (O.) ＝ -A2- See also XifRN. ＝ -A3- XfR [app. XafRN] also signifies Pimples, or small pustules, that come forth and then go away. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)

XifRN c
XifRN: see XafRN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, Mgh, O, K,) and XafRN↓, (L, K,) but the former is that which is well known, (L, TA,) and XafiyfN↓, (TA,) Gain, or profit; increase obtained in traffic: and excess, surplus, or redundance: syn. riboHN [q. v.]: and faDolN; (S, Mgh, O, K;) and ziyaAdapN. (Mgh, TA.) Hence (Mgh) nahaI Eano XifRi maA lam yuDomano, meaning [He (the Prophet, TA) forbade] the riboH [i. e. gain, or profit, of that for which one has not made himself responsible to the purchaser]. (O, Mgh.) And one says, lihecaA EalaI hecaA XifRq [There is, or pertains, to this, an excess above this]. (Ksh in ii. 15.) And qaAla qawolFA XifRFA He said a saying that was a redundance. (TA.) ― -b2- And A deficiency: thus having two contr. meanings. (ISk and S and O in explanation of the first word, K in explanation of the first and second words, and TA in explanation of all.) ― -b3- Also, the first word, i. q. mahonaON: one says to a person when regarding him with a wish for the like of a thing that he has attained, or that he possesses, without desiring that it should pass away from him, XifRN laka yaA fulaAnu [May it be an unalloyed gratification to thee, O such a one]. (TA.) ― -b4- And A thing that is little, or small, in quantity; mean, or paltry. (TA.) [See also XafiyfN, last signification.]

XafafN c
XafafN: see XafiyfN, last signification. ＝ -A2- Also i. q. xifRapN [Lightness, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And sometimes it signifies Evilness, or narrowness of the circumstances, (riqRap,) of one's state, or condition. (TA.)

XufaAfN c
XufaAfN: see XufaAfapN.

XafiyfN c
XafiyfN: see XafRN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see XifRN. ＝ -A3- Also Cold, as a subst.; (ISk, S, O, Msb;) thus in the saying, wajada fiI OasonaAnihi XafiyfFA [He felt, or experienced, in his teeth, cold]; (S, O;) and so XafRaAnN↓: (ISk, Msb:) or, as some say, (O,) the hurting, or paining, (lacoE, [in the CK ladog,] of cold: (S, O, K:) and intense cold, with rain and wind; and XifaAfN is its pl.: (TA:) or intense cold [alone]: (Msb:) or a cold wind in which is moisture: (O:) and XafRaAnN↓ signifies the cold of a wind in which is moisture: (S:) or XafiyfN has this last signification; and XafRaAnN↓, the signification next preceding it: one says, lahaA OalojaOahu XafRaAnN↓ XafiyfN A cold and moist wind, having [much] cold and moisture, made him to betake himself to a covert: (IDrd, IF, Msb:) or XafiyfN signifies rain and hail: (O:) or so XafRaAnN↓; [or rain and cold: for brd is written in my original without any syll. sign;] wherefore some of the lawyers say that it is rain and more: (Msb:) or XafiyfN signifies also rain in which is hail: (K, TA:) or rain in which is cold: (CK:) or a cold wind; (K;) as also XafoXaAfN↓: (O, K:) or this last signifies a wind of mild cold: (S, TA:) and XafRaAnN↓, cold and wind: (O, K:) one says, gadaApN caAtu XafRaAnK a morning having cold and wind (S, * O, K) with moisture. (S.) ― -b2- And Intense heat (IDrd, EsSarakustee, O, Msb, K) of the sun: (IDrd, O, K:) thus having two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b3- And Pain in the stomach. (Aboo-Sa'eed, O.) ＝ -A4- [Also Affected with pain: or with hurt, or grief. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)] ＝ -A5- Also Small, or little, in number, quantity, or amount; and so XafafN↓. (O, K.) [See also XifRN, last signification.]

XufaAfapN c
XufaAfapN A portion of water remaining in a vessel; (S, O, K;) and likewise, of milk: (TA:) or the last drop remaining in a vessel: (Ham p. 239:) IAth says that some of the later writers mention it as being with s. (TA.) Dhu-rRummeh uses the phrase AlXRafaA XufaAfa↓, in a verse, as meaning In the remaining portion of the day. (O.)

XafRaAfN c
XafRaAfN Extremely [or very] thin or fine or delicate, so that a thing behind it is visible: (KL:) [translucent:] transparent: applied to a gem, or the like; and to a garment, or piece of cloth. (TA.) [See also XafRN.]

XafRaAnN c
XafRaAnN: see XafiyfN, in six places.

XafoXaAfN c
XafoXaAfN A garment, or piece of cloth, not well or strongly or compactly [woven or] made. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- See also XafiyfN.

XafaAXifu c
XafaAXifu Vehement thirst. (O, K.)

OaXafRu c
OaXafRu [a noun denoting excess]. It is said in a trad. of Ráfi', fakaAna AlxaloxaAlu OaXafRa minohaA qaliylFA, meaning [And the anklet, or pair of anklets, was] more than they [in value or weight]; (syn. OafoDal and Oazoyad;) i. e. more [in value or weight] than the dirhems. (Mgh.) And one says, fulaAnN OaXafRu mino fulaAnK, meaning Such a one is a little greater, or older, (Oakobaru qaliylFA,) than such a one. (TA.)

maXofuwfN c
maXofuwfN is said by Ibn-Buzurj to be like majofuwfN
[part. n. of jafRahu; i. e. Collected; or collected together and taken away]. (TA.)

muXafoXafN c
muXafoXafN (O, K) and muXafoXifN↓, (K,) the latter on the authority of IAar, (TA,) Slender, shallow, or weak, in intellect, and evil in disposition. (O, K.) And [both words agreeably with different explanations of the verb] One in whom is, (K,) or, accord. to Saad, one who is as though there were in him, (O,) a trembling, and confusion, (O, K,) resulting from jealousy, (K,) or from vehement jealousy, (O,) and solicitous affection, or pity or compassion, for his Huram [or wives, or women under covert, and household, (in the CK his Haram,)] as though jealousy wasted his heart, and made him lank and lean: or evil in disposition, and very jealous: and ↓the latter word, solicitously affectionate; or pitying, or compassionating. (TA.)

muXafoXifN c
muXafoXifN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

1 XafVra
1: The primary signification of [the inf. n.] Xfr [i. e. XaforN, of which the verb is app. Xafara,] is The act of cutting, or cutting off; syn. qaToEN. (Ham p. 57.) ＝ -A2- XafarahaA, (K,) inf. n. XaforN, (TA,) He struck her (a woman's) Xufor (K, TA) in compressing her. (TA.) ― -b2- And Xafara [or app. Xafara UinosaAnFA] He annoyed, molested, harmed, or hurt, a man. (IAar, O, TA.) ＝ -A3- Xafirato, aor.
Xafara
, inf. n. XafaArapN, She (a woman) was one whose gratification of her venereal lust (XahowatuhaA) soon took place: (K:) or she emitted; [or, app., emitted soon;] syn. Oanozalato. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And Xafira, aor.
Xafara
, It decreased, diminished, or became defective or deficient. (IAar, K.)

2 XfRrhA c
2. XfRrhA, (K,) inf. n. taXofiyrN, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K,) He compressed her (i. e. a woman, Ibn-'Abbád, O) on the Xufor of her faroj. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And XafRarotu AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. as above, I eradicated, or extirpated, the thing. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XfRr AlmaAlu, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) The property became little: (O, K:) and went away: (K:) from IAar. (TA.) ― -b2- And XfRr said of a man, He gave little. (Ham p. 242.) ― -b3- And XfRrt AlXRamosu (O, K) liloguruwbi (O) (assumed tropical:) The sun became near to setting; (O, K;) being likened to a man whose property has become little, and gone away. (TA.) ― -b4- And in like manner, (TA,) XfRr EalaI OamorK (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K) and liOamorK, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, on the brink, or verge, of the affair, or event, or case. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

4 AXfr c
4. AXfr is said in the Tekmileh to signify He (a camel) strove, or exerted himself, in running: but perhaps it should be AXgr, mentioned before [in art. Xgr]. (TA.)

XaforN c
XaforN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

XuforN c
XuforN The place of growth of the eyelash, (Sh, T, S, A, Msb, K,) which is the edge of the eyelid; (S, Msb;) as also XaforN↓ (Kr, A, K) and XafiyrN↓: (K:) or, accord. to some, this last signifies the upper side of the inner angle of the eye: (TA:) and with the vulgar, the first signifies the eyelash; but this is [said to be] a mistake: (IKt, Msb:) it occurs, however, in this sense, in a trad. of Esh-Shaabee; (IAth, TA;) and in like manner the pl. occurs in another trad.; but the word XaEar should be considered as understood before it; or what grows is thus called by the name of the places of growth, and the like of this is not rare: (Mgh:) it is of the masc. gender: (Lh, K:) and the pl. is OaXofaArN, (Sb, S, Mgh, Msb,) the only pl. form. (Sb, TA.) [Hence,] one says, maA biAldRaAri XaforN↓, (Ks, Fr, T, S, Msb, K,) and XuforN, (Lh, Msb, K,) but Sh disallows this latter, (TA,) and XaforapN↓, (Fr, Sgh, K,) (tropical:) There is not in the house any one: (S, Msb, K, &c.:) and maA raOayotu minohumo XaforFA↓ (tropical:) I saw not of them any one: from the Xfr of the eye: meaning one having a Xfr: (A:) and Xfr is also used in this sense without a negation. (TA.) One says likewise, maA tarakati AlsRanapu
ZuforFA walaA XuforFA (tropical:) The year of drought left not anything: and sometimes they said XaforFA↓, with fet-h, and in this case they said ZaforFA, for assimilation. (A.) ― -b2- Also, (S A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and XafiyrN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) The edge, border, margin, brink, brow, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or side, (A, K,) of anything; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as of a valley and the like, (S,) or as of a river &c.: (Mgh and Msb, in relation to the latter word:) one says, AlnRahori qaEaduwA EalaI Xafiyri↓, and AlbiYori, and Alqabori, They sat upon the side of the river, and of the well, and of the grave: (A:) and both words signify the side of the upper part of a valley. (K.) ― -b3- And AlXRuforu, (K,) or Xuforu Alfaroji, (Msb,) and Xuforu AlmaroOapi, (TA,) The edge, (Msb, K,) or border, (TA,) of the vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation, [meaning, of each of the labia majora,] of a woman: (Msb, K, TA:) pl. OaXofaArN: (Msb:) the UisokataAni are the two sides [or labia majora] of the vulva of a woman; and the XuforaAni are the two borders of the said AsktAn: (AHeyth, Mgh, TA:) Lth says that the XaAfiraAni↓ are [two parts] of the pudendum muliebre: (TA:) and Xuforu AlrRaHimi and XaAfiruhaA↓ signify [in like manner] the edges of the vulva: (S:) and XuforaA AlmaroOapi and XaAfiraAhaA↓, the two edges of the raHim [or vulva (for AlrRaHim is here used tropically, for Alfaroj, as it is in many other instances,)] of a woman. (TA.)

XiforN c
XiforN: see XaforapN, first sentence.

XafarN c
XafarN: see safanN, first sentence.

XafirN c
XafirN [an epithet of which the fem. only is mentioned]. XafirapN and XafiyrapN↓ signify A woman who experiences the gratification of her venereal lust (XahowatahaA) in her Xufor; so that she emits (tunozilu) speedily: or [in the CK “ and ”] who is content with the least of coitus: (K, TA:) contr. of qaEirapN and qaEiyrapN. (TA.)

XaforapN c
XaforapN A large knife; (S, A, K;) as also XiforapN↓, though this is mentioned only by the author of the Mgh; (MF; [but it is not in my copy of the Mgh; and Golius mentions XuforapN↓ as having this signification, on the authority of Meyd;]) or a broad knife: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. XifaArN (Msb, K) and XafaraAtN (Msb) and [coll. gen. n., of which XiforapN is the n. un., or it may be a quasi-pl. n. of XaforapN,] XiforN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (Mgh, TA,) (tropical:) A servant; (S, Mgh, TA;) because of his utility. (TA.) It is said in a prov., OaSogaru Alqawomi Xaforatuhumo (tropical:) The least of the party is their servant. (S, Mgh.) ― -b3- Also A shoemaker's knife. (S, K.) ― -b4- And A piece of iron made broad, and edged, or pointed. (K.) ― -b5- A broad blade: so says the author of the Mgh. (TA. [But not in my copy of the Mgh.]) ― -b6- The edge, or cutting part, (HadR,) of a sword: (S, Mgh, K:) or the edge of the cutting part of a sword. (TA. [See cubaAbN.]) The side of a blade: (K:) or each of the two sides thereof. (AHn, TA.) [Each of the two sharp sides or edges of a spear-head and of an arrow-head.] ― -b7- See also XuforN, second sentence.

XuforapN c
XuforapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XiforapN c
XiforapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XafuwrN c
[XafuwrN i. q. zunobuwrN The hornet, or hornets. (Golius, on the authority of Meyd.)]

XafiyrN c
XafiyrN: see XuforN, in three places. ― -b2- Also The edge of the lip of a camel. (K.) ＝ -A2- XafiyrapN: see XafirapN, voce XafirN.

yarobuwEN XufaAriIRN c
yarobuwEN XufaAriIRN A jerboa having hair upon its ears: (S:) or having large ears: or having long ears, and bare toes, [in the CK, for AlEaAriI AlbaraAvini, which is evidently the right reading, we find AlEAlI AlbrAvn,] not quickly overtaken: (K:) it is [of] a species of jerboa called DaOonu AlyaraAbiyEi, the fattest and the best, with ears somewhat long: (TA:) or having long legs, and soft and fat flesh: (K:) it is said that it has a nail in the middle of its shank. (TA. [See tadomuriIRN.]) ― -b2- DabRN XufaAriIRN A long and bulky [lizard of the kind called] DbR. (Ham p. 242.) ― -b3- OucunN XufaAriyRapN (as also XuraAfiyRapN [q. v.], TA) A large ear: (K:) or a bulky ear: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or a long ear: (AZ, TA:) or a broad ear, soft in the upper part: (TA:) or an ear having much hair and fur. (Ham p. 242.)

XafRaArN c
XafRaArN The possessor of a Xaforap [or large knife]. (A, * TA.)

XaAfirN c
XaAfirN, and its dual: see XuforN, last sentence, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also One who destroys, or makes away with, his property: so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)

maXofarN c
maXofarN: see what next follows.

miXofarN c
miXofarN The lip of a camel; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also maXofarN↓: (K:) and (tropical:) of a horse: (S, TA:) and (tropical:) of a human being: (K, TA:) or (tropical:) of an Abyssinian, as being likened to that of a camel: (A'Obeyd, TA:) pl. maXaAfiru. (S, K.) It is said in
a prov., OaraAka baXarN maA OaHaAra miXofarN [lit. External skin hath shown thee what a lip hath transmitted to the stomach;] meaning, the external appearance hath rendered thee in no need of inquiring respecting the internal state: (S, K:) originally said of a camel; (TA;) for when you see his external skin, whether he be fat or lean, you take it as an indication of the quality of his food. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also The vulva, or external portion of the organs of generation, of a woman: (R, MF:) but this is strange. (TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A piece of land: and of sand: (K, TA:) each by way of comparison [to the lip of a camel]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A state of resistance; inaccessibleness, or unapproachableness: (K:) strength, or power; (K, * TA;) vehemence, or hardness, or firmness. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And A state of perdition or destruction: and thus it is expl. as used in the saying mentioned by Meyd [in his Proverbs, perhaps the origin of this explanation], tarakotuhu EalaI mivoli miXofari AlOasadi [which may be rendered I left him at the like of the lip of the lion]; (TA;) applied to him who is exposed to destruction. (Meyd, TA. *)

EayoXN muXafirN c
EayoXN muXafirN Strait, scanty, subsistence. (O, K.)

XufaArijN c
XufaArijN A tray (TabaqN) on which are small saucers, or cups, fayoxaAt and sukurRajaAt: (O, K:) a Pers. word, (S, O,) arabicized; (S, O, K;) from biyXobaArajo or biyXobaArijo (K, TA) or biyXaArajo; (as in some copies of the K;) or what people call biyXobaAriajo: (Yaakoob, S:) [i. e. PiyXo PaAro or PiyXo PaAraho, “ pésh pár, ” and “ pésh párah, ” meaning “ sweetmeats presented to a guest: ”] accord. to ElJawáleekee, it signifies different kinds of flesh-meat in TbAyx: [but what this means I know not: I suppose it to be a corruption of some word signifying saucers or the like:] in the “ Kitáb el-Moheet, ” XafaAriyju is said to be pl. of XufaArijN, signifying a kind of food. (TA.)

1 XafaEahu c
1. XafaEahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
XafaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XafoEN, (S, Msb,) He made it to be a XafoE; (S, K, TA;) meaning (TA) he made it (a single thing) to be a zawoj [i. e. he made it to be one of a pair or couple; and sometimes, he made it to be a pair or couple together]: (Mgh, TA:) or he adjoined it to, or coupled it with, that which was a single thing: (Msb:) accord. to Er-Rághib, AlXRafoEu signifies the adjoining a thing to its like. (TA.) You say, kaAna witorFA faXafaEotuhu, (S,) or kaAna witorFA faXafaEotuhu biMxara i. e. [It was a single thing, and] I made it to be one of a pair, or couple, with another. (Mgh. [In Har p. 194, I find the phrase bMxr kAn wtrA fXfREh↓, expl. in like manner; but XfREh thus used I do not find in any lexicon: it may, however, be correctly thus used; for tXfRE, which has the form, app. has also the signification, of its quasi-pass.]) [And XufiEa Almiloku bimilokK Mxara The possession (here meaning house, or piece of land,) was coupled by purchase with another possession: and XufiEa bihi milokN It had a possession coupled with it by purchase: see XufoEapN.] You say also, XafaEotu AlrRakoEapa I made the rkEp to be two. (Msb.) And a poet says,
maA kaAna OaboSaraniI bigirRaAti AlSRibaI
faQloyawoma qado XufiEato liIa QloOaXobaAHu
[How clear was my sight with the inadvertencies of youth! but to-day, objects have become doubled to me]: i. e., I see the object [as] two objects, by reason of the weakness and dispersedness of my sight. (O, K. *) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says of a she-camel, (S, O,) and of a ewe, or she-goat, (O,) XafaEato, (S, O,) inf. n. XafoEN, (S,) meaning She became such as is termed XaAfiEN [q. v.]: (S, O:) she is thus termed liOanRa waladahaA XafaEahaA Oawo XafaEatohu [because her young one has made her to be one of a pair, or couple, with itself, or because she has made it to be one of a pair or couple, with another that is in her belly], (S, O, K,) inf. n. XafoEN, or the inf. n. in this case is XifoEN, with kesr. (O, K.) ― -b3- One says also, UinRahu layaXofaEu EalaIRa biAlEadaAwapi, (K,) or liI, (O,) i. e. (tropical:) Verily he aids [another, becoming to him one of a pair, by enmity] against me, and acts injuriously to me [conjointly with another]. (O, K, TA.) Accord. to Er-Rághib, yaXofaEu means He joins himself to another, and aids him, becoming to him one of a pair, or a XafiyE [i. e. an intercessor], in doing good or evil, so that he aids him, or partakes with him, in [procuring] the benefit or the harm thereof; and thus it means in the saying in the Kur [iv. 87], mano yaXofaEo XafaAEapF HasanapF [and in what follows the same]: (TA:) or these words mean Whoso adds a [good] deed to a [good] deed: (O, K:) or, as some say, the XfAEp here is a man's instituting, or prescribing, to another, a way of good or evil, so that he [the latter] imitates him, and thus becomes as though he were to him one of a pair. (TA.) [But accord. to the expositors in general, and accord. to the general usage of the inf. n. XafaAEapN as distinguished from XafoEN, what is here meant is Intercession.] ― -b4- [Hence also,] XafaEa lahu UilaI fulaAnK, (S, * K, * TA,) or AlI AlOamiyri, (MA,) aor.
XafaEa
, (K, TA,) inf. n. XafaAEapN; (MA, K, TA;) and lahu tXfRE↓, (MA,) or fiyhi tXfRE↓; (S, TA;) He made petition, or intercession, for him [to such a one, or to the prince or the like; thus adjoining himself to him as an aider]: (MA, TA:) and XafaEa bayona AlnRaAsi [He interceded between the people], inf. n. XafaAEapN: (Jel in iv. 87:) and XafaEotu fiI AlOamori, (Msb,) inf. n. XafaAEapN (IKtt, Msb, TA) and XafoEN, (Msb, [but the latter is scarcely to be found elsewhere thus used,]) I pleaded, [or interceded,] in the affair, or case, [in favour of another,] for some means of access or ingratiation, or some right or due: (IKtt, * Msb, TA: *) XafaAEapN is mentioned, but not explained, in the K: (TA:) as distinguished from XafoEN meaning as expl. above, it signifies the joining oneself to another as an aider to him or a petitioner respecting him [or for him]; and in most instances the former person is one of higher station than the latter: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the speaking of the XafiyE [or intercessor] to the king [or some other person] respecting some object of want which the speaker asks for another person: it is also expl. as signifying the passing over without punishment, or the forgiving, [or rather the asking, or requesting, the passing over &c., (for the word Talabu, probably accidentally omitted by the transcriber at the commencement of the explanation, should doubtless be supplied,)] of sins, crimes, or misdeeds. (TA.) Hence, in a trad., AiXofaEo tuXafRaEo↓ [Intercede thou: thou shalt have thine intercession accepted]. (TA.) The saying in the Kur [ii. 117], walaA tanofaEuhaA XafaAEapN [Nor shall intercession profit it] means that it shall have no XaAfiE [or intercessor] for his XafaAEap [or intercession] to profit it; being a denial of the XaAfiE; (Ibn- 'Arafeh, O, K;) and the same is the case in the Kur lxxiv. 49, (Ibn-'Arafeh, O, TA,) and xx. 108. (TA.) XafaEa, inf. n. XafoEN and XafaAEapN, also signifies He prayed, or supplicated: and thus Mbr and Th explain the words of the Kur [ii. 256], mano caA QlRaciI yaXofaEu Einodahu UilRaA biUiconihi [Who is he that shall pray, or supplicate, in his presence, except by his permission?]. (TA.) ― -b5- Accord. to El-Kutabee, (Mgh,) [i. e.] El-Kuteybee, (TA,) one says also, of a neighbour of one who desires to sell a dwelling [or land] XafaEa Uilayohi fiI maA baAEa, meaning He made a demand to him, i. e. to the latter, respecting that which he sold [for the right of pre-emption]: and of the latter person, faXafRaEahu↓ [and he admitted his right of pre-emption, i. e.] and he pronounced him to have a better right, or title, or claim, [as a purchaser,] to that which was sold, that he whose connexion was more remote. (Mgh, TA. *) ＝ -A2- XafaEa, inf. n. XafoEN, signifies also He, or it, was, or became, tall, or high. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And XufiEa, like EuniIa, He (a man) was smitten by the [evil] eye. (IKtt, TA. [But see XufoEapN, last sentence.])

2 XafRaEa
2: see 1, near the beginning. ― -b2- XafRaEotuhu fiyhi, inf. n. taXofiyEN, I accepted his intercession (XafaAEatahu) [for him]. (S, * O, K.) See, again, 1, in the last quarter of the paragraph. ― -b3- And see another signification of the verb in a later part of the same paragraph.

5 tXfRE c
5. tXfRE [signifies It was made a pair or couple, accord. to the K voce witorN; this word being there expl. as meaning maA lamo yataXafRaEo mina AlEadadi: but in the M and A, in the same place, instead of yataXafRaEo, we find yuXofaEo]. ― -b2- tXfRE lahu, and fiyhi: see 1, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b3- [It is said in the TA that taXafRaEahu also is quasi-pass. of AisotaXofaEa bihi: but taXafRaEahu is evidently, here, a mistranscription, app. for taXafRaEa, meaning He was granted intercession.] ＝ -A2- Also He became a XaAfiEiIR [i. e. a follower of the Imám Esh-Sháfi'ee] in persuasion: but this is post-classical. (TA.)

10 AisotaXofaEotuhu UilaI fulaAnK c
10. AisotaXofaEotuhu UilaI fulaAnK I asked him to make intercession for me (Oano yaXofaEa liI) to such a one. (S, O, K. *) And AisotaXofaEotu bihi I sought, or demanded, intercession (AlXRafaAEapa) [by means of him]. (Msb.) A poet, cited by Aboo-Leylà, says,
zaEamato maEaAXiru OanRaniI musotaXofiEN
lamRaA xarajotu Oazuwruhu OaqolaAmahaA
i. e. Companies of men asserted me to be seeking intercession (zaEamuwA OaniI OasotaXofiEu) for the object of eulogy, [when I went forth repairing to visit him,] by means of their writing-reeds (biOaqolaAmihimo), meaning by their letters (bikutubihimo). (O, TA.)

XafoEN c
XafoEN contr. of witorN; (S, Mgh, O, K;) i. q. zawojN [i. e., like zawojN, it signifies One of a pair or couple; and sometimes, but rarely, a pair or couple together; and sometimes, (see for instance zakaA) an even number, a number that may be divided into two equal numbers]: (O, K:) also one with which another is made to be a pair or couple: (TA:) [and, as will be seen in what follows, one with which an odd number is made to be an even number:] pl. XifaAEN, (TA,) and app. OaXofaAEN, whence AlSRalaApu bayona AlOaXofaAEi, meaning AltRaraAwiyH [q. v. voce tarowiyHapN]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- AlXRafoEu also signifies The day of the sacrifice; (O, K;) thus in the words of the Kur [lxxxix. 2] waQlXRafoEi waQlowitori; by Alwtr being meant the day of 'Arafát: (O:) or in this instance it means the creatures of God, (O, K,) because of the saying in the Kur [li. 49], “ and of everything we have created two of a pair; ” (K;) Alwtr meaning God: (O, K:) or Adam's wife; Alwtr meaning Adam, who was made a pair with her: (I'Ab, O, TA:) or Adam's children: (TA:) or the two days after the sacrifice; Alwtr meaning the third day: (O, TA:) or God; [and Alwtr, those who compose an odd number;] because of the saying in the Kur [lviii. 8], “ there can be no secret discourse of three, but He is the maker of them, with Himself, to be four: ” (K:) or the meaning of AlXRafoEu waAlwitoru is the prayers; of which some are XafoE [i. e. an even number of rek'ahs], and some are witor [i. e. an odd number of rek'ahs]: (O, TA:) [for] it is said that all the numbers consist of XafoE [i. e. even] and witor [i. e. odd]. (TA.)

XafoEapN c
XafoEapN: see the next paragraph, in two places, near the end.

XufoEapN c
XufoEapN is used in relation to a house and to land; (S, TA;) and XufuEapN↓, with two dammehs, is a dial. var. thereof thus used. (TA.) It signifies A milok [here meaning house, or piece of land,] that is coupled (maXofuwE) [by purchase] with one's milok [i. e. house, or piece of land, previously possessed, and adjoining thereto]; (Mgh, Msb; *) from the phrase kaAna witorFA faXafaEotuhu [expl. above, in the second sentence of this art.]; (Mgh; [and the like is said in the Msb;]) a noun of the same class as luqomapN; being of the measure fuEolapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Mgh, Msb: *) this is the primary signification: then it was applied to denote a particular kind of obtaining possession; (Mgh;) [i. e.] it is also used as meaning the obtaining possession of that milok [or house, or piece of land, by purchasing it, and coupling it with that previously possessed, and adjoining thereto]; (Msb;) or one's making a demand respecting that which he seeks [to possess, for the right of the pre-emption thereof], and adjoining it to that which he [already] has: (O, K:) and with the lawyers it signifies the right of obtaining possession of a piece of land, [i. e. the right of pre-emption thereof, or of a house,] against one's co-sharer whose possession is recent, by compulsion, for a compensation: (K:) or the right of obtaining possession of a piece of land, by compulsion, for [the payment of] what it cost the [former] purchaser, by reason of partnership or of [immediate] neighbourship: (KT:) or the right of [immediate] neighbourship with respect to [pre-emption of] a house or land. (PS.) [See 1 in art. sqb.] El-Kutabee says, in explaining this word, in the Time of Ignorance, when a man desired to sell a house, his neighbour used to come to him and to make a demand to him (XafaEa Uilayohi i. e. Talaba) respecting that which he sold [for the right of pre-emption], and he pronounced him to have a better right, or title, or claim, [as a purchaser,] to that which was sold, than he whose connexion was more remote: as though he took it from AlXRafaAEapu: but the [right] derivation is that first mentioned. (Mgh.) We have not heard, (Mgh,) or there is not known, (Msb,) any verb belonging to it [in the classical language]. (Mgh, Msb.) Esh-Shaabee uses it in the first and in the second of the senses expl. above, [or nearly so,] in his saying, mano biyEato XufoEatuhu wahuwa HaADirN falamo yaTolubo celika falaA XufoEapa lahu [i. e. He whose claimed possession to be coupled by purchase with one already belonging to him is sold when he is present without his demanding that possession, there shall be no obtaining possession for him by his purchasing it for that purpose]. (Mgh. [And the like is said in the Msb.]) Esh-Shaabee says [also], AlXRufoEapu EalaI ruWuwsi AlrijaAli [The possession that is coupled by purchase with another possession is apportioned according to the heads of the men entitled thereto]: i. e., when the house is shared by a company of men whose shares are different, and one of them sells his portion, what is sold to his co-sharers is to be apportioned among them equally, according to their heads, not according to their [former] shares: (O, K, TA:) so in the Nh. (TA.) ― -b2- XufoEapu AlDRuHaI The two rek'ahs (rakoEataAni) of the [prayer that is performed in the period of the morning called the] DuHaI; as also AlDHI XafoEapu↓: (O, K:) occurring in a trad., thus accord. to two different relations. (O.) ＝ -A2- Also Diabolical, or demoniacal, possession; or madness, or insanity; (AA, O, K;) and so XafoEapN↓; the latter expl. in this sense by IAar; and as syn. with safoEapN and XunoEapN and radRapN and naZorapN, [perceived] in the face: [see these words; the second and third of which generally mean an unseemliness or ugliness; and so, sometimes, does the last:] the pl. of XufoEapN in the sense here expl. on the authority of AA is XufaEN. (TA.) ― -b2- And IF states that it has been said to signify The [evil] eye, by which one is smitten: but he doubts its correctness; and thinks that it may be with the unpointed s. (O.) [See safoEapN, not sufoEapN.]

XufuEapN c
XufuEapN: see XufoEapN, first sentence.

XafuwEN c
XafuwEN A she-camel that fills two milking-vessels in one milking. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also XaAfiEN.

XafiyEN c
XafiyEN i. q. SaAHibu XafaAEapK; (S, K, TA;) i. e. (TA) An intercessor; as also XaAfiEN↓: pl. of the former XufaEaMCu. (Msb, TA.) [See AlsRuqafaMC, in art. sqf.] ― -b2- Also i. q. SaAHibu XufoEapK; (S, K;) [meaning A possessor of the right termed XufoEap; or] one who demands, and is granted, as a neighbour [or a partner], in preference to him whose connexion is more remote, the right of purchasing a house [or piece of land] that is to be sold. (TA.)

XafaAYiEu c
XafaAYiEu Sorts of pasture, or herbage, that grow two and two: (Ibn-Abbád, O, K:) or twins (tuWaAm [pl. of tawoCam]) of plants. (O, K.)

XaAfiEN c
XaAfiEN [act. part. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- Hence], applied to a she-camel, (tropical:) Having a young one in her belly and another following her: (Fr, Sh, S, Mgh, K, TA:) or applied in this sense to a ewe or she-goat: (K:) or, thus applied, having her young one with her: (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh:) thus called because her young one has made her to be one of a pair [with it], or because she has made it to be one of a pair [with her]: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) and XafuwEN↓, thus applied, signifies the same as XaAfiEN: and one says also, hecihi XaApu AlXRaAfiEi, like as one says SalaApu AlOuwlaI and masojidu AljaAmiEi. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A he-goat, (O, K, TA,) himself: (O:) or a ram: or such as, when he impregnates, impregnates with twins. (O, K.) ― -b4- EayonN XaAfiEapN An eye [that makes a thing to appear a pair, i. e.,] that sees doubly. (O, K.) ― -b5- fulaAnN yuEaAdiyniI walahu XaAfiEN means (tropical:) Such a one treats me with enmity, and has one who aids him to do so. (A, TA.) ― -b6- See also XafiyEN and muXafRaEN.

OaXofaEu c
OaXofaEu Tall, or high. (L, TA.)

muXofiEN c
muXofiEN A ewe, or she-goat, that suckles any animal. (IAar, TA.)

muXafRaEN c
muXafRaEN One whose intercession is accepted: hence the Kur-án is termed by Ibn-Mes'ood muXafRaEN XaAfiEN↓, i. e. An intercessor of which the intercession will be accepted, for him who follows it and does according to what is in it, that his unpremeditated transgressions may be forgiven. (O, TA.)
