muXafiEN c
muXafiEN One who accepts intercession. (L, TA.)

maXofuwEN c
maXofuwEN A possession (milokN [here meaning house, or piece of land,]) coupled [by purchase] with a man's possession [previously belonging to him,
upon certain conditions expl. voce XufoEapN]. (Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A2- Also Affected with diabolical, or demoniacal, possession; or with madness, or insanity; (O, K;) and masofuwEN, with the unpointed s, is a dial. var. thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- And maXofuwEapN is said to signify A woman smitten by the [evil] eye: (IF, O, L: [but see XufoEapN, last sentence:]) the masc. is not used in this sense. (L, TA.)

1 Xafiqa c and Xafaqa
1. Xafiqa Xafaqa: see 4, in five places. ― -b2- Xafiqa Ealayohi signifies He was niggardly of it: (TA:) [thus] the saying [of a poet]
kamaA Xafiqato EalaI AlzRaAdi AlEiyaAlu
means [Like as the household] are niggardly of the provision: (IDrd, M, O:) because he who is niggardly of a thing is Ealayohi muXofiqN↓ [i. e. fearful, or cautious, on account of it]. (M.)

2 taXofiyqN c
2. taXofiyqN signifies (tropical:) The making [a gift or the like (see muXafRaqN)] scanty, or little in amount or quantity; as also UiXofaAqN↓. (O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) The weaving badly. (K, TA.) You say, XfRq AlmiloHafapa (tropical:) He wove badly, (M,) or so as to make it scanty in the yarn, or unsubstantial, (TA,) the [kind of wrapper called] mlHfp. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, last sentence.

4 AXfq c
4. AXfq signifies He feared, or was cautious; as also Xafiqa↓ [in the CK Xafaqa]; or only the former: (K, TA:) [accord. to ISd,] Xafiqa↓, inf. n. XafaqN, signifies he feared: (M:) IDrd says, Xafiqotu↓ [in one of my copies of the S Xfaqtu] and OaXofaqotu are syn., (S, O, TA,) as some assert, (O, TA,) but the lexicologists disallow this, (S, O,) saying that one should only say OaXofaqotu: (O:) accord. to Er-Rághib, AlUiXofaAqu signifies [the being affected with] care, or solicitude, mixed with fear; and when it is trans. by means of mino, the meaning of fear is most apparent in it; but when trans. by means of EalaI, the meaning of care, or solicitude, is most apparent in it: (TA: [and the like is said by Bd in xxi. 29:]) or it signifies [the being affected with] fright [or fear]; sometimes mixed with faithful or sincere or honest advice; and sometimes divested thereof: (Ham p. 179:) one says, OaXofaqotu minohu, (S,) or mino kacaA, (Msb,) I feared, or was cautious of, (S, Msb,) him, or it, (S,) or such a thing: (Msb:) or AXfq minohu he feared him, or it: (MA:) and OaXofaqotu Ealayohi, (S, [in which it is implied that this differs from OaXofaqotu minohu,]) or EalaI AlSRagiyri, I was affectionate, kind, or compassionate, and favourably inclined, [towards him, or] towards the little one: (Msb: [and a similar explanation is given in the MA:]) and Xafaqotu↓, aor.
Xafiqa
, is a dial. var. thereof [i. e. of OaXofaqotu when trans. by means of EalaI, and perhaps also when it is trans. by means of mino]: (Msb:) or AXfq Ealayohi signifies [he was solicitously affectionate, &c., towards him; agreeably with the explanation of Er-Rághib above, and with that here following;] he was affected with pity, or compassion, and tenderness, and fear, for him, at the same time giving him faithful or sincere or honest advice, Oano yanaAlahu makoruwhN [lest some disliked or evil event should betide him]: (TA:) or he feared, or was cautious, for him: and AXfq minohu he was impatient of him, or it: and Xafaqa↓ is a dial. var. [of AXfq when trans. by means of mino, and app. also when trans. by means of EalaI]. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also 2. ＝ -A3- Also He entered upon [the time of] the Xafaq [q. v.]. (M.) And He came in a [time of] Xafaq: and so XfRq↓. (M.)

XafaqN c
XafaqN Fear: (K:) [see also Xafiqa, (of which it is the inf. n.) in the next preceding paragraph:] or fear [arising] from strictness (XidRap) of faithful or sincere or honest advice; (M, TA;) as also XafaqapN↓: (M:) or ↓the latter signifies the fear of him who gives faithful or sincere or honest advice, in consequence of his doing so, for him to whom such advice is given: (O:) or the former, (K, TA,) and ↓the latter also, (TA,) the eagerness, or striving, of him who gives such advice, to rectify, or amend, the state of him to whom that advice is given: (K, TA: [said in the latter to be a tropical application of the words; but why, I see not:]) XafaqapN↓ is subst. from AlUiXofaAqu, (S, Msb, TA,) and XafaqN is syn. therewith (S, O, K, TA) as being also a subst. from AlUiXofaAqu: (S, TA:) [it is said that] the primary signification of XafaqapN↓ is weakness: (Ham p. 179:) and it is conjoined with xawofN [fear]; therefore it is not applied as an attribute to God: (Idem p. 722:) [generally] it signifies affection, kindness, benignity, compassion, or favourable inclination: (MA:) [or solicitous affection &c.:] or pity, or compassion, and tenderness, and fear of the betiding of some disliked or evil event, together with faithful or sincere or honest advice. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XafaqN also signifies The redness (Kh, S, Msb, K) in the horizon (K) from sunset until the time of the last EiXaMC [i. e. nightfall], (Kh, S, Msb, K,) when it disappears, (Kh, S, Msb,) and the white Xafaq remains until the middle [or rather until a late period varying at different seasons] of the night: (Msb:) or until near that time: or until near the Eatamap [q. v., generally meaning the same, or nearly so]: (K:) or the redness that is seen in the sky at sunset: (IDrd, O:) or the remains of the light and redness of the sun in the first part of the night, until near the Eatamap: (S:) or the light and redness of the sun, seen at sunset, until the time of the prayer of nightfall: (M:) or the mixture of the light of day with the blackness of night at sunset: (Er-Rághib, TA:) accord. to Zj, the redness that is in the region of sunset after the setting of the sun: this is the meaning given as of common repute in the books of lexicology; and Mtr says [in the Mgh] that it means the redness accord. to a number of the Companions of the Prophet and of the people of the generation next succeeding them: but accord. to Aboo-Hureyreh, it means the whiteness [after sunset, which, to distinguish it from the Xafaq commonly so called, is often termed the white Xafaq, as in an instance above]: (Msb:) IAth says that this word has two contr. meanings; being applied to the redness that is seen after sunset; and to the whiteness remaining in the western horizon after the said redness. (TA.) Fr says, I heard one of the Arabs say, Ealayohi vawobN kaOanRahu AlXRafaqu [Upon him is, or was, a garment as though it were the Xafaq]: and it was red. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed red. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- And Day. (Zj, M, K.) ＝ -A3- Also i. q. naAHiyapN (assumed tropical:) [A side, &c.; or a remote side]: pl. OaXofaAqN. (O, K.) One says, OanaA fiI OaXofaAqK mino hecaA AlOamori i. e. nawaAHK [meaning (assumed tropical:) I am apart, or aloof, from this affair; as though in, or on, remote sides thereof]: (O, TA:) and in like manner fiI EuruwDK minohu [app. a mistranscription for EaruwDK i. e. naAHiyapK] and fI OaEoraADK mnh i. e. nawaAHK. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And (tropical:) A bad thing; syn. radiIoCN: (Lth, S, M, O, K, TA: [in the TA said to be written by J with kesr to the f; but not so in either of my copies of the S:]) applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (Mgh, TA, and Ham p. 179,) [in this sense, or] as meaning bad and thin: (Mgh in art. xrv:) [said to be] from XafaqapN signifying “ weakness: ” (Ham ubi suprà:) seldom pluralized: (O:) and used alike as masc. and fem., being applied as an epithet to a miloHafap, (M, O,) meaning radiyYapN. (M.)

XafiqN c
XafiqN: see XafiyqN, in two places.

XafaqapN c
XafaqapN: see XafaqN, in five places.

XafuwqN c
XafuwqN: see the next paragraph.

XafiyqN c
XafiyqN is syn. with muXofiqN↓ as part. n. of 4 [signifying Fearing, or fearful, or cautious; and also affectionate, kind, or compassionate, &c.]; (S, O, Msb, * K;) as also XafiqN↓ (Msb) [and in an intensive sense XafuwqN↓; and, from what follows, it appears that XafiyqN also is used as an intensive epithet]: or XafiqN↓ signifies fearing; and its pl. is Xafiquwna: (M, TA:) and XafiyqN, one giving faithful or sincere or honest advice, eager, or striving, to rectify, or amend, the state of him to whom that advice is given. (M.)
UinRa AlXRafiyqa bisuwoCi ZanK muwlaEN
[Verily the affectionate, &c., or the very affectionate &c., is addicted to evil opinion,] is a prov., applied in the case of the man who fears, for his friend, the accidents of fortune, by reason of his excessive Xafaqap [or affection, &c.]. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xxi. 50], wahumo mina QlsRaAEapi muXofiquwna↓ [meaning And who are fearful of the time of the resurrection]; the signification of fear being most apparent when muXofiqN is thus trans. by means of mino. (TA.) See also an instance of muXofiqN↓ [in a similar sense] in the first paragraph of this art.

muXofaqN c
muXofaqN: see the last paragraph. ＝ -A2- [Accord. to Freytag, it signifies also Fear: but he names no authority for this.]

muXofiqN c
muXofiqN: see XafiyqN, in three places.

EaTaMCN muXafRaqN c
EaTaMCN muXafRaqN (tropical:) A gift made scanty, or little in
amount or quantity; (S, TA;) as also muXofaqN↓. (TA.)

1 Xafahahu c
1. Xafahahu, aor.
Xafaha
, (K,) inf. n. XafohN, (TK,) He struck his Xafap [i. e. lip]. (K.) ― -b2- Xufiha, [said of a water, (assumed tropical:) It had many lips of drinkers applied to it; i. e. it had many drinkers: (see its part. n.:) and] said of food, (tropical:) It had many eaters: (K, TA:) or [as a consequence thereof] it became little in quantity. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence], said of property, (assumed tropical:) It had many seekers. (K.) ― -b4- And, said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He had many askers, or beggars, (K, TA,) so that they consumed what he had, or possessed. (TA.) [Or (assumed tropical:) He was importuned by begging, so that what he had, or possessed, was consumed: as pass. of what next follows.] ― -b5- Xafahahu (assumed tropical:) He importuned him by begging, so that he consumed what he had, or possessed. (S, K.) And one says, kaAda AlEiyaAlu yaXofahuwna maAliI (tropical:) The family, or household, almost consumed my property. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- Also, (S, K,) inf. n. XafohN, (S,) i. q. Xagala. (S, K.) You say, XafahaniI Eano kacaA (assumed tropical:) He, or it, occupied me so as to divert me from such a thing; syn. XagalaniI. (S.) And naHonu naXofahu Ealayoka AlmarotaEa, and AlmaMCa, meaning (assumed tropical:) We occupy the place of pasturage so as to keep it from thee, and the water, (naXogaluhu Eanoka,) i. e. it is sufficient for us without being more than sufficient. (S, TA.) And Xufiha Eanoka maA EinodanaA (assumed tropical:) What we had was employed so as to be kept from thee; syn. Xugila Eanoka. (JK.) ＝ -A2- IAar mentions the phrase Xafahotu naSiybiI, with fet-h, without explaining it; but Th says that it is sfht, [i. e. safihotu, with s, and with kesr to the f,] meaning “ I forgot [my share, or portion]. ” (TA.)

3 XAfhhu c
3. XAfhhu, (K,) inf. n. muXaAfahapN, (TA,) He put his lip (Xafatahu) near to his [another's] lip. (K, TA.) And kalRamahu muXaAfahapF (Msb, TA) and muXaAfaApF (Msb) He spoke to him putting his lip near to his lip: (TA:) [or mouth to mouth; for,] accord. to J, (TA,) muXaAfahapN signifies the talking with another mouth to mouth: (S, TA:) but the usage of the inf. n. of a verb different from that which it is thus made to qualify is, as Sb says, restricted to instances that have been heard: the phrase kalRamahu mufaAwahapF [has not been heard, and therefore] is not allowable. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] XAfh Albalada, and AlOamora, (tropical:) He was, or became, or drew, near to the town, or country, and the affair. (A, K, TA.)

XafapN c
XafapN, (T, S, Msb, K, &c.,) also pronounced XifapN↓, (K,) is a word of which the third, i. e. the final, radical letter is elided; (T, Msb;) and accord. to some, (Msb,) this letter is h, (T, Msb, K, TA,) so accord. to all of the Basrees, (TA,) the word being originally Xfhp↓, (T, S, Msb, TA,) i. e. XafahapN, (so in copies of the S,) or XafohapN, like kalobahN and sajodapN, (Msb,) because it has the former of the dims. mentioned below, and the first of the pls. mentioned below, with h, (S, Msb, *) and it is sometimes pronounced Xfhp; (T, TA;) or, as some assert, the deficient letter is w, (S, Msb,) the word being originally XafowapN, like XahowapN, (Msb,) because it has the last of the pls. mentioned below, (S, [but omitted in one of my copies,] and Msb, *) and the latter of the two dims. mentioned below; (Msb;) both of which assertions are stated on the authority of Kh; (IF, Msb;) [The lip of a human being;] XafataA AlUinosaAni meaning the two covers of the mouth of the human being: (K:) it is [properly] only of a human being: (Msb:) but it is sometimes, metaphorically, of the horse: and in like manner, of the dalow [or leathern bucket] as used by A'Obeyd; but ISd has expressed a doubt whether he had heard this from the Arabs: (TA:) the pl. is XifaAhN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and XafahaAtN (Lth, Msb, TA) and XafawaAtN, (Lth, S, Msb, K,) the second of which is said by Lth to be more agreeable with analogy than the third, though the third is more common, as being likened to sanawaAtN [pl. of sanapN]: (Az, (Msb, TA:) and Ks mentions the phrase, UinRahu lagaliyZu AlXifaAhi [as meaning Verily he is thick in the lip], as though the term XafapN applied to every portion of the Xafap: (TA:) the dim. is Xufayohapu↓ (S, Msb) and XufayRapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] humo Oaholu AlXRafapi (assumed tropical:) They are those who have the right of drinking with their lips (biXifaAhihimo) and of watering their beasts. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And binotu XafapK (tropical:) A word; (S, Msb, K, TA;) as also caAtu XafapK. (TA.) One says, maA kalRamotuhu bibinoti XafapK (assumed tropical:) I spoke not to him a word: (S:) or maA kalRamaniIbinota XafapK (assumed tropical:) He spoke not to me a word: (TA:) and maA samiEotu minohu binota XafapK (assumed tropical:) I heard not from him a word: (Msb:) and maA kalRamotu fulaAnFA caAta XafapK (assumed tropical:) I spoke not to such a one a word. (AZ, T voce cuw.) ― -b4- And fulaAnN xafiyfu AlXRafapi (tropical:) Such a one is a person who asks, or begs, little of people: (ISk, S, K, * TA:) and also, (tropical:) importunate, (K, TA,) one who asks, or begs, much of people: (TA:) thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b5- And lahu fiI AlnRaAsi XafapN (assumed tropical:) He has praise, or commendation, among the people: (S:) and lahu fiynaA XafapN HasanapN (tropical:) He has a good report, or reputation, among us. (A, K, TA.) And UinRa Xafapa AlnRaAsi Ealayoka laHasanapN (tropical:) Verily the people's speaking of thee is good. (Lh, TA.) And maA OaHosana Xafapa AlnRaAsi Ealayoka (tropical:) How good is the people's speaking of thee! (K, TA.) ― -b6- See also XafFA, in art. Xfw and XfI.

XifapN c
XifapN, and see the next preceding paragraph.

XafahapN c
XafahapN or XafohapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XafahiIRN c
XafahiIRN and XafiIRN are both allowable as rel. ns. of XafapN [i. e. as meaning Labial: and so, accord. to some, is XafawiIRN]. (S.) AlHuruwfu AlXRafahiyRapu (Kh, T, S, Msb, K) and AlXRafawiyRapu, (Kh, T, Msb,) or the latter is not allowable, (S,) [i. e. The labial letters,] are b and f and m: (T, S, K:) [or, accord. to Lumsden (Ar. Gr. p. 28), b and m and w: and, it seems, accord. to some, (see De Sacy's Gr. Ar. sec. ed. i. 27,) j and X and D, which is strange:] so called because their place of utterance is from the Xafap, without any action of the tongue. (T, TA.)

XufayohapN c
XufayohapN: dim. of XafapN, q. v.

XufaAhiIRN c
XufaAhiIRN A man (S, Mgh) large [in some copies of the S thick] in the XafataAni [or lips]; (S, Mgh, K;) as also OaXofahu↓. (Mgh. [But see this latter below.])

XaAfihN c
XaAfihN Thirsty, (K, TA,) not finding water enough to moisten his lip: like saAfihN, mentioned in art. sfh. (TA.)

OaXofahu c
OaXofahu: see XufaAhiIRN. ― -b2- [Accord. to some,] OaXofaI signifies A man whose lips do not close together: (S, K:) but there is no proof of its correctness: (S:) the fem. in this sense is XafoyaMCu. (TA in art. XfI.)

maXofuwhN c
maXofuwhN (tropical:) A water at which there are many lips (XifaAh TA, and Har p. 669,) of those coming to drink, (Har,) so that it has become little in quantity; (TA;) or water at which are many people: (S, K: *) or water that is sought: or, as some say, forbidden to those who come to drink of it because of its being little in quantity. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (Har ubi suprà,) (tropical:) Food upon which are [put] many hands; (K, TA, Har;) having many eaters: or that has become little in quantity. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Property sought by many: (TA:) [or little in quantity; for] one says, OataAnaA wa OamowaAlunaA maXofuwhapN (tropical:) He came to us when our possessions were little in quantity. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A man of whom people have asked, or begged, much, (S,) or importuned by begging, (K,) so that all that he had, or possessed, is consumed: (S, K:) like mavomuwdN, and maDofuwfN, and makovuwrN Ealayohi: (so in one of my copies of the S:) and sometimes it means (assumed tropical:) one whose household and guests have consumed his property. (IB, TA.)

1 Xafati AlXRamosu c
1. Xafati AlXRamosu, aor.
1a2u2a
, [inf. n. app. XafFA, but said in the TK to be XafowN,] The sun was, or became, near to setting: (K in art. Xfw:) and Xafat, (K in art. XfI,) [aor.
1a2i2a
,] inf. n. XafFA, (TA,) it (the sun) set; as also Xafiyat: (K:) or, accord. to IKtt, set save a little; and the like is said in the T. (TA.) qubayola AlXRafaA means A little before the setting of the sun. (TA.) [See also XafFA below.] ― -b2- And XafaA said of the hilaAl [or moon a little after or before the change], It rose. (K.) And said of a XaxoS [or bodily form or figure seen from a distance, or a person], It, or he, appeared, or became apparent. (K.) ＝ -A2- XafaAhu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
1a2i2a
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XifaMCN, (S, Msb,) He (God, S, Msb) recovered him, or restored him to convalescence, syn. OaboraOahu, so in the M, but in the K baraAhu, (TA,) namely a sick person, (Msb,) mino maraDihi [from his disease, or sickness]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, Xafayotuhu, in art. bDE in the S, said by a person respecting one who asked him concerning a
question, as meaning (assumed tropical:) I relieved him from doubt: and XafaAhu Eani AlmasoOalapi in the same art. in the K, as meaning (assumed tropical:) He relieved him from doubt respecting the question. See 8 as quasi-pass. of the verb thus used.] ― -b3- And yaXofiyka Uino qaAla (assumed tropical:) [He will please thee if he speak; i. e.] his speech will please thee. (Har p. 433.) ― -b4- XafaAhu also signifies He sought, or demanded, or desired, for him, recovery, or restoration to convalescence; and so OaXofaAhu↓: (K, TA:) thus in the M. (TA.)

2 XfRAhu bikuli XaIoCK c
2. XfRAhu bikuli XaIoCK, inf. n. taXofiyapN, He treated him medically, or curatively, with everything whereby he might attain recovery, or restoration to convalescence. (TA.) ― -b2- maA XafRaI fulaAnN OafoDalu mimRaA XafRayota i. e. maA QzodaAda and rabiHa [meaning The gain of such a one (mA being here what is termed maSodariyRap, as AizodaAda and rabiHa are intrans.,) is more excellent than thy gain] is said to be an instance of substitution, [originally XafRafa and XafRafota,] like [qaSRaI and taqaSRaI and] taqaDRaI [for qaSRaSa and taqaSRaSa and taqaDRaDa]. (TA.)

3 muXaAfaApN c
3. muXaAfaApN [an inf. n. of which the verb, if used, is XaAfaI]: see 3 in art. Xfh.

4 AXfI Ealayohi c
4. AXfI Ealayohi He was, or became, on the brink of it; (S, Msb, K, TA;) namely, a thing; and death: (S, Msb:) mostly used in relation to evil, but also in relation to good: so says IKtt. (TA.) [See XafFA.] ― -b2- And AXfI [alone] (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, at the point of [giving or receiving] a charge or an injunction, or a trust or deposit. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, in the last part of the night; which is termed XafaA AllRayoli. (TA.) ＝ -A2- OaXofaI nafosahu EalaI hulokK (K and TA in art. xTr) and AXfI bihaA (TA in the same) i. e. EalaI XafaA hulokK [meaning (assumed tropical:) He caused himself to be on the brink of destruction]. (TA ibid.) ＝ -A3- AXfAhu He gave him a remedial medicine. (Az, TA.) And He prescribed for him a remedy in which should be his recovery, or restoration to convalescence. (TA.) And OaXofayotuka AlXRaIoCa (S, K *) I gave thee the thing in order that thou shouldst attain, or seek, recovery, or restoration to convalescence, thereby. (S: in two copies thereof, bihi taXotafiI↓: in two other copies thereof, and in like manner in the K, bihi tasotaXofiI↓.) And AXfAhu QllRehu EasalFA God made honey to be his remedy. (AO, S: and the like is said by IKtt as cited in the TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence. ― -b3- AXfI also signifies (assumed tropical:) He gave [a person] something. (TA.)

5 tXfRI c
5. tXfRI: see 8 [with which it is syn.]. ― -b2- [Hence,] tXfRI mino gayoZihi (S, MA, K) (assumed tropical:) He recovered from his anger, wrath, or rage. (MA.) And tXfRI mino EaduwRihi, (T, TA,) or biAlEaduwRi, and bh AXtfI↓, (Msb,) (assumed tropical:) He inflicted injury upon his enemy [or the enemy] in a manner that rejoiced him [or relieved him from his anger]: (T, TA:) [or he attained what he desired from his enemy or the enemy, and so appeased his anger:] because latent anger is like a disease; and when it departs by reason of that which one seeks to obtain from his enemy, he is as though he became free, or recovered, from his disease. (Msb.)

6 taXaAfayotu AlmaMCa c
6. taXaAfayotu AlmaMCa a phrase mentioned by IAar as meaning I exhausted the water: said by ISd to be originally taXaAfafotu. (TA in art. Xf.)

8 AXtfI bikacaA c
8. AXtfI bikacaA (S, K, TA) He attained recovery, or restoration to convalescence, by means of such a thing: (TA;) and so tXfRI↓: (TK:) and mino EilRatihi AstXfI↓ [if not a mistranscription for AXtfI] he became free from his disease, sickness, or malady; recovered from it; or became convalescent. (TA.) See 4, latter part. ― -b2- And see also 5. ― -b3- [Also (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, content with such a thing; or relieved from doubt thereby: and] (assumed tropical:) he profited by such a thing. (MA.) One says, AiXotafayotu bimaA OaxobaraniI fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) I was, or became, content with that which such a one told me, [or relieved from doubt thereby,] because it was true. (IB in art. Hk, from Az.) And Oaxobarahu fulaAnN faQXotafaI bihi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one gave him information] and he profited by his veracity. (TA.)

10 AstXfI c
10. AstXfI He sought, or demanded, a remedy, or cure. (TA.) See 4, latter part. ― -b2- And see also 8.

XafFA c
XafFA The point or extremity, verge, brink, or edge, of anything; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) like XafapN↓; for XafaA AlHuforapi (Ksh in iii. 99) or XafaA AlbiYori (Bd ibid.) and XafatuhaA both signify the same, (Ksh, Bd,) i. e. HarofuhaA (Ksh) or TarafuhaA; (Bd;) but the final w in the former is changed into A, and in the latter [accord. to those who hold XafapN to be originally XafowapN] it is elided; (Ksh, Bd;) XafFA being originally XafawN: (Bd:) [but XafFA generally signifies as expl. above; and XafapN almost always signifies the “ lip ” of a human being:] the dual is XafawaAni; this being known, as Akh says, by the fact that UimaAlap in the word XafFA is not allowable: (S:) and the pl. is OaXofaMCN. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [iii. 99], wakunotumo EalaI XafaA HuforapN mina QlnRaAri faOanoqacakumo minohaA [And ye were on the verge, or brink, of a pit of the fire of Hell, and He saved, or rescued, you from it]. (S.) And one says, huwa EalaI XafaA AlhalaAki (tropical:) [He is on the brink of destruction]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A little; (S, A, K, TA;) a small part, or portion; somewhat; (A, TA;) somewhat remaining of the moon when near the change, (K, TA, [AlhalAk in the CK is erroneously put for AlhilaAl,]) and of the sight (AlbaSar), and of the day, and the like, as in the T. (TA.) One says of a man on the occasion of his dying, and of the moon at [the last period of the month called] its muHaAq, and of the sun at its setting, (S,) maA baqiIa minohu UilRaA XafFA [and minohaA when said of the sun] (assumed tropical:) There has not remained of him, or it, save a little: (S, K: *) and [in like manner] mina AlEumuri [of life]. (S.) And one says, Oatayotuhu biXafFA mino DawoCi AlXRamosi (assumed tropical:) [I came to him in a time when there was little remaining of the light of the sun]. (TA.) El-'Ajjáj says,
OaXorafotuhu bilaA XafFA Oawo biXafaA
wamirobaOK EaAlK limanN taXarRafaA
meaning [Many an elevated place of observation, high to him who ascends it, I have ascended] when the sun had set or when there was somewhat of it remaining. (S.) One says also, SaAra fiI XafaA Alqamari meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, in the last part of the night. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., (in relation to [the temporary marriage termed] AlmutoEap,) falawo laA nahoyuhu EanohaA maA QHotaAja UilaI AlzRinaA UilRaA XafFA, accord. to the T meaning [Were it not for his (i. e. God's) forbidding it, none would need having recourse to fornication,] save a small number of men: (T, TA:) or, accord. to 'Atà, it means, but would be on the brink thereof, without falling into it; XafFA being thus used in the place of the inf. n. UiXofaMC: so says IAth, as from Az. (TA.)

XafapN c
XafapN, in which the deficient letter is w, (K, TA,) for it has for pl. XafawaAtN, (TA,) or h, (K, TA,) for it has [also] for pl. XifaAhN, (TA,) has been mentioned before, (K, TA,) in art. Xfh [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also XafFA above, first sentence.

XifaMCN c
XifaMCN, (K, TA,) like kisaMCN, (TA,) [in the CK erroneously written XafAC,] primarily signifies The becoming free from disease, sickness, or malady; recovering therefrom; or becoming convalescent: ― -b2- and then, Medical, or curative, treatment: (TA:) the giving of health; (KL:) inf. n. of XafaAhu [q. v.]: (S, Msb, TA:) ― -b3- and [then], (TA,) A medicine, or remedy: pl. OaXofiyapN, and pl. pl. OaXaAfK. (K, TA.) [Hence, daAru AlXifaMCi The hospital.] ― -b4- [And hence,] one says, XifaMCu AlEiIRi AlsRuWaAlu (tropical:) [The remedy of inability is the asking information]. (TA.)

XafiIRN c
XafiIRN: see art. Xfh.

XufayRapN c
XufayRapN: see art. Xfh.

XafawiIRN c
XafawiIRN: see art. Xfh.

XaAfK c
XaAfK [Recovering, or restoring to convalescence; remedial;] health-giving. (KL.) ― -b2- [Hence, jawaAbN XaAfK (assumed tropical:) An answer that relieves from doubt.]

OaXofaI c
OaXofaI More [and most remedial or] healthgiving. (KL.) ＝ -A2- Also A man whose lips do not close together: fem. XafoyaMCu. (TA.) See OaXofahu, in art. Xfh.

UiXofFI c
UiXofFI An instrument for perforating; (K;) a thing pertaining to the makers or sewers of boots or shoes or sandals &c.; (S;) [i. e.] the awl used by them: (MA, KL:) and the instrument with which leather, or skin, is sewed: (Mgh, K:) or, accord. to ISk, it is [an instrument used] for water-skins and water-bags and the like; and the mixoSaf is for sandals: (S:) [see also art. AXf:] masc. and fem.: (K, * TA:) pl. OaXaAfK. (Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- Th mentions the saying, Uino laATamotahu laATamota AlUiXofaI [if thou contend with him in slapping, thou wilt do so with the AXfI]; meaning that when one does so, it will be against himself. (TA.) ― -b3- And UiXofaI Almirofaqi, a phrase used by a poet, means (assumed tropical:) Sharp in the elbow. (TA.)

1 XaqRahu c
1. XaqRahu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
Xaquqa
, (M, Msb,)
inf. n. XaqRN, (S, M, Msb,) He cut it [or divided it] lengthwise; (TA in art. qd;) [i. e.] he clave it, split it, rived or rifted it, or slit it; so as to separate it; [i. e. he clave, split, rived or rifted, slit, rent, ripped, tore, broke, or burst, it asunder;] or without separating it; [i. e. he cracked, chapped, incided or incised, gashed, slashed, furrowed, or trenched, it; or clave, split, &c., or cut, it open;] syn. SadaEahu; (K;) or [more explicitly] AlXRaqRu signifies AlSRadoEu AlbaAYinu [the cleaving &c. that separates]; or gayoru AlbaAYini [that which does not separate]; or AlSRadoEu [the cleaving, &c.,] in a general sense: (M:) and in like manner, [but with an intensive signification, or implying frequency or repetition of the action, or its application to several objects, generally meaning he clave it, &c., much, or in pieces, or in several places,] XqRqhu↓: (M, K:) you say, XqRq AlHaTaba (S, K) wagayorahu (S) i. e. XaqRahu [but properly meaning He clave in pieces the firewood &c.]. (K. [In the CK, XaqRa AlHaTaba is erroneously put for XqRq AlHTb.]) ― -b2- [XaqRa raOosahu generally means He clave his head, or his pericranium: and sometimes, as in an instance in the K voce XaqaOa, he divided the hair of his head.] ― -b3- XaqRa AlEaSaA [lit. He split the staff] means (tropical:) he separated himself from the community; (S, K, TA;) and particularly, that of the Muslims: because the staff is not thus called but when it is whole, not when it is split: accord. to Lth, yaXuqRu EaSaA Almusolimiyna and yuXaAqRuhumo↓ signify alike: but they differ in meaning, as will be shown hereafter. (TA.) XaqRa EaSaA Almusolimiyna, K, TA,) said of a xaArijiIR [i. e. heretic or schismatic], also means (assumed tropical:) He effected disunion and dissension in the body of the Muslims. (TA.) And one says also, XaqRa EaSaA AlTRaAEapi (assumed tropical:) [He broke the compact of allegiance, or obedience; became a rebel]. (M.) ― -b4- laA waAlRaciI XaqRa AlrRijaAla liloxayoli waAljibaAla lilsRayoli [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) No, by Him who clave men for the riding upon horses, and the mountains for the flowing of the torrent,] is a saying mentioned by IAar, but not expl. by him. (M. [It is there added, waEinodiI OanRahu jaEala AlrRijaAla waAljibaAla jumolapF waAHidapF vumRa xaraqahumaA fajaEala AlrRijaAla lihecihi waAljibaAla lihecaA: an expression of opinion which is, to me, by no means clear, though reconcilable with my rendering.]) ― -b5- AlmaAlu bayonanaA XaqRa AlOabolamapi and AlOubolumapi [The property is divided between us as in the dividing of the Ablmp; or the cattle are divided &c.;] means we are equal in respect of the property, or cattle: for the Ablmp means the [kind of leaf called] xuwSap, which, when it is split lengthwise, splits in halves: (M:) or, accord. to Aboo-Ziyád, the Ablmp is a herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) to which there come forth pods, like [those of] the bean; and when you split them lengthwise, they split in halves, equally, from the first part to the last thereof: XaqRa is in the accus. case as an inf. n., maXoquwqN being understood. (Har p. 639.) [See also XiqRN.] ― -b6- XaqRa, (S, M, K,) aor.
Xaquqa
, inf. n. XuquwqN, (M,) said of the canine tooth of a camel, (tropical:) It [clave the gum and] came forth: (S, M, K, TA:) [said to be] a dial. var. of XaqaOa: (S:) and said of the canine tooth of a child, (M, TA,) in like manner, (TA,) meaning it made its first appearance: (M:) and said also of a plant, [as meaning it came forth] on the ground's first cleaving open from it. (M, TA.) ― -b7- Also, aor.
Xaquqa
, inf. n. XaqRN, said of the dawn, (tropical:) It rose; as though it clave the place of its rising and came forth therefrom. (TA.) ― -b8- Also, aor.
Xaquqa
, (TA,) inf. n. XaqRN, said of lightning, (tropical:) It [clave the clouds, and] extended high, into the midst of the sky, without going to the right and left: (K, TA:) so says A'Obeyd: (TA: [see XaqiyqN:]) and AnXqR↓ and tXqRq↓, said of lightning, signify AinoEaqRa [probably meaning the same; (see EaqiyqapN;) or, as expl. in the S and also in the O, in art. Eq, it was, or became, in a state of commotion, (taDarRaba,) in the clouds]: (M, TA:) or tXqRq↓ said of lightning means it spread wide and long. (JK.) ― -b9- XaqRa AlsRabiyla (K in art. Ebr) (assumed tropical:) He passed along the way; as though he cut it, or furrowed it. (TK in that art.) And XaqRa AlnRahora (assumed tropical:) He crossed the river by swimming. (TA in art. qTE.) ― -b10- XaqRa AlmaMCa (assumed tropical:) He opened a way, passage, vent, or channel, for the water to flow forth; syn. bajasahu. (A and K in art. bjs.) ― -b11- XaqRa Oamorahu, aor.
Xaquqa
, inf. n. XaqRN, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, discomposed, deranged, or disordered, so that it became incongruous, or inconsistent, his affair, or state of affairs. (M, TA.) [A phrase similar to XaqRa AlEaSaA, mentioned above. And so, app., what next follows.] ― -b12- XaqRa AlkalaAma, i. q. qadRahu [also expl. as syn. with qaTaEahu, which generally means (assumed tropical:) He cut short, or broke off, the speech; or ceased from speaking; but sometimes, and perhaps in this case, he articulated speech, or the speech: compare a signification of 2.]. (M and L in art. qd.) ― -b13- See also 8. ― -b14- XaqRa baSaru AlmayRiti i. q. XaxaSa [i. e. (assumed tropical:) The eye, or eyes, of the dying man became fixedly open; or his eyelids became raised upwards, and he looked intently, and became disquieted, or disturbed]: (M, TA:) and (TA) the dying man looked at a thing, his sight not recoiling to him: (S, K, TA:) said of him to whom death is present: (S, TA:) or [simply] the eyes of the dying man became open: (TA:) one should not say XaqRa AlmayRitu baSarahu: (S, M, K:) and XuqRa, with damm to the X, is not approved. (IAth, TA.) ― -b15- XaqRa Ealayohi, (M, K, in the S EalaIRa, and in the Msb EalayonaA,) aor.
Xaquqa
, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. XaqRN (S, M, K) and maXaqRapN, (S, K,) [or the latter is a simple subst., as seems to be indicated in the M and Msb,] (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, S, or an affair, or event, M, Msb, K) affected him severely; had a severe effect upon him; distressed, afflicted, troubled, molested, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied, him: (M:) it was difficult, hard, distressing, grievous, or severe, to him; (K, TA;) and onerous, burdensome, oppressive, or troublesome, to him. (TA.) And XaqRa Ealayohi, [inf. n., app., XaqRN only,] (assumed tropical:) He caused him to fall into a difficult, hard, distressing, grievous, or severe, case: (K, TA:) imposed upon him that which was onerous, burdensome, oppressive, or troublesome. (TA.) And XaqRati AlsRaforapu (assumed tropical:) The journey was [difficult, hard, or] far-extending. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- XuqRa, said of the solid hoof, and of the pastern of a horse or the like, It was, or became, affected with the disease termed XuqaAq, occasioning cracks. (M, TA.)

2 XaqRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- XqRq AlkalaAma, (S, K, TA,) inf. n. taXoqiyqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He uttered, or pronounced, speech, or the speech, in the best manner: (S, K, TA:) and he sought with repeated efforts, in speaking, to utter, or pronounce, the speech in the best manner. (TA.)

3 XAqRhu c
3. XAqRhu, (M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. muXaAqRapN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and XiqaAqN, (S, M, Msb, K,) the latter inf. n. occurring in the Kur ii. 131 and iv. 39 [&c.], (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He acted with him contrariously, or adversely, (S, * M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and inimically; (K;) properly, each of them doing to the other that which was distressing, grievous, or troublesome, so that each of them was in a XiqR [or side] other than that of his fellow; (Msb;) or as though he became in a XiqR, i. e. side, in respect of him: (Mgh:) accord. to Er-Rághib, the inf. n. signifies the being in a XiqR [or side] other than that of one's fellow: or it is from XaqRu AlEaSaA bayonaka wabayona SaAHibika [meaning “ the effecting disunion and dissension between thee and thy fellow ”], so that it is tropical: (TA:) or the primary meaning of AlXRiqaAqu is the being [mutually] remote. (Ham p. 326.) See also 1, in the first quarter of the paragraph.

4 AXqR AlnRaxolu c
4. AXqR AlnRaxolu The palm-trees put forth their XawaAqR, pl. of XaAqRapN [q. v.]: mentioned by Th, on the authority of some one or more of the BenooSuwáäh. (M.)

5 tXqRq c
5. tXqRq quasi-pass. of 2: (S, M, K:) said of firewood (S, K) &c. (S) [as meaning It became cloven in pieces]. See 7, in two places. ― -b2- Said of lightning: see 1, in two places, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b3- Said of a horse, (tropical:) He was, or became, lean, or light of flesh; slender and lean; or lean, and lank in the belly. (A'Obeyd, TA.)

6 taXaAqRaA c
6. taXaAqRaA, said of two adversaries, or litigants, as also AiXotaqRaA↓, They wrangled, quarrelled, or contended, each with the other, (M, TA,) and took to the right and left in contention; (TA;) fiI AlXRaIoCi [in respect of the thing]. (M.)

7 AnXqR c
7. AnXqR quasi-pass. of XaqRahu as expl. in the first sentence of this art.: [i. e. it signifies It became divided lengthwise, cloven, split, riven or rifted, slit, rent, ripped, torn, broken, or burst, asunder; or it became cracked, chapped, incided or incised, gashed, slashed, furrowed, or trenched; or cloven, or split, &c., or cut, open: or it clave, split, &c.:] (S, M:) and in like manner, tXqRq↓ is quasi-pass. of XaqRaqahu: [i. e. it signifies it became cloven or split &c., or it clave or split &c., much, or in pieces, or in several or many places:] (M:) or the former signifies [sometimes] it opened so as to have in it an interstice. (Msb.) waQnoXaqRa Alqamaru, in the Kur liv. I, means And the moon hath been cloven (Bd, Jel) in twain, (Jel,) as a sign to the
Prophet: (Bd, Jel:) or shall be cloven on the day of resurrection: but the former is confirmed by another reading, waqadi OonoXaqRa Alqamaru: (Bd:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) the case hath become manifest. (TA.) One says, AnXqR AlXRaIoCu biniSofayoni [The thing became cloven, &c., in halves]. (S.) [And AnXqR minohu It became cloven, &c., from it: and it branched off from it; as a river from another river, and the like. And AnXqR Eanohu It clave asunder from over it, so as to disclose it: see also 8.] ― -b2- [Hence,] AnXqR flaAnN mina AlgaDabi (assumed tropical:) Such a one was as though his interior were filled with anger so that he split. (TA.) ― -b3- And AinoXaqRati AlEaSaA (assumed tropical:) The affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, or disordered: (S, K, TA:) and AnXqRt AlEaSaA biAlbayoni, and tXqRqt↓, (Lth, M, TA,) (assumed tropical:) the affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, or disorganized, by separation: (Lth, TA:) and AnXqR AlOamoru (assumed tropical:) the affair, or state of affairs, became discomposed, deranged, or disorganized, being incongruous, or inconsistent. (M, TA.) And AnXqRt EaSaA AlTRaAEapi (assumed tropical:) [The compact of allegiance, or obedience, became broken]. (M.) ― -b4- AnXqR said of lightning: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

8 AiXotiqaAqN c
8. AiXotiqaAqN signifies The taking the XiqR of a thing, (S, K,) i. e. the half thereof. (S.) One says, AXtqR AlXRaIoCa He took the XiqR [or half] of the thing. (TK.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The taking [or deriving] a word from a word, (S, K,) with the condition of reciprocal relation in meaning and [radical] composition, and of reciprocal difference in form: [and it is of three kinds:] AlAiXotiqaAqu AlSRagiyru is that derivation in which there is a reciprocal relation between the two words in the letters and in the order [thereof]; as in Daraba from AlDRarobu: AlAXtqAq Alkabiyru is that in which there is a reciprocal relation between the two words as to the letter and the meaning, exclusively of the order; as in jabaca from Aljacobu: AlAXtqAq AlOakobaru is that in which there is a reciprocal relation between the two words in the place [or places] of utterance; as in naEaqa from AlnRahoqu. (KT.) [You say, AXtqR HarofFA or kalimapF or lafoZFA, and QsomFA, He derived a word, and a name, mino Mxara from another; and XaqRahu↓ sometimes signifies the same, as is shown by a citation voce raHimN.] ― -b3- [And, as syn. with AixotiraAEN, (see 8 in art. xrE,)] The constructing, or founding, (bunoyaAn,) of a thing of, or from, what is originated without premeditation. (M.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) The taking to the right and left, (S, K, TA,) not pursuing the right, or direct, course, (S, TA,) in speech, and in contention, or disputation, or litigation: (S, K, TA:) or AiXotiqaAqu AlkalaAmi signifies the taking to the right and left in speech: (so in a copy of the M: [but I think that the right reading is AlAiXotiqaAqu fiI AlkalaAmi, agreeably with what here follows:]) you say, AXtqR fiI AlkalaAmi, and fiI AlxuSuwmapi. (TK.) See also 6. And [in like manner] one says of a horse, AXtqR fiI Eadowihi (assumed tropical:) He went to the right and left in his running. (M. [See also OaXaqRu.]) ― -b5- AXtqR AlTRariyqu fiI AlfalaApi (tropical:) The road went [or branched off] into the desert. (TA. [See also 7.])

10 AstXqR biAljuwaAliqi c
10. AstXqR biAljuwaAliqi He turned the sack upon one of his two sides (EalaI OaHadi XiqRayohi), in order to pass through a door. (TA.) ― -b2- [AstXqR, as stated by Freytag, is expl. by Jac. Schultens, but on what authority is not said, as signifying “ Prodiit, manifestus evasit. ”]

R. Q. 1 XaqoXaqa c
R. Q. 1. XaqoXaqa, (JK, S, K,) inf. n. XaqoXaqapN, (S,) said of a stallion [camel], He brayed [in his XiqoXiqap, or faucial bag]. (JK, S, K.) [It is said that] the primary meaning of XaqoXaqapN is Loudness of voice; or the being loud in voice. (JK.) ― -b2- And said of a sparrow, It uttered a cry: (K, TA:) or one says of a sparrow, yuXaqoXiqu fiI Sawotihi [app. meaning It makes a loud twittering in its cry]. (S.)

XaqRN c
XaqRN sing. of XuquwqN; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) originally an inf. n.; (S, Msb;) An opening forming an interstice in a thing: (Msb:) or a fissure, cleft, chink, split, slit, rent, crack, or the like, syn. SadoEN, in wood or a stick, or in a wall, or in a glass vessel [&c.]: (T, TA:) [or] a place that is maXoquwq [i. e. cloven or cleft, split, &c.: (see 1, first sentence: and see also maXaqRN:) and often signifying an incision, a gash, or a furrow, or trench]: (M, K:) as though an inf. n. used as a subst. in this sense: pl. as above, XuquwqN: (M:) it differs from XuqaAqN, (S, Mgh,) by having a general signification: (Mgh:) accord. to Yaakoob, one says, biyadi fulaAnK XuquwqN (S, Mgh) and birijolihi (S) [i. e. In the hand, or arm, of such a one are cracks, or the like, and in his foot, or leg]: but [it is asserted that in this case] one should not say XuqaAqN: (S, Mgh: [see, however, this word:]) and hence, XaqRu Alqabori The trench, or oblong excavation, in the middle of the grave: and accord. to As, XuquwqN signifies SuduwE [i. e. fissures, &c.,] in mountains, and in the earth, or ground. (Mgh.) ― -b2- The rima vulvæ of a woman; i. e. the gap [or chink] between the two edges, or borders, of the labia majora of her vulva: as also maXaqRN↓. (M, K.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The daybreak. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph, first and fifth sentences. ＝ -A3- And see the last two sentences of the same paragraph.

XiqRN c
XiqRN The half (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of a thing (S, Msb, K) of any kind; as also XaqRN↓: (K:) or the half of a thing when it is cloven, or split, or divided lengthwise; (M;) as also XiqRapN↓. (AHn, S, * M, K.) One says, Oaxacotu XiqRa AlXRaApi and XiqRapa↓ AlXRaApi I took the half of the sheep or goat: (S, TA:) the vulgar pronounce the X with fet-h. (TA.) And xuco hecaA AlXRiqRa Take thou this XiqRap↓ [i. e. half] of the sheep or goat. (TA.) Hence the trad., taSadRaquwA walawo biXiqRi tamorapK i. e. [Give ye alms though it be but] the half of a date; meaning deem not anything little that is given as alms. (TA.) And AlmaAlu bayoniI wabayonaka XiqRa AlXRaEarapi and AlXRaEarapi XaqRa↓, (O, K, * [in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K XqRu, but the former reading appears to be the right, XaqRa being an inf. n. as in a similar saying in the former half of the first paragraph of this art., and XiqRa being a subst. used as an inf. n. or for kaXiqRi,]) meaning [The property is between us] two halves, equal [in division]. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] A certain kind of the jinn, or genii; (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K;) a species of diabolical beings having the form of the half of a human being. (Kzw in his Descr. of the Jinn.) ― -b3- The lateral half, or half and side; as when one says that a person paralyzed has a XiqR inclining; and as when one speaks of the XiqR of a maHomil [meaning either of the two dorsers, or panniers, or oblong chests, which are borne, one on either side, by a camel, and which, with a small tent over them, compose a maHomil: see this last word, and maHaArapN]. (Mgh.) ― -b4- The side of the body; as when one says of a person that his left XiqR was grazed, or abraded. (Mgh.) [Hence,] one says of a horse, yamiylu EalaI OaHadi XiqRayohi [He inclines, or leans, upon one of his two sides]. (O.) [And maXaI EalaI XiqRK and fiI XiqRK He went, or walked, inclining upon one side.] ― -b5- The side, or lateral part, (Lth, Msb, K, TA,) of a thing; the two sides of a thing being called XiqRaAhu: (Lth, TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) the side of a mountain. (S, TA.) [Hence,] one says, fulaAnN mino XiqRi AlEaXiyrapi laA mino SamiymihaA (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is of the collateral class of the kinsfolk, or tribe, not of the main stock thereof]. (Mgh in art. ErD.) ― -b6- I. q. XaqiyqN↓; (S, Msb, K;) [which primarily signifies The cloven-off half of a thing; i. e.,] when a thing is cloven in halves, each of the halves is called the Xaqiyq of the other. (S, K.) ― -b7- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) The counterpart of a person or thing: and this appears to be meant by J, and accord. to SM in the K, where it is said that XiqRN is syn. with XaqiyqN↓; for they add immediately after:] one says huwa OaxiI waXiqRu nafosiI (tropical:) [He is my brother, and the counterpart of myself]; (S, TA;) as though he were cloven from me, because of the resemblance of each of us to the other. (TA.) One says also, hcaA Xaqiyquhu↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) This is the like of him, or it. (TA.) And [hence] it is said in a trad., AlnRisaMCu XaqaAYiqu AlrRijaAli, [in which XaqaAYiqu is the pl. of XaqiyqN↓ as fem., or of XaqiyqapN in the same sense,] meaning (assumed tropical:) Women are the likes of men in natural dispositions; as though they were cloven from them; or because Eve was created from Adam. (TA.) ― -b8- And (tropical:) A man's brother; (M;) and so XaqiyqN↓; (S, M, O, K, TA;) meaning a brother by the father and mother; (TA;) from XaqiyqN as meaning “ either half of a thing that is cloven in halves; ” (S, TA;) or as though the relationship of one were cloven from that of the other: (IDrd, O, K:) pl. of the latter OaXiqRaMCu. (M, Msb.) ― -b9- And a name for A thing at which one looks: (Lth, O, K:) [but this is app. taken from the following
saying of Lth, in which I think AlXRiqRu is a mistranscription for AlXRaqRu, meaning “ the crack, ” &c.:] AlXRaqRu is the inf. n. of Xaqaqotu, and AlXRiqRu is a name for that at which one looks [i. e. for the visible effect of the act signified by the verb], and the pl. is AlXRuquwqu [which is well known as the pl. of AlXRaqRu]. (JK.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. maXaqRapN↓ (S, M, O, Msb, K) i. e. Difficulty, hardship, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, fatigue, or weariness; (M, TA;) and languor, or lack of power, that overtakes the mind and the body; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and so XaqRN↓; (IJ, S, M, O, K;) thus it is sometimes pronounced with fet-h; mentioned by A'Obeyd; (S;) and by AZ; (M;) or this is an inf. n., and XiqRN is the subst.; (O, K;) and XuqRapN↓ and XiqRapN↓ also signify the same as maXaqRapN, (K,) or such as overtakes a man in consequence of travel; (TA;) and the pls. of these two are XuqaqN, (K, TA,) mentioned by Fr, (TA,) and XiqaqN, (K, TA,) mentioned on the authority of some one or more of [the tribe of] Keys: (TA:) the pl. of maXaqRapN↓ is maXaAqRu and maXaqRaAtN. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [xvi. 7], lamo takuwnuwA baAligiyhi UilRaA biXiqi QloOanofusi [Which ye would not reach save with difficulty, or distress, &c., of the souls]; where some read biXaqRi↓. (S, * TA.)

XuqRapN c
XuqRapN primarily signifies The half of a garment [consisting of two oblong pieces sewed together, side by side]: then it was applied to [such] a garment as it is [when complete: in both of these senses it is used in the present day]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or a piece (qiToEapN) of a garment: (Mgh:) or the XuqRap of viyaAb [thus, and thus only, in the S, meaning of garments and of cloths, for it is of both,] is an oblong piece; syn. sabiybapN musotaTiylapN: (M, K:) [it is often applied to an oblong piece of cloth of those pieces of which a tent is composed:] pl. XuqaqN and XiqaAqN. (M, Mgh, TA.) One says, fulaAnN yabiyEu XiqaAqa AlkatRaAni [Such a one sells pieces, or oblong pieces, &c., of linen]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also A piece of a mazaAdap [q. v.]. (B, TA in art. bSr.) ― -b3- And A piece, or portion, [or tract,] of Hell; likewise pronounced XiqRapN↓. (Ham p. 816.) ― -b4- And A far journey; as also XiqRapN↓, (S, M, K,) sometimes thus pronounced with kesr: (S:) a far, long journey: a far-extending space: (TA:) or a road difficult to him who travels it: (Mgh:) or [simply] a journey: and i. q. vnyA [so in my copy of the Msb, app. a mistranscription for vaniyRap, i. e. a mountain-road, &c.]: pl. XuqaqN. (Msb.) ― -b5- And A part, region, quarter, or tract, (Ibn-'Arafeh, Er-Rághib, K, TA,) towards which one draws near, (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA,) or towards which the traveller directs himself, (K, TA,) [like XukRapN,] or in the reaching of which one is overtaken by difficulty, or distress; (Er-Rághib, TA;) And XiqRapN↓ signifies the same. (K.) ― -b6- And Distance; and so XiqRapN↓. (K.) ― -b7- See also XiqRN, last sentence but one.

XiqRapN c
XiqRapN A splinter (S, K) that splits off, (S,) or a piece (M, Mgh, TA) split off, (M, TA,) of a plank, (S, M, K, TA,) or of wood, (TA,) or of a piece of wood, (S, Mgh,) or other thing: (M, TA:) a piece split, or divided, lengthwise, of a staff, or stick, and of a garment, or piece of cloth, &c.: (IDrd, O, K:) and a piece split (K, TA) from anything; such as the half: (TA:) pl. XiqaqN. (O, TA.) One says of him who is angry, AiHotadRa faTaArato minohu XiqRapN fiI AlOaroDi waXiqRapN fiI AlsRamaMCi (assumed tropical:) [He became excited by sharpness of temper, or angriness, and he was as though a bit flew from him upon the ground, and a bit into the sky]. (S, * M, TA: in the S, fI AlArD &c. is omitted.) See also XiqRN, first three sentences. ― -b2- See also XuqRapN, in four places. ― -b3- And see XiqRN, again, last sentence but one.

XaqaqN c
XaqaqN The quality, in a horse, (M, K,) and in a man, (M,) denoted by the epithet OaXaqRu [q. v.]. (M, K.)

XaqaqapN c
XaqaqapN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] Enemies. (TA.)

XuqaAqN c
XuqaAqN A cracking in several places, (taXaqRuqN, S, K,) or cracks, (Mgh,) or a certain disease occasioning cracks, (M,) in the pasterns of horses or the like, (S, M, Mgh, K,) and in their hoofs, (M, Mgh,) and sometimes rising to their shanks: so says Yaakoob: (S:) and, accord. to Lth, (Mgh,) and Az, (TA,) a cracking in several places (taXaqRuqN) of the skin, from cold or some other cause, in the hands or arms, and the face: (Mgh, TA:) or it signifies also any crack, or slit, in the skin, from disease: (M, TA:) As says that it is in the hand or arm, and the foot or leg, of a human being, and in the fore leg and kind leg of an animal: (Mgh, TA:) but this is inconsistent with what is said by Yaakoob [as stated voce XaqRN, first sentence]. (Mgh.) See also OasoEadu: and XarajN.

XaqiyqN c
XaqiyqN: see XiqRN, in five places. ― -b2- Xaqiyqu Albaroqi [so in a copy of the M, but the right reading may be Xaqiyqapu Albaroqi, which occurs in the next sentence of the M,] i. q. Eaqiyqatuhu [expl. in the S, in art. xfw, as meaning Lightning that cleaves the clouds, and extends high, into the midst of the sky, without going to the right and left: but see XaqiyqapN]. (M.) ＝ -A2- Also A calf that has become firm, or strong: (O, K:) and applied likewise to (assumed tropical:) a man [that has become so; by way of comparison]: (O:) or a bull such as is termed jacaEN [i. e. in his second, or third, year]. (JK.)

XaquwqapN c
XaquwqapN A certain bird; also called XaqiyqapN↓: (M, K:) and XuqayRiqapN↓ is the dim. thereof: (K:) AHát says, the Xaquwqap↓ is a very little thing, grayish (zurayoqaMCu), of the colour of ashes; ten and fifteen of what are thus called congregate; and I think it to be the XuqayRiqap↓, which is a duxRalap of the duxRal [q. v.]; it is somewhat dusky; and its form is the form of these, but it is smaller than they: it is called XuqayRiqap↓ becanse of its smallness: IDrd, in the class of fuEayoEil, mentions AlXRuqayRiqu↓ as signifying a certain species of birds [app. as a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p]. (O, TA.)

XaqiyqapN c
XaqiyqapN [accord. to Golius, A fissure; as from the KL; but not so expl. in my copy of that work. ― -b2- ] An intervening space or tract between two elongated, or extended, tracts of sand, (S, M, * O, K, * [in the last of which Aljabalayoni is erroneously put for Aljabolayoni,]) thus expl. to AHn by an Arab of the desert, (TA,) producing herbage: (S, M, O, K:) or a rugged tract between two elongated, or extended, tracts of sand, producing good herbage; (M, TA;) so in the T, as expl. to its author by an Arab of the desert: (TA:) pl. XaqaAYiqu, (T, S, O, K, TA,) expl. by some as meaning sands themselves: (TA:) or a great piece of sand: or a piece of sand between two pieces thereof. (Ham p. 282.) ― -b3- [In the A and TA voce qiTRu, it is used as meaning A slice cut off of a melon &c.] ＝ -A2- A rain, (M,) or a violent rain, consisting of large drops, (K, TA,) wide in extent: so called because the clouds cleave asunder from it: (M, K, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b2- The pl., XaqaAYiqu, is expl. by Az as signifying Clouds that have cloven asunder with copious rains. (O, TA.) ― -b3- Xaqiyqapu baroqKi, (O, K,) and Eaqiyqatuhu, both as expl. by Aboo-Sa'eed, (O,) A flash of lightning that has spread (O, K) in the horizon, (O,) or from the horizon: (K: [but see Xaqiyqu Albaroqi:]) or XaqiyqapN signifies a flash of lightning that has spread in the breadth of the clouds, and filled the sky: pl. as above. (Ham p. 557.) ＝ -A3- A headache, (JK, T, TA,) or a pain, (S, O, K,) or a certain disease, (M,) in the half of the head, (JK, T, S, M, O, K,) [i. e. hemicrania,] and of the face: (JK, T, S, O, K:) or, accord. to IAth, a sort of headache in the fore part of the head and towards the sides thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A4- XaqaAYiqu AlnRuEomaAni, used alike as sing. and pl., (S, O, K,) having no proper sing., (Msb,) or its sing. is XaqiyqapN; (M, O, Msb;) [The red, or blood-coloured, anemone;] a certain plant; (M;) a certain red flower; (Lth, O;) well known; (S, K;) the Xaqir; (Msb;) or, as AHn says, on the authority of AA and Aboo-Nasr and others, it is the Xaqirap [n. un. of XaqirN]; and the sing. of XqAYq is XaqiyqapN: (O, TA:) it is called XqAYq AlnEmAn because of its redness, as being likened to the Xaqiyqap of lightning: (M, K:) or from AlnRuEomaAn as meaning “ blood, ” as resembling blood in colour; (Msb, TA;) so that it signifies “ pieces of blood: ” (TA:) or in relation to En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir, because he prohibited to the public a piece of land in which it abounded: (S, K, TA:) or because he alighted upon XaqaAYiq of sand that had produced red Xaqir, and he deemed them beautiful, and commanded that they should be prohibited to the public; so the Xaqir were called the XqAYq of En-Noamán, by the name of the place of their growth. (TA.) ＝ -A5- See also XaquwqapN.

XuqayRiqN c
XuqayRiqN, and with p: see XaquwqapN, in four places.

XaqRaAqN c
XaqRaAqN, meaning One who glories, or boasts, vainly, and praises himself for that which is not in him, is not of the [classical] language of the Arabs. (L, TA.)

XaqRiIRN c
XaqRiIRN A horse with which his rider ex-
periences difficulty in striving to master him. (JK.)

XiqRiyRapN c
XiqRiyRapN A certain mode of jimaAE, (K, TA,) in which the woman lies upon her XiqR [or side]. (TA.)

XiqoXiqapN c
XiqoXiqapN [The bursa faucium, or faucial bag, which is placed behind the palate of the he-camel, and which, when excited, he inflates, and blows out from the side of his mouth;] a thing resembling the lungs, or lights, which the he-camel protrudes from his mouth when he is excited by lust; (S, O, K;) a skin in the fauces of the Arabian camel, which he inflates with wind, and in which he brays; whereupon it appears from the side of his mouth; so says En-Nadr; and he adds that it does not pertain to any but the Arabian camel, [as is said in the M, and] as Hr says; but this requires consideration; (TA;) [also expl. as] the lahaAp [q. v.] of the he-camel, (M, and Har p. 16,) which he protrudes from his mouth when he brays: (Har ubi suprá:) pl. XaqaAXiqu. (TA.) ― -b2- To this is likened the tongue of the chaste, or eloquent, and able speaker; himself being likened to the braying stallion-camel: (O:) and hence they say of an orator, or a preacher, that he is cuw XiqoXiqapK: (S:) one says likewise of an orator, or a preacher, that is loud in voice and skilful in speech, huwa Oahoratu AlXiqoXiqapi [lit. He is wide, or ample, in respect of the XqXqp]: (TA:) and one says, hadarato XiqoXiqatuhu (assumed tropical:) [meaning His utterance was sonorous and fluent]. (A and TA in art. hdr.) Orators, or preachers, are also termed XaqaAXiq [for cawuw XaqaAXiqa]: and one says, fulaAnN XiqoXiqapu qawomihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is the noble, and the chaste in speech, or eloquent, of his people. (M.) And in a trad. of 'Omar, (M, O, TA,) accord. to A'Obeyd and others, or of 'Alee accord. to Hr, (TA,) XaqaAXiq are assigned to the Devil, in his saying, UinRa kaviyrFA mina AlxuTabi mino XaqaAXiqi AlXRayoTaAni [lit. Verily many of the orations, or harangues, are from the XqAXq of the Devil]; because of the lying introduced into them. (M, O, * TA. *)

AlxuTobapu AlXRiqoXiqiyRapu c
AlxuTobapu AlXRiqoXiqiyRapu an appellation applied to a certain xuTobap [i. e. oration, or harangue, or sermon,] of 'Alee, because of his saying to Ibn- 'Abbás, (O, K,) on his having cut short his speech, (O,) in reply to a remark of the latter person upon his not having continued his speech uninterruptedly, tiloka XiqoXiqapN hadarato vumRa qarRato [That was a XqXqp that uttered a braying, then became still]. (O, K.)

XaAqRN c
XaAqRN Difficult, hard, distressing, grievous, afflicting, troubling, molesting, fatiguing, or wearying. (KL.) One says OamorN XaAqRN [An affair, or event, that is difficult, &c.]; from XaqRa EalayonaA AlOamoru. (Msb.) And XuqRapN XaAqRapN (S, Msb) A long journey [that is difficult, &c.]. (Msb.)

XAfRapN c
XAfRapN The spadix of a palm-tree, that has become a span in length; so called because it cleaves the envelope: pl. XawaAqRu. (M.)

OaXaqRu c
OaXaqRu, (S, M, O, K,) fem. XaqRaMCu, and pl. XuqRN, (K,) applied to a horse, Wide between the hind legs: (IAar, Th, T, O, * K, * TA:) and the fem. signifies wide in the OarofaAg [or groins, or similar parts]; (TA;) and is applied to a mare: (IDrd, O, TA:) and wide in the vulva; (IAar, O, K;) applied in this sense to a woman. (IAar, O, TA.) And OaXaqRu Almanoxirayoni, applied to a horse, Wide in the nostrils. (Lth, O, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (O, K,) Tall, or long; (T, S, M, O, K;) applied to a horse; (T, S, M, K;) thus expl. by As; (T, TA;) and so too applied to a man: (M, TA:) and the fem., as above, applied to a mare. (S.) ― -b3- And, applied to a horse, That goes to the right and left in his running, (JK, * O, K, TA, [in the CK, yasobiqu is erroneously put for yaXotaqRu, and in like manner in my MS. copy of the K, with the additional mistranscription of mn Eadowihi for fiI Eadowihi,]) as though (O, TA) leaning upon one of his sides: (JK, O, TA:) so says Lth; and he cites as an ex.,
watabaAzayotu kamaA yamoXiI AlOaXaqRu
[as though meaning And I moved my posteriors in walking, like as goes the horse that inclines to the right and left in his running: but this may be rendered and I stepped wide, like as does the tall, or long-bodied, horse]. (O, TA.)

maXaqRN c
maXaqRN [properly A place of cleaving, splitting, &c.: and hence a fissure, cleft, &c., like XaqRN: pl. maXaAqRu]: see XaqRN. ― -b2- maXaqRu AlEayoni [The slit of the eye]. (TA in art. HwS.)

maXaqRapN c
maXaqRapN [said in the S and K to be an inf. n. of XaqRa trans. by means of EalaI]: see XiqRN, in the last quarter of the paragraph, in two places.

1 XaqaOa c
1. XaqaOa, (S, K,) aor.
XaqaAa
, (K,) inf. n. Xaqo N and XuquwoCN, said of the naAb [or tush] (S, K) of a camel, (S,) It grew forth; (S, K;) it appeared; (TA;) as also XakaOa. (K in art. XkO.) [See also XaqRa.] XaAqiI, with the C softened [or changed into I], occurs in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh [for the part. n. XAqY]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XaqaOa raOosahu He divided his head; syn. XaqRahu: [meaning, his hair:] or he separated it (farRaqahu) [i. e. his hair] with the miXoqaMC [or comb]: (K:) or XaqaOa XaEarahu biAlmuXoTi, inf. n. XaqoCN, he separated his hair with the comb. (AZ, S.) ― -b2- And XaqaOahu, (S, K,) inf. n. XaqoCN, (S,) He hit his maXoqaO, i. e. the place of the parting of the hair of his head, (S, K,) with a staff, or stick. (S.)

UibilN XuwayoqiYapN c
UibilN XuwayoqiYapN Camels of the age when the naAb [or tush] grows forth: and so XuwayokiYapN: (As, TA:) [or XuwayokiyRapN, q. v. in art. Xwk.]

maXoqaON c
maXoqaON (S, K) and maXoqiYN↓, (Fr, O, TA,) like maforaqN and maforiqN, (O, TA,) The place of the parting of the hair of the head. (Fr, S, O, K.)

miXoqaON c
miXoqaON A comb; (IAar, S, K;) as also miXoqaMCN↓ and mXoqaOapN↓, and miXoqFA [or miXoqFI]. (K: the last also mentioned in the K in art. Xqw.)

maXoqiYN c
maXoqiYN: see maXoqaON.

miXoqaOapN c
miXoqaOapN: see miXoqaON. ― -b2- Also i. q. midoraApN; (K;) [i. e. A thing, or an iron instrument, with which the head is scratched; or a thing like a large needle, with which the female hair-dresser adjusts, or puts in order, the locks of a woman's hair;] or a piece of wood, or stick, [like a skewer,] which a woman inserts in her hair; or a horn prepared for that purpose (TA) [or for adjusting the locks of a woman's hair: see midoraApN].

miXoqaMCN c
miXoqaMCN: see miXoqaON.

1 XaqaHa AlnRaxolu c
1. XaqaHa AlnRaxolu, and XqRH↓, The palm-trees were, or became, goodly with their fruit. (TA.) [See also 4.] ＝ -A2- XaqaHa QllRehu fulaAnFA, [inf. n. XaqoHN,] accord. to AZ, is syn. with qabaHahu QllRehu [i. e. God removed such a one far from good, or prosperity, &c.; or may God remove &c.]: (TA:) [or, as may be inferred from what follows, the former of these verbs is used by some as an imitative sequent to the latter of them:] and accord. to Sb, (TA,) XaquHa, (K, TA,) inf. n. [XuqoHN and] XaqaAHapN, (TA,) is syn. with qabuHa [i. e. He, or it, was, or became, bad or evil, foul or ugly, &c.]: (K, TA:) [but in this case also it seems that the former of these verbs may be used by some as an imitative sequent to the latter of them: for] one says, qaboHFA lahu waXaqoHFA [May removal far from good, or prosperity, &c., betide him], (S, O, K,) in which XaqoHFA is an imitative sequent to qaboHFA, or syn. therewith; (S, K;) and [in like manner] quboHFA lahu waXuqoHFA; (O, K;) and, of a man, qabuH waXaquHa, inf. n. of the latter as above and in like manner of the former; (S;) and jaMCa biAlqabaAHapi waAlXRaqaAHapi [He did, or said, what was bad or evil, &c.]: (K:) and huwa qabiyHN XaqiyHN↓ [He is bad or evil, foul or ugly, &c.]: (S, * O, K: *) and qaEada maqobuwHFA maXoquwHFA↓ [He sat, or remained, far removed from good, or prosperity, &c.]: in like manner: (K:) but Sb intimates that XaqyiHN↓ is not an imitative sequent, by his stating that the Arabs say XaqiyHN wacamiymN [Bad, or evil, &c., and blamed, &c.; or, more probably, XaqiyHN wadamiymN, meaning foul and ugly]: (L, TA:) and [it is said that] XaqiyHN↓ signifies Recovering (naAqihN [for which Freytag appears to have read naAqap]) from disease; (O, K, TA;) and hence one says, fulaAnN qabiyHN XaqiyHN [as though meaning Such a one is unsightly, being just recovering from disease]: (TA:) and accord. to AZ, maXoqawHN↓ is [not an imitative sequent, but] syn. with maqobuwHN: (L, TA:) in the phrase abovementioned, maXoquwHFA is said in the 'Ináyeh to mean broken: or far removed: (TA:) or it means reviled. (O.) ＝ -A3- [As indicated above,] XaHaqahu, aor.
XaqaHa
, (Lh, O, K,) inf. n. XaqoHN, (Lh, O,) also
signifies He broke it. (Lh, O, K.) One says, laOaXoqaHanRaka XaqoHa Aljawozapi biAljanodali, i. e. I will assuredly break [or crush] thee [as in the breaking of the walnut] with stones: (O, TA: *) or I will assuredly extract all that thou hast [as in the extracting of the contents of the walnut by means of stones]: for XaqaHa Aljawozapa, inf. n. as above, means He extracted what was in the walnut. (TA.)

2 XaqRaHa
2: see 1, first sentence: and see also 4, in three places.

3 XAqHhu c
3. XAqHhu He reviled him; or contended with him in reviling; (K, TA;) and contended with him in annoyance. (O, TA.)

4 AXqH AlnRaxolu c
4. AXqH AlnRaxolu; (S, A, Mgh, O, K;) as also XqRH↓, (S, * A, Mgh, O,) inf. n. taXoqiyHN; (S;) i. q. OazohaI [meaning The palm-trees showed redness, or yellowness, in their fruit]: (S, A, O, K:) or their dates became altered from greenness to yellowness: (Mgh:) the former is said by As to be of the dial. of El-Hijáz: and ↓the latter verb is also said of the [kind of tree called] OaraAk, meaning it became coloured in its fruit. (TA.) And AXqH AltRamoru, (O,) or Albusoru, (K,) inf. n. UiXoqaAHN; (TA;) and XqRH↓, (O, K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) The dates, or the unripe dates, became coloured, (O, K,) red, or yellow: (O, TA:) or, as some say, became sweet. (TA.) The Prophet forbade the selling of dates before their becoming in this state. (S, * A, * O, TA.) ＝ -A2- AXqHhu He removed him far away. (O, K. *) ＝ -A3- OaqobiHo bihi waOaXoqiHo [app. How foul, or ugly, or the like, is he! as seems to be shown by what here follows]: IDrd cites,
OaqobiHo bihi mino waladK waOaXoqiHo
mivolu juraIRi Alkalobi laA balo OaqobaHo
[How foul is he, as offspring, and how ugly! like the little whelp of the dog; nay, rather, more foul!]. (O.)

XuqoHN c
XuqoHN [and inf. n. of XaquHa, q. v. ― -b2- And,] accord. to AZ, i. q. XuHRN [i. e. Niggardliness, &c.; or the being niggardly, &c.: see 1 in art. XH]. (TA.)

XaqoHapN c
XaqoHapN: see what next follows.

XuqoHapN c
XuqoHapN and XaqoHapN↓ An unripe date altering in redness, (K,) or altered to redness. (As, TA.) ― -b2- And the former signifies The [ruddy] colour termed Xuqorap. (O, K.)

HulRapN XuqaHiyRapN c
HulRapN XuqaHiyRapN A red [dress, or garment, such as is termed] HulRap: (K:) the latter word being a rel. n. from XuqoHapN meaning “ an unripe date altering to redness. ” (TA.)

XaqiyHN c
XaqiyHN: see 1, in three places.

OaXoqaHu c
OaXoqaHu Red; (TA;) or [of a ruddy colour;] i. q. OaXoqaru: (O, K, TA:) so says AHát. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ragowapN XaqoHaMCu [Forth, app. of milk,] that is not of a pure white hue, (O, K, TA,) but coloured. (TA.)

maXoquwHN c
maXoquwHN: see 1, in two places.

1 Xaqica c
1. Xaqica, aor.
Xaqaca
, (S, M, L, K,) inf. n. XaqacN, (S, M, L,) He scarcely ever, or never, slept, and had a malignant eye, affecting, or hurting, others, therewith: (S, M, L, K: *) or he had a strong, or powerful, eye, quickly affecting or hurting [others therewith]. (M, L, K.) ― -b2- And Xaqica, (S, M, L, K,) aor.
Xaqaca
; (K;) and Xaqaca, aor.
Xaqica
; (L, K;) He went away, (S, M, L, K,) and went far off, (S, L,) being driven away. (S, L, K.)

3 XAqchu c
3. XAqchu, (S, L,) inf. n. muXaAqacapN, (K,) He regarded him, or treated him, with enmity, or hostility. (S L, K.)

4 AXqchu c
4. AXqchu, (inf. n. UiXoqaAcN, L,) He drove him away. (S, M, L, K.)

XaqocN c
XaqocN: see XaqacaAnN, in three places.

XufocN c
XufocN: see XaqacaAnN, in four places: ― -b2- and see also XaqacN.

XiqocN c
XiqocN: see XaqacaAnN, in three places.

XaqacN c
XaqacN: see XaqacaAnN. ― -b2- maA bihi XaqacN walaA naqacN There is not in him any motion. (IAar, S, L.) ― -b3- And, (L, K, in the CK mA bh XaqocN wlA naqocN,) as also mA wlA nuqocu bh XuqocN↓, (K,) There is not in it (namely, a commodity, or household furniture, L) any fault, or defect: and there is not in it (namely, language, or speech, L) any defect, imperfection, or unsoundness. (L, K. *) ― -b4- And maA lahu XaqacN walaA naqacN He possesses not anything. (L, K.) ― -b5- And maA duwnahu XaqacN walaA naqacN There is not anything to be feared, nor anything to be disliked, in the way to the attainment thereof. (Meyd, TA.)

XaqicN c
XaqicN: see XaqacaAnN, in six places.

XuqacN c
XuqacN: see XaqacaAnN, in two places.

XiqacN c
XiqacN: see XaqacaAnN, in the latter half.

XiqocapN c
XiqocapN and XaqicapN: see XaqacaAnN, near the end; the latter, in two places.

XaqacaI c
XaqacaI: see what next follows.

EuqaAbN XaqocaMCu c
EuqaAbN XaqocaMCu An eagle vehemently hungry, (S, M, L, K,) and eager in seeking food; (M, L;) as also XaqacaI↓. (K.) A poet likens a horse thereto. (M, L.)

XiqocaAnN c
XiqocaAnN, as a sing. n.: see XaqacaAnN (of which it is also a pl.), in two places, near the end.

XaqacaAnN c
XaqacaAnN One who scarcely ever, or never, sleeps; (S, M, L, K;) as also XaqicN↓; (S, M, K;) and who has a malignant eye, (S, M,) affecting, or hurting, others therewith; as also XaqicN↓ (S, M, K, in the TA XaqocN,) and XaqiycN↓: (M:) or who has a strong, or powerful, eye, quickly affecting or hurting [others therewith]; (M, L, K;) as also XaqicN↓ and XaqiycN↓: (M:) and AlEayoni Xaqicu↓ one who scarcely ever, or never, sleeps; whom drowsiness does not overcome. (T, L.) ― -b2- Also Driven away, and remote; and so XaqicN↓. (L.) ― -b3- And XaqacaAnapN A light-spirited woman: (Th, M, L:) foul, or obscene, in her speech; clamorous, and foul-tongued. (T, L.) ＝ -A2- Also The male chameleon; (M, L, K;) and so XaqicN↓ and XiqocN↓ and XuqocN↓: or all these words signify a slender and compact male chameleon, with a small head, that cleaves to the trunk of the kind of tree called EiDaAh: (M, L:) pl. XiqocaAnN (M, L, K) and XaqaAcaI: (M:) the former pl. like kirowaAnN, pl. of karawaAnN; (L;) and also used as a sing., meaning a male chameleon; (Th, M;) thus used by a poetess; (M:) also XiqocN↓ (S, M, L, K) and XuqocN↓ (M, L) and XuqacN↓ (M, L, K) and XaqocN↓ (K) the young one of a chameleon: (Lh, S, M, L, K:) pl. XiqocaAnN (S, M, L, K) and XaqaAcaI: (M, L, K:) the former pl. like SinowaAnN, pl. of SinowN. (S.) A poet says, describing asses,
raOati AlXRaqaAcaI taSoTaliI
faraEato bihaA HatRaI UicaA
And they pastured therein until the heat became vehement and they saw the male chameleons thirsty, desiring to go to water, and repairing to the sun: some say, that XqAcI here signifies moths, (faraAX), but this is a mistake. (M, L.) XiqocaAnN also signifies The animals called DabR and waral and TuHan and saAmRu OaboraS and dasRaAsap: and the sing. is XiqocapN↓: (M, L:) or any small animals that creep or walk upon the earth, and venomous or noxious reptiles and the like: (M, L, K:) sing. XaqicapN↓ (M, L) and XiqacN↓, (M,) or XaqicN↓, (L,) and XuqacN↓, (M,) or XaqacN↓; (L;) but it does not appear how XaqicapN↓ can be a sing. of XiqocaAnN unless the augmentative letter be regarded as elided. (M, L.) ― -b2- Also The wolf; (M, L, K;) and so XaqocaAnN↓ (Th, M, L, K) and XuqocN↓, (M, L,) or XiqocN↓, (K,) or XaqocN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The hawk; syn. SaqorN; (M, L;) and so XaqocaAnN↓ (Th, M, L) and XuqocN↓, (M, L,) or XaqocN↓. (TA.) ― -b4- And XiqocaAnN [the pl.] also signifies The young ones of the kinds of birds called HbaAraI and qaTFA (M, L, K) and the like. (M, L.)

XaqiycN c
XaqiycN: see XaqacaAnN, in two places.

TarodN miXoqacN c
TarodN miXoqacN A driving far away. (M, L.)

1 Xaqira c
1. Xaqira, aor.
Xaqara
, inf. n. XaqarN (M, L, Msb, K [in the CK and TA XaqorN, which is evidently wrong,]) and XuqorapN, (Lth, K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (M;) and Xaqura; and AiXoqarRa↓; (M, K;) He was, or became, of the colour termed XuqorapN. (M, L, Msb, K.)

9 UiXoqarRa
9: see 1.

XaqorN c
XaqorN: see XuquwrN.

XaqirN c
XaqirN [The red, or blood-coloured, anemone;] i. q. XaqaAYiqu AlnRuEomaAni: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) it is not a sweet-scented flower: (Msb:) n. un. with p; (S, M, Msb, K;) pl. [of the n. un.] XaqiraAtN: (K:) as
also XuqRaArN↓ and XaqiraAnN↓, (so in some copies of the K,) the latter so written by IDrd and Sgh, and thought by IDrd to be a place or a plant, (TA,) or XuqoraAnN↓, (so in some copies of the K and in the TA,) and XuqRaAraI↓ and XuqaAraI↓: (K:) or XaqirN is the name of a certain other plant, not the XqAYq, but red like it: (M, * K, * TA:) or it signifies cinnabar: (A:) or XaqirapN has this signification, (T, K,) as well as that first assigned to it above: (K:) and accord. to AHn, (M, TA,) XuqRaAraI↓ is the name of a certain plant (S, M, TA) that grows is sands, having a pungent odour, which is tasted in the flavour of milk: and he adds that, accord. to some, it is the same as the Xaqir; but that this opinion is not well founded: (M, TA:) it is also said that it is a certain plant having a flower of a dingy red colour, the seed, or grain, of which is called ximoximN: (TA:) and that XuqRaAraI↓ (M, TA) and XuqaAraI↓, (M,) or XuqRaArN↓, (TA,) are names of a certain plant, having a flower of a colour somewhat of that termed XukolapN, with slender, or delicate, dust-coloured leaves, which grows in the manner of qaDob [a kind of trefoil], is approved in pasturage, and grows only in fruitful years. (M, TA.)

jaMCa biAlXRuqari waAlbuqari c
jaMCa biAlXRuqari waAlbuqari: see jMC biAlSRuqari waAlbuqari, in art. Sqr.

XuqorapN c
XuqorapN The colours described in the explanations of the epithet OaXoqaru, below. (S, M, Msb, &c.)

XaqiraAnN c
XaqiraAnN, or XuqoraAnN: see XaqirN.

XaqirRaAqN c
XaqirRaAqN and its vars.: see in art. Xqrq.

XaquwrN c
XaquwrN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

XuquwrN c
XuquwrN (AHeyth, Fr, A'Obeyd, S, K) and XaquwrN↓ (AHeyth, As, Abu-l-Jarráh, S, K) A want; or a needful, or requisite, thing, affair, or business: (S, K:) or the former signifies wants: (Ham p. 716:) A'Obeyd says that the former word is the more correct, because XuquwrN signifies things, or affairs, that cleave to the heart, disquieting it; and is pl. of XaqorN↓; and that XaquwrN↓, with fet-h, has the signification of an epithet [meaning cleaving to the heart and disquieting it]: (S:) or, accord. to some, this latter signifies grief, mourning, sorrow, or sadness; disquietude of mind: or disquietude of mind that causes one to be sleepless: the former is also expl. as signifying a man's case, and his secret: and ↓both are also said to signify tidings: and a man's state, or condition. (TA.) One says, Oaxobarotuhu biXuquwriI I acquainted him with my want; like as one says OafoDayotu Uilayohi biEujariI wabujariI: (S:) or I acquainted him with my tidings. (TA.) And OafoDayotu Uilayohi biXuquwriI I acquainted him with my case, and with what I kept secret from others; (TA;) and so nafaDotu lahu XuquwriI: (Ham p. 716:) or I revealed to him my secret, and acquainted him with all my affairs. (Mgh.) And bavRahu Xaquwrahu↓, and Xuquwrahu, He complained to him of his state, or condition. (M, TA.)

XuqaAraI c
XuqaAraI: see XaqirN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also jaMCa biAlSRuqari waAlbuqari, in art. Sqr.

XuqRaArN c
XuqRaArN: see XaqirN, in two places.

XuqRaAraI c
XuqRaAraI: see XaqirN, in three places.

OaXoqaru c
OaXoqaru, applied to a man, [Of a ruddy complexion combined with fairness: or] of a clear ruddy complexion, with the outer skin inclining to white: (S:) or having a red, or ruddy, tinge, over a white, or fair, complexion: (M, Msb, K:) and applied to a horse, [of a sorrel colour;] of a clear red colour, (S, IF, Msb,) or of a red colour inclining to [the dull red hue called] mugorapN, (M, K,) with a red mane and tail: (S, M, K:) when the mane and tail are black, the epithet kumayotN [meaning bay, or dark bay, or brown,] is applied to the horse: (S:) the AXqr is said to be the best of horses: (IAar, M: [but it is said in Har p. 399 to be regarded by the Arabs as of evil omen:]) and applied to a camel, intensely red: (S:) or of a colour resembling that of a horse thus termed: (M:) fem. XaqoraMCu: and pl. XuqorN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, applied to blood, That has become thick, (maA SaAra EalaqFA, M, Msb, TA,) and not been overspread with dust. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And the fem., XaqoraMCu, is used as [a subst.] signifying Fire. (Ham p. 718.)

XaqirRaAqN c
XaqirRaAqN and XiqirRaAqN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the former accord. to IAar, (Th, TA,) the latter accord. to Fr, (TA,) but disallowed by IKt, and asserted by him to be a mispronunciation of the vulgar, (Msb,) and XiqoraAqN, (Msb, K,) and XaqoraAqN, (accord. to the CK,) and, (S, O, K,) as they sometimes said, (S, O,) XiriqoraAqN, (S, O, K,) and XaraqoraAqN, and XaraqoraqN, (K,) [the first and second now applied to The green wood-pecker, picus viridis: and to the common roller, coracias garrula:] a certain bird, (S, O, Msb, K,) well known, (K,) among the Arabs, (Fr, TA,) called Oaxoyal, (Fr, S, O, Msb, TA,) [a name likewise now applied to the green wood-pecker,] and regarded by the Arabs as of evil omen; (S;) less than the pigeon, the colour of which is green, and the beak black, and having blackness in the extremities and exterior of its wings: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, the XaqirRaAq is with the Arabs the OaxoTab [q. v.]: (TA:) accord. to the K, or XqrRAq and XrqrAq accord. to Lth, (TA,) a certain bird speckled, or spotted, with green and red and white (K, TA) and black, (TA,) and found, accord. to the copies of the K, in the land of the Haram, but correctly, as in the words of Lth, bArD Aljrm, thus, with j, [perhaps rightly biAlOaroDi Aljaromi, in the land that is hot, or very hot,] in the places in which palm-trees grow; of the size of the hudohud [or hoopoe]: accord. to Lh, XqrRAq is of the measure fElRAl: XrqrAq is mentioned by J and Sgh [as well as in the K] in the present art.; but should, properly, be mentioned under the head of Xrqrq, as it is in the L. (TA.)

2 XqRShu c
2. XqRShu, (L, TA,) inf. n. taXoqiySN, (L, Mgh, K,) He divided it into parts, or portions: (Mgh:) or he cut it up, and separated its members (A, L, K *) into just portions among the sharers; (L, K; *) namely, a slaughtered animal, (K,) or particularly a slaughtered sheep or goat, and a pig: (L, A, TA:) or he divided it (namely, a pig,) into parts or portions, and members, for eating and selling. (Mgh.) Hence the trad. mano baAEa Alxamora faloyuXaqiSi AlxanaAziyra (L, A) He who sells wine, let him cut up swine and divide their members, as is done to a sheep or goat when its flesh is sold: meaning, he who holds the selling of wine to be lawful, let him hold the selling of swine to be so; for they are equally forbidden. (L, TA.)

XiqoSN c
XiqoSN A piece, or part, of a thing; (S, M, Mgh, Msb;) as also XaqiySN↓: (M, Mgh:) or a little, of much; (M, TA;) as also ↓the latter: (IDrd, M, K:) and ↓the latter, a little, or paltry, thing: (TA:) and the former, a piece of land: (S:) or a share; syn. sahomN, (A, K,) or HaZRN, (M,) and naSiybN, (A, Mgh, K,) and XirokN, (A, K,) which signifies the same as naSiybN; (Sh, on the authority of Khálid;) as also XaqiySN↓; (Sh, M, Mgh, K;) like niSofN and naSiyfN: (M:) as, for instance, in property; (IDrd;) and of a slave: (TA:) or a certain share not divided: (EshSháfi'ee, TA:) or if divided it may also be thus called: (Az, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXoqaASN (M, Msb) and [of mult.] XiqaASN. (M, TA.)

XaqiySN c
