XaqiySN: see XiqoSN, throughout. ＝ -A2- Also A sharer, or partner. (S, A, K.) You say, huwa XaqiySI He is my sharer, or partner, (S, A,) in a piece of land. (S.) ＝ -A3- And A fleet, or swift, and excellent horse: (K:) but an epithet not known to Lth. (TA.)

miXoqaSN c
miXoqaSN A broad naSol [or iron head] (IDrd, Msb, K) of an arrow: (IDrd:) or an arrow having such a nSl, (Lth, IF, K,) with which wild animals are shot; (Lth;) but Az says that this explanation is at variance with what has been heard from the Arabs: (TA:) or it signifies, (M,) or signifies also, (K,) a long nSl; (M, K;) not a broad one: (M:) or an arrow having such a nSl; (M;) with which wild animals are shot: (K:) or a long and broad nSl: (S:) or it is of half the size of a nSl, and is worthless; children play with it, and it is the worst kind of arrow [-head], and is used for shooting at objects of the chase and any other thing: (TA:) pl. maXaAqiSu. (S.)

muXaqiSN c
muXaqiSN A butcher. (A, K.)

1 XaqiIa c
1. XaqiIa, (S, Msb, K,) originally Xaqiwa, (S, TA,) aor.
Xaqawa
, (S, Msb,) dual thereof yaXoqayaAni, (S,) inf. n. XaqaAwapN and XiqaAwapN, (S, * K,) the latter accord. to a reading of the Kur xxiii. 108, (S,) and XaqaMCN and XiqowapN and XaqowapN (S, * K) and XaqFA, (K.) or the last of these is the inf. n., and XaqaAwapN and XiqowapN [and the rest, none of which is expressly specified as an inf. n. in the S,] are simple substs., (Msb,) He
was, or became, unprosperous, unfortunate, unhappy, or miserable; (S, Msb, TA;) XaqiIa being contr. of saEida; (Msb;) and XaqaAwapN &c. contr. of saEaAdapN: (S, TA:) or he was, or became, in a state of straitness, distress, adversity, or difficulty. (Az, K, TA.) [See also XaqaAwapN below.] ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He suffered, or experienced, fatigue, (TA, and Ksh and Bd and Jel in xx. 1,) fiI kacaA [in such a thing]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XaqaAhu: see 3: ― -b2- and 4.

3 XAqAhu c
3. XAqAhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. muXaAqaApN (S, TA) and XiqaMCN, (TA,) He laboured, strove, or struggled, with him, to prevail, or overcome, (S, K, TA,) in war, or battle, and the like; (K, TA;) so in the T; (TA;) he struggled, or contended, with, or against, the difficulty, or trouble, or inconvenience, that he experienced from him; (S, * TA;) syn. EaAlajahu; (K, TA;) or maArasahu; and EaAnaAhu. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- And XAqAhu faXaqaAhu↓, aor. of the latter verb
Xaquwa
, He endeavoured to surpass him in mutual labouring, or striving, or struggling, to prevail, or overcome, &c., (gaAlabahu fiI AlXRiqaMCi, [in the CK, fI AlXRaqACi, but the former seems to be the right reading, and may be best rendered in the mutual striving against difficulty,]) and he surpassed him [therein]. (K. [In the S, XaAqaAniI fulaAnN faXaqawotuhu, aor. OaXoquwhu; and only the latter verb as thus used is there explained.]) ― -b3- muXaAqaApN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The treating [one] with hardness, harshness, or illnature. (TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) The vying, one with another, in patience, or endurance: a rájiz says,
UicaA yuXaAqiI AlSRaAbiraAni lamo yarivo
yakaAdu mino DaEofi AlquwaI laA yanobaEivo
[When the two patient ones vie in endurance, he does not lag behind, almost, by reason of the weakness of powers, failing to hasten in pace]: he means a camel vying with the attendant thereof in endurance of going. (TA.)

4 AXqAhu QllRehu c
4. AXqAhu QllRehu God caused him to be unprosperous, unfortunate, unhappy, or miserable; contr. of OasoEadahu: (S, * Msb, TA:) or God caused him to be in a state of straitness, distress, adversity, or difficulty: and so XaqaAhu↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- And AXqI He combed. (AZ, K. [See miXoqFI.])

XiqowapN c
XiqowapN an inf. n. of XaqiIa, as also XaqowapN: (S, * K:) or a simple subst. (Msb.)

XaqiIRN c
XaqiIRN Unprosperous, unfortunate, unhappy, or miserable: (S, Msb, TA:) [or in a state of straitness, distress, adversity, or difficulty: (see its verb:)] pl. OaXoqiyaMCu. (TA.) walamN Oakuno biduEaAYika rabRi XaqiyRFA, in the Kur [xix. 4, And I have not been, in supplicating Thee, my Lord, unprosperous], means I have been one whose prayer has been answered. (TA.)

XaqaAwapN c
XaqaAwapN an inf. n. of XaqiIa; (S, * K;) or a simple subst.; (Msb;) signifying Unprosperousness, &c.; [see its verb;] contr. of saEaAdapN: (S, Er-Rághib, TA:) it is of two kinds; OuxoraAwiyRapN [relating to the world to come] and dunoyaAwiyRapN [relating to the present world]: and the latter is of three kinds; nafosiyRapN [relating to the soul] and badaniyRapN [relating to the body] and xaArijiyRapN [relating to external circumstances]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Fatigue; syn. taEabN; but the latter has a more general signification; every XqAwp being tEb, but every tEb is not XqAwp. (TA.)

OaXoqaI c
OaXoqaI [More, and most, unprosperous, &c. ― -b2- And] (tropical:) More [and most] fatigued. (TA.)

miXoqFI c
miXoqFI A comb: a dial. var. of miXoqaON. (AZ, K.)

1 XaqaI c
1. XaqaI, inf. n. XaqoIN, said of the naAb [or tush] of a camel, It grew forth: a dial. var. of XaqaOa. (K in art. Xqw [but belonging to the present art.: mentioned in the TA, as not in the K, on the authority of ISd].) ― -b2- [Freytag states, as on the authority of Abu-l-'Alà, that XaqaI is used for XaqRa He clave, or split, &c.: ― -b3- and that Reiske has explained it as signifying He opened the mouth with a wide grinning (“ amplo rictu ”).]

XaAqK c
XaAqK A long prominence, or projecting portion, or ledge, (HayodN TaAliEN TawiylN,) of a mountain, (K, TA,) that cannot be ascended: (TA:) by rule it should be with C [i. e. XaAqiYN, as being derived from XaqaOa]: (Sgh, TA:) pl. XawaAqiI (K [correctly XawaAqK]) and XuqoyaAnN. (TA. [Mentioned in the K in art. Xqw, but belonging to the present art.])

1 XakRa c
1. XakRa is intrans. by itself, and trans. by means of the particle fI: ― -b2- one says XakRa AlOamoru, aor. yaXukRu [contr. to analogy in the case of an intrans. verb of this class], inf. n. XakRN, The thing, or case, or affair, was, or became, dubious, or confused: (Msb:) ― -b3- and XakRa fiyhi, (MA, K,) first pers. Xakakotu fyh, (S, Msb,) aor. as above, (JM, PS, &c.,) and so the inf. n., (MA, &c.,) He doubted, wavered or vacillated in opinion, or was uncertain, respecting it; (MA, Msb, and so accord. to explanations of XakRN [q. v. infrà] in the S and Msb and K &c.;) syn. AirotaAba; (Msb;) and tXkRk↓ signifies the same. (S, K.) ― -b4- XakRa EalaIRa AlOamoru means XaqRa [i. e. The case, or affair, was difficult, hard, distressing, &c., to me]: (O, TA:) or, as some say, [was such that] I doubted (Xakakotu) respecting it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XakRa said of a camel, (IAar, S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) He limped, or halted; or had a slight lameness, (IAar, S, TA,) of his hind leg: (IAar, TA:) or his arm stuck to his side, (K, TA,) and he had a slight lameness in consequence thereof: (TA:) and AXtkR↓, likewise said of a camel, he had a slight lameness; (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA;) like XakRa. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) ― -b2- XakRN also signifies The cleaving or sticking [of a thing to another thing]. (S, O, TA.) So in a verse of Aboo-Dahbal El-Jumahee cited voce yalabN. (S.) And one says, XakRati AlrRaHimu The relationship was, or became, closely united. (O, TA. [See raHimN XaAkRapN, voce XaAkRN.]) ― -b3- XakRa fiI AlsRilaAHi, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He put on [or around him,] or attired himself with, the arms, or weapons, completely, not leaving any of them; (TA;) [as though] he entered amid them. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- Xakakotuhu biAlrRumoHi, (S, O, Msb, in the K XakRahu,) and biAlsRahomi, and the like, aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Msb, TA,) I pierced, or transpierced, him, or it, (TaEanotuhu, Msb, or xazaqotuhu, O, and in like manner in the TA, but in my copies of the S xaraqotuhu [meaning I made a hole in him, or it], and thus in one place in the TA, and AinotaZamotuhu, S O, and in like manner in the K,) with the spear, (S, O, Msb, K,) and with the arrow, &c.: (TA:) but IDrd says that, accord. to some, XakRN is only by the conjoining two things with an arrow or a spear: (O, TA:) [thus,] faXakRa rijolahu maEa rikaAbihi means And he clave and transpierced his leg, or foot, together with his stirrup. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Xakakotu Uilayohi AlbilaAda I traversed, or crossed, or cut through, the countries, or districts, to him. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And XukRa Ealayih AlvRawobu The garment was put [or drawn] together upon him, and fastened with a thorn or a wooden pin: or was let down, or made to hang down, upon him. (TA.) ― -b4- XakRuwA buyuwtahumo They placed their tents in one row, or series, (O, Msb, K,) in one regular order, (T, TA,) near together. (Msb.) ― -b5- Hence; XakRuwA AlOaroHaAma They made the relationships to be closely connected. (Msb.) And XukRa He was made, or asserted, to be connected with the lineage of another. (IAar, O.) ― -b6- And Xakakotuhu said of anything means I drew and joined, or adjoined, it [to another thing]. (Msb.) [And I infixed it in, or thrust it into, another thing.] ― -b7- maA XakRa kafiI xaliyluhaA, [or, more probably, mA XukRa,] a phrase in a verse of El-Farezdak,] in which it forms an apodosis,] means maA qaArana [i. e., app., Its friend (the sword, or the spear, both of which are meanings of Alxaliyl,) would not be conjoined (or grasped) with my hand]. (TA.) ― -b8- XakRa AlvRawoba He (the sewer) made the stitch-holes far apart [in sewing the garment, or piece of cloth]. (O, TA.) [Thus the verb has two contr. meanings.] ＝ -A4- Xakikotu Uilayohi, with kesr, and Xakikotuhu, (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, and so in the K accord. to the TA, as also in the TK, in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K Xakakotuhu and Alyh,) I inclined to him, or it; or trusted to, or relied upon, him, or it, so as to be, or become, easy, or quiet, in mind; or leaned, rested, or relied, upon him, or it; syn. rakanotu. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

2 XkRknI fiyhi c
2. XkRknI fiyhi, (S, O, K, *) inf. n. taXokiykN, (O,) He made me to doubt, to waver or vacillate in opinion, or to be uncertain, respecting it; (S, K, TA;) he threw me, or made me to fall, into doubt, &c., respecting it. (O.)

5 taXakRaRa
5: see the first paragraph.

8 UiXotakaka
8: see the first paragraph.

XakRN c
XakRN [used as a subst.] signifies Doubt; (Msb; [see 1;]) or the contr. of yaqiynN; (S, O, Msb, K;) by which explanation is meant a wavering or
vacillation in opinion between two things, whether they be equal [in probability] or such that one of them outweighs [therein] the other; or, as the expositors explain its meaning in the Kur x. 94, uncertainty: (Msb:) or a wavering or vacillation in opinion, between two inconsistent things, without making either of them to outweigh the other in the estimation of him who conceives the XakR: or, as some say, a pausing, or hesitation, between two extremes that are equal [in probability], without the mind's inclining to either of them: when one of them is made to outweigh, without the other's being rejected, it is ZanRN: (KT:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it is the alternation, or confusedness, of two inconsistent things, in the judgment of a man, and their being equal: this is sometimes because of there being two indications, equal in his judgment, of the two inconsistent things; or of there being no indication thereof: and sometimes it relates to the question whether a thing be, or be not; and sometimes, to the question of what kind it is; and sometimes, to some of its qualities; and sometimes, to the accident that is the cause of its being: it is a species of jahol; but is more special than this; for jhl is sometimes the utter nonexistence of knowledge of the two inconsistent things; so that every XkR is jhl, but every jhl is not XkR: (TA:) accord. to some, the primary meaning is a state of commotion, or disturbance, of the heart and mind: (Msb:) pl. XukuwkN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence, yawomu AlXRaki The day of which one doubts whether it be the last of one month or the first of the next month: and generally, whether it be the last of Shaabán or the first of Ramadán; and to fast on this day is forbidden.] ＝ -A2- Also A small crack in a bone. (K.) ― -b2- And A seam, or line of sewing, of a garment. (L in art. SwH.) ― -b3- [And accord. to Freytag, A coat of mail composed of narrow rings: but he names no authority for this.] ＝ -A3- And [Arsenic;] a certain medicament, that destroys rats; brought from Khurásán, from the mines of silver; (K, TA;) of two kinds, (TA,) white and yellow; (K, TA;) now known by the name of samRu AlfaOori [ratsbane]. (TA.)

XikRN c
XikRN A covering (HulRap) that is put upon the backs of the two curved extremities of the bow: (K:) so says ISd. (TA.)

XakRapN c
XakRapN [an inf. n. of un.] A single piercing through two men on a horse. (Ham p. 271.)

XukRapN c
XukRapN i. q. XuqRapN: (O, K:) so in the saying, UinRah labaEiydu AlXRukRapi [Verily he is one whose region to which he directs himself is far distant]. (O.)

XikRapN c
XikRapN Arms, or weapons, (S, K, TA,) that are worn. (TA.) ― -b2- And A broad piece of wood, (K,) or small broad piece of wood, (S, O,) that is put into the hole (xurot) [in which is inserted the end of the handle] of the axe, or adz, and the like, in order to narrow it. (IDrd, S, O, K.) ＝ -A2- rajulN muxotalifu AlXRikRapi means A man discordant in natural dispositions. (TA.)

XakikN c
XakikN A camel having a slight lameness; that limps, or halts. (TA.)

XukukN c
XukukN, with two dammehs, [a pl. of which the sing., in the sense here indicated, is not mentioned,] i. q. OadoEiyaMCu [Persons who make a claim in respect of relationship; or who claim to be sons of persons not their fathers; or who are claimed as sons by persons not their father; or adopted sons: pl. of daEiIRN]. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- [Also said to be pl. of XakiykapN, q. v.]

XikaAkN c
XikaAkN Tents arranged in a row: (O, K:) one says, DarabuwA buyuwtahumo XikaAkFA They pitched their tents in one row: but accord. to Th, it is sikaAkFA, [q. v.], from AlsRikRapu. (TA.)

XakuwkN c
XakuwkN (tropical:) A she-camel of which one doubts whether she be fat or not (S, K, TA) in her hump, (K, TA,) by reason of the abundance of her fur, wherefore her hump is felt: (S, TA:) pl. XukRN. (K.)

XukuwkN c
XukuwkN Sides; syn. jawaAnibu. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, TA.) [Perhaps pl. of XakaAkapN (q. v.), next after which it is mentioned in the O; like as SuliIRN (originally SuluwIN) is pl. of SalaAyapN.]

XakaAkapN c
XakaAkapN A region, quarter, or tract, syn. naAHiyapN, of the earth. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

XakiykapN c
XakiykapN A party, sect, or distinct body or class, (AA, S, O, K,) of men: (AA, S, O:) pl. XakaAYiku; (AA, S;) [and app. XikakN also, for,] accord. to IAar, XikakN signifies distinct bodies of soldiers. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting or conduct or the like: (IDrd, O, K:) thus in the saying, daEohu EalaI Xakiykatihi [Leave thou him intent on pursuing his way, &c.]: (IDrd, O:) pl. XakaAYiku (IDrd, O, K) and XukukN, (so in copies of the K,) or XikakN; if the latter of these two, extr. [with respect to analogy]. (TA.) ― -b2- And Natural disposition; syn. xuluqN. (TK, as from the K. [The only reading that I find in copies of the K is with H in the place of x, i. e. Haloq; and thus, but without any vowel-sign, in the TA: but I think that the right reading is evidently that in the TK.]) ＝ -A3- Also The [kind of basket called] salRap in which are [put] fruits. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, *) ＝ -A4- And [the pl.] XakaAYiku signifies The pieces of wood with which, they being joined together, are formed the tent-like tops of the vehicles called hawaAdij [pl. of hawodajN]. (AA, O, TA.)

XukukRapN c
XukukRapN, applied to a woman, meaning Just in proportion, or beautiful, and slender; or light, or active, in her work; and clever; is vulgar. (TA.)

XakRiIRN c
XakRiIRN, (so in the O, occurring there in three instances,) or XukRiIRN, (thus in the K, [but if this were the right reading, the rule of the author would require him to add “ with damm, ” therefore I suppose it to have been mistranscribed in an early copy of the K,]) applied to a lijaAm [i. e. bit, or bridle], Difficult. (O, K.) [See also XakRiIRN in art. Xkw and XkI.]

XakRaAkN c
XakRaAkN: see XaAkRN.

XakoXakapN c
XakoXakapN Sharp arms or weapons: (IAar, O, K:) or the sharpness of arms or weapons: (K:) or the latter should be the meaning accord. to analogy. (O.)

XaAkRN c
XaAkRN [act. part. n. of XakRa]. ― -b2- rajulN XaAkRu AlsRilaAHi and XaAkRN fiI AlsRilaAHi [A man completely armed]: the former expl. as meaning a man wearing a complete set of arms, or weapons: [pl. XukRaAkN, agreeably with analogy:] you say qawomN XukRaAkN fiI AlHadiydi [a people, or party, completely clad in sets of iron arms or weapons]. (S, O. [In one of my copies of the S, biAlHadiydi.]) [Accord. to the TA, one says mino qawomK XukRaAkK rajulN XakRaAkN↓: but XakRaAkN seems evidently to be a mistranscription for XaAkRN. See also XaAku AlsRilaAHi and XaAkiI AlsRilaAHi in arts. Xwk and Xkw.] ― -b3- raHimN XaAkRapN Near relationship. (O, TA. [See XakRati AlrRaHimu.]) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

XaAkRapN c
XaAkRapN A tumour in the fauces; (O, K;) mostly in children: (O:) pl. XawaAkRu: or, accord. to Abu-lJarráh, the sing. of XawaAkRu is XaAkRN↓, meaning the tumour. (TA.)

miXakRN c
miXakRN The thong with which the coat of mail is [in certain parts thereof] conjoined (yuXakRu bihi): 'Antarah says,
wamiXakRi saAbigapK hatakotu furuwjahaA
biAlsRayofi Eano HaAmiI AlHaqiyqapi muEolami
(O, TA:) [but in the EM it is masakRi, thus with s, and with fet-h to the m; a word which I do not find in any lexicon: it is said that] msk signifies a coat of mail narrow in the rings: and the poet means, And of many an ample coat of mail [narrow in the rings] have I rent open the middle parts with the sword, from over a man who was the defender of those who, or that which, it was his duty to defend, who was pointed to as being the cavalier of the army. (EM p. 243.)

OamorN maXokuwkN c
OamorN maXokuwkN [for maXokuwkN fiyhi] An affair, or a case, in which there is doubt. (TA.) ＝ -A2- minobarN maXokuwkN e. q. maXoduwd [i. e. A pulpit made firm or strong &c.]. (TA. [See also masokuwk.])

1 Xakadahu c
1. Xakadahu, aor.
Xakuda
. (S, L) and
Xakida
, (L,) inf. n. XakodN; (S, L, K;) and AXkdhu↓, (M, L,) but this latter, which is erroneously said in the copies of the K to be syn. with XakRada, instead of Xakada, is, accord. to ISd, not of high authority; (TA;) He gave him: (S, L, K:) or he gave him a thing as a free gift. (L.)

4 AXkdhu c
4. AXkdhu He gave him of dates on their being cut, and of wheat on its being reaped. (L.) He gave him of a heap of reaped corn on the occasion of measuring, and of the bundles (Huzam) [of corn] on the occasion of reaping: of the dial. of ElYemen. (L.) He gave him food to eat, or milk to drink, after it had been deposited in the house or tent. (L.) ― -b2- See also 1.

10 AstXkd c
10. AstXkd He sought, or demanded, what is termed Xukod [q. v.]. (L.) ― -b2- And jaMCa yasotaXokiduniI He came seeking, or demanding, of me Xukod; meaning what is given of a heap of reaped corn on the occasion of measuring, and of the bundle (Huzam) [of corn] on the occasion of reaping: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (L.)

XukodN c
XukodN A gift: (S, L, K:) or a free gift: pl. OaXokaAdN. (L.) A recompense. (L.) [See XukomN in two places.] What is given of dates when they are cut, and of wheat when it is reaped. (L.) What is given of a heap of reaped corn on the occasion of the measuring, and of the bundles (Huzam) [of corn] on the occasion of the reaping: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (L.) Travelling-provisions with which one is furnished, consisting of milk, or [the preparation of dried curd called] OaqiT, or clarified butter, or dates, and with which one goes forth from the abodes of a people. (L.) And Meat and drink deposited in a house or tent. (L.)

1 Xakara lahu c
1. Xakara lahu, and Xakarahu, (S, Mgh, K,) but the former is the more chaste, (S,) and the latter is for Xakara niEomatahu, (A,) aor.
Xakura
, (TA,) inf. n. XukorN and XukoraAnN (S, A, * Msb, K) and XukuwrN, (S, K) which last, in the Kur lxxvi. 9, may be either an inf. n. or pl. of XukorN [used as a simple subst.], (S,) He thanked him; or praised, eulogized, or commended, him, for a benefit or benefits: (S:) he was grateful, or thankful, to him; or he acknowledged his beneficence, and spoke of it largely: (S, * K: [but in the S, the verb in the former sense has XukorN only for its inf. n., and it is implied that in the latter sense it has for its inf. n. only XukoraAnN, as will be seen below:]) and Xakara lilRehi, and Xakara QllReha, (Lh, Msb, K,) which latter is less common than the former, and even disallowed by As in prose, though allowed by him in verse, (Msb,) and Xakara biQllRehi and Xakara niEomapa QllRehi, and Xakara biniEomapi QllRehi, (Lh, K,) and Xakara lilRehi niEomatahu, (A,) inf. n. XukorN and XukoraAnN (Msb) [and XukuwrN], He thanked, or praised, God for his beneficence: (A:) he was grateful, or thankful, to God; or acknowledged his beneficence, and spoke of it largely: (K:) he acknowledge the beneficence of God, and acted in the manner incumbent on him in rendering Him obedience and abstaining from disobedience; so that Xukor is in word and in deed: (Msb:) and lahu taXakRara↓ signifies the same as Xakara lahu: (S, A, Msb, K:) you say, lahu maA SanaEa taXakRarotu↓ [I thanked him, &c., for what he did]: (A:) and lahu balaMCahu tXkRr↓ [He was grateful to Him, &c., i. e. to God, for his probation]: (K:) and OaXokuru Uilayoka niEama QllRehi [I praise to thee, or mention to thee with thanks, the favours of God]: (L in art. Hmd:) [but there are many explanations of Xakara beside those given above: its meanings will be more fully shown by what here follows:] XukorN is the thanking a benefactor; or praising, eulogizing, or commending, him, (S, A,) for a benefits: (S:) or the being grateful, or thankful; or acknowledging beneficence; and speaking of it largely; and [in the copies of the K, “ or, ” but this is evidently a mistake,] it is only on account of favour received; (K;) and XukoraAnN is [the same, being] contr. of kuforaAnN: (S:) XukorN [sometimes] differs from HamodN; (Msb in art. Hmd;) for Xkr is only on account of favour received; whereas Hmd is sometimes because of favour received, (Th, Az, TA in art. Hmd, and Msb ubi suprà,) and sometimes form other causes; (Th ubi suprà;) [and thus] the latter is of more common application than the former; (S in art. Hmd;) therefore you do not say Xakarotuhu EalaI XajaAEatihi, but you say Hamidotuhu ElI XjAEth: (Msb ubi suprà:) or XukorN is more common than HamodN with respect to its kinds and means, and more particular with respect to the objects to which it relates; and the latter is more common with respect to the objects to which it relates, and more particular with respect to the means; for the former is, with the heart, the being humble, or lowly, and submissive; and with the tongue, the act of praising, eulogizing, or commending; and acknowledging beneficence; and with the members, the act of obeying, and submitting one's self; and the object to which it relates is the benefactor, exclusively of his essential qualities; therefore one does not say XakaronaA QllReha EalaI HayaAtihi [we thanked God for his existence, or praised Him, &c.]; but He is maHomuwd on that account, like as He is for his beneficence; and XukorN is also for beneficence: thus HamodN relates to every object to which, as an object, XukorN relates; but the reverse is not the case: and everything whereby is Hmd, thereby is Xkr; but the reverse is not the case; for the latter is by means of the members, or limbs, and the former is by means of the tongue: XukorN is of three kinds; with the heart, or mind, which is the forming an [adequate] idea of the benefit; and with the tongue, which is the praising, eulogizing, or commending, the benefactor; and with the members, or limbs, which is the requiting the benefit according to its desert: it rests upon five foundations; humility of him who renders it towards him to whom it is rendered; his love of him; his acknowledgment of his benefit; the eulogizing him for it; and his not making use of the benefit in a manner which he [who has conferred it] dislikes: it is also explained as devotion of the heart to love of the benefactor, and of the members to obey him, and the employment of the tongue in mentioning him and eulogizing him: [and there are several other explanations of it which it is unnecessary to add:] some say that it is formed by transposition from kaXorN, the “ act of uncovering, or exposing to view: ” others, that it is from EayonN XakoraI “ a full fountain, or eye; ” accord. to which etymology it would signify the being full of the praise of the benefactor. (B, TA.) ― -b2- XukorN on the part of God signifies (tropical:) The requiting and commending [a person]: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) the forgiving a man: or (tropical:) the regarding him with content, satisfaction, good will, or favour: and hence, necessarily, (tropical:) the recompensing, or rewarding, him: the saying Xakara QllRehu saEoyahu signifies (tropical:) May God recompense, or reward, his work, or labour. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Xakirato, aor.
Xakara
, (S, K,) inf. n. XakarN, (S,) (tropical:) Her (a camel's) udder became full (S, K, TA) of milk: (S, TA:) or she (a camel) obtained a good share of leguminous herbage, or [other] pasturage, and in consequence abounded with milk after having had little milk: (T, TA:) and she (a beast;) became fat, (K, TA,) and her udder became full of milk. (TA.) ― -b2- And Xakira (tropical:) He was, or became, liberal, or bountiful, (A, K,) after having been niggardly: (A:) or he gave largely after having been niggardly. (K.) ＝ -A3- Xakirato said of a tree (XajarapN), (Fr, S, A, K,) aor.

XakarN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) It produced, or put forth, what are termed Xakiyr, (Fr, S, K,) i. e. what grow around it, from its OaSol [i. e. root, or base, or stem]; (S;) as also AXkrt↓, (Fr, TA,) and AXtkrt↓: (Sgh, TA:) or its Xakiyr, i. e. sappy twigs or shoots, from its stem, or small leaves beneath the large, became abundant. Xakara
, (K,) inf. n. XakarN; (TA;) and Xakara, aor.

; and AXkr↓; (K;) said of palm-trees (naxolN), (assumed tropical:) They had many Xakiyr, i. e. offsets, or suckers. (AHn, K, * TA.) ― -b3- And Xakara and AXkr↓ and AXtkr↓ are all verbs from XkiyrN. (K.) [It is said in the K that these verbs are from Xkyr in all of certain significations there mentioned; app. meaning, all that are there mentioned after the next preceding verb: and hence they seem to have the significations here following: ― -b4- said of palmtrees (naxol), (assumed tropical:) They put forth leaves around their branches:: ― -b5- and, said of trees in general Xajara, (assumed tropical:) They put forth branches: ― -b6- and (assumed tropical:) They produced bark: ― -b7- and, said of a grape-vine, (assumed tropical:) it grew from a shoot planted: ― -b8- in the TA it seems to be implied that, said of a vine, they signify (assumed tropical:) It put forth long shoots, or upper shoots.]

4. AlsRamaMCu (assumed tropical:) The rain fell vehemently: (S:) or the sky rained much. XakorN c
XakorN The vulva, or pudendum, of a woman: (S, M, Msb, K:) or the flesh thereof: (M, K, * MF:) as also XikorN↓, in either of these senses: (K:) pl. XikaArN: (Msb, TA:) laHomuhaA, in the K, as the second explanation, is a mistake for laHomuhu. (MF.) The act of compressing, or of contracting marriage with, a woman]. (TS, K.)

XukorN c
XukorN and inf. n. of Xakara: (S, A, * Msb, K:) and it may [be used as a simple subst., and, as such,] have for its pl. XukuwrN. (S. [See 1.])

XikorN c
XikorN: see XakorN.

XukorapN c
XukorapN (assumed tropical:) [Fulness of the udder of a camel; and so XakariyRapN↓ is expl. in the TK;] a subst. from OaXokara Alqawomu [q. v.]. (K.) One says, hecaA zamanu AlXRukorapi, so in the L and other lexicons, (TA,) or AlXRakarapi↓, (so in my copies of the S,) or AlXRakariyRapi↓, (so in the O and K,) (assumed tropical:) [This is the time of the fulness of the udder,] when the camels abound with milk, or have their udders full, (UicaA Hafalato, q. v.,) from the [herbage called] rabiyE. (S, O, L, K.)

XakarapN c
XakarapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XakirapN c
XakirapN (tropical:) A she-camel, (As, S, A, K,) and ewe or she-goat, (A,) having her udder full (As, S, A, K) of milk, (S,) whatever be the fodder, or herbage, she has eaten; (A;) as also miXokaArN↓: (K:) or the former, that has obtained a good share of leguminous herbage, or of [other] pasture, and in consequence abounds with milk after having had little milk: (T, TA:) and ↓the latter, that abounds with milk though having had but a small share of pasture: (TA:) or that abounds with milk in summer and ceases in winter: (IAar, TA:) pl. of the former XakaAraI, (S, K,) applied to camels and to sheep or goats, (S,) and XakoraI (K) and XakiraAtN: (S, K:) and XakaAraI is applied to camels, and sheep or goats, as meaning abounding with milk, or having their udders full, (UicaA Hafalato,) from the [herbage called] rabiyE. (S, TA.) [XakoraI↓ is also a sing. epithet, having a similar signification: as well as a pl.] One says DarRapN XakoraI↓ (tropical:) An udder abounding with milk: (A:) or having much milk. (S.) And EayonN XakoraI↓ (assumed tropical:) A full source or eye. (B, TA.) And fidorapN XakoraI↓ (assumed tropical:) A fat piece of flesh-meat: (K:) or (tropical:) [a piece of flesh-meat] flowing with grease, or gravy: (A: [but in my copy, qidorapN is erroneously put for fidorapN:]) pl. XakaAraI. (A.)

XakoraI c
XakoraI: see the next four preceding sentences.

XakariyRapN c

XakuwrN c
XakuwrN an intensive epithet, (TA,) signifying kaviyru AlXRukori [i. e. One who thanks much; or who is very thankful or grateful: see 1]: (K, TA:) and one who is earnest, or does his utmost, in thanking his Lord, or in being thankful or grateful to Him, by obedience to Him, performing his appointed religious services: (TA:) or one who does his utmost in showing his thankfulness, or gratitude, with his heart and his tongue and his members, or limbs, with firm belief, and with acknowledgment [of benefits received]: or who sees his inability to be [sufficiently] thankful or grateful: or who renders thanks, or is thankful or grateful, for probation: or, for what is denied him: (KT:) pl. XukurN. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A beast that is sufficed by little fodder or herbage, (S, A,) and that fattens upon it: (A:) or that fattens upon little fodder or herbage: (K:) as though thankful for that small benefit. (TA.) ― -b3- AlXRakuwru, applied to God, (tropical:) [He who approves, or rewards, or forgives, much, or largely:] He who gives large reward for small, or few, works: He in whose estimation small, or few, works performed by his servants increase, and who multiplies his rewards to them. (TA.)

XakiyrN c
XakiyrN (tropical:) The shoots that grow around a tree, from its OaSol [i. e. root, or base, or stem]: (S:) or sappy twigs or shoots, that grow from the stem of a tree: or small leaves beneath the large: (A:) or fresh and tender twigs or shoots, that grow among such as have become thick and tough: and what grow at, or upon, the OuSuwl [i. e. roots, or bases, or stems,] of large trees: or small leaves that grow at, or upon, the root, or base, or stem, of a tree: (IAar, TA:) and offsets, or suckers, or sprouts, of palm-trees: (K:) and the leaves that are around the branches of the palm-tree: (Yaa- koob, K:) and plants, and hair, and feathers, and abundant ostrich-feathers (EifaMC, K, TA, in the CK EafAC), such as are small, growing among such as are large: or the first, of herbage, growing after other herbage that has become dried up and dusty: (K:) and downy hair, or down: and any soft, fine hair: (A:) or hair growing among the plaits: pl. XukurN: and weak hair: (TA:) and hair at the roots of a horse's mane, (K, TA,) like down, and in the forelock: (TA:) and the hair that is next to the face and the back of the neck: (A, K:) and branches: (AHn, K: [in the CK, wAlguSuwni is erroneously put for wAlguSuwnu:]) and the bark (liHaMC) of trees: pl. XukurN: (K:) and the pl. also signifies the long shoots of a grape-vine: or its higher, or highest, shoots: (AHn, TA:) and the sing., a grape-vine growing from a planted shoot. (AHn, K, TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Young men: (A:) or young offspring. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The young ones of camels: (K, TA:) as being likened to the Xakiyr of palm-trees. (TA.)

; thus correctly, as pointed by IKtt; accord. to the K XkRlt↓; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) She (a woman) plaited two locks of her hair, of the fore part of her head, on the right and left, (O, K, TA,) and then bound with them her other cawaAYib [or pendent locks or plaits]. Xakala
; (K, TA,) inf. n. XakalN, (TA,) She (a woman) used amorous gesture or behaviour; or such gesture, or behaviour, with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition; displayed what is termed Xikol, i. e. gunoj and dalR and gazal; (K, TA;) and tXkRlt↓ [signifies the same], i. e. tadalRalato [and in like manner tXkRl is said of a man]. 2. XkRl, as an intrans. verb: see 4: ― -b2- and see also 5. ＝ -A2- XkRlhu, inf. n. taXokiylN, He formed, fashioned, figured, shaped, sculptured, or pictured, it; syn. SawRarahu; (K, TA;) namely, a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, in three places.

3 muXaAkalapN c
3. muXaAkalapN signifies The being conformable, suitable, agreeable, similar, homogeneous, or congenial; syn. muwaAfaqapN; (S, K;) as also taXaAkulN↓: (IDrd, S, K:) Er-Rághib [strangely] says that AlmuXaAkalapu is from AlXRakolu signifying “ the binding, ” or “ shackling, ” a beast [with the XikaAl]. (TA.) You say, huwa yuXaAkiluhu [He, or it, is conformable, &c., with him, or it; or resembles him, or it]. (Msb.) And hecaA AlOamoru laA yuXaAkiluka i. e. laA yuwaAfiquka [This affair will not be suitable to thee]. (TA.) And taXaAkalaA↓ They resembled each other. (MA.)

4 AXkl c
4. AXkl [primarily] signifies SaAra caA XakolK [meaning It, or he, was, or became, such as had a likeness or resemblance, or a like, or match, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, app.,] said of a thing, or case, or an affair; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also Xakala↓, (O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, Xakila, evidently not meant by the author of the K, as it is his rule, after mentioning a verb of this form, to add kafariHa or the like,]) inf. n. XakolN; (TA;) and XkRl↓, (K,) inf. n. taXokiylN; (TA;) (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, dubious, or confused; syn. Ailotabasa, (S, O, Msb, K,) and AixotalaTa, (O, TA,) or AiXotabaha: (Mgh:) [and AXtkl↓ is mentioned in this sense by Golius as on the authority of J (whom I do not find to have mentioned it either in this art. or elsewhere), and by Freytag as on the authority of Abu-l-'Alà: accord. to Sh, AXkl in this sense is from XukolapN signifying “ redness mixed with whiteness: ” (see muXokilN:) but] accord. to Er-Rághib, UiXokaAlN in a thing, or case, or an affair, is metaphorical, [and] like AiXotibaAhN from AlXibohu. (TA.) One says, AXkl AlOamoru EalaI AlrRajuli (assumed tropical:) [The thing, or case, or affair, was, or became, dubious, or confused, to the man]; and Xakala↓ means the same. (Zj, O.) And OaXokalato EalaIRa AlOaxobaAru (assumed tropical:) [The tidings were dubious, or confused, to me], and OaHokalato; both meaning the same. (TA.) And one says also, Ealayohi UiXokaAlN and Elyh UiXokaAlaAtN [meaning There is doubt, or uncertainty, and there are doubts, or uncertainties, respecting it: thus using the inf. n. as a simple subst., and therefore pluralizing it]. (Mz, 3rd nwE; &c.) ― -b3- It is also said of a disease; [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) It became nearly cured; because still in a somewhat doubtful state;] like as you say tamaAvala; and so Xakala↓. (TA.) ― -b4- AXkl AlnRaxolu The palm-trees became in that state in which their dates were sweet (Ks, S, A, O, K) and ripe, (Ks, S, O, Msb,) or nearly ripe; (A, TA;) and tXkRl↓ signifies the same. (O.) ― -b5- And AXklt AlEayonu The eye had in it what is termed XukolapN [q. v.: see also XakalN]. (K.) ＝ -A2- AXkl AlkitaAba: see 1.

5 tXkRl c
5. tXkRl It (a thing, TA) was, or became, formed, fashioned, figured, shaped, sculptured, or pictured; syn. taSawRara. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And He became goodly in shape, form, or aspect. (TK in art. Trz.) ― -b3- tXkRl AlEinabu, (S, K,) and Xakala↓, and XkRl↓, (K,) The grapes became in that state in which some of them were ripe: (S, K:) or became black, and beginning to be ripe: (K:) thus in the M. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 4, near the end. ― -b5- And see 1, also near the end.

6 taXaAokala
6: see 3, in two places.

8 UiXotakala
8: see 4.

10 AstXklhu c
10. AstXklhu is often used by the learned in the present day as meaning He deemed it (i. e. a word or phrase or sentence) dubious, or confused.]

XakolN c
XakolN i. q. XabapN [as meaning A likeness, resemblance, or semblance; a well-known signification of the latter word, but one which I do not find unequivocally assigned to it in its proper art. in any of the lexicons]. (AA, K, TA. [In the CK, and in my MS. copy of the K, in the place of AlXRabahu as the first explanation of AlXRakolu in the K accord. to the TA, we find AlXRibohu; but that the explanation which I have given is correct, is shown by what here follows.]) One says, fiI fulaAnK XakolN mino Oabiyhi, meaning XabahN [i. e. In such a one is a likeness, or resemblance, of his father]: (AA, TA:) and mino Oabiyhi fiyhi OaXokalapN↓ and XukolapN↓ (AA, O, K, TA)
and XaAkilN↓, (O, K, TA,) [likewise] meaning XabahN, (AA, O, K, TA,) and muXaAbahapN: (TK:) and XaAkilapN↓ also is syn. with XakolN [in the sense of XabahN]; (K, TA;) [for] one says, hecaA EalaI XaAkilapi Oabiyhi as meaning Xabahihi [i. e. This is accordant to the likeness of his father]. (TA.) ― -b2- And I. q. mivaAlN: you say, hecaA EalaI Xakoli hecaA, meaning ElI mivaAlihi [i. e. This is according to the model, or pattern, or the mode, or manner, of this]. (TA.) ― -b3- And The shape, form, or figure, (Suwrap,) of a thing; such as is perceived by the senses; and such as is imagined: (K:) the form (hayoYap), of a body, caused by the entire contents' being included by one boundary, as in the case of a sphere; or by several boundaries, as in those bodies that have several angles or sides, such as have four and such as have six [&c.]: so says Ibn-El-Kemál: (TA:) pl. [of pauc., in this and in other senses,] OaXokaAlN and [of mult.] XukuwlN. (K.) ― -b4- [It often means A kind, sort, or variety, of animals, plants, food, &c.] ― -b5- [And The likeness, or the way or manner, of the actions of a person:] it is said in a trad. respecting the description of the Prophet, saOalotu OabiI Eano Xakolihi, meaning [I asked my father respecting the likeness of his actions, or] respecting what was like his actions; accord. to IAmb: or, accord. to Az, respecting his particular way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct: (O:) and XaAkilapN↓ [likewise, and more commonly,] signifies a particular way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct; (S, O, K, TA;) as in the saying, kulRN yaEomalu EalaI XaAkilatihi, (S, O, TA,) in the Kur [xvii. 86], (O, TA,) i. e. Every one does according to his particular way, &c., (Ibn-'Arafeh, S, O, Bd, Jel, TA,) that is suitable to his state in respect of right direction and of error, or to the essential nature of his soul, and to his circumstances that are consequent to the constitution, or temperament, of his body: (Bd:) and according to his nature, or natural disposition, (Ibn-'Arafeh, Er-Rághib, O, TA,) by which he is restricted [as with a XikaAl]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and his direction towards which he would go: (Akh, S, O, K, * TA:) and his side [that he takes]: (Katádeh, O, K, * TA:) and his aim, intention, or purpose: (Katádeh, O, K, TA:) and XakolN [likewise] signifies aim, intention, or purpose; syn. qaSodN. (TA.) ― -b6- Also A thing that is suitable to one; or fit, or proper, for one: you say, hecaA mino hawaAIa wamino XakoliI [This is of what is loved by me and of what is suitable to me]: (K, TA:) and layosa Xakoluhu mino XakoliI [What is suitable to him is not of what is suitable to me]. (TA.) [And hence, app.,] one says, maAXakoliI waXakoluhu, meaning What is my case and [what is] his, or its, case? because of his, or its, remoteness from me. (T and TA voce OumRN.) ― -b7- And sing. of OaXokaAlN (L, K, TA) signifying Discordant affairs and objects of want, concerning things on account of which one imposes upon himself difficulty and for which one is anxious: (Lth, TA:) and dubious, or confused, affairs: (TA:) or discordant, and dubious, or confused, affairs. (K. [In the CK, AlmuXakRalap is erroneously put for AlmuXokilap.]) ＝ -A2- Also A like; syn. mivolN; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) and so XikolN↓: (O, K:) or, as some say, the like of another in nature or constitution: (Msb: [and accord. to Er-Rághib, it seems that the attribute properly denoted by it is congruity between two persons in respect of the way or manner of acting or conduct: but in the passage in which this is expressed in the TA, I find erasures and alterations which render it doubtful:]) pl. OaXokaAlN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K *) and XukuwlN [as above]. (S, O, Msb, K. *) One says, hecaA Xakolu hecaA This is the like of this. (Msb.) And fulaAnN Xakolu fulaAnK Such a one is the like of such a one in his several states or conditions [&c.]. (TA.) In the saying in the Kur [xxxviii. 58], waMxaru mino Xakolihi, (O, TA,) meaning And other punishment of the like thereof, (Zj, TA,) Mujáhid read mn Xikolihi↓. (O, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also sing. of OaXokaAlN signifying, (O, K,) accord. to IAar, (O,) Certain ornaments (O, K) consisting of pearls or of silver, (K,) resembling one another, worn as ear-drops by women: (O, K:) or, as some say, the sing. signifies a certain thing which girls, or young women, used to append to their hair, of pearls or of silver. (O.) ＝ -A4- And A species of plant, (IAar, O, K,) diversified in colour, (K,) yellow and red. (IAar, O, K.) ＝ -A5- [And The various syllabical signs, or vowel-points &c., by which the pronunciation of words is indicated and restricted: originally an inf. n., and therefore thus used in a pl. sense.] ＝ -A6- See also the next paragraph.

XikolN c
XikolN: see the next preceding paragraph, latter part, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, as an attribute of a woman, Amorous gesture or behaviour; or such gesture, or behaviour, combined with coquettish boldness, and feigned coyness or opposition; syn. dalRN, (S, O, Msb, K,) and gunojN, and gazalN; (K; [in the CK, gazol, which is a mistranscription;]) or her gunoj, and comely or pleasing dalR, whereby a woman renders herself comely or pleasing; (TA;) and XakolN↓ signifies the same. (K.) One says AimoraOapN caAtu XikolK [A woman having amorous gesture or behaviour; &c.]. (S, O, Msb.)

XakalN c
XakalN, in a sheep or goat, The quality of being white in the XaAkilap. (S, O. [See OaXokalu.]) [In this sense, accord. to the TK, an inf. n., of which the verb is Xakila↓, said of a ram &c.]. ― -b2- And in an eye, The quality of having what is termed Xukolap [q. v.]. (S, O.) [Accord. to the TK, in this sense also an inf. n., of which the verb is Xakila↓, said of a thing, as meaning It had a redness in its whiteness.]

XukolapN c
XukolapN: see XakolN, first signification. ― -b2- One says also, fiyhi XukolapN mino sumorapK [In him, or it, is an admixture of a tawny, or brownish, colour], and XukolapN mino sawaAdK [an admixture of blackness]: (TA:) [or] XukolapN signifies redness mixed with whiteness: (Sh, Msb, TA:) in camels, (K, TA,) and in sheep or goats, (TA,) blackness mixed with redness, (K, TA,) or with dust-colour: in the hyena, accord. to IAar, a colour in which are blackness and an ugly yellowness: (TA:) in the eye, a redness in the white: (Mgh:) or, in the eye, i. q. XuholapN [q. v.]: (K:) or, accord. to AO, (TA,) the like of a redness in the white of the eye; (S, O, TA;) and such was in the eyes of the Prophet; (O;) but if in the black of the eye, it is termed XuholapN: (S, O, TA:) and the like is in the eyes of the [hawks, or falcons, termed] Suquwr and buzaAp: accord. to some, it is yellowness mixing with the white of the eye, around the black, as in the eye of the hawk (AlSRaqor); but he [i. e. AO] says, I have not heard it used except in relation to redness, not in relation to yellowness. (TA.) fiyhi XukolapN mino damK means In him, or it, is a little [or a small admixture] of blood. (TA.)

XakilapN c
XakilapN A woman using, or displaying, what is termed Xikol, i. e. gunoj and dalR and gazal [meaning amorous gesture or behaviour, &c.], (K, TA,) in a comely, or pleasing, manner. (TA.)

XakolaMCu c
XakolaMCu fem. of OaXokalu [q. v.]. (S, O.) ＝ -A2- Also A want; syn. HaAjapN; and so OaXokalapN↓, (S, O, K, [both of these words twice mentioned in this sense in the K,]) and XawokalaMCu↓; this last and the second on the authority of IAar; (O;) accord. to Er-Rághib, such as binds, or shackles, (tuqayRid,) a man [as though with a XikaAl]. (TA.) One says, lanaA qibalaka OaXokalapN↓ [&c.] i. e. HaAjapN [We have a want to be supplied to us on thy part; meaning we want a thing of thee]. (S, O.) ＝ -A3- Also i. q. mudaAhanapN. (So in the O and TA. [But whether by this explanation be meant the inf. n., or the fem. pass. part. n., of daAhana, is not indicated. Words of the measure faEolaMCu having the meaning of an inf. n., like bagoDaMCu, are rare.])

XikaAlN c
XikaAlN, of which the pl. is XukulN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the latter also pronounced XukolN, (TA,) i. q. EiqaAlN [A cord, or rope, with which a camel's fore shank and arm are bound together]: (S, O:) [or, accord. to the TA, by EqAl is here meant what next follows:] a rope with which the legs of a beast (daAbRap) are bound: (K:) a bond that is attached upon the fore and hind foot [or feet] of a horse [or the like] and of a camel: (KL:) [hobbles for a horse or the like, having a rope extending from the shackles of the fore feet to those of the hind feet: so accord. to present usage; and so accord. to the TK, in Turkish kwstk: Fei says only,] the XikaAl of the beast (dAbRp) is well known; and the pl. is as above. (Msb.) In relation to the [camel's saddle called] raHol, (K, TA,) accord. to As, (S, O, TA,) A string, or cord, that is put [or extended and tied] between the taSodiyr [or fore girth] and the Haqab [or hind girth], (S, O, K, TA,) in order that the latter may not become [too] near to the sheath of the penis; also called the ziwaAr, on the authority of AA: (S, O, TA:) and [in relation to the saddle called qatab,] a bond [in like manner extended and tied, for the same purpose,] between the Haqab [or hind girth] and the biTaAn [by which is meant the fore girth, answering to the taSodiyr of the raHol]: and a bond [probably meaning the rope men-
tioned in the explanation given from the K in the preceding sentence] between the fore leg and the hind leg. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, in a horse, (tropical:) The quality of having three legs distinguished by [the whiteness of the lower parts which is termed] taHojiyl, and one leg free therefrom; (S, O, K, TA;) [this whiteness] being likened to the EiqaAl termed XikaAl: (S, O:) or having three legs free from taHojiyl, and one hind leg distinguished thereby: (S, O, K, * TA: *) accord. to A'Obeyd, it is only in the hind leg; not in the fore leg: (S, O:) or, accord. to AO, (TA,) having the whiteness of the taHojiyl in one hind leg and fore leg, on the opposite sides, (Mgh, * TA,) whether the whiteness be little or much: (TA:) [when this is the case, the horse is said to be cuw XikaAlK mino xilaAfK: see 3 (last sentence) in art. xlf:] the Prophet disliked what is thus termed in horses. (O.)

XakiylN c
XakiylN (tropical:) Foam mixed with blood, appearing upon the bit-mouth, or mouth-piece of the bit. (Z, O, K, TA.)

XaAkilN c
XaAkilN: see XakolN, first signification. ― -b2- Also A whiteness between the EicaAr [which see, for it has various meanings,] and the ear. (Ktr, S, O. [See also XaAkilapN.])

XawokalN c
XawokalN: see XawokalapN. ― -b2- One says, AijoEali AlOamora XawokalFA waAHidFA, meaning Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr, TA in art. bOj.)

XaAkilapN c
XaAkilapN: see XakolN, former half, in two places. ＝ -A2- AlXRaAkilapu, also, signifies The flank; syn. AlxaASirapu, i. e. AlTRafoTafapu: (S, O:) [or,] in a horse, the skin that is between the side (EuroD) of the xaASirap and the vafinap, (K, TA,) which latter means [the stifle-joint, i. e.] the joint of the faxic and saAq: or as some say, the XaAkilataAni are the two exterior parts of the TafoTafataAni [or two flanks] from the place to which the last of the ribs reaches to the edge of [the hip-bone called] the Haroqafap on each side of the belly. (TA.) One says, OaSaAba XaAkilapa AlrRamiyRapi, meaning [He hit] the xaASirap [or flank] of the rmyRp [or animal shot at]. (TA.) [Hence,] one says, OaSaAba XaAkilapa AlSRawaAbi (tropical:) [He hit the point that he aimed at, of the thing that was right]: and huwa yaromiI biraOoyihi AlXRawaAkila (tropical:) [He hits, by his opinion, or judgment, the right points]. (TA.) Ibn-'Abbád says that [the pl.] XawaAkilu signifies [also] The hind legs; because they are shackled [with the XikaAl]. (O.) ― -b2- Also The part between the ear and the temple. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b3- And XawaAkilu (which is the pl. of XaAkilapN, TA) (assumed tropical:) Roads branching off from a main road. (K.) You say TariyqN cuw XawaAkila (assumed tropical:) A road having many roads branching off from it. (O.) ― -b4- And XaAkilataA AlTRariyqi means (tropical:) The two sides of the road: you say TariyqN ZaAhiru AlXRawaAkili (tropical:) [A road of which the sides are apparent, or conspicuous]. (TA.)

XawokalapN c
XawokalapN, (so in the O, as on the authority of IAar,) or XawokalN↓, (so in the K,) thus says EzZejjájee, but Fr says the former, [like IAar,] (TA,) i. q. rajRaAlapN [as meaning The footmen of an army or the like]: (Fr, IAar, Ez-Zejjájee, O, K, TA:) or mayomanapN [meaning the right wing of an army]: or mayosarapN [meaning the left wing thereof]. (Ez-Zejjájee, K, TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. naAHiyopN [probably as meaning The side, region, quarter, or direction, towards which one goes; like XaAkilapN, as expl. by Akh and others, in a saying mentioned voce XakolN]. (IAar, O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. EawosajapN [i. e. A tree of the species called Eawosaj, q. v.]. (IAar, O, K.)

XawokalaMCu c
XawokalaMCu: see XakolaMCu, above.

OaXokalu c
OaXokalu More, and most, like; syn. OaXobapu: so in the saying, hecaA OaXokalu bikacaA [This is more, or most, like to such a thing]. (S, K. *) ― -b2- Also Of a colour in which whiteness and redness are intermixed; (S, Msb, K;) applied to blood; and, accord. to IDrd, a name for blood, because of the redness and whiteness intermixed therein; (S;) [and] applied to a man; (Msb;) or to anything: (TA:) or in which is whiteness inclining to redness and duskiness: (K:) or it signifies, with the Arabs, [of] two colours intermixed. (TA.) [Hence,] it is applied to water, (K, TA,) as meaning (tropical:) Mixed with blood: (TA: [see an ex. in a verse cited voce HatRaI:]) pl. XukolN. (K.) And the fem., XakolaMCu, is applied as an epithet to an eye, (S, K,) meaning Having in it what is termed XukolapN, which is the like of a redness in the white thereof; like XuholapN in the black: (S:) pl. as above. (K.) A man is said to be OaXokalu AlEayoni, meaning Having a redness, (Mgh,) or the like of a redness, (O,) in the white of the eye: (Mgh, O:) the Prophet is said to have been OaXokalu AlEayoni: and it has been expl. as meaning long in the slit of the eye: (K:) but ISd says that this is extraordinary; and MF, that the leading authorities on the trads. consentaneously assert it to be a pure mistake, and inapplicable to the Prophet, even if lexicologically correct. (TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a camel, (K, TA,) and to a sheep or goat, (TA,) of which the blackness is mixed with redness, (K, TA,) or with dust-colour; as though its colour were dubious to thee: (TA:) pl. as above, applied to rams &c., (K, TA,) in this sense. (TA.) ― -b4- Applied to a sheep or goat, White in the XaAkilap [or flank]: (S, O:) fem. XakolaMCu; (S;) applied to a ewe, as meaning white in the XaAkilap, (K, TA,) the rest of her being black. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The mountain-species of sidor [or lote-tree]; (S, O, K;) described to AHn, by some one or more of the Arabs of the desert, as a sort of trees like the EunRaAb [or jujube] in its thorns and the crookedness of its branches, but smaller in leaf, and having more branches; very hard, and having a small drupe, (nubayoqap, [dim. of nabiqapN, n. un. of nabiqN, which means the “ drupes of the sidor, ”]) which is very acid: the places of its growth are lofty mountains; and bows are made of it [as is shown by an ex. in the S and O]: (TA:) [app. with tenween, having a] n. un. with p: (S, K:) AHn says that the growth of the AXkl is like [that of] the trees called XiroyaAn [of which likewise bows are made]. (TA.)

OaXokalapN c
OaXokalapN: see XakolN, first signification. ― -b2- Also i. q. lubosN [meaning (assumed tropical:) Dubiousness, or confusedness]. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also XakolaMCu, in two places. ＝ -A3- Also A single tree of the species called OaXokal [q. v.]. (S, K.)

muXokilN c
muXokilN, from OaXokala in the first of the senses assigned to it above, signifies Entering among [meaning confused with] its likes. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence, app., or] accord. to Sh, from XukolapN meaning “ redness mixed with whiteness, ” it signifies (assumed tropical:) Dubious, or confused. (TA.) [Used as a subst.,] it has for its pl. muXokilaAtN [and maXaAkilu also: for] one says, huwa yafukRu AlmaXaAkila, meaning (assumed tropical:) [He solves] the things, or affairs, that are dubious, or confused. (TA.) ― -b3- mXkl [app. muXokilN], applied to a horse, means Having a whiteness in his flanks. (AA, TA in art. dEm.)

muXakRalN c
muXakRalN Endowed with a goodly aspect, or appearance, and form. (TA.)

maXokuwlN c
maXokuwlN A horse bound, or shackled, with the XikaAl [q. v.]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) A horse distinguished by the whiteness in the lower parts of certain of the legs which is denoted by the term XikaAlN [q. v.]: (S, Mgh, * O, TA:) such was disliked by the Prophet. (S.) [See also muHajRalN.] ― -b3- And (tropical:) A writing restricted [in its meaning or pronunciation] with the signs of the desinential syntax [and the other syllabical signs and the diacritical points]. (AHát, TA.)

1 Xakamahu c
1. Xakamahu, aor.
Xakuma
, inf. n. XakomN, He bitted him; [namely, a horse or the like;] he put the bit (Xakiymap) into his mouth. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence], Xakama AlwaAliIa, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He bribed the wAlI [i. e. prefect, or the like]; as though he stopped his mouth with the Xakiymap, (S, K, TA,) i. e. the [bit, or] iron thing of the lijaAm. (TA.) And Xakama faAhu biAlUitaAwapi i. e. (assumed tropical:) [He stopped (lit. bitted) his mouth] with the bribe. (TA in art. Atw.) ― -b3- And faEala fulaAnN OamorFA faXakamotuhu (assumed tropical:) Such a one did a thing, or performed an affair, and I settled, or established, it. (Lth, TA.) ― -b4- And Xakamahu, (S, K,) aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n.; (K;) and AXkmhN↓; (Th, K;) He repaid, requited, compensated, or recompensed, him; (S, K; *) or gave him what is termed Xukom [q. v.]: (K:) he gave him his hire, or pay. (S, from a trad.) ― -b5- And, as some say, (S,) Xakamahu, inf. n. XakomN and XakiymN, He bit him. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Xakima, aor.
Xakama
, (K,) inf. n. XakamN, (TK,) He was, or became, hungry. (K.)

4 OaXokama
4: see the preceding paragraph.

XukomN c
XukomN (S, K, &c.) and XukomaI↓; (K;) of the latter, ISd says, “ I think it to be a dial. var., but I am not certain of it; ” (TA;) A repayment, requital,
compensation, or recompense; (El-Umawee, A' Obeyd, S, K;) and XukobN is a dial. var. thereof: (TA:) when the gift is initial, it is termed XukodN: (S:) or a substitute; or thing given, received, put, or done, by way of replacement or exchange: (Ks, TA:) and (K) a gift; (As, K, TA;) as also XukodN; (As, TA;) or the latter signifies a gift without compensation: (TA:) or XukomN signifies a benefaction, bounty, or gratuity; syn. nuEomaI. (Lth, TA.)

XakimN c
XakimN A lion: (K:) expl. in this sense as occurring in a verse of Aboo-Sakhr El-Hudhalee: or, accord. to Skr, as there used, quickly, or soon, angry; or violently angry. (TA.)

XukomaI c
XukomaI: see XukomN.

XakiymN c
XakiymN: see XakiymapN, in three places. ― -b2- Also The loop-shaped handles of the cooking-pot. (S, K.)

XakaAmapN c
[XakaAmapN expl. by Golius as meaning “ Malitia indolis, contumacia, ” as on the authority of the KL, is app. a mistake for XakaAsapN, which I find expl. in the KL as signifying the “ being evil in nature, or natural disposition, ” but not XkAmp. ― -b2- Freytag explains it as meaning also Likeness; a signification of XakiymapN, also mentioned by him; but for this he names no authority, and I know of none.]

XakiymapN c
XakiymapN, in the lijaAm, [The bit-mouth, or mouthpiece of a pit; i. e.] the transverse piece of iron in the mouth of the horse, in which is the faOos [q. v.]; (S, K;) as also XakiymN↓: (S:) [see also lijaAmN, and misoHalN:] or XakiymN↓ is pl. of XakiymapN, as also XakaAYimu and XukumN, (K, TA,) this last with two dammehs, [but written in the CK XukomN,] or [rather XakiymN↓ is a coll. gen. n., and] XukumN is said by some to be pl. of XakiymN, not of XakiymapN. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, [as used in phrases mentioned below,] (TA,) (tropical:) Resistance, or incompliance: (S, TA:) disdain, scorn, or disdainful and proud incompliance or refusal: and self-defence from wrong treatment: (K:) and self-magnification, pride, or haughtiness; syn. XamamN; AlsRamRu in the copies of the K being a mistake for AlXRamamu: (TA:) firmness, strength, or vehemence, of spirit; (TA, and Ham p. 140;) and evilness of nature or disposition: (Ham ibid:) strength of heart: (IAar, TA:) hardiness; courage, or courage and energy; or determination; syn. EaAriDapN: vigorousness, strenuousness, or energy: (TA:) also [simply] nature, or natural disposition; syn. TaboEN. (K, TK: in the CK AlTRabaEu is [erroneously] put in the place of AlTRaboEu.) One says, fulaMnN cuw XakiymapK (tropical:) Such a one is resistant, or incompliant: (S, TA:) or disdainful, or scornful; resistant, unyielding, or incompliant: one who defends himself from wrong treatment: proud: hardy: courageous: one possessing prudence or discretion, or firmness or soundness of judgment. (TA.) And fulaAnN Xadiydu AlXRakiymapi, meaning [in like manner] (tropical:) Such a one is firm, strong, or vehement, of spirit; (S, TA, and Ham p. 140;) disdainful, or scornful; resistant, unyielding, or incompliant; (S, K, TA;) so says ISk: (TA:) or, as some say, one possessing strength, or vehemence, of tongue; and perspicuity, or eloquence, of speech or language; or perspicuity of speech with quickness, or sharpness, of intellect; and much hardiness, or courage, or courage and energy, or determination. (Ham p. 140.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Likeness, or resemblance. (K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A compact, or covenant; syn. EahodN: (K, TA:) in some copies of the K, Alfahodu is erroneously put for AlEahodu. (TA.)

1 XakaA c
1. XakaA, (K,) first pers. Xakawotu, (S, Msb,) of which Xakayotu is a dial. var., (K in art. XkI,) aor.
1a2u2a
, (S, Msb,) [and of the latter
1a2i2a
,] inf. n. XakowN, (S, Msb,) or XakowaI, (K,) or this is a simple subst., (S, Msb,) also pronounced XakowFI, (K,) and XikaAyapN, (S, K,) with kesr, (K,) in which the I is [said to be] substituted for w because most inf. ns. of the measure fiEaAlapN of verbs ending with an infirm radical letter are of verbs of which that letter is I, (TA,) or this also is a simple subst., (Msb,) and XakaApN, (S, K,) or this too is a simple subst., (Msb,) and XakaAwapN, (K,) and XakiyRapN, (S, K,) is a trans. verb; (S, Msb, K;) and AXtkI↓ signifies the same; (S, K;) as also tXkRI↓: (K:) one says, XakaA Oamorahu UilaI QllRehi and AXtkI↓ [i. e. AXtkI Oamorahu], and tXkRI↓ [i. e. tXkRI Oamorahu], (K, TA,) meaning [He complained of his case to God; or] he told to God the weakness of his condition: (TA:) and Xakawotu fulaAnFA and AiXotakayotuhu↓ [I complained to such a one of his conduct to me]; (S;) [or] XakaA fulaAnFA means he told such a one of his evil conduct to him: (TA:) and XakaA fulaAnFA UilaI fulaAnK He complained of such a one to such a one: (MA:) [and Xakawotu Uilayohi kacaA I complained to him of such a thing:] see 4: and [in like manner] Uilayohi kacaA AXtkI↓ He complained to him of such a thing: (MA:) and minohu AiXotakayotu↓ [I complained of him, or it; like Xakawotuhu]: (Msb:) Er-Rághib says, AlXikaAyapu is The showing, or revealing, of grief, or sorrow; whence the saying in the Kur [xii. 86], UinRamaA OaXokuw bavRiI waHuzoniI UilaI QllRehi [I only show my grief and my lamentation to God]; and in the same [lviii. 1], UilaI QllRehi wataXotakiI↓ [And showeth her grief, or sorrow, to God]; the primary signification of AlXRakowu being the opening of the small skin for water or milk called Xakowap, and showing what is in it; so that it is as though originally metaphorical [though what is termed HaqiyqapN EurofiyRapN (expl. in art. Hq)]; like the phrases bavavotu lahu maA fiI wiEaAYiI and nafaDotu lahu maA fiI jiraAbiI, meaning “ I showed him what was in my heart. ” (TA.) ― -b2- XakaA is also said of a camel as meaning He stretched out his neck, and made much moaning, or prolonged utterance of a complaining voice, being fatigued by journeying. (TA.) ― -b3- And XakaAhu, (MA, K, TA,) inf. n. XakowN and XakaApN and XakowaI, (MA, TA,) is said in relation to a disease, or sickness; (MA, K, TA;) meaning He (a diseased, or sick, person) complained of it, namely, his disease, or sickness; (MA; [accord. to the TK, followed in this case, as in many others, by Freytag, it means it (i. e. disease, or sickness,) afflicted him; which I think to be indubitably a mistake;]) and tXkRI↓ and AXtkI↓ signify the same [as XakaA maraDahu he complained of his disease, or sickness]: (TA:) [or] these two verbs (tXkRI and AXtkI) signify [or signify also] he was, or became, diseased, or sick. (TA in additions at the end of this art.) One says also, AXtkI↓ EuDowFA mino OaEoDaAYihi and tXkRI↓, both meaning the same [i. e., originally, He complained of a pain, or disease, in some one of his members; but generally meaning he had a complaint of, or a pain or a disease in, some one of his members; and XakaA EuDowFA not unfrequently occurs used in the same sense]: (S:) [thus one often says of a brute; for ex.,] As says, in explaining AlqulaAbu as meaning “ a certain disease that attacks the camel, ” minohu qalobahu yaXotakiI↓ [he has a pain in consequence thereof in his heart; in which qalobahu, though determinate, may be considered as an explicative, like baTonahu in the phrase Oalima baTonahu, q. v.]. (S in art. qlb.) ― -b4- One says also, huwa yuXokaI bikacaA, meaning He is accused, or suspected, of such a thing; syn. yutRahamu bihi: (K: [there mentioned as though it were from OuXokiIa, and held to be so by the author of the TK; but it is from XukiIa; as though meaning he is complained of by reason of such a thing:]) mentioned by Yaakoob, in the “ Alfádh. ” (TA.) ＝ -A2- XkI fulaAnN [thus in my original, app. XakaA or XakaI,] is mentioned by Az as meaning The nails of such a one became split in several, or many, places. (TA.)

2 XakRati AlnRisaMCu c
2. XakRati AlnRisaMCu, inf. n. taXokiyapN; and AXtkt↓; and tXkRt↓; (K;) or, accord. to Th, only this last; (TA;) The women took for themselves, or made, a Xakowap [q. v.] for the churning of milk; (K, TA;) because it was little in quantity; the Xkwp being small, so that only a small quantity can be churned in it: (TA:) or, as in the T, XkRI and tXkRI↓ he took for himself, or made, a Xakowap: (TA:) [or] so AXtkI↓: (S:) and so AXkI↓. (IKtt, TA.) ＝ -A2- XakRaI XaAkiyahu, inf. n. taXokiyapN, expl. in the K as meaning kafRa Eanohu and TayRaba nafosahu, is a foul mistranscription: correctly, salRaI XaAkiyahu, meaning “ He comforted his complainer, and consoled him for that which had befallen him; ” as in the Tekmileh. (TA.)

3 XAkAhu c
3. XAkAhu, inf. n. muXaAkaApN, He complained of him, i. q. XakaAhu: or he told of his deceit, guile, or circumvention, and his vices, or faults. (TA.)

4 AXkAhu c
4. AXkAhu [He made him, or caused him, to complain;] he did to him that which made him, or caused him, to have need to complain of him. (S, Msb.) He increased his annoyance and complaining. (Az, K, TA.) ― -b2- And He removed, or did away with, his complaint; or made his complaint to cease; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K;) he caused him to be pleased or contented [and so relieved him from his complaint]; syn. OaEotabahu mino XakowaAhu; (S, and Har p. 337;) i. e. OaroDaAhu; (Har ibid.;) and
he desisted from that of which he complained: (S, * Msb:) thus it has two contr. significations. (S, K.) Hence the saying, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) in a trad., (TA,) UilaI rasuwli QllRehi HarRa AlrRamoDaMCi XakawonaA↓ fiI SiyaAminaA falamo yuXokinaA [We complained, to the Apostle of God, of the heat of the burning ground, in our fasting,] and he did not remove, or cause to cease, our complaint. (Mgh, * Msb, TA.) And [hence] one says, AXkI fulaAnFA mino fulaAnK, meaning He took for such a one, from such a one, what pleased or contented him [and so relieved him from complaining of him]. (ISd, K, TA: omitted in the CK.) ― -b3- Also He told him his complaint, and the desire, or longing of the soul, that he endured. (TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. wajadahu XaAkiyFA [which may mean He found him to be complaining, or, as seems to be indicated by what immediately precedes it in the K, he found him to be complaining of a disease of the slightest sort]: (K:) or, as in the T, AXkI [app. meaning AXkI Habiybahu] signifies he found the object of his love, or his friend, to be complaining; expl. by SaAdafa Habiybahu yaXokuw. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 2.

5 tXkRI c
5. tXkRI He expressed complaint or lamentation, pain, grief, or sorrow; syn. tawajRaEa; (Msb and K in art. wjE;) he made complaint or lamentation. (MA, KL.) See 1, in four places. ― -b2- [Hence] one says, tXkRI XaMYiI OaroDa kacaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) [My sheep or goats] forsook such a land, [as though they complained of it,] and did not go near it. (TA. [But I have substituted XaAYiI for what is there written XAkI, an evident mistranscription.]) ＝ -A2- See also 2, in two places.

6 taXaAkawoA c
6. taXaAkawoA They complained, one to another. (K.)

8 Ui1ota2a2a
8: see 1, in nine places: ＝ -A2- and see also 2, in two places.

XakowN c
XakowN inf. n. of XakaA. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- It is also used in the sense of wajodN [meaning Grief, mourning, or sorrow]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, and XakowaI↓, and XakaApN↓, and XakaMCN↓, and XakowaMCu↓, (K,) this last mentioned by Az, (TA,) [but it is omitted in some copies of the K,] A complaint, meaning a disease, malady, or sickness. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, the first, A small, or young, lamb: or a small, or young, camel: (K accord. to different copies: in some, AlXRakowu having for its explanation AlHamalu AlSRagiyru, and thus in the TA: in others, Aljamalu AlSgyr:) mentioned by ISd. (TA.)

XakaApN c
XakaApN an inf. n. of XakaA; (S, K;) or a simple subst., like XakowaI. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also XakowN. ― -b3- Also i. q. EayobN [A vice, fault, &c.]. (TA.) [See a verse cited voce rifaAqN.]

XakowapN c
XakowapN The skin of a sucking kid, (T, * S, M, *) for milk: that of the jacaE and of such as is above that [in age] is termed waTobN; (S;) or that of the jacaE is termed siqaMCN; and that of such as is weaned, badorapN: (T, TA:) or a receptacle of skin or leather, for water and for milk, (K, TA,) or, as some say, in which water is cooled and in which milk is kept close: (TA:) or a small skin for water or milk: or a small receptacle in which water is put: (Er-Rághib, TA:) the dim. is XukayRapN↓: (TA:) and the pl. is XakawaAtN and XikaMCN (K, TA) and XukiIRN [like as buduwrN is a pl. of badorapN, being originally XukuwwN, like as duliIRN (pl. of dalowN) is originally duluwwN]. (TA.)

XakowaI c
XakowaI an inf. n. of XakaA, as also XakowFI; (K;) or a simple subst. [signifying Complaint]: (S, Msb:) pl. XakaAwaI. (TA.) ― -b2- See also XakowN.

XakowaMCu c
XakowaMCu: see XakowN.

XakaMCN c
XakaMCN: see XakowN.

XakiIRN c
XakiIRN i. q. XaAkK↓ [i. e. Complaining]; (Msb;) [or a complainer; i. e.] AlXRakiIRu signifies AalRaciI yaXotakiI, (S,) or AlcI yaXokuw. (JM.) ― -b2- And Pained; syn. muwjaEN; (K, TA;) in this sense an instance of faEiylN in the sense of mafoEuwlN: (TA:) or causing pain; syn. muwjiEN: [thus accord. to both of my copies of the S: and this appears to be correct; for it is there immediately added,] El-Tirimmáh says,
wasomiI XakiIRN walisaAniI EaArimu
[which is inconsiderately cited in the TA immediately after the former of these two explanations: I say “ inconsiderately ” because the meaning evidently is, not that thus indicated in the TA, but, My branding, or stigmatizing, by satire, (for one says wasamahu biAlhijaMCi,) is such as causes pain, and my tongue is vehement: or XakiIRN may here have the last but one of the meanings expl. in this paragraph]: wasomiI is from AlsRimapu. (S.) ― -b3- Also Affected with a complaint, meaning disease, malady, or sickness, [app. in an absolute sense, (see XakowN,) and also] of the least, or lightest, or slightest, sort; and so XaAkK↓. (M, K.) ― -b4- And i. q. maXokuwRN↓, (S, Msb, K,) which is a pass. part. n. of XakaA; [and therefore signifies Complained of; and also complained to; but mostly seems to be used in the former of these senses;] as also maXokiIRN↓. (S, Msb.)

XikaAyapN c
XikaAyapN an inf. n. of XakaA; (S, K:) or a simple subst., like XakowaI. (Msb.)

XakiyRapN c
XakiyRapN an inf. n. of XakaA. (S, K.) ― -b2- And also (TA) a subst. signifying A thing complained of (AisomN limaXokuwRK); like ramiyRapN a subst. signifying “ a thing cast at or shot at ” (AisomN limaromiyRK): (Msb, TA:) pl. XakaAyaA. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A remainder, or remaining portion, (K and TA in art. XkI,) of a thing: mentioned by Sgh. (TA.)

XukayRapN c
XukayRapN dim. of XakowapN, q. v. (TA.)

XakRiIRN c
XakRiIRN, (thus in copies of the K,) or XukRiIRN, with damm to the X, (TA,) is mentioned in art. Xk [q. v.], and J has committed a mistake (K, TA) in mentioning it here, as Sgh has observed: (TA:) [accord. to F, it seems to be a rel. n. applied to a bit, or bridle; for it is said to be so applied in the K, as well as in the O, in art. Xk, in which both explain it as meaning Difficult; and also to a skin; for immediately after asserting that J has committed a mistake, F adds,] and XakRaI, like HatRaI, is a town in Armenia, whence [are brought] bits, or bridles, (lujum,) and skins, (K,) [and SM adds that they are termed XkRyRp: but what I find J to have stated is as follows:] AlXRakiIRu, [thus in one of my copies of the S,] or AlXukiI, [thus in the other of those copies,] in relation to weapons, is an arabicized word, and is in Turkish laX or laXo. (S. [But in the JM, this last word is written, as from the S, tXn: it may therefore be correctly laXon, or laXin, which, though used in Turkish, is a Pers. word, meaning smooth.])

XaAkK c
XaAkK: see XakiIRN, in two places. ＝ -A2- In the phrase rajulN XaAkiI AlsRilaAHi, (S,) which means A man whose weapon is sharp, or whose weapons are sharp, (S, K, *) Akh says that XAkI is formed by transposition from XaAYik [q. v. in art. Xwk]: (S:) and accord. to AZ, one says also XaAkK fiI AlsRilAHi. (TA in art. Xwk.) ― -b2- And AlXRaAkiI [is app. formed in like manner from AlXRaAYiku, and] signifies The lion. (K.)

miXokaApN c
miXokaApN A niche in a wall; i. e. a hole, or hollow, (kuwRapN,) in a wall, not extending through; (Fr, S, M, K, &c.;) in which a lamp, placed therein, gives more light than it does elsewhere: thus expl: by the generality of the expositors [of the Kur-án]; and this is said by Ibn-' Ateeyeh to be the most correct explanation: (TA:) said by Aboo-Moosà to mean the iron, or leaden, thing in which is the wick [of the lamp]: thought by Az to mean the tube which is the place of the wick in the glass lamp, as being likened to the kuwRap which is thus called: (TA:) some expl. it as having this meaning in the Kur xxiv. 35, and say that the miSobaAH there mentioned is the lighted wick: (Bd:) accord. to Mujáhid, the pillar, or the like, (AlEamuwd,) upon the top, or head, of which the miSobaAH [meaning lamp] is put: or the iron things by means of which the qinodiyl [or lamp] is suspended: IJ says that its A is originally w, and hence it is [often] written miXokewpN: and Zj says that it is an Abyssinian word, and used in the language of the Arabs: (TA:) [the pl. is maXaAkK, like masaAHK pl. of misoHaApN:] Kaab says that, in the verse of the Kur [xxiv. 35], by the miXokaAp is meant the breast of Mohammad; and by the miSobaAH, his tongue; and by the zujaAjap, his mouth. (TA.)

maXokuwRN c
maXokuwRN and maXokiIRN: see XakiIRN, last sentence.

1 XalRato yamiynuhu c
1. XalRato yamiynuhu, (S, O,) or yaduhu, (Mgh, TA,) or Alyadu, (Msb, K,) originally Xalilato, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) aor. taXalRu, (S, O, &c.,) inf. n. XalalN (S, * O, * Mgh, Msb, K) and XalRN, (Msb, K,) or the latter
is not allowable; (Ham p. 69;) this is the chaste form of the verb; (Th, TA;) and OuXilRato↓; (Th, K;) and XulRato, (Th, O, K,) but this last is bad, (Th, O, TA,) and is disallowed by Fr; (TA;) His right hand or arm, or his hand or arm, or the hand or arm, was, or became, unsound, or vitiated: (S, O, TA:) or deprived of the power of motion by an unsound, or a vitiated, state of its Euruwq [meaning veins or nerves]: (Msb:) or dried up; or stiff: or it went [or wasted] away. (K, TA.) One says, in praying for a person, laA taXolalo yaduka [May thy hand, or arm, not become unsound, &c.]: (S, Msb, * K: *) and laA XalalFA and laA XalaAli↓, which mean the same; the last word like qaTaAmi. (K.) And XalRa EaXoruhu, and xamosuhu, [His ten fingers became unsound, &c., and his five fingers,] and some say XalRato, but this is more rare; i. e., the suppression of the fem. t is more usual in a case of this kind. (Lh, TA.) To one who has shot or thrown, or who has pierced or thrust, well, one says, laA XalalFA walaA EamFI [Mayest thou not experience unsoundness, &c., nor blindness]; and laA XalRa EaXoruka [May thy ten fingers not become unsound, &c.], meaning OaSaAbiEuka. (S, O.) He who says XalRa AlmaArinu and XalRati AlOucunu is a foreigner. (Mgh.) The lawyers [improperly] use AlXRalal in relation to the cakar. (Msb.) One says also, Xalilota yaA rajulu [Thou hast become unsound, &c., in thy hand or thine arm, O man]. (S, O.) And laA Xalala, meaning laA taXolalo, because it occupies the place of an imperative. (Lth, TA.) In the saying of the rájiz, (S,) namely, Abu-l-Khudree El-Yarboo'ee, (O, TA,)
muhora OabiI AljaboHaAbi laA taXalRiI
[Colt of Abu-l-Habháb, mayest thou not become unsound, &c., in the fore leg], (S, TA, [in the O, AbI AlHarivi, for AbI AlHerivi,]) the last word is thus [for lA taXolalo] on account of the rhyme: (S, O, TA:) [for] the next hemistich is
baAraka fiyka QllRehu mino ciI OalRi
[God bless thee as one possessing fleetness, or swiftness]; (O, TA;) cI AlR in this instance meaning cI suroEapK. (S in art. Al.) ＝ -A2- XalRahu; (K;) and Xalalotu AlUibila, (S, O,) and AlrRajula; (Msb;) aor.
Xalula
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. XalRN (S, O, Msb, K *) and XalalN, (K, * and Ksh in xii. 3,) like as qaSaSN is inf. n. of qaSRa, (Ksh ibid.,) or XalalN is a simple subst.; (S, O;) He drove him away; (K;) and I drove away (S, O, Msb) the camels, (S, O,) and the man. (Msb.) And marRa fulaAnN yaXulRuhumo biAlsRayofi Such a one passed along urging them on, and driving them, with the sword. (S.) [See also 4. ― -b2- Hence,] AlSRuboHu yaXulRu AlZRalaAma (tropical:) The dawn drives away the darkness. (TA.) ― -b3- And XalRati AlEayonu damoEahaA (assumed tropical:) The eye sent forth [or shed] its tears: (Lh, K:) like XanRatohu: (Lh, TA:) asserted by Yaa- koob to be formed by substitution [of l for n]. (TA.) ― -b4- And XalRa AldRiroEa, (O, TA,) and XalRahaA Ealayohi, aor.
Xalula
, inf. n. XalRN, (TA,) He put on himself the coat of mail; on the authority of ISh. (O, TA.) ― -b5- Xalalotu AlvRawoba, (S, O, Msb, TA,) inf. n. XalRN, (O,) I sewed the garment, or piece of cloth, (S, O, Msb, TA,) slightly; (S, O, TA; [omitted, probably by inadvertence, in my copy of the Msb;]) [previously to the second sewing termed AlkafRu;] strangely omitted in the K: XilaAlapN↓ is [app. a subst., not an inf. n., signifying The act, or art, of so sewing;] the contr. of kifaAfapN. (TA.)

4 AXlR yamiynahu c
4. AXlR yamiynahu, (S,) or yadahu, (Fr, K,) He (i. e. God, S) made his right hand or arm, (S,) or his hand, or arm, (K,) to become unsound, or vitiated: (S:) or to become dried up, or stiff: or to go [or waste] away: (K:) or AXlR Alyada He (i. e. God) made the hand or arm to become deprived of the power of motion by an unsound, or a vitiated, state of its Euruwq [meaning veins or nerves]. (Msb.) And AXlR QllReh yadahu is said by way of imprecation [as meaning May God render his hand or arm unsound, &c.]. (O.) See also 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- [It is said that] UiXolaAlN signifies The driving away a camel, and a troop or company with the sword: [like XalRN: see 1, latter half:] ― -b2- and The making war. (KL.)

7 AnXlR c
7. AnXlR He became driven away. (K, TA. [In some of the copies of the K, AnXlR bihi, meaning He became driven away by, or with, him, or it.]) And AnXlRt AlUibilu The camels became driven away. (S.) And AnXlRwA maToruwdiyna [They went driven away]; referring to a company of people. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AnXlR AlcRiYobu fiI Alganami (assumed tropical:) The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats; as also AnXnR: mentioned by Az in art. nXg. (TA.) ― -b3- And AnXlR AlsRayolu (assumed tropical:) The torrent began to be impelled, before its becoming vehement: (Sh, O, K:) and so AnslR. (Sh, O.) ― -b4- And AnXlR AlmaTaru (assumed tropical:) The rain descended. (K.)

R. Q. 1 XaloXalotu AlmaMCa c
R. Q. 1. XaloXalotu AlmaMCa I made the water to fall in drops; (S;) in consecutive drops. (TA.) And XaloXala bawolahu, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, taXaloXala,]) and bibawolihi, (S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. XaloXalapN and XiloXaAlN, [both incorrectly written by Freytag,] (K, TA,) He (a boy, S, O, TA) scattered his urine; emitted it dispersedly: (K, TA:) the subst. [signifying the act of doing so] is XaloXaAlN↓ with fet-h. (K.) And XaloXala AlsRayofu AldRama, [in the CK, erroneously, bAldRami,] and bihi taXaloXala↓, The sword poured forth the blood. (K, TA.)

R. Q. 2 taXaloXala c
R. Q. 2. taXaloXala It (water) fell in consecutive drops. (TA.) And taXaloXala damFA It (a wound) dripped with blood in consecutive drops. (TA.) See also R. Q. 1, last sentence.

XalRapN c
XalRapN: see the next paragraph.

XulRapN c
XulRapN i. q. niyRapN [app. as meaning The thing, or place, that one proposes to himself as the object of his aim]: (S, O, K:) the place that a company of men have proposed to themselves as the object of their aim or journey: so in the M: (TA:) or the niyRap [in the sense thus expl. in the M and TA] in journeying: (T, K:) and thus also XulRaI↓, and likewise in fasting, and in warring: one says, Oayona XulRaAhumo↓ [Where is the place that they propose to themselves as the object of their aim in journeying, &c.?]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A remote affair (S, O, K) that one seeks; (K;) as also XalRapN↓. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- See also XalalN. ＝ -A3- And see XaliylN.

XalalN c
XalalN An unsoundness in the hand or arm, or a vitiated state thereof. (S, O.)
