[See also 1, first sentence, where it is mentioned as an inf. n.] ― -b2- And (tropical:) A stain, (S, O,) or a blackness, (K,) or a dust-colour, (TA,) in a garment, or piece of cloth, that does not become removed by washing. (S, O, K, TA.) One says, maA hecaA AlXRalalu fiI vawobika, (S, O,) or bivawobika, (TA,) (tropical:) [What is this stain, &c., in thy garment?] ＝ -A2- Also The act of driving away: (S, O, K:) a subst.: (S, O:) or an inf. n., (Ksh in xii. 3,) [see 1, latter half,] i. q. TarodN, like [the inf. n.] XalRN, (K,) as also XulRapN↓. (TA.)

XulalN c
XulalN and XululN: see XuloXulN.

laA XalaAli c
laA XalaAli: see 1, second sentence.

jaAWuwA XilaA lFA c
jaAWuwA XilaA lFA They came driving away the camels. (S, O.) ― -b2- And cahaba Alqawomu XilaAlFA The people went driven away (AinoXalRuwA maToruwdiyna). (TA.) ― -b3- And XilaAlN signifies A company of men in a scattered, or dispersed, state. (S, O.)

XaluwlN c
XaluwlN, of she-camels, and of women, (O, K, in the latter of which, in the place of waAlnRisaMCi, is found wAlXRaMCi [i. e. and of sheep or. goats], TA,) is like naAbN [meaning Aged]. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also XuloXulN, in two places.

XaliylN c
XaliylN, (S, O, K,) accord. to AO, (S,) or A 'Obeyd, (O, TA,) An innermost covering for the body, worn beneath the coat of mail, (S, O, K,) whether it be a vawob or some other thing: (S, O:) and, (S, O, K,) sometimes, (S, O,) a short coat of mail, (S, O, K,) worn beneath the upper one, (S, O,) or worn beneath the large one: or in a general sense: (K:) [i. e.] a coat of mail itself is called XaliylN; (ISh, TA;) and also XulRapN↓: (TA:) pl. OaXilRapN; (S, O, TA;) in the K, erroneously, XilRapN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (S, O, K) A [cloth such as is termed] Hilos, (S, O,) or misoH, of wool or of [goats'] hair, (K,) that is put upon the rump, or croup, of the camel, (S, O, K,) behind the [saddle called] raHol. (K.) [See also saniyfN.] ＝ -A2- And The part, of a valley, in which the water flows: (K:) or the middle of a valley, (S, O, K,) where flows the main body of water: (S, O:) so says A 'Obeyd, on the authority of AO; but the word commonly known [in this sense] is saliylN, with the unpointed s. (O.) ＝ -A3- And The nuxaAE [or spinal cord]; (K, TA;) [also called the saliyl;] i. e. the white Eiroq [or nerve] that is in the vertebræ of the back: mentioned by Kr. (TA.) ― -b2- And Long streaks, or strips, of flesh, extending with the back: (K, TA:) n. un. with p also mentioned by Kr: but the more approved word
is with [the unpointed] s. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And Clouds in which is no water; syn. jahaAmN. (AA, O.)

XilaAlapN c
XilaAlapN: see 1, last sentence.

XulRaI c
XulRaI: see XulRapN, in two places.

XaloXalN c
XaloXalN Water, and blood, falling in consecutive drops; as also mutaXaloXilN↓. (K, TA.) ― -b2- A ziqR [or skin for wine &c.] flowing [or leaking]. (TA.) And Roasted flesh-meat (XiwaMCN) of which the grease, or gravy, drips; like XaroXarN and raXoraAXN. (TA in art. Xr.) ― -b3- maMCN cuw XaloXalK (S, O) and XaloXaAlK↓ (S, O *) Water having a dripping. (S, O.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

XuloXulN c
XuloXulN A man light, active, or agile; (S;) [and] so miXalRN↓, (O,) and XaluwlN↓: (O, TA:) or the first, a boy, or young man, sharp-headed; light, or active, in spirit; brisk, lively, or sprightly, in his work; and so XuEoXuEN, and julojulN: (IAar, TA:) or a man clever, ingenious, acute, or sharp; light, active, or agile: (O:) or light, active, or agile, in accomplishing that which is wanted; quick; a good companion; cheerful in mind; as also XaloXalN↓, and miXalRN↓ [in the CK (erroneously) muXilRN], and XaluwlN↓, and XululN↓, and XulalN↓, (K, TA,) of which last the pl. is Xulaluwna, it having no broken pl. because of the rareness of fuEalN as the measure of an epithet: (Sb, TA:) and having little flesh; light, active, or agile, in that which he commences, (K, TA,) of work &c.; (TA;) as also mutaXaloXilN↓: (K, TA:) or this latter [simply] lean, or having little flesh. (S, O.)

XaloXalapN c
XaloXalapN The falling of water in drops, (K, TA,) consecutively. (TA.) [If an inf. n. in this sense, its verb is most probably XuloXila.]

XaloXaAlN c
XaloXaAlN: see R. Q. 1: ― -b2- and see also XaloXalN.

XulaAXilN c
XulaAXilN, applied to a plant, or herbage, Fresh, juicy, or sappy. (TA.)

OaXalRu c
OaXalRu A man whose hand, or arm, has become unsound, or vitiated: (S, TA:) or deprived of the power of motion by an unsound, or a vitiated, state of its Euruwq [meaning veins or nerves]: (Msb:) or dried up, or stiff: or whose hand, or arm, has gone [or wasted] away: (K, TA:) fem. XalRaMCu. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And yadN XalRaMCu (Mgh, TA) A hand, or an arm, that will not comply with that which its possessor desires of it, by reason of disease therein. (TA.) ― -b3- And EayonN XalRaMCu An eye of which the sight has gone. (O, Msb, K.)

miXalRN c
miXalRN A [spear of the kind called] miTorad [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- And A he-ass that drives away [his she-asses] much. (K. [In the CK, in this sense, erroneously written miXolN. See muXalilN.]) ― -b3- See also XuloXulN, in two places. ― -b4- One says also UinRahu lamiXalRN EawonN [thus app., but written in my original without any syll. signs,] meaning Verily he is a writer soundly, or thoroughly, learned; or skilled, intelligent, and experienced; and sufficing. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A garment with which the neck is covered: mentioned by the sheykh Zádeh in his Commentary on El-Beydáwee. (TA.)

muXalRilN c
muXalRilN A he-ass much busied by the care of his she-asses. (IAar, O, L, K. [See also miXalRN.])

mutaXaloXilN c
mutaXaloXilN: see XaloXalN: ― -b2- and see also XuloXulN.

XalojamN c
XalojamN A well-known plant; (S;) [colza: see salojamN:] mentioned by the author of the L, and other leading lexicologists, following J. (TA.)

XilRamN c
XilRamN Sparks of anger: so in the saying yataTaAyaru XilRamuhu [His sparks of anger fly about]: (K:) and so XinRamuhu. (TA.)

XaAlamN c
XaAlamN: see what follows.

XawolamN c
XawolamN: see what follows.

XayolamN c
XayolamN The ruWaAn [now applied to darnel-grass (but see this latter word zWAn)] that is [often found] in wheat; also called XaAlamN↓ (Msb, K) and XawolamN↓; (K;) of Pers., or foreign, origin; (OaSoluhu OaEojamiIRN;) and it is said that one of its two extremities is sharp and the other thick: (Msb:) of the dial. of the Sawád: accord. to IAar, i. q. ziywaAn [sic.] and saEiyE: AHn says that it is a small, oblong, red, erect grain, resembling in form the suws [or grub] of wheat; and it does not intoxicate, but renders the wheat very bitter: and in one place he says, the plant of the Xylm spreads upon the ground, and its leaves are like those of the xilaAf [or salix Aegyptia] that is termed baloxiIR, very green, and juicy, or tender; people eat its leaves when they are fresh, and they are pleasant [to the taste], without bitterness; but its grain is more intensely, or nauseously, bitter (OaEoqaI) than aloes. (TA.) [Forskål, in his Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. 199, after describing the zWAn, says, “ Xylm etiam agri vitium; a priore tamen diversa species: decocto plantæ obtunduntur sensus hominis qui operationem chirurgicam subire debet; Avicenna sic referente. ” See also sakarapN.] ＝ -A2- [Golius says, on the authority of a gloss in a copy of the KL, that it signifies also A short, or little, avaricious, man; “ vir curtus, avarus: ” a meaning, if correct, app. tropical.]

1 XalaA c
1. XalaA, aor.
Xaluwa
, He went, or journeyed. (K.) ＝ -A2- And He raised, uplifted, or took up, a thing; syn. rafaEa. (IAar, Az, K.)

4 AXlI c
4. AXlI, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. UiXolaMCN, (Msb,) He called a dog, (AZ, S, Msb,) &c.: (Msb:) and he called a she-camel, (ISk, S, K,) and a ewe or she-goat, by her name, (ISk, S,) to milk her. (ISk, S, K.) And AXlI daAbRatahu He showed the mixolaAp [or nose-bag (in the CK erroneously AlmixolATa)] to his beast in order that it should come to him. (K.) [See also 10.] Accord. to IAar and several others, one says, OaXolayotu Alkaloba EalaI AlSRayodi, meaning I incited, or urged, the dog [against the object, or objects, of the chase]; like Oagorayotuhu in measure and in signification: (Mgh, ast; Msb, TA:) but this is disallowed by ISk, (S, Msb, TA,) and by Th; (S, Mgh, TA;) and in like manner, AXlythu biAlSRayodi in the same sense; though they are allowed by others: one says, however, [by common consent,] OaXolayotu Alkaloba lilSRayodi, meaning I called the dog to the chase. (Mgh.)

8 UiXotalawa
8: see the next paragraph, in two places.

10 AstXlAhu c
10. AstXlAhu, (S, K,) and AXtlAhu↓, (S, * K, [accord. to my copies of the former, OaXolaAhu, but a verse immediately following as an ex. shows the right reading,]) He called him in order to save him, or rescue him, (S, K,) or to make him come forth, (S,) from straitness, or perdition, (K,) or from a place: (S:) this is the primary signification. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] the former, (S, K, TA,) and ↓the latter also, (S, TA, i. e. AXtlAhu, [thus in this instance in the copies of the S,]) (tropical:) He saved him, or rescued him. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- And AstXlI He (a man, TA) was, or became, angry. (K, TA.)

XalFA c
XalFA: see the next paragraph.

XilowN c
XilowN A limb, or member; (Msb, K;) as also XilowapN↓: (TA:) or a limb, or member, of flesh-meat: whence, in a trad., AytiniI biXilowihaA AlOayomani [Bring thou to me its right limb]: (S:) pl. OaXolaMCN (S, Msb, TA) and OaXolK, [originally OaXoluwN,] like OadolK pl. of dalowN. (TA.) ― -b2- And The body of anything [i. e. of any animal]: as also XalFA↓; (K;) which latter is expl. by ISd as signifying the skin and body of anything; and is applied in a trad. to the inner side of a haunch as meaning having no flesh upon it: (TA:) [or,] accord. to IDrd, Xilowu AlUinosaAni signifies the body of the man after its wasting, or decaying: (Msb, TA:) [or] OaXolaMCu AlUinosaAni means the members, or limbs, of the man after wasting, or decaying, and becoming dissundered: (S, TA:) and (hence, Msb) one says, banuw fulaAnK OaXolaMCN fiI baniI fulaAnK, meaning (assumed tropical:) The sons of such a one are remains among the sons of such a one: (S, Msb:) and huwa mino OaXolaMCi Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) He is of the remains of the people: [for] XilowN signifies (assumed tropical:) a remain, or remaining portion: and XlIR [app. XuliIRN, said to be like gnIR, but this is, I doubt not, a mistranscription for EuniIRN, i. e. originally of the measure fuEuwlN, is another pl. of XilowN, and] signifies (assumed tropical:) remains of any thing. (TA.) [See also XaliyRapN.] ― -b3- Also Any skinned animal of which somewhat has been eaten and a portion remains: (K:) or a portion remaining, whether much or little, of a sheep or goat of which part has been eaten: (L voce saliyxN:) pl. OaXolaMCN. (K.) ― -b4- And OaXolaMCu AllRijaAmi (assumed tropical:) The straps, or thongs, of the bit or bridle: (A, K:) or such as have become old, and of which the iron appertenance has become slender, (K,
TA,) or, as in the M, [of which] the iron appertenances [have become slender], without straps, or thongs: app. likened to limbs, or members, of flesh-meat. (TA.)

XilowapN c
XilowapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XaliyRapN c
XaliyRapN A piece, or portion, of flesh-meat &c. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A remnant, or remaining portion; (K, TA;) only of property: (S, K, * TA:) pl. XalaAyaA. (S, TA.) One says, cahabato maAXiyapu fulaAnK wabaqiyato lahu XaliyRapN (assumed tropical:) [The cattle of such a one went away, but a remnant remained to him]. (AZ, S.) [See also XilowN.]

muXalRFI c
muXalRFI Lean, or light of flesh: (K, TA:) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)

maXaAlK c
maXaAlK, in the dial. of El-Hijáz, The Things, or instruments, with which scarification is performed upon the cheeks: app. pl. of miXolaApN. (TA.)

AlXRaloyaAqu c
AlXRaloyaAqu A certain northern constellation, [namely, Lyra,] consisting of ten stars, the bright star [alpha] of which is called AlnRasoru AlwaAqiEu: the Arabs liken it to a vulture (nasor) which has contracted its wings to itself, as though it had alighted upon a thing: the vulgar call [the three chief stars in] it AlOavaAfiI: and before the bright star is a dim star which the Arabs call AlOaZofaAr [i. e. the talons]. (Kzw. [Not in any of my Lexicons.])

1 Xamimotu c
1. Xamimotu, aor. OaXamRu; and Xamamotu, aor. OaXumRu; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) the latter mentioned by AO; (S, TA;) third pers. of each XamRa; (Mgh;) inf. n. XamRu (S, Msb, K) and XamiymN, (S, K,) which are of both verbs, (TA,) and XimRiymaI, mentioned by Z (K, TA) alone; (TA;) I smelt, i. e. perceived by the nose, (K,) a thing, (S, Msb, K, *) or an odour; (Mgh;) and AiXotamamotu↓ signifies the same; (S, Msb, K, TA; [AaXomamotuhu in the CK is a mistranscription for AiXotamamotuhu;]) and taXamRamotu↓ also, (K,) and XamRayotu↓, thus in the copies of the K, but correctly XamRamotu↓: (TA: [both, however, are mentioned in the CK: the former like qaSRayotu for qaSRaSotu:]) or AlXRaIoCa taXamRamotu↓ signifies Xamimotuhu fiI muholapK [I smelt the thing leisurely, or gently]: (S, TA:) or AlXRaIoCa tXmRm↓ and AXtmRhu↓ both signify he put the thing near to his nose in order that he might draw in its odour. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- See an ex. in a prov. mentioned voce ximaArN. ― -b3- [Hence,] XumRa (assumed tropical:) He was tried, or proved by trial or experiment or experience; syn. Auxotubira. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A2- XamRa, see. pers. Xamimota, aor. yaXamRu, (Msb,) inf. n. XamamN, (S, * Msb, K, *) He (a man) was high, or elevated, in the nose. (S, * Msb, K. *) ― -b2- [And hence,] XamRa, (K,) [sec. pers. Xamimota,] inf. n. XamamN, (TA,) (tropical:) He (a man, TA) magnified himself; or behaved proudly, or haughtily. (K, TA. [And AXmR has a similar meaning.]) ― -b3- [This verb is also probably used in other senses, said of a mountain, &c.: see XamamN below.] ― -b4- See also 4, near the end.

2 XamRamotu c and XamRayotu
2. XamRamotu XamRayotu: see above, in two places.

3 XaAmRaA c
3. XaAmRaA, (K,) inf. n. muXaAmRapN, (S, TA,) They smelt each other; (S, * K;) as also tXAmRA↓, (K,) inf. n. taXaAmRN. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] XaAmimohu (tropical:) Look thou to see what is with him, or in his mind, (maA Einodahu, S, K, TA,) and draw near to him, (K, TA,) and seek after the knowledge of what is with him, or in his mind, (mA Endh,) by means of informations and disclosure; as though each smelt what was with the other in order to act according thereto. (TA.) And hence the saying, XaAmamonaAhumo vumRa naAwaXonaAhumo (tropical:) [We endeavoured, or looked, to ascertain their condition; then we engaged them in near, though not close, conflict]. (TA.) You say also, XaAmamotu AlrRajula meaning [simply] (assumed tropical:) I drew near to the man. (S.) muXaAmRapN [used tropically] signifies (assumed tropical:) The looking into a thing. (KL.) And (assumed tropical:) The approaching the enemy so that the two parties see each other. (S.)

4 AXmRhu UiyRaAhu c
4. AXmRhu UiyRaAhu He made him to smell it, or perceive it by the nose. (K.) You say, OaXomamotuhu AlTiyba [I made him to smell the perfume]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says to the prefect, or governor, or prince, or commander, OaXomimoniI yadaka OuqabRilohaA (assumed tropical:) [Suffer me to approach thy hand that I may kiss it]; (S, * TA;) a phrase like naAwiloniI yadaka, (TA,) but better than the latter phrase: so says Kh. (S.) ― -b3- And AXmR AlxitaAna, and AXmRt AlbaZora, (tropical:) He, and she, i. e. the operator, took, (K, TA,) or cut off, (TA,) a small portion of the prepuce, and of the baZor [q. v.]: (K, TA:) or the latter signifies she cut off a portion of the nawaAp [q. v.], not extirpating it. (TA.) ― -b4- And AXmR AlHarofa, (S, * K,) inf. n. UiXomaAmN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He made the consonant to have a smack of the dammeh or the kesreh, (lit., made it to smell, S, or to taste, K, the dammeh or the kesreh,) in such a manner (S, K) that the UiXomaAm, (S,) or that the dammeh or kesreh, (K,) was not heard, (S, K,) what is termed UiXomaAmu AlHarofi being less than what is termed rawomu AlHarakapi, the former being apparent only by the motion of the lip, (S,) or of the upper lip, (so in one of my copies of the S,) no account being taken of it, (S, K,) i. e. of the dammeh or kesreh, (K,) it not being reckoned as a Harakap because of its feebleness, the consonant in this case being quiescent or like that which is quiescent, (S,) and the prosodical measure not being broken thereby: (K:) for ex., in the following verse,
mataI OanaAmu laA yuWarRiqoniI AlkariI
layolFA walaA OasomaEu OajoraAsa AlmaTiI
[meaning AlkariIR and AlmaTiIR, (as is said in one of my copies of the S,) i. e. When I sleep, he who lets beasts on hire will not render me wakeful by night, nor do I hear the bells of the camels on which people ride], the Arabs [or, as is said in the TA, some of the Arabs] make the q [in yWrRqnI] to have a smack of the dammeh; but if you took account of the Harakap of the UiXomaAm [in this case,] the measure of the verse would be broken, [the foot] rqnI AlkrI becoming, in the scanning, mutafaAEiluno, which may be only in the kaAmil; whereas this verse is of the rajaz: (Sb, S:) another case of UiXomaAm is that of the I in duwayobRapN, [in which that letter is quiescent, but made to have a smack of kesreh,] as is the same letter in every similar case, in a dim. noun, when followed by a doubled letter. (Zj, T in art. db.) Also He pronounced the consonant with a Harakap [or vowel-sound] between damm and kesr, apparent only in utterance, not in writing; as in qiyla and giyDa in the Kur xi. 46. (I 'Ak pp. 130 and 131.) [See also rawomu AlHarakapi, voce raAma.] ― -b5- [Golius explains AXmR as signifying also “ Reduxit, fecit ut converteret se ab aliqua re; ” as on the authority of the KL; in my copy of which, however, I do not find this meaning.] ＝ -A2- AXmR, (S, K,) inf. n. UiXomaAmN, [as an intrans. verb,] said of a man, (S,) also signifies He passed by, or along, raising his head; (S, K, TA;) and magnified, or exalted, himself; behaved proudly, or disdainfully; or elevated his nose, from pride. (TA. [See also 1, near the end.]) ― -b2- And He turned away from a thing. (K.) One says bayonaA humo fiI wajohK Uico OaXamRuwA, i. e. [While they were in a certain direction, lo,] they turned away; (S, TA, as from AA;) or XamRuwA↓. (Thus in one of my copies of the S [but I think it to be a mistranscription].) And AXmR Alqawomu The people, or party, deviated in their directions to the right and left: a phrase heard in this sense by AA. (S.)

5 taXamRaRa
5: see 1, in three places.

6 taXaAomama
6: see 3, first sentence.

8 UiXotamama
8: see 1, in two places.

10 AstXmR c
10. AstXmR He desired to smell. (KL.) ― -b2- And He perceived a smell, or an odour, from a thing. (KL.) ― -b3- daxala AlmuxaATu Oanofahu faOosotaXamRahu faOadoxalahu fiI Haloqihi, said of a man, means AisotanoXaqahu [i. e. (tropical:) The mucus entered his nose, and he snuffed it up, and made it to pass into his fauces]; the verb being metaphorically thus used, like as AlAisotinoXaAqu is metaphorically used for AlXRamRu. (Mgh.)

XamamN c
XamamN inf. n. of the intrans. verb XamRa [q. v.]. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Used as a simple subst.,] Highness of the nose: (Msb:) or highness of the bone of the nose, (S, K,) and beauty thereof, (K,) with evenness, or straightness, of its upper part, (S, K, when there is in it a gibbousness it is termed qanFA, S,) and uprightness of the end, or lowest part: (K:) or, as some say, this last quality [alone]: (TA:) or length of the end, or lower part, of the nose, so that it extends over the middle of the mustache, (wuruwdu AlOaronabapi,) with beautiful evenness, or straightness, of the bone, and highness thereof greater than the highness that is termed calafN: or length and slenderness of the nose, and a downward extending of its rawovap [i. e. end or tip, or part where the blood that flows from the nostrils drops or drips]: (K:) or [simply] length.
in the nose. (Ham p. 789.) ― -b3- And, in a man, The quality of having what is termed XamamN of the nose. (S.) ― -b4- [And hence, (tropical:) Self-magnification, or pride, or haughtiness: see 1, near the end.] ― -b5- And (tropical:) Generosity. (Ham p. 728.) ― -b6- Also Highness, (K,) or tallness of the head, (S,) of a mountain. (S, K.) ― -b7- And (tropical:) Nearness: and (tropical:) remoteness: thus having two contr. meanings. (K, TA.) It has both of such meanings in the phrase daAruhu XamamN (tropical:) [His house, or abode, is near: and, remote]: (K, TA:) and in the phrase raOayotuhu mino XamamK (tropical:) [I saw him, or it, from within a short distance: and, from afar]. (TA.)

XamuwmN c
XamuwmN A thing [odorous, fragrant, or] fit to be smelt. (KL.)

XamiymN c
XamiymN High, or elevated: (S, K:) applied in this sense to a [camel's saddle such as is called] qatab. (S.)

XamRaAmN c
XamRaAmN A sort of melon resembling a small colocynth, [or rather a small melon resembling a colocynth,] streaked with redness and greenness and yellowness: called in Pers. dasotanobuwyah [i. e. “ perfume ”]; (K;) originally dasoto buwI [or dasoto buwyaho]: (TA:) its odour is cool, pleasant, lenitive, and narcotic; and the eating of it is laxative to the bowels: (K:) [The cucumis dudaïm of Linn.; called by Forskål cucumis schemmam: the latter thus describes it (Flora Aegypt. Arab. p. 169): “ Caules 5-sulcati, setis rigidis, scandentes, cirrhosi: folia cordato-oblonga, acuta, subsinuata, dentato-repanda, hispida: calyces villosi, molles: flores flavi, conferti in alis: fructus globosoovatus, glaberrimus, magnitudine citri, flavus, maculis inæqualibus, fulvo-ferrugineis, versus polos in lineas confluentibus; pulpa aquosa, seminibus tota plena: fructus juvenis villosus; maturus glaber: odor, fortis nec ingratus; eamque ob caussam cultus; non edulis: ” in the present day, the same appellation is applied in Egypt to several species of melon, of pleasant odour and taste; but this application I believe to be of very late origin: see also lufRaAHN: and see De Sacy's “ Rel. de l'Égypte par Abd-allatif, ” pp. 126-7.]

XamRaAmaAtN c
XamRaAmaAtN Sweet odours that one smells. (K.)

XamaAXimu c
XamaAXimu Ripe dates remaining upon the raceme. (AZ, K.)

XaAmRN c
[XaAmRN Smelling, or perceiving by the nose.] ― -b2- yaA Qbona XaAmRapi Alwacorapi [O son of her who smells the wacorap] is an expression of reproach. (S.)

OaXamRu c
OaXamRu, applied to a man, (Msb,) Having that quality of the nose which is termed XamamN; (Msb, K;) or so OaXamRu AlOanofi, thus applied: (S:) fem. XamRaMCu: (Msb, TA:) and pl. XumRN. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence, (tropical:) Self-magnifying, or proud, or haughty: or] a chief characterized by disdainfulness, scornfulness, or disdainful and proud incompliance, (K, TA,) and high-minded. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A mountain tall, (S, TA,) or high, (TA,) in the head. (S, TA.) [And High, as applied to a place of ascent in a mountain: see an ex. of the pl. in a verse cited voce taSadRafa.] ― -b4- And A shoulder high in the head of its bone. (K.) ― -b5- [Freytag mentions two other meanings: ― -b6- “ Ventus ex alto veniens, qui penetrantioris est odoratus: ― -b7- [and] fem. XamRaAC Jugum extensum in monte: ” from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.]

muXimRN c
muXimRN [Turning away, or averse]. One says, EaraDotu Ealayohi kacaA faUicaA huwa muXimRN laA yuriyduhu [I offered to him such a thing, and lo, he was averse, not desiring it]. (S.)

miXamRN c
[miXamRN An instrument of smelling; like as misomaEN signifies “ an instrument of hearing. ” ― -b2- Hence, its pl.] maXaAmRu signifies Noses. (KL.) ― -b3- [This pl. is expl. by Jac. Schultens, as meaning Perfumes (odoramenta): so says Freytag.]

maXomuwmN c
maXomuwmN A thing that is smelt; such as any sweet-smelling plant: like as maOokuwlN signifies “ a thing that is eaten: ” (Msb:) [and] musk: (S, K:) [pl. maXomuwmaAtN.]

1 Xamita c
1. Xamita, aor.
Xamata
, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. XamaAtapN (S, K) and XamaAtN, (K,) or the former is a simple subst., (Msb, [in which no inf. n. is mentioned,]) He (an enemy) rejoiced: (TA:) or he (a man, TA) rejoiced at the affliction of the enemy: (K, TA:) you say, Xamita bihi He rejoiced at his [an enemy's] affliction. (S, A, Msb.)

2 XamRata
2: see 4. ― -b2- taXomiytN is syn. with tasomiytN: [i. e.] taXomiytu AlEaATisi signifies The uttering a prayer for the sneezer; (S;) when he has, in obedience to an injunction of the Prophet, said AlHamodu lilRehi [Praise be to God]: (Har p. 250:) you say, XamRata AlEaATisa, (ISd, A, TA,) and XmRt Ealayohi, meaning [as expl. in art. smt: or] He prayed for the sneezer that he might not be in a state in which his enemy might rejoice at his affliction: (ISd, TA:) XmRt is better and more common than smRt: (A 'Obeyd, TA in art. smRt and in the present art.:) but the latter is said by Th to be the original word: or the meaning is, he said to the sneezer, May God put away, or avert, from thee that on account of which one would rejoice at thy affliction: or it is from AlXRawaAmitu as signifying “ the legs ” of a quadruped, as though meaning he prayed for the sneezer that he might be firm, or steadfast, in his obedience to God. (L and TA from the Fáïk &c.) And XmRt lahu and Ealayohi, inf. n. as above, He prayed for what was good for him; prayed for a blessing upon him; as also smRt, but the former is the better and the more common. (L and TA from the T and Fáïk &c.) ― -b3- Also i. q. taxoyiytN: (K:) you say, XmRthu fulaAnN, meaning xayRabahu [Such a one disappointed him; or caused him to be disappointed of attaining what he desired or sought: or denied him, refused him, prohibited him from attaining, or debarred him from, that which he desired or sought]. (TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. jamoEN [The act of collecting, &c.]. (K. [But SM says that he had searched to the utmost for this meaning without finding it in any other lexicon.])

4 AXmthu QllRehu bihi c
4. AXmthu QllRehu bihi God made him (i. e. the enemy, A, Msb) to rejoice at his affliction. (A, * Msb, K, TA.) For falaA tuXomito biIa QloOaEadaMCa [Therefore make not thou the enemies to rejoice at my affliction], in the Kur [vii. 149], Mujáhid is related to have read flA tuXamRito↓: but the correctness of this is doubted. (TA.)

5 taXamRutN c
5. taXamRutN signifies A people's returning disappointed of attaining their desire, without spoil. (K.)

8 AiXotimaAtN c
8. AiXotimaAtN [A camel's] beginning to be fat. (K. [See the part. n., below.])

XimaAtN c
XimaAtN Disappointment; frustration of one's endeavour or hope: (IB, TA:) a subst. from taXomiytN as signifying taxoyiybN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, thus written in copies of the K, [and in the S,] with kesr, (TA,) [but in the CK XamAt,] and XamaAtaI↓, (K,) Persons suffering disappointment; or failing of attaining their desire; (K, TA;) without spoil: (TA:) [pls.] without any sing.; (K:) or the latter has no sing. known to ISd: (TA:) [but] XaAmitN↓ has this meaning as a sing. part, n., and XmAt [app. XimaAtN] is its pl. (IB, TA.) One says, rajaEuwA XamaAtaI↓, (IAar, TA,) or XimaAtFA, (S,) They returned suffering disappointment; or failing of attaining their desire; (IAar, S, TA;) without spoil; and so muXamRatiyna↓ and mutaXamRitiyna↓. (TA.)

XamiytN c
[XamiytN Reproach (“ convicium ”): so Golius, as from the KL; but I do not find it in my copy of that work.]

XamaAtaI c
XamaAtaI: see XimaAtN, in two places.

XaAmitN c
XaAmitN One rejoicing at the affliction of an enemy: [fem. with p: pl. masc. XumRaAtN and fem. XawaAmitu; or the latter may be anomalously masc., like fawaArisu &c.; and as such it is evidently used in the L, in one place; but in another place, where it cites an explanation by AO, as fem.: both are mentioned in the M and L and TA, and the latter in the S and A also.] One says, AallRehumRa laA tuTiyEanRa liI XaAmitFA [O God, comply not with the desire of one who is to me a rejoicer at my affliction]; meaning, do not with me that which one who rejoices at my affliction likes, or approves; for in that case, Thou wouldst be as though Thou obeyedst him. (ISk, L, TA.) And baAta fulaAnN balayolapi AlXRawaAmiti Such a one passed a night such as would make to rejoice those, or those females, that would rejoice at the affliction of an enemy; (S, A, L, TA;) i. e., a distressing night. (A.) [And a verse cited in the next paragraph presents, as some read it, a similar ex. of AlXRawaAmit.] ＝ -A2- See also XimaAtN.

XaAmitapN c
XaAmitapN [fem. of XaAmitN, q. v. ＝ -A2- Also], as a subst., sing. of XawaAmitu (S, TA) which signifies The legs of a beast. (S, A, K, TA.) One says, laA taraka QllRehu lahu XaAmitapF, i. e. [May God not leave to him] a leg
of a beast. (AA, S, A, TA.) And En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee] says,
faQrotaAEa mino Sawoti kalRaAbK fabaAta lahu
TawoEa AlXRawaAmiti mino xawofK wamino Saradi
[And that has been frightened at the voice of a huntsman with his dogs,] and passed the night in consequence thereof standing, (lit. obeying the legs,) by reason of fear and [also] of cold; the poet describing a [wild] bull: (AO, L, TA:) but some read TawoEu (instead of TawoEa); and accord. to this reading, the meaning is, and passed the night having, of fear and of cold, what was agreeable with the desire of such as would rejoice at his affliction; the phrase being like the saying AallRehumRa laA tuTiyEanRa liI XaAmitFA meaning as expl. in the next preceding paragraph: (ISk, L, TA:) or he passed the night having [of fear and of cold] what would rejoice the XawaAmit that heard thereof: (AO, L, TA:) [and in like manner, Z says,] baAta TawoEa AlXRawaAmiti [without lahu, and with TwE in the accus. case, lit. he passed the night obeying those, or those females, that rejoiced at his affliction,] means, as those that rejoiced at his affliction liked, or approved. (A.)

muXamRatN c
muXamRatN A king prayed for (K, TA) with the prayers that are offered for kings. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also XimaAtN, last sentence.

muXamRitN c
muXamRitN Any one praying, or who prays, for what is good; as also musamRitN. (S.)

UibilN muXotamitapN c
UibilN muXotamitapN Camels beginning to be fat. (TA.)

mutaXamRitN c
mutaXamRitN: see its pl. voce XimaAtN, last sentence.

1 Xamaxa c
1. Xamaxa, (S, L, K,) aor.
Xamuxa
, inf. n. XumuwxN, (L,) It (a mountain) was high, or lofty. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (Har p. 442,) Xamaxa biOanofihi, (S, A, L, K,) and Xamaxa Oanofuhu, aor. and inf. n. as above, (L,) He (a man) magnified, or exalted, himself; was proud; (S, A, L, K;) behaved proudly, or disdainfully; elevated his nose, from pride. (L.) [See also zamaxa.]

niyRapN XamaxN c
niyRapN XamaxN (L, K) and XamuwxN↓ (L) A distant, far-reaching, or far-aiming, intention, purpose, or design; [in an action or a journey &c.;] (L, K;) as also nyRapN zamaxN and zamuwxN. (L.)

mafaAzapN XamuwxN c
mafaAzapN XamuwxN A desert, or waterless desert, farextending; (K;) as also zmuwxN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also XamaxN.

XamRaAxN c
XamRaAxN: see what follows, in two places.

jabalN XaAmixN c
jabalN XaAmixN A high, or lofty, mountain; (S, A, L;) as also XamRaAxN↓ [but in an intensive sense, i. e. a very high or lofty mountain]: (L:) pl. jibaAlN XawaAmixu (S, A) and XumRaxN. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, XaAmixN signifies also Proud; (L, TA;) elevating the nose, from pride, or disdain: [like zaAmixN:] pl. XumRaxN: (L, K:) and XamRaAxN↓ a man who magnifies, or exalts, himself much; or elevates his nose much, from pride. (L.) ― -b3- And OunuwfN XumRaxN [Noses elevated, from pride]; like zumRaxN. (S.) ― -b4- And nasabN XaAmixN (tropical:) [A proud, or high, lineage]. (TA.)

1 Xamara c
1. Xamara, aor.
Xamura
, inf. n. XamorN: see the next paragraph, in five places.

2 XmRr c
2. XmRr, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. taXomiyrN, (S, K,) He raised, (S, Msb, K,) or tucked up, or contracted, (A,) his garment, (Msb, K,) or his waist-wrapper, (S,) [or his sleeve,] or his skirts. (A.) One says, XmRr Eano saAqihi [He raised, or tucked up, his garment, or waist-wrapper, or skirts, from his shank]. (S.) [And in like manner, tXmRr↓ signifies He raised, or tucked up, his garment, &c.: for] one says also, tXmRr Eano saAEidayohi [He tucked up his sleeves from his fore arms]. (TA.) It is said in a prov., XamRara cayolFA waQdRaraEa layolFA i. e. [lit.] He contracted, or drew up, his [or a] skirt [and clad himself with night as with a tunic]: (TA:) or Xamiro cayolFA waQdRariEo layolFA, meaning (tropical:) Use thou prudence, or precaution, or good judgment, and journey all the night. (S and K in art. drE.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He strove, or laboured, exerted himself or his power or ability, employed himself vigorously or laboriously or with energy, or took extraordinary pains, (AA, Msb, TA,) and was quick, (AA, TA,) fiI AlOamori [in the affair]; as also Xamara↓, inf. n. XamorN: (TA:) and fiI AlEibaAdapi [in religious service]: (Msb:) and fiI sayorihi [in his pace, or journeying]; like tajarRada and Ainojarada. (L and TA in art. jrd.) Also, (K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and Xamara↓, (K,) aor.
Xamura
, inf. n. XamorN; (TA;) and AnXmr↓, and tXmRr↓; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He passed along striving, or exerting himself, or vigorously: or he passed along with a proud and self-conceited gait; (K;) [and] marRa yaXomuru↓, inf. n. as above, has the latter meaning. (S.) And XmRr fiI AlOamori (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, light, or active, (S, Msb, K,) and quick, (Msb,) in, or for, the affair: (S, Msb, K:) and XmRr liloOamori, and XmRr liloOamori OacoyaAlahu, (A, TA,) and XmRr Eano saAqihi, (TA,) (tropical:) He was, or became, light, or active, and he rose, or hastened, to do the thing, or affair. (A, TA.) And XmRrt AlHarobu and XmRrt Eano saAqihaA (tropical:) [The war, or battle, became vehement; like kaXafato Eano saAqK]. (A.) ― -b3- Also He contracted a thing; syn. qalRaSa; (TA;) [and so, perhaps, Xamara↓; for] AlXRamoru signifies taqoliySu AlXRaIoCi, like AltRaXomiyru: (K:) [or the author of the TA may have misunderstood this explanation in the K, and the meaning may be it (a thing) contracted, or became contracted; for qalRaSa is trans. and also (like qalaSa) intrans.: that XmRr has this latter meaning, whether it have also, or have not, the former, is shown by the statement that] one says, XamRarati AlXRafapu meaning qalaSat [i. e. The lip became contracted, or became contracted upwards]: (M in art. qlS:) and tXmRr↓ [in like manner] signifies it (a thing) contracted, or became contracted; syn. taqalRaSa. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (inf. n. as above, As, S,) (tropical:) He launched forth a ship, or boat; let it go; let it take its course; (As, IAar, S, A, K;) and in like manner, a hawk; (A;) and he discharged, or shot, an arrow: (As, IAar, S, A, Msb:) and hence, (As, S,) (tropical:) he sent, sent forth, or sent away, (As, S, M, A, K,) a thing. (M, A.) [See also samRara.] And XmRr AlUibila, inf. n. as above; (TA;) and AXmrhA↓; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He hastened the camels; made them to hasten; syn. OakomaXahaA, [which seems to be either syn. with, or a mistranscription for, kamRaXahaA, (see samRara,)] and OaEojalahaA. (O, K, TA.) ― -b5- And XamRarotu AlnRaxola (tropical:) I cut off the fruit of the palm-trees; syn. Saramotuhu; (A, TA;) or so Xamarotuhu↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) [for] AlXRamoru signifies SiraAmu AlnRaxoli. (K.)

4 AXmr AlUibila c
4. AXmr AlUibila: see 2, last sentence but one. ― -b2- AXmr Aljamalu Taruwqatahu The he-camel impregnated the she-camel covered by him. (O, K.) ― -b3- AXmrhu biAlsRayofi He destroyed him with the sword; syn. Oadorajahu. (O, K.)

5 tXmRr c
5. tXmRr: see 2, third sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] tXmRr liloOamori, (S, K,) or liloEamali (A,) and AnXmr↓ lalAmr, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He prepared himself (S, A, K) for the affair, (S, K,) or for the work. (A.) [Freytag mentions AXmr llAmr in a similar sense, “ Paratus fuit ad rem peragendam, ” as on the authority of J; but I do not find it in the S,] ― -b3- See also 2 as syn. with 1 and 7. ＝ -A2- [Also, app., as quasipass. of 2, It (a garment, &c., was, or became, raised, or tucked up, or contracted; and so signifies AnXmr↓.] ― -b2- See 2 again, in the latter part of the paragraph.

7 AnXmr c
7. AnXmr: see 5, in two places. ― -b2- See also 2 as syn. with 1 and 5. ― -b3- Also He (a horse) hastened, or went quickly. (S, O. [Accord. to Freytag, the verb in this sense in the S is AXtmr; but this is a mistake.]) ― -b4- And i. q. maDaI and nafaca [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) It, or he, acted with a penetrative force or energy (see XimorN and XamRariIRN)]; and so AXtmr↓. (TA.) ― -b5- And It (the water of a wall) went away. (A, TA.)

8 UiXotamara
8: see the next preceding paragraph.

XimorN c
XimorN, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Light, agile, or active; acute, or sharp, or quick, in intellect; clever, knowing, or intelligent; syn. zawolN; and baSiyrN; (ElMuärrij, O, K;) and naAqidN; (O, K;) thus accord. to the copies of the K [probably from the O]; but in the Tekmileh &c., naAfic, [which I regard as the right reading, meaning one who acts with a penetrative energy, or who is sharp, vigorous, or effective,] (TA,) in everything. (O, TA.) See also XamRariIRN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous; (O, K;) and courageous. (TA.)

XamarN c
XamarN: see XamaArN.

XimorapN c
XimorapN The gait, or manner of walking, of a
vitious, or depraved, man; (O, K;) or, accord. to IAar, of a man who goes to and fro, and round about. (TA.) [See also XanorapN.]

XarRN XimirRN c
XarRN XimirRN Severe evil. (S, O, K.) It is said in a prov., OalojaOahu Alxawofu UilaI XarRK XimirRK, (TA,) or OajaMCahu, (so in a copy of the A,) [Fear compelled him to betake himself to that which was a severe evil:] i. e. he feared an evil, and fear reduced him to a greater evil. (A.)

XamaArN c
XamaArN i. q. raAziyaAnajN, in the dial. of Egypt, (O, K, TA,) also [and more commonly] called XamarN↓ [applied to the Anethum graveolens, or common garden-dill, and to its seed; and also to the anethum fœniculum, or fennel: see also sanRuwtN]. (TA.)

XamRariIRN c
XamRariIRN [in the CK XamariIRN, without teshdeed to the m,] (tropical:) A man, (S,) penetrating, or acting with a penetrative energy, or sharp, vigorous, and effective, in the performing of affairs, and expert, or experienced; (S, * K, TA;) mostly with respect to travel; (TA;) as though it were a rel. n. from XamRara; (S;) as also XimRariIRN (S, K) and XimRiriIRN [in the CK XimiriIRN] and XumRuriIRN [in the CK XumuriIRN] and XimorN↓ and XimRiyrN↓, (K,) the last an intensive form, (TA,) and muXamRirN↓: (K:) or clever in the performing of affairs, and quick: (Fr, TA:) or one who strives, labours, or exerts himself, and is clever and skilful: (Aboo-Bekr, TA:) or quick in evil, and in what is vain, or false; who strives, labours, or exerts himself, therein; from XamRara meaning “ he strove, laboured, or exerted himself, and was quick: ” (AA, Aboo-Bekr, TA:) or one who goes his own way, or pursues a headlong, or rash, course, and will not refrain. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) ― -b2- naAqapN XamRariyRapN, (S, K,) and XimRariyRapN, and XimRiriyRapN, and XumRuriyRapN, (K, TA,) [all in the CK without teshdeed to the m,] and XimRiyrN↓, (S, K,) (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that is quick (S, K) in pace. (TA.)

XamRuwrN c
XamRuwrN, occurring in a trad. respecting 'Ooj Ibn- 'Unuk, [or Ibn-'Ook,] as meaning something with which a mass of rock was hollowed out according to the size of his head, (TA,) Diamond: (K:) thought by El-Khattábee to have this meaning; but he says, “ I have not heard respecting it anything upon which I place reliance. ” (IAth, TA.)

XimRiyrN c
XimRiyrN (assumed tropical:) One who strives, labours, or exerts himself; who employs himself vigorously, laboriously, or with energy; (K, TA;) in the performance of affairs. (TA.) See also XamRariIRN, in two places.

XaApN XaAmirN c
XaApN XaAmirN, and XaAmirapN, A ewe or she-goat, having her udder drawn up to her belly: (S, K:) an epithet having no verb. (TA.) ― -b2- XafapN XaAmirapN, and mutaXamRirapN↓, A contracted lip. (TA.) ― -b3- livapN XaAmirapN, (A, K,) and mutaXamRirapN↓, (K,) or muXamRirapN↓, (so in a copy of the A,) A gum cleaving to the roots of the teeth. (A, K.)

muXamRirN c
muXamRirN: see XamRariIRN: ― -b2- and see also XaAmirN.

mutaXamRirN c
mutaXamRirN: see its fem. voce XAmirN, in two places.

Q. 1 Xamoraxa AlnRaxolapa c
Q. 1. Xamoraxa AlnRaxolapa He stripped off the unripe dates of the palm-tree. (L.) And Xamorixi AlEicoqa Strip thou the XamaAriyx [or fruit-stalks] of the raceme of the palm-tree with the mixolab, cutting off [the dates]. (L, * K. [In the former, in the place of qaToEFA, the last word in the explanation in the K, is put qaEoTFA, app. by a mistake of the copyist.])

XimoraAxN c
XimoraAxN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and XumoruwxN↓ (S, Msb, K) A [fruit-] stalk of the raceme of a palm-tree; (Mgh;) the EivokaAl, (S, L,) or thing, (Msb,) upon which are the dates; (L, Msb;) [i. e. any one of the stalks that branch off from the main stem of the raceme, and on which hang the dates; each of these stalks comprising a number of dates, one below another:] pl. of both XamaAriyxu: (Msb:) the Eicoq, or kibaAsap, [q. v.,] comprises the XamaAriyx: (Msb voce EicoqN:) or an EivokaAl upon which are unripe dates, or grapes: (K:) originally relating to a raceme of dates; but sometimes, to grapes: (L:) and the former word [or each] signifies a small bunch of grapes, growing apart, but attached to the lower portion of the stalk of a larger bunch. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also, XimoraAxN, The head of a mountain: (S, K:) or a round, tall, slender head, or peak, of a mountain: (L:) accord. to As, [the pl.] XamaAriyxu signifies the heads of mountains: (TA:) or it signifies the upper, or uppermost, part [or parts] of a mountain; and in like manner, of trees. (Ham p. 786.) And (assumed tropical:) The upper, or uppermost, parts of clouds: (K:) or [the pl.] XamaAriyxu is metaphorically applied to the upper, or uppermost, parts of clouds. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b3- And A blaze upon the face of a horse, when it is narrow, (S, K, TA,) and long, (TA,) and extending so as to cover the [part of the nose called] xayoXuwm, but not reaching to the lip: (S, K, TA:) or a blaze, upon the face of a horse, extending downwards on the nose. (Lth, TA.) [See gurRapN saAYilapN, in art. syl.] Accord. to J, The horse itself [that has such a blaze] is also thus called; but this is a mistake: (K:) it seems that he meant to have said cuw XimoraAxK; but this, in a verse which he cites, is the name of a horse of Málik Ibn-'Owf En-Nadree, as is said in the K. (MF.) ― -b4- [The pl.] AlXRamaAriyxu is also a name applied by the Arabs to (assumed tropical:) The stars of Centaurus (qanoTuwrus) and Lepus (AlsRabuEu) collectively. (Kzw.)

XumoruwxN c
XumoruwxN: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence. ― -b2- Also A slender, and soft or tender, branch, that has grown forth, within a year, upon the upper part of a thick branch. (L.)

AlXRimoraAxiyRapu c
AlXRimoraAxiyRapu A sect of the heretics, or schismatics, (AlxawaArij,) the companions [or followers] of 'AbdAllah Ibn-Shimrákh. (S, K.)

XamarodalN c
XamarodalN A youth, strong and hardy; and in the like sense applied to a camel: (Lth, TA:) or tall; as also XamarodaliIRN↓: (Ham pp. 728 and 789:) or a bulky camel: (IAar, TA:) or, of camels &c., (S, O, K,) the swift; (S, O;) or youthful, swift, and goodly in make: (K:) and with p, a she-camel goodly, beautiful in make. (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K.)

XamarodaliIRN c
XamarodaliIRN: see the preceding paragraph.

XamarocalN c
XamarocalN a dial. var. of XamarodalN [q. v.]. (Lth, O, K.)

1. Xamazato nafosiI minohu, aor.
Xamuza
, (TK,) inf. n. XamozN, (IAar, K,) My soul shrank from it in dislike or hatred. (IAar, K, TK.) [See also 5, and Q. Q. 4.]

5 tXmRz wajohuhu c
5. tXmRz wajohuhu His face became changed, or altered, (T, S, K,) by anger, (K,) and contracted. (T, S, K.) See also what next follows.

Q. Q. 4 AiXomaOazRa c
Q. Q. 4. AiXomaOazRa, (S, K,) inf. n. AiXomiYozaAzN, (S,) He (a man, S) shrank, or became contracted; (S, K, TA;) as also tXmRz↓: (TA:) he quaked, or shuddered: (IAar, K:) or he was frightened (AZ, S, K) at a thing. (AZ, S.) It is said in the Kur xxxix. 46, waUicaA cukira QllRehu waHodahu QXomaOazRato quluwbu QlRaciyna laA yuWominuwna biQloMxirapi And when God is mentioned alone, the hearts of those who will not believe in the world to come become contracted, and shrink with aversion: (Bd, Jel:) or quake, or shudder. (Zj, TA.) And you say, qulotu lahu kacaA faQXomaOazRa minohu [I said to him such a thing, and he shrank from it; or quaked, or shuddered, at it; or was frightened at it]. (A.) And AXmOzR AlXRaIoCa, (K,) without a prep., accord. to Kr, (TA,) He disliked, or hated, the thing. (K.) [See also 1, and 5.]

XumaOoziyzapN c
XumaOoziyzapN [a subst.] from Q. Q. 4, [A shrinking, or contraction: a quaking, or shuddering: or fright: and dislike, or hatred.] (S, K, * TA.) You say, rajulN fiyhi XumaOoziyzapN [A man in whom is a shrinking, &c.] (TA.)

muXomaYizRN c
muXomaYizRN Shrinking with aversion; syn. naAfirN: (K:) disliking, or hating, (K,) a thing: (TA:) frightened, or afraid. (K.)

[only]; (TA;) and AXms↓; (S, K;) It (a day) was, or became, sunny, or sunshiny; it had sun, or sunshine: (S, Msb, K:) or it had sun, or sunshine, all the daytime: or it was, or became, clear, or unobscured: (TA:) or its sun was, or became, vehement. (IF, Msb.) ＝ -A2- Xamasa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Xamusa
(Msb, TA) and
Xamisa
, (Msb,) inf. n. XumuwsN
and XimaAsN, (S, Msb, K,) He (a horse) refused to be ridden or mounted: (S, K:) or took fright and broke loose and ran away, refusing to be ridden, by reason of the vehemence of his force of resistance, [for liXidRapi mtEbh in the TA, I read lXdRp manaEatihi,] and his sharpness of temper, so that he would not remain still: (TA:) or became rebellious against his rider. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Xamasati AlmaroOapu (assumed tropical:) The woman abstained from looking at men, and from exciting their desire. (TA.) ― -b3- And Xamasa liI fulaAnN (tropical:) Such a one showed enmity to me: (K: *) or showed his enmity to me, (T, S, A,) and almost made it to take effect, (A,) or as though he purposed to act: (T, TA:) or Xamasa fiI fulaAnK signifies, [unless fI be a mistake for liI, and fulaAnK for fulaAnN,] he showed his enmity [towards such a one], and could not conceal it. (M in TA.) [See also 3.] ― -b4- And Alxamoru taXomusu biSaAHibihaA (assumed tropical:) Wine overcomes, and runs away with, its drinker. (TA.)

2 XmRs c
2. XmRs, (TK,) inf. n. taXomiysN, (K,) He worshipped the sun. (K, TK.) ＝ -A2- And He spread a thing in the sun, or sunshine, (K, TK,) in order that it might dry. (TA.)

3. XAmshu, inf. n. muXaAmasapN and XimaAsN, He opposed him, and treated him with enmity or hostility. (Th, TA.) [See also 1.]

4 OaXomasa
4: see 1, first signification. ― -b2- [Also He ascended a mountain towards the sun. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

5 tXmRs c
5. tXmRs He (a man) sat in the sun, or sunshine: (TA:) he set himself up [or exposed himself standing] to the sun. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- tXmRs Ealayohi He was niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious, to him. (TA.) [See also the part. n., below.]

AlXRamosu c
AlXRamosu [The sun;] the body of the solar light, that runs its course in the firmament: (Lth, * TA:) it is fem.: (S, * Msb, K:) and has neither dual nor pl.: (Msb:) or it has a pl., [though this is not used in a pl. sense,] namely, XumuwsN, (S, K,) as though they called every part of it a Xms, like as they said mafaAriqu for maforiqN. (S.) When it is made determinate without the article Al, [as] in the name Eabodu Xamosa, meaning The Servant of the Sun, (Msb, K,) i. e., of this luminous object, (Msb,) the Xms of heaven, because they used to worship it, (K,) it is imperfectly decl., (Aboo- 'Alee, Msb, K,) because it is determinate and of the fem. gender, (Aboo-'Alee, K,) or because it is a proper name and of the fem. gender and altered from AlXRamos: (Msb:) and a poet says,
kalRaA waXamosa lanaxoDibanRahumu damFA
[Nay verily, by the sun, we will assuredly dye them with blood], making Xms imperfectly decl. because he means the art. Al to be understood: (IAar, TA:) but some say that in the former instance, (Msb, TA,) and in the latter, (TA,) the word in question has a different signification, which will be shown below: (Msb, TA:) and Sb says that none of the Arabs made Xms determinate without the art. Al, except in the proper name mentioned above, in which all of them made it so. (TA.) The dim. is XumayosapN↓. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [Also The sun, or sunshine.] You say, qaEada fiI AlXRamosi [He sat in the sun, or sunshine]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K, TA,) or XamosN, (Msb,) A certain ancient idol. (Msb, K.) Accord. to Ibn-El-Kelbee, it is this that is meant by the proper name mentioned above; and if so, it is perfectly decl.: (Msb:) and some say that it is this also that is meant in the words of the poet cited above, and that he makes the word imperfectly decl. because he uses it as a proper name of the image (AlSRuwrap). (TA.) ＝ -A2- XamosN also signifies A kind of necklace or collar: (S, K:) or a pendant, or suspended ornament, (miEolaAq,) of the necklace or collar upon the neck: or the collar of a dog: (TA:) or a kind of women's ornament: of the masc. gender: (Lh, TA:) pl. XumuwsN. (TA.) ― -b2- And A kind of comb, (K,) with which women in the first age used to comb themselves; (TA;) as also XamosapN↓. (IDrd, TA.) ＝ -A3- yawomN XamosN: see XaAmisN.

yawomN XamisN c
yawomN XamisN: see XaAmisN.

XamosapN c
XamosapN: see XamosN, last sentence but one.

XamosiIRN c
XamosiIRN [Of, or relating to, the sun; solar]. AlsRanapu AlXRamosiyRapu The solar year. (Mgh.) ― -b2- It is also a term applied by some of the Arabs to The first [annual] increase [of sheep and goats]. (Aboo-Nasr, TA voce SafariIRN, q. v.)

XamaAsN c
XamaAsN The disposition, in a horse, of refusing to be ridden, or mounted. (S.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) The disposition, in a woman, of abstaining from looking at men, and from exciting their desire: a subst. from XamasatN. (TA.)

XamuwsN c
XamuwsN A horse that refuses to be ridden or mounted; (S, K;) as also XaAmisN↓: (K:) or that takes fright and breaks loose and runs away, refusing to be ridden, by reason of the vehemence of his force of resistance and his sharpness of temper, so that he will not remain still: (TA: [see 1:]) or that will hardly remain still: (A:) or that rebels against his rider: (Msb:) or that refuses to be ridden or mounted, and will hardly remain still: (Mgh:) also applied to a she-camel: (TA:) XamuwSN, with S, applied to a horse is not allowable: (Msb:) pl. XumusN (A, Mgh, Msb, K) and XumosN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A woman who abstains from looking at men, and from exciting their desire; as also XaAmisapN↓: pl. of the former, XumusN; and of the latter, [XawaAmisu and] XumuwsN. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, (Msb,) (tropical:) A man refractory, untractable, perverse, stubborn, or obstinate, in disposition: (S, Msb, TA:) and a man hard, harsh, or illnatured, in his enmity, vehement in contrariousness to him who opposes him: (TA:) XamuwSN [with S] is not allowable. (S.) ― -b4- [Hence too,] AlXRamuwsu (assumed tropical:) Wine: (AHn, K:) because it overcomes, and runs away with, its drinker, like the horse to which this epithet is applied. (AHn.)

XumayosapN c
XumayosapN dir of XamosN, q. v.

XamRaAsN c
XamRaAsN One of the heads of the Christians, who shaves the middle of his head, and keeps to the church: (Lth, A, Mgh, K:) [in the present day, a deacon: see jaAvaliyqu:] not pure Arabic, (IDrd,) or not sound Arabic: (M:) [probably, as Golius says, from the Chaldee ???:] pl. XamaAmisapN. (Mgh, K: [in the TA, XmAsp; and in a copy of the A, XamRaAsap; but the right reading is that in the Mgh.])

XaAmisN c
XaAmisN A sunny, or sunshiny, day; a day having sun, or sunshine: or having sun, or sunshine, all the daytime: or clear; unobscured: and in like manner, XamosN↓ and XamisN↓, a clear, cloudless, day: and XaAmisN also signifies intensely hot: (TA:) and muXomisN↓, applied to a day, signifies the same as XaAmisN; (A;) and so maXomuwsN↓. (Th, TA.) ＝ -A2- A neck having [ornaments of the kind called] Xumuws [pl. of XamosN, q. v.]: a possessive epithet. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also XamuwsN, in two places.

OaXomasu c
OaXomasu More, and most, incompliant or resisting. (Ham p. 324.)

muXomisN c
muXomisN: see XaAmisN.

muXamRasN c
muXamRasN Made [or spread to dry (see 2)] in the sun, or sunshine. (S.)

muXamRisN c
muXamRisN A worshipper of the sun. (O, TA.)

maXomuwsN c
maXomuwsN: see XaAmisN.

mutaXamRisN c
mutaXamRisN [Sitting in or] setting himself up to [or exposing himself standing to] the sun. (K.) ＝ -A2- A man who defends what is behind his back: (ISh, TA:) a man strong (ISh, K, TA) in that which sustains or supports him; syn. qawiIRN Xadydu AlquwmiyRapi: (ISh, TA:) Sgh says Xadydu AlquwRapi; but the former is the right reading: (TA:) and niggardly, tenacious, or avaricious, to the utmost degree. (K.)

1 XamiTa c
1. XamiTa, aor.
XamaTa
, inf. n. XamaTN, He (a man, S, TA) was, or became, grizzled in the hair of his head; he had whiteness in the hair of his head, mixed with its blackness: (S, Mgh, * K:) as also OaXomaTa↓, (K, but wanting in one copy,) and AiXomaTRa↓, and AiXomaATRa↓, and AiXomaOaTRa↓: (K:) [or he had hair of two different colours, black and white: or he had whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, mixed with the blackness of youth: or he had whiteness, or hoariness, in his beard: but XamiTato, said of a woman, she had whiteness, or hoariness, in the head: see XamaTN, below.] ＝ -A2- XamaTa, aor.
XamiTa
, (S, K,) inf. n. XamoTN, (S,) He mixed a thing; (S, K;) he mixed together any two things: (S, Mgh:) and OaXomaTa↓ signifies the same. (AZ, K.) You say, XayaTa bayona AlmaMCi waAllRabani He mixed together the water and the milk. (TA.) And Eamalaka biSadaqapK OaXomiTo↓ (assumed tropical:) Mix thou thy work with alms. (AZ.) And Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà used to say to his companions, AXomiTuwA, [i. e. either
AiXomiTuwA or OaXomiTuwA↓,] meaning (assumed tropical:) Betake yourselves at one time to reading, or reciting, somewhat of the Kur-án, and another time to some tradition, and another time to something strange [that is to be elucidated], and another time to poetry, and another time to lexicology; i. e., mix ye these [subjects of study]: (TA:) or, accord. to one relation, XamRiTuwA↓. (Har p. 177; where it is expl. in a similar manner).

2: see above, last sentence.

9: see 1, first sentence.

Q. Q. 4: see 1, first sentence.

XamaTN c
XamaTN Whiteness of the hair of the head mixed with its blackness: (S, Mgh, K:) or difference in the hair by being of two colours, black and white: (M, TA:) or mixture of whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, with the blackness of youth: (Mgh:) or in a man, whiteness, or hoariness, of the beard: (Lth, Mgh, TA:) but in a woman, whiteness, or hoariness, of the head. (Lth, TA.) [See 1.] ― -b2- Also XamaTaAtN, which is its pl., White hairs that are in the head. (TA.)

XamiyTN c
XamiyTN Mixed; as also maXomuwTN↓: (K:) mixed together; (S, TA;) applied to any two things; (S;) or any two colours. (TA.) ― -b2- canabN XamiyTN; in the K, ciYobN, which is a mistake; (TA;) A tail (TA) in which are blackness and whiteness. (K, TA.) And farasN XamiyTu AlcRanabi A horse in whose tail are two colours. (TA.) And TaAYirN XamiyTu AlcRunaAbaI A bird having a whiteness (Lth, K) and blackness (Lth) in the tail. (Lth, K.) ― -b3- nabotN XamiyTN A plant of which part is dried up, or dried up and yellow, (Lth, S, K,) and part green. (Lth, K.) ― -b4- AlXRamiyTu, [in a copy of the Mgh, XumayoTN↓, which is probably a mistranscription,] (tropical:) The dawn: (S, K:) because of the mixture of its whiteness with the remains of the darkness of night: (S, Mgh:) or because its colour is a mixture of darkness and whiteness. (TA.) ― -b5- labanN XamiyTN (tropical:) Milk which is such that one knows not whether it be sour or what has been collected in a skin, and had fresh milk poured upon it, by reason of its pleasantness. (K, TA.) ― -b6- waladN XamiyTN (tropical:) Children of whom half are males and half are females. (L, K.)

XumayoTN c
XumayoTN: see XamiyTN. ＝ -A2- See also SuradN.

OaXomaTu c
OaXomaTu A man (S) having the hair of his head grizzled; having whiteness in the hair of his head, mixed with its blackness: (S, K:) [or whose hair is of two different colours, black and white: or having whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, mixed with the blackness of youth: or having whiteness, or hoariness, in his beard: see XamaTN, above:] or whose hair of his head is white in one place, the rest being black: (Mgh:) fem. XamoTaMCu: (Lth, S, Mgh:) one should not apply to a woman the epithet XayobaMCu: (Lth, Mgh:) pl. XumoTaAnN (S, K) and XumoTN. (K.) ― -b2- naAqapN XamoTaMCu A she-camel having white lips. (TA.) ― -b3- laHumN OaXomaTu [Flesh-meat marbled with fat]. (Az, TA in art. krX.)

maXomuwTN c
maXomuwTN: see XamiyTN.

1 XamaEa c
1. XamaEa, aor.
XamaEa
, inf. n. XamoEN and XumuwEN and maXomaEapN, He played, sported, gamed, jested, or joked: (S, O, K:) or he was mirthful, and laughed: and XamaEatN, aor. as above, inf. n. XamoEN and XumuwEN, She cheered by her discourse. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mano yatRabiEi AlmaXomaEapa yaXomaEi QllRehu bihi (S, * O) He who follows the practice of play, or sport, or unprofitable play or sport, with men, (S, O,) and derision and laughter and enjoyment with them, God will requite him for that, (O,) or God will cause him to be in a state in which the like shall be done with him. (S, O.) ― -b2- And XamaEa, inf. n. XumuwEN, It was, or became, scattered, or dispersed. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

2 XmREhu c
2. XmREhu, (K,) inf. n. taXomiyEN, (O, K,) He, or it, made him to play, sport, game, jest, or joke. (O, * K.) ＝ -A2- XmRE AlvRawoba He dipped the garment, or piece of cloth, in liquified XamoaE [i. e. wax]. (O, K.)

4 AXmE AlsRiraAju c
4. AXmE AlsRiraAju The lamp, or lighted wick, diffused its light. (S, K.)

XamoEN c
XamoEN and XamaEN, both chaste accord. to ISd: (TA:) accord. to Fr, (S, O, Msb, TA,) the former is post-classical; (S, O, Msb, K, TA;) but ISd says that this is a mistake: (TA:) accord. to ISk one should say the latter, and not the former: (TA:) or accord. to him, the word is with fet-h to the m, and some of the Arabs make the m quiescent: accord. to Th, it is with fet-h to the m; and if you will, you may make it quiescent: accord. to IF, the m is sometimes with fet-h; so that he gives one to understand that it is more frequently made quiescent: (Msb:) A kind of thing with which one lights himself: (S, O, Msb, K:) or i. q. muwmN [which, or rather muwmo, in Pers., signifies both wax and the wax-candle; both of which or rather the former and wax-candles, are meant by XamoEN and XamaEN]: (ISk, TA:) or the muwm of honey [i. e. bees' wax]: (Lth, K:) the n. un., (CK,) or what denotes a piece, or portion, thereof, (so in copies of the K and in the TA,) is with p, (K, TA,) XamoEapN and XamaEapN, (TA,) [i. e.] XmEp has a more particular signification. (S, O.)

XamoEiIRN c
XamoEiIRN or XamaEiIRN (K [as there mentioned app. meaning A dealer in wax or wax-candles, like XamRaAEN↓ in the present day,]) a rel. n. from XamoEN or XamaEN. (TA. [The latter said in the K to be the correct form.])

XimaAEN c
XimaAEN Mirth and laughter and jesting or joking; as also XimaAEapN↓. (TA. [Not mentioned there as inf. ns.])

XamuwEN c
XamuwEN, applied to a woman, (S, K,) That jests, or jokes, much; (K, TA;) pleasant in discourse; that kisses one, and will not comply with one's desire otherwise than by doing thus: (TA:) [or] playful, sportful, or gamesome, and wont to laugh; (S, K, TA;) and in this sense applied also to a man: or, applied to a woman, that cheers by her discourse. (TA.)

XimaAEapN c
XimaAEapN: see XimaAEN.

XamRaAEN c
XamRaAEN A manufacturer of XmE [meaning waxcandles]: (TA:) or a melter of XmE [meaning wax]. (KL.) See also XamoEiIRN.

miXomaEapN c
miXomaEapN A candlestick: pl. maXaAmiEu. (MA.)

muXamRaEN c
muXamRaEN A garment, or cloth, dipped in liquified XamoaE [i. e. wax]. (TA.)

misokN maXomuwEN c
misokN maXomuwEN Musk mixed with ambergris. (O, K.)

Q. 1 XamoEala c
Q. 1. XamoEala, (O, K, TA, [in the CK taXamoEala,]) inf. n. XamoEalapN, (TA,) It became scattered or dispersed. (O, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- And XamoEalapN signifies The reading, or reciting, of the Jews, (S, O, K, TA,) when they assemble fI mhrhm: (TA: [but I know not what this means:]) one says of them XamoEalat [i. e. XamoEalati Alyahuwdu]. (TA.)

Q. 4 AiXomaEalRa c
Q. 4. AiXomaEalRa He hastened, made haste, or went quickly; syn. OasoraEa: this is the primary signification. (Ham p. 282.) One says of a she-camel AXmElRt meaning She hastened, &c. (S.) ― -b2- And AXmElRt AlUibilu The camels went, or went away, and scattered or dispersed themselves, by reason of briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness: (Kh, S, O, K:) or spread themselves, or became scattered or dispersed; as also AXmETRt: (Aboo-Turáb, TA:) or became scattered or dispersed, going [away] quickly. (TA.) And in like manner, (Kh, S, O,) AXmElRt AlgaArapu fiI AlEaduwRi, (Kh, S, O, K,) meaning The horsemen making a sudden attack upon the enemy scattered, or dispersed, themselves; (Aboo-Turáb, K, * TA;) and so AXmETRt. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.) And AXmElR Alqawomu fiI AlTRalabi The people, or company of men, hastened, and scattered or dispersed themselves, in seeking; (Aboo-Turáb, S, O, K;) as also AXmETR. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.) ＝ -A2- And i. q. OaXorafa [q. v.]. (O, K.)

XamoEalN c
XamoEalN, and with p: see the following paragraph.

muXomaEilRN c
muXomaEilRN A swift she-camel; (Az, S;) or so muXomaEilRapN: (O:) and XamoEalN↓ and XamoEalapN↓ (O, K) and muXomaEilRN (K) a she-camel brisk, lively, or sprightly, (O, K,) and swift, (K,) and light, active, or agile. (TA.) muXomaEilRapN in the first of these senses is [said to be] from the phrase qirobapN muXomaEilRapN A water-skin of which the water flows out. (Har p. 111.) ― -b2- Also A man quick and penetrating or having a penetrative energy: and with p, a very active woman. (TA.) A man light, active, or agile; excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, &c., or clever, ingenious, or acute in mind: or tall. (K.) A man vigorous, strenuous, or energetic, and light, active,
or agile. (Ham p. 384.) ― -b3- Also applied to milk, meaning Sour, (K, TA,) overcoming by its sourness. (TA.)

1 Xamilahumu AlOamoru c
1. Xamilahumu AlOamoru, aor.
Xamala
; and Xamalahum, aor.
Xamula
; (S, Msb, K;) but the latter verb was unknown to As, (S, TA,) and is said by Lh to be rare; (TA;) inf. n. XamalN, (Msb, K,) which is of the former, (Msb,) and XumuwlN, (Msb, K,) and XamolN; (K;) i. q. EamRahumo [i. e. The event, or case, included them in common, in general, or universally, within the compass of its effect or effects, its operation or operations, its influence, or the like]: (S, Msb, K:) or Xamilahumo xayorFA or XarRFA, or xayorFA and XarRFA, (accord. to different copies of the K,) like fariHa, (in the CK, or like fariHa,) [app. means he, or it, caused that] good or evil, or good and evil, betided them [in common, in general, or universally]: and XarRFA OaXomalahumo↓ [means] EamRahumo bihi [i. e. he, or it, included them in common, in general, or universally, with, or by, evil]: (K:) but one should not say, AXmlhm xayorFA. (TA.) [Whether what precedes, or what next follows, should be regarded as giving the primary signification of Xamila, is uncertain.] ― -b2- Xamilahu, aor.
Xamala
, inf. n. XamolN and XumuwlN, He covered [or enveloped] him with the Xamolap, (K, TA,) or, with the miXomalap: such is thought by ISd to be meant by the explanation given by Lh, which is, gaTRaI Ealayohi AlmiXomalapa. (TA.) ― -b3- hecihi XamolapN taXomaluka means tasaEuka [i. e. This is a Xmlp sufficient in its dimensions, or sufficiently large, for thee]. (TA.) You say, AiXotarayotu XamolapF vaXomaluniI [I bought a Xmlp sufficient in its dimensions, &c., for me]. (ISk, S, O.) ― -b4- Xamilato liqaAHFA, aor.
Xamala
, (S, O, K,) inf. n. XamalN, (S, O,) said of a she-camel, (S, O, K,) She admitted impregnating seed, (K,) or she conceived, mino faHoli fulaAnK, [from the stallion of such a one]. (S, O.) ― -b5- Xamilato Uibilukumo baEiyrFA lanaA Your camels concealed among them a he-camel belonging to us, by his entering amid their dense multitude: (K, TA:) so in the M and the Moheet. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Xamala AlXRaApa, aor.
Xamula
(S, K) and
Xamila
, (K,) inf. n. XamolN, (S,) He suspended upon the ewe, or she-goat, the kind of bag called XimaAl, and bound it upon her udder: (S, * K, TA:) and some say, Xamala AlnRaAqapa, he suspended a XimaAl upon the she-camel. (T, TA.) Also, and AXmlhA↓, He put to the ewe, or she-goat, (K, TA,) or he made for her, (TA,) a XimaAl. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- Xamala bihi, (K, TA,) inf. n. XamolN, (TA,) He took [in it, i. e. in travelling it, (see the pass. part. n.,)] the direction of the left hand; syn. Oaxaca caAta AlXRimaAli: (K, TA:) so expl. by IAar. (TA.) ― -b2- Xamalati AlrRiyHu, aor.
Xamula
, inf. n. XumuwlN (S, O, TA) and XamaAlN, (O,) or XamolN, (TA,) The wind shifted to a northerly direction (XamaAlFA); (S, TA;) so expl. by Lh: (TA:) or the wind blew northerly; syn. habRato XamaAlFA; as also OaXomalat↓. (O. [In the TA, I find OaXomalat AlryH chbt XmAlyl mvl XamRalt: but this, I doubt not, is a mistranscription of the passage in the O, which I have here followed; i. e. OaXomalati AlriyHu habRat XamAlFA mivl Xamalat; or of a similar passage in which UicaA habRato is put instead of habRato alone.]) One says of two persons when they are separated, Xamalato riyHuhumaA (assumed tropical:) [Their wind has become north, or northerly]. (TA voce januwbN, q. v. [See also maXomuwlN.]) ― -b3- Xamala Alxamora, (K,) aor.
Xamula
, inf. n. XamolN, (TA,) He exposed the wine to the XamaAl [i. e. north, or northerly, wind], so that it became cold, or cool. (K.) ― -b4- And XumiluwA, (S, and in like manner in the Ham p. 595,) or XamiluwA, [expressly said to be] like fariHuwA, (K, [but this I think to be a mistake, the weight of authority, and the form of the part. n., which is maXomuwlN, being against it,]) They were smitten, or blown upon, by the wind called the XamaAl. (S, K.) ＝ -A4- Xamala AlnRaxolapa, (K,) aor.
Xamula
, inf. n. XamolN, (TA,) He picked the ripe dates that were upon the palm-tree; as also AXmlhA↓, and XamolalahaA↓: (K:) or this last (which is mentioned on the authority of Seer), accord. to some, signifies he took of the XamaAliyl of the palmtree; i. e., of the few dates remaining upon it. (TA.)

2 taXomiylN c
2. taXomiylN [properly inf. n. of XamRala]: see 5, of which it is an anomalous inf. n. (TA.) ― -b2- And for its proper verb see 7. ＝ -A2- Also The taking by the XimaAl [or left hand]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And XmRl AlnRaxolapa He bound pieces of [the garments called] Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMCN] beneath the racemes of the palm-tree, because of its shaking off its fruit. (TA.)

4 OaXomalahumN XarRFA c
4. OaXomalahumN XarRFA: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- AXml AlfaHolu Xawolahu, (AZ, S, O,) inf. n. UiXomaAlN; (S;) or AXml Xawolahu liqaAHFA; (K;) The stallion-camel got with young from half to two thirds of the number of his Xawol [or she-camels that had passed seven or eight months since the period of their bringing forth]: (AZ, S, O, K:) when he has got them all with young, one says, OaqamRahaA; (AZ, S, O, TA;) and of the Xwl one says, qamRato, inf. n. qumuwmN. (TA.) ― -b3- AXml fulaAnN xaraAYifahu Such a one picked the ripe dates that were upon his xrAYf [or palm-trees of which he gathered the fruit for himself and his household], except a few. (S, O.) ― -b4- See also 1, last sentence. ＝ -A2- AXmlhu He gave him a Xamolap [q. v.]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- AXml AlXRaApa: see 1. ＝ -A3- AXml He became possessor of a miXomalap, (Lh, TA,) or, of a miXomal. (K.) ＝ -A4- AXmlwA They entered upon [a time in which blew] the [north, or northerly,] wind termed AlXRamaAl: (S, O, K:) like as they say, AjnbwA in the case of the januwb. (TA.) ― -b2- OaXomalati AlrRiyHu: see 1, latter half. ― -b3- See also 7.

5 tXmRl biAlXRamolapi c
5. tXmRl biAlXRamolapi, [and tXmRl AlXRamolapa, (see 5 in art. drs,)] inf. n. taXamRulN and taXomiylN↓; (K;) the former reg.; the latter, which is mentioned by Lh, irreg., an instance like that in the saying [in the Kur lxxiii. 8], watabatRalo Uilayohi tabotiylFA; (TA;) He covered himself with the Xamolap [q. v.]. (K.) [See also 8.]

7 AnXml c
7. AnXml i. q. XamRara, (K, TA,) or AinoXamara, (O, TA,) [both of which signify He passed along striving, or exerting himself; and the latter signifies also he acted with a penetrative force or energy; and he hastened, or went quickly;] fiI HaAjatihi [in his needful affair]. (O, TA.) And i. q. OasoraEa [He hastened; went quickly; or was quick, swift, or fleet]: (K:) or so OaXomala↓: (thus in the O, as on the authority of IDrd:) or so AXtml↓, inf. n. AXtmAl: (thus accord. to my copy of the Msb:) and likewise (O, K) Xamolala↓, (S, O, K,) inf. n. XamolalapN: (S:) and so XmRl↓, (K,) inf. n. taXomiylN. (TA.) And i. q. AinoXamara (O, TA) and AinoDamRa, (TA,) [both meaning It became contracted,] as used by a poet in relation to a she-camel's udder. (O, TA.)

8 AXtml bivawobihi c
8. AXtml bivawobihi He wrapped, or inwrapped, himself with his garment; syn. talafRafa: (S, O:) or AXtml biAlvRawobi signifies he wrapped the garment around the whole of his body so that his arm, or hand, did not come forth from it: (K:) or, as some say, he wrapped himself with the garment, and threw [a part of] it upon his left side. (TA.) [See also 5.] AiXotimaAlu AlSRamRaMCi, which is forbidden by the Prophet, is, accord. to As, The wrapping oneself with the garment so as to cover with it his body, not raising a side thereof in such a manner that there is in it an opening from which he may put forth his hand, or arm: (O:) this is also termed AltRalafRuEu: and sometimes one reclines in the state thus described: (TA:) but A 'Obeyd says, accord. to the explanation of the lawyers, it is the wrapping oneself with one garment, not having upon him another, then raising it on one side and putting it upon his shoulders: [so says Sgh; and he adds,] he who explains it thus has regard to the dislike of one's uncovering himself and exposing to view the pudenda; and he who explains it as do the lexicologists dislikes one's covering his whole body for fear of his becoming in a state in which his respiration would become obstructed so that he would perish: (O:) or it is one's covering his whole body with the kisaMC or with the UizaAr; (S, Msb;) to which some add, not raising aught of the sides thereof. (Msb.) [See also art. Sm.] One says also, yaXotamilu EalaI AlsRayfi [He wraps his garment over the sword; or] he covers the sword with his garment. (S, O.) ― -b2- [Hence, AXtml EalaI kacaA It comprehended, or comprised, such a thing.] One says, AlrRaHimu taXotamilu EalaI Alwaladi (assumed tropical:) The womb comprises [or encloses] the young. (TA.) [And in like manner one says of a woman, AXtmlt minohu EalaI waladK (assumed tropical:) She became with child by him. And AlkitaAbu yaXotamilu EalaI kacaA wakacaA (assumed tropical:) The book, or writing, comprises such and such things. And hence the phrase in grammar, badalu QXotimaAlK (assumed tropical:) A substitute for an antecedent to indicate an implication therein.] ― -b3- One says also, AXtml Ealayohi AlOamoru, meaning (tropical:) The event [such as a misfortune or an evil of any kind beset him, or beset him on every side, or] encompassed him; (K, TA;) like as the kisaMC encompasses the body.
(TA.) ― -b4- One says of wine, taXotamilu EalaI AlEaqoli fatamolikuhu watacohabu bihi (assumed tropical:) [It compasses the intellect, and so takes possession of it, and makes away with it]: (Ham p. 555:) or taXotamilu EalaI Eaqoli AlUinosaAni fatugayRibuhu (assumed tropical:) [It compasses the intellect of the man, and conceals it]; and thus one says of the present world or its enjoyments (AldRunoyaA). (TA.) [AXtml EalaI XaIoCK often means (assumed tropical:) He took, or got, possession of a thing; got it, or held it, within his grasp, or in his possession.] ― -b5- [Hence,] one says, AXtml EalaI naAqapK facahaba bihaA (assumed tropical:) He mounted a she-camel and went away with her. (AZ, O.) ― -b6- And AXtml Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) He shrouded, covered, or protected, him with himself, or his own person. (TA.) ― -b7- See also 7

R. Q. 1 Xamolala c
R. Q. 1. Xamolala: see 1, last sentence: ＝ -A2- and see also 7.

XamolN c
XamolN A state of union or composedness: and a state of disunion or discomposedness: thus having two contr. significations: (MF, TA:) or a united, or composed, state of the affairs, (S, Msb, TA,) and of the number, (TA,) of a people, or company of men: (S, Msb, TA:) and a disunited, or discomposed, state of the affairs [&c.] thereof. (S, Mgh, Msb.) In imprecating evil upon enemies, (O, TA,) [or upon an enemy,] one says, XatRata QllRehu Xamolahumo, (O, TA,) or farRaqa QllRehu Xamolahumo, (Msb,) or frRq AllReh Xamolahu, (S,) i. e. [May God dissolve, break up, discompose, derange, disorganize, disorder, or unsettle,] their, (Msb,) or his, (S,) united, or composed, state of affairs; (S, Msb;) and XatRa Xamoluhumo i. e. [May their united, or composed, state of affairs &c.] become dissolved, broken up, discomposed, &c.: (O, TA:) and [in the contr. case] one says, jamaEa QllRehu Xamolahumo, (S, O, Msb, TA,) or Xamolahu, (Mgh,) i. e. [May God unite, or compose,] their, (S, Msb,) or his, (Mgh,) disunited, or discomposed, state of affairs [&c.]. (S, Mgh, Msb.) And XamalN↓ signifies the same: El-Ba'eeth says,
qado yanoEaXu QllRehu AlfataI baEoda EavorapK
waqado yajomaEu QllRehu AlXRatiyta mina AlXRamalo
[Sometimes, or often, God raises the young man after a stumble: and sometimes, or often, God unites, or composes, what is dissolved, or broken up, of the state of affairs previously united, or composed]: (S, O:) AZ cites this ex. in his “ Nawádir: ” (S:) but Aboo-'Omar El-Jarmee says that he had not heard the word thus except in this verse: (S, O:) Ibn-Buzurj, however, cites another verse as presenting an ex. of the same. (TA.) ― -b2- daxala fiI XamolihaA and XamalihaA↓, said of a he-camel that has become concealed among a herd of [she-] camels, means He entered amid their dense multitude: (K, TA:) so in the M and the Moheet. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (AHn, O, K,) and so XimolN↓, and XimilRN↓, (K,) A raceme of a palm-tree: (AHn, O, K:) Et-Tirimmáh likens thereto a camel's tail: (TA:) or such as has little fruit: (K:) or of which some of the fruit has been plucked: but AO used to say that it is the produce [or spadix] of the male palm-tree, while not abundant and large. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also XamaAlN. ＝ -A4- And XamolN mino junuwnK signifies Fear, or fright, like insanity: and so XamalN↓ [used alone, and thus written]. (TA.)

XimolN c
XimolN: see the next preceding paragraph, near the end.

XamalN c
XamalN: see XamolN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also i. q. kanafN [as meaning Quarter, or shelter or protection]: Alkatifu in the copies of the K being a mistake for Alkanafu: one says, naHonu fiI Xamalikumo i. e. fiI kanafikumo [We are in your quarter, &c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And A small quantity (S, K) of dates upon a palm-tree (S) or of ripe dates: (K:) and of rain: (S, K:) and a small number (S, K) of men and of camels (S) or of men &c.: pl. OaXomaAlN: and in like manner XumoluwlN↓ [app. in all of these applications]; (K;) [or] as meaning a light quantity of fruit of the palm-tree; (TA;) and the pl. of the latter is XamaAliylu: (K:) one says, maA EalaI AlnRaxolapi UilRaA XamalN and XamalapN↓ and XamaAliylu↓ There is not upon the palm-tree save a small quantity remaining of its fruit: (S, TA:) or maAbaqiIa fiI AlnRaxolapi UilRaA XamalapN↓ and XamaAliylu↓ There remained not upon the palm-tree save somewhat in a sparse state [of its fruit]: (TA:) and OaSaAbanaA XamalN mino maTarK A small quantity of rain fell upon us: and raOayotu XamalFA mina AlnRaAsi waAlUibili I saw a small number of men and of camels. (S.) ＝ -A4- See also XamaAlN, in two places: ＝ -A5- And see XamolN, last sentence.

XamilN c
XamilN Wrapping, or inwrapping, himself (muXotamilN↓) with a Xamolap [q. v.]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And Thin; syn. raqiyqN: thus expl. by Sh, as applied in this sense by Ibn-Mukbil to a she-camel's tail, which he terms liyf. (TA.)

XamolapN c
XamolapN A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC, with which one wraps, or inwraps, himself (yuXotamalu bihi), (S, Mgh, K,) smaller than the qaTiyfap; as also miXomalN↓ (K) and miXomalapN↓; (S, K;) the last two expl. by Lth as a kisaMC having a sparse villous substance, with which one wraps himself, smaller than the qaTiyfap: (TA:) or the first signifies a small kisaMC which one wears in the manner of the UizaAr [or waist-wrapper]: (Msb:) or with the Arabs it is a miYozar [or waist-wrapper] of wool or of [goats'] hair, which one wraps round him: and miXomalapN↓, such as is made of two pieces sewed together, with which a man wraps himself when he sleeps by night: (Az, TA:) and this last, accord. to Meyd, signifies a kisaMC comprising the steel with which one strikes fire, with the apparatus of this latter: (Har p. 628:) the pl. of the first is XimaAlN (Msb, TA) and XamalaAtN. (Msb.) [See also miXomaAlN.] ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] DamRa Ealayohi AllRayolu Xamolatahu (tropical:) [The night contracted upon him its covering of darkness]. (TA.) ― -b3- And OumRu Xamolapa (tropical:) The present world, or its enjoyments; syn. AldRunoyaA: (IAar, K, TA:) so called because compassing the intellect of a man (taXotamilu EalaI Eaqolihi), and concealing it. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Wine: (AA, K, TA:) so called for the same reason. (TA.) ― -b5- And The sun. (Z, TA; and T in art. Am).

XimolapN c
XimolapN A mode, or manner, of AiXotimaAl [or wrapping oneself with a garment as expl. above: see 8]. (K, TA.) AlXimolapu AlSRamRaMCu is That [mode of wrapping oneself] which is without a shirt and without drawers beneath; in the case of which, prayer is disliked. (TA. [See 8, and see also art. Sm.])

XamalapN c
XamalapN: see XamalN, in two places.

XamalRN c
XamalRN: see XamaAlN.

XimilRN c
XimilRN: see XamolN, near the end of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also, (TA,) and XimilRapN; (S, O, K, TA;) the former applied to a he-camel; (TA;) and the latter to a she-camel, as also XimolaAlN↓ and XimoliylN↓, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) which are likewise applied to a he-camel, (TA,) and XimaAlN↓; (K;) Light, active, or agile; (S, O, Msb, K;) or swift. (Msb, K, TA.) Hence the phrase TaOoTaOotu XimolaAliI↓ [I hastened my light one, or my swift one]: or, accord. to AA, he means his hand, or arm, called the XimaAl; [i. e. I lowered my left hand or arm;] XimolaAlN and XimaAlN meaning the same. (S, O.)

XamaAlN c
