XamaAlN, (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) the most common form of the word, (Msb,) and XimaAlN↓, [a form which I think objectionable as likely to cause confusion, though it is probably the original form,] (K,) and XamoOalN↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) and XamoOalRN↓, (S, O, K, [in one place in the O erroneously written XaOmalR,]) and XaOomalN↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) which last is formed by transposition, (S, O, Msb,) and XaAmalN↓, without C, (MF, TA,) and XawomalN↓, and XayomalN↓ and XamuwlN↓, (O, K,) and XamiylN↓, (K,) and XamalN↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) and XamolN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the last said by ISd not to have been heard except in the poetry of El-Ba'eeth, (TA,) and XamalRN↓, (MF, TA,) [every one of these] used as a subst. and as an epithet, (K,) [so that one says riyHu AlXRamaAli &c. as well as riyHN XamaAlN &c. and XamaAlN &c. alone; The north wind: or a northerly wind:] the wind that is the opposite to the januwb: (Msb:) the wind that blows from the direction of the quTob [or pole-star]: (S:) or the wind that blows from the direction of the Hijor [which is on what is called the north, but what is rather to be called the north-west, side of the Kaabeh]: (M, K:) or the wind that blows from the direction of the right hand of a person facing the Kibleh [by which is meant the angle of the Black Stone; i. e., correctly speaking, from the north]: (Th, M, K:) or, correctly, the wind that blows from between the place of sunrise and the constellation of the Bear (banaAt naEoX): or from between the place of sunrise and the place of setting of the constellation of the Eagle (AlnRasor
AlTRaAYir): (IAar, K:) [i. e. the wind that blows from some point of the north-east quarter, or nearly so: but it was probably thus named as being the wind that blows from the direction of the XimaAl (or left side) of a person facing the rising sun; and therefore the north wind or a northerly wind:] it seldom, or never, blows in the night: (K:) when it blows for seven days upon the people of Egypt, they prepare the graveclothes, for its nature is deadly: it is cold and dry: (TA:) [see also nakobaMCu:] the pl. of XamaAlN is XamaAlaAtN (S, O, K) and XamaAYilu, which is anomalous, as though pl. of XamaAlapN: (S, O:) AlOaXaAmil also occurs, coupled with AlOajaAnib, in a verse of Et- Tirimmáh; and [as OajaAnibu is a reg. pl. of OajonubN, which is a pl. of januwbN,] ISd thinks that they formed from XamolN the pl. OaXomalN; and then from this last, the pl. OaXaAmilu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, OaSabotu mino fulaAnK XamalFA↓ i. e. riyHFA [(assumed tropical:) I perceived from such a one an odour, app. meaning a foul odour]. (TA.)

XimaAlN c
XimaAlN, (S, O, Msb, K, &c.,) applied to one of the hands or arms, (S, Msb,) The left; contr. of yamiynN; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also XiymaAlN↓, (K, TA, [in the CK, AlXRamAl and AlXRmAl are erroneously put for AlXRimaAl and AlXRiymaAl,]) the latter thought by ISd to be used only by poetic license, for XimaAlN, (TA,) and XimolaAlN↓, (AA, S, O, K,) this last not known to Ks nor to As: (TA:) of the fem. gender: (S, O, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXomulN, (S, O, Msb, K,) because it is fem., (S, O,) and [of mult.] XamaAYilu, (S, O, Msb, K,) which is anomalous, (S, O,) and XumulN, and XimaAlN like the sing. (K.) ― -b2- And The direction [or side] of the hand so called: you say, Ailotafata yamiynFA waXimaAlFA i. e. [He looked, or turned his face,] in the direction of the ymyn and in the direction of the XmAl: and the pl. in this sense also is OuXomulN and XamaAYilu: (Msb:) you say, cahaba UilaI Oayomuni AlUibili waOaXomulihaA He went to the right sides of the camels and the left sides thereof. (TA in art. ymn.) ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) Ill luck, unluckiness, or evil fortune. (K, TA.) Tayoru AlXRimaAli means (tropical:) Birds of ill luck: (A, TA:) every bird from which one augurs evil. (O, TA.) One says, jaraI lahu guraAbu XimaAlK, meaning (assumed tropical:) What was disliked, or hated, happened to him: as though the bird [to which this is likened] came to him from the XimaAl [or direction of the left hand]. (TA.) And when the place that a person occupies is rendered evil, one says, fulaAnN EinodiI biAlXRimaAli (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is with me, or in my estimation, in an evil plight]. (TA.) ― -b4- See also XamaAlN. ― -b5- Also Every handful of corn, or seedproduce, which the reaper grasps [app. because grasped with his left hand]. (K.) ＝ -A2- And A sort of bag that is put upon the udder of the ewe or goat (S, O, K) when it (i. e. the udder, TA) is heavy [with milk]: (K, * TA:) or it is peculiar to the she-goat: (K:) pl. XumulN. (K voce EaraAbapN.) ― -b2- And A similar thing that is put to the raceme of a palm-tree, made with pieces of [the garments called] Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMCN], in order that the fruit may not be shaken off. (S, O.) [In this sense it may perhaps be from the same word as pl. of XamolapN.] ＝ -A3- And A mark made with a hot iron (simapN) upon the udder of a ewe or goat. (K.) ＝ -A4- Also A nature; or a natural disposition or temper or the like: (O, Msb, K:) accord. to Er-Rághib, so called because [it is as though it were a thing] inwrapping the man [and restricting his freedom of action], like as the [garments called] XimaAl [pl. of XamolapN] inwrap the body: (TA:) the pl. is XamaAYilu, (O, K, TA,) and XimaAlN, also, [which seems to be rarely used as a sing. in this sense,] may be a pl., like dilaASN. (TA; and Ham p. 489, q. v.) 'Abd-Yaghooth El-Hárithee says,
Oalamo taEolamaA OanRa AlmalaAmapa nafoEuhaA
qaliylN wamaA lawomiI OaxiImino XimaAliyaA
[Know not ye two that the utility of censure is little, and my censuring my brother is not of my nature, or of my natural dispositions?]: (O, TA:) here it may be a pl., of the class of hijaAnN and dilaASN: or it may be [XamaAliyaA,] an instance of transposition, for XamaAYiliI. (TA.) ＝ -A5- See also XimilRN.

XamoOalN c
XamoOalN and XamoOalRN: see XamaAlN.

XamuwlN c
XamuwlN: see XamaAlN. ― -b2- Also Wine: (S, K:) or wine that is cool (K, TA) to the taste; but this is not of valid authority; (TA;) as also maXomuwlapN↓: [wine is said to be] thus called because it envelops (taXomalu) men with its odour: or because it has a strong puff (EaSofap), [when opened,] like that of the [wind called] XamaAl [in the CK XmAl]. (K, TA.)

XamiylN c
XamiylN: see XamaAlN.

XmAlp c
XmAlp [thus in my original, without any syll. signs, probably XimaAlapN, like sitaArapN &c.,] The lurkingplace (qutorap) of a hunter or sportsman: pl. XamaAYilu. (TA.)

XamaAliIRN c
XamaAliIRN Of, or relating to, the quarter of the XamaAl [or north, or northerly, wind]. (KL.) ― -b2- And A cold day. (KL.)

XimolaAlN c
XimolaAlN: see XimilRN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see XimaAlN.

XumoluwlN c
XumoluwlN; and its pl. XamaAliylu: see XamalN, in three places. ― -b2- XamaAliylu also signifies The shoots that divaricate at the heads of branches, like the fruitstalks of the raceme of the palm-tree. (S, O.) ― -b3- [Hence,] cahabuwA XamaAliyla They went away in distinct parties: (K:) or they dispersed themselves. (S, O.) ― -b4- And vawobN XamaAliylu A garment, or piece of cloth, rent, or slit, in several places; (O, TA;) like XamaATiyTu. (S, O.) ― -b5- XamaAliylu AlnwI means baqaAyaAhu [i. e. The remains of AlnwI: but I doubt whether this word be correctly transcribed]. (TA.)

XimoliylN c
XimoliylN: see XimilRN.

XaAmalN c
XaAmalN and XaOomalN: see XamaAlN.

OamorN XaAmilN c
OamorN XaAmilN i. q. EaAmRN [i. e. An event, or a case, that includes persons or things in common, in general, or universally, within the compass of its effect or effects, its operation or operations, its influence, or the like; or that is common, general, or universal, in its effect &c.]. (S, * O, * Msb, TA.) ― -b2- lawonN XaAmilN A black colour overspread with another colour. (O, TA.)

XawomalN c
XawomalN: see XamaAlN.

XayomalN c
XayomalN: see XamaAlN.

XiymaAlN c
XiymaAlN: see XimaAlN.

miXomalN c
miXomalN: see XamolapN. ― -b2- Also A short sword, (S, O, K,) or a short and slender sword, like the migowal, (TA,) over which a man covers himself with his garment. (S, O, K.)

maXomalapN c
maXomalapN The place [or quarter] whence blows the [north, or northerly, wind called] XamaAl. (Ham p. 628.)

miXomalapN c
miXomalapN: see XamolapN, in two places.

miXomaAlN c
miXomaAlN A [garment of the kind called] miloHafap, (K, TA,) with which one wraps, or inwraps, himself (yuXotamalu bihi). (TA.) [See also XamolapN.]

maXomuwlN c
maXomuwlN A man smitten, or blown upon, by the [north, or northerly,] wind called XamaAl: (S, O:) and in like manner, a meadow, and a pool of water left by a torrent; (O;) or, applied to this last, smitten by the wind thus called so as to become cool: (S:) and hence, with p, wine (tropical:) cool to the taste; (S, O, TA; *) or wine exposed to the XamaAl and so rendered cool and pleasant: (TA: see also XamuwlN:) and fire upon which the wind called the XamaAl has blown: (S, O:) and a night cold, with [wind that is called] XamaAl. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) One whose natural dispositions are liked, approved, or found pleasant: (K:) from [the same epithet applied to] water upon which the XamaAl has blown, and which it has cooled: or, as ISd thinks, from XamuwlN [q. v.]: (TA:) or maXomuwlu AlxalaAYiqi a man whose natural dispositions are commended; as being likened to wine that is commended: and also whose natural dispositions are discommended; as though from AlXRamaAlu, because they do not commend it when it disperses the clouds: (Har p. 285:) [for] OaxolaAqN maXomuwlapN [sometimes] means discommended, evil, natural dispositions. (IAar, ISk, TA.) The saying of Aboo-Wejzeh,
maXomuwlapu AlOunosi majonuwbN mawaAEiduhaA
is expl. by IAar as meaning (assumed tropical:) Her familiarity passes away with the XamaAl, and her promises pass away with the januwb [which is the opposite of the XamaAl]: or, as some relate it,
majonuwbapu AlOunosi maXomuwlN mawaAEiduhaA
[meaning in like manner, as is said in the TA, on the authority of IAar, in art. jnb: or,] accord. to ISk, meaning her familiarity is commended,
because the jnwb, with rain, is desired for abundance of herbage; and her promises are not commended. (TA.) ― -b3- nawFI maXomuwlapN, a phrase used by Zuheyr, is expl. as meaning (assumed tropical:) [A tract, or place, towards which one journeys,] that separates friends; because the [wind called] XamaAl disperses the clouds: (TA:) or it means quickly [or soon] becoming exposed to view; (ISk, O, TA;) from the fact that when the wind called the XamaAl blows the clouds, they delay not to become cleared away, and to depart: (O:) or, accord. to IAar, it means maOoxuwcN bihaA caAtu AlXRimaAli [in which the direction of the left hand is taken]. (TA.) ― -b4- In the saying,
Hamalato bihi fiI layolapK maXomuwlapN
the meaning is, fariEapN [i. e. One in a state of fright became pregnant with him in a certain night]. (TA, referring to the phrase XamolN mino junuwnK.)

muXotamilN c
muXotamilN: see XamilN ― -b2- One says, jaMCa muXotamilFA bisayofihi like as one says murotadiyFA [i. e. He came having his sword hung upon him]. (TA.) ― -b3- And jaMCa fulaAnN muXotamilFA EalaI daAhiyapK (tropical:) [Such a one came conceiving a calamity]. (TA.)

1 XanRa AlmaMCa c
1. XanRa AlmaMCa, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
Xanuna
, inf. n. XanRN, (Mgh, TA,) He scattered the water; (S, K;) or poured it scatteringly; (Mgh;) or poured it and scattered it; or, as some say, poured it in a manner like that which is termed naDoHN [i. e. sprinkling]; (TA;) EalaI AlXRaraAbi [upon the wine, or beverage]: (S, K:) sanRahu signifies “ he poured it gently. ” (TA.) And XanRati AlEayonu damoEahaA The eye poured forth its tears; (TA;) or sent forth [or shed] its tears; like XalRat, (Lh, TA in art. Xl,) which is asserted by Yaakoob to be formed by substitution [of l for n]. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- And, from the former, XanRa AlgaArapa, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) (tropical:) He scattered, (S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) or poured, (K, TA,) the horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, and engaging in conflict, or the horsemen urging their horses, AlgaArapa meaning Alxayola Almugiyrapa, (Mgh, Msb,) from every direction, Ealayohimo [upon them]; (S, K;) as also AXnRhA↓; (S, Msb, K;) the latter mentioned in the Mj, (Msb,) by IF, but disapproved by the people of chaste speech. (TA.) ― -b3- And XanRa bisaloHihi (AA, S, * TA) He cast forth his excrement, or dung, in a thin [and scattered] state: and one says of the HubaAraI [or bustard] taXunRu bicaroqihaA [It casts forth its dung in a thin and scattered state]. (AA, TA.) ― -b4- And XanRa Ealayoihi diroEahu He put (lit. poured) on him his coat of mail. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XanRa Aljamalu mina AlEaTaXi, [aor. accord. to general rule
Xanina
,] The camel became dried up [like a XanR, q. v.,] from thirst. (TA.) And XanRati Alxiroqapu The rag became dried up. (TA.)

2 taXoniynN c and taXonaAnN
2. taXoniynN taXonaAnN [inf. ns. of XnRn] The dripping, or dropping by degrees, of water from the XanRap [or old and worn-out water-skin or the like]. (TA. [See also XaniynN.])

4 OaXonana
4: see 1: ― -b2- and see also what next follows.

5 taXanRanati Alqirobapu c
5. taXanRanati Alqirobapu, and tXAnRt↓, (S, K,) and AXnRt↓ and AstXnRt↓, (K,) The water-skin became old, and worn out: (S, K:) or tXAnR↓, said of skin, or a skin, does not signify thus, but signifies, (AA, S,) or signifies also, (K,) and so tXnRn, (S, K, TA,) said of the skin of a man, in extreme old age, (S,) it contracted, shrank, shrivelled, or wrinkled; or became contracted or shrunk &c.; (S, K, TA;) and dried up: (S, TA:) and AstXnR↓ is likewise said of the skin of a man, meaning it became old, and worn out, like the old, and worn-out, XanR. (Har p. 675.) It is said in a trad., AlquroMnu laA yatofahu walaA yataXaAnRu↓ [expl. in art. tfh]. (TA.) See also a tropical usage of AstXnR↓ in a trad. cited in the first paragraph of art. bl. ― -b2- tXnRn is also said of the skin of a man as meaning It became altered [for the worse] in odour, in extreme old age. (TA.)

6 taXaAnRa c
6. taXaAnRa: see 5, in three places. ― -b2- Also It was or became, mixed. (K.)

7 UinoXanana
7: [AnXnR It became poured out, or forth; it flowed. (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.) ― -b2- Hence,] AnXnR AlcRiYobu fiI Alganami (assumed tropical:) The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats; as also AnXlR: mentioned by Az in art. nXg. (TA.)

10 AstXnR c
10. AstXnR: see 5, in three places. ― -b2- Also, (Kh, S, K,) said of a man, (Kh, S, TA,) and of a camel, (TA,) (tropical:) He became lean, or emaciated, (Kh, S, K, TA,) like the water-skin that has become old, and worn out: so says Aboo-Kheyreh: (TA:) or, said of an animal, he became dried up, and lean, or emaciated. (Har p. 530.) ― -b3- And AstXnR UilaI AllRabani i. q. EaAma, (K,) i. e. He betook himself to milk, or the milk, and desired it eagerly, or longed for it. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 XanoXanapN c
R. Q. 1. XanoXanapN [an inf. n., of which the verb, if it be used, is XanoXana,] The motion of paper, and of a new garment: [or rather the making a kind of crackling sound by the motion thereof:] mentioned by Az in art. fqE: (TA:) and naXonaXapN signifies the same: both thus expl. by IAar. (TA in art. qE.)

XanRN c
XanRN A skin, (Msb,) or a water-skin, (S, Mgh,) or a small water skin, (K,) or, as some say, any vessel made of skin, (TA,) applied by a poet to a dalow [or leathern bucket], (Ham p. 602,) that is old, and worn out; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) and so XanRapN↓; (S, K;) but app. one that is small: (S: [in which this addition to the explanation seems to relate peculiarly to the latter word: see an ex. of this latter word in some verses cited in the first paragraph of art. sqI:]) or both signify an old water-skin; as also miXanRN↓: (MA:) and XananN↓, also, signifies an old, worn-out, water-skin: (TA:) pl. (of the first, Mgh, Msb) XinaAnN: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and Lh mentions the phrase qirobapN OaXonaAnN, as though they applied the term XanRN to every portion of the qrbp and then pluralized it thus; but he says that he had not heard OaXonaAnN as a pl. of XanRN except in this case: (TA:) the water in a XanR is cooler [than that in a skin not so old]. (Mgh.) It is said in a prov., laA yuqaEoqaEu liI biAlXRinaAni [A confused and clattering noise will not be made to me with the old and worn-out water-skins to frighten me]: (S in the present art.: [in the S and K in art. qE, with maA in the place of lA; and in the K in that art., with lahu in the place of lI:]) maA yuqaEoqaEu lahu biAlXRinaAni is applied to him who will not be abased by misfortunes, nor frightened by that which has no reality: (Sgh and K in art. qE:) or it means, he will not be deceived nor frightened: XinaAn being pl. of XanRN, a dried up skin, which is shaken to a camel to frighten him. (L and TA in art. qE.) An old man is likened to the skin thus termed. (Har p. 675.) And XanRapN↓ signifies also (tropical:) A worn-out old woman; as being likened to the skin thus termed. (IAar, TA.) And one says, rafaEa fulaAnN AlXRanRa, meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a man raised himself bearing upon the palm of his hand. (IKh, TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. grD [app. garaDN, i. e. A butt, at which one shoots or casts: probably because an old water-skin was sometimes used as a butt]: pl. as above. (Msb.) ― -b3- [And, as Freytag states, on the authority of Meyd, (assumed tropical:) Dry herbage.] ＝ -A2- Also Weakness. (TA.)

XanRapN c
XanRapN: see XanRN, in two places.

XananN c
XananN: see XanRN, first sentence.

XanaAnN c
XanaAnN a dial. var. of XanoMnN [inf. n. of XaniYa], (S, K,) signifying Hatred; [or the hating of another;] (S;) mentioned by AO. (S in art. XnO.)

XunaAnN c
XunaAnN Water in a scattered state, or being scattered. (S, K.) ― -b2- And (K) Cold water: (As, Skr, ISd, K:) this explanation is preferred by Aboo-Nasr. (TA.) ― -b3- And Clouds (saHaAb) pouring (yaXunRu i. e. yaSubRu) water. (Skr, TA.)

XanuwnN c
XanuwnN A camel in a state between that of the lean, or emaciated, and that of the fat; (S;) so called because some of his fatness has gone: (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA:) one says mahozuwlN; then munoqK, when he has become a little fat; then XanuwnN; then saAHRN; and then muvaroTimN, when fat in the utmost degree: (Lh, TA:) so says Aboo-Ma'add El-Kilá- bee. (TA in art. sH.) [But it is said that] it signifies also Lean, or emaciated; (K;) applied to a beast: (TA:) and fat: thus having two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b2- Also Hungry: (S, K:) applied in this sense by Et-Tirimmáh to a wolf, because this animal is not described as fat or lean. (S.)

XaniynN c
XaniynN Poured forth: applied in this sense by the Hudhalee poet 'Abd-Menáf to thick blood (Ealaq). (TA.) ― -b2- And Pure milk upon which cold water has been poured: (IAar, TA:) or any milk, whether fresh or collected in a skin at different times, upon which water is poured. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- And The dropping (S, K, TA) by degrees, (TA,) of water (S, K, TA) from a skin, (TA,) and of tears. (S, TA. [See also 2, and see XinoXinapN.])

XunaAnapN c
XunaAnapN Water that drops (S, K) from a skin, or from a tree. (S.)

XaAnRapN c
XaAnRapN The [channel called] madofaE [q. v.] of a small valley: or a small madofaE of a valley: (TA: [the want of a vowel-sign in my original renders it doubtful which of these meanings is the right one:]) or XawaAnRu, its pl., signifies the channels of water, of mountains, that pour forth into valleys from a rugged place. (AA, TA.)

XinoXinapN c
XinoXinapN A nature; or a natural, a native, or an innate, disposition or temper or the like; syn. TabiyEapN, (S, Mgh, K,) and xuluqN, (S,) and sajiyRapN: (TA:) and a custom, habit, or wont: (Mgh, K:) [pl. XanaAXinu.] One says fiyhi mino Oabiyhi XanaAXinu In him are habits [or natural dispositions inherited] from his father. (TA.) Hence,
XinoXinapN OaEorifuhaA mino Oaxozamo
[A natural disposition, or a habit, which I know, as inherited from Akhzam]: (S, Meyd, Mgh:) or, accord. to one relation, niXoniXapN, which is app. formed by transposition from XinoXinapN: (Meyd:) a prov.: (Meyd, Mgh:) [of its origin there are different explanations: see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 658, and Har pp. 591 and 596:] Oaxozamu is the proper name of a man: (Meyd, Mgh, &c.:) or accord. to Lth, it is an epithet applied to a penis; one says kamarapN xazomaMCu “ a glans of a penis having a short frænum, ” and cakarN Oaxozamu; and XnXnp means the dropping of water [i. e., in this case, of the seminal fluid]: (Meyd:) the prov. is applied in relation to nearness of resemblance. (Meyd, Mgh.) ＝ -A2- Also A bit of flesh-meat, as much as is chewed at once; syn. muDogapN: or a piece of flesh-meat; (K, TA;) and so niXoniXapN: on the authority of AA. (TA.) ― -b2- And [the pl.] XanaAXinu signifies Bones; like sanaAsinu. (IAar, L in art. sn.)

miXanRN c
miXanRN: see XanRN, first sentence.

miXanRapN c
miXanRapN A thing like the mikotal: [in the present day, a round shallow basket is thus called: pl. maXaAnRu.] (TA.)

1 XaniYahu c
1. XaniYahu, (Th, S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) and XanaOahu, (K,) but this is said by AHeyth to be a bad dial. var. of the former, (TA,) aor.
XanaAa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XanoCN (AO, S, Msb, K) and XinoCN and XunoCN (Aboo- 'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, S, K) and XanoOapN (K, TA, in the CK XanACap [i. e. XanaMCapN, which is afterwards added in the TA, not as in the K, and mentioned in the S but not there said to be an inf. n.,]) and XanaON (TA from Es-Safákusee) and XanaMCN (TA [as from J, but perhaps from Az, for I do not find it in the S,]) and maXonaON (S, CK, and TA as from Es-Safá- kusee, not as from the K,) and maXonaOapN and maXonuWapN (K, TA, the last in the CK maXonuwCap [i. e. maXonuwoCapN],) and maXoniYapN (TA from Es-Safákusee) and XanaMnN, (S, K,) which is anomalous as being of a measure regularly employed [only] for the inf. n. of a verb signifying motion and agitation, as DarabaAnN and xafaqaAnN, (S, TA,) for though it has been said that [hatred (which it signifies) is attended by anger and] anger is accompanied by agitation of the heart, there is no necessary connection between hatred and anger, and it is anomalous also as being of a measure not proper to [the inf. n. of] a trans. verb, (TA,) and XanoMnN, (S, Msb, K,) which is also anomalous, and [said to be] the only instance of its kind (S, TA) except layRaAnN, though some few others have been mentioned, as zayodaAnN, but this is not well known, [and xaXoyaAnN, of which the same may be said,] and waXokaAnN [perhaps a simple subst.], and jawolaAnN which is said to occur in a verse [perhaps contracted from jawalaAn by poetic license], (TA,) and AO mentions XanaAnN, without C, as being like XanoMnN; (S;) these inf. ns. being fourteen, which is said by IKtt to be the greatest number of inf. ns. to any one verb, only seven other verbs, he says, having this number, namely, qadara, laqiIa, warada, halaka, tamRa, makava and galaba; but Es-Safákusee makes the inf. ns. of XaniYa to be fifteen, [though the fifteenth form (which is perhaps maXonuwoCapN) I do not find mentioned,] and this is the greatest number known; (TA;) He hated him: (IKoot, IF, S, ISd, IKtt, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.:) or, as some say, he hated him vehemently. (TA.) yXnI, [app. yuXonaI, for yuXonaOu,] with the hemzeh changed into I, occurs in a trad. (TA.) And XuniYa signifies He (a man, S) was hated, (S, and so accord. to some copies of the K,) or was rendered hateful, or an object of hatred, (so accord. to other copies of the K,) even if beautiful or comely. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- XaniYa lahu HaqRahu, (K,) so says A'Obeyd, or, accord. to Th, XanaOa Uilayohi, like manaEa [in form], and this is the more correct, aor. of each
XanaAa
, (TA,) He gave him his right, or due. (A'Obeyd, Th, K, TA.) And XaniYa bihi He acknowledged it: (S, Msb, K:) or he gave him (K) his right, or due, (TA,) [or the meaning in the K may be he gave it,] and declared himself clear, or quit, of him or it; as also XanaOa: (K:) [but accord. to SM, this is wrong, for he says that] the author of the K should have said, or XaniYa Uilayohi, like XanaOa, aor.
XanaAa
, he gave him, and declared himself clear, or quit, of him or it. (TA.) And XaniYa AlXRaIoCa He produced the thing: (K, TA:) or, as A'Obeyd says, XaniYa HaqRahu he acknowledged his right, or due, and produced it from his possession. (TA.)

6 taXaAnaWuwA c
6. taXaAnaWuwA They hated one another. (S, O, K.)

XanoCN c
XanoCN and XinoCN and XunoCN [all mentioned above as inf. ns., when used as simple substs. signify Hatred; and thus XanaMCapN↓, likewise mentioned above as an inf. n., signifies accord. to the S; and so XaniyoYapN↓ accord. to Freytag, as on the authority of Meyd; and app. also XanuwoCapN, q. v.; or all signify] vehement hatred; in which sense the first is expl. by AO: (TA:) or XanaMCapN↓ signifies hatred mixed with enmity and evilness of disposition. (Ham p. 108)

XanuWapN c
XanuWapN: see XanuwoCapN, in three places.

XanaMCapN c
XanaMCapN: see XanoCN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, and XanaAYiyapN↓, epithets applied to a man, Rendered hateful, or an object of hatred, evil in disposition. (Lth, O, TA.) [See also the latter word voce XanoMn; and see maXonuwoCN, and miXonaMCN.]

XanuwoCapN c
XanuwoCapN The removing oneself far, or keeping aloof, from unclean things; (S, K, TA;) and the continual doing so, or the continual purification of oneself; as also XanuWapN↓; and accord. to the K, XunuwoCapN, but this is not found elsewhere. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) Oazodu XanuwoCapa, the appellation of a tribe of El-Yemen; (S, K; *) sometimes called Oazodu XanuwRapa: (ISk, S, K:) [or] this tribe was so called because of XanoMn among them; (K, TA;) i. e. because of mutual hatred that occurred among them: (TA:) [whence it seems that XanuwoCapN signifies also Hatred:] or because of their removing far from their [original] district: or, accord. to El-Khafájee, because of their high lineage, and good deeds; from the phrase rajulu XanuwodapK, meaning A man of pure lineage and of manly virtue; and AO says the like. (TA.) ― -b3- [And accord. to Reiske, as stated by Freytag, (who has written it XanuWapN↓ in all its senses,) it is expl. by Meyd as meaning What is esteemed sordid, of words and of actions.] ＝ -A2- Also One who removes himself far, or keeps aloof, from unclean things; (K, TA;) and so XanuWapN↓. (TA.) Thus both of these words are epithets, as well as substs. (TA.)

XaniyoYapN c
XaniyoYapN: see XanoCN.

XanoMn c
XanoMn, of which the fem. is XanoMnapN and XanoOaI, [so that one may say either XanoMnN or XanoMnu,] is an epithet applied to a man; (K;) [signifying either Hating or (like maXonuwoCN) hated; the former meaning seeming to be indicated by what immediately precedes it in the K; but the latter appears from what here follows to be the right meaning, and perhaps it may be that which is meant in the K;] as also XanaAniYapN↓ or XanaAYiyapN↓ [q. v. voce XanaMCapN]: so accord. to different copies of the K. (TA.) ― -b2- In the Kur v. 3 and 11, it is accord. to some an inf. n., and some read there XanaMn: [see 1, first sentence:] accord. to others, it is an epithet, signifying mubogaDN or bagiyDN [i. e. Hated or odious]. (TA.) ― -b3- XanoMnu AlXRitaMCi, in a trad. of Kaab, is said to be a metaphorical expression for barodu AlXRitaMCi (tropical:) [The cold of winter]; because it is hated: or, as some say, by the barod thereof is meant ease and repose: and the meaning intended is either mutual hatred or ease and repose. (TA.)

XanaAYiyapN c
XanaAYiyapN: see XanaMCapN, and XanoMn.

XanaAniYapN c
XanaAniYapN: see XanoMn.

XaAniYN c
XaAniYN Hating, or a hater, (Fr, S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and an enemy: (Fr, TA:) fem. with p. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- laA OabaA liXaAniYika, as also laA Oaba liXaAniYika, (S, O, [but in my two copies of the S liXaAniyka, which perhaps expresses the general pronunciation, and in the TA lA AbA lXAnYk and lA AbA lXAnyk,]) means limubogiDika [i. e., lit., May there be no father
to thy hater]; and is said by ISk to be a metonymical expression for laA OabaA laka [q. v., lit. an imprecation, but generally meant as an expression of praise]. (S, O, TA.)

XawaAniYu AlmaAli c
XawaAniYu AlmaAli means [Camels, or the like,] not avariciously retained; as though hated, and therefore liberally given away: (IAar, K, TA:) XwAnY being app. an act. part. n. [in the pl.] used in the sense of a pass. part. n., like the instances in maMCN daAfiqN and EiyXapN raADiyapN. (MF, TA.)

maXonaON c
maXonaON, applied to a man, (A'Obeyd, S, O,) like maXonaEN [in form, and perhaps in meaning], (A'Obeyd, TA,) Foul, or ugly, in aspect; as also miXonaMCN↓: (S, O:) or foul, or ugly, (K, TA,) in face, (TA,) even if made an object of love [by good qualities]: (K, TA:) [originally an inf. n., and therefore] used alike as sing. (S, O, K) and dual (S, O) and pl. (S, O, K) and masc. and fem.: (K:) so says Lth: (TA:) or one who hates men; (K;) and so miXonaMCN↓, accord. to 'Alee Ibn- Hamzeh El-Isbahánee: (TA:) or ↓this last signifies one whom men hate: or it may be well rendered one who does much for which he is to be hated; for it is one of the measures of the act. part. n. [used in an intensive sense]. (A'Obeyd, K.)

miXonaMCN c
miXonaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

maXonuwoCN c
maXonuwoCN, applied to a man, (S,) Hated, (S, and so in some copies of the K, [see also XanoMn,]) or rendered hateful, or an object of hatred, (so accord. to other copies of the K,) even if beautiful, or comely; (S, K;) and maXonuwRN and maXoniIRN signify the same. (K in art. Xnw.)

maXoniyoYapN c
maXoniyoYapN, occurring in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, [A kind of food that is supped, or sipped;] i. q. HasaMCN and talobiynapN: [see these two words:] said by IAth to be irregularly formed from maXonuwoCapN, by changing the C into I [so that the word becomes maXonuwyapN, and then, by rule, maXoniyRapN, which is mentioned in the TA, in art. Xnw, as occurring thus in a trad.,] and then by restoring the C [in the place of the second I], the meaning being hated. (TA.)

1 Xaniba c
1. Xaniba, aor.
Xanaba
, (K,) inf. n. XanabN, (TA,) He had the quality termed XanabN meaning as expl. below. (K.) ― -b2- And It (a day) was, or became, cool, or cold. (A, K.)

XanabN c
XanabN Lustre, and fineness, or delicacy, or thinness, and coolness, and sweetness, in the teeth: (A, K:) or lustre, and fineness, or delicacy, or thinness, in the fore teeth: (TA:) or these two qualities, together with coolness and sweetness, in the mouth, accord. to As, or in the teeth: (TA:) or coolness and sweetness in the teeth: or sharpness of the teeth: (S:) or sharpness of the canine teeth, like garobN, so that they appear like a saw: (K:) or white specks in the teeth: (A, K:) or the state of the teeth when they appear somewhat tinged with blackness, like the appearance of blackness in hail; guruwbN signifying the “ lustre ” of the teeth; and ZalomN, their “ whiteness that is as though there were over it a blackness: ” (ISh, TA:) Abu-l-'Abbás says, It is variously expl., as a serrated state of the teeth: and their clearness and cleanness: and their being separate, or apart, one from another: and the sweetness of their odour: (TA:) El-Jarmee says, I heard As say that this word signifies coolness of the mouth and teeth; and I said, Our companions say that it is their sharpness when they come forth; by which is meant their new, or recent, and fresh state; for when they have undergone the lapse of years, they become abraded, or worn: but he said, It is nothing but their coolness: and the saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,
wafiI AllRivaAti wafiI OanoyaAbihaA Xanabu
[which should be rendered And in the gums, and in her canine teeth, is coolness], corroborates the assertion of As; for there is no sharpness in the gum: (S, L, TA:) it is also related of As that he said, I asked Ru-beh respecting the meaning of XanabN, and he took a grain of pomegranate, and pointed to its lustre: (Mz, TA:) [and XunobapN↓ signifies the same:] a poet says,
munaSRabuhaA HamoXN OaHamRu yaziynuhu
EawaAriDu fiyhaA XunobapN waguruwbu
[Her even set of front teeth are slender and white, side teeth in which are coolness and lustre adorning them]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- [In the present day, it signifies The mustache.]

XanibN c
XanibN and XaAnibN↓, (A, K,) the former regular, the latter on the authority of usage, (TA,) A cool, or cold, day. (A, K.)

XunobapN c
XunobapN Coolness, or coldness, of a day. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also XanabN, near the end.

XaniybN c
XaniybN: see OaXonabu.

XaAnibN c
XaAnibN: see XanibN: ― -b2- and what here follows.

OaXonabu c
OaXonabu Having the quality termed XanabN meaning as expl. above; (A, O, K;) as also XaAnibN↓, (K,) which is irregular, (TA,) and XaniybN↓, (K,) [which is likewise irregular;] but the first of these three is the most common: (TA:) applied to a man, (O,) and to the vagor [or front teeth], (A,) [and to the mouth, as in a verse cited voce zaronabN:] fem. XanobaMCu, (S, O, K,) applied to a woman, (S, O,) and also written XamobaMCu, (K,) the n being changed into m because of the following b, and in like manner [the pl. XunobN is also written] XumobN. (TA.) ― -b2- XanobaMCu also signifies A pomegranate (rumRaAnapN) such as is termed UimoliysiyRapN, having no grains, but only juice within the rind, (A, K, TA,) in the form of grains without stones. (TA.)

miXonabN c
miXonabN A young boy whose teeth are sharp and serrated by reason of his youthfulness. (IAar, O.)

maXaAnibu c
maXaAnibu Sweet mouths. (O, K.)

Q. 1 Xanobava AlhawaI qalobahu c
Q. 1. Xanobava AlhawaI qalobahu, (S and L in art. Xbv, as Q. Q., and K in the present art.,) inf. n. XanobavapN, (S, L,) Love clave to his heart. (S, L, K.)

AlXRanobavu c
AlXRanobavu The lion; as also AlXRunaAbivu↓. (K.)

XunaAbivN c
XunaAbivN Thick, gross, big, bulky, coarse, or rough; syn. galiyZN. (K.) ― -b2- See also AlXRanobavu.

xiyaAru Xanobara c
xiyaAru Xanobara: see the former word in art. xyr.

1 Xanija c
1. Xanija, aor.
Xanaja
, inf. n. XanajN; and tXnRj↓, (S, A, Mgh, K,) and AnXnj↓, (S, K,) and AXnj↓; (TA;) said of the skin (S, Mgh, K) in consequence of the touch [or proximity] of fire [&c.], (Mgh,) and of the face, and of a member or limb, (A,) of a finger, &c., (TA,) It contracted, shrank, shrivelled, or wrinkled; or became contracted or shrunk &c. (S, A, Mgh, K, TA.) [taXanRujN↓ is often used as meaning Spasmodic contraction of a muscle &c.] And one says, fiI OaEoDaAYihi taXanRujN↓ and taXoniyjN↓ [In his limbs, or members, is a contraction]. (A.)

2 XnRjhu c
2. XnRjhu, inf. n. taXoniyjN, He [or it] contracted, shrunk, shrivelled, or wrinkled, it; namely, the skin [&c.]. (S, K.) See 1, last sentence. One says also, XnRj AlxayRaATu AlqabaMCa [The tailor puckered the tunic]. (A. [In the Mgh, the wrinkling around the anus is said to be like the taXoniyj of the qabaMC.])

4 OaXonaja
4: see 1.

5 taXanRaja
5: see 1, in three places; and see muXanRajN.

7 UinoXanaja
7: see 1.

XanajN c
XanajN inf. n. of 1. (S &c.) ＝ -A2- Also A camel: (Lth, IDrd, K:) or a heavy camel. (L in art. gnj.) ganajN EalaIXanajK is a phrase of the tribe of Hudheyl, meaning A man upon a camel: (Lth, IDrd, O:) or a man, or an old man, upon a heavy camel. (L in art. gnj.) ― -b2- It is also said, in the L, that it signifies An old man, in the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)

XanijN c
XanijN, applied to the skin &c., Contracted, shrunk, shrivelled, or wrinkled. (TA.) And, applied to a man, Contracted, &c., in the skin, and in the arm, or hand; as also OaXonaju↓. (M, TA.) And yadN XanijapN means DayRaqapu AlkafRi [i. e. An arm contracted, or narrow, in the hand; or a hand contracted, &c., in the palm, or in the palm and fingers]. (TA.) Xaniju AlnRasaA means Contracted in the Eiroq called AlnsA [app., in this instance, the sciatic nerve]: (TA:) it is an epithet of commendation applied to a horse; because, when he is contracted therein, his hind legs are not relaxed: (S, K:) or it is an epithet of com-
mendation applied to a horse of good breed; but not so when applied to a hackney: it is also applied to some other animals, that do not walk with freedom; to a gazelle, and to a wolf: (T, TA:) and sometimes to the raven, or crow, (T, S,) which hops as though it were shackled. (T, TA.)

OaXonaju c
OaXonaju: see XanijN. ― -b2- XanijN OaXonaju and XanijN muXanRajN↓ are expressions sometimes used; [OaXonaju being syn. with XanijN, as shown above, and in this case a corroborative; and] muXanRajN↓ [when thus used] meaning Intensely contracted or shrunk &c. (Lth, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Having one of his testicles smaller than the other; like OaXoraju, which is more approved. (TA.)

muXanRajN c
muXanRajN: see OaXonaju, in two places. ― -b2- qabaMCN muXanRajN [A puckered tunic: see 2]. (A, Mgh.) saraAwiylu muXanRajapN, mentioned in a trad., in which they are forbidden, are said to be Such [drawers, or trousers,] as are so ample that they fall down upon the boot so as to cover half of the foot; as though meaning that, being ample and long, they cease not to rise, and become puckered (fatataXanRaju↓). (TA.)

2 XnRr Ealayohi c
2. XnRr Ealayohi, inf. n. taXoniyrN, He blamed him; found fault with him; attributed or imputed to him, or accused him of, a vice, or fault: (K:) or the same, (K,) or XnRr bihi, (O,) or XnRrhu, (TA,) he rendered him infamous; exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions; disgraced him; or put him to shame. (O, K, TA.)

XanorapN c
XanorapN The gait, or manner of walking, of a righteous man. (O, K.) [See also XimorapN.]

XanaArN c
XanaArN A vice, or fault: (S, O:) or the foulest vice or fault: (K:) and a disgrace, or shame, or thing that occasions one's being reviled: (S, O, K:) or a disgraceful vice or fault: seldom used unless conjointly with EaArN: (TA:) accord. to Sh, (O,) a thing, or an affair, notorious for badness or foulness: (O, K:) pl. XanaAYiru. (TA.)

XunaAraI c
XunaAraI one of the names of The cat. (O, K. *)

XunRaArN c
XunRaArN A certain white bird, found in water: of the dial. of Syria. (TA.)

XinRiyrN c
XinRiyrN and XinRiyrapN↓, (O, K,) [the latter having an intensive meaning,] applied to a man, (O,) Abounding in evil or mischief, and in vices, or faults; bad in disposition. (O, K.)

XinRiyrapN c
XinRiyrapN: see what next precedes.

maXonuwrapN c
maXonuwrapN A liberal, bountiful, or generous, woman: as also manoXuwrapN. (IAar, T in art. nXr, TA.)

XuwniyzN c
XuwniyzN, (Mgh, K,) so called by the Persians, (TA,) [and generally by the Arabs in the present day,] and XawoniyzN, as in the “ Towsheeh ” of ElJelál Es-Suyootee, (TA,) and XiynyzN, (AHn, L, and so in some copies of the K,) without hemz, (AHn, L,) the proper form, for so the Arabs called it, (IAar, TA in art. swd,) or XiYoniyzN, (as in some copies of the K, and in the TA,) with hemz, (TA,) and XuwnuwzN, or XuWonuwzN, (as in different copies of the K,) and XihoniyzN, (ADk, K,) A kind of seed, (L,) or grain; (Mgh;) the same as AlHabRapu AlsRawodaMCu [the black aromatic seed of a species of nigella; a sort of all-spice]; (K;) or said to be so: (Mgh:) or it is of Persian origin: (K:) so it is accord. to Ed-Deenäwaree [AHn]: (TA:) but some say that AlHbRp AlswdAC is the same as AlHabRapu AlxaDoraMCu. (TA in art. swd.)

1 XanuEa c
1. XanuEa, aor.
XanuEa
, inf. n. XanaAEapN (S, O, Msb, K) and XanaEN and XanaAEN, but this last, occurring in a verse, may be used by poetic license for XanaAEapN, (TA,) It (a thing, S) was, or became, bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; (S, * O, * Msb, K;) syn. qabuHa. (Msb. [In the S and O and K, it is said that XanaAEapN signifies the same as faZaAEapN; but the latter seems to import more than the former.]) ＝ -A2- XanaEa fulaAnFA He regarded such a one as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, (AisotaqobaHahu, S, O, K, TA, in the CK AsotaxafRahu,) and reviled, or vilified, him, (Xatamahu, O, K, TA, and so accord. to one of my copies of the S,) or loathed him, (saYimahu,) thus in some of the lexicons, [and accord. to one of my copies of the S,] but [SM says that] Xatamahu is shown to be the right reading by the saying of IAar that XanaEahu, inf. n. XanoEN, means sabRahu. (TA.) [See also 10.] ― -b2- Also, (O, K,) inf. n. XanoEN, (TA,) He disgraced such a one; put him to shame; or exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions. (O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And XanaEa Alxiroqapa He frayed the torn-off piece of cloth so that it became shaggy (XaERavahaA HatRaI tanafRaXa): (O, K: [in the CK, in the place of the last word of the explanation, which is for tatanafRaXa, is put tanofaXRa:]) and in like manner one says of a thing similar to a xiroqap. (O.) ＝ -A3- XaniEa bihi: see 10.

2 AltRaXoniyEu c
2. AltRaXoniyEu signifies takoviyru AlXRanaAEapi [app. meaning The uttering, or saying, much, or often, what is bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly: and the doing what is bad &c. much or often]: (K:) or the uttering, or saying, what is bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, (KL, PS,) against any one: (PS:) and the representing, or regarding, as bad, &c.: (KL, PS: *) and the committing [an action that is bad, &c., or] a fault, or vitious action. (KL.) You say, XanRaEotu Ealayohi, inf. n. taXoniyEN, (S, O,) I uttered, or said, what was bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, against him: (PS:) from AlXRanaAEapu. (O.) And XnRE Ealayohi AlOamora, inf. n. as above, He showed, or declared, to him that the affair was bad, evil, &c.: (TA: [see also 5:]) or characterized the affair to him as bad, evil, &c. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- And The striving, labouring, or exerting oneself, and being quick, and vigorous, or energetic, syn. AltRaXomiyru, (S, O, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AltRaXohiyru,]) and AlAinokimaAXu, and AljidRu, (O, K,) in pace, or going; (O, * K;) as also AltRaXanRuEu↓ (K) [and AlUiXonaAEu↓]: thus XnRE is said of a man, meaning He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, and was quick: (TA:) and in like manner XanRaEato is said of a she-camel, (As, A'Obeyd, S, O,) and of camels, (O,) as also tXnREt↓, (S, * O, expl. in the former by jadRato only,) and AXnEt↓; (O;) in pace, or going: (S, O:) or AXnEt↓ said of a she-camel means she was quick, or swift. (K.)

4 OaXonaEa
4: see the next preceding sentence, in three places.

5 tXnRE Alqawoma c
5. tXnRE Alqawoma He showed, or declared, the case of the people, or party, to be bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, by reason of their disagreement, and the unsound, or unsettled, state of their opinion. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And tXnRE He (a man) purposed to do a bad, an evil, an abominable, a foul, or an unseemly, thing or affair. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2, last sentence, in two places. ― -b3- Hence, (IAar, TA,) He prepared himself for fight: (IAar, K, TA:) or, said of a party of men, they prepared themselves for fight: (O:) and accord. to AA, tXnRE lilXRarRi He prepared himself for evil, or mischief. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And It ( a garment, or piece of cloth,) became rent, or slit. (O, K.) ＝ -A3- tXnRE AlgaArapa He spread, or dispersed, the horsemen making a raid, or sudden attack, upon an enemy. (AA, S, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And tXnRE Alfarasa He mounted the horse. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And tXnRE AlsRilaAHa He put on the weapon, or weapons. (S, O, K.)

10 AstXnEhu c
10. AstXnEhu He reckoned it bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (O, TA.) And accord. to Lth, (O, TA,) one says, bihi raOaI OamorFA XaniEa↓, meaning AstXnEhu, (O, K, TA,) i. e. [He saw a thing] which he regarded as bad, evil, &c. (TA.) ― -b2- And accord. to him, one says also, qadi QsotaXonaEa bifulaAnK jaholuhu, (O, TA,) meaning His ignorance has rendered such a one light, inconstant, or unsteady. (TA.)

XaniEN c
XaniEN: see XaniyEN.

XunoEapN c
XunoEapN the subst. from XanuEa; (S, O, K;) [i. e.] Badness, evilness, abominableness, foulness, or unseemliness; syn. quboHN; (Har p. 196;) as also XunuwEN↓: (O, K:) thus in the saying, fiI fulaAnK XunuwEN↓ [In such a one is unseemliness, or ugliness]; as also naZorapN and radRN [or rather radRapN]: (TA:) and one says also, fiI wajohihi XunoEapN and radRapN and naZorapN [app. meaning In his face is unseemliness, or ugliness]. (IAar TA voce XufoEapN.) ― -b2- Also Diabolical, or demoniacal possession; or madness, or insanity. (IAar, TA.)

XunuwEN c
XunuwEN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

XanaEonaEN c
XanaEonaEN Incongruous, unsound, weak, or faulty, [and therefore unseemly,] in make; (IDrd, O, K, TA;) as also Alxaloqi OaXonaEu↓; applied to a man: the former is from AlXRunuwEu: and some say that it signifies tall. (TA.)

OaXonaEu c
OaXonaEu; and its fem. XanoEaMCu: see XaniyEN, in four places: and see also XanaEonaEN.

maXonaEN c
maXonaEN: see maXonaON, in art. XnO.

muXanRaEN c
muXanRaEN; and its fem., with p: see XaniyEN, in two places.

maXonuwEN c
maXonuwEN i. q. maXohuwrN [Well, or commonly, known; notorious; &c.]. (O, L, K.)

1 Xanafotu UilaI AlXRaIoCi c
1. Xanafotu UilaI AlXRaIoCi, (S,) aor.
Xanifa
, (O, Msb,) inf. n. XanofN, (S, O, K,) I looked in a state of opposition, or resistance, (fiI QEotiraADK,) at the thing; like Xafanotu: (S, O: *) or AlXRanofu signifies the looking at a thing, (O,) or the looking at a thing like him who is opposing it, or resisting it, (kaAlmuEotariDi Ealayohi, K, TA,) and the raising of the eyes in looking at a thing, (TA,) like him who wonders at it, or like him who dislikes it, or hates it; (O, K, TA;) and so AlXRafonu, as AZ says. (TA.) [See also 2.] ＝ -A2- Xanifa lahu, (S, O, K,) and bihi also, or, correctly, accord. to ISd, this verb is trans. in the sense here next following without any particle, (TA,) [but two exs. are cited in the O from trads. in which it is trans. by means of l,] aor.
Xanafa
, (S, K,) inf. n. XanafN, (S, O,) He hated him, (OabogaDahu,) and met him in a morose manner: (S, O, K: [in the K, the latter meaning is expressed by tanakRarahu, for tanakRara lahu: in the S and O, the former meaning is expressed as above, on the authority of ISk; and it is also said that AlXRanofu is syn. with AlbugoDu and AltRanakRuru:] in the former of these two senses it is like XaYifahu, with C: (S, O:) or AlXnf [i. e. AlXRanafu] is a subst. signifying vehemence of enmity. (Ham p. 108.) ― -b2- And Xanifa lahu, (IAar, ISd, O, * K, TA,) and bihi, (ISd, TA,) i. q. faTina [i. e. He knew it; knew, had knowledge, or was cognizant, of it; or knew it instinctively; &c.]. (IAar, ISd, O, K, TA.) ＝ -A3- And Xanifa, (K, TA, [in the former of which it is erroneously implied that the verb is followed by lahu,]) His upper lip turned upwards; (K, TA;) inf. n. XanafN; (TA;) or this is a subst., signifying a turning upwards of the upper lip: so says AZ. (O.)

2 XanRafahaA c
2. XanRafahaA, inf. n. taXoniyfN, He adorned her (i. e. a woman, S, or a girl, or young woman, O, K) with the [ornament called] Xanof; (S, O, K;) like as one says, qarRaTahaA; (S, TA;) as also OaXonafahaA↓. (Zj, O, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] XanRafa kalaAmahu waqarRaTahu (tropical:) [He adorned and embellished his language]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XnRf Uilayohi, inf. n. as above, He looked at him, or it, from the outer corner of the eye. (Yaakoob, TA.) [See also 1.]

4 OaXonafa
4: see the next preceding paragraph.

5 tXnRft c
5. tXnRft She adorned herself with the [ornament called] Xanof; (S, O, K;) like as one says, tqrRTt. (S.)

XanofN c
XanofN (incorrectly pronounced with damm, IDrd, O, K, i. e. XunofN, O, TA) The upper quroT [i. e. ear-ring or ear-drop]: (S, O, K:) or a pendant (miEolaAqN) in [or suspended from] the quwf [app. meaning the upper part, or perhaps, the helix, in the CK erroneously written fawoq,] of the ear; (Lth, O, K;) and likewise such as is attached to necklaces: (Lth, O:) or such as is suspended from the upper part of the ear; what is suspended from the lower part [or lobe] thereof being termed quroTN; (IDrd, O, K;) or this latter is termed ruEovapN: (IAar, TA:) or, as some say, i. q. quroTN: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] XunuwfN (IDrd, S, O, K) and [of pauc.] OaXonaAfN. (TA.)

XanifN c
XanifN Hating, (S, O, K,) and meeting in a morose manner. (K.) IB cites, as an ex.,
walano tudaAwiI EilRapa Alqalobi AlXRanifo
[And thou will not cure the hating heart]. (TA.)

XafapN XanofaMCu c
XafapN XanofaMCu [A lip, meaning an upper lip] turning upwards: (O:) or XaApN XanofaMCu [A sheep or goat] having the upper lip turning upwards. (TA.)

XaAnifN c
XaAnifN Turning away, or averse. (O, K.) One says, maA liI OaraAka XaAnifFA EanRiI What ails me that I see thee turning away, or averse, from me? (O.) ― -b2- And UinRahu laXaAnifN EanRaA biOanofihi (tropical:) Verily he is raising his nose [in aversion] from us. (O, * K.)

maXonuwfapN c
maXonuwfapN (assumed tropical:) A she-camel having a zimaAm [or noserein] attached to her. (AA, O, K.)

1 Xanaqa AlbaEiyra c
1. Xanaqa AlbaEiyra, aor.
Xanuqa
(S, M, Msb, K) and
Xaniqa
, (M, K,) inf. n. XanoqN, (S, M, Msb,) He curbed the camel by means of his zimaAm [or nose-rein], (S, K,) or pulled the xiTaAm [or halter, or leadingrope,] of the camel, (M,) while riding him, (S, M,) in the direction of his [own] head, (M,) so as to make the prominences behind his [the camel's] ears cleave to the upright piece of wood rising from the fore part of the saddle: (M, K:) or he raised the camel's head (M, Msb, K) by pulling his zimaAm, (M, Msb,) while riding him, (Msb, K,) like as the rider of the horse does with his horse: (Msb:) and AXnqhu↓ signifies the same: (S, M, Msb, K:) or AXnq↓ is intrans.; you say, Xanaqa AlbaEiyra and huwa AXnq↓, the reverse of the usual rule; (IJ, M;) or the latter is intrans. also; (S, Msb, K;) signifying he (the camel) raised his head. (S, M, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- Hence, XanaqotuhaA, occurring in a trad., referring to a female hare, inf. n. as above, means, as implying restraint, I cast, or shot, at her, or I struck her, so as to render her incapable of motion. (O.) ― -b3- And Xanaqa AlbaEiyra, or AlnRaAqapa, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He bound the he-camel, or the she-camel, with the XinaAq [q. v.]. (M, K.) ― -b4- And Xanaqa raOosa AldRaAbRapi, (M,) or raOosa Alfarasi, (K,) (tropical:) He bound (M, K) the head of the beast, (M,) or the head of the horse, (K,) to the upper part of a tree, (M,) or to the head of a tree, or to a tree, (accord. to different copies of the K,) or to a peg, (M,) or to an elevated peg, (K,) so that his neck became extended and erect. (M, TA.) ― -b5- And Xanaqa Alqirobapa, (IDrd, O, K,) aor.
Xanuqa
, (IDrd, O,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He bound the mouth of the water-skin with the bond called wikaMC, and then bound the extremity of its wikaMC to its fore legs: (IDrd, O, K, TA: [in the CK, OawokaOahA is erroneously put for OawokaAhaA, or, as in some copies of the K, wakaAhaA:]) or he suspended it: and [in like manner] Alqirobapa AXnq↓, inf. n. as above, he suspended the water-skin to a peg: (TA:) or the latter signifies he put a XinaAq to the water-skin: (M:) or he bound the water-skin with a XinaAq, (S, K, TA,) i. e. a cord with which its mouth is bound. (S.) ― -b6- [Hence Xanaqahu, as used in the present day, and in post-classical works, meaning (assumed tropical:) He hanged him by the neck, till he died: (see the pass. part. n., below:) whence miXonaqapN↓, meaning A gallows; pl. maXaAniqu.] ― -b7- Xanaqa AlxaliyRapa, (M, K,) aor.
Xanuqa
, inf. n. XanoqN; (M;) and XnRqhA↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taXoniyqN; (TA;) He put a piece of wood, which is called XaniyqN↓, (M, K,) pared for the purpose, (M,) into the hive, and with it raised a portion of the honey-comb in the width of the hive, (M, K, *) having fixed the Xynq beneath it; and sometimes two portions of the honey-comb, and three: (M: [accord. to which one says also, Xanaqa fiI AlxaliyRapi AlquroSayoni waAlvRalaAvapa:]) this is done only when the bees are rearing their young ones. (M, K. *) ― -b8- Accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, AlXRaIoCa OaXonaqotu↓ and Xanaqotuhu signify the same: (TA: [in which the meaning is not expl.; but it is immediately added, app. to indicate the meaning here intended;]) El-Mutanakhkhil El-Hudhalee says, describing a bow and arrows,
Xanaqotu bihaA maEaAbila murohafaAtK
i. e. I put its string into [the notches of] arrows [broad and long in the heads, made sharp or
pointed]. (O, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Xaniqa, (M, K,) aor.
Xanaqa
; (K;) and Xanaqa, (M, K,) aor.
Xaniqa
; (K;) He loved a thing, and became attached to it; (M, K, TA;) said of a man: (TA:) and Xaniqa, inf. n. XanaqN, is said of a man's heart, (O, TA,) meaning as above: (O:) or XanaqN signifies the heart's yearning towards, or longing for, or desiring, a thing. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- XanaqN also signifies The being long: (M:) or the being long in the head, (JK, S, TA,) as though it were stretched upwards: (TA:) one says of a horse, Xaniqa inf. n. XanaqN, meaning He was long in the head. (JK.) ― -b2- Xanaqu AlmaroOapi, signifies AisotinaAnuhaA mina AlXRaHomi [app. meaning The woman's becoming sleek, like masaAnR (or whetstones) by reason of fat: see AisotanRati AlfiSaAlu, in art. sn]: and the epithet applied to her is XaniqapN↓, pl. XaniqaAtN. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O, TA.)

2 XnRq AlxaliyRapa c
2. XnRq AlxaliyRapa, inf. n. taXoniyqN: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b2- taXoniyqN also signifies The cutting [a thing] in pieces. (O, K. [See the pass. part. n.]) ― -b3- And The adorning [a person or thing]. (K. [See 5.]) ― -b4- See also the next paragraph, near the end.

3 XAnqhu c
3. XAnqhu, inf. n. muXaAnaqapN and XinaAqN, He mixed his cattle with his [i. e. another's] cattle: (K, TA:) this is when [contributions to the poor-rate such as are termed] OaXonaAq [pl. of XanaqN] are incumbent on a man, or two men, or three, when their cattle are separate, and one says to another, XaAniqoniI, i. e. Mix thou my cattle and thy cattle; for if they are separate, a Xanaq will be obligatory, or incumbent, on each of us; and if they are mixed, the case will be light to us: so the XinaAq signifies the sharing in the Xanaq or in the XanaqaAni. (L, TA.) [See also what follows in this paragraph: and see XanaqN.] One says also laA taXaAnaquwA↓ [for laA tataXaAnaquwA] Ye shall not put together what are separate [of cattle]; AltRaXaAnuqu being syn. with AlmuXaAnaqapu. (TA.) ― -b2- XinaAqN signifies also The taking somewhat from the Xanaq: and hence the trad., laA XinaAqa: (K, TA:) this means There shall not be taken from the Xanaq [any contribution to the poorrate] unless it is complete [in number]: (A' Obeyd, S, TA:) the Xanaq being, of camels, such as exceed five, up to ten; and what exceed ten, up to fifteen: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer says, up to nine; and up to fourteen: but this is pronounced in the L to be wrong: (TA:) [Mtr also says,] it means there shall not be taken aught of what exceed five, up to nine, for example: or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer, it is like the mixing; but this requires consideration: (Mgh:) Aboo-Sa'eed says that laA XinaAqa means a man shall not adjoin (laA yuXoniqu↓ [thus written here and thus expl. in the TA]) his sheep or goats, and his camels, to the sheep or goats [and the camels] of another person, in order to annul what is obligatory, or incumbent, on him, of the poor-rate: this is [for instance] in the case in which each of them has forty sheep or goats; so that it is incumbent on them to give two sheep or goats; but when one of them adjoins (OaHaduhumaA faUicaA XanRaqa↓ [thus in this instance in the TA, perhaps a mistranscription for OaXonaqa,]) his sheep or goats to those of another, and the collector of the poorrate finds them in his [the latter's] possession, he takes from them one sheep or goat. (TA.)

4 AXnq c
4. AXnq: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- UiXonaAqN [as inf. n. of OuXoniqa, from OaXonaqa Alqirobapa expl. in the first paragraph,] also signifies The having the hand attached to the neck by means of a gulR [q. v.]. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- See also 3, in the latter half. ＝ -A2- Accord. to IAar, (O, TA,) AXnq also signifies He took (O, K, TA) the Xanaq, i. e., (O, TA,) the [fine termed] OaroX: (O, K, TA:) or it was, or became, obligatory, or incumbent, on him to give the OaroX; thus having two contr. meanings [assigned to it]: (K:) or it signifies also, accord. to IAar, it was, or became, obligatory on him to give what is termed a Xanaq; and this is the case until his camels amount to five and twenty, when what is due of them is [a she-camed such as is termed] Aibonap maxaAD. (O.) A man of the Arabs said, minRaA mano yuXoniqu, which may mean Of us is he who gives the Xunuq, i. e. cords, pl. of XinaAqN: or it may mean, who gives the Xanaq, i. e. OaroX. (O.) ― -b2- AXnq Ealayohi He exalted himself above him; domineered over him; or oppressed him. (O, K.)

5 tXnRq c
5. tXnRq He adorned himself; or was, or became, adorned: (JK, O:) and he clad himself with garments. (JK.)

6 taXaAonaqa
6: see 3.

XanaqN c
XanaqN What is between one fariyDap and the next fariyDap, (A'Obeyd, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) [meaning a number that is between two other numbers whereof each imposes the obligation of giving a due termed fariyDap,] of camels, and of sheep or goats, (M, TA,) in relation to the poorrate: (S, Mgh, K, TA:) so called because nothing is taken therefrom; so that it is adjoined (OuXoniqa i. e. OaDiyfa) to that [number] which is next to it [of the numbers below it]: (JK:) accord. to some, it is syn. with waqaSN; (Mgh, Msb;) but some say that it relates peculiarly to camels; (M, Mgh, Msb;) and waqaSN, to bulls and cows: (Mgh, Msb:) used in relation to sheep or goats, it is what is between forty and a hundred and twenty; and in like manner as to other numbers [that impose the obligation of giving a fryDp]: K, TA:) Ahmad Ibn-Hambal is related to have said that the Xanaq is what is above the fryDp, absolutely; as, for instance, what is above forty sheep or goats: (TA: [I here render the word duwna “ above, ” though it also means “ below, ” because nothing is due from sheep or goats fewer than forty:]) as A'Obeyd says, it is, of camels, such as exceed five, up to ten; and what exceed ten, up to fifteen: (O, * TA: [see also 3:]) Ks states, on the authority of some one or more of the Arabs, that it is up to twenty-five; and says that it is what does pot impose the obligation of the fryDp; meaning what is between five and twenty-five: (Fr, TA:) [but it is also expl. as applied to the due itself that is to be contributed to the poorrates for certain numbers of camels: thus] Aboo- 'Amr Esh-Sheybánee says, the Xanaq for five camels is a sheep or goat; for ten, two sheep or goats; for fifteen three sheep or goats; and for twenty, four sheep or goats; the term XanaqN being applied alike to the sheep or goat, and to the two sheep or goats, and to the three sheep or goats, and to the four sheep or goats; what exceeds this last being termed fariyDapN: (TA:) or, in the case of the poor-rate, the lowest Xanaq (AlXRanaqu AlOasofalu) is a sheep or goat for five camels; and the highest Xanaq (AlXRanaqu AlOaEolaI) is a binot maxaAD for five and twenty: (O, K:) the pl. of XanaqN is OaXonaAqN (M, Msb, TA) and XinaAqN. (M.) ― -b2- Also What is above the bloodwit (maA duwna AldRiyapi): (As, S, O, Msb, K:) the term OaXonaAq, (S, M, Msb,) pl. of XanaqN, (M,) being applied to the fines, for wounds, that are sent with the complete bloodwit (S, M, * O, Msb) by him upon whom rests the obligation to send such; (S, O, Msb;) as though they were attached to the main, or greatest, fine: (S, M, * O:) and an addition, in the bloodwit, (M, Msb,) of five, (M,) or of six, (M, Msb,) or of seven, (Msb,) to the hundred camels [which constitute the complete bloodwit], (M, Msb, *) in order that it may be described as ample: (Msb:) [for,] as IAar and As and El-Athram say, the man of rank or quality, when he gave [the bloodwit], used to add to it five [or more] camels, to show thereby his excellence and his generosity: (TA:) a redundancy [in the case of the bloodwit]; (O, K;) one of the explanations of the term given by As: (O:) or in the case of bloodwits (diyaAt), the lowest Xanaq (AlXRanaqu AlOasofalu) is twenty camels whereof every one is a binot maxaAD; and the highest Xanaq (AlXRanaqu AlOaEolaI) is twenty camels whereof every one is a jacaEap: (O, K:) and some say that OaXonaAqu AldRiyaAti means the sorts of bloodwits; the bloodwit for purely-unintentional homicide being a hundred camels, which those who are responsible for it undertake to give in fifths, consisting of twenty whereof every one is an Aibonap maxaAD, and twenty whereof every one is an Aibonap labuwn, and twenty whereof every one is an Aibon labuwn, and twenty whereof every one is a HiqRap, and twenty whereof every one is a jacaEap; these also being termed OaXonaAq. (TA.) ― -b3- It signifies also A fine, or mulct, for a wound or the like; (O, Msb, K;) as, for instance, for a burn, (O, TA,) or such as a wound on the head that lays bare the bone, (Msb, TA,) and other wounds, (Msb,) and for a tooth [knocked out], and for an eye blinded, and for an arm or a hand vitiated, or rendered unsound and motionless, or stiff; and for anything short of what requires the complete bloowit: (TA:) or, as some say, a fine for that which does not render obnoxious to retaliation; as a scratch, or laceration of the skin, and the like: (M:) pl. OaXonaAqN. (M, Msb.) ＝ -A2- Also A burden borne on one side of a beast, equiponderant to another borne on the other side; syn. EidolN: (K, TA: [in the CK and my MS. copy of the K, AlEadolu is
erroneously put for AlEidol:]) AlXRanaqaAni signifies AlEidolaAn. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O, TA. *) ― -b2- And A rope, or cord. (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.) ― -b3- And A bow-string; (O, TA;) as also XinaAqN↓; (O, K, * TA;) so called because it is bound to the head of the bow: (O, TA:) or, accord. to Sh, a good bow-string, i. e. strong and long. (TA.) [See what follows.] ＝ -A3- AlXRanaqu also signifies AlEamalu [The making a thing]: (K:) thus accord. to some in the saying of Ru-beh, describing a sportsman [and his bow],
sawRaI lahaA kabodaMCa tanozuw fiI AlXRanaqo
[as though meaning He prepared for it, or them, a bow such that the part whereby it was held filled the hand, springing in the making by reason of its elasticity and strength: but the word which I have written tanozuw, and which is thus in one place in the TA, and in another place in the same, where the verse is repeated, tanozuwA, is illegible in the copy of the O, and may be a mistranscription]: accord. to others, however, the last word, AlXRanaqo, here means the bow-string. (O, TA.)

XaniqN c
XaniqN, applied to a heart, Loving intensely, or very passionately or fondly; syn. hayomaAnu. (M, TA.) Accord. to Lth, qalobN XaniqN miXonaAqN↓ signifies TaAmiHN UilaI kulRi XaIoCK [app. meaning A heart aspiring to everything]: (O, L, TA:) in the K, qalobN XaniqN kakatifK muXotaAqN TaAmiHN UilaI kulRi XaIoCK; but the right reading is qalobN XaniqN miXonaAqN kakatifK wamiHoraAbK, and the signification as above; primarily relating to the eye. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, Cautious; or fearful. (TA.) ― -b3- XaniqapN, applied to a woman: see 1, last sentence.

XinaAqN c
XinaAqN A rope, or cord, with which the head of a he-camel and of a she-camel is pulled: [see 1, first sentence:] pl. [of pauc.] OaXoniqapN and [of mult.] XunuqN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- A cord, (A' Obeyd, S, K,) or thong, (A' Obeyd, K,) with which the mouth-of a water-skin is bound, (A' Obeyd, S, Mgh, K,) and that of a leathern water-bag, and which is untied in order that the water may pour forth: (A' Obeyd, TA:) or the suspensory cord of a water-skin: and any cord by which a thing is suspended. (M.) ― -b3- See also XanaqN, in the last quarter of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- As an epithet, Tall: (ISh, S, K:) used alike as masc. and fem. (ISh, K) and dual (ISh) and pl., (ISh, K,) not dualized nor pluralized: (ISh:) applied to a man, (S, TA,) and to a woman, and to a he-camel, and to a she-camel: applied to a she-camel as meaning tall, and longnecked; as also XanoqaMCu↓: and to a he-camel as meaning tall and slender: (ISh, TA:) also, and maXonuwqN↓, applied to a horse as meaning tall. (T, TA.) See also OaXonaqu.

XaniyqN c
XaniyqN One whose origin is suspected; syn. daEiIRN: a poet says,
OanaA AldRaAxilu AlbaAba AlRaciI laA yaruwmuhu
daniIoCN walaA yudoEaI Uilayohi Xaniyqu
[I am he who enters the door that the ignoble seeks not, and to which one whose origin is suspected is not invited]. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, latter half.

XanRiyqN c
XanRiyqN A man evil in disposition: (M, L:) or a self-conceited young man. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.) And XanRiyqapN, like sikRiynapN, [in some copies of the K XaniyqapN, like sakiynapN,] A woman talking, or conversing, or who talks, or converses, in an amorous and enticing manner. (JK, Ibn-' Abbád, O, K.)

XiniqonaAqN c
XiniqonaAqN a name for A calamity or misfortune (daAhiyap): (Ibn-' Abbád, O, K: *) or, as some say, a name of The chiefs of the Jinn, or Genii: (Ibn- 'Abbád, O:) or also a certain chief of the Jinn. (K.)

OaXonaqu c
OaXonaqu Long; applied to a neck. (M.) And, as also maXonuwqN↓, Long in the head; applied to a horse and to a camel; and so XanoqaMCu [the fem. of the former] and XinaAqN↓ applied to the female. (M.) For the fem., see also XinaAqN. ＝ -A2- [The fem.] XanoqaMCu signifies [also] A female bird that feeds her young ones with her bill, ejecting the food into their mouths. (O, K.)

miXonaqapN c
miXonaqapN: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

muXanRaqN c
muXanRaqN Flesh-meat (Ks, S) cut in pieces: (Ks, S, K:) applied to flesh-meat, (M,) it is from the OaXonaAq [pl. of XanaqN] of the diyap [or bloodwit]. (Ks, S, M.) ― -b2- And Dough cut into pieces, and prepared with oil of olives: (El-Umawee, S, M, K:) or dough cut into lumps, or pieces, upon the table, before it is spread out; also called farazodaqN and EajaAjiyru. (IAar, TA.)

miXonaAqN c
miXonaAqN: see XaniqN.

maXonuwqN c
maXonuwqN [as pass. part. n. of Xanaqa means Curbed by means of his nose-rein, &c. ― -b2- And] (assumed tropical:) Hanged: one says, qutila maXonuwqFA (assumed tropical:) He was put to death [by being] hanged. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also XinaAqN: and OaXonaqu.

maXonuwRN c
maXonuwRN and maXoniIRN: see maXonuwoCN, in art. XnO.

maXoniyRapN c
maXoniyRapN: see maXoniyoYapN, in art. XnO.

1 Xahiba c
1. Xahiba, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Xahaba
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XahabN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) It (a thing, S) was, or became, of the colour termed Xuhobap, (S, Msb, K,) i. e. of a [gray] colour in which whiteness predominated over blackness, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or in which whiteness was interrupted by blackness; (K, * TA;) as also Xahuba, aor.
Xahuba
; and AXhbR↓; (K;) the last, inf. n. AiXohibaAbN, said in the former sense of a horse; as also AXhAbR↓, inf. n. AiXohiybaAbN; (S;) and this last verb, said of the head, its whiteness predominated over its blackness; (TA;) as also AXthb↓. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Xahabahu, aor.
Xahaba
, (K,) inf. n. XahobN, (TK,) said of heat and of cold, It altered his colour; as also XhRbhu↓: (K:) or, accord. to A' Obeyd, (TA,) AlXRajara XhRb↓, (O, TA,) inf. n. taXohiybN, (O,) said of cold, It altered the colour of the trees: and AlnRaAsa XhRb↓ is likewise said of cold [as meaning It altered the colour of the men or people]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- And Xahabati AlsRanapu Alqawoma The year of drought destroyed the cattle (OamowaAl) of the people or party: (so accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K:) or the verb in this sense is OaXohabat↓. (So accord. to the text of the K as given in the TA.) ― -b3- [Freytag erroneously assigns to this verb, as from the K, another meaning, belonging to 4.]

2 XahRaba
2: see the preceding paragraph, in three places.

4 AXhb c
4. AXhb, said of a stallion, He had offspring of the colour termed Xuhobap born to him: so accord. to the K: but accord. to IM and the other lexicologists, it is said of a man, meaning the offspring of his horses were of the colour termed Xuhobap: IAar says that there are not, among horses, such as are termed XuhobN [pl. of OaXohabu]: A' Obeyd, however, [as will be seen below,] explains Xuhobap as meaning a colour of horses. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence but one.

8 UiXotahaba
8: and 9: see 1, first sentence.

11 UiXohaAobRa
11: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also, said of seedproduce, (tropical:) It dried up, or became yellow, (S, A,) but with somewhat green remaining in its interstices: (S:) or was near to yielding, and became white, and dried up, but with a little greenness remaining in its interstices. (TA.) ― -b3- Accord. to the L, one says also AXhAbRt maXaAfiruhu [app. meaning His lips became of an ashy hue]. (TA.)

XahobN c
XahobN A mountain overspread with snow. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- And a boy, or young man, light, or active, in body, and sharp-headed. (IAar, TA voce EaDobN. [See also XihaAbN.])

XahabN c
XahabN: see what next follows.

XuhobapN c
XuhobapN A [gray] colour in which whiteness predominates over blackness, (S, Msb,) or in which whiteness is interrupted by blackness; as also XahabN↓; (A, K;) which latter is [properly] an inf. n., of Xahiba: (S, Msb:) or whiteness mixed with blackness: (Har p. 150:) not pure whiteness, as some have imagined it to be. (TA.) And in horses, A colour in which the main hue is interrupted by a hoariness, or by some white hairs, whether the horse be [in his general colour] kumayot or OaXoqar or Oadoham. (A' Obeyd, TA.)

XahabaAnN c
XahabaAnN A kind of plant (XajarN), resembling the vumaAm [or panic grass]; (K;) like XabahaAnN. (TA. [But see this last word.])

XahaAbN c
XahaAbN (AHát, S, K) and XuhaAbapN↓ (AHát, Kr, K) Milk mixed with much water: (AHát, S:) or a mixture of which one third is milk and the rest water: (K, TA:) Az heard several of the Arabs apply the former term to milk mixed with water: so called on account of the alteration of its colour. (TA.)

XihaAbN c
XihaAbN, in its primary acceptation, A XuEolap [i. e. either brand or flame (app. the former, agreeably
with what follows,)] of fire: (TA:) or a XuEolap of fire gleaming or radiating: (S, K:) accord. to ISk, a firebrand; i. e. a stick in which is fire: or, accord. to AHeyth, originally, a piece of wood, or stick, in which is fire gleaming or radiating: (Az, TA:) pl. XuhubN, (S, K,) and some allow XuhobN, (TA,) and XuhobaAnN (Akh, S, K) and XihobaAnN, (K,) which is strange, (TA,) and OaXohubN, (K,) which last is [a pl. of pauc., but] thought by IM to be a quasi-pl. n. (TA.) The reading biXihaAbi qabasK, instead of biXihaAbK qabasK, in the Kur [xxvii. 7], is an instance of a word prefixed to another identical therewith. (Fr. L.) ― -b2- Hence, [A shooting, or falling, star;] a star, or the like of a star, that darts down [or is hurled] by night; and particularly after a devil; as occurring in the Kur [xv. 18 and] xxxvii. 10; and in a trad.; respecting the attempt of a devil to hear, by stealth, words uttered in heaven. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AlXRuhubu signifies The shining, or brightly-shining, stars: (K:) or the seven stars [or planets; meaning, not the Pleiades (which are called AlnRajomu), but the Moon, Mercury, Venus, the Sun, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn: the first three of which are said by Freytag to be called SigaAru AlXRuhubi]. (TA.) ― -b4- For another meaning assigned in the K to AlXRuhubu, see AlXRuhobu, voce OaXohabu. ― -b5- XihaAbN also signifies (tropical:) One who is penetrating, sharp, or energetic, in an affair; (K, TA;) as being likened to the [shooting] star. (TA.) One says, UinRa fulaAnFA laXihaAbu HarobK (tropical:) Verily such a man is one who is penetrating, sharp, or energetic, in war. (S, A. *) And heWulaMCi XuhobaAnu AljayoXi (tropical:) [These are the braves, or heroes, of the army]. (A.) ― -b6- Also the name of A certain devil: occurring in a trad.: hence the Prophet changed the name of a certain man [originally] thus named. (TA.)

XuhaAbapN c
XuhaAbapN: see XahaAbN.

katiybapN XahRaAbapN c
katiybapN XahRaAbapN: see OaXohabu.

XaAhibN c
XaAhibN: see OaXohabu, first sentence.

XawohabN c
XawohabN The hedge-hog; syn. qunofucN. (S, K.)

OaXohabu c
OaXohabu Of the colour termed XuhobapN; (S, Msb, K;) as also XaAhibN↓, (K,) occurring in the poetry of Hudheyl: (TA:) fem. of the former XahobaMCu: (S, Msb, K: *) and pl. XuhobN: (O:) the former epithet is applied to a horse, (S,) [contr. to an assertion of IAar, (see 4,)] and to a he-mule, (Msb,) and XahobaMCu to a she-mule. (Mgh, Msb.) [Golius, on the authority of Meyd, explains OaXohabu Oadohamu, applied to a horse, as meaning Subniger, spadiceus: and OaXohabu OaxoDaru as meaning lucide leviterve viridis: the correct meaning of the former seems to be of a blackish, or brownish, gray: and that of the latter, of a dark dustcoloured gray: see Oadohamu and OaxoDaru.] AlXRahobaMCu was the name of a mare belonging to El-Kattál ElBejelee. (O, K; in the CK El-Bejlee.) Applied to a she-goat, XahobaMCu signifies Of a white colour intermixed with black: thus applied, it is like maloHaMCu applied to a ewe. (K.) Applied to a gurRap [or blaze on a horse's forehead], it means In which are hairs differing from the whiteness [of the blaze]. (S.) And AlOaXaAhibu is [a pl. formed from AlOaXohabu as though this were a subst.] applied to the Benu-l-Mundhir, (K,) or one of the troops of En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir, consisting of the sons of his paternal uncle and his maternal uncles, and their brethren; (TA;) so called because of their comeliness, (K,) or because of the whiteness of their faces. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to ambergris, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Of an excellent colour, i. e., (TA,) inclining to whiteness. (K, TA.) And applied to an iron head or blade of an arrow or of a spear &c., (tropical:) That has been filed so that its blackness has gone: (S, A, TA:) or that has been filed lightly, so that all its blackness has not gone. (AHn, TA.) [Hence,] katiybapN XahobaMCu (assumed tropical:) A great troop having numerous weapons; (K;) so called because of the iron; (S;) or because of the whiteness of the weapons and iron, intermixed with blackness: or a troop of which the iron [of the weapons and armour] is white and bright: (TA:) or, as also katiybapN XahRaAbapN↓, a troop upon which is [seen] the whiteness of the iron [weapons &c.]. (T, TA. [See also katiybapN maloHaMCu, voce OamolaHu.]) And jayoXN OaXohabu A strong army [app. because of its numerous weapons]. (TA.) ― -b3- OaroDN XahobaMCu (assumed tropical:) A land in which is no verdure, by reason of the paucity of rain. (TA.) And [hence,] sanapN XahobaMCu (tropical:) A year of drought, or sterility, white in consequence thereof, (TA,) in which is no verdure, or in which is no rain: (K, TA:) next in degree is the bayoDaMC; then, the HamoraMC, which is more severe than the bayoDaMC; (TA;) and then, the sawodaMC: (TA in art. Hmr:) or a year that is white by reason of the abundance of snow and the want of herbage: (IB, TA:) or a year of drought, or sterility; because the seedproduce dries up therein, and becomes yellow: and EaAmN OaXohabu signifies the same. (Har p. 150.) And OaXohabaAni (assumed tropical:) Two white years (EaAmaAni OaboyaDaAni) between which is no verdure (K, TA) of herbage. (TA.) And yawomN OaXohabu (tropical:) A cold day: (A, K:) or a day of cold wind; thought to be so called on account of the snow and hoar frost and hail therein: (L, TA:) or a day of hoar-frost: (Az, TA:) a day of cold wind and hoar frost; and [in like manner] the night (AllRayolapu) is termed XahobaMCu. (S.) In the following verse, cited by Sb,
fidFI libaniI cuholi boni XayobaAna naAqatiI
UicaA kaAna yawomN cuw kawaAkiba OaXohabu
[May my she-camel be a ransom for the sons of Dhuhl Ibn-Sheybán when there is a day of difficulties, or distresses,...] the meaning may be AXhb [or whitish] by reason of the whiteness of the weapons, or by reason of the dust. (TA.) And AlXRuhobu [pl. of OaXohabu], (O,) or AlXRuhubu↓ [pl. of XihaAbN], (K,) [but the former, I think, is evidently the right,] (assumed tropical:) The white nights; (AllRayaAliI AlbiyDu;) [i. e. the thirteenth and fourteenth and fifteenth nights of the lunar month; so called because lighted by the moon throughout, (see art. byD;)] (O;) three nights of the month; (K, TA;) because of the alteration of their colour. (TA.) ― -b4- OaXohabu [or OamorN OaXohabu] also signifies (assumed tropical:) A hard, or difficult, affair or case, (K, TA,) such as is disliked, or hated. (TA.) And OaXohabu baAzilN (assumed tropical:) A hard, or difficult, affair or case, that is beyond one's power [of accomplishment or endurance]: termed bAzl because the camel thus termed is one that has attained its utmost strength. (O, TA. [See also art. bzl.]) ― -b5- And AlOaXohabu signifies The lion. (O, K.) [And in the Deewán of Jereer, it is applied to The swine. (Freytag.)]

1 Xahida c
1. Xahida, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) aor.
Xahada
; (K;) and Xahuda, aor.
Xahuda
; (K;) also pronounced and written Xahoda, (Akh, S, K,) and Xihoda, and Xihida, accord. to a rule applying to all verbs of the measure faEila of which the medial radical letter is a faucial; (MF;) inf. n. XahaAdapN (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and Xhd; (TA;) [there written without any syll. sign, and not found by me in any other Lex.;]) He told, or gave information of, what he had witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye: (Mgh, L, Msb:) this is the primary signification: (L:) he declared what he knew: he gave testimony, attestation, or evidence; he bore witness: (L:) he gave decisive information. (S, A, L, K.) [See also XahaAdapN below.] You say, Xahida bikacaA, inf. n. as above, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) He told, or gave information of, such a thing, as having witnessed it, or seen or beheld it with his eye; (Mgh, Msb;) or declared such a thing as knowing it; (L;) or gave his testimony, attestation, or evidence, respecting it; or bore witness of it, or to it; (S, A, L, K;) Einoda AlHaAkimi [in the presence of the judge]; lifulaAnK [for, or in favour of, such a one], (S, Mgh, L, K,) and EalaI fulaAnK [against, or in opposition to, such a one]. (Mgh.) And Xahida EalaI kacaA He gave decisive information [respecting such a thing (as in the Kur xlvi. 9, and in many other instances); he testified respecting it]. (S, L. [See also another meaning of this phrase in what follows.]) [Hence,] Xahida QllRehu OanRahu laA UilaAha UilRaA huwa, in the Kur [iii. 16], means God hath given evidence that there is no deity but He: (Abu-l- 'Abbás, IAmb, Jel:) or God knoweth &c.; (Ah- mad Ibn-Yahyà, K;) and so Xahida QllRehu throughout the Kur-án: (Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà:) or God saith &c.: or God hath written &c. (K.) And OaXohadu Oano laA UilaAha UilRaAQllRehu I know, (Msb, K,) [or acknowledge,] and I declare, [or testify, that there is no deity but God:] (K:) [Fei says,] the verb is trans. in this phrase by itself [i. e. without the intervention of a prep.] because it is used in the sense of OaEolamu. (Msb.) [And hence, kalimapu AlXRahaAdapi means The sentence declaring that there is no deity but God and that Mohammad is God's apostle.] ― -b2- Xahida biQllRehi, (Mgh, * Msb,) aor.
Xahada
, inf. n. XahaAdapN, (Mgh,) means He swore by God: (Mgh, Msb:) and OaXohadu bikacaA I swear by such a thing. (S, K.) OaXohadu biQllRehi laqado kaAna kacaA I swear by God that such a thing happened, or took place, combines the meaning of witnessing with that of swearing and that of informing at the time of
uttering these words; as though the speaker said, I swear by God that I witnessed such a thing, and now I inform of it. (Msb.) Accord. to some, when one says only OaXohadu, not adding biQllRehi, it is an oath. (TA.) ― -b3- Xahida EalaI kacaA, a phrase of which one meaning has been expl. above, means also He became a witness (XaAhid) of, or to, such a thing; (S, K;) he had knowledge of such a thing, and witnessed it, or saw it or beheld it with his eye: (Msb:) and Xahidahu, (Mgh, L,) inf. n. XahaAdapN, (L,) [likewise] signifies he witnessed it; or saw, or beheld, it, or him, with his eye; (Mgh, L;) and (Mgh, L, Msb) so XAhdhu↓, (A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. muXaAhadapN. (S, A, L, Msb.) [Hence,] one says, minohu HaAlN jamiylapN Xuwhidato↓ [A comely, or pleasing, state, or condition, of him was witnessed]. (A.) ― -b4- And Xahidahu, (aor.
Xahada
