, K,) inf. n. XuhuwdN, He was, or became, present at it, or in it; (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, * K;) namely, a place, (Mgh,) or an assembly. (Msb.) Hence the saying, (Msb,) famano Xahida minokumu QlXRahora faloyaSumohu, in the Kur [ii. 181], Therefore whosoever of you shall be present in the month, and stationary, not journeying, he shall fast therein (Mgh, Msb) as long as he shall remain present and stationary: (Msb:) AlXhr being here in the accus. case as an adv. n. of time. (Mgh, Msb.) [And hence,] Xahida AljumoEapa He attained to [the being present at] the jumoEap [here meaning, as in many other instances, the prayer of Friday]: (Mgh:) and Xahida AlEiyda he attained to [the being present at] the Eiyd [or festival, or the prayer thereof]. (Msb.) [Hence also,] it is said in a trad., yaXohadu bayoEakumu AlHalifu waAllRagowu [Swearing, and unprofitable speech, attend your selling]. (TA in art. Xwb: see 1 in that art.)

2: see 4.

3 XaAohada

4 OaXohadotuhu EalaI kacaA c
4. OaXohadotuhu EalaI kacaA I made him to be a witness (XaAhid) of, or to such a thing: (S, Mgh, L:) [and in like manner,] OaXohadotuhu AlXRaIoCa I made him to have knowledge of the thing, and to witness it, or see it or behold it with his eye. (Msb.) See also 10. UiXohaAdN in relation to criminal matters means [The causing one to take notice of a thing that threatens to occasion some injury, with a view to the prevention of such injury; as, for instance,] the saying to the owner of a house, “ This thy wall is leaning, therefore demolish it, ” or “ feared, therefore repair it. ” (Mgh.) ― -b2- AXhdhu also signifies He caused him to be present. (K.) You say, OaXohadaniI UimolaAkahu He caused me to be present [at, or on the occasion of, his being put in possession]. (S.) ― -b3- OuXohida: see 10. ＝ -A2- AXhd [as intrans.] (assumed tropical:) Humorem tenuem e pene emisit vir propter lusum amatorium vel osculum; (S, K;) as also XhRd↓, (K,) inf. n. taXohiydN: (TA:) [from XahodN signifying “ honey; ” for] EusayolapN is a term for macoIN. (S.) (assumed tropical:) He rendered his miYozar [or waist-wrapper] of a reddish hue and of a dark dust-colour (OaxoDar) [by the act above-mentioned]. (L.) (assumed tropical:) He (a boy) attained to puberty. (Th, TA.) And AXhdt She (a girl) menstruated: and attained to puberty. (K.)

5 AltRaXahRudu c
5. AltRaXahRudu in prayer is well known; (S, K;) The reciting of the form of words commencing with AltRaHiyRaAtu lilRehi: [see art. HI:] from the occurrence therein of the words OaXohadu Oano laA UilaAha UilRaA QllRehu waOaXohadu OanRa muHamRadFA Eaboduhu warasuwluhu. (Mgh, * TA. [See also Har p. 611.]) ― -b2- And taXahRada also signifies He sought, or desired to obtain, martyrdom. (L.)

10 AstXhdhu c
10. AstXhdhu He asked him, or required him, to tell what he had witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye; to declare what he knew; to give testimony, or evidence; to bear witness; or to give decisive information. (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K.) You say, AisotaXohadotu fulaAnFA EalaI fulaAnK I asked, or required, [or cited, or summoned,] such a one to give his testimony, or evidence, or to bear witness, against such a one. (L.) And AisotaXohadotu AlrRajula EalaI UiqoraAri Algariymi and OaXohadotuhu↓ I asked, or required, [&c., and made,] the man to bear witness to, or to be witness of or to, the confession, or acknowledgment, of the debtor. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AstXhd bibayotK EalaI maEonaI kalimapK [He adduced, or urged, or cited, a verse as an evidential example of the meaning of a word]. (A phrase of frequent occurrence in the larger lexicons.) ― -b3- AusotuXohida (S, K) and OuXohida↓ (K) He was slain a martyr in the cause of God's religion. (S, K. [See XahiydN.])

XahodN c
XahodN: see XaAhidN, first sentence. ＝ -A2- Also, and XuhodN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the former of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of the people of El-'Áliyeh, (Msb, TA,) Honey: (K:) or honey in its wax [i. e. its comb]; (S, Msb;) honey not expressed from its wax [or comb]: (TA:) pl. XihaAdN: (S, Msb, K:) XahodapN is a more particular term, (S, K,) the n. un., [signifying a portion thereof; and a honey-comb, or a portion of a honey-comb;] as also XuhodapN. (TA.)

XuhodN c
XuhodN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XuhuwdN c
XuhuwdN: see XaAhidN, in two places.

XahiydN c
XahiydN is also written and pronounced XihiydN, with kesr to the X: (K, TA:) and in like manner is every word of the measure faEiylN having a faucial letter for its, medial radical, whether an epithet, like this, or a subst., like ragiyfN and baEiyrN: ElHemdánee says, in the “ Iaráb el-Kur-án, ” that the people of El-Hijáz, and Benoo-Asad, say raHiymN and ragiyfN and baEiyrN, with fet-h to the first letter; and Keys and Rabee'ah and Temeem say raHiymN and rigiyfN and biEiyrN, with kesr to the first letter: Sub says, in the R, that Temeem pronounce every faEiyl of which the medial radical letter is hemzeh or any other faucial with kesr to the first letter: and En-Nawawee states, on the authority of Lth, that some of the Arabs do the same when the medial radical letter is not a faucial; as in kbyr and krym and jlyl and the like thereof. (TA.) [This last pronunciation obtains extensively in the present day: and so, in similar cases, does the intermediate pronunciation termed UimaAlapu AlfatoHi, (i. e. the pronouncing fet-h like “ e ” in the English word “ bed, ”) which may be justly regarded as the best to be followed because intermediate and because sanctioned by the usage of the classical times, except in cases that are pointed out by the grammarians as presenting obstacles to the pronunciation thus termed.] ― -b2- XahiydN is syn. with XaAhidN [in several senses, as shown below]: and its pl. is XuhadaMCu. (S, K.) See XaAhidN, in six places. ― -b3- Also Possessing much knowledge with respect to external things: xabiyrN is used in the like sense with respect to internal things; and EaliymN, in the like sense absolutely. (L.) [Hence, perhaps,] waQdoEuwA XuhadMCakumo, in the Kur ii. 21, [as though meaning And call ye to your aid those of you who possess much knowledge: or] the meaning here is, your helpers: (Bd:) or your gods whom ye worship. (Jel.) AlXRahiydu as a name of God means The Faithful, or Trusty, in his testimony (Zj, L,) or in testimony: (K:) and (Zj, K) as some say, (Zj,) He from whose knowledge nothing is hidden; the Omniscient. (Zj, L, K.) ― -b4- Also, derived from AlXRahaAdapu, or from AlmuXaAhadapu, or from AlXRuhuwdu, [all inf. ns.,] accord. to different opinions; (TA;) and of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; (Msb, TA;) or in the sense of the measure faAEilN; (TA;) A martyr who is slain in the cause of God's religion; (S, K;) [i. e.] one who is slain by unbelievers on a field of battle; (Msb;) one who is slain fighting in the cause of God's religion: (IAth:) so called because the angels of mercy are present with him; (K;) because the angels are present at the washing of his corpse, or at the removal of his soul to Paradise: (Msb:) or because God and his angels are witnesses for him of his title to a place in Paradise: (IAmb, Mgh, * K:) or because he is one of those who shall be required to bear witness on the day of resurrection, (K, TA,) with the Prophet, (TA,) against the people of past times, (K, TA,) who charged their prophets with falsehood: (TA:) or because of his falling upon the XaAhidap↓, or ground: (K:) or because he is still living, and present with his Lord: (ISh, Mgh, K:) or because he witnesses. or beholds, God's world of spirits and his world of corporeal beings: (K, * TA:) [and several other reasons are assigned for this appellation:] the primary application is that expl. above: but it is also applied by the Prophet to one who dies of colic: one who is drowned: one who is burned to death: one who is killed by a building falling to ruin upon him: one who dies of pleurisy: (IAth, L:) one who dies of plague, or pestilence: a woman who dies in a state of pregnancy: (L:) and to some others: (IAth:) the pl. is XuhadaMCu. (A, Msb, K, &c.)

XahaAdapN c
XahaAdapN [see 1:] Information of what one has witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye: (IF, Mgh, L, Msb:) this is the primary signification: (L:) said to be a subst. from AlmuXaAhadapu: (Msb:) declaration of what one knows: testimony, attestation, evidence, or witness: (L:) decisive information. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- An oath: pl. XahaAdaAtN: so in the Kur xxiv. 6 [and 8]. (TA.) ― -b3- Martyrdom in the cause of God's religion.
(S, K. [See XahiydN.]) ― -b4- Also i. q. maXohadN as expl. below: see the latter word. ― -b5- [And it is used in the sense of muXaAhadN: thus,] EaAlimu Algayobi waAlXRahaAdapi, in the Kur vi. 73 &c., means The Knower of what is unseen and of what is seen. (Jel.)

XahiydapN c
XahiydapN A roasted lamb: or [the kind of food called] hariysap [q. v.]: pl. XihaAdN. (Har. p. 609.)

XahRaAdN c
[XahRaAdN Always present. (Freytag from the Deewán of the Hudhalees.)]

XaAhidN c
XaAhidN (S, Mgh, L, K) and XahiydN↓ (S, * Mgh, L) One who tells, or gives information of, what he has witnessed, or seen or beheld with his eye: (Mgh, L:) one who declares what he knows: (L:) one who knows, and declares what he knows: (ISd, TA:) a witness, as meaning one who gives testimony, or evidence; who bears witness: (S, * L, K: *) [one who gives decisive information: (see 1, first sentence:)] pl. of the former XahodN↓, (Akh, S, K,) or [rather] this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, TA,) like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, and saforN of saAfirN, (S,) but some disallow this; (TA;) and XuhuwdN↓ [but see what is said of this in the latter half of the paragraph] and OaXohaAdN are also pls. of XaAhidN, (Mgh, L,) or of XahodN: (S, K:) the pl. of XahiydN↓ is XuhadaMCu. (S, Mgh.) [Hence,] maEahaA saAYiqN waXahiydN↓, in the Kur 1. 20: see art. swq. ― -b2- [Hence also] AlXRaAhidu a name of the Prophet; (K;) meaning The witness against those to whom he has been sent. (Jel in xxxiii. 44.) ― -b3- And XaAhidN An angel: (S, L, K:) or a guardian angel: (Mujáhid:) pl. OaXohaAdN: or this means the prophets. (TA.) ― -b4- And The tongue: (S, L, K:) from the saying, lifulaAnK XaAhidN HasanN Such a one has an elegant diction. (L.) One says also, maA lifulaAnK ruwaMCN walaA XaAhidN Such a one has neither goodliness of aspect nor tongue. (Aboo-Bekr, L.) ― -b5- [As a conventional term used in lexicology &c.,] An evidential example, generally poetical, of the form or meaning of a word or phrase: pl. XawaAhidu: the sciences that require XawaAhid being those of AllRugap and AlSRarof and AlnRaHow and AlmaEaAniI and AlbayaAn and AlbadiyE and AlEaruwD and AlqawaAfiI. (MF on the xuTobap of the K.) [One says, hecaA XaAhidN likacaA and EalaI kacaA This is an evidential example of such a thing.] With respect to the classical language, absolutely, XwAhd are taken, by universal consent, from the Kur-án, and from the language [both verse and prose (Kull p. 348)] of those Arabs who lived before the period of the corruption [in any considerable degree] of the Arabic tongue: [see muwalRadN:] also, accord. to the general decision of the learned, from the Traditions of Mohammad; [which last source is excluded by some because traditions may be corrupted in language by their transmitters, and interpolated, and even forged;] and electively from the language of those Arabs who lived after the first corruption of the Arabic tongue, but before the corruption had become extensive. (Mz, 1st nwE; and MF ubi suprà. [See, again, muwalRadN.]) The classes of the poets from whose poetry XwAhd are taken are the Pagan Arabs, the Mukhadrams, the Islámees, and the Muwelleds: [see jaAhiliIRN and muxaDoramN and UisolaAmiIRN and muwalRadN:] with respect to all the sciences above mentioned, they are taken from the poetry of the first, second, and third, classes; from that of the first and second by universal consent, and from that of the third electively: (MF ubi suprá:) but they are taken from the poetry of the fourth class with respect only to the sciences of AlmaEaAniI and AlbayaAn and AlbadiyE. (Idem, and Kull p. 348.) [The age of the earliest existing classical poems (though some older fragments and couplets and single verses have been preserved) is only about a century before the birth of Mohammad: that of the latest, about a century after his death. (See the Preface to this work.)] ― -b6- Knowing, (Msb,) and witnessing, or seeing or beholding with his eye; a witness, as meaning an eyewitness; (L, Msb;) as also XahiydN↓: pl. of the former [or, as is said in the L in art. mjd, of the former or of the latter,] OaXohaAdN and XuhuwdN; [but see what is said of these pls. in the first sentence of this paragraph;] and of the latter XuhadaMCu. (Msb.) [See an ex. of XahiydN↓ in this sense in a verse cited voce rabRN.] ― -b7- [Hence, in the present day, applied to A notary, who hears and writes and attests cases to be submitted for judgment in the court of a kádee.] ― -b8- Present; a witness as meaning one personally present; (S, L, Msb, K;) as also XahiydN↓: (Msb:) pl. of the former XuhRadN (S, L, K) [and OaXohaAdN, as above,] and XuhuwdN↓, (K,) or this last is used as a pl. but is originally an inf. n. (S, L.) One says, AlXRaAhidu yaraI maA laA yaraI AlgaAYibu, meaning The present knows what the absent knows not. (Msb.) And qawomN XuhuwdN People, or persons, present. (S, A.) And kalRamotuhu EalaI ruWuwsi AlOaXohaAdi [I spoke to him before witnesses, or persons present]. (A.) ― -b9- [Hence, app., being opposed to gaAYibN,] A running in which a horse exerts his force unsparingly; (A, L;) as in the saying, lilofarasi gaAYibN waXaAhidN The horse has a run which he reserves [for the time of need], and a run which he performs unsparingly; like the saying, lahu SawonN wabacolN: (A: [see 1 in art. bcl:]) or XaAhidN means a running that testifies the excellence of a horse, (IAar, K,) and his quality of outstripping others. (IAar, TA.) ― -b10- A star [app. when visible]; (Aboo-Eiyoob, K;) as being present and apparent in the night. (TA.) ― -b11- [Hence, accord. to some,] SalaApu AlXRaAhidi The prayer of sunset; (A, L, Msb, K;) because it is the prayer that is performed when the star becomes visible; (Sh, L;) also called SalaApu AlbaSari, because the stars are seen at the time thereof: or, accord. to some, the prayer of daybreak; (L;) [and so, accord. to some, SalaApu AlbaSari; (see art. bSr;)] as also AlmaXohuwdu↓; (TA;) and it is said to be so called because he who is travelling must perform it without abridging it, like him who is present at his home: Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer says that the former prayer is so called for this reason [as is also said in the A and Msb]: AM asserts that the first reason assigned above is the right one, because the prayer of daybreak, in like manner, may not be abridged, and is not thus called; but it is thus called by a poet. (L.) ― -b12- And AlXRaAhidu is a name of Friday; (Fr, K;) as also AlmaXohuwdu↓: or the latter is the day of resurrection: (K:) or the day of 'Arafeh: (Fr, K: [see Earafapu:]) because of the presence and congregation of people on each of those days. (TA.) ― -b13- XaAhidN also signifies Matter resembling mucus, that comes forth with the fœtus: (S, K:) pl. XuhuwdN: which latter, accord. to ISd, means the OagoraAs [pl. of girosN, q. v.,] upon the head of a young camel at the time of its birth. (TA.) And XuhuwdN AlnRaAqapi means The marks left by the blood, or by the membrane that enclosed the fœtus, of the she-camel, in the place where she has brought forth. (S, K.) ― -b14- Also A quick, or an expeditious, thing or affair. (K.)

AlXRaAhidapu c
AlXRaAhidapu The earth, or ground. (K.) See XahiydN, last sentence.

maXohadN c
maXohadN A place where people are present or assembled; a place of assembling; an assembly; (S, L, K;) as also maXohadapN↓ and maXohudapN↓ (K) and XahaAdapN↓: (L:) pl. maXaAhidu. (A.) [Hence,] maXaAhidu makRapa The places of religious visitation, where the ceremonies of the pilgrimage &c. are performed, at Mekkeh. (L.) ― -b2- [A funeral assembly or procession. ― -b3- A place where a martyr has died or is buried. ― -b4- And The aspect, or outward appearance, of a person; like maroOFI: see an instance voce EawodN.]

muXohadN c
muXohadN Slain a martyr in the cause of God's religion. (K. [See also XahiydN.])

AimoraOapN muXohidN c
AimoraOapN muXohidN, (S, A, K,) without p, (S,) and muXohidapN, (A,) A woman whose husband is present with her: (S, A, K:) opposed to AimoraOapN mugiybapN; (S, A;) this last with p. (S.)

maXohadapN c
maXohadapN and maXohudapN: see maXohadN.

majolisN maXohuwdN c
majolisN maXohuwdN [A place of assembling at which numerous persons are present]. (A.) And yawomN maXohuwdN [A day on which numerous persons are present: and particularly] a day on which the inhabitants of heaven and earth will be present. (TA.) And SalaApN maXohuwdapN makotuwbapN A prayer at the performance of which the angels are present, and the recompense of which, for the performer, is written, or registered. (L.) See also XaAhidN, in two places, in the last quarter of the paragraph. ― -b2- maEohuwdN wamaXohuwdN wamawoEuwdN Past and present and future; the tenses of a verb. (Kh, L in art. Ehd.)

XahodaAnijN c
XahodaAnijN, (K accord. to the TA,) with fet-h to the X and kesr to the n, (TA,) and XaAhodaAnijN, (K accord. to the TA,) or XahodaAnajN, (Mgh, Msb, and so in the CK, except that it is there written as though imperfectly decl.,) with fet-h to the n, (Msb,) and XaAhodaAnaj, (CK,) arabicized from [the Pers.] XaAho daAnaho, which means “ king of grains, ”
(Ibn-El-Kutbee, TA,) The seed of the qinRab [or hemp]: (Mgh, Msb, K:) it is useful as a remedy for the quartan fever, (K,) prepared as a beverage, (TA,) and for the [kinds of leprosy called] bahaq and baraS, (K,) applied as a liniment, (TA,) and it kills what are called HabRu AlqaroEi, (K,) which are worms in the belly, [tape-worms,] (TA,) when eaten, and also when applied to the belly externally. (K.)

1 Xaharahu c
1. Xaharahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
Xahara
, (S, K,) inf. n. XahorN and XuhorapN; (S;) and XhRrhu↓, (S, A, O, K,) inf. n. taXohiyrN; (S;) and AXthrhu↓; (S, K;) He made it apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, notable, commonly known, or public: (S, O, MF:) or [it generally means] he made it apparent, &c., as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; he exposed it as such; or rendered it notorious in a bad sense, or infamous. (A, K.) You say, Xaharotu AlHadiyva, inf. n. as above, I divulged the story, or discourse. (Msb.) And lifulaAnK faDiylapN QXotaharahaA↓ AlnRaAsu [Such a one has an excellent quality which the people have made commonly known]. (S.) And Xaharotuhu bayona AlnRaAsi I rendered him conspicuous [or notorious or celebrated or renowned] among the people. (Msb.) And Xaharotu zayodFA bikacaA and XhRrth↓ [I rendered Zeyd conspicuous, notorious, celebrated, or renowned, for such a thing]; (Mgh, * Msb;) [but] the latter has an intensive signification: OaXoharotuhu↓, with A, in the sense of Xaharotuhu, has not been transmitted: (Msb:) or is not of established authority. (Mgh.) One says also, Xuhira bikacaA, and AiXotahara↓, [generally, but not always, in a bad sense, meaning] He was rendered, or became, notorious, or infamous, for such a thing: (A:) the latter verb being intrans. as well as trans. (TA.) And [hence one says,] AiXotaharotu↓ fulaAnFA meaning (tropical:) I held such a one in light, or little, estimation, or in contempt, and exposed his vices, faults, or evil qualities or actions. (A.) ― -b2- And Xahara sayofahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
Xahara
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. XahorN, (S, Msb,) He drew his sword (S, Msb, TA) from its scabbard: (TA:) or he drew his sword and raised it over the people; (A, K;) as also XhRrhu↓. (K.)

2 XahRara
2: see above, in three places. [In modern Arabic, XhRr often signifies He paraded an offender as a public example; and it occurs in this sense in the S and TA in art. bls, &c.: the offender, in this case, is generally mounted upon an ass or a camel, and often with his face towards the animal's tail.]

3 XAhrhu c
3. XAhrhu, (K,) inf. n. muXaAharapN (S, K) and XihaArN, (K,) He hired him, or took him as a hired man or hireling, for [or by] the month: (Lh, K:) or he made an engagement, or a contract, with him for work or the like, by the month, or month by month: (TA:) AlmuXaAharapu from AlXRahoru is like AlmuEaAwamapu from AlEaAmu. (S, TA.)

4 OaXohara
4: see 1. ＝ -A2- OaXoharonaA, (S, Msb, * K,) inf. n. UiXohaArN, (Msb,) A month passed (lit. came) over us. (S, Msb, * K.) And AXhr AlSRabiIRu [The child became a month old; or] a month passed (lit. came) over the child: similar to OaHowala, (A,) or to OaHaAla. (Msb.) And AXhrt AldRaAru The house became altered, or changed, and months passed over it. (TA in art. Hwl.) ― -b2- Also We remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, a month in a place. (ISk, S.) ― -b3- And We entered upon the month, i. e., the lunar month. (Th, S.) ― -b4- And AXhrt She (a woman) entered upon the month of her bringing forth. (Msb, K.)

8 AXthr c
8. AXthr It was, or became, apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, notable, commonly known, or public: (S:) or [it generally means] it was, or became, apparent, &c., as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; it was, or became, exposed as such, or rendered notorious in a bad sense or infamous. (A, K.) It (a story, or discourse,) became divulged, or public. (Msb.) AXthr bikacaA: see 1. ＝ -A2- As a trans. verb: see 1 in three places.

XahorN c
XahorN The new moon, when it appears: (IF, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) so called because of its conspicuousness. (Mgh, Msb.) This is the original signification. (Mgh.) [See the last sentence of this paragraph.] You say, raOayotu AlXRahora, meaning I saw the new moon of the month. (Mgh.) Hence it is said in a trad., SuwmuwA AlXRahora, meaning Fast ye the first day of the lunar month. (Lh, TA.) And hence the trad., UinRamaA AlXRahoru tisoEN waEiXoruwna, meaning The utility of watching for the new moon is on the nine and twentieth night. (L, TA.) [Or the meaning is, that the lunar month is a period of nine and twenty nights.] ― -b2- Also The moon: or the moon when conspicuous, and near to being full. (K.) ― -b3- And [A lunar month;] a certain well-known number of days: so called because made manifest by the moon: (ISd, K:) an arabicized word; or, as some say, Arabic; (Msb;) and so called because of its being manifest: (Msb, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXohurN (Msb, K) and [of mult.] XuhuwrN. (S, Msb, K.) The following are the modern names of the months: 1. AlmuHarRamu [to which the epithet AlHaraAmu is often added]: 2. SafarN [to which the epithet Alxayoru is often added]: 3. rabiyEN AlOawRalu: 4. rabiyEN AlMxiru [or AlvRaAniI]: 5. jumaAdaI AlOuwlaI: 6. jumaAdaI AlMxirapu [or AlvRaAniyapu]: 7. rajabN [to which is often added the epithet AlOaSamRu, and that of Alfarodu]: 8. XaEobaAnu [to which we often find the epithet AlmuEaZRamu added, and sometimes that of AlXRariyfu]: 9. ramaDaAnu [to which the epithet AlmubaAraku is appropriated]: 10. XawRaAlN [to which the epithet AlmukarRamu is frequently added]: 11. cuw AlqaEodapi: and 12. cuw AlHijRapi: [see the second of the two tables in p. 1254:] and the following are the names by which they were called by the tribe of 'Ád, agreeably with the foregoing numeration: 1. muWotamirN: 2. naAjirN: 3. xawRaAnN: 4. buSRaAnN [q. v.]: 5. rubRaI: 6. HaniynN: 7. AlOaSamRu: 8. EaAcilN: 9. naAtiqN: 10. waEolN: 11. waronapu: and 12. burakN [or buraku?]. (Ibn-El-Kelbee, in TA, voce muWotamirN. [But authors differ respecting some of these names, as will be seen in other articles.]) OaXohurN maEoluwmaAtN, said, in the Kur [ii. 193], to be the period of the pilgrimage, for by AlHajRu, which immediately precedes, is meant waqotu AlHajRi, (Mgh, Msb,) or zamaAnu AlHajRi, (Msb,) applies to Showwál and Dhul-Kaadeh and ten days of Dhu-l-Hijjeh, (Mgh, Msb,) accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh (Mgh) and most of the learned, part of Dhu-l-Hijjeh being called a month tropically, as is often done by the Arabs in similar cases, relating to time; for ex. when they say, maA raOayotuhu muco yawomaAni, the period of separation having been a day and a part of a day: (Msb:) or [and] nine days of Dhu-l-Hijjeh with the night preceding the day of the sacrifice, accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee: (Mgh:) or [and] all Dhu-l-Hijjeh, accord. to Málik: (Mgh, Msb:) [in these two explanations the two months next preceding being meant to be included:] or Showwál and Dhu-l- Kaadeh and Dhu-l-Hijjeh and Moharram, accord. to Aboo-'Amr Esh-Shaabee. (Msb.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) A learned man: (O, K:) [because of his celebrity:] pl. XuhuwrN. (O, TA.) ― -b5- [And accord. to the K, it signifies also The like of a nail-paring: but this is app. a mistake, perhaps originating from a mutilated transcript of what here follows:] a poet says, describing camels,
OabodaOona mino najodK EalaI viqapK
waAlXRahoru mivolu qulaAmapi AlZRufori
[They went forth from Nejd in a state of confidence, the new moon being like the nail-paring]. (O.)

XuhorapN c
XuhorapN a subst. from AlAiXotihaAru, (Mgh,) signifying The appearance, conspicuousness, manifestness, notoriousness, notableness, or publicity, of a thing: (S, O, Msb:) or [generally] its appearance, &c., as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly; its notoriousness in a bad sense, or infamousness. (A, K.) ― -b2- Any evil thing that exposes its author to disgrace; any disgraceful, or shameful, thing; a vice, or fault, or the like. (IAar, O, TA.) ― -b3- A dress of the most excellent or superb kind; and one of the vilest or meanest kind: both of which are forbidden. (Mgh.) ― -b4- [It is also used in the sense of maXohuwrN.] One says, jaEalahu XuhorapF (tropical:) [He rendered him notorious, either in a bad or in a good sense]. (A.) And SaAra XuhorapF, (K in art. dwl,) i. e. maXohuwrFA (assumed tropical:) [He became notorious, &c.]; said of a man. (TK in that art.)

birocawonN XihoriIRN c
birocawonN XihoriIRN A brcwn [or hackney] between the ramakap [or mare of mean breed] and the horse of generous breed: one says, lamo yarokabi AlXRihoriyRapa and AlXRahaAriIa [He did not ride hackneys of the sort above mentioned]: (A:) or XihoriyRapN signifies baraAciyn [or hackneys]; and its pl. is XahaArK: (Mgh:) or a sort of baraAciyn [or hackneys]; (Lth, O, K;) a horse of which the dam is Arabian but not the sire. (Lth, O.)

XahiyrN c
XahiyrN: see maXohuwrN. ― -b2- XahiyrapN A woman, and a she-ass, broad (O, K) and bulky. (O.)

OaXoharu c
[OaXoharu More, and most, apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, &c.; better, and best, known. ― -b2- Hence, AlOaXoharaAni The drum and the banner. (Gol., from Meyd.)]

OaXaAhiru c
OaXaAhiru [in the CK AaXAhiyru] The whiteness of the narcissus. (K, TA.)

muXohirN c
muXohirN A child a month old. (O, TA.)

muXahRarN c
muXahRarN: see the following paragraph.

maXohuwrN c
maXohuwrN Of known place or station; (K;) well known; well spoken of; celebrated; held in repute; reputable; notable; eminent; (O, K, TA;) applied to a man; (O, TA;) as also XahiyrN↓, (O, K, TA,) and [in an intensive sense] muXahRarN↓. (TA.) [And Anything apparent, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, notable, commonly known, or public: lit. rendered apparent &c. Applied to a word or phrase or meaning, Commonly known or obtaining or received; well known; or held in repute. Hence EalaI AlmaXohuwri According to common, or well-known, usage; or according to common repute.]

1 Xahaqa c
1. Xahaqa, aor.
Xahaqa
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. XuhuwqN, (Msb,) [said of a mountain, and of a building, &c., (see XaAhiqN,)] It rose high; or became high, or elevated, or lofty. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Xahaqa, aor.
Xahaqa
and
Xahiqa
, inf. n. XahiyqN [and taXohaAqN], said of an ass, [He uttered the ending of his braying, or the final sounds thereof;] (S;) [for] XahiyqN signifies the ending, or final part, of the crying, or braying, of the ass; (S, O;) and to this the cries of the punished in Hell are likened in the Kur xi. 108; (O;) and zafiyrN signifies the “ beginning, or commencing part, thereof: ” (S:) or Xhyq signifies the drawing back of the breath; and zfyr the “ emitting thereof: ” (Lth, S: [but the reverse is said by Lth and in the S in art. zfr:]) and taXohaAqN signifies the same as XahiyqN: (S:) or both of these words signify [absolutely] the crying, or braying, of the ass: (O, K:) Zj says that XahiyqN as denoting one of the cries of the afflicted [in Hell] means a very high-sounding moaning: and that, accord. to some, zafiyrN [as used in the Kur ubi suprà] is similar to the beginning of the cry of the ass, termed Xahiyq; and that XahiyqN is in the chest. (TA.) [Said of a man,] Xahaqa, aor.
Xahaqa
and
Xahiqa
; and Xahiqa, aor.
Xahaqa
; inf. n. XahiyqN and XuhaAqN (O, K) and XuhuwqN (O) and taXohaAqN; signify The [sound of] weeping became reiterated in his chest: (O, K:) or, as in the L, he reiterated the [sound of] weeping in his chest. (TA.) [Or] Xahaqa, aor.
Xahaqa
and
Xahiqa
, inf. n. XahiyqN, signifies [or signifies also] He reiterated his breath, making his voice audible, naturally. (Msb.) One says also, Xahaqa fulaAnN XahoqapF famaAta Such a one uttered a single cry and died. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And Xahaqato Eayonu AlnRaAZiri Ealayohi (tropical:) The eye of the looker smote him with evil influence: (O, K, TA:) or, was pleased with him, and therefore continued looking at him. (A, TA.)

XahoqapN c
XahoqapN A single cry. (S, TA.) [See 1, last sentence but one.]

XuhoqapN c
XuhoqapN Height, elevation, or loftiness. (TA.)

XaAhiqN c
XaAhiqN High, or lofty; applied to a mountain, (S, O, Msb, K,) and to a building, &c.: (O, K:) or, applied to a mountain, high and inaccessible: (JK, TA:) pl. XawaAhiqu: (JK, Msb, TA:) you say jibaAlN XaAhiqapN and XaAhiqaAtN and XawaAhiqu. (Msb.) ― -b2- Applied to a vein [or an artery], (tropical:) Pulsing upwards: (O, K, TA:) a term of the physicians. (O, TA.) ― -b3- cuw XaAhiqK (tropical:) A man whose anger is vehement: (JK, S, A, O, L, TA:) wrongly expl. in the K by the words laA yaXotadRu gaDabuhu: (TA:) and so cuw SaAhilK. (A, TA.) And (tropical:) A stallion [camel] Excited by lust, assaulting [the she-camels], and causing a sound to be heard from his inside; as also cuw SaAhilK. (TA.)

taXohaAqN c
taXohaAqN an inf. n. (S, * O, K. [See 1.]) ― -b2- [And also an epithet.] One says DaHikN taXohaAqN [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) A loud laughing, likened to the taXohaAq of the ass]. (S, O.)

1 Xahila c
1. Xahila, aor.
Xahala
, (K,) inf. n. XahalN, (S, * O, * TA,) He (a man, S, O) had that quality of the eye which is termed XuholapN [expl. below]; (S, O, K;) as also AXhlR↓, inf. n. AiXohilaAlN. (K.) [And in like manner each of these verbs is probably used as said of the eye.]

2 taXohiylN c
2. taXohiylN is a vulgar dial. var. of tasohiylN [inf. n. of sahRala, q. v.]. (TA.)

3 XAhlhu c
3. XAhlhu, (K,) inf. n. muXaAhalapN, (S, O, TA,) He acted with him in an evil manner; or contended, or disputed, with him; syn. XaArRahu; (S, * O, * K, TA;) and laAHaAhu [which has the latter of these significations]: and opposed him, being opposed by him; syn. EaAraDahu: (TA:) he reviled him; or reviled him, being reviled by him: (K:) he exchanged bad names with him; syn. qaAraSahu: (S, * TA: [in the O, AlmuqaAraDap is put for AlmuqaAraSap:]) he bandied words with him. (S, O, TA.)

5 tXhRl c
5. tXhRl, said of the freshness, or brightness, and beauty, of the face, (maMC Alwajoh,) It went away, or departed, (O, K, TA,) by reason of emaciation. (TA.)

9 UiXohalRa
9: see 1.

XaholN c
XaholN A mixture of two colours. (ISk, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (ISk, TA,) one says, fiI fulaAnK waloEN and XaholN, (ISk, O, K, *) or fI flAn XaholN, (JK,) (assumed tropical:) In such a one is lying. (ISk, JK, O, K.) ＝ -A2- See also XaholapN.

XahalN c
XahalN [properly inf. n. of Xahila]: see XuholapN.

XaholapN c
XaholapN A middle-aged, intelligent woman: an epithet peculiarly applied to a woman: (S, O, K:) one says AimoraOapN XaholapN kaholapN, but not rajulN XaholN↓ kaholN; though IDrd mentions XaholN kaholN. (TA.) ― -b2- And An old woman. (K.)

XuholapN c
XuholapN A tinge, or mixture, of zuroqap [i. e. blueness, or grayness, or a greenish hue,] in the black of the eye: (S, O:) or, as also XahalN↓, [this latter mentioned above as inf. n. of Xahila, a tint] less than zaraqN, [in the CK AlzRuroq is erroneously put for AlzRaraq, which is here used in the sense of AlzRuroqap,] and more beautiful than this, in the black of the eye: (K, TA:) thus in the M: (TA:) or a tinge of redness in the black of the eye, not in lines, like XukolapN, but [consisting in] a paucity of blackness of the black of the eye, so that it is as though it inclined to redness: (K:) or a hue of the black of the eye between redness and blackness: or a lack of purity of the blackness thereof: or a redness in the black of the eye; XukolapN being the like of a redness in the white thereof; thus expl. by A 'Obeyd; and in like manner by Es-Semmák. (TA.)

XaholaMCu c
XaholaMCu fem. of OaXohalu [q. v.]. (S, O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also A want; syn. HaAjapN: (S, O, K:) said by IF to be originally XakolaMCu. (O.)

XiholiyliIRN c
XiholiyliIRN A diroham [app. meaning a silver coin] of the measure of the breadth of the hand. (Mgh.)

OaXohalu c
OaXohalu, applied to a man, (S, O,) Having that quality of the eye which is termed XuholapN: (S, O, K:) accord. to AZ, syn. with OaXokalu: (TA: [but see this latter epithet:]) fem. XaholaMCu; (K;) which is applied as an epithet to an eye. (S, O.) ― -b2- Also A mountain, and a wolf, dust-coloured inclining to whiteness. (En-Nadr, TA.) ― -b3- And AlOaXohalu is the name of A certain idol. (Ibn-El-Kelbee, O, K.)

1 Xahuma c
1. Xahuma, aor.
Xahuma
, (S, K,) inf. n. XahaAmapN (S, TA) and XuhuwmapN, (TA,) He (a man) was, or became, hardy, strong, sturdy, enduring, or patient; (S;) [or] acute of mind or intellect; (S, K;) clever, ingenious, sharp, or penetrating. (K.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) He (a horse) was, or became, swift; brisk, lively, sprightly, or agile; and strong. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And app. It was, or became, rough, harsh, or coarse: for] XahaAmapN signifies xuXuwnapN. (Ham p. 699.) ＝ -A2- Xahamahu, (S, K,) aor.
Xahama
and
Xahuma
, inf. n. XahomN and XuhuwmN, (K,) He frightened him, or made him afraid; (S, K;) namely, a man. (K.) ― -b2- And Xahama Alfarasa, aor.
Xahama
, (K,) inf. n. XahomN, (TA,) He chid the horse; (K;) or incited him to quickness. (JK, K, and Ham p. 699.)

XahomN c
XahomN, applied to a man, Hardy, strong, sturdy, enduring, or patient; (S;) acute of mind or intellect; (S, K;) clever, ingenious, sharp, or penetrating; and maXohuwmN↓ signifies the same: pl. of the former XihaAmN (K) [and app. XuhumN also: see suhumN, and see what here follows]. ― -b2- A chief whose judgment, or judicial decision, or exercise of authority, is effectual in affairs; (K, * TA;) courageous; or sharp, or vigorous and effective, in affairs which others are unable to accomplish: or, accord. to Fr, forbearing, or clement; who performs well that which is imposed upon him; whom one finds not otherwise than forbearing, or clement, and pleased, or content, with that which
is imposed upon him: and in like manner applied to other than a man: (TA:) pl. XuhuwmN (K) [and app. XuhumN]: see suhumN, with which XuhumN is syn. (TA in art. shm.) ― -b3- And, applied to a horse, (tropical:) Swift; brisk, lively, sprightly, or agile; and strong. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A stone which is placed at the entrance of a trap (maSoyadap or maSiydap in different copies of the K) for a lion, and which falls upon it when he enters: as also sahomN: (K, * TA:) the latter is the word [better] known to the leading lexicologists. (TA.)

XahaAmN c
XahaAmN i. q. siEolaApN [app. meaning The kind of goblin, or demon, thus called]. (As, S, K.)

XayohamN c
XayohamN The dulodul [q. v., i. e. hedge-hog; or a certain species of hedge-hog; &c.]: (K:) [see also the last sentence of this paragraph:] and, (K,) or accord. to AZ, (TA,) the male hedge-hog: (S, K, TA:) or such as has large prickles or spines, of male hedge-hogs, (K, TA,) and the like. (TA.) EalaI Zahori XayohamK, occurring in a verse of El-Aashà, is said by AO to mean (assumed tropical:) In a state of fright, or fear. (TA.) ― -b2- XayohamapN An old woman: (K:) or, accord. to IAar, a hedge-hog. (TA.)

maXohuwmN c
maXohuwmN: see XahomN. ＝ -A2- Also Frightened, or made afraid. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And, applied to a horse, Chidden; or incited to quickness. (TA.)

XihoniyzN c
XihoniyzN i. q. XiyniyzN, (ADk, K,) and XuwniyzN, i. e. AlHabRapu AlsRawodaMCu. (ADk, TA.)

1 Xahiyahu c and XahaAhu
1. Xahiyahu XahaAhu: see 8. ＝ -A2- XahaA, aor.
Xahuwa
; and XahiIa, aor.
Xahawa
; inf. n. XahowapN; It [food &c.] was good, sweet, pleasant, or the like. (MA. [But this, the only meaning there assigned to these two verbs, I do not find elsewhere.])

2 XahRayotuhu c
2. XahRayotuhu [I made him, or caused him, to desire, to long, or to desire eagerly]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And XhRI It excited desire, longing, eager desire, or appetence. For ex., in art. smq in the K, yuXahRiI is said of the sumRaAq, or berry of the sumach, meaning It excites appetence.] ― -b3- And XhRI AlXRaIoCa He, or it, caused the thing to be desired, longed for, or desired eagerly: made it to be good, sweet, pleasant, or the like. (MA.) One says, hecaA XaIoCN yuXahRiI AlTRaEaAma i. e. [This is a thing that causes the food to be desired, &c.; that makes it sweet, &c.; or] that incites to desire, or eager desire, of the food. (S, TA.) ― -b4- [And accord. to an explanation of the inf. n., taXohiyapN, in the KL, XhRAhu seems to signify also He said to him, I will give to thee what thou desirest, longest for, or eagerly desirest; agreeably with a rendering of the verb alone, as on the authority of that work, by Golius.]

3 XAhAhu c
3. XAhAhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. muXaAhaApN, (TA,) He was, or became, like him; he resembled him. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also He jested, or joked, with him: (IAar, TA:) [and] so haAXaAhu. (K in art. hXw.) ― -b2- And accord. to IAar, it is also used in relation to the smiting action of the [evil] eye [perhaps meaning He vied with him in smiting with the evil eye: see also 4]. (TA.)

4 AXhAhu c
4. AXhAhu He gave him what he desired or eagerly desired. (K.) ― -b2- And He smote him with an [evil] eye: (K:) in this sense [said to be] formed by transposition from OaXaAhahu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- maA OaXohaAhaA UilaIRa means that she is desired, or eagerly desired, [i. e. How great an object of desire is she to me!] as though it were from XuhiIa, though this was not said: and maA OaXohaAniI lahaA means that thou art desiring, or eagerly desiring, [i. e. How desirous, or eagerly desirous, am I of her!] so says Sb. (TA.)

5 tXhRI c
5. tXhRI He demanded with repeated desire. (K, TA.) So in the saying, (TA,) tXhRI EalaI fulaAnK kacaA (S, TA) [He demanded with repeated desire, of such a one, such a thing]. ― -b2- See also what next follows.

8 AXthAhu c
8. AXthAhu (S, &c.) He desired it, or longed for it: (Msb:) he loved it; and desired it, or wished for it: (K:) or he desired it eagerly, or intensely: (M in art. frs: [see an ex. in a poetical citation voce farRasa:]) and Xahiyahu↓, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
Xahawa
; (Msb, K;) as also XahaAhu↓, aor.
Xahuwa
; (AZ, Msb, K;) inf. n. XahowapN (S, TA) and XaAhiyapN, which last is an inf. n. [of a rare class] like EaAqibapN; (TA;) signifies the same: (S, Msb, K:) and so does tXhRAhu↓. (K.) [See what next follows.]

XahowapN c
XahowapN [mentioned above as an inf. n.] is a word of well-known meaning; (S;) Desire, or longing, or yearning, of the soul for a thing; (Er-Rághib, Msb, TA;) [meaning for a thing gratifying to sense: or eager, or intense, desire; particularly for such a thing; for] it has a more intensive signification than UiraAdapN; and the intelligent agree in opinion that it is not commendable: (M in art. frs:) [being either lawful or unlawful, it may be rendered as above: or appetite: or appetence: or lust: or carnal lust:] in the present state of existence, it is of two sorts, SaAdiqapN [i. e. true], and kaAcibapN [i. e. false]; the former being that without which the body becomes in an unsound state, as the Xahowap [or desire &c.] for food on the occasion of hunger; and the latter being that without which the body does not become in an unsound state: and sometimes it is applied to the object of desire &c., or thing desired &c.: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and agreeably with this last explanation the first of the following pls. is used in the Kur iii. 12: (Ksh, Bd, Jel:) sometimes also it is applied to the faculty to which a thing is made an object of desire &c.: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [also, to the gratification of venereal lust; thus in the K in art. Xfr; see Xafirato and XafirapN:] the pl. is XahawaAtN (Msb, TA) and OaXohiyapN and XuhFI; the last mentioned by AHei, and a rare instance of a pl. of the measure fuEalN from a sing. of the measure faEolapN having an infirm letter for its last radical, like juhFI pl. of jahowapN [and like qurFI pl. of qaroyapN]. (TA.) [AlXRahowataAni means The two appetites, that of the stomach and that of the generative organ.] AlXRahowapu AlxafiyRapu [The latent desire &c.] mentioned in a trad. is said to be any act of disobedience which one conceives in his mind, and upon which he resolves: or one's seeing a beautiful young woman, and lowering his eyes, then looking with his heart, and imaging her to his mind, and so tempting himself. (JM.) [Xahowapu AlTRiyni, lit. The longing for clay, is app. used as a general term for malacia: see HumRaADN.]

XahowaAnu c
XahowaAnu (S, Msb, K, TA) and XahowaAniIRN↓ and XahiIRN↓, (K, TA,) applied to a man, Desirous, or longing; (S, * Msb, * K, * TA;) or very desirous or longing; greedy; or voracious: (TA:) fem. (of the first, Msb) XahowaI: (Msb, K, TA:) pl. [of the first] XahaAwaI, (K, TA,) like sakaAraI [pl. of sakoraAnu]. (TA.) [See an ex. of the pl. in a verse cited voce jarodabaAnN.] One says, rajulN XahowaAnu lilXRaIoCi [A man desirous &c. of the thing]. (S.)

XahowaAniIRN c
XahowaAniIRN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XahiIRN c
XahiIRN i. q. muXotahFI↓ (S, Msb) [i. e. Desired, longed for, or eagerly desired:] or pleasant, delicious, or sweet: (Msb, TA:) applied to food, (S,) and to water. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oabuw AlXRahiIRi (assumed tropical:) The barobaT [or Persian lute]. (KL.) ― -b3- [And Golius adds, as on the authority of a gloss in a copy of the KL, (assumed tropical:) The water-melon (anguria).] ＝ -A2- See also XahowaAnu.

XahRaMCN c
XahRaMCN A man having much, or frequent, desire or longing or eager desire. (TA.) [See also XahowaAnu.]

XaAhK c
XaAhK [act. part. n. of 1; Desiring, or longing; &c.]. (Sb, TA.) ＝ -A2- XaAhiI AlbaSari A man sharp of sight: (S, K:) formed by transposition from XaAYihu AlbaSari. (S.)

OaXohaI c
OaXohaI [More, and most, desirable, or pleasant or delicious or sweet]. One says, huwa OaXohaI UilaIRa mino kacaA [It is more desirable, or pleasant &c., to me, or in my estimation, than such a thing]. (Msb voce UilaI.) See also another ex. in a verse cited voce UilaI, in art. Alw.

muXotahFI c
muXotahFI: see XahiIRN. ― -b2- [Used as a subst., its pl. is muXotahayaAtN.]

1 XaMCaniI c
1. XaMCaniI, formed by transposition from XaMniI, aor. yaXuwoCu and yaXiIoCu, [but the latter form of the aor. is disallowed by MF,] He preceded me, or outwent me. (K.) ＝ -A2- And He grieved me. (K.) ― -b2- And He pleased me. (K.) Thus it bears two contr. significations. (TA.) And XuWotuhu, aor. OaXuwoWuhu, I pleased him. (Lth, O.) ― -b3- And XuWotu bihi I was pleased with, and rejoiced in, him, or it. (Lth, O, K.) [See also art. XOw.]

XaMCN c
XaMCN, n. un. XaApN: see art. Xwh.

XayRiMnN c
XayRiMnN, (K, TA, and L in art. tyH,) in form like the dual of sayRidN [except as to the final vowel], (TA,) [erroneously written in the CK XayoYAen,]
and XayRaMnN, like tayRiHaAnN and tayRaHaAnN [q. v.], (L in art. tyH,) [applied to a man,] Far-sighted; (K;) either in the proper sense, or metonymically applied to a man characterized by deliberation, and reflection, and looking to the results of affairs. (TA.) Each is also applied as an epithet to a horse. (L in art. tyH.) [The radical letters of this epithet are either XwO or XyO; therefore it is mentioned again in art. XyO; and another form thereof, without C, (XayRaAn,) is mentioned in art. XwI.]

1 XaAbahu c
1. XaAbahu, aor. yaXuwbuhu, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. XawobN (S, A, Msb, K) and XiyaAbN, (K,) He mixed it; (S, A, Msb, K;) such as milk with water; (Msb;) or honey with water. (A.) [And It mingled with it: for] one says also, kaOanRa riyqatahaA xamorN yaXuwbuhaA EasalN [As though her saliva were wine with which honey mingled]. (A.) ― -b2- [It is sometimes used in a good sense, but more frequently in a bad sense; and often means He adulterated, vitiated, or sophisticated, it.] It is said in a trad., yaXohadu bayoEakumu AlHalifu waAllRagowu faXuwbuwhu biAlSRadaqapi (assumed tropical:) [Swearing, and unprofitable speech, attend your selling; therefore mix ye it with alms]. (TA.) And it is said in a prov., huwa yaXuwbu wayaruwbu (assumed tropical:) He mixes, or confounds, or makes a confusion or disorder, in speech and in actions: (S, TA:) or he says right one time and wrong another time: (As, TA:) or he defends without energy: (TA:) or he is sometimes incited to motion, or action, and defends himself, but without energy, and sometimes he is motionless, and does not become excited to motion, or action; and it is not from [the words XawobN and rawobN applied to] milk: so says Aboo-Sa'eed [i. e. As]: and he says also that XaAba Eanohu waraAba means he defended him at one time, and was sluggish, or indolent, at another time: and that Enh XwRb↓, inf. n. taXowiybN, means he defended him without energy: and thus this latter is expl. in the K, as is likewise XAb Enh: also that the Arabs say, laqiytu fulaAnFA Alyawoma yaXuwbu Eano OaSoHaAbihi, meaning I found such a one to-day defending his companions in some measure. (TA.) [See also art. rwb.] ― -b3- XAb also signifies He acted treacherously, perfidiously, or unfaithfully: (Fr, TA:) he lied: he deceived in selling or buying: and he acted dishonestly, insincerely, or with dissimulation. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- [See also Har p. 448; where it is implied that it signifies also He spoke truth, or was veracious.]

2 XawRaba
2: see the preceding paragraph.

7 UinoXawaba
7: see what next follows.

8 UiXotawaba
8: AXtAb It was, or became, mixed; (O, K;) as also AnXAb↓. (K.)

XawobN c
XawobN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, A, &c.) ― -b2- [Hence,] laA Xawoba walaA rawoba, occurring in a trad., means There is, or shall be, no dishonesty, insincerity, or dissimulation, nor mixing, in the selling, or buying: so says IAar: or I am irresponsible with respect to this commodity: or, as he is related to have said, thou art irresponsible for its being faulty, or defective. (TA. [See also XawobapN.]) ― -b3- And XawobN (TA) and XiyaAbN↓, (S, TA,) [each an inf. n. used as a subst. properly so termed,] or XiyaAbapN↓, (so in one copy of the S,) signify A mixture; an admixture; or a thing mixed with another thing. (S, TA.) Thus XawobFA signifies in the Kur xxxvii. 65: (TA:) or, accord. to one reading, the word there is XuwbFA↓, meaning a thing with which another thing is mixed. (Bd.) AlXRawobu also signifies [particularly] What is mixed [with something else], of water or of milk: (K:) one says, saqaAhu AlcRawoba biAlXRawobi He gave him to drink honey with water, or milk, mixed [therewith]: (TA:) or saqaAhu AlXRawoba biAlcRawobi He gave him to drink milk [mixed] with honey. (IDrd, TA.) And Mixed honey; as in the saying, maA EinodiI XawobN walaA rawobN I have not mixed honey nor milk such as is termed raAYib [q. v.]: (IAar, TA:) or [simply] honey &c.; (A, Msb, TA;) so called because they mix it with beverages; (Msb;) as in the saying, saqaAhu AlXRawoba biAlrRawobi He gave him to drink honey with clarified butter, or with milk. (A.) And Broth; as in the saying, maA Einodahu XawobN walaA rawobN He has not broth nor milk. (S, K: but in the latter, maA lahu.) And XawobN signifies also A piece of dough. (K.) ― -b4- And [the pl.] OaXowaAbN signifies (assumed tropical:) A medley, or mixed multitude, of sundry sorts: a less particular term than OawobaAXN, which signifies a medley, or mixed multitude, of the low, or lower, or lowest, sort: (TA, from a trad.:) accord. to El-Jawáleekee, it is an arabicized word, from the Pers. MXuwbN. (TA in art. wXb.)

XuwbN c
XuwbN: see XuwbFA in the next preceding paragraph.

XawobapN c
XawobapN Deceit, delusion, guile, or circumvention: (K: [see also XawobN:]) [or, app., somewhat thereof:] one says, fiI fulaAnK XawobapN [In such a one is deceit, &c.]. (TA.)

XayobaMCu c
XayobaMCu A virgin in the night of her devirgination: (Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed, MF:) [either from XaAba having for its aor. yaXuwbu, signifying “ he mixed, ” or from XaAba having for its aor. yaXiybu, signifying “ he became white-headed, or hoary; ” as shown by what follows:] one says, baAtato bilayolapi XayobaMCa, (S and A in art. Xyb, and K in the present art.,) and bilayolapi AlXRayobaMCi, (K,) She passed the night of a virgin then devirginated, (S, A, K,) and of the virgin then devirginated: (K, TA:) said of a virgin-bride when she is devirginated by the bridegroom in the night in which she has been first brought to him: (A, K, TA:) in the contr. case, when she is not devirginated, one says, baAtato bilayolapi HurRapK: (S, TA:) and one says also, bilayolapK XayobaMCa and bilayolapK HurRapK: (TA in art. Hr:) Z, in the A, mentions the first phrase in art. Xyb, and makes it to be tropical, as though the bride were in that night afflicted by an event so severe as to cause the locks of her hair to become white: in the L it is said that the I in XybAC is substituted for w, because of [the allusion of the phrase to] the mixing of the sperma genitale of the man with that of the woman; but that eXawobaMC has not been heard instead of XybAC: ISd, in the M, mentions it in arts. Xwb and Xyb; observing that the I is said to take the place of w: J, as well as Z and others, mentions it in art. Xyb [q. v.]. (TA.)

XiyaAbN c
XiyaAbN and XiyaAbapN: see XawobN.

XaAYibapN c
XaAYibapN sing. of XawaAYibu meaning The whiteness [mixing] with the darkness of night. (Har p. 58.) ― -b2- The saying layosa fiyhi XaAYibapu mulokK may be from XaAbahu “ he mixed it; ” meaning There is not in it anything [of ownership, or right of possession,] mixed therewith, though small, or however small; like as one says, layosa fiyhi EuloqapN walaA XubohapN; it being an instance of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN, as in EiyXapN raADiyapN: thus the lawyers use it. (Msb.) ― -b3- XaAYibapN is also sing. of XawaAYibu meaning Uncleannesses, filths, or pollutions; or unclean, filthy, or foul, things. (S, Msb, K. *)

maXuwbN c
maXuwbN (S, Msb) and maXiybN, the latter from Xiyb [“ it was mixed ”], Mixed. (S, Msb.) A poet says, (namely, Suleyk Ibn-Es-Sulakeh EsSaadee, TA,)
wamaMCu quduwrK fiI AlqiSaAEi maXiybu
i. e. [And the water of cooking-pots, in the wooden bowls,] mixed with seeds for seasoning and with sauces. (S.) ― -b2- AlfatoHapu AlmaXuwbapu biAlkasorapi means [The fet-hah that is mingled with kesreh; which is] the fethah that precedes the A of UimaAlap; as in EaAbidN and EaArifN [when they are pronounced “ 'ébidun ” and “ 'érifun ”]; for AmAlp consists in inclining [the sound of] fet-hah towards [that of] kesreh; whereby [the sound of] the A that follows it is inclined, and is not a pure A; for like as [the sound of] the fet-hah is mingled [with that of kesreh], so is [the sound of] the A [mingled with that of I]. (L, TA.)

muXaAwabN c
muXaAwabN, with damm [to the m], and fet-h to the w, [not with both of these vowels to the w as supposed by Freytag,] The case (gilaAf) of a flash or bottle; (K;) because it is mixed with redness and yellowness and greenness; mentioned by AHát on the authority of As: (TA:) pl. maXaAwibu: (AHát, K:) or the pl. signifies [receptacles of the sorts called] OasofaAT [pl. of safaTN] and Huqaq [pl. of HuqRapN] made of palm-leaves. (A.)

5 tXwRc c
5. tXwRc and AXtAc↓ (assumed tropical:) He turbaned himself; attired himself with a turban. (AZ, T, S, L, K.) [See above.]

8 UiXotawaca
8: see what next precedes.

fulaAnN Hasanu AlXRiycapi c
fulaAnN Hasanu AlXRiycapi (assumed tropical:) Such a one is goodly in his manner of turbaning. (K.)

xayoru AlOaXaAwici c
xayoru AlOaXaAwici (assumed tropical:) The best of the creation, or of mankind, or people; syn. xayoru Alxaloqi. (K.)

miXowacN c
miXowacN (assumed tropical:) A turban; (IAar, S, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) as also miXowaAcN↓: (K:) pl. of the former maXaAwicu; (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) and of the latter maXaAwiycu. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A king: (K:) a crowned king. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A lord, or chief, (K,) to whom obedience is paid. (TA.)

miXowaAcN c
miXowaAcN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 XaAra c
1. XaAra, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaXuwru, (Msb,) inf. n. XaworN (Msb, K) and XiyaArN and XiyaArapN and maXaArN and maXaArapN; (K;) and AXtAr↓, and AXAr↓, (S, K,) and AstXAr↓; (A, K;) He gathered honey; (S, Msb;) extracted it from the small hollow [in the rock in which it had been deposited by the wild bees]; (A, K;) gathered it from its hives and from other places. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XAr, inf. n. XaworN, He exhibited, showed, or displayed, a thing. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- XAr AldRaAbRapa, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. XaworN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and XiwaArN, (K, TA,) or XawaArN; (CK;) and XwRrhA↓, (A, K,) inf. n. taXowiyrN; (TA;) and AXArhA↓, (Th, K,) but this last is rare; (Th, TA;) He exhibited, or displayed, the beast, for sale, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) going to and fro with it, (S, Mgh,) or making it to run, and the like: (Msb:) he tried the beast, to know its pace, or manner of going: (A, Mgh:) he made the beast to run, that he might know its power: (TA:) he broke, or trained, the beast: or he rode it on the occasion of exhibiting, or displaying, it to its purchaser: or tried it, to see its powers: or he examined it, as though he turned it over; and in like manner, AlOamapa the female slave. (K, TA.) [Hence] XAr nafosahu He displayed his agility, to show his power. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- And Xurotuhu I ornamented, or decorated, it. (TA.) ＝ -A3- XAr He (a man) became goodly in countenance. (Fr, TA.) ― -b2- He (a horse) became fat and goodly: (S:) and so XArt said of a she-camel: (TA:) [and tXwRrt↓ said of a woman: (Freytag, from the Deewán of the Hudhalees:)] or XArt said of a she-camel, she became fat; (K;) and in like manner AXtAr↓ and AstXAr↓ said of a he-camel: (S:) and AXtArt↓ AlUibilu the camels became somewhat fat: (S:) and AstXArt↓ they became fat and goodly: (K:) or this last signifies (tropical:) they became fat; because their owner points to such with his fingers; as though they desired to be pointed to. (A.)

2 XwRr AldRaAbRapa c
2. XwRr AldRaAbRapa, inf. n. taXowiyrN: see 1. ― -b2- XwRr bihi He did to him a deed of which one should be ashamed: (Yaakoob, Th, A, K:) or he made bare his pudenda: (O:) or as though he made bare his pudenda. (S.) ― -b3- And XwRrhu, (Lh, S,) and XwRr bihi, (Lh, TA,) He made him to be confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of shame; or ashamed, and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, in consequence of a deed that he had done. (Lh, S.) ― -b4- XwRr AlquTona He turned over [or separated and loosened] the cotton by means of the miXowaAr [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 4, in two places.

3 XAwrhu c
3. XAwrhu, (inf. n. muXaAwarapN and XiwaArN, TA,) and AstXArh↓, both signify the same, (S, Msb,) He consulted him, or consulted with him; he debated with him in order that he might see his opinion; (Msb;) fiI AlOamori respecting the thing or affair: (S, Mgh, * Msb: *) or ↓the latter, (A, K,) or both, (TA,) he sought, desired, or asked, of him counsel, or advice. (A, K.) See also 6.

4 OaXowara
4: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- OaXironiI EasalFA, (K,) or EalaI AlEasali, (Sh, Sgh, L,) Help thou me to collect honey, or the honey. (Sh, Sgh, L, K.) ＝ -A2- AXAr AldRaAbRapa: see 1. ― -b2- AXAr AlnRaAra, and AXAr bihaA, (K,) and OaXowarahaA, or OaXowara bihaA, (accord. to different copies of the K, the former accord. to the text of the K in the TA,) and bihaA XwRr↓, (K, TA,) He stirred up the fire, or made it to burn up; syn. rafaEahaA. (K.) ＝ -A3- AXAr Uilayohi, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiXaArapN, (Msb,) He made a sign to him, with the hand, (S, Msb, K,) or with the head, (Msb,) or with the eye, or with the eyebrow, (K,) or with a thing serving to convey intelligence of what he would say; as when one asks another's permission to do a thing, and the latter makes a sign with his hand or with his head, meaning that he should do it or not do it; (Msb;) as also Alyh XwRr↓, (ISk, S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taXowiyrN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And He, or it, pointed to it or at it, pointed it out, or indicated it. Hence, in grammar, Aisomu UiXaArapK A noun of indication; as caA &c. And] AXAr UilaI AlHarakapi biSawotK xafiIRK [He indicated the vowel by a somewhat obscure sound;] meaning he pronounced the vowel in the manner termed AlrRawomu. (I'Ak p. 351.) And AXAr UilaI AlUiEoraAbi fiI Alwaqofi [He indicated the caseending by the pronunciation termed AlrRawomu in pausing; as when you say OaIRu with a slurring of the final vowel-sound to one who says to you marRa biI rajulN]. (S voce OaIRN.) ― -b3- AXAr bihi He made it known. (Har p. 357.) ― -b4- AXAr Ealayohi He made known, or notified, to him the manner of accomplishing the affair that was conducive to good, and guided him to that which was right. (Har ibid.) ― -b5- AXAr Ealayohi bikacaA [in the CK Alyh] He counselled him, or advised him, to do such a thing; (S, * Msb;) showed him that he held it right for him to do such a thing: (Msb:) or he commanded, ordered, or enjoined, him to do such a thing. (K.)

5 tXwRr c
5. tXwRr He had a deed done to him of which one should be ashamed. (Yaakoob, Th, A, K.) [It occurs in a saying of Yaakoob, respecting an indecent action of an Arab of the desert, app. as meaning His pudenda became exposed; (see 2;) but some disapprove it, and say that it is not genuine Arabic; as is stated in the TA.] ― -b2- He was, or became, confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, by reason of shame; or ashamed, and confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course, in consequence of a deed that he had done. (Lh, S.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence.

6 tXAwrwA c
6. tXAwrwA and AiXotawaruwA↓ (A, Mgh, Msb) They consulted one another, or consulted together; they debated together in order that they might see one another's opinion: (Msb:) taXaAwurN signifies the extracting, or drawing forth, opinion; as also muXaAwarapN↓ and maXowarapN↓ and maXuwrapN↓, from XaAra “ he extracted honey; ” (Bd in ii. 233;) and XuwraI↓ signifies the same as taXaAwurN. (Bd in xlii. 36, and Mgh.) ＝ -A2- taXaAyarahu AlnRaAsu occurs in a trad. as meaning AiXotaharuwhu biUiboSaArihimo [app. The people rendered him conspicuous, or notorious, by their looking at him]. (TA. [There mentioned in the present art.; as though the I were a substitute for w.])

8 AXtAr c
8. AXtAr: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- And see 10. ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence, in two places. ＝ -A3- AXtAr canabahu i. q. AikotaAra [He (a horse) raised his tail in running]. (Sgh, TA.) ＝ -A4- AiXotawaruwA: see 6.

10 AstXAr c
10. AstXAr: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- See also 3, in two places. ― -b3- AstXAr AlnRaAqapa He (a stallioncamel) smelt the she-camel and examined her, to know if she had conceived or not; (K;) as also AXtArhA↓. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ＝ -A2- It (a man's case or affair) became manifest. (AZ, K.) ― -b2- He put on, or clad himself with, goodly apparel. (K.) ― -b3- See also 1, last sentence, in two places.

XaArN c
XaArN: see XayRirN, in two places.

XaworN c
XaworN Honey gathered, or extracted, from its place: (K, TA:) originally an inf. n. (TA.) ― -b2- See also XuwrapN, with which it is syn. in several senses accord. to the O and some copies of the K.

XuwrN c
XuwrN: see XuwrapN, with which it is syn. in several senses accord. to the L and some copies of the K.

XaArapN c
XaArapN: see XuwrapN, in three places.

XaworapN c
XaworapN: see XuwrapN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see miXowaArapN. ＝ -A3- Also i. q. xajolapN [i. e. Confusion, or perplexity, and inability to see one's right course, by reason of shame: &c.]. (K.)

XuwrapN c
XuwrapN, (S, IAth, O, L, K,) with damm, (IAth, L,) and XaworapN↓, (TA, and so in some copies of the K,) and XaArapN↓, (S, O, L, K,) in which the | is changed from w, (TA,) and XuwrN↓, (so in the L and in some copies of the K,) or XaworN↓, (so in other copies of the K and in the O,) and XawaArN↓, (S, O, K,) and XiyaArN↓, (O, K,) Form, or appearance; figure, person, mien, feature, or lineament; external state or condition; state with respect to apparel and the like, or garb. (S, IAth, O, L, K.) One says, fulaAnN Hasanu AlXRaArapi↓ and AlXRuwrapi Such a one is goodly in form or appearance, &c. (TA.) And huwa rajulN Hasanu AlSRuwrapi waAlXRuwrapi He is a man goodly in respect of form and of appear-
ance, &c. (Fr. S. [See also below.]) ― -b2- Goodliness, or beauty: (IAth, L, K:) so XuwrapN is expl. by IAar: (O:) and XaworapN↓, with fet-h, is expl. as signifying pleasing beauty: (TA:) app. from XaworN, the “ act of exhibiting, or showing, ” a thing. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- Clothing, or apparel: (S, O, L, K:) XaworapN↓, with fet-h, is said to have this signification by Th: and XaArapN↓ is also expl. as signifying goodly, or beautiful, apparel. (TA.) ― -b4- Ornament, ornature, or finery. (K.) ― -b5- Fatness. (K.) ― -b6- And XuwrapN, with damm, and miXowaArN↓, Aspect, or pleasing aspect; syn. manoZarN: and Internal, or intrinsic, state or quality; syn. maxobarN. (K, * TA.) One says, layosa lifulaAnK miXowaArN↓ i. e. manoZarN [Such a one has not a pleasing aspect]. (TA.) And fulaAnN Hasanu AlSRuwrapi waAlXRuwrapi Such a one is good in respect of form, and of internal state or qualities, when tried. (TA.) And fulaAnN Hasanu AlmiXowaAri↓ Such a one is good when one tries him. (As, TA.) ＝ -A2- For the first word (XuwrapN), see also miXowaArapN. ＝ -A3- And see musotaXiyrN.

XaworaI c
XaworaI A certain marine plant; (K;) a sort of trees, of the trees of the shores of the sea: (Sgh, TA:) [it is, as supposed by Freytag, the plant called by Forskål (Flora Aegypt. Arab, p. 37,) sceura marina; of the class tetrandria, order monogynia; foliis lanceolatis, integris; floribus fulvis: &c.: said by him to be called in Arabic “ schura ” Xwrh; and by the people of Maskat, “ germ ” qrm:] a sort of trees growing in inlets of the sea, in the midst of the water of the sea, resembling the dulob in the thickness of its stem and the whiteness of its bark, and also called quromN. (O.)

XuwraI c
XuwraI: see maXowarapN, in four places; and 6.

XaworaAn c
XaworaAn [whether with or without tenween is not shown] i. q. EuSofurN [i. e. Safflower, or bastard saffron]. (K.)

XawaArN c
XawaArN: see XuwrapN. ＝ -A2- Also, (ISk, S, Msb, K,) and XiwaArN↓, and XuwaArN↓, (Msb, K,) The furniture and utensils of a house or tent; (ISk, S, Msb, K;) such as are deemed goodly: (Ham p. 305, in explanation of the first:) and of a camel's saddle. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And the first, (S, Msb, K,) and ↓second, (Msb, K,) and ↓third, (K,) The pudendum, or pundenda, (faroj, S, Msb,) of a woman and of a man: (S:) or a man's penis, [see also miXowaArN,] and his testicles, and his posteriors or anus (Aisot). (K.) OabodaI QllRehu XawaArahu is a form of imprecation, (TA,) meaning May God make bare his pudenda. (S, A, TA.) ＝ -A3- riyHN XawaArN A soft, or gentle, wind: (Sgh, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Sgh, TA.)

XuwaArN c
XuwaArN: see XawaArN; each in two places.

XiwaArN c
XiwaArN: see XawaArN; each in two places.

XiyaArN c
XiyaArN: see XuwrapN. ＝ -A2- Also a name given by the Arabs to Saturday, (S in this art., and K in art. Xyr,) in the Time of Ignorance: (TA in art. Xyr:) pl. [of pauc.] OaXoyurN and [of mult.] XuyurN and XiyrN: (Zj, K:) accord. to Zj, you may say valaAvapu XiyrK [Three Saturdays, using Xiyr as a pl. of pauc.]: so in the Tekmileh. (TA.)

XayRirN c
XayRirN One's consulter, or counseller with whom he consults: and one's waziyr [q. v.]: (K:) one qualified for consultation: (S, TA:) pl. XuwaraMCu. (K.) One says, fulaAnN xayRirN XayRirN Such a one is [good,] qualified for consultation. (S, TA.) ― -b2- A man goodly in respect of XaArap [i. e. appearance, or apparel, &c.]: (Fr, S, A:) or beautiful, or good: in this or in the former sense, the fem., with p, is applied to a woman. (TA.) One says, UinRahu laSayRirN XayRirN Verily he is goodly in form and in appearance or apparel &c. (Fr, S, A.) ― -b3- A man goodly in his internal, or intrinsic, states or qualities, when tried; as also XaArN↓: one says rajulN XayRirN SayRirN and SaArN XaArN↓ A man goodly in his internal, or intrinsic, states or qualities, and equally so in his outward appearance. (TA.) ― -b4- Fat: (TA:) or fat and goodly: (S, K, TA:) pl. XiyaArN, applied to horses, (S, K,) and to camels. (S.) ― -b5- qaSiydapN XayRirapN A beautiful ode; (K;) an excellent ode. (TA.)

OaXowaru c
OaXowaru [More, and most, distinguished by Xuwrap or XaArap, i. e., form, or appearance; &c.]. OaXowaru EaruwsK turaI [The comeliest bride that was to be seen] is a phrase occurring in a trad. relating to Ez-Zebbà [a queen of El-Heereh, celebrated for her beauty]. (A, TA.)

maXaArN c
maXaArN A xaliyRap [or habitation of bees, generally a hollow in a rock,] (S, K,) from which one gathers, or extracts, honey; (S;) a bee-hive; as also muXotaArN↓. (KL.) See the next paragraph. [And see also miXowaArapN.]

maAciIRN muXaArN c
maAciIRN muXaArN White honey (TA) gathered, (S, TA,) or which one has been assisted to gather. (K, TA.) AA cites the following verse, (S,) of El-Kutámee, (accord. to a copy of the S,) or of 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd, (O, TA.)
wasamaAEK yaOocanu AlXRayoxu lahu
waHadiyvK mivoli maAciIRK muXaArN
[And a singing, or a musical performance, (or, instead of And, the meaning may be Many,) to which the old man would lend ear, and a discourse like gathered white honey]: but As disapproves of this, and says that the right reading is maAciIRi maXaArN↓ [white honey of a habitation of bees from which it has been extracted], the former of these words being prefixed to the latter, governing it in the gen. case, and the latter being with fet-h to the m. (S, TA.)

maXuwrN c
maXuwrN A thing ornamented, or decorated. (K.)

miXowarN c
miXowarN, (S,) or miXowaArN↓, (K,) or both, (TA,) The wooden implement with which honey is gathered: (S, K, * TA:) pl. of the former maXaAwiru. (S.)

maXaArapN c
maXaArapN: see miXowaArN. ＝ -A2- Also A rivulet, or streamlet, for irrigation; syn. saAqiyapN: (TA voce rakiybN:) or a channel of water: (TA voce dabor:) or a daborap [i. e. either a small channel of water for irrigation or a portion of ground] in land sown or for sowing: (S, K:) or a daborap [app. here meaning a portion of ground] cut off, or separated, from the adjacent parts, (muqoTaEapN,) for sowing and for planting: it may be of this art., or from AlmaXorapu: (ISd, TA:) or what is surrounded by dams [or by ridges of earth] which confine, or retain, the water [for irrigation]; as also daborapN and HibosN: (R, TA:) pl. maXaAwiru and maXaAYiru. (K.)

maXuwrapN c
maXuwrapN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

maXowarapN c
maXowarapN and maXuwrapN↓ and XuwraI↓ signify the same: (S:) the first and second are substs. from XaAwarahu, and the third is a subst. from taXaAwaruwA: (Msb:) or the first (Lth) and second [which is written in the CK maXowarapN] (Lth, K) and third (K) are from AlUiXaArapu (Lth) or OaXaAra Ealayohi: (K:) [they signify Consultation; or mutual debate in order that one may see another's opinion; or counsel, or advice: or a command, an order, or an injunction: or] the extracting, or drawing forth, opinion: (Bd, as mentioned above: see 6:) maXuwrapN↓ [in the CK maXowarapN] is of the measure mafoEulapN, [originally maXowurapN, in the CK mafoEalapN,] not mafoEuwlapN, (K, TA,) because it is an inf. n., [or rather a quasi-inf. n.,] and such a noun has not this last measure: (TA:) it is like maEuwnapN; (Msb;) and is a contraction of maXowurapN: (Fr, TA:) and it is said also to be from XaAra AldRaAbRapa; or, accord. to some, from XaAra AlEasala; good counsel or advice being likened to honey. (Msb.) One says, Ealayoka biQlomaXowarapi fiI Oumuwrika and biQlomaXuwrapi↓ [Keep thou to consultation, or take counsel, in thine affairs]. (A.) And fulaAnN jayRidu AlmaXuwrapi↓ and AlmaXowarapi [Such a one is good, or excellent, in consultation, or counsel]. (TA.) And Oamoruhumo XuwraI↓ bayonahumo, like Amrhm fawoDaI bynhm, [Their affair, or case, is a thing to be determined by consultation among themselves,] i. e., none of them is to appropriate a thing to himself exclusively of others. (Msb.) It is said of 'Omar, taraka AlxilaAfapa XuwraI↓ (A, Mgh) He left the office of Khaleefeh as a thing to be determined by consultation: for he assigned it to one of six; not particularizing for it any one of them; namely, 'Othmán and 'Alee and Talhah and Ez-Zubeyr and 'Abd-Er-Rahmán Ibn-'Owf and Saad Ibn-Abee-Wakkás. (Mgh.) And one says also, AlnRaAsu fiyhi XuwraI↓ [The people are to determine by consultation respecting it]. (A.)

AlmuXiyrapu c
AlmuXiyrapu The forefinger, or pointing finger. (A, K.)

vawobN muXawRarN c
vawobN muXawRarN A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with XaworaAn, meaning EuSofur [i. e. safflower]. (K, TA.)

miXwaArN c
miXwaArN: see miXowarN. ― -b2- Also The string of the minodaf [q. v.]: (K, TA:) because the cotton is turned over [or separated and loosened] (yuXawRaru i. e. yuqalRabu) by means of it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A place in which beasts are exhibited, or displayed,
(S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) for sale, and in which they run. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence the saying, UiyRaAka waAlxuTaba faUinRahaA miXowaArN kaviyru AlEivaAri (tropical:) [Avoid thou orations, for they are means of display in which one often stumbles]. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- And The pace, or manner of going, of a horse: one says farasN Hasanu AlmiXowaAri [A horse good in respect of pace, or manner of going]. (A.) ＝ -A3- See also XuwrapN, latter part, in three places. ― -b2- One says of camels, (K,) or of a beast, (daAbRap, TA,) Oaxacato miXowaArahaA and maXaAratahaA↓ They, or it, became fat and goodly (K, TA) in appearance. (TA.) ＝ -A4- [It occurs in the O and K, in art. xwq, as signifying The penis of a horse: perhaps a mistranscription for XiwaAr, q. v.: I find it expl. in this sense in Johnson's Pers., Arab., and Engl. Dict.; but he may have taken it from the K.] ＝ -A5- [It is said to signify] also A portion that a beast has left remaining of its fodder: (O, K, TA:) but Kh says, “ I asked ADk, Is it niXowaArN or miXowaArN? and he said niXowaArN, and asserted it to be Pers.: ” (O, TA:) it is an arabicized word, (K,) originally niXoxuwaAr: (O, K: or, as in the CK, nuXoxwAr: [correctly niXoxowaAro or nuXoxowaAro:]) one says, naXowarati AldRaAbRapu niXowaArFA. (TA.)

miXowaArapN c
miXowaArapN A place in which bees deposit their honey; as also XuwrapN↓; (K;) or, as written by Sgh, the latter word is [XaworapN↓,] with fet-h. (TA.) [See also maXaArN.]

muXotaArN c
muXotaArN A gatherer of honey. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also maXaArN.

musotaXiyrN c
musotaXiyrN Fat; (AA, S;) as also XuwrapN↓, with damm, applied to a she-camel: (K:) or the latter signifies of generous race; or excellent. (TA.) [See also XayRirN.] ― -b2- And A stallion-camel (ElUmawee, T, S) that knows the female which has not conceived, and distinguishes her from others. (El-Umawee, T, S, K.)

1 Xawisa c
1. Xawisa, (K,) aor. yaXowasu, (TA,) inf. n. XawaXN; (S, A, K, TA;) and XaAsa, aor. yaXaAsu, (Lth, K, TA,) or yaXuwsu; (Ham p. 68;) He looked from the outer angle of his eye, by reason of pride, or of anger, or rage: (S, A, K:) or, as in the M, he looked with one of his eyes, inclining his face towards the side of that eye; doing so naturally, or by reason of pride and self-conceit and anger: or he raised his head in pride: (TA:) or he made the eye small, contracting the lids, to look: and tXAws↓ has the first of the meanings above mentioned; (A, K;) or the last: (A:) or one says, tXAws fiI naZarihi, meaning he looked with the look of the haughty, or proud: (TA:) or tXAws Uilayohi he looked at him from the outer angle of his eye, inclining his face towards the side of the eye with which he looked: (AA, S, TA: [see also 3:]) or tXAws signifies he looked towards the sky with one of his eyes: or it means he showed, or manifested, pride and self-conceit, and haughtiness; agreeably with the general analogy of verbs of this measure: and XawasN is in the natural disposition. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He was such as is termed OaXowas meaning bold, or daring, to engage in fight, and strong. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XawosN [inf. n. of XaAsa] in relation to the siwaAk [or toothstick] is a dial. var. of XawoSN: (IAar, K, TA:) one says, XaAsa faAhu biAlsRiwaAki, like XaASahu [q. v.]. (Fr, TA.)

3 XaAwasahu c
3. XaAwasahu [He looked at him in the manner of him who is termed OaXowas; like tXAws Uilayohi: see muXaAwisN].

6 taXaAowasa
6: see the first paragraph.

OaXowasu c
OaXowasu, applied to a man, (S, A,) Who looks in the manner expl. above, in the first sentence of this art.: (S, A, K:) or in whose look is known anger; or rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; and pride: (TA:) or raising his head by reason of pride: (AA, TA:) fem. XawosaMCu: (A, TA:) and pl. XuwsN. (S, A, K.) [Hence the saying,] buliIa fulaAnN biXuwsi AlxuTuwbi (tropical:) [Such a one was tried with terrifying, or severe, calamities or afflictions]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also Bold, or daring, to engage in fight, and strong. (TA. [See also XuwXN: and see OaXorasu.])

muXaAwisN c
muXaAwisN (tropical:) Water hardly to be seen, by reason of its paucity, and the depth to which it has sunk; (A, * K;) as though it looked at him who came to it in the manner of him who is termed OaXowas (kaOanRahu yuXaAwisu AlwaArida). (A, TA.)

2 XwRX Ealayohi AlOamora c
2. XwRX Ealayohi AlOamora, inf. n. taXowiyXN, He rendered the affair, or state, or case, confused, disordered, or perplexed, to him: (El-Fárábee, S, * Msb: the inf. n., and that only, mentioned in the S in art. XyX:) or, accord. to certain of those skilled in the abstrusities and niceties of science, XwRX is a post-classical word, and the chaste word is hawRaXa: accord. to IAmb, the leading lexicologists hold that one should only say hwRX; and Az and others say the same: (Msb:) [F also says,] taXowiyXN is a mistake for tahowiyXN. (K.) See also XawaAXK.

5 tXwRX Ealayohi AlOamoru c
5. tXwRX Ealayohi AlOamoru The affair, or state, or case, became confused, or perplexed, to him: (ElFárábee, S, Msb: mentioned in the S in art. XyX:) or this is post-classical: (Msb:) or taXawRuXN is a mistake for tahawRuXN. (K.)

6 tXAwX Alqawomu c
6. tXAwX Alqawomu The people, or company of men, became mixed, or confounded, together; syn. tahaAwaXa. (Sgh, K. *)

XawXN c
XawXN in the phrase OaboTaAlN XuwXN i. q. XuwsN [pl. of OaXowasu, q. v.]. (O, K.)

XawoXaMCu c
XawoXaMCu and XawoXaApN, (Lth, O, K,) or the former is a mistake, (TA,) the latter said by Az to be that which he heard from the Arabs, (O, TA,) applied to a she-camel, Light, or agile: (Lth, O, K:) or, so applied, swift: (A'Obeyd, O:) and applied to a woman as an epithet of discommendation. (O.) A poet, cited by AA, applies the epithet XawaAXiY↓, with hemz, by poetic license, to a naADiH [properly meaning a camel upon which water is drawn from a well]; originally from XawoXaMCu, (O,) or XawoXaApN, (TA,) meaning “ Light, ” or “ agile, ” applied to a she-camel: so says AA. (O, TA.)

bayonahumo XawaAXK c
bayonahumo XawaAXK, (O, and so in the TA as from the K,) or XawaAXN, (so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K,) Between them is disagreement, dissension, discord, or difference: (O, K:) the vulgar say taXowiyXN↓. (O, TA.)

XawaAXiY c
XawaAXiY: see XawoXaMCu.

maXuwXN c
maXuwXN, (so accord. to my copy of the KL,) or miXowaXN, (so accord. to Golius from the KL,) A small turban (dasotaAroJaho). (KL. [Comp. miXowacN.])

muXaAwiXN c
muXaAwiXN Water not to be seen, (K,) or hardly to be seen, (TA,) by reason of its remoteness [from the surface of the ground] or its paucity: (K:) a dial. var. of muXaAwisN [q. v.]. (TA.)

1 XaASa c
1. XaASa, aor. yaXuwSu (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and yaXaASu, in all its senses, (O, K,) inf. n. XawoSN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He set up a thing with his hand: (Msb, K:) or he put it into a state of commotion: (Msb:) or it signifies also he moved it violently from its place. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- He rubbed a thing with his hand. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- He washed (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh, Msb, K) a thing, (Msb,) or anything: (A'Obeyd:) he cleansed (AO, S, K) a thing: (AO:) as, for instance, his mouth, with the siwaAk [or toot-stick]: (S:) he rubbed and cleansed the teeth and the side of the mouth. (IAar.) You say XaASa faAhu He cleansed and washed his teeth, (Mgh,) biAlsRiwaAki [with the tooth-stick]. (Msb.) And XaASa OasonaAnahu, (A,) or faAhu, (TA,) [or app., XaASa alone, accord. to the K,] He cleansed his teeth with the siwaAk: (AA, K, TA:) or he did so by passing it across his teeth: (A, TA:) or from below upwards: (K, TA:) or by thrusting it into them, or between them: (TA:) and in like manner you say, faAhu AXAS↓, (TA,) inf. n. UiXaASapN; (Fr, K, TA;) and fAh XwRS↓, (TA,) inf. n. taXowiySN. (K, TA.) ― -b4- Also He chewed a siwaAk [app. to separate the fibres at the end and so make it like a brush, to prepare it for cleaning his teeth with it]. (K, * TA.)

2 XawRaSa
2: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

4 OaXowaSa
4: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

XawoSu AlsRiwaAki c
XawoSu AlsRiwaAki The washings (gusaAlap) of the toothstick: or what remains from the tooth-stick when one cleans his teeth with it: each of these meanings is assigned to it in explanations of a trad.: AisotagonuwA Eani AlnRaAsi walawo biXawoSi AlsRiwaAki [Be ye independent of other men, if it be only by means of possessing the washings, &c., of the tooth-stick: i. e., as long ye possess anything]. (TA.)

1 XaATa c
1. XaATa, aor. yaXuwTu, inf. n. XawoTN, He ran a heat,
or single run, or a run at once, to a goal, or limit. (TA.)

2 XwRT c
2. XwRT, inf. n. taXowiyTN, He (a man, IAar) made a long journey; his journey was, or became, long. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A2- XwRT Alfarasa: see 5. ― -b2- XwRT safiynatahu He voyaged with his ship. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also XwRT He made a cooking-pot to boil. (El-Kilábee.) ― -b2- He cooked thoroughly flesh-meat; (Ibn- 'Abbád, Sgh, K;) as also XyRT: (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh:) or both signify he smoked it, or made it smoky, and did not thoroughly cook it. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (hoar-frost, or rime,) burned (OaHoraqa, q. v.) a plant, or herbage: (K:) and in like manner one says of medicine which is sprinkled upon a wound. (TA.) See also 4 in art. XyT, in two places.

5 tXwRT Alfarasa c
5. tXwRT Alfarasa, [in the CK, XawRaTa↓, but as this, in the manner in which it is there mentioned, is a needless repetition, being implied, if correct, it is doubtless a mistranscription,] He continued to drive, or urge on, the horse, until he was tired, or fatigued. (K, * TA.)

XawoTN c
XawoTN A heat; a single run, or a run at once, to a goal, or limit; (Mgh, Msb, K;) syn. TalaqN: (S, Msb:) pl. OaXowaATN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, EadaA XawoTFA He ran a heat. (S.) And TaAfa baAlbayoti saboEapa OaXowaATK He performed seven circuits round the House [of God, i. e. the Kaabeh]: (S, TA:) from the [Black] Stone to the [Black] Stone [again] is one XawoT: (S, Msb, TA:) but some of the lawyers disapprove of this application of the term AXwAT.
