(IF, K, TA.) ― -b2- [It is also, app., an inf. n. used as an epithet: for one says, jaMCa XawoTN mina Alxayoli: see sananN, in the latter part of the paragraph.] It is sometimes used in relation to the wind: so says Lth: and he cites the following as an instance in which the wind is meant:
wanaAziHK muEotakiri AlOaXowaATi
[app. meaning And a wind, or many a wind, exhausting, or drying up, the waters, the blasts thereof bringing dust]. (TA.) ― -b3- And it is also [used as meaning A bout] of shooting arrows. (T and M in art. rXq.) ― -b4- Also The space of ground over which a horse runs; such as a mayodaAn, and the like; which is [said by some to be] the primary signification; [but the primary signification is said by others to be the first given above; (see Har p. 574;)] and so taXowiyTapN↓. (TA.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) A scope; an object to be reached, or accomplished; syn. gaAyapN: whence the saying, AlXRawoTu baTiynN (assumed tropical:) The scope is remote: (Har p. 574:) a prov., relating to the long extent of hope. (TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) A place between two elevated tracts of ground, through which water and men pass, as though it were a road, extending as far as the voice of a caller can be heard, then ending, (ISh, O, K,) of such depth that it will conceal the camel and his rider, found only in plain, or soft, ground, and producing good herbage: (ISh, O:) pl. XiyaATN; (ISh, O, K;) originally XiwaATN. (ISh, O.) Z writes it with s. (TA. See sawoTN.) ＝ -A2- XawoTu baraAHK i. q. Aibonu MwaI [The jackal]: (IDrd, S, Z, O, L, K:) or some other beast. (L.) ＝ -A3- XawoTu baATilK: see sawoTu baATilK, in art. swT: accord. to IDrd, it is not of established authority. (O.)

taXowiyTapN c
taXowiyTapN: see XawoTN. ― -b2- It is also, metonymically, applied to (tropical:) The plague, or pestilence; and other destructive diseases. (TA.)

XuwaAZN c
XuwaAZN and XiwaAZN, (S, K, &c., [but in one copy of the S, I find only the former, which is the more common,]) occurring in the Kur [lv. 35], where Ibn-Ketheer read XiwaAZN, (TA,) Flame (S, Bd, Jel, K) without smoke: (S, Jel, K:) or smoke of fire: and heat of fire: (ISh, K:) and heat of the sun: (K, TA:) or a piece of fire in which is no smoke: or flame of fire: or only of fire and something mixed therewith. (L.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (tropical:) Vehemence of thirst: (K, TA:) or simply, thirst. (A, TA.) You say, jamalN bihi XwAZN (tropical:) A thirsting camel. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) Clamour. (K, TA.)

1 Xufotuhu c
1. Xufotuhu, (S, O, K,) aor. OaXuwfuhu, (O,) inf. n. XawofN, (O, K,) I polished it; (S, O, K;) namely, a thing, (S, O,) or an ornament of gold or silver. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Xiyfati AljaAriyapu, (S, O, K,) also written Xuyofat, (thus in one of my copies of the S, in the other written XuYifat, and thus only,) aor. tuXaAfu, (S, O, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) The girl, or young woman, was adorned. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And [hence likewise,] XawofN also signifies The smearing of a camel with tar. (K.) One says, Xufo baEiyraka Smear thy camel with tar. (O.) ＝ -A2- [The inf. n.] XawafaAnN as syn. with taXawRufN [but in what sense is not said] is vulgar. (TA.) ― -b2- So too is [the inf. n.] XawofN as meaning The act of seeing [and of looking]. (TA.) [XAf is much used in the present day as meaning He saw, and he looked at, a thing.]

2 XwRf AljaAriyapa c
2. XwRf AljaAriyapa, inf. n. taXowiyfN, He adorned the girl, or young woman. (TA.) ＝ -A2- XyRf AldRawaMCa He made the medicament to be what is termed XiyaAf [q. v.]. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) [The I in this verb is substituted for w.]

4 AXAf Ealayohi c
4. AXAf Ealayohi i. q. OaXorafa [meaning He was, or became, on the brink, or verge, or at the point, of it], (S, O, K,) namely, a thing; like OaXofaI; (S, O;) from which it is formed by transposition. (S.) ― -b2- And AXAf He feared. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) You say, AXAf minohu He feared him, or it. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 5, last sentence.

5 tXwRf c
5. tXwRf He adorned himself: (K:) or tXwRft she (a woman, IDrd, O, or a girl, or young woman, S) adorned herself. (IDrd, S, O.) One says of a woman divorced by a sentence that admits of her returning, tutaXawRafu lizawojihaA i. e. She adorns herself for her husband, by making her face clear, and polishing her cheeks; from 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- tXwRft AlOawoEaAlu The mountain-goats ascended upon the tops of the mountains, (Lth, O, Msb,) and looked down, (Lth, O,) to see the plain country and its freedom from those whom they feared, in order that they might repair to the water and the pasturage. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, tXwRf likacaA He (a man) raised, or stretched and raised, his eyes, or sight, towards such a thing: and hence the verb became used to denote hope, or expectation, and desire, or seeking. (Msb.) And tXwRf mina AlsRaToHi He stretched himself up, and looked, and overlooked, or looked down, from the house-top. (K.) One says, AlnRisaMCu yataXawRafona mina AlsRuTowHi The women look, [or look down,] stretching themselves up, from the house-tops. (S, O.) [See also 8.] And one says also, tXwRf UilaI AlXIoCi, (S,) or AlI Alxayori, (O, K,) or AlI Alxabari, (CK,) He looked for [the thing, or good, or the news or tidings], (S, O, K,) &c. (TA.) ― -b3- And tXwRf AlXRaIoCu The thing rose, or became high or elevated; as also AXAf↓. (TA.)

8 AXtAf c
8. AXtAf He (a man, S, O) stretched himself up, and looked: (S, O, K:) and in like manner one says of horses. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- And AXtAf Albaroqa He looked at the lightning, or at the cloud thereof, to see whither it was tending, and where it would rain; syn. XaAmahu. (S, O, K.) ＝ -A2- Also, said of a wound, It became rough, or thick; (AZ, O, K;) and so AstXAf↓, thus without hemz. (TA.)

10 UisotaXowafa
10: see what next precedes.

XawofN c
XawofN The mijarR, (O, K,) i. e. a wooden implement, (O,) [meaning a harrow,] by means of which the ploughed land is made even. (O.)

XaAfapN c
XaAfapN: see XaOofapN, in art. XOf. (TA.)

XiyaAfN c
XiyaAfN Medicaments for the eye and the like: (O, K:) from 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above: originally XiwaAfN. (O.)

XawRaAfN c
XawRaAfN A sharp-sighted man. (TA.)

XayRifapN c
XayRifapN A scout, or scouts, (TaliyEapN,) employed to look out for a party; (IAar, S, O, K;) as also XayRifaAnN↓. (IAar, O, K.)

XayRifaAnN c
XayRifaAnN: see what next precedes.

maXuwfN c
maXuwfN Polished: applied to a diynaAr [&c.]. (S, O, K.) 'Antarah says,
walaqado Xaribotu mina AlmudaAmapi baEoda maA
rakada AlhawaAjiru baAlmaXuwfi AlmuEolami
[And verily I have drunk wine, after that the vehement noon-day-heats of summer had remitted, purchased with the polished, charactered deenár]: (S, O, and EM p. 237:) he means the deenár polished by the minter thereof: (TA:) or, as some say, he means the bright, charactered, or figured, bowl. (O, TA. *) ― -b2- Also A camel smeared with tar; (O, K;) because it polishes him. (TA.) ― -b3- And (K) accord. to AA (O, TA) and A'Obeyd, (TA,) as used by Lebeed, (O, TA,) A camel in a state of excitement by lust: (O, K: *) but as some relate the verse in which it occurs, the word is with s, and means “ smelt ”
by the [other] camels because smeared with tar. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And, (K,) as some say, (O, TA,) it means [A camel] decorated with wools of various colours, and with other things. (O, K. [In the CK, AlmuzayRinu is erroneously put for AlmuzayRanu.])

muXawRafapN c
muXawRafapN like muEaZRamapN [in measure], A woman who exposes herself to view in order that men may see her. (Aboo-'Alee, TA.)

1 XaAqaniI c
1. XaAqaniI, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaXuwquniI, (S, Msb,) inf. n. XawoqN; (Msb, TA;) and XawRaqaniI↓, (S, Msb, * K,) inf. n. taXowiyqN; (TA;) It (a thing, S and Msb in relation to the former verb, or the love of a female, K, and the mention of her, and her beauty, TA, or the latter verb is said of a man, Msb,) excited my desire, or the yearning or longing of my soul. (S, Msb, * K * TA.) [Hence,] one says, Xuqo Xuqo fulaAnFA, meaning Render thou desirous, render thou desirous, such a one (XawRiqohu↓) for the ultimate abode or ultimate state of existence in the world to come (UilaI AlMxirapi). (IAar, K, TA. [See also 2.]) ― -b2- And XAq AlTRunuba UilaI Alwatidi, (K,) aor. yaXuwquhu, inf. n. XawoqN, (TA,) (tropical:) He tied, and made fast, the tent-rope to the tent-peg; (K, TA;) as also XAqh having for its inf. n. XayoqN; (TA in art. Xyq;) like naATahu bihi, inf. n. nawoTN: mentioned also by Z. (TA.) ― -b3- And XAq Alqirobapa, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He set up the water-skin, leaning it against the wall: (K, TA:) mentioned by Ibn-Buzurj. (TA.)

2 XawRaqa
2: see above, in two places. A poet says, (O,) a man of the tribe of Kelb, (Ham pp. 145 et seq.,)
waHanRato naAqatiI TarabFA waXawoqFA
UilaI mano biAlHaniyni tuXawRiqiyniI
[And my she-camel uttered a yearning cry, by reason of lively emotion, and desire; whereupon I said, For whom, by the yearning cry, dost thou render me desirous?]: tuXawRiqiyniI being for tuXawRiqiynaniI. (O, and Ham p. 146, q. v.) Lth says that AltRaXowiyqu in relation to reading or recitation [of the Kur-án], and [sacred] narratives, is as when one says, XawRiqonaA yaA fulaAnu [lit. Do thou render us desirous, O such a one], meaning do thou mention [to us] Paradise and what is therein, by narratives, or reading or recitation; may-be we shall become desirous of it, and therefore work for it. (O, TA.)

4 AXAqhu c
4. AXAqhu signifies wajadahu XaAYiqFA [app. meaning, EaAXiqFA, i. e. He found him to be an excessive, or attached, or admiring, lover]. (IAar, * TA.) ― -b2- One says also, maA OaXowaqaniI Uilayoka [How great is my desire, or the yearning or longing of my soul, for thee!]. (TA.)

5 tXwRq c
5. tXwRq He was, or became, excited by desire, or yearning or longing of the soul; quasi-pass. of XawRaqahu (S, TA) and XaAqahu. (TA.) See also 8. ― -b2- And (TA) He showed, or made a show of, (O, K, TA,) and affected, (O,) or affecting, (K, TA,) desire, or a yearning or longing of the soul. (O, K, TA.)

8 AXtAq Uilayohi c
8. AXtAq Uilayohi, (MA, O, Msb, K,) and AXtAqhu, both signifying the same, (MA, O, K,) as also Uilyh tXwRq↓, i. e. He was, or became, desirous of it; or affected with desire for it; (MA;) [or he yearned or longed for it in his soul; for] AiXotiyaAqN is syn. with XawoqN, (q. v.) as expl. below. (S.)

XawoqN c
XawoqN Desire, or yearning or longing of the soul, (S, O, Msb, K,) UilaI XaIoCK for a thing; (S, Msb;) as also AiXotiyaAqN↓: (S:) [or] the motion of love: (IAar, O, K:) pl. OaXowaAqN. (K.) One says, barRaHa biI AlXRawoqu [Desire, &c., distressed me]: and balagato minRiI AlOaXowaAqu [meaning in like manner Desires, &c., distressed me]. (TA.) banaAtu AlXRawoqi means (assumed tropical:) The effects of AlXwq [or desire, &c.]. (Ham p. 539.) ＝ -A2- Also inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Msb, TA.)

XiyqN c
XiyqN: see what next follows.

XiyaAqN c
XiyaAqN (assumed tropical:) The thing with which a thing is extended in order to its being tied to a thing; (O, K;) like niyaATN; (S in art. Xyq, O, TA;) originally. XiwaAqN: and XiyqN↓, originally XiwoqN, signifies the same. (TA.)

XaAYiqN c
XaAYiqN Exciting one's desire, or the yearning or longing of the soul of a person. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also [a possessive epithet, meaning cuw XawoqK. And hence,] An excessive, or attached, or admiring, lover; syn. EaAXiqN; and so maXuwqN↓: (Har, p. 142:) or ↓the latter signifies one whose desire, or yearning or longing of the soul, is excited: (S, TA:) the former is sing. of XuwqN, (TA,) which is syn. with EuXRaAqN [pl. of EaAXqNi] (IAar, O, K, TA) as well as pl. of OaXowaqu. (K.)

XayRiqN c
XayRiqN i. q. muXotaAqN↓ [i. e. Desirous, or yearning or longing in the soul]: (O, Msb, K:) or i. q. maXuwqN [q. v. voce XaAYiqN, in two places]: (JK:) originally XayowiqN, of the measure fayoEilN. (O, TA.)

XawRaAqN c
XawRaAqN [Very desirous; or desiring, or yearning or longing, in the soul, much]. (JK and Msb voce tawRaAqN.)

OaXowaqu c
OaXowaqu Tall; (IDrd, O, K;) applied to a man; but not of established authority: (IDrd, O:) pl. XuwqN. (K.)

maXuwqN c
maXuwqN: see XaAYiqN, in two places. ― -b2- qirobapN maXuwqapN (tropical:) A water-skin set up, leaned against a wall. (Ibn-Buzurj, O, K, TA.)

muXotaAqN c
muXotaAqN: see XayRiqN. AlmuXotaOaq (so in the S,) or AlmuXotaYiq, because muXotaAqN is originally muXotawiqN, of the measure mufotaEilN, (O,) is used by poetic license for muXotaAq, (S, O,) as Sb says; (S;) for the poet, requiring to make the last letter but one movent, makes it so by the original vowel. (O.)

1 XaAkatoniI AlXRawokapu c
1. XaAkatoniI AlXRawokapu, (As, S, O, K, *) aor. taXuwkuniI, (As, S, O,) inf. n. XawokN, (TA,) The thorn entered into [or pierced me, or] my body or person. (As, S, O, K. *) And XAkt UiSobaEahu It (a thorn) entered into [or pierced] his finger. (TA.) And XaAkatoniI AlXRawokapu, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) The thorn hurt me, or wounded me; syn. OaSaAbatoniI. (K, TA.) And XaAkaniI AlXRawoku, aor. yaXuwkuniI, The thorns hurt, or wounded, (OaSaAba,) my skin. (Msb.) [Hence,] laA yaXuwkuka minRiI XawokapN↓ (tropical:) No harm, or hurt, shall ensue to thee from me. (TA.) ― -b2- Xukotuhu, aor. OaXuwkuhu, [I pierced him with a thorn;] I made a thorn to enter into his body or person; (S, O, K;) as also OaXakotuhu↓, (K,) inf. n. UiXaAkapN: (TA:) the former verb from Ks; (T, S, O;) as though he made it to be doubly trans. [meaning that XawokapF is to be understood]. (Az, TA.) And XawokapF maA OaXaAkahu↓ [and maA XaAkahu biXawokapK as is meant by its being added] walaA XaAkahu bihaA He did not hurt him with a thorn; (K, * TA;) as expl. by IF: (TA:) and OaXakotuhu↓ I hurt him with thorns: (TA:) or biAlXRawoki XawRakotuhu↓ and bihi OaXakotuhu↓ I hurt him, or wounded him, with thorns, or the thorns. (Msb.) ― -b3- Accord. to IAar, (TA,) XAk AlXRawokapa, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, AlXRawokapu,]) aor. yaXaAkuhaA, (TA,) signifies xaAlaTahaA [app. meaning He pierced (lit. mixed or blended) himself with the thorn: unless Xawokap be improperly used in this instance, by poetic license, as a coll. gen. n., as seems to be implied in the S and O by an explanation of a verse cited-voce naqaXa, q. v., in which case the meaning is, he entered among the thorns]. (K, TA.) ― -b4- [It is also said that] XAk AlXRawokapa, aor. yaXaAkuhaA, inf. n. XawokN, signifies He (a man) extracted the thorn from his foot. (MA.) ― -b5- Xiyka, aor. yuXaAku, inf. n. XawokN, He (a man) was, or became, pierced by a thorn. (S, O.) ― -b6- XaAka, (K,) or [first pers.] Xikotu, (S, O,) aor. yaXaAku, (K, and the like in the S and O,) inf. n. XaAkapN and XiykapN, (S, O, K,) He, (K,) or I, (S, O,) fell, or lighted, among thorns: (S, O, K: [whence, accord. to the S and O, the verse above referred to, voce naqaXa:]) and Xikotu AlXRawoka, aor. OaXaAkuhu, I fell, or lighted, among the thorns: (K:) accord. to IB, Xikotu, aor. OaXaAku, is originally Xawikotu. (TA.) ― -b7- XAkt AlXRajarapu, aor. taXaAku, inf. n. XawokN; and AXAkt↓; (Msb;) or XawRakat↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. taXowiykN; in some of the copies of the K Xawikat; (TA; [in the CK, Xawakat;]) and OaXowakat↓; (K;) The tree was thorny, or prickly; abounded with thorns, or prickles: (Msb, K, TA:) [and] OaXowakat↓ said of a palm-tree has the like signification. (S, O.) ― -b8- [Hence,] XAk laHoyaA AlbaEiyri (assumed tropical:) The two jaws of the camel put forth his canine teeth; (S O;) as also XwRk↓, (S, O,) inf. n. taXowiykN: (S:) or the phrase with the latter verb means The camel's canine teeth became long. (K.) ― -b9- And XAk vadoIu AljaAriyapi (assumed tropical:) The breast of the girl was ready to swell, or become protuberant or prominent; as also XwRk↓, inf. n. taXowiykN; (S;) and, accord. to Z, Xawika, like
fariHa: (TA:) or vadoyuhaA XwRk↓ signifies (tropical:) her breast became pointed in its extremity, (IDrd, O, K, TA,) and its protrusion appeared. (IDrd, O, TA.) ― -b10- XAk AlrRajulu, aor. yaXaAk, inf. n. XawokN, (tropical:) The man exhibited his Xawokap [i. e. vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, &c.], and his sharpness. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) [And The man was completely armed; (as though meaning he bristled with arms;) for] the inf. n. XawokN signifies a man's being completely armed. (KL.) ― -b11- And Xiyka (tropical:) He was, or became, affected with the disease termed Xawokap [q. v.]. (K, TA.)

2 XawRakotuhu biAlXRawoki c
2. XawRakotuhu biAlXRawoki: see 1, former half. ― -b2- XwRk AlHaAYiTa, (S, K,) inf. n. taXowiykN, (TA,) He put thorns upon the wall. (S, K.) ― -b3- See also 1, latter half, in four places. ― -b4- XwRk AlzRaroEu (tropical:) The seed-produce, or corn, became white, before its spreading: (K:) or came forth [pointed,] without forking, or shooting forth into separate stalks, (HadRada,) and became white, before its spreading; as also OaXowaka↓: (TA:) [or began to come forth: see muXawRikN.] ― -b5- XwRk naAbu AlbaEiyri (assumed tropical:) [The canine tooth of the camel grew forth]. (TA.) ― -b6- XwRk riyXu Alfaroxi, (IDrd, O,) and XaAribu AlgulaAmi, (IDrd, O, K,) (tropical:) The feathers of the young bird, (IDrd, O,) and the mustache of the young man, became rough to the feel. (IDrd, O, K, TA.) And XwRk Alfaroxu (assumed tropical:) The young bird put forth the heads of its feathers: (S, * K, TA:) in [some of the copies of] the S and A, XwRk Alfaroju, thus with j, expl. by Oanobata. (TA.) And XwRk AlrRaOosu baEoda AlHaloqi (tropical:) The head put forth its hair after the shaving. (S, K, TA.)

4 OaXowaka
4: as a trans. verb: see 1, former half, in four places: ― -b2- as intrans.: see 1, latter half, in three places: and see also 2.

5 taXawRukN c
5. taXawRukN The having thorns; expl. by baA xaArN Xudano. (KL.)

XaAkN c
XaAkN; and its fem., with p: see XaAYikN, in four places.

XawokN c
XawokN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) of a tree, (Msb,) or of a plant, (TA,) Thorns, prickles, or spines; (PS, TK;) the kind of thing that is slender [or pointed] and hard in the head; (TA;) well known: (Msb, K:) n. un. with p. (S, O, Msb, K, TA.) [Hence the saying,] laA yaXuwkuka minRiI XawokapN: see 1, near the beginning. [The Xawok of the palm-tree are commonly called sulRaMCN.] Xawoku AlsRunobuli [The sharp prickles that compose the awn, or beard, of the ear of corn]. (AHn, TA in art. bhm.) ― -b2- [For other significations of XawokapN, see this word below.]

XawikN c
XawikN; and its fem., with p: see XaAYikN, in three places.

XawokapN c
XawokapN n. un. of XawokN [q. v.]. (S &c.) [Hence various meanings here following; all of which seem to be tropical.] ― -b2- OaSaAbatohumo Xawokapu AlqanaA [app. (assumed tropical:) The point of the spear hit, hurt, or wounded, them]. (TA. [There expl. only by the words whI Xbh AlAsnp, i. e. wahiIa Xibohu AlOasinRapi; as though relating to a pl. number.]) ― -b3- jaAWuwA biAlXRawokapi waAlXRajarapi (tropical:) They came with multitude [app. meaning of armed men]. (TA.) ― -b4- Xawokapu AlEaqorabi (assumed tropical:) The sting of the scorpion. (S, O, K.) ― -b5- Xawokapu AlHaAYiki (tropical:) The weaver's implement with which he makes the warp and the woof even: (S, O, TA:) i. e., (TA,) AlXRawokapu signifies AlSRiySiyapu, (O, K, in the CK AlSRiySapu,) as having this meaning: ― -b6- and also as meaning (tropical:) The spur of the cock. (O, TA.) ― -b7- And AlXRawokapu, (Lth, O,) or Xawokapu AlkatRaAni, (K, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A piece of clay, (Lth, O, K, TA,) in a moist state, (K, TA,) made into a round form, and having its upper part pressed so that it becomes expanded, then (Lth, O, TA) prickles of the palm-tree are stuck into it, (Lth, O, K, TA,) and it dries; (K, TA;) used for clearing [or combing] flax therewith: (Lth, O, K, TA:) mentioned by Az: and also called AlkatRaAni XuwaAkapu↓. (TA.) ― -b8- XawokapN also signifies (tropical:) A weapon, or weapons; syn. silaAHN; (K, TA, and Ham p. 526;) as in the phrase fulaAnN cuw XuwokapK (tropical:) [Such a one is a possessor of a weapon or weapons; though this admits of another rendering, as will be shown by what follows]: (TA:) or (tropical:) sharpness thereof: (K, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the point, or edge, in a weapon. (S, O.) ― -b9- And (assumed tropical:) Vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) in respect of fighting: (K, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) vehemence of encounter: and (assumed tropical:) sharpness: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) the infliction of havock, or vehement slaughter or wounding, syn. nikaAyapN, [app. meaning effectiveness therein,] among the enemy: (K, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) strength in weapons [app. meaning in the use thereof]: (Msb:) and [simply] (assumed tropical:) strength, or might. (Ham p. 526.) One says, lahumo XawokapN fiI AlHarobi (assumed tropical:) [They have vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, in war]: and huwa cuw XawokapK fiI AlEaduwRi (assumed tropical:) [He has effectiveness in the infliction of havock among the enemy]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., halumRa UilaI jihaAdK laA Xawokapa fiyhi (assumed tropical:) [Come to a war in the cause of religion wherein is no vehemence of might or strength, &c.]; meaning the pilgrimage. (TA.) ― -b10- Also (tropical:) A certain disease, (IDrd, O, K, TA,) well known; (K;) namely, plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwn. (IDrd, O.) And (assumed tropical:) A redness that arises (A, * O, K) upon the body (K) or upon the face, and part of the body, and is [said to be] allayed by means of charms, or spells: (O:) because the sting of the scorpion, which is thus called, when it strikes a man, mostly produces redness. (A, TA.) ― -b11- [In one instance, in the CK, XawokapN is erroneously put for XawikapN, as an epithet applied to a tree.]

XawokaMCu c
XawokaMCu, applied to a [garment such as is called] burodap, (S, O,) or to a [garment or dress such as is called] HulRap, (A, O, K,) (tropical:) Rough to the feel, because new: (AO, S, O, K, TA:) but As said, “ I know not what it is. ” (O, L, TA.)

XaAkiI AlsRilaAHi c
XaAkiI AlsRilaAHi and XaAkK fiI AlslAHi: see XaAYikN, in three places.

XuwaAkapu AlkatRaAni c
XuwaAkapu AlkatRaAni: see XawokapN.

XuwayokapN c
XuwayokapN, like juhayonap [in measure], accord. to the K, A certain species of camels; and thus in the Moheet and the Mohkam: but the correct word is that which here follows. (TA.)

UibilN XuwayokiyRapN c
UibilN XuwayokiyRapN, (S, O, TA,) thus [says Sgh] I have seen the latter word in a verse in the Deewán of Dhu-r-Rummeh in the handwriting of Skr, with a distinct sheddeh to the [latter] I, but in the handwriting of El-Bujeyrimee without a sheddeh; (O, TA;) (assumed tropical:) Camels whose canine teeth have grown forth: (S, * O, TA:) some say that it is XuwayokiYap, with C, and is for XuwayoqiYap [q. v.], the q being changed into k. (O, TA.)

XajarN XaAYikN c
XajarN XaAYikN (S, O) and XawikN↓ and XaAkN↓ (O) Trees having thorns; (S, O; *) and XajarapN muXiykapN↓ a tree having thorns: (TA:) [or thorny; having many thorns; for] XajarapN XaAkapN↓ signifies a thorny tree, or a tree having many thorns, (S, O, K,) accord. to ISk; (S, O;) as also Xjrp XawikapN↓ [in the CK (erroneously) XawokapN] and XaAYikapN (K, TA) and muXowikapN↓. (S, O, K, * TA.) And OaroDN XaAkapN↓ A thorny land, or a land in which are many thorns: (K, TA:) and [in like manner] OaroDN muXowikapN↓ (S, O, K) a thorny land, or a land abounding with thorns; (O;) a land in which are the [thorny trees called] siHaMC and qataAd and haraAs. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- XaAYiku AlsRilaAHi (S, O, Msb, K) and AlslAHi XaAku↓, (Fr, K, TA,) with refa to the k, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, XAki,] and Xawiku↓ AlslAHi, (K,) which is of the dial. of El-Yemen, (TA,) and AlslAHi XaAkiI↓, (Fr, S, O, Msb, K,) this last formed by transposition from the first, (S, O, Msb, TA,) or, as Fr says, XaAkiI AlslAHi and XaAku AlslAHi are like jurufo haArK and haArN, (TA,) (tropical:) A man who exhibits his Xawokap [i. e. vehemence of might or strength, or of valour or prowess, &c.], and his sharpness: (S, O, Msb:) or a man whose weapon is sharp, or whose weapons are sharp: (K, TA:) or AlslAHi XaAkiI↓, as some explain it, a man whose spear-head and arrow-head and the like are sharp: (TA:) [or all may be rendered bristling with arms:] and accord. to AZ, one says fiI AlsRilaAHi XaAkK↓ and XaAYikN. (TA.)

maXuwkN c
maXuwkN Affected with the disease, (K, * TA,) or redness, (O, K, *) termed XawokapN; (O, K, TA;) applied to a man. (O.)

muXowikN c
muXowikN: see its fem. voce XaAYikN, in two places.

muXiykN c
muXiykN: see its fem. voce XaAYikN.

zaroEN muXawRikN c
zaroEN muXawRikN Seed-produce of which the first portion has come forth. (A, TA. [See also 2.])

1 XaAla c
1. XaAla, [aor. yaXuwlu,] (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. XuwolN, (TK,) It rose; or became raised, or elevated; (S, O, Msb, K;) said, in this sense, of a she-camel's tail; (S, O, K;) [and in like manner of a star; (see Ham p. 239;)] and AnXAl↓ signifies the
same, (O, K,) said of a stone, (K,) and so AnXAlt said of a jar (jarRap); (S, O;) and likewise AXtAl↓. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] XAl AlmiyozaAnu The balance had one of its two scales higher than the other, (S, O, Msb, TA,) by reason of its lightness. (Msb.) Whence the saying, XAl miyzaAnu fulaAnK, aor. yaXuwlu, inf. n. XawalaAnN, meaning (tropical:) Such a one was overcome in contending with another for superiority in glory or the like. (TA.) ― -b3- And XAlt Alqirobapu, and XAl AlzRiqRu, The legs of the water-skin, and of the skin for wine &c., became raised, or elevated, on the occasion of its being filled, or inflated. (TA.) ― -b4- And XaAla labanuhaA [meaning Her milk became drawn up, or withdrawn,] is said of a camel. (TA.) ― -b5- One says also, XAlt naEaAmatuhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, flurried, agitated, or excited, (xafRa,) and angry, and then became calm. (K.) And XAlt naEaAmatuhumo (assumed tropical:) Their might (EizRuhumo) departed: (O, K:) or their abodes became clear of them, as though lightened of them, (xafRato manaAziluhumo minohumo, K, TA,) and they went away: (TA:) or their expression of opinion was, or became, discordant: (tafarRaqato kalimatuhumo: K:) or they died: and they became scattered, or dispersed; as though there remained not of them save a remnant; [see XawolN;] AlnRaEaAmapu signifying AljamaAEapu: (TA:) or they became irresolute, by reason of fear, and fled: (Msb:) or they were frightened, and fled. (M in art. rOl.) [See also naEaAmapN: and see a verse cited voce UimRaA.] ＝ -A2- Xulotu bihi, and Xulotuhu; (Msb;) and OaXalotuhu↓; (O, Msb;) or Xulotu biAljarRapi, for which one should not say Xilotu [which the vulgar say in the present day, making it trans. by itself]; (S, O;) and OaXalotuhaA↓; (S;) or XAl biAlHajari; and AXAlhu↓, (K,) inf. n. UiXaAlapN; (TA;) and XAwlhu↓; (K;) aor. of the first as above, inf. n. XawolN; (S, O, Msb;) I raised, (S, O, Msb,) or he raised, (K,) it, (O, Msb,) namely, a thing, (O,) or the jar, (S, O,) or the stone. (K.) And XAlt bicanabihaA, (S, O, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, O, K,) inf. n. XawolN (O, Msb, K) and XawalaAnN; (O, K;) and AXAlthu↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiXaAlapN; and AstXAlthu↓; (TA;) She (a camel) raised her tail, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) having become pregnant. (Msb. [See XaAYilN: and see also 2.]) And XAlt bicanabihaA It (a scorpion) raised its tail. (TA.) And XAl yadahu He raised his arm or hand; like XAl bihaA. (Msb.) And biDaboEihi AXAl↓ He raised his DaboE [generally expl. as meaning the upper half of the arm, from the elbow to the shoulder-blade]. (TA.)

2 XawRala
2: XwRlt, said of a she-camel, (S, O, K,) She became such as is termed XaAYilap: (S, O, TA: [in one of my copies of the S, SaAra XawolFA is erroneously put for SaArato XaAYilapF:]) or her supplies of milk dried up; (jafRato OalobaAnuhaA; K, TA; [but perhaps the right reading is xafRato, meaning became scanty; for SM adds,]) and became little in quantity. (TA.) And XwRlt AlUibilu The camels became in such a state that their bellies [were drawn up as though they] reached their backs: (K, TA:) or became such as to have [only] a Xawol [or small quantity remaining] of milk: like as one says, (O, TA,) XwRlt AlmazaAdapu The mzAdp [or leathern water-bag] had little water remaining in it: (O, K, TA:) one should not say XaAlat. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] taXowiylN of the cakar signifies Its being in a relaxed state on the occasion of mujaAmaEap. (O, K.) And XwRl said of a horse means, like rafRaDa, He put forth his veretrum without being vigorously lustful. (TA in art. rfD.) ― -b3- XwRl said of a garob [or large bucket], Its water became little in quantity. (O, K.) Said of a she-camel's milk, It became deficient: (K, TA:) and it became withdrawn. (TA.) And said of water, It became little in quantity. (K.) ― -b4- In the following saying, (S, TA,) of Abu-n-Nejm, (TA,)
HatRaI UicaA maA AlEiXoru EanohaA XawRalaA
the poet means, cahaba and taSarRama [i. e. Until, when the coming to water on the tenth day after the next preceding period of abstinence ceased from her or them... referring to a camel or to camels]. (S, TA.) ― -b5- XwRl fiI AlmazaAdapi He left somewhat remaining (OaboqaI XawolFA) of water in the mzAdp [or leathern water-bag]. (K, * TA.)

3 XAwlhu c
3. XAwlhu: see 1, latter half. ― -b2- Also, and XAwl bihi, and XAwl bihi fiI AlTRiEaAni, [inf. n. muXaAwalapN,] He contended with him in thrusting [with the spear]. (TA.) See also 6. ― -b3- And XAwl AlfaHolu AlfaHola The stallion [camel] fought with, or combated, the stallion [camel]. (Ham p. 660.)

4 OaXowala
4: see 1, latter half, in five places.

6 tXAwlwA c
6. tXAwlwA They reached, or smote, one another, (tanaAwala baEoDuhumo baEoDFA,) in fight, with the spears: and muXaAwalapN↓ has a similar signification [to taXaAwulN, as shown above by an explanation of its verb, 3]. (AZ, S, O.)

7 UinoXawala
7: see 1, first sentence.

8 UiXotawala
8: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- AXtAl lahu (tropical:) He opposed himself to him, and reviled him. (O, K, TA.)

10 UisotaXowala
10: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

XaAlN c
XaAlN A certain fish of the sea, or of great rivers (samakapN baHoriyRapN): (TA:) [in Egypt this name is applied to a fish of the genus silurus, found in the Nile: it is well described by Sonnini, in p. 407 of the 4to Engl. ed. of his Travels in Upper and Lower Egypt.] ＝ -A2- Also A certain kind of ridaMC [here meaning shawl], made in Cashmere and Lahore, and brought for sale to other countries; [erroneously] said to be made of camels' fur; and so called because raised to the shoulders, if it be an Arabic word [which is not the case, for it is from the Pers. XaAlN, whence our word “ shawl ”]: pl. XiylaAnN and XaAlaAtN. (TA.)

XawolN c
XawolN: see XaAYilapN, voce XaAYilN: ＝ -A2- and XawolapN. ＝ -A3- Also Somewhat remaining of water in the skin and in the bucket, (K,) and of milk in the udder: (TA:) and a small quantity of water (S, O, K, TA) in the bottom of the water-skin (S, O, TA) and of the leathern water-bag: (TA:) [in the CK, AlmAlu Alqaliylu is erroneously put for AlmaMCu Alqaliylu:] pl. OaXowaAlN. (S, O, K.) It is said in a prov.,
maA DarRa naAbFA XawoluhaA AlmuEalRaqu
(Meyd, TA,) i. e. Her small quantity of water [that is hung upon her does not harm an aged she-camel]: or naAbiI [my aged she-camel]: applied to the case of carrying that which will not harm thee if it be with thee, and will be useful to thee if thou be in want of it: (Meyd:) or applied to him who is enjoined to take the prudent course and to supply himself with travelling-provision though he be going to such provision. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And Light, active, or agile; syn. xafiyfN: (K:) so in the M. (TA.) [See also the next paragraph.]

XawilN c
XawilN One that raises a thing. (TA. [See also XaAYilN.]) ― -b2- And A man light, active, or agile, (xafiyfN,) in work, and in service, (S, O, K,) and in respect of what is wanted; and quick: (K:) thus in a verse of El-Aashà: (O, TA:) [but accord. to the reading of AO of that verse, it is XuwulN↓, which has a similar, but intensive, meaning. (De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., ii. 484-5.) See also what next follows.]

XuwalN c
XuwalN, like SuradN [in measure], One who aids, or assists, much or well; syn. naSuwrN. (O, TA.) [See also what next precedes.]

XuwulN c
XuwulN: see XawilN.

XawolapN c
XawolapN The part that it raises of the tail of the scorpion; (S, O, K;) and so XawolN↓: (Ham p. 649:) or, accord. to Sh, its sting, with which it strikes. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlXRawolapu (assumed tropical:) Two bright stars, near together, [ λ and ν,] (S, O,) in the end of the tail of Scorpio, (Kzw,) which are one of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, O, Kzw,) namely, the Nineteenth Mansion; (Kzw;) also called Humapu AlEaqorabi. (S, O.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] ― -b3- And Xawolapu is a proper name for The scorpion; (O, TA;) [and] so XawRaAlapu↓. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A foolish, or stupid, woman. (IAar, O, K.) Xawolapu was the name of A certain foolish female slave, belonging to [the tribe of] 'Adwán, and she used to give advice to her masters, and it resulted in evil to them; whence the saying, Oanota Xawolapu AlnRaASiHapu [Thou art Showleh the giver of advice]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- Also the name of The mare of Zeyd-el-Fawáris Ed-Dabbee. (O, K.)

XuwayolaMCu c
XuwayolaMCu A certain plant, (AHn, O, K,) mentioned, but not described, by As; of the kind termed EuXob, growing in plain, or soft, land, (AHn, O,) used as a medicament, (AHn, O, K,) and well known: (AHn, O:) [Sgh says,] I have seen it: it is dust-coloured, spreads upon the ground, has no thorns, and the cattle eagerly desire it: (O:) it is called (O, K) sometimes, (K,) by some of the people of El-'Irák, (O,) XuwRayolN↓, like fubRayoTN [in measure]. (O, K.)

XawRaAlN c
XawRaAlN The tail of the scorpion. (TA. [So called
because often raised.]) ― -b2- Also, (S, O, Msb, K,) and sometimes it is called AlXRawRaAlu, (Msb,) The month of the festival of the breaking of the fast; (Msb, K; *) the month next after ramaDaAn; (TA;) the first of the months of the pilgrimage; (S, O;) [the tenth month of the lunar year:] as some assert, (IDrd, O,) so called because [when first thus named] it coincided with the season when the she-camels [being seven or eight months gone with young] raised their tails: (IDrd, O, Msb, TA:) [for the camels generally couple in winter:] or because of their milk becoming then withdrawn; such being the case with the camels in the time of vehement heat and of the coming to an end of the juicy fresh herbage: [see a table of the months voce zamanN:] the Arabs used to regard the making of marriage-contracts in this month as of evil omen; and to say that the woman [then] married would resist him who married her, like as the she-camel resists the stallion and raises her tail; but the Prophet abolished their thus auguring, and he married 'Áïsheh in this month: (TA:) the pl. is XawRaAlaAtN and XawaAwiylu (S, Msb, K) and XawaAwilu, this last formed by rejecting the augmentative letter [in the second]. (TA.)

XuwRayolN c
XuwRayolN: see XuwayolaMCu.

XawRaAlapN c
XawRaAlapN [not (as is implied in the K) XawRaAlapu] A certain bird, (AHát, O, K,) a duxRalap [n. un. of duxRalN q. v.], of a dusky colour, which, when it alights upon a stone or a tree, moves up and down its tail like as does the camel; so called because it raises its tail; and in its belly and its hinder part is somewhat of redness. (AHát, O, TA.) ― -b2- See also XawolapN. ― -b3- [Hence, as being likened to the scorpion, whence also the phrase UinRahu latadibRu EaqaAribuhu,] AimoraOapN XawRaAlapN (assumed tropical:) A woman wont to calumniate. (K.)

XaAYilN c
XaAYilN A she-camel raising her tail, (S, O, Msb, K,) having conceived, (Msb,) or by reason of having conceived, and having no milk whatever: (S, O, K:) or a she-camel that has conceived, and raises her tail to the stallion as a sign of her having conceived, raising her head therewith, and elevating her nose: (Az, TA:) the word is without p because it is an epithet of peculiar application [to a female]: (Msb:) or it is without p anomalously; for the male also raises his tail: (ISd, TA:) the pl. is XuwRalN (Az, S, O, Msb, K) and XuyRalN and XiyRalN and XuwRaAlN. (K.) Also, with p, applied to a mare, as meaning Raising the tail. (TA.) ― -b2- And XaAYilapN, which is anomalously with p because it is an epithet denoting an attribute not shared with the female by the male, (ISd, TA,) A she-camel that has passed seven months, (S, O, K,) or eight, (S, O,) since the period of her bringing forth, (S, O, K,) or of her becoming pregnant, (K,) and whose milk has dried up, (jafRa labanuhaA, K, and so in a copy of the S,) or whose milk has become scanty, (xafRa labanuhaA, O, and so in another copy of the S,) and her udder drawn up, (S, O,) there remaining in her udder no more than a Xawol, a third of the quantity of the contents thereof when her bringing forth was recent: (TA:) she-camels in this case are termed XawolN↓, (S, O, K,) an anomalous pl., (K,) [or rather a quasi-pl. n.,] expl. by some as applied to she-camels whose milk has become deficient, which is the case when their young are weaned at the period of the [auroral] rising of suhayol [or Canopus, a period which commenced, in Central Arabia, about the beginning of the era of the Flight, on the 4th of August, O. S.], and they cease not to be thus termed until the stallion is sent among them; (TA;) the pl. pl. [or pl. of XawolN] is OaXowaAlN; (K;) and XawaAYilu is a pl. of XaAYilapN meaning [as expl. above, or] a she-camel whose milk has become withdrawn. (TA.) ― -b3- XaAYilN is also applied to Anything that is raised, or drawn up, or withdrawn. (TA.)

XawoXalaMCu c
XawoXalaMCu Initus; syn. nayokN: said to be an Abyssinian word. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.)

miXowalN c
miXowalN A small minojal [or reaping-hook: in the CK, erroneously, munoxul]. (S, O, K, TA.)

muXiylN c
muXiylN act. part. n. of 4. See an ex. in a verse cited voce xaAfiD; cited also in the present art. in the S and O.

miXowalapN c
miXowalapN is said by Yz to signify A certain thing with which one plays. (O, TA.)

miXowaAlN c
miXowaAlN A stone that is raised. (Lh, K.)

1 XaAha wajohuhu c
1. XaAha wajohuhu, aor. yaXuwhu; (K;) and XaAhati Alwujuwhu, aor. taXuwhu; (S, Msb;) inf. n. XawohN (S, K) and XawohapN, (K,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (TA;) and Xawiha wajohuhu, (K,) inf. n. XawahN; (TA;) His face was, (K,) and the faces were, (S, Msb,) foul, unseemly, or ugly. (S, Msb, K.) And Xawiha, (Msb,) and Xawihato, (Mgh,) inf. n. XawahN, (Mgh, Msb,) He, (a man, Msb,) and she, (a woman, Mgh,) was, or became, foul, unseemly, or ugly, (Mgh, Msb,) in face, (Mgh,) or in make. (Msb.) ― -b2- XawahN is also syn. with HusonN [app. as an inf. n., of which the verb is Xawiha signifying He was, or became, beautiful: thus having two contr. meanings]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) as an inf. n., (TK,) The neck's being long, (K, TA,) and high, and the head's overtopping; whence OaXowahu↓ applied to a horse: (TA:) and the neck's being short: thus [again] having two contr. meanings: (K:) one says, [app. of a horse,] Xawihato Eunuquhu His neck was long [&c.]: and his neck was short: (TK:) or XawahN said of the neck [of a horse] signifies the being extended: and said of the Xidoq [or side of the mouth], the being wide, (JK. [It probably signifies any of the attributes denoted by the epithet OaXowahu, q. v.]) ― -b4- Also, [and app. in this sense likewise an inf. n. of which the verb is Xawiha,] The being quick to smite with the [evil] eye. (S.) ― -b5- And one says, XaAha fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. XawohN, (TA,) He smote such a one with the [evil] eye; (K, TA;) as also AXAhhu↓: (TA in art. Xhw:) and in like manner, maAlahu [his cattle, or property]: (Lh, TA:) or XawohN signifies the smiting vehemently therewith. (TA.) And EalaIRa laA tuXawRiho↓ Smite not thou me with an [evil] eye: (K:) or, accord. to Abu-l-Mekárim this means say not, How eloquent art thou! (Az, TA,) or say not, How beautiful art thou! (ISk, S,) and so doing smite me with the [evil] eye, or with an [evil] eye. (ISk, Az, S, TA.) tXwRh↓ signifies He practised artifice to smite people with the evil eye. (JK.) And one says, OamowaAla AlnRaAsi liyuSiybahaA biAlEayoni huwa yataXawRahu↓ i. e. He raises his look towards the cattle, or possessions, of the people to smite them with the [evil] eye. (TA.) [See also 1 in art. Xyh.] ― -b6- Also, He frightened, or terrified, such a one. (Lh, K.) ― -b7- And He envied such a one. (K.) ― -b8- And XaAhato nafosuhu UilaI kacaA His desire became raised towards such a thing. (AA, K.)

2 XwRhhu c
2. XwRhhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taXowiyhN, (TA,) He (God) rendered foul, unseemly, or ugly, his face: (S, K, TA:) and it, i. e. the conformation of the face. (TA, from a verse of El-Hotei-ah.) And XawRahotu Alwujuwha I rendered foul, unseemly, or ugly, the faces. (Msb.) ― -b2- And XawRaha QllRehu Huluwqakumo God rendered, or may God render, wide your throats, or fauces. (TA.) ― -b3- laA tuXawRiho EalaIRa: see 1, latter half. ― -b4- XwRh biyadihi He (a man) made a sign with his arm, or hand. (JK.)

4 AXAhhu c
4. AXAhhu: see 1.

5 tXwRh lahu c
5. tXwRh lahu He became altered in countenance to him, so as to be not known by him, (syn. tanakRara, S, K,) and assumed various appearances. (S.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places, near the end. ＝ -A2- tXwRh XaApF He hunted a XAp [app. here meaning a wild bull, as seems to be indicated by the context in the S]. (S, K.)

XaMCN c
XaMCN: see the next paragraph.

XaApN c
XaApN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) originally XaAhapN, (S, Msb, TA,) A sheep, or goat; [each and either, but more commonly the former; see an instance voce SuwfN;] i. e. one of what are termed ganam; (S, * Msb, * K;) applied to the male and to the female; (S, Msb, K;) so that one says of the male, hecaA XaApN, (Msb,) which is said by Kh to be like the phrase hecaA raHomapN mino rabRiI; (Sb, TA;) and of the female, hecihi XaApN; and XaApN cakarN and XaApN OunovaI: (Msb:) or it may be [one] of sheep, and of goats, and of gazelles or antelopes, and of the bovine kind [app. of the wild bovine kind i. e. of bovine antelopes], and of ostriches, and of wild asses; (K;) it is applied to a wild bull by Tarafeh, in his saying,
kasaAmiEataIo XaApK biHawomala muforadi
(S) i. e. Like the two ears of a wild bull, in Howmal, solitary; the poet likening thereto the ears of a she-camel in respect of sharpness and erectness; (EM p. 76;) and likewise by Lebeed, and by El-Farezdak: (IB, TA:) and it is also applied to [a wild cow; (though said in the K in art. XwI to signify the wild bull, specially the male;) and hence, as being likened thereto,] (tropical:) a woman; (K, TA;) thus by El-Aashà; and thus also by Antarah, in his saying,
yaA XaApa maA qanaSK limano HalRato lahu
Harumato EalaIRa walayotahaA lamo taHorumi
(TA) O XAp [i. e. wild cow] of the chase (mA being redundant) for him to whom she is lawful: she has become forbidden to me, and would that she were not forbidden: (EM p. 246:) pl. XaMCN↓, (S, Msb, K,) originally XaAhN, (K,) used when they are many in number, (S,) [but this is properly termed a coll. gen. n.,] and XiyaAhN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) with h, which is used of a number from three to ten [inclusive], for more than which it is with t [meaning p, i. e. XaApN, agreeably with a general rule], (S,) and XiwaAhN, [the original of XiyaAhN,] (K,) and XawiIRN↓, (S, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, XawFI,]) which is pl. of XaMCN, (S, TA,) or rather a quasi-pl. n., originally XawiyhN, the h being changed into I like as it is in ciI for ciho, (TA,) and OaXaAwihu, (K,) and XayohN↓, (so in copies of the K, [in the TA said to be like EinabN, which is a mistake, (perhaps for EayonN,) for it is there said to be a quasi-pl. n., which could not be said if it were XiyahN,]) and XiyhN↓, (CK, [but this, which is another quasi-pl. n., is not in my MS. copy of the K nor in the TA,]) and XayRihN↓, (K,) originally XayowihN, but this, also, is a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and XiyapN↓ also is syn. with XaMCN: (IAar, K in art. XwI:) it has not a pl. formed with A and t, [i. e. it has not for a pl. XaAMtN,] whether it be used as a gen. n. or as a proper name: (TA:) the dim. is XuwayohapN↓. (S, Msb.) The sing. is also used in the sense of the pl., in the saying fulaAnN kaviyru AlXRaApi waAlbaEiyri [Such a one is possessor of a large number of sheep or goats, and of camels], because the article Al denotes the genus. (S.) And it is said in a trad. faOamara lahaA biXiyaAhi ganamK [And he ordered that sheep or goats should be given to her]: XyAh being prefixed to gnm, governing it in the gen. case, for the sake of distinction; because the Arabs [sometimes] call an animal of the wild bovine kind XAp. (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- AlXRaApu is also the name of (assumed tropical:) Certain small stars (K in art. XwI) between AlqrHh [or Alfrjp, thus in the work of Kzw, in his descr. of Cepheus, and there said to be the star in the breast of Cepheus,] and AljadoIu [i. e. the pole-star]; (TA in that art.;) [the same that are described by Kzw as certain small stars, called by the Arabs AlOagonaAmu, between the legs of Cepheus and the star AljadoIu.]

XaAhu AlbaSari c
XaAhu AlbaSari, and XaAhiI AlbaSari: see XaAYihN.

XawahN c
XawahN an inf. n., of Xawiha. (Mgh, Msb, TA. [See 1, in several places.]) ＝ -A2- Also a subst. meaning Unluckiness, or inauspiciousness, of a woman. (TA.)

XayohN c
XayohN and XiyhN and XiyapN: see XaApN.

XuwhapN c
XuwhapN Remoteness: (K, TA:) and so buwhapN: one says, in dispraise, XuwhapF lahu wabuwhapF [i. e. buEodFA lahu, lit. Remoteness to him! meaning may God alienate him or estrange him, from good, or prosperity! or, curse him!]. (TA.)

XawiIRN c
XawiIRN, originally XawiyhN: see XaApN.

XuwayohapN c
XuwayohapN dim. of XaApN, q. v. (S, Msb.)

XaAYihN c
XaAYihN Envying: pl. XuwRahN: (As, Lh, TA:) or the latter signifies persons practising artifice to smite men with the [evil] eye. (JK.) ― -b2- And XaAYihu AlbaSari, (JK, S, K,) and AlbaSari XaAhu↓, (JK, K,) and XaAhiI AlbaSari, (JK, TA, and S and K in art. Xhw,) the last formed by transposition from the first, (S in art. Xhw,) A man sharp of sight. (JK, S, K.)

XaAYiIRN c
XaAYiIRN: see the next paragraph.

XaAhiIRN c
XaAhiIRN: see the next paragraph.

XaAwiIRN c
XaAwiIRN and XaAhiIRN↓ A man possessing XaMC [meaning sheep or goats or both]: (K:) the former is the rel. n. of XaMCN; and the latter, that of XaApN: but used as a proper name of a man, it is XaAYiIRN↓, and, if you will, XaAwiIRN. (S, TA. *)

XayRihN c
XayRihN: see the next paragraph: ＝ -A2- and see XaApN.

OaXowahu c
OaXowahu, applied to a man, (Msb,) Foul, unseemly, or ugly, (JK, Msb, K,) in face, (JK, K,) or in aspect, (Msb,) and, as also XayRihN↓, of which the pl. is XayRihuwna, in make: (JK:) fem. XawohaMCu: (JK, Mgh, Msb:) and pl. XuwhN. (Msb.) Any created thing incongruous in its several parts; as also muXawRahN↓. (TA.) And the fem., A woman frowning, or morose, in face; (K, * TA;) foul, unseemly, or ugly, in make: (TA:) and also beautiful, goodly, or comely; (K, * TA;) that excites admiration and approval by her beauty: (TA:) thus having two contr. meanings. (K, TA.) Also, the fem., Unlucky, or inauspicious. (K.) ― -b2- And the masc. applied to a man, (Lth, S, TA,) and the fem. applied to a woman, (Lth, TA,) That smites quickly with the [evil] eye: (Lth, S, TA:) or that smites people effectually with his, and her, [evil] eye. (TA.) And OaXowahu AlEayon Having an evil eye. (Fr, TA in art. Xzr.) ― -b3- The fem. is also applied to a mare, (JK, T, S, K,) as an epithet of commendation, but not the masc. to a horse, meaning, it is said, Wide in the XidoqaAni [or two sides of the mouth]: (S:) or long in the head, and wide in the nostrils: (JK:) or tall, and such as excites admiration and approval by her beauty or excellence: (K, * TA:) or exceedingly wide in the XidoqaAni [or two sides of the mouth] and the nostrils: (K, TA:) or, as some say, wide in the mouth: (TA:) and small in the mouth: thus having two contr. meanings: (K, TA:) or sharpsighted: (T, TA:) or sharp in spirit: (TA:) see also 1. ― -b4- Also, the masc., Proud, and self-conceited. (K.) ― -b5- And xuTobapN XawohaMCu [An oration from the pulpit] in which a blessing is not invoked on the Prophet. (TA.)

OaroDN maXaAhapN c
OaroDN maXaAhapN A land in which are XaMC; (A'Obeyd, S, K;) like as one says OaroDN maOobalapN: (A'Obeyd, S:) or in which are many thereof. (K.)

muXawRahN c
muXawRahN Rendered foul, unseemly, or ugly, in face, by God: (TA:) or foul, &c., in shape. (K.) See also OaXowahu, second sentence. ― -b2- And Bad in intellect. (TA.)

1 XawaI AllRaHoma c
1. XawaI AllRaHoma, (aor.
XawiIa
, TA,) inf. n. XaIRN, (S, MA, Msb, K,) He roasted, broiled, or fried, the flesh-meat; (MA, KL, * PS;) and AXwAhu↓ signifies the same; as also AXtwAhu↓; (Msb, TA;) or this last, (TA,) or AXtwI [alone], (S, MA,) signifies he prepared, or prepared for himself, (S, MA, * TA,) XiwaMC, (S, TA, *) or roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat. (MA.) ― -b2- And XawaI AlmaMCa, (IAar, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) He heated the water. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- [And accord. to Freytag, XawaI signifies also He cut off from (mn) roasted flesh-meat: but for this he has named no authority.] ＝ -A2- See also 4.

2 XawRaIa
2: see 4. ― -b2- Also XwRAhu laHomFA He gave him flesh-meat [app. in an unrestricted sense]. (TA.)

3 yuXaAwiI c
3. yuXaAwiI, for yuXaAYiI: see 3 in art. XOw.

4 AXwI AllRaHoma c
4. AXwI AllRaHoma: see 1. ― -b2- OaXowaAhumo; (S, Msb, K;) and XawRaAhumo↓, inf. n. taXowiyapN; (K;) He fed them with XiwaMC [i. e. roasted, or broiled, or fried, flesh-meat]. (S, Msb, K.) And (both verbs with their complements) He gave them flesh-meat that they might roast, or broil, or fry, thereof. (AZ, K.) ＝ -A2- And AXwI (tropical:) He left a portion remaining of his supper: (S, K, TA:) or he left some roasted, or broiled, or fried, flesh-meat of his supper. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And AXwI AlqamoHu The wheat became fit to be rubbed with the hands and to be roasted. (ISd, K.) ― -b3- And AXwI AlsRaEafu (assumed tropical:) The palmbranches became yellow on the occasion of their drying up; (K, TA;) as though a roasting affected them. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also He got, or acquired, the worse, or viler, sort of cattle. (K.) ＝ -A4- AXwAhu said of a shooter or caster, He hit (S, * Msb, * K) his XawaI, (K,) i. e. [one or more of his] extremities, (TA,) not a [vital] place where a wound would occasion death; (S, Msb, K;) and so XawaAhu↓, as in the Tekmileh: in the K, erroneously, XwRAhu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, He missed it, i. e. the object of his aim. See muXowFI: and see also Ham p. 91.] ― -b3- [Hence, also, app.,] Hr says that AXwI is allowable in the sense of OasoqaTa (assumed tropical:) [He dropped, left out, omitted, &c., anything]; like OasowaI [q. v.]. (TA in art. swI.) ＝ -A5- In the saying maA OaEoyaAhu waOaXoyaAhu (S, K, [in some copies of the K wamaA OaXoyaAhu,]) and so in mA AEyAh waOaXowaAhu, (S, * K, * TA,) the latter verb is an imitative sequent to the former [added only for the purpose of corroboration]. (S, K, TA.)

7 AnXwI AllRaHomu c
7. AnXwI AllRaHomu The flesh-meat became roasted, broiled, or fried; (MA;) quasi-pass. of XawaI AllRaHoma; (S, * M, Msb, K;) as also * AXtwI; (M, K;) [or] the latter in this sense is not allowable. (S, Msb.)

8 UiXotawaIa
8: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] AiXotawayotuhaA, referring to a she-camel, (assumed tropical:) I journeyed upon her until the heat of the middays of summer emaciated her and she became as though she were burnt. (Ham p. 783.) ＝ -A2- See also 7.

XaApN c
XaApN: see what next follows: and see more in art. Xwh.

XiyapN c
XiyapN i. q. XaMCN [q. v. in art. Xwh]; as also XawiIRN↓; (IAar, K;) the latter is like ganiIRN, [AlXRaweI in the CK as syn. with AlXRACu being a mistranscription,] and is said by IAth to be a quasi-pl. n., or [what lexicographers term] a pl., of XaApN↓ [n. un. of XaMCN]. (TA.)

XiIRN c
XiIRN is originally XiwoIN. (ISd, TA.) One says, jaMCa biAlEiIRi waAlXRiIRi, (S, K,) using the latter noun as an imitative sequent to the former [for the purpose of corroboration: see art. EI]. (TA.)

XawFI c
XawFI is pl. of XawaApN: [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n. of which the latter is the n. un.:] the latter signifies The skin of the head: (S, TA:) so [accord. to some] in the Kur lxx. 16: (TA:) or the exterior of the skin of the head, in which grows the hair: (Aboo-Safwán, TA in art. bXr:) and some say, the exterior of all, or of any part, of the skin: (TA in the present art.:) and the former signifies the arms or hands and the legs or feet, or the fore and hind legs, (S, K,) and (K) the extremities (Msb, K) collectively, (K,) and the head of a human being, (S,) or the qiHof of the head [i. e. the bone above the brain, or a separate portion of the skull, or a distinct bone of the skull], (K,) but of a horse the legs, not the head, because one says Eabolu AlXRawaI [i. e. thick in the legs], for this cannot relate to the head of the horse, (S,) and any part that is not a [vital] place [i. e.] where a wound causes death (S, Msb, K) such [for instance] as the legs. (Msb.) vaAlibapu AlXRawaI means A woman having cracked, or chapped, feet. (S and K in art. vlb.) ― -b2- It is also a subst. [app. meaning a quasi-inf. n.] from OaXowaAhu [q. v.] as said of a shooter or caster: (TA:) [and hence] the saying (S, TA) of the Hudhalee, (S, [accord. to the TA, Khálid Ibn-Zuheyr,])
faUinRa mina Alqawoli AlRatiI laA XawaI lahaA
UicaA zalRa Zahori AllRisaAni QnofilaAtuhu
means (assumed tropical:) [And, or for] verily of speech is that sentence (kalimap, a word understood,) which does not hit a place where a wound will not occasion death, [i. e. which does not miss its object, when its escaping from the upper surface of the tongue is quick,] but which kills. (S, TA.) And XawFI is used [app. in like manner, as a quasi-inf. n.,] in the case of anything that has missed an object of aim, though there be to it [really] no place where a wound would occasion death nor anything that is [properly] termed XawFI [as meaning a place where a wound will not occasion death]. (TA.) And [hence] it signifies (assumed tropical:) A mistake; syn. xaTaON. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) A thing, (S,) or an affair, (K,) that is paltry, mean, despicable, or of no account or weight or worth: (S, K, * TA:) in this sense, from the same word as signifying the “ extremities ” [of an animal]. (IAth, TA.) Hence, in a trad. of Mujáhid, kulRu maA OaSaAba AlSRaAYima XawFI UilRaA Algayobapa (tropical:) [Everything that befalls the faster is a matter of no account, except absence of mind]; i. e. nothing that befalls the faster annuls his fast except Algybp, for this does annul it. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The worse, or viler, sort of cattle, (S, K, TA,) of camels, and of sheep or goats; and the small, or young, thereof. (TA.) [See also XuwaAyapN.] ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) A remainder, or remaining portion. (TA.) [See, again, XuwaAyapN.] ― -b6- Also i. q. UiboqaMCN (assumed tropical:) [The making, or causing, or suffering, to remain; or, perhaps, to continue in life, and if it mean thus, it may be from the same word in a sense expl. above, for the animal that one hits in a part that is not vital is suffered to continue in life]. (TA.)

XuwaMCN c
XuwaMCN: see what next follows.

XiwaMCN c
XiwaMCN Roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat; (S, * MA, Msb, K, * KL;) as also XuwaMCN↓; (Ks, Sgh, K;) but the former is more usual and more chaste: (TA:) a subst. from XawaI AllRaHoma: and XiwaMCapN↓ [as its n. un.] signifies a piece thereof. (S.)

XawiIRN c
XawiIRN (K) and maXowiIRN↓ (Msb) [Roasted, broiled, or fried], the latter originally maXowuwIN. (Msb.) [In the K the former is said to be like XiwaMCN; but it has the signification of the latter, i. e., of a pass. part. n.] ＝ -A2- See also XiyapN. ＝ -A3- Ks says, (S,) in the phrase EayiIRN XayiIRN, and so in EayiIRN XawiIRN, (S, K,) some say (S) the latter word is an imitative sequent to the former [i. e. a corroborative: see art. EI]. (S, K.)

XiwaMCapN c
XiwaMCapN: see XiwaMCN.

XawiyRapN c
XawiyRapN: see the next paragraph.

XawaAyapN c
XawaAyapN: see the next paragraph.

XuwaAyapN c
XuwaAyapN What is cut off from, or of, flesh-meat: (K, TA:) or what the slaughterer cuts off from, or of, the extremities of a sheep or goat. (TA.) ― -b2- A small thing [or portion] of that which is large; as a piece, or detached portion, of a sheep, or goat: one says, maA baqiIa mina AlXRaApi UilRaA XuwaAyapN [There remained not of the sheep, or goat, save a piece]. (S.) ― -b3- Also, (S, K,) and XiwaAyapN↓ and XawaAyapN↓, (K,) A quroS [or round cake, or small round cake,] of bread. (S, K.) ― -b4- And, all the three, A remaining portion of people, or of cattle, that have perished; as also XawiyRapN↓; (K;) or this last, a remaining portion of people that have perished: (S:) pl. (of the last, S) XawaAyaA. (S, K.) [See also XawFI.] ― -b5- And (tropical:) The bad, or vile, sort, (K, TA,) or worse, or viler, sort, (TA,) of camels, and of sheep, or goats: (K, TA:) in this sense written by ISd with kesr and with fet-h. (TA.) [See, again, XawFI.] ― -b6- [And accord. to Freytag, XwAyp AlrDf (i. e. XwAypu AlrRaDofi) is expl. by Meyd as meaning Cooked milk cast upon a hot stone, so that only a small portion remains.]

XiwaAyapN c
XiwaAyapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

XawRaMCN c
XawRaMCN A seller of roasted, broiled, or fried, flesh-meat. (KL.)

XayRaAnu c
XayRaAnu [mentioned in this art. as though originally XawoyaAnu] i. q. damu AlOaxawayoni [The red, resinous, inspissated juice called dragon's blood: see art. dmw]. (S. K.) ＝ -A2- And Far-seeing. (S, K.)

XaAwiIRN c
XaAwiIRN A possessor of XaMC [meaning sheep or goats or both]. (S, K. [In the CK without teshdeed. Mentioned also in art. Xwh, q. v.]) ＝ -A2- saEafapN XaAwiyRapN (with teshdeed to the I, TA, [but in the CK without teshdeed,]) (assumed tropical:) A palm-branch that has become yellow in drying up. (K. [See 4.])

XawoXaApN c
XawoXaApN, (S, K, [in some copies of the K XawoXaMCN, but]) like mawomaApN, (S,) A swift she-camel. (S, K.)

OaXaAwaI c
OaXaAwaI a pl. pl. of XaIoCN, q. v.

muXowFI c
muXowFI, like muhodFI, (K, TA, [in the CK, maXowiIR, like mahodiIR, erroneously, as is proved by a verse cited as an ex. in the TA, pass. part. n. of 4,]) applied to a portion of a living serpent, (TA,) That has been missed by the stone [cast at it]. (K, TA.)

miXowFI c
miXowFI (K in art. Swl) A frying-pan. (TK in that art.)

maXowiIRN c
maXowiIRN: see XawiIRN.

muXotawFI c
muXotawFI [A place of roasting, broiling, or frying, flesh-meat]. (S in art. Tbx.)

4 OaXoyaAhu c
4. OaXoyaAhu an imitative sequent to OaEoyaAhu in the phrase maA OaEoyaAhu waOaXoyaAhu: see 4 in art. XwI.

XiyapN c
XiyapN, syn. with XaMCN: see art. XwI.

XaIRN c
XaIRN: and yaA XaIRa maA liI: see XaIoCN, in art. XyO.

XiIRN c
XiIRN an imitative sequent to EiIRN: see art. XwI.

XayiIRN c
XayiIRN an imitative sequent to EayiIRN: see XawiIRN.

XayRaAnu c
XayRaAnu: see art. XwI.

1 XaMCahu c
1. XaMCahu, (Msb,) [originally XayiYahu,] like xaAfahu, [which is originally xawifahu,] (MF,) first. pers. XiYotuhu, (S, K,) aor. yaXaAWuhu, (Msb,) [and by poetic license yaXaAhu, without C,] first pers. OaXaAWuhu, (S. K,) inf. n. XaIoCN (Msb, K) and maXiyoYapN, (S, * K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and maXaMCapN and maXaAYiyapN, (K,) [or these two also are simple substs.,] He, and I, willed, wished, or desired, it; syn. OaraAdahu (Msb) and Oaradotuhu: (S, * K:) most of the scholastic theologians make no difference between AlmaXiyoYapu and AlUiraAdapu, though they are [said to be] originally different; for the former, in the proper language, signifies the causing to be or exist, syn. AlUiyjaAdu; and the latter, the willing, wishing, or desiring; syn. AlTRalabu. (TA.) A Jew objected, to the Prophet, his people's saying maA XaMCa QllRehu waXiYotu [What God hath willed and I have willed], as implying the association of another being with God: therefore the Prophet ordered them to say maA XaMCa QllRehu vumRa XiYotu [What God hath willed, then I have willed]. (TA.) [maA XaMCa QllRehu as signifying What hath God willed! is used to express admiration. And as signifying What God willed it is a phrase often used to denote a vague, generally a great or considerable, but sometimes
a small, number or quantity or time: See De Sacy's Relation de l'Égypte par Abdallatif, pp. 246 and 394 &c.] ＝ -A2- See also 1 in art. XwO

2 XayRaOotuhu EalaI AlOamori c
2. XayRaOotuhu EalaI AlOamori [in some copies of the K (erroneously) XiYotuhu] I incited him, or made him, to do the thing, or affair. (As, S, L, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- And XayRaOa QllRehu wajohahu, (K, TA,) and xaloqahu, (TA,) God rendered, or may God render, foul, unseemly, or ugly, his face, (K, TA,) and his make. (TA.)

4 OaXaMCahu Uilayohi c
4. OaXaMCahu Uilayohi He, or it, compelled him, constrained him, or necessitated him, to have recourse, or betake himself, to it; syn. OalojaOahu; (S, K;) a dial. var. of OajaMCahu; (S;) of the dial. of Temeem. (TA.) Temeem say, XarRN maA yuXiyWuka UilaI muxRapi EuroquwbK, meaning yujiyWuka [q. v., i. e. It is an evil thing that compels thee to have recourse to the marrow of a hock]. (S.)

5 tXyRO c
5. tXyRO His anger became appeased: (K:) said of a man. (TA.)

XaIoCN c
XaIoCN [A thing; anything; something; somewhat;] a word of well-known meaning: (K:) [sometimes, in poetry, written and pronounced XaIRN: see an ex. in a verse cited voce SuWaAbapN: see also the last sentence but one of this paragraph:] AlXRaIoCu properly signifies what may be known, and that whereof a thing may be predicated: (Mgh, KT:) accord. to Sb, it denotes existence, and is a name for anything that has been made to have being, whether an accident, or attribute, or a substance, and such that it may be known, and that a thing may be predicated thereof: (KT:) MF says that it is app. an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n., meaning what is willed, and meant, or intended, [in which sense maXiyoYapN↓ (pl. maXiyoMtN) is often used,] without restriction to its actuality or possibility of being, so that it applies to that which necessarily is, and that which may be, and that which cannot be; accord. to the opinion adopted by the author of the Ksh: [or, as an inf. n. in the sense of a pass. part. n., it may be expl., agreeably with what is said to be the proper meaning of the verb, as signifying what is caused to be or exist; accordingly,] Er-Rághib says that it denotes whatever is caused to be or exist, whether sensibly, as material substances, or ideally, as sayings; and Bd and others expressly assert that it signifies peculiarly what is caused to be or exist; but Sb says that it is the most general of general terms; and some of the scholastic theologians apply it to what is non-existent; such, however, are overcome in their argument by its not being found to have been thus used by the Arabs, and by such passages as kulRu XaIoCK haAlikN UilRaA wajohahu [Everything is subject to perish except Himself (Kur xxviii. last verse)] and waUino mino XaIoCK UilRaA yusabRiHu biHamodihi [And there is not anything but it glorifies Him with praising (Kur xvii. 46)], for what is nonexistent cannot be described as perishing nor imagined to glorify God: (TA:) the pl. is OaXoyaMCu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) imperfectly decl., (Msb, TA,) or rather this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, TA,) respecting the formation of which there is much difference of opinion [as will be shown hereafter], (Msb, TA,) and OaXoyaAwaAtN, (S, K,) a pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of OaXoyaMCN], (MF, TA,) and OaXaAwaAtN, [a contraction of that next preceding,] (K,) and OaXaAwaI, (S, K,) with fet-h to the w, (MF, TA,) and it is also mentioned as with kesr, (TA,) [and is written in both of my copies of the S OaXaAwaI, though if with kesr it should be either OaXaAwK or OaXaAwiIRu, but OaXaAwaI only is meant by J, as is shown by what here follows,] originally OaXaAyiIRu, with three I s, not OaXaAYiIRu as J says, [or rather as the word is written in copies of the S, for J may have held it to be OaXaAYiIRu or OaXaAyiIoCu, as he says that the C was changed into I thus occasioning the combination of three Is, so that he held its secondary form to be OaXaAyiIRu, as will presently be shown,] because the first I is radical, not augmentative, (IB, K,) the medial I of the three being suppressed, and the final one changed into A [though written I], and the initial one changed into w, (S,) and another form of pl. is OaXaAyaA, (S, Msb, K,) with the I preserved, not changed into w [as it is in OaXaAwaI], (TA,) [likewise] a pl. of OaXoyaMCu, (Msb,) and OaXayaAyaA also is mentioned, (K,) as formed [from OaXoyaMCu] by the change of C into I and adding A, (TA,) and OaXaAwihu, which is strange, (Lh, K,) as there is no h in OaXayaMCu, (Lh,) or in XaIoCN: (K:) with respect to the first of these forms, [the quasi-pl. n.] OaXayaMCu, the most probable opinion is that of Kh: (Msb, TA:) accord. to him, (S, Msb, K,) it is originally of the measure faEolaMCu, (S, K, *) in lieu of OafoEaAlN, (K,) and therefore imperfectly decl., (S,) [i. e.] it is originally XayoYaMCu, (Msb,) and the two hemzehs combined in the latter portion being found difficult of pronunciation, the former of them is transposed to the beginning of the word, so that it becomes of the measure lafoEaMCu, (S, Msb,) as is shown by its having for its pls. OaXaAwaI and OaXaAyaA and OaXoyaAwaAtN: (S:) accord. to Akh, it is [originally] of the measure OafoEilaMCu; (S, K;) but if it were thus a broken pl., [not a quasi-pl. n.,] its dim. would not be OuXoyRaMCu↓, as it is, but XuyayoMtN: (S:) accord. to Ks, it is of the measure OafoEaAlN, and made imperfectly decl. because of frequency of usage, being likened to faEolaMCu; but were it so, OabonaMC and OasomaMC would be imperfectly decl.: (S, K:) accord. to Fr, XaIoCN is originally XayRiYN, and therefore has a pl. of the measure OafoEilaMCu, afterwards contracted to faEolaMCu; but were it so, it would not have for its pl. OaXaAwaI. (S. [Much more respecting this pl. is added in the TA, but it is comparatively unprofitable.]) The dim. of XaIoCN is XuyaIoCN↓ and XiyaIoCN↓; (S, K, TA, but only the former in some copies of the K, the word being written in other copies XuiyaIoCN;) not XuwaIRN↓, or XuwaIoCN↓; (the former accord. to my two copies of the S and accord. to the copies of the K followed in the TA, in which it is said to be with teshdeed to the I, and the latter accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K;) or this is a dial. var. of weak authority, (K,) used by post-classical poets in their verses. (MF, TA.) ― -b2- When a man says to thee, “ What dost thou desire? ” thou answerest, laA XayoYFA [Nothing]: and when he says, “ Why didst thou that? ” thou answerest, lilaA XaIoCK [For nothing]: and when he says, “ What is thine affair? ” thou answerest, laA XaIoCN [Nothing]: it is with tenween in every one of these cases. (As, AHát, TA.) [When one says laA XaIoCa, he means thereby There is nothing.] ― -b3- layosa biXaIoCK means [It is nought, of no account or weight; it is not worthy of notice, or not worth anything;] it is not a good thing; or it is not a thing to be regarded. (W p. 27.) ― -b4- [layosa mina AlOamori fiI XaIoCK is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning He has no concern with the affair; see two exs. in the first paragraph of art. HwS. ― -b5- fiyhi XaIoCKi mina AlTRuwli occurs in the TA voce HusobaAnapN, meaning In it is somewhat, or some degree, of length; i. e. it is somewhat long; and is used in the present day in this sense.] ― -b6- In the phrase huwa OaHosanu minoka XayoYFA, the last word is for biXaIoCK [i. e. He is better than thou in something; meaning he is somewhat better than thou]. (IJ, L.) ― -b7- maA Oagofalahu Eanoka XayoYFA is a phrase of the Arabs [app. lit. signifying How unmindful of thee is he as to anything!] mentioned by Sb as meaning daEi AlXRakRa Eanoka [Dismiss doubt from thee (respecting him as to anything)]: IJ says that XyYA is here put in the accus. case as an inf. n., as though the saying were maA Oagofalahu Eanoka gufuwlFA, because the verb of wonder does not require to be corroborated by the inf. n. [proper to it]: (L, TA:) [or it is a specificative:] IF says that it is a phrase of dubious meaning; and that the most probable explanation of it is this; that mA is here lit. interrogative, but in meaning denotative of wonder; and that XyYA is governed in the accus. case by some other word, or phrase, as though the saying were dismiss a thing by which he is not occupied in mind, and dismiss doubt as to his being occupied in mind by it. (TA in art. mA.) ― -b8- [XayoYFA faXayoYFA means Thing by thing, part by part, bit by bit, piecemeal, inch by inch, drop by drop, little and little in succession, by little and little, by degrees or gradually.] ― -b9- OaIRu XaIoCK [meaning What thing?] is, by the alleviation of the I [in AIR] and the suppression of the C [in XIC], made into one word, OayoXaIo: so says El-Fárábee: (Msb:) or, [as is commonly the case in the present day,] by reason of frequency of usage, it is contracted into OayoXa. (TA in art. jrm, as on the authority of Ks.) ― -b10- XaIoCN in the Kur lx. 11 may mean Any one (Bd, Jel) or more. (Jel.) ― -b11- [It is also applied to (assumed tropical:) The penis of a man; as in the explanation of a phrase mentioned voce canabN; like as its syn. hanN is to the same and (more commonly) to the “ vulva ” of a woman.] ― -b12- In algebra, it signifies [A square root;] a number that is multiplied into itself; which in arithmetic [and in algebra also] is called jcr [i. e. jacorN]; and in geometry, DlE [i. e. DiloEN or DilaEN]; (“ Dict. of the Techn. Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans, ” p. 202;) an unknown number that is multiplied into itself.
(Idem, p. 730.) ＝ -A2- It is also said, on the authority of Lth, to signify Water: and he cites as an ex.,
taraI rakobahu biAlXRaIoCi fiI wasoTi qaforapK
[Thou seest, or wilt see, his company of riders at the water in the midst of a desert]: but AM says, I know not AlXIC in the sense of “ water, ” nor know I what it is. (TA.) ＝ -A3- yaA XaIoCa is an expression of regret, (El-Ahmar, Ks, TA,) or of wonder, (K, TA,) [or of both,] meaning [Oh! or] O my wonder! (Ks, Lh, TA.) One says, yaA XaIoCa maA liI, (El-Ahmar, Ks, Lh, K,) and yaA XaIRa maA liI, i. e. with and without C, (Ks, TA,) and yaA haIoCa maA liI, (Lh, K,) yA haIRa mA lI, and yaA faIRa mA lI, (El-Ahmar, Ks, TA,) neither of these two with C, (Ks, TA,) [meaning Oh! or O my wonder! What has happened to me?] in all of these, (Ks, TA,) mA being in the place of a noun in the nom. case. (Ks, Lh, TA.) ― -b2- Some also say, yaA XaIoCa and yaA haIRa and yaA faIRa, and some add maA, saying, yaA XaIoCa maA and yaA haIRa maA and yaA faIRa maA, meaning How good, or beautiful, is this! (Ks, TA.)

XiyoYapN c
XiyoYapN [Will, wish, or desire,] a subst. from XaMCahu, (Lh, K,) [and] so is maXiyoYapN↓ [which is mentioned in the K as an inf. n.]. (Msb.) One says, kulRu XaIoCK biXiyoYapi QllRehi, (S, K,) i. e. bamiXiyoYatihi↓ [Everything is by the will of God]. (S.)

XuyaIoCN c
XuyaIoCN and XiyaIoCN and XuwaIRN or XuwaIoCN: see XaIoCN in the middle of the paragraph.

XayRiMnN c
XayRiMnN and XayRaMnN: see art. XwO.

OuXayRaMCu c
OuXayRaMCu dim. of OaXoyaMCu: see XaIoCN, in the latter part of the former half of the paragraph.

maXiyoYapN c
maXiyoYapN: see XiyoYapN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also XaIoCN, near the beginning of the paragraph.

muXayRaON c
muXayRaON Incongruous, unsound, (K, TA,) foul, or ugly, (TA,) in make, or formation. (K, TA. [See Ham p. 192.]) ― -b2- And accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, A child born preposterously, the legs coming forth before the arms. (TA.)

1 XaAba c
1. XaAba, aor. yaXiybu, inf. n. XayobN and XayobapN (Msb, TA) and maXiybN, (TA,) He became whitehaired, or hoary. (Msb, TA.) And XAb raOosuhu (S,) and raOosuhaA, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. XayobN and XayobapN, (S,) His head, and her head, became white, or hoary. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] XaAbato ruWuwsu AlMkaAmi (tropical:) [The heads, or summits, of the hills became white, or hoary]. (A.) ＝ -A2- And XAb AlrRaOosa It whitened the head: so expl. by ISk as used in the following saying, (S,) ascribed by J to 'Adee, but it is of 'Abeed Ibn-El-Abras: (IB, TA:)
taSobuw waOanRaI laka AltRaSaAbiI
waAlrRaOosu qado XaAbahu AlmaXiybu↓
[Thou inclinest to silly and youthful conduct: but whence cometh to thee the inclining to such conduct when hoariness, or the entering upon the period of hoariness, hath whitened the head?]. (S, * IB, TA.) [See also 2.]

2 XyRbhu AlHuzonu c
2. XyRbhu AlHuzonu, (Ks, S, A,) and XyRb AlHuzonu raOosahu, and biraOosihi, (Ks, S, Msb, K,) which last is a strange phrase, as it exhibits together two means by which a verb is rendered trans., [namely, the doubling of the medial radical letter of the verb and the introduction of the prep. bi,] (TA,) Grief rendered him white-headed, or hoary-headed; (Ks, S, A, Msb, K;) as also AXAbhu↓, (A,) and AXAb↓ raOosahu and biraOosihi. (Ks, S, Msb, K. *)

4 AXAb c
4. AXAb, said of a man, He had children that had become white-headed, or hoary. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

XayobN c
XayobN The hair (K, TA) itself: sometimes it is thus called: (TA:) [but app. only when white, or hoary; in which sense it is often used; as in the TA in arts. xDb and Sbg &c.:] or (K, TA, in the CK “ and ”) whiteness of the hair, or hoariness; (A, K, TA;) as also maXiybN↓: (K, TA:) both signify the same [and are thus used as simple substs. and are also inf. ns.]: (S:) or the former has the latter of the two significations given above; (As, S, Mgh, Msb;) and is little and much [whiteness of the hair]: one says, EalaAhu AlXRayobu [Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, came upon him]: (TA:) but maXiybN↓ signifies a man's entering upon the period of whiteness of the hair, or hoariness: (As, S, Msb:) see an ex. of this latter in the first paragraph. In the phrase in the Kur [xix. 3], waQXotaEala AlrRaOosu XayobFA, (S,) meaning And whiteness of the hair of the head hath spread therein like as the radiance of fire spreads in firewood, (Jel,) [or the head has become glistening with whiteness of the hair, or hoariness,] XybA is in the accus. case as a specificative: or, accord. to Akh, as an inf. n., as though it were said waXaAba AlrRaOosu XayobFA. (S, TA. *)

XiybN c
XiybN, of a whip, a genuine Arabic word of wellknown meaning; (S;) The thong (K, TA) at the upper extremity (TA) of a whip: (K, TA:) there are two of such thongs, called XiybaAni. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A word imitative of the sounds made by the lips of camels (S, K) in drinking. (S.) ＝ -A3- And pl. of OaXoyabu [q. v.]. (S, K, &c.)

XuyubN c
XuyubN a pl. of which the sing. is doubted: see OaXoyabu.

XayobapN c
XayobapN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And accord. to El-Khafájee, A white, or hoary, beard: but MF says that this is a conventional postclassical meaning. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Also, in the present day, applied to A species of artemisia; (Forskål's Flor. Aegypt. Arab., p. lxxiii., no. 439;) the artemisia arborescens of Linn.: (Delile's Flor. Aegypt. Illustr., no. 799:) ― -b2- and Lichen; (Forskål ubi suprà;) the lichen prunastri of Linn. (Delile, ib., no. 976 (assumed tropical:).) And Xayobapu Aljabali Lichen scyphifer. (Forskål, p. lxxviii., no. 559.)]

XayobaAnu c
XayobaAnu: see OaXoyabu; near the end of the paragraph: ― -b2- and see also the paragraph here following.

XiybaAnu c
XiybaAnu and miloHaAnu, (S, A,) thus in a verse of El-Kumeyt, as related by Ibn-Selemeh, with kesr to the X and m, (S,) or the former word is written XayobaAnu↓, and sometimes XiybaAnu, and the latter is as above, (K,) and sometimes maloHaAnu, (TA,) (tropical:) The two months of winter; (A, TA;) [as though meaning the second of the Six Seasons, commencing two months after the autumnal equinox; (see the former of the two tables in p. 1254;)] i. q. XahoraA qimaAHK, (S, A, K, TA,) which are the two coldest months; (S, K, TA;) so called because of the earth's being then white with snow and hoar frost; (S, TA;) falling at the period of the [auroral] rising of the Scorpion and the Vulture, (AlEaqorab and AlnRasor, [by which latter is meant AlnRasoru AlwaAqiEu, i. e. the star a of Lyra,]) said by him who knows not to be the two Kánoons [i. e. kaAnuwnu AlOawRalu and kaAnuwnu AlvRaAniI, corresponding to December and January O.S.]: (TA:) [it appears that they nearly agree with the two Kánoons; for El-Kazweenee and others say that Alqalobu (i. e. the heart of the Scorpion, which is the 18th of the Mansions of the Moon,) and AlnRasoru AlwaAqiEu rise together, and their auroral rising in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, accord. to my calculation, (see manaAzilu Alqamari in art. nzl,) was on the 25th of November O. S.: see also miloHaAnu, and qimaAHN: it is also said that] XiybaAnu [used alone] is a name of [the month] kAnwn AlAwRl, because of the whiteness of the earth by reason of the hoar-frost and snow. (Mgh.)

XiyaAbN c
XiyaAbN and XiyaAbapN [the former erroneously written by Golius XayRaAbN]: see XawobN, in art. Xwb.

XayuwbN c
XayuwbN: see OaXoyabu.

XaAYibN c
XaAYibN [Being, or becoming, white-haired, or hoary]: see OaXoyabu. ― -b2- XayobN XaAYibN is a phrase like layolN laAYilN, (S,) or like XiEorN XaAEirN: it means Intense whiteness of the hair. (TA.)

OaXoyabu c
OaXoyabu White-haired, white-headed, or horary: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) [it is said to be] anomalous in form; (S, Mgh, Msb;) for an epithet of this measure is only formed [by rule] from a verb of the measure faEila, aor. yafoEalu; (S, TA;) and it is a condition of the formation of such an epithet that it must denote a defect or the like, or a colour: but OaXoyabu signifies white-headed, or hoaryheaded; [so that it does denote a colour;] and ElKhafájee says that it is reckoned among epithets denoting defects, or blemishes, like OaEomaI and OaEoraju: (MF, TA:) it is said in the K that it has no faEolaMC, i. e., (TA,) the epithet XayobaMCu is not applied to a woman; (Msb, TA;) XamoTaMCu being used in its stead; (TA;) though one says XaAba raOosuhaA: (Msb, TA:) [but see Har p. 418, where XayobaMCu is mentioned, applied to a woman, as meaning aged, and white, or hoary, in the head: and see XayobaMCu in art. Xwb:] the pl. is XiybN; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) with which is syn. XuyRabN; (TA, as from the K; [but not found by me in the copies of the K to
which I have had access;]) and XuyubN↓: (K, TA:) this last is said by IM to be allowable in poetry, EalaI AltRamaAmi [here meaning as though it were a word composed of sound letters]; and this is the assertion of the lexicologists [in general]: ISd thinks it to be pl. of XaAYibN↓ [q. v.], like as buzulN is of baAzilN; or pl. of XayuwbN↓ [which app. means very white or hoary in the head], accord. to the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, who say dajaAjapN bayuwDN and dajaAjN buyuDN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, raOayotu AljibaAla XiybFA (tropical:) I saw the mountains white with snow and hoar frost. (A, TA.) And XiybN [used alone] signifies (assumed tropical:) Mountains upon which snow falls, and which are white, or hoary, therewith: (S, L:) or mountains white with snow or with dust: and, some say, white clouds: sing. OaXoyabu. (L, TA.) And, applied to truffles (kamoOap), (assumed tropical:) White and large: (TA:) or simply white. (Id. voce taEaAXiybu.) ― -b3- yawomN OaXoyabu (assumed tropical:) A day in which are cold and clouds and SuraAd [correctly SurRaAd, meaning thin clouds, or cold and humid clouds, in which is no water]; as also yawomN XayobaAnu↓. (K.) ― -b4- layolapu AlXRayobaMCi, (K,) or layolapu XayobaMCa, (TA,) and layolapN XayobaMCu, (TA voce HurRN,) (assumed tropical:) The last night of the [lunar] month: (K, TA:) its first night is called layolapu HurRapK and layolapN HurRapN.
