(K voce HurRN.) baAtato bilayolapi XayobaMCa, and bilayolapi AlXRayobaMCi: see in art. Xwb.

maXiybN c
maXiybN: see XayobN, in two places.

1 XaAHa c
1. XaAHa: see 4. ― -b2- [Also, accord. to Freytag, on the authority of the “ Kitáb el-Addád, ” He was brave, or bold: thus having two contr. significations. ― -b3- Another meaning assigned to it by him, in common with XaAyaHa and OaXaAHa, as on the authority of the K, i. e. “ Diligens fuit, ” is a mistake.]

2 XyRHhu c
2. XyRHhu, (O,) inf. n. taXoyiyHN, (K,) He cautioned him; or made him to fear, or be in fear. (O, K. *) ― -b2- And He removed him, or it, far away. (O.) ＝ -A2- And XyRH, (O, TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He looked at his adversary, or antagonist, and straitened him, or treated him with hardness or harshness: (O, K, * TA:) from IAar. (TA.)

3 XaAoyaHa
3: see the next paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- Also He fought. (T, K.)

4 AXAH c
4. AXAH, (S, A, K,) inf. n. UiXaAHapN, (IAar, TA,) He was cautious, or in fear, (S, A, K,) minohu [of it], (A, TA,) i. e. a thing, or an affair, (TA,) and EalaI HaAjatihi [for the thing that he wanted]; (K;) as also XAyH↓, (S, A, K,) inf. muXaAyaHapN and XiyaAHN; and XaAHa↓: (K:) or he was cautious and in fear, endeavouring to repel death. (L.) ― -b2- But in the dial. of Hudheyl, (S,) He strove, laboured, toiled, or exerted himself, fiI OamorK [in an affair]; and so XAyH↓. (S, A.) ― -b3- And He continued journeying, or going on. (O.) ― -b4- AXAH biwajohihi He turned away his face, (S, A, TA,) from a [person or] thing, or from the heat of fire, or a hot odour, and from something hurtful: (TA:) or he exerted himself in aversion or turning away. (IAar, TA.) One says, kalRamotuhu faOaXaAHa biwajohihi I spoke to him, and he turned away his face. (A.) ― -b5- AXAH also signifies He advanced, or came forward; syn. Oaqobala. (Fr, O, TA.) [Thus it has two contr. meanings. See also the part. n., muXiyHN.] ― -b6- And He defended what was behind his back. (IAth, TA.) [See, again, the part. n.] ― -b7- AXAH bicanabihi, said of a horse, He let his tail hang down loosely. (Lth, S.) F, in the K, following Az and Sgh, says that this is a mistranscription of the verb, for AsAH; but his assertion requires proof. (MF.) [See the latter verb, in art. syH.] ＝ -A2- AXAHt AlOaroDu The land produced the plant called XiyH. (AHn, O, K.)

XiyHN c
XiyHN Cautious, or fearing; (A, K;) as also XaAYiHN↓, (A, TA,) and muXiyHN↓: (As, O:) or this last, cautious, or fearing, and at the same time striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself: (Az, TA:) or all signify prudent; discreet; or having, or using, precaution, or good judgment; (Ham p. 281;) and so XayoHaAnu↓. (Id. p. 43.) ― -b2- In the dial. of Hudheyl, (S, O,) Striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, (S, A, O, K,) in affairs; (S, O, K;) and so XaAYiHN↓, (A, K,) and muXiyHN↓: (As, O, K:) pl. of the first [and app. of the second also] XiyaAHN: (S, O.) ＝ -A2- Also [The artemisia Judaïca; and absinthium Ponticum; species of wormwood;] a certain plant, (AHn, S, A, O, K,) well known, (AHn, O, K,) of several species, (AHn, O,) of some [species] whereof brooms are made, (L,) [and which is also used for fumigation,] the leaves of which are [of the kind called] hadab; (AHn, O, L;) it has a sweet odour, but its taste is bitter; is pasture for horses and camels; and the places of its growth are the plains and the meadows: (AHn, O, L:) pl. XiyHaAnN. (Fr, O, L.) ＝ -A3- Accord. to the K, [probably on the authority of Lth,] it signifies also A [garment of the kind called] burod, of El-Yemen: but Az says that there is no kind of garment so called: the correct word is sayoHN, with [the unpointed] s [and with fet-h]. (TA.)

XayoHaAnu c
XayoHaAnu [and probably with tenween also]: see XiyHN. ― -b2- Also Very jealous; (S, O, K;) because such is cautious for his wives, or women under covert, or household or family; (S, O;) and so XaAYiHN↓. (K.) ― -b3- Also, (O, K,) and XiyHaAnN↓, (As, O, K,) Tall: (O, K:) or goodly in tallness. (L.) ― -b4- And the former, That makes, or utters, a low sound in running; [so I render yatahamRasu EadowFA in the K and TA; in the O and in my MS. copy of the K, yatahamRaXu; but the former I think the right reading; app. by reason of quickness, or swiftness; for it is added,] quickness, or swiftness, is meant thereby: (O, TA: *) mentioned by Az, on the authority of Khálid Ibn-Jembeh. (TA.) [In this sense it seems to be with tenween: for] XayoHaAnapN [is its fem. and] means A quick, or swift, she-camel. (S, O.) ― -b5- Also A horse strong in spirit; syn. Xadiydu AlnRafosi; (O, K, TA; in the CK, AlnRafasi [i. e. in breath];) and so XiyHaAnN↓: thus expl. by Skr. (O.)

XiyHaAnN c
XiyHaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

XiyaAHN c
XiyaAHN Mutual caution or fear. (And The act of striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting oneself, in anything. (K.) [But in both of these senses it seems to be an inf. n. of 3, q. v.] ＝ -A2- Also (K) Drought, dearth, scarcity. (O, K.)

XaAYiHN c
XaAYiHN: see XiyHN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also XayoHaAnu.

muXiyHN c
muXiyHN: see XiyHN, in two places. It is also expl. as meaning Striving, labouring, toiling, or exerting himself, and persevering in his work: (A:) and striving &c., and hastening, or going quickly. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Advancing, or coming forward, to one. (Fr, O, K.) ― -b3- And Defending what is behind one's back. (Fr, O, K.)

muXayRaHN c
muXayRaHN is expl. as meaning Striped; applied to a garment: but Az says that there is no such word, so applied: the correct word is musayRaHN, with [the unpointed] s. (TA.)

maXiyHaI c
maXiyHaI: see the following paragraph.

maXiyHaMC c
maXiyHaMC: see the following paragraph.

maXoyuwHaI c
maXoyuwHaI: see the following paragraph.

maXoyuwHaMCu c
maXoyuwHaMCu (S, O, K) and maXiyHaI↓ (O, K) A state of haste: (S, O, K:) or a state of confusion: (K:) the latter meaning mentioned in the L: (TA:) you say, humo fiI maXoyuwHaMCa mino Oamorihimo (S, O, K) and fI maXiyHaI mn Amrhm (O, K) They are in a state of haste in respect of their affair: (S, O, K:) or in a state of confusion in their affair: (L, K:) as having the latter meaning, Ibn-Málik says that it is maXiyjaMC, with j and medd, of the measure faEiylaMC, not mafoEilaMC; but this requires consideration: Ibn-Umm-Málik and others, following AHei, say that Alqawomu fiI maXiyHaMCa↓ mino Oamorihimo means the people, or party, are in a state of striving, labour, toil, or exertion, and determination, or resolution, in respect of their affair. (TA.) ＝ -A2- maXoyuwHaMCu also signifies A land that produces the plant called XiyH; (S, O, K;) and so maXoyuwHaI↓: (O, K:) or it signifies many plants of the kind so called: thus in the T, on the authority of As and A 'Obeyd, and so says AHn, as is stated [in the O and] in the R; (TA;) AHn saying further that it is like maXoyuwxaMC meaning a company of Xuyuwx [or elderly men], and maEoyuwraMC meaning a herd of Euyuwr [or asses], &c.; (O;) [so that it is a quasi-pl. n.;] but this is disallowed by El-Mufaddal Ibn-Selemeh. (TA.)

1 XaAxa c
1. XaAxa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yaXiyxu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. XayaxN, with fet-h to the I, (S, K,) and
XuyuwxapN (K) and XiyuwxapN (TA) and XuyuwxiyRapN (K) and XiyuwxiyRapN (Zbd, TA) and XayoxuwxapN [the most common form, respecting which see what follows,] (S, A, Msb, K) and XayoxuwxiyRapN; (K;) and XyRx↓, inf. n. taXoyiyxN; (S, A, K;) and tXyRx↓; (K;) He became a Xayox [i. e. an old, or elderly, man; &c.]: (S, A, Msb, K:) in XayoxuwxapN, the I is originally movent [with fet-h], and afterwards made quiescent, for there is not in the language a word of the measure faEoluwlN [except SaEofuwqN, as is said in the S in art. Hyd]: as to the similar words whose medial radical letter is w, as kayonuwnapN and qayoduwdapN and dayomuwmapN and hayoEuwEapN, these are originally kayRanuwnapN [for kayowanuwnapN, of the measure fayoEaluwlapN,] and the like, and are contracted; for were it not so, they would be kawonuwnapN and the like. (S, L.)

2 XyRx c
2. XyRx: see the preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- XyRxhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taXoyiyxN, (TA,) He called him by the appellation of Xayox, to pay him honour, or respect. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A3- And XyRx Ealayohi He attributed or imputed to him, or charged him with, a vice, or fault; blamed, or reproached, him; (K, TA;) cast a bad, an evil, a foul, or an excessively bad or evil or foul, imputation upon him. (TA.) And XyRx bihi [and so XyRxhu accord. to an explanation of XayRaxotu Alrjl, as on the authority of AZ, in the TA, but this may be a mistranscription for XyRxt biAlrRajuli,] He exposed his vices, faults, or evil actions; disgraced him; or put him to shame. (K, TA.)

5 tXyRx c
5. tXyRx: see 1. ― -b2- [It signifies also] He feigned, or made a show of, old age. (KL.)

XayoxN c
XayoxN (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K, &c.) and XayoxuwnN↓, (K,) but the latter is a strange word, mentioned by some of the expositors of the Fs, as expressing more than the former word, (MF,) [An old, or elderly, man; an elder, as meaning a man whose age gives him a claim to reverence or respect; a senior;] one advanced in age, (Mgh,) such as is beyond him who is termed kaholN, (Mgh, Msb,) which means him whose XabaAb [i. e. youthfulness, or prime of manhood,] is ended: (Mgh:) one in whom age has become apparent, (L, K,) and hoariness: (L:) or a man from the age of fifty, or fifty-one, to the end of his life, or to the age of eighty: (L, K:) also expl. as meaning a man advanced in age but having strength, or vigour, to fight: and an old and weak, or a decrepit, man, who is of no service: (Mgh:) [in the present day, XayoxN is used in the senses above mentioned; and is also especially applied, as an appellation of honour, to a doctor of religion and law; a head, or chief, of a religious confraternity; a chief of a tribe or the like, and of a village; and to a reputed saint:] fem. XayoxapN↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) an old, or aged, woman; syn. EajuwzN: (A:) [and applied in the present day particularly to a learned woman; an instructress; and the like:] the pl. [of pauc.] of XayoxN is OaXoyaAxN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and XiyxapN (Kr, ISd, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of mult.] XuyuwxN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and XiyuwxN (K, with kesr, to agree with the I, TA) and XiyxaAnN (S, A, Msb, K) and XiyaxapN (S, Mgh, K) and XayaxapN (A [there said to be like EabadapN]) and maXoyaxapN↓, (K, and so in one of my copies of the S,) or this last is a quasi-pl. n., (Mgh, Msb,) and [so are] miXoyaxapN↓ and maXoyuxapN↓ and miXoyuxapN↓ (TA) and maXiyxapN↓ (K, and so in one of my copies of the S,) and maXoyuwxaMCu↓, (S, K,) the last like maXoyuwHaMCu and maEoluwjaMCu and masoluwmaMCu and maEobuwdaMCu and maEoyuwraMCu, which are said to be the only other instances of this form, (TA,) [but to these should be added maHomuwraMCu and makobuwraMCu and matoyuwsaMCu and perhaps some other instances,] and maXoyuxaMCu↓, (K,) and another pl. is maXaAyixu↓, (S, A, K,) or this last is pl. of maXoyaxapN, (Mgh, Msb,) and is disallowed by IDrd and Kz (TA) [though very commonly used in the present day, especially as applied to doctors of religion and law]; and the pl. of OaXoyaAxN is OaXaAyiyxu, like OanaAyiybu pl. of OanoyaAbN: (Z, TA:) the dim. of XayoxN is XuyayoxN↓ (S, A, K) and XiyayoxN↓, (S, K,) with kesr to the X: (S:) XuwayoxN↓ is not allowable, (S, A,) or is rare. (K.) ― -b2- [AlXRayoxaAni, The two Sheykhs, is a title peculiarly applied to the first two Khaleefehs, Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar.] ― -b3- XayoxN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A woman's husband, (K,) though young: and in like manner, a man's wife, whether old or young, is called his Eajuwz. (Az, TA in art. Ejz.) ― -b4- [And (tropical:) An ancestor. Accord. to a copy of the A that seems to have been used by the author of the TA, one says, wariva mino maXiyxapi Alkaram and mn OaXoyaAxihi, which is tropical, meaning mino MbaAYihi: but the right reading is evidently mn maXiyxatihi↓, and Alkarama; and the meaning, (tropical:) He inherited, from his ancestors, generosity.] ― -b5- Xayoxu AlnRaAri means (tropical:) Iblees: because he was created of fire, or because his ultimate place will be the fire of Hell. (Har p. 130.) ― -b6- And AlXRayoxu (assumed tropical:) The mountain-goat that is advanced in age, or fullgrown. (TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) The milk-skin. (TA.) ― -b8- OaXoyaAxu AlnRujuwmi i. q. OuSuwluhaA, (K,) i. e. (assumed tropical:) The seven [or five] planets; (TK;) or the daraAriIoC [also applied by some to the five planets, Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn]; accord. to IAar, AXyAx Alnjwm, (TA in this art.,) or OasonaAxu AlnRujuwmi as is related by Th, (TA in art. snx,) means the stars that do not make their [temporary] abode in the Mansions of the Moon, which [latter] are called nujuwmu AlOaxoci: ISd says, I think that he means, by the njwm, the fixed stars: Th says that they are called only OasonaAxu AlnRujuwmi, i. e. the OuSuwl thereof, around which the [other] stars revolve, and pursue their courses. (TA. [See also sinoxN, last sentence.]) ＝ -A2- XayoxN signifies also A certain tree; (AZ, K, TA;) also called Xajarapu AlXRuyuwxi, the fruit of which is a jirow [q. v.] like that of the xirRiyE, which is the bastard saffron (Xajarapu AlEuSofuri); it grows in the meadows, and the quroyaAn [or places where water runs to, or in, or into, meadows, &c.]. (AZ, TA.)

XayoxapN c
XayoxapN fem. of XayoxN, q. v. (S, A, Msb, K.)

XayoxuwnN c
XayoxuwnN: see XayoxN.

XuyayoxN c
XuyayoxN and XiyayoxN and XuwayoxN: dims. of XayoxN, q. v.

maXoyaxapN c
maXoyaxapN and miXoyaxapN &c.; and the pl. maXaAyixu: see XayoxN, in seven places.

maXoyuxaMCu c
maXoyuxaMCu: see XayoxN.

maXoyuwxaMCu c
maXoyuwxaMCu: see XayoxN.

1 XaAdahu c
1. XaAdahu, aor. yaXiydu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. XayodN, (S,) He plastered it (a wall) with Xiyd, (S, K,) i. e. gypsum, or the like: (K:) he built it (a structure) with Xiyd, meaning gypsum. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 2. ― -b3- XaAduwA AldRiyna (assumed tropical:) They strengthened and exalted the religion: from XaAda in the first of the senses expl. above: (Har p. 5:) [or rather from this verb as syn. with XayRada and OaXaAda.] ― -b4- See also 4. ― -b5- As inf. n. of XaAda in the phrase XaAda biAlUibili, aor. as above, (TK,) XiyaAdN signifies (assumed tropical:) The calling camels, (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K, TA,) as also UiXaAdapN↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) raising the voice in doing so. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, (K,) as inf. n. of the same verb, (TK,) (assumed tropical:) The rubbing perfume with the skin; (K;) as also taXayRudN↓; in some copies of the K, taXoyiydN↓: (TA:) [the former of these two seems to be the right; and the meaning seems to be, the rubbing the skin with perfume; for,] accord. to AA, one says bihecaA AlTRiybi taXayRado↓, meaning Rub thy skin with this perfume. (O.) ＝ -A2- XaAda, (said of a man, TA,) aor. as above, (K,) inf. n. XayodN, (TA,) also signifies He perished, or died. (K.)

2 XyRdhu c
2. XyRdhu, (A, L, Msb, TA,) inf. n. taXoyiydN, (L, Msb, TA,) He raised it high; (A, Msb, TA;) namely, a palace, (A,) or a building; (Msb, TA;) as also AXAdhu↓, (A, L, TA,) and XaAdahu↓: (A: [this last is app. included with the two other verbs, in the A, as having this meaning, which is confirmed, as pertaining to it, by an explanation of its pass. part. n., maXiydN, q. v.:]) or XyRdhu [implies a repetition of the act of building: (see maXiydN:) or] signifies he built it firmly, or strongly, and raised it high. (L.) ― -b2- See also 1.

4 AXAdhu c
4. AXAdhu: see 2. ― -b2- Hence, (L,) UiXaAdapN signifies (tropical:) The raising the voice in saying a thing (Lth, S, L, K) [of any kind, or] such as one's companion dislikes; like tanodiydN. (Lth, L.) See also 1. You say, AXAd Sawotahu and biSawotihi (tropical:) He raised his voice. (A.) And AXAd bihi (tropical:) He proclaimed it, or cried it, raising his voice; namely, a stray, or any other thing: (As, L:) (tropical:) he made it known; (AA, S, A,
K; *) namely, a stray. (S, K.) And AXAd bicikorihi (tropical:) He raised his good fame, by praising him; raised a good report of him: (S, * A, L:) and he raised his ill fame, by dispraising him; raised an evil report of him: and AXAdhu and XaAdahu↓ he raised his notoriety or fame. (L.) And AXAd Ealayohi (tropical:) He published against him something disliked, disapproved, or odious: one says, AXAd Ealayohi qabiyHFA and biqabiyHK (tropical:) [He published against him something bad, evil, abominable, or foul]. (A.) ― -b3- And UiXaAdapN also signifies (tropical:) The act of destroying: (K, TA:) from the same word as syn. with tanodiydN. (TA.)

5 taXayRada
5: see 1, in two places.

XayodN c
XayodN, a Pers. word, [or rather of Pers. origin, from XayodaA,] Possessed; or mad, or insane: or intoxicated. (TA.)

XiydN c
XiydN Anything with which a wall is plastered, (S, A, K,) consisting of gypsum and the like; (A, K;) J says, of gypsum or balaAT; but this last word is a mistake, [probably originated by an early transcriber of the S,] for milaAT, i. e. mud, or clay: (K:) or [peculiarly] gypsum. (Msb.) ― -b2- Az says that some of the Arabs sometimes call thus A HiSon [i. e. fortress, fort, or fortified place]. (TA.)

maXiydN c
maXiydN Plastered with Xiyd; and so, as some say, muXayRadN↓: (T:) or built with gypsum: (Msb:) or made with Xyd, (S, A, K,) i. e. gypsum; and so, some say, muXayRadN↓: (A:) or the latter signifies raised high, or made lofty; (A 'Obeyd, S, A, K;) and so the former, applied to a place, (A,) or building: (TA:) the former has this meaning in the Kur xxii. 44: (Jel:) J says in the S, Ks says, maXiydN is applied to a sing., from the saying in the Kur, [ubi suprà,] waqaSorK maXiydK; and muXayRadN↓, to a pl., from the saying in the same, [iv. 80,] fiI buruwjK muXayRadapK: but this is a mistake: what Ks says is that muXayRadapN, with p and teshdeed, is a pl. [i. e. a lexicological, not a grammatical, pl.] of muXayRadN: (IB, K: *) or the saying of Ks [if as quoted in the S] may be expl. accord. to the opinion of those who hold that maXiydN and muXayRadN both signify plastered with Xiyd, on the supposition that the Arabs did not use maXiydapN as applied to a pl., but only to a sing.: (Az, L:) [for] Fr says that the pass. part. n. of the unaugmented verb only is used when applied to a sing. and not denoting repetition, or muchness; but either this or the pass. part. n. of the verb of the measure faERala may be used when applied to a sing. and denoting repetition, or muchness, and when applied to a pl.: thus you say kaboXN macobuwHN [“ a slaughtered ram ”]; but not mucabRaHN; but you may say vawobN muxarRaqN [as meaning “ a garment in which holes have been repeatedly made, ” or “ in which many holes have been made, ” or “ much pierced with holes, ” as well as vawobN maxoruwqN meaning “ a garment in which a hole has been made, ” or “ in which holes have been made, ”] and kibaAXN mucabRaHapN [“ slaughtered rams ”]: and hence you may say qaSorN muXayRadN↓; because taXoyiydN denotes building, and the act of building is repeated, and a building becomes high by degrees. (L.)

muXayRadN c
muXayRadN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

6 tXAyr c
6. tXAyr: see 6 in art. Xwr.

XiyarN c
XiyarN: n. un. with p: pl. of the latter XiyaraAtN: and dim. XuyayorapN and XiyayorapN: see XajarN.

XiyaArN c
XiyaArN: see art. Xwr.

XayRirN c
XayRirN: see art. Xwr.

XiyzN c
XiyzN and XiyzaI↓ A kind of black wood, of which bowls (qiSaAE) are made: (S, K:) or the latter is a certain black wood of which combs and bowls (jifaAn) are made: (Mgh:) or ebony: or saAsam [a certain wood of which bows or arrows are made]: (AA, K:) or walnut-wood: (As, EdDeenäwaree [AHn], Mgh, K:) As says of the XyzI, by the name of which the Arabs call bowls (jfAn and qSAE) and the sheaves of pulleys, that it is walnut-wood, but it becomes blackened by grease, and therefore is thus called, and it is not Xyz: so says AHn: and he adds, the case is as he has described it; for the Xyz does not become thick so as that bowls may be carved from it: (Sgh, TA:) of this latter, only combs and the like are made; and it is black: it is also said, in the T, that bowls made from the walnut-tree are called XiyzaI. (TA.)

XiyzaI c
XiyzaI: see the preceding paragraph.

4 AXAXt AlnRaxolapu c
4. AXAXt AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree produced dates such as are termed XiyX. (O, K.)

XiyXN c
XiyXN and XiyXaMCN↓ A sort of dates which do not organize and compact stones; (Fr, O, K;) or, if they do so, they do not become hard; and when they dry, they become such as are termed HaXaf, not sweet: (O, K:) dial. vars. of XiySN and XiySaMCN: (S:) accord. to AHn, (TA,) of Persian origin. (O, TA.)

XiyXaMCN c
XiyXaMCN: see the next preceding paragraph.

2 XayRaSa
2: see the next paragraph.

4 AXASt AlnRaxolapu c
4. AXASt AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree was not fecundated by the flowers, or pollen, of the male tree: (A, K:) or its dates dried up: and it bore dates such as are termed XiyS: (Msb:) or it became bad, and its dates became such as are termed XyS; (TA;) as also XyRSt↓. (Kr, TA.)

5 tXyRS AltRamoru c
5. tXyRS AltRamoru The dates became such as are termed XiyS. (S.)

XiySN c
XiySN Dates of which the stones do not become hard; as also XiySaMCN↓; (S, A, K;) which is only the case when the palm-tree has not been fecundated by the flowers, or pollen, of the male tree: (S:) and sometimes, having no stones: (Fr, TA:) or bad dates: (A:) or the worst of dates; (IF, Msb, K;) as also ↓the latter word: (Msb:) or the worst of dates when full-grown but unripe: (Lth, TA:) called in the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab, SiySN; and by the people of El-Medeeneh, suxRalN: (El-Umawee, TA:) and said by some to be a Persian word, arabicized: (TA:) n. un. with p; (A, Msb, K;) i. e., XiySapN and XiySaMCapN. (A, Msb.)

XiySaMCN c
XiySaMCN: n. un. with p: see XiySN, in two places.

1 XaATa c
1. XaATa, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaXiyTu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. XayoTN and XiyaATapN (K) and XayoTuwTapN, (Lth, K,) It (a thing, Msb, TA, or, as some say, particularly, olive-oil, and rob, TA) burned, or became burnt; (Msb, K, TA;) as also tXyRT↓, (K,) said of flesh-meat: (TA:) or both, said of flesh-meat, signify its upper part became burnt by the contact of fire: (Lth, TA:) the latter is also said of wool; and the former likewise, of wool, and of hair: (TA:) the former also signifies it was near to becoming burnt: (TA:) and, said of clarified butter, and of olive-oil, (S, K,) it became cooked so much that it burned; (S;) because, in that case, it perishes; (O;) [which implies that a signification hereafter to be mentioned is held to be the primary one;] or became thick; or became cooked so much that it almost perished. (K.) You say also, XaATati Alqidoru The cooking-pot burned, and had something sticking in it: (S:) or had something burnt sticking in the bottom of it. (O, K.) ― -b2- XaATa, (S, K,) aor. as above, (S,) also signifies He (a man) perished, or died. (S, K.) [The art. in the S commences with this signification, which, as remarked above, seems to be regarded by some as the primary one.] ― -b3- Also He burned with anger. (TA in art. XTn.) ― -b4- And It was, or became, null, void, of no account, or of no force. (Msb, TA.) ― -b5- His (a man's) blood, (S,) or it, (his blood,) (Mgh, Msb, K,) went (S, Mgh, Msb, K) for nothing, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; it was, or became, of no account. (S, Mgh, * Msb.) ― -b6- And It (any- thing) went away; ― -b7- XaATati Aljazuwru (tropical:) The slaughtered camel became dispensed; syn. tanafRaqat; (S, K, TA;) there remained not of it any portion that was not divided and given: (As, S:) and XaATa laHomu Aljazuwri The flesh of the slaughtered camel went away divided and distributed, nothing thereof remaining. (A, TA.) ― -b8- XaATa also signifies (tropical:) He hastened (S, K, TA) in an affair. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- [XaATahu seems to be dial. var. of saATahu, as signifying He mixed it. ― -b2- And hence,] XaATa AldRimaMCa (tropical:) He mixed the bloods; as though he shed, or poured forth, the blood of the slayer upon that of the slain. (S, K, TA.) A poet, (S,) namely, El-Mutalemmis, (TA,) uses the expression lawo tuXaATu dimaAWunaA [If our bloods were
mixed]; (S, TA;) accord. to one relation; but accord. to another, the verb is with s. (TA.) ― -b3- XaATa bidamihi: see 4.

2 XayRaTa
2: see the next paragraph, in five places.

4 AXAThu c
4. AXAThu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. UiXaATapN, (Msb,) He burned it, or made it to burn; (Msb, K;) namely, a thing, (Msb,) as, for instance, olive-oil; (TA;) as also XyRThu↓, (K,) inf. n. taXoyiyTN. (TA.) ↓The latter also signifies He burned its wool, namely, that of a sheep, in order to cleanse it; and so XwRThu: (S, TA:) and each of these, he (a cook) set it on fire, namely the foot of a bull or cow, or of a sheep or goat, and the head, so that what was upon it, of hair, or wool, became burnt. (TA.) You say also, XAT Alqidora He made the cooking-pot to burn, and to have something sticking in it. (S.) And Alqidora XyRT↓ He made the cooking-pot to boil; as also XwRThA. (ElKilábee.) And AllRaHoma XyRT↓ He cooked thoroughly the flesh-meat; as also XwRThu: (Ibn-'Abbád:) or he smoked it, or made it smoky, and did not thoroughly cook it; (S;) and so the latter. (TA in art. XwT.) And AlDRabuEu AlnRabota XyRT↓; and AldRawaMCu AljuroHa; (tropical:) The year of drought burned the herbage; and the medicine, the wound. (A, TA:) [See also XawRaTa.] ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He destroyed him, or it. (S, K.) ― -b3- AXAT damahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and bidamihi, (S, K,) He (the Sultán, Mgh, Msb) made his blood to go for nothing, unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulct; made it to be of no account: (Mgh, Msb, K, * TA:) or the latter, (TA,) or both, (K,) he laboured to destroy him, or to kill him: (K, TA:) or both, he exposed him to slaughter: (S, K:) or, accord. to IAmb, you say, bidamihi XaATa↓, meaning he exposed him to destruction. (TA.) You say also, AXAT dama Aljazuwri He shed the blood of the camel that was to be slaughtered. (As, K.) ― -b4- AXAT AllRaHoma (tropical:) He distributed the flesh, (K, TA,) i. e. the flesh of a slaughtered camel: (TA:) or AXAT Aljazuwra he dispensed the last remaining portion of the slaughtered camel, after all beside had been distributed. (S, TA.) Also (assumed tropical:) He cut up, or cut in pieces, the flesh of the slaughtered camel before the distribution. (ISh.)

5 taXayRaTa
5: see 1, first sentence.

10 AstXAT c
10. AstXAT (tropical:) He became inflamed by anger; Ealayohi against him: (K, TA:) or he became as though he were inflamed in his anger; accord. to As, from miXoyaATN as applied to a she-camel: (S, TA:) [or] he burned, and became inflamed, by vehement anger. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a man, TA) became brisk, or sharp; (K, * TA;) he burned; (TA;) mina AlOamori by reason of the thing, or affair. (K, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) It (a pigeon) flew briskly. (K, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) He sought to be slain in war or fight. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) He became at the point of destruction. (TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) He (a camel) became fat: (S, TA:) [as though he desired, or demanded, that he should be slaughtered, and that his flesh should be distributed:] or fatness spread in him. (TA.)

XayoTaAn c
XayoTaAn [i. e. XayoTaAnN or XayoTaAnu, accord. to different authorities, as shown below, A devil; and with the article Al, the devil, Satan;] is, accord. to some, from XaATa, (Msb, K, TA,) as signifying “ it was, or became, null, void, of no account; ” and the like: (Msb, TA:) or “ he perished: ” (K, TA:) or “ he went away: ” or “ it burned, ” or “ became burnt: ” two reasons given for this derivation are, that among the names of the devil are Almucohabu and AlbaATilu: and another is this; that several read, in the Kur xxvi. 210, AlXRayaATuwna [instead of AlXRayaATiynu]: but some say that it is from XaTana, signifying “ he became distant, ” or “ remote: ” Sb gives both of these derivations: respecting the former of which, it should be observed that if from XAT as signifying “ it burned, ” or “ became burnt, ” it is proper; but if from the same in any of the other senses mentioned above, it is tropical: and if belonging to this art., it is imperfectly decl., being of the measure faEolaAn: (S in art. XTn, in which see it:) [but in the Kur-án it is always perfectly decl.: and SM says that] it is perfectly decl., unless used as a proper name; in the latter case being imperfectly decl. (TA.)

XiyaATN c
XiyaATN The smell of a piece of cotton burning, or burnt. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also miXoyaATN.

XaAYiTN c
XaAYiTN and XaATK, like haAYirN and haArK, [the latter being formed by transposition from the former, XaATK and haArK being for XaATiIN and haAriIN,] Flesh-meat [&c.] burning, or being burnt. (TA.)

taXoyiyTN c
taXoyiyTN Flesh-meat roasted, (K,) or made good, and roasted, (TA,) for a company of men: (K:) a subst., like tamotiynN. (K, TA.) [In the CK, for AisomN kaAltRamotiyni, we find wAsmN kAltRamotiyni.]

miXoyaATN c
miXoyaATN (tropical:) A she-camel that quickly becomes fat: (As, S, A, K:) applied also to a he-camel: (TA:) pl. maXaAyiyTu; (S, K;) in some of the copies of the S, maXaAyiTu: and you say also UibilN XyAT↓ [app. a mistake for miXoyaATN, which is fem., like UibilN, as well as masc.]: AA says that mXAyT, [or maXaAyiyTu,] applied to camels, signifies assigned for slaughter; from XaATa said of a person's blood. (TA.)

musotaXiyTN c
musotaXiyTN (tropical:) A fat camel. (K.) [See 10.] ― -b2- (tropical:) Laughing exceedingly; (K;) laughing vehemently, like one exerting himself in his laughing. (ISh.)

1 XaAEa c
1. XaAEa, aor. yaXiyEu, (S, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. XuyuwEN (O, Msb, K) and XayoEuwEapN (S, O, K) and XayoEN (K) and XayaEaAnN and maXaAEN, (O, K, the last, in the CK, maXaAEap,) said of information, an announcement, a piece of news, or a narrative, or story, (TA,) or of a thing, (O, Msb,) It became spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, or disclosed; (S, O, K, TA;) or it became apparent, or manifest; (Msb, TA;) fiI AlnRaAsi [among the people]; so as to reach every one, becoming equally known by the people, not known by some exclusively of others. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] XAE, aor. as above, said of a thing, signifies also (assumed tropical:) It became scattered, or dispersed; like XaERa. (TA in art. XE.) You say, XAE AllRabanu fiI AlmaMCi, (Msb,) or XAEt qaTorapN mina AllRabani fiI AlmaMCi, and tXyREt↓, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The milk, (Msb,) or the drop of milk, (TA,) became dispersed in the water, (Msb, TA,) and mixed: (Msb:) and fiyhi XayRaEa↓ likewise signifies it became dispersed in it. (TA.) And XAE AlXRayobu, inf. n. XayoEN and XiyaAEN and XayaEaAnN and XuyuwEN and XuyuwEapN and maXiyEN, (tropical:) Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, appeared, and became scattered: and XAE fiyhi AlXRayobu, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness, spread upon him; as also tXyREhu↓ [or tXyRE fiyhi, agreeably with what has been said above]. (TA.) And XAE AlSRadoEu fiI AlzRujaAjapi (assumed tropical:) The crack spread, and became dispersed, in the glass, or glass vessel. (Th, TA.) And AlUibilu tXAyEt↓ (assumed tropical:) The camels became scattered, or dispersed; or they scattered, or dispersed, themselves. (TA.) ＝ -A2- As trans. by means of bi: see 4, in two places. ＝ -A3- [It is also trans. by itself.] XaAEakumu AlsRalaAmu is like the saying Ealayokumu AlsRalaAmu [Safety, or peace, &c., be, or light and abide, on you]; (S, O, K;) but is only said by a man to his companions when he desires to quit them: (S, O:) or it means [may safety, &c.,] follow you: (O, K:) or, not quit you: (K:) whence, (TA,) one says also XaAEaka Alxayoru may prosperity not quit thee; and in like manner Lebeed says of praise (HamodN): (O, TA:) [and J says that] XAEhu, inf. n. XiyaAEN, signifies he, or it, followed him: (S:) or XAEkm AlslAm, (Yoo, O, K,) aor. yaXaAEukum, inf. n. XayoEN, (Yoo, O,) means [may safety, &c.,] fill you: (Yoo, O, K:) [app. from what next follows.] ― -b2- One says also XiEotu AlUinaMCa, (K, TA,) aor. OaXiyEuhu, inf. n. XayoEN, (TA,) I filled the vessel. (K, TA.)

2 XyRE fiyhi c
2. XyRE fiyhi: see 1. ＝ -A2- XyRE said of a pastor, He blew in the reed-pipe [called XiyaAE, by means of which the camels are called together]. (Lth, K, TA.) ― -b2- XyRE biAlUibili He (a pastor) called to the camels, whereupon they followed one another; (Msb;) in [some of] the copies of the K, i. q. AXAC bhA, [in the CK AaXAbahA,] but correctly bihaA OaXaAEa↓, (TA,) which means he called to the camels, (K in another part of the art., and TA,) when some of them remained, or lagged, behind: (TA:) and [in like manner] biUibilihi XAyE↓, (S, K,) inf. n. muXaAyaEapN and XiyaAEN, (S,) he (a pastor, S) shouted and called to his camels, (S, K,) when some of them remained, or lagged, behind: (S:) or XyRE Uibilahu he (a pastor) called out among his camels, whereupon they went along, following one another: (Mgh:) and XyRE Alganama he urged on the sheep, or goats, (K, * TA,) because of their lagging behind, (TA,) in order that they might follow the others. (K, TA.) [The last two phrases are app. from the second of the explanations here following.] ― -b3- XyREhu, inf. n. taXoyiyEN,
also signifies He sent, or sent on, him, or it. (TA.) ― -b4- And He made him, or it, to follow. (TA.) ― -b5- [And He made it to be followed by another thing.] One says, XayRaEotu ramaDaAna bisitRK mino XawRaAlK [or rather bisitRapK] (assumed tropical:) I made [the fasting of] Ramadán to be followed by [the fasting of] six [days] of Showwál expl. by OatobaEotuhu bihaA [a well-known phrase, of frequent occurrence, but one which I have not found in any of the lexicons, except in explanations; the approved phrase used in its stead being OatobaEotuhu UiyRaAhaA, lit. meaning “ I made them to follow it; ” this being virtually the same as “ I made it to be followed by them ”]: (Msb:) [and in like manner, the elliptical phrase] XyRE ramaDaAna, (K,) or XyRE Xahora ramaDaAna, (O, TA,) means He fasted after Rama- dán, or the month of Ramadán, six days; (O, K, TA;) i. e. OatobaEahu bihaA. (TA.) ― -b6- XayRaEotuhu Einoda raHiylihi (Lth, * S, O, Msb, K *) I went forth with him (Lth, O, Msb, K) on the occasion of his departure, (O, Msb,) namely, a guest, (Msb,) in order to bid him farewell, and to conduct him to his place of alighting, [app. meaning, to his first place of alighting,] (Lth, O, K,) or to show honour, or courtesy, to him; and I bade him farewell: (Msb:) or XyRE AlDRayofa signifies he followed the guest [app. on the occasion of his departure, in order to bid him farewell, &c.]: (Mgh:) or XyREhu Einoda raHiylihi he went forth with him on the occasion of his departure, desiring to cheer him by his company to some place: and XAyEhu↓ signifies the same. (TA.) ― -b7- [XyREhu sometimes signifies He followed him, not coming up with him, but always going behind him]. See AlmuXayRiEapu, voce muXayRaEN. ― -b8- [And He followed, or imitated, him; conformed, agreed, or complied, with him; like XaAyaEahu]. See 3, in three places. ― -b9- XyRE fulaAnFA (tropical:) He encouraged such a one, and emboldened him, (O, K, TA,) and strengthened him. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN yuXayRiEuhu EalaI celika (tropical:) Such a one strengthens him to do that. (TA.) And XayRaEa hecaA bihecaA (assumed tropical:) He strengthened this with this. (TA.) ― -b10- XyREhu AlnRaAra (tropical:) He threw, or put, firewood upon the fire to make it blaze or flame, burn up, or burn brightly or fiercely. (ISk, S, K, TA.) ― -b11- And XyREhu biAlnRaAri (assumed tropical:) He burned him, or it, with fire. (S, K, TA.) Of anything that has been burned, one says, XuyRiEa. (TA.)

3 muXaAyaEapN c
3. muXaAyaEapN primarily signifies The following another, or conforming with him, in, or as to, an affair, and an opinion; as also XiyaAEN; [an inf. n. of XAyEhu, like the former;] and so too signifies taXayRuEN↓ [if not a mistranscription for taXoyiyEN↓, which I rather think it to be, agreeably with what follows]: and the agreeing, or complying, with him, or obeying him. (TA.) You say, XAyEhu EalaI OamorK, (Lth, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. muXaAyaEapN (Msb) [and XiyaAEN], He followed him, or conformed with him, [&c.,] in, or as to, an affair: (Lth, O, Msb:) or he did so, and strengthened him; and likewise ElI raOoIK in, or as to, an opinion; as also Ealayohi XyREhu↓, referring to an opinion [and an affair]. (TA.) And maA tuXaAyiEuniI rijoliI walaA saAqiI My leg does not conform with [my wish] nor aid me to walk, nor does my shank. (TA.) And XaAyaEatohu nafosuhu EalaI celika His soul conformed [or complied] with him, [i. e. with his wish,] and encouraged him, to do that; as also XayRaEatohu↓. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Also (O, K) He befriended him, or was friendly to him; syn. waAlaAhu, (S, O, K,) from AlwaliIRu. (S.) ― -b3- XAyEhu Einoda raHiylihi: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph. ― -b4- XAyE biUibilihi: see 2, near the beginning. [Hence, app.,] one says also, XaAyaEa bihimu AldRaliylu faOaboSaruwA AlhudaI The guide called to them [and they saw the right direction]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AlXRiyaAEu occurs in a trad., as some relate it, and is expl. as there meaning AlmufaAxarapu bikavorapi AljimaAEi: but AA says that it is a mistranscription for AlsRibaAEu, with s and b; or that it may be from XaAEapN signifying “ a wife. ” (IAth, TA.)

4 AXAE Alxabara c
4. AXAE Alxabara, (S, O,) or AlXRaIoCa, (Msb, K,) or rather AlsRirRa, as in the L; (TA;) and AXAE bihi; (O, * K;) as also bihi XAE↓, first pers. XiEotu bh; (Msb, K;) He spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, or disclosed, (S, O, K,) and (K) made apparent or manifest, (Msb, K,) the information, announcement, news, narrative, or story, (S, O,) or the thing, (Msb, K,) or the secret. (L, TA.) And AXAE cikora AlXRaIoCi He made the mention, or fame, of the thing to fly [abroad, or to spread]. (TA.) ― -b2- OaXaEotu AlmaAla bayona Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) I dispersed, or distributed, the property among the people, or party; and Alqidora fiI AlHaIRi the [contents of] the cooking-pot among the tribe. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) [See also its pass. part. n.] ― -b3- AXAEt bibawolihaA (assumed tropical:) She (a camel) ejected her urine, (S, K,) scattering it, (K,) and stopped it; (S, K; expl. in the K in two places;) but this is only when the stallion has leaped her, and is only said in relation to camels; and bbwlhA AXtAEt↓ signifies the same: and in like manner AXAE is said of a he-camel. (TA.) ― -b4- OaXaAEakumu QllRehu AlsRalaAma, (S, O,) or biAlsRalaAmi, (K,) or both, (TA,) as also QllRehu biAlsRalaAmi XaAEakumu↓, (K,) May God make safety, or peace, &c., [to light and abide upon you, or] to accompany and follow you. (S, O, K. [See also 1, latter half.]) ― -b5- AXAE biAlUibili: see 2. ― -b6- [AXAEt is also expl. in the TA as meaning xrjt: but I suspect a mistranscription or an omission in this case.]

5 taXayRaEa
5: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- tXyRE said of a man, (S, O,) He asserted himself to hold the tenets of the XiyEap [q. v.]: (S, O, K, KL, TA:) or he became a XiyaEiIR: a verb similar to taHanRafa and taXafRaEa. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [Accord. to Golius, it is expl. in the KL as meaning He left a portion of a thing undistributed: but this explanation is not in my copy of that work.] ― -b2- tXyRE fiI AlXRaIoCi He strove, or laboured, or he distressed himself, or he courted death, (Aisotaholaka,) in his love of the thing. (TA.) ＝ -A3- tXyREhu AlgaDabu Anger excited him to lightness, levity, or unsteadiness; or flurried, or disquieted, him. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 3, first sentence.

6 tXAyEt AlUibilu c
6. tXAyEt AlUibilu: see 1. ― -b2- tXAyEwA is from AlXRiyEapu, (S, O,) and signifies They became XiyaE [i. e. separate parties, &c., pl. of XiyEapN, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And They went, or went along, together. (KL.) ― -b4- [See also the part. n., voce XayRiEN.]

8 AXtAEt bibawolihaA c
8. AXtAEt bibawolihaA, said of a she-camel: see 4. ― -b2- [See also the part. n., voce XayRiEN.]

XaAEN c
XaAEN, originally XaAYiEN: see the latter word. ― -b2- Also The urine of the she-camel, that becomes scattered when the stallion leaps her. (As, O, K.) And, (As, O, [accord. to the K “ or, ”] The urine of the he-camel when he is excited by lust. (As, O, K.)

XayoEN c
XayoEN A space [of time]. (S, O, K.) One says, OaqaAma fulaAnN XahorFA Oawo XayoEahu (S, O) i. e. Such a one remained, or stayed, a month or the space thereof: or nearly the space thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- One says also, Mtiyka gadFA Oawo XayoEahu I will come to thee to-morrow or after it: (S, O, K:) or to-morrow or the day after it. (L, TA.) ― -b3- And hecaA XayoEu hecaA This is he that was born next after this; like XawoEuhu: (S, O, K, all in art. XwE:) or this is the like of this. (A 'Obeyd, O and K in the present art.) ― -b4- XayoEN signifies also A follower: and a friend, or a comrade, or an assistant. (KL.) ― -b5- And A lion's whelp: (Lth, IDrd, S, O, K:) or when he has attained to taking prey; so in the L: and some say the lion [himself]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also XaAYiEN.

XiyEu nisaMCK c
XiyEu nisaMCK One who follows after women, and mixes, associates, or converses, with them. (K, * TA.)

XaAEapN c
XaAEapN A wife: because she follows, or conforms with, [the wishes of] her husband. (Sh, O, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also XaAYiEN.

XayoEapN c
XayoEapN A certain tree, (O, K,) below the stature of a man, having knotted, or jointed, rods, and small, dark-red blossoms, smaller than the jasmine: (O:) the bees feed upon it; (O, K;) and men eat its tender extremities, being rendered healthy, or sound, thereby; (yataSaHRaHuwna bihi;) and it has a hot quality in the mouth; and is sweet in odour: (O:) clothes become sweet-scented by adhering to it, (O, K, * TA,) i. e. to its blossom, agreeably with what is said in the “ Book of Plants, ” not to the tree, to which the pronoun refers in the O and K; (TA;) and its honey is clear, (O, K,) very clear, and is well known: it is a pasture; and grows in the plains, and near to seed-produce. (O.)

XiyEapN c
XiyEapN A separate, or distinct, party, or sect, (O, K, TA,) of men: this is the primary signification: so called from their agreeing together, and following one another: or, accord. to some, the I is originally w, and it is from XuwRaEa qawomahu, which means “ he collected his people or party: ”
(TA:) the followers and assistants (S, O, Msb, K) of a man: (S, O, K:) any people that have combined in, or for, an affair: (Msb, TA:) accord. to Az, persons who follow, or conform with, one another, [though] not all of them agreeing together: (TA:) and any assistant and partisan of a man: (O, TA:) [for] the word is applied to one and to two and to a pl. number and to the male and to the female, (K, TA,) without variation: (TA:) the pl. is XiyaEN and OaXoyaAEN, (S, * O, Msb, K,) the latter a pl. pl.; (Msb;) and the former is applied to any people, or party, whose affair, or case, is one, who follow one another's opinion. (S.) The saying, in the Kur [xxxiv. last verse], kamaA fuEila biOaXoyaAEihimo mino qabolu means As was done with the likes of them, of the same persuasion as they, of the peoples that have gone before: (S, * TA:) and similar to this is the saying in the Kur liv. 51. (TA.) ― -b2- Afterwards, AlXRiyEapu became a name of A particular party [or sect]; (Msb, K;) being predominantly applied to all who took as their friends, or lords, 'Alee and the people of his house: (K:) those who followed 'Alee, saying that he was the [rightful] Imám after the Apostle of God, and believing that the office of Imám should not depart from him and his descendants: (KT:) they are an innumerable people, who are innovators; the extravagant zealots among them are the Imámeeyek, who revile the Two Sheykhs [Aboo-Bekr and 'Omar]; and the most extravagant of them call the Two Sheykhs disbelievers: some of them rise to the pitch of [that misbelief which is termed] AlzRanodaqap [q. v.]. (TA.) [It is also applied to A single person of this party, or sect; agreeably with what has been said above; and such a person is likewise called XiyaEiIRN↓: see 5.]

XiyaEiIRN c
XiyaEiIRN: see the next preceding sentence.

XiyaEiyRapN c
[XiyaEiyRapN and XiyoEiyRapN The way of doctrine and practice, or the system of tenets, of the sect called AlXRiyEapu.]

XayaAEN c
XayaAEN: see the next paragraph.

XiyaAEN c
XiyaAEN The reed-pipe of the pastor; (IAar, O, K;) the instrument with which the pastor blows; so named because he calls together the camels with it: (A, TA:) or the sound of the pastor's reed-pipe. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And Callers, or summoners; syn. duEaApN, (O, K,) pl. of daAEK: (K:) in the Tekmileh, duEaMC [a call, or calling, &c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (S, O, K,) and XayaAEN↓, (O, K,) but the former is the more chaste, (O, [and the same is implied in the K,]) (tropical:) Slender firewood, with which a fire is made to blaze or flame, burn up, or burn brightly or fiercely: (S, O, K, TA:) and XayuwEN↓ signifies [the same, i. e.] slender firewood (AHn, O, K) that is quickly kindled by a weak fire, so that it prevails over the thick, or large, firewood. (AHn, O.)

XayuwEN c
XayuwEN: see next preceding sentence.

XayRiEN c
XayRiEN A sharer, or partner: (TA:) pl. XuyaEaMCu. (O, K, TA.) One says, humo XuyaEaMCu fiyhaA [They are sharers, or partners, in it, i. e. a house (daAr) or land;] i. e. every one of them is a XayRiE to his fellow [or fellows]. (O, K.) And humaA mutaXaAyiEaAni↓ fiI daArK, (O, K,) or OaroDK; (O;) and muXotaAEaAni↓, (O, TA,) in the copies of the K, erroneously, mutaXaAEaAni; (TA;) They two are sharers, or partners, in a house, (O, K,) or land. (O.) ― -b2- And AldRaAru XayRiEapN bayonahumo The house is undivided [i. e. shared] among them; syn. muXaAEapN↓. (O, K. [See also XaAYiEN.])

XaAYiEN c
XaAYiEN Information, an announcement, a piece of news, a narrative, or a story, spreading; or becoming spread, published, divulged, revealed, made known, disclosed, apparent, or manifest; fiI AlnRaAsi [among the people]; so as to reach every one, becoming equally known by the people, not known by some exclusively of others: (TA:) and XaAEapN↓ [is app. a pl. thereof, like as baAEapN is of baAYiEN, signifying, or so OaxobaArN XaAEapN,] news, or tidings, &c., spreading, or becoming spread. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b2- [(assumed tropical:) A thing scattered, or dispersed, or in a state of dispersion: fem. with p: pl. of the latter XawaAYiEu; which may also be pl. of the former applied to a rational being, like fawaArisu pl. of faArisN.] One says, jaMCati Alxayolu XawaAYiEa (assumed tropical:) The horsemen came scattered, or dispersed, or in a state of dispersion; as also XawaAEiIa, formed by transposition. (TA. [But the latter is also mentioned as belonging to art. XEw.]) ― -b3- Also A lot, share, or portion, (sahomN, S O, Msb, K, and naSiybN, TA,) undivided; and so XaAEN↓, (S, O, K, TA,) like as one says saAYiru AlXRaIoCi and saAruhu; (S, O;) and muXaAEN↓; (S, K;) [i. e. shared in common; as though] spread; (TA;) so called because mixed, not being separated: (Msb:) [and it seems, from the usage of a phrase in art. xlT of the K, (AlmuXaAriku fiI AlXuyuwEi,) that XayoEN↓, as sing. of XuyuwEN, signifies an undivided portion.] ― -b4- Also Anything that is a supplement to a thing: or an addition, or augment, thereto. (TA.)

muXaAEN c
muXaAEN; and its fem., with p: see XaAYiEN and XayRiEN.

maXiyEN c
maXiyEN Filled; (O, K;) applied to a vessel. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Very rancorous, malevolent, malicious, or spiteful; filled with baseness, meanness, or sordidness. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously said to be, in this sense, miXoyaE, like makoyal; instead of maXiyE, like makiyl.]) Hence also, huwa DabRN maXiyEN (assumed tropical:) He is [like a lizard of the kind called DbR that is] very rancorous, &c. (TA.) IAar says, I heard Abu-l-Mekárim revile a man, saying, huwa xabRN maXiyEN, [perhaps correctly DabRN, but see this word, which is used as a syn. sequent to xabRN,] meaning He is like a DabR that is very rancorous, &c., and unprofitable; (O, TA;) maXiyEN, here, being with fet-h to the m; (O;) from XiEotuhu “ I filled it. ” (O, TA.)

miXoyaEapN c
miXoyaEapN A qufRap [or kind of basket, of palmleaves,] in which a woman puts her cotton and other things: (IDrd, O, L, K:) so called because it accompanies and follows her. (TA.)

miXoyaAEN c
miXoyaAEN One who will not keep, or conceal, a secret; or one who is unable to conceal his information, news, or tidings; [a babbler of secrets &c.;] syn. micoyaAEN. (S, O, K.)

muXayRaEN c
muXayRaEN (tropical:) Courageous: (S, O, K, TA:) as though he were encouraged and emboldened and strengthened by another, or encouraged and emboldened by the strength of his heart: (O, K:) or whose heart is encouraged and emboldened by every formidable affair in which he has embarked. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) Very quick or speedy or hasty. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, O, K.) ― -b3- AlmuXayRaEapu, in a trad. relating to sheep or goats to be slaughtered as victims on the day of sacrifice, in which trad. such are forbidden, (O, Msb, K,) means the sheep or goat (Mgh) that requires one to urge it on after the [other] sheep or goats, (Mgh, O, Msb, K,) because of its weakness (Mgh, K) and leanness, (Mgh,) or because of its lack of strength to follow them: (O:) or, as some relate it, the word is AlmuXayRiEapu↓, (Mgh, O, Msb, K,) meaning that ceases not to follow the [other] sheep or goats, (Alganama laA tazaAlu tuXayRiEu↓, O, K, * i. e. tatobaEuhaA, Mgh, O, K,) or that ceases not to lag behind the [other] sheep or goats, (Msb,) not coming up with them, (Mgh, TA,) but always going behind them, (TA,) because of its leanness; (Mgh, Msb, K;) from XayRaEa AlDRayofa [expl. above (see 2)]; (Mgh;) or as though urging on the [other] sheep or goats. (Msb.)

AlmuXayRiEapu c
AlmuXayRiEapu: see what next precedes.

muXaAyiEN c
muXaAyiEN Overtaking, or coming up with another or others; or one that overtakes, &c.: (S, K, TA:) as in the saying of Lebeed,
kamaA DamRa OuxoraI AltRaAliyaAti AlmuXaAyiEu
[Like as he that overtakes collects together the last of those cattle that go behind the others]. (TA.)

muXotaAEN c
muXotaAEN: see the dual of each, voce XayRiEN.

mutaXaAyiEN c
mutaXaAyiEN: see the dual of each, voce XayRiEN.

2 XyRf AldRawaMCa c
2. XyRf AldRawaMCa [from XiyaAfN]: see 2 in art. Xwf.

XiyfN c
XiyfN The prickles (Xawok) that are at the back of the Easiyb [or leafless portion, next above the lowest and thickest part, of the branch] of the palm-tree: (O, K:) so says AHát: (O:) but Lth says that the word is [siyfN, q. v.,] with the unpointed s. (TA.)

XiyaAfN c
XiyaAfN, originally XiwaAfN: see art. Xwf.

XiyRifapN c
XiyRifapN and XiyRifaAnN: see art. Xwf.

1 Xiqotu AlTRunuba UilaI Alwatidi c
1. Xiqotu AlTRunuba UilaI Alwatidi, (S,) inf. n. XayoqN, (TA,) is like nuTotuhu. (S.) [See 1 (last sentence but one) in art. Xwq.]

XiyqN c
XiyqN A mountain: (IAar, S:) or the highest part of a mountain: (Skr, O, K:) or a part that is even, (Lth, O, K,) and small in breadth, in the face of a mountain, resembling a wall, (fiI lihobi jabalK,) (Lth, O,) that cannot be ascended: (Lth, O, K: *) or the most difficult place in a mountain. (S, O, K.) A poet says, cited as using it in the last sense,
XagowaMCu tawTinu bayona AlXRiyqi waAlnRiyqi
[An eagle dwelling between the most difficult place in a mountain and the highest part thereof]. (S, O.) See also a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb cited voce xaAfapN, in art. xwf. ― -b2- A long, or tall, mountain; (jabalN TawiylN;) (K;) thus accord. to some in the verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb. (TA.) ― -b3- And accord. to some, it signifies in that verse (TA) A narrow cleft in a mountain: or in the head thereof: or a cleft between two rocks. (K, TA.) ― -b4- A side; syn. jaAnibN. (Skr, O, K.) One says, AimotalOa mina AlXRiyqi UilaI AlXRiyqi It became filled from side to side. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The head [or glans] of the penis. (IAar, O, K.) ＝ -A3- The hair of a horse's tail: n. un. with p. (IAar, O, K.) ＝ -A4- A species of fish. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b2- The aquatic bird [or rather birds] called burak [pl. of burokapN, q. v.]: (K:) n. un. with p. (TA. [In the K, XiyqapN is mentioned in another place as meaning a certain aquatic bird: and in the O as meaning a species of aquatic birds.]) ＝ -A5- And accord. to Ibn- 'Abbád, i. q. kitaAbN [A writing, or book, &c.]. (O.) ＝ -A6- See also art. Xwq.

XiyaAqN c
XiyaAqN: see art. Xwq.

XayRiqN c
XayRiqN: see art. Xwq.

1 XayolN c
1. XayolN is a bad [or vulgar] dial. var. of XawolN: one says, Xilotu bihi, [and now, more commonly, Xilotuhu, like Xulotuhu, meaning I raised it; and, as now used, I lifted it; and hence, I removed it, or took it away; and I carried it; and I loaded it, namely, luggage upon a beast &c.;] aor. OaXiylu, inf. n. XayolN and maXoyalN, the latter [in measure] like maqoEadN. (TA.)

XiyaAlapN c
XiyaAlapN The occupation of the XayRaAl, i. e. porter, or carrier of burdens. (TA.)

XuyRalN c
XuyRalN and XiyRalN pls. of XaAYilN. (K in art. Xwl, in which see the singular.)

XayRaAlN c
XayRaAlN, from Xilotu bihi [expl. above], A porter, or carrier of burdens. (TA.)

farasN miXoyaAlu Alxaloqi c
farasN miXoyaAlu Alxaloqi A horse incongruous, unsound, faulty, or weak, in make: (AO, O and TA in the present art.:) mentioned in the L in art. Xwl. (TA.)

1 XaAma AlXRaIoCa fiI AlXRaIoCi c
1. XaAma AlXRaIoCa fiI AlXRaIoCi, (K,) [aor. yaXiymu,] inf. n. XayomN, (TA,) He hid, or concealed, the thing in the thing: (K, TA:) and he inserted the thing in the thing. (TA.) [Hence,] XAm sayofahu, (K,) first pers. Ximotuhu, (S,) aor. as above, (K,) inf. n. XayomN, (TA,) He sheathed his sword; (S, K;) and [in like manner] XAm nabolahu [He put his arrows into the quiver]: (TA:) and the former signifies also He drew his sword: thus having two contr. meanings: (S, K:) A 'Obeyd doubted of the latter meaning; and Sh knew it not; but the verb is said to have this meaning in a verse of ElFarezdak. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr that a complaint was made to him against Khálid Ibn-El-Weleed, and he said, laA OaXiymu sayofFA salRahu QllRehu EalaI AlmuXorikiyna i. e. I will not sheath a sword [which God has drawn against the believers in a plurality of gods]. (TA.) [Hence also,] one says, XAm OabaA EumayorK (K, TA) i. e. [He sheathed] the cakar; (TA;) meaning (assumed tropical:) he attained his desire of the virgin. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And XAm fiI Alfarasi saAqahu He struck the mare with his shank to make her run: (K:) or he impressed (lit. inserted) his leg [or shank] in the belly of the mare, striking her [with it]. (Aboo-Málik; TA.) ＝ -A2- Ximotu maxaAyila AlXRaIoCi I directed my look towards the indications, or symptoms, of the thing, waiting, or watching, for it. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence, or the reverse may be the case,] Ximotu Albaroqa, (S, Msb, K, *) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) I looked at, (S, K, *) or watched, or observed, (Msb,) the lightning, (Msb, K,) or the cloud thereof, to see where it would rain, (S,) or to see where it would pour, or bring rain, (Msb,) or to see whither it tended and where it would rain: (K:) this is done only when it flickers and disappears without delay: and [it is said, but, in my opinion, fancifully, and with little reason, that] the drawing and sheathing of a sword are likened to lightning flickering and disappearing. (TA.) [Hence the phrase, Ximotu baroqa fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) I looked hoping for the benefits of such a one: mentioned by Freytag on the authority of Meyd: and the like is said in Har p. 319.] And XAm AlsRaHaAba He looked at the clouds from afar: and [in like manner,] AlnRaAra the fire. (TA.) It is said in a prov.,
laA taXimi Algayova faqado OawodaI AlnRaqado
i. e. [Look not thou hoping for rain, for] the lambs have perished: addressed to him who mourns for that which has past. (Meyd.) And one says, fulaAnN muwsirN walaA OaXiymuhu mino faqorK (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is wealthy, and I do not look at him in hope by reason of poverty]; meaning that he is independent of him. (Z, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] Ximo maA bayonahumaA (tropical:) Compute thou, or estimate, or consider, (K, TA,) and look, or see, (TA,) what [relation, or difference,] is between them two. (K, TA. [In the CK, XayRama is erroneously put for Ximo; and qadRarahu, in the explanation, for qadRirohu.]) ＝ -A3- XaAma also signifies It (a thing, TA) entered, fiI XaIoCK into a thing; (K, TA;) quasi-pass. of the same verb in the latter of the two senses expl. in the first sentence of this art.; (TA;) and so AnXAm↓, (S, K, TA,) and AXAm↓, and AXtAm↓, and tXyRm↓, and XyRm↓. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. XayomN and XuyuwmN, He made a valid charge, or assault, or attack, in war, or battle. (K.) ＝ -A4- Also, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) He (a man) had a black raqomap [app. meaning spot, or mole, i. e. XaAmap,] apparent in his skin. (K.) And Xiyma, inf. n. XayomN, [perhaps a mistranscription for XayamN,] He was marked with a XaAmap [or mole]: or, as some say, [the pass. part. n.] maXoyuwmN [signifying “ marked with a XAmp ”] has no verb: and AZ says that XayamN↓, signifying the having upon him a XAmp, has no known verb: (TA:) or XayamN is an inf. n. signifying the having upon him XaAm [i. e. moles]. (Ham p. 361.) ＝ -A5- XaAma fulaAnFA, (K,) aor. as above, (TA,) He soiled the legs, or feet, of such a one with dust, or earth: (K, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the K, gayRara rijolayohi biAlXRiyaAmi; but correctly, [as in the CK and in my MS copy of the K,] gabRara; and accord. to the M, from AlXRiyaAm, [meaning that the verb is derived from this word,] i. e. AltRuraAb. (TA.)

2 XayRama
2: see 1, in the latter half. ＝ -A2- XyRm yadayohi fiI raOosihi, or vawobihi, He seized his head, or his garment, fighting him. (K.)

4 OaXoyama
4: see 1, in the latter half.

5 taXayRama
5: see 1, in the latter half. ― -b2- tXyRmhu AlDRiraAmu The kindling of fire entered it; namely, a wood; as used in a verse of Sá'ideh: or, as some relate it, tasanRamahu [q. v.]. (S, TA.) And tXyRm AlHariyqu AlqaSaba The fire entered, and mixed with, the reeds, or canes. (TA.) ― -b3- And tXyRmhu AlXRayobu (tropical:) Hoariness came upon him, (K, TA,) and became intermixed upon him: or, accord. to IAar, became abundant upon him, and spread; (TA;) as also tasanRamahu. (IAar, M and TA in art. snm.) ＝ -A2- tXyRm OabaAhu He resembled his father in Xiymp i. e. nature, or natural disposition. (IAar, K, TA.)

7 AnXAm c
7. AnXAm: see 1, in the latter half. ＝ -A2- Also He (a man) became one who was looked at. (S, K.)

8 UiXotayama
8: see 1, in the latter half.

XaAmN c
XaAmN: see XaAmapN, in three places. ＝ -A2- The country of AlXRaAm [i. e. Syria] has been mentioned in art. XOm [as originally AlXRaOom].

XiymN c
XiymN A certain species of fish. (S, K. *) ＝ -A2- Also pl. of OaXoyamu [q. v.]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- And pl., in one sense, of XiyaAmN [q. v.]. (K.)

XayamN c
XayamN: see 1, near the end. ＝ -A2- Also Any land, or ground, in which one has not yet dug, remaining in its [original] hard state, (Aboo-Sa'eed, K, TA,) so that the digging therein is more difficult [than elsewhere] to the digger. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.)

XaAmapN c
XaAmapN A mole, syn. xaAlN, (S, Msb, TA,) upon the person; (Msb;) [i. e.] a pimple inclining to blackness, upon the person; (Mgh;) or a [natural] mark differing from the colour of the person upon which it is: (K, * TA:) its medial radical letter is originally I: (S, TA:) and it is
also with C, i. e. XaOomapN: (IAth, TA:) pl. XaAmN↓, (S, Msb, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [the pl. properly so termed is] XaAmaAtN. (Msb, K.) HatRaI takuwnuwA kaOanRakumo XaAmapN fiI AlnRaAsi [So that ye may be as though ye were a mole amid the people], occurring in a trad., means [that ye may] be in the goodliest garb or guise, appearing like the XAmp, at which one looks exclusively of the rest of the person. (IAth, TA.) And one says, SaAruwA XaAmFA↓ fiI AlbilaAdi, meaning (assumed tropical:) They became scattered [in the countries] like the XAm [or moles] upon the person. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A black mark upon the person, [an explanation which seems to apply, like the former in the K, to a mole, though given as differing therefrom,] and upon the ground: pl. [or coll. gen. n.] XaAmN↓. (K.) ― -b3- It is also [A mark, or spot,] upon a mare, upon a place that is disapproved, and sometimes upon her dawaAYir [which means what are termed feathers, pl. of daAYirapN, q. v.]. (ISh, TA.) ― -b4- And A spot (nukotap) [upon the face] of the moon. (K.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) A black she-camel: (IAar, S, K, TA:) accord. to Niftaweyh, XaOomapN, with; but ISd says, I know not the reason of this, unless it be extr., like AlxaOotamu and AlEaOolimu. (TA.) One says, maA lahu XaAmapN walaA zahoraMCu, meaning, (tropical:) He has not a black she-camel nor a white one. (S, K, TA.)

XiymapN c
XiymapN Nature; natural, native, or innate, disposition, temper, or other quality or property; (S, Msb, K;) as also XiYomapN, (K,) which is an extr. dial. var.: (TA:) pl. XiyamN. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- Also Dust, or earth, dug from the ground; (As, S, K;) and so XiyaAmN↓. (S, as on the authority of As; but only in one of my two copies of the S.)

XayaAmN c
XayaAmN Soft, or plain, land; (AA, K, TA;) of which the earth is soft, or uncompact. (TA.) ― -b2- See also the paragraph here following, in two places.

XiyaAmN c
XiyaAmN Dust, or earth, (K, TA,) in a general sense; (TA;) as also XayaAmN↓: (K:) see also XiymapN: [or,] accord. to Kh, a hollow dug in the ground: or, as some say, land of which the earth is soft, or uncompact. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A [covert such as is termed] kinaAs: so called because of the wild animal's entering (lAinoXiyaAmi AlwaHoXi i. e. duxuwlihi) into it. (As, S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The rat, or mouse; syn. faOorN: (IAar, K, TA:) but written by Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid XayaAmN↓, and said by him to be the jurac [generally meaning a large field-rat]: (TA:) pl. XiymN. (K.)

qawomN XuyuwmN c
qawomN XuyuwmN A people, or party, in a state of security: occurring in a trad.: and it is said that Xywm is an Abyssinian word: but, as some relate the trad., it is suyuwmN [q. v., voce saAYimN, of which it is said to be pl.]. (TA.)

OaXoyamu c
OaXoyamu A man (S, Msb) having a XaAmap [or mole] upon his person; (AZ, S, Mgh, Msb, K; *) and maXiymN↓ (S, K) and maXuwmN↓ (K) and maXoyuwmN↓ (S, K) signify the same [or rather marked with a mole]: (S, * K:) or OaXoyamu signifies having upon him XaAm [or moles]: (Ham p. 361:) fem. XayomaMCu: (TA:) and pl. XiymN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And A beast, (Lth, AO, TA,) and anything, (Lth, TA,) having upon him, or it, a [mark such as is termed] XaAmap, (Lth, AO, TA,) or [marks such as are termed] XaAm. (AO, TA.) ― -b3- And Xiymu AlUibili (assumed tropical:) Such as are black, of camels: sing., masc. and fem., as above: (TA:) occurring in this sense in a verse of Aboo-Dhueyb, as related by AA: but as heard by As, in this verse, XuwmuhaA, and thought by him to be a pl. [originally Xuyom] of OaXoyamu. (S.) See also OaXoOamu (in art. XOm), last sentence.

maXuwmN c
maXuwmN: see the next preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- And see maXoWuwmN, in art. XOm.

maXiymN c
maXiymN: see OaXoyamu: ＝ -A2- and see also the paragraph here next following.

maXiymapN c
maXiymapN The giros; (S, TA;) i. e. (TA) the place of, (K, TA,) or [membrane that encloses, or forms the] covering of, (Msb,) the fœtus (Msb, K, TA) of a human being: (Msb: [see girosN:]) originally maXoyimapN: (S, Msb:) pl. maXaAyimu (S, K) and [coll. gen. n.] maXiymN↓. (IB, K.) [See also salFI.]

maXoyuwmN c
maXoyuwmN: see OaXoyamu.

1 XaAnahu c
1. XaAnahu, aor. yaXiynuhu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. XayonN, (S, * Msb, TA,) He, or it, disgraced him, or dishonoured him; rendered him ugly or unseemly, disfigured him, or blemished him; (MA, PS;) i. q. EaAbahu; (Msb, TA;) contr. of zaAnahu; (S, * K;) [and XyRnhu↓, inf. n. taXoyiynN, signifies the same, (the verb alone rendered by Freytag, on the authority of Meyd, “ dehonestavit, ”) like as the contr. zyRnhu signifies the same as zaAnahu.] ― -b2- The saying of Lebeed,
yaXiynu SaHaAHa Albiydi kulRa EaXiyRapK
biEuwji AlsRaraMCi Einoda baAbK muHajRabi
[They deface what is unmarred of the deserts, every evening, with the crooked things (i. e. the bows) of the wood of the tree called saraMC, at a veiled door, (referring to a company of men, and therefore the verb is sing.,)] means that they vie, one with another, in glorying, or boasting, and make marks, or lines, with their bows, upon the ground, as though they disfigured it (XaAnuwhaA) with those marks, or lines. (S.)

2 XayRana
2: see 1. ＝ -A2- XyRn XiynFA HasanFA (T, TA) or HasanapF (K) He made, (Th, TA,) or wrote, (K,) a beautiful X. (Th, K, TA.)

XayonN c
XayonN is the contr. of zayonN: (S, Msb;) and maXaAyinu↓ [in the CK maXAYin] is an anomalous pl. thereof: (TA:) the latter signifies Disgraces or dishonours, i. e. things, or qualities, that cause to be disgraced or dishonoured; things that render ugly or unseemly, that disfigure, or that blemish; syn. maEaAyibu, (S, K, TA,) and maqaAbiHu; (S, TA;) on the authority of Fr.: (TA:) [XaAYinapN↓, also, signifies the same; and its pl. is XawaAYinu;] one says hecihi XaAYinapN mina AlXRawaAYini [This is one of the things that disgrace or dishonour, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- [It is also used as epithet, like as is its contr. zayonN:] one says, wajohuhu XayonN, i. e. His face is ugly, or unseemly; for cuw XayonK; mentioned by Az. (TA.)

XiynN c
XiynN One of the letters of the alphabet, (S, K,) [i. e. the name of that letter; (see art. X,)] of the letters termed mahomuwsap [expl. in art. X], with somewhat of AltRanogiym and AltRagoXiyap [app. meaning that kind of utterance which is undertoned, and muffled, exactly like our “ sh ”], its place of utterance being the Xajor, i. e. the place of the opening of the mouth, (K, TA,) near the place of utterance of j: masc. [as meaning a Harof, or letter], and fem. [as meaning a kalimap, or word]: pl. OaXoyaAnN and XyAnAt [a mistranscription for XiynaAtN]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, thus with kesr, A man having many riqaAE [i. e. patches in his garment, pl. of ruqoEapN]. (Kh, TA.) ＝ -A3- And A long marokab [app. meaning ship or boat]. (TA.)

fiEolN XaAYinN c
fiEolN XaAYinN [An action that disgraces or dishonours, &c.]. (TA.)

XaAYinapN c
XaAYinapN [a subst. from XaAYinN]: see XayonN.

maXiynN c
maXiynN Disgraced, or dishonoured; rendered ugly or unseemly, disfigured, or blemished; pass. part. n. of 1. (Msb.)

maXaAyinu c
maXaAyinu an anomalous pl. of XayonN, q. v. (TA.)

1 XaAhahu c
1. XaAhahu, aor. yaXiyhuhu, (K,) inf. n. XayohN, (TA,) i. q. EaAnahu, (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously EAbahu,]) i. e. He smote him with the [evil] eye. (TA.) [See also 1 in art. Xwh.]

XayohN c
XayohN and XiyhN: see XaApN (of which they are quasipl. ns.) in art. Xwh.

XiyaAhN c
XiyaAhN: see XaApN (of which it is a pl.) in art. Xwh.

XayuwhN c
XayuwhN That smites vehemently with the [evil] eye. (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA. [In the CK, EayuwbN is erroneously put for EayuwnN.])

XayRihN c
XayRihN: see XaApN (of which it is a quasi-pl. n.) in art. Xwh.

OaXoyahu c
OaXoyahu [More, and most, wont to smite with the evil eye]. One says, huwa mino OaXoyahi AlnRaAsi [He is of the most wont, of men, to smite with the evil eye: this meaning being indicated by the context]. (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA.)
